column2: The entourage that accompanied Harry Belafonte in his recital of folk songs at Carnegie Hall last night included an orchestra of fifty pieces in addition to his usual group of two guitars, string bass, conga drums and piano.
Plans for an $18,000,000 redevelopment along five blocks of lower Fulton Street in Brooklyn were announced yesterday by Robert Moses, chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance.
LANGHORNE, Pa. April 19 (UPI) -- Fred Lorenzen of Elmhurst, Ill., won the abbreviated 150-mile national championship late model stock car race at the Langhorne Speedway today.

BOSTON, April 19 -- Herman D. Kenin, president of the American Federation of Musicians, said today that the two greatest deterrents to musician employment were automation and the 20 per cent cabaret tax.
Great Britain's shipping industry has been urged to overcome its reluctance for red ink and to go ahead with costly experiments in nuclear ship power.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 19 -- A British soldier was stabbed and another was beaten late last night by a gang of Greek Cypriote youths in Famagusta, a port city of eastern Cyprus.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Britain and the United States are run by conservatives, but on budget policy the two regimes seem far apart.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Net working capital of corporations rose $8,100,000,000 in 1958 as companies paid off debts and piled up cash and United States Government securities, the Government reported today.
Americans who are saved from fatal diseases by modern medicine pay more in taxes yearly than the whole Federal budget for medical research, a new publication estimates.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, April 15 -- Machines made in the state factories of East Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary are offered for sale alongside the products of American and West European private manufacturers in the Royal Netherlands Industries Fair.
Joy Clements and Frank Porretta took the romantic leads for the first time in the New York City Opera Company's production of Kurt Weill's "Street Scene" at yesterday's matinee at the City Center.
Yekaterina Maximova, a 19-year-old girl with startling blue eyes and a remarkably expressive face, took a trip by boat around Manhattan yesterday.

Commencement of the Buddhist Spring Festival, Wesak, was marked yesterday at the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street. Wesak commemorates the birth of the Gautama Buddha and is celebrated at this time by Buddhists the world over.
A small dinner dance will be held May 7 in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East for the benefit of the American-Russian Aid Association. The organization assists victims of communism.
Fred C. Trump, a commercial builder, has appealed to Mayor Wagner in a new effort to take the controversial Warbasse Housing project in Brooklyn from the United Housing Foundation.
O. Roy Chalk, who has offered to buy New York City's transit system, indicated yesterday that he had not yet made his final proposal.

NICE, France, April 19 (AP) -- Roberta Beltram of Italy defeated Linda Vail of San Francisco today in the women's singles final of the Beaulieu international tennis tournament. The scores were 6--0, 6--8,[ 6--1.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 19 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Orchestra won the $1,000 international music relations award of the National Federation of Music Clubs today.

The Superior Officers Council of the Police Department disagreed yesterday with Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy's view that public safety made it more important to fill police vacancies than raise the pay of policemen.
New York University plans within the next twelve months to complete or begin construction of buildings with an estimated value of $35,000,000, Dr. Carroll V. Newsom said yesterday.

Although Carlisle Floyd's "Susannah" is far from being the oldest work on the City Center's list this season, its successful presentation in the fall of 1956 was one of the events that prepared the way for the burst of American works that followed.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- C. Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, returned today from Southeast Asia, confident that the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization was "providing a defensive military shield" for the area's economic and social progress.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -The Atomic Energy Commission has agreed to construct a large plutonium-producing reactor that could eventually be converted into one of the largest atomic power plants. It will he built at Hanford, Wash.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Justice Potter Stewart's long and somewhat rocky road to senate confirmation has evoked new critical questions about the wisdom of recess appointments to the Supreme Court.

It is gratifying to read in The Times of April 11 that a private letter to Boris Pasternak in the U. S. S. R. received an answer. It is apparently not well known that corresponding with Russia is usually not different from corresponding with any other foreign country.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 19 -- The Sisters of Notre Dame de Namur, a Roman Catholic teaching order, have announced plans for a million-dollar novitiate for their Connecticut province.

Grain was the big commodity last week in the steamship charter market, and an accompanying slight rate improvement was also noted. General volume, however, failed to maintain the pace of a week earlier.

Mayor Wagner, radio and television executives and many stars of the entertainment world participated last night in a testimonial dinner for Joey Adams, comedian, held as a benefit for the March of Dimes. Proceeds of the $50-a-plate dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel brought more than $30,000 to the March of Dimes.

BOSTON, April 19 -- The Yankees went to considerable lengths to lose a ball game to the Red Sox today. To be exact, they went twelve innings, at which point a homer by Frank Malzone off Ryne Duren sank the Bombers, 5 to 4, before a roaring crowd of 20,707.
COMMUGNY, Switzerland April 19 (UPI) -- Mme. In Pidoux today became the first woman in the 668-year history of the Swiss confederation cast a vote.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., April 19 (UPI) -- A train of seven covered wagons drawn by Missouri mules and horses rolled out of Independence today on a 2,000-mile westward trek after a send-off by the honorary wagon master -- Mr. Truman.
SILIGURI, India, April 19 -- Trumpets brayed and cymbals clashed as the mountain people of Sikkim, Kalimpong and Darjeeling welcomed the self-exiled Dalai Lama here today.
Vice Admiral John M. Will, commander of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, has ordered seven Government-owned T-2 tankers inactivated as soon as they complete current voyages.
Buying mutual funds from an independent dealer is like shopping in the five and dime; there's plenty of choice.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday that the exploration of outer space was in full agreement with the Christian faith and the Bible.
LAMAR, Mo., April 19 -- The birthplace of Harry S. Truman was dedicated here today as a Missouri state shrine.

The "widespread and general departure from the Biblical standard" of marriage and sex was attacked here yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken. He spoke on "The Sanctity of Marriage" at the Riverside Church.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 19 -- Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike said today that the British system of cabinet government was dictatorship in the guise of democracy.

PARIS, April 19 -- Seventy years ago tomorrow, Adolf Hitler was born to an Austrian couple named Schicklgruber. Had the father kept that ridiculous name, it is possible that at least some of his son's monstrous aspirations might never have developed. As it was, "Heil Hitler" became one of the most preposterous slogans of all time.

IF you are a woman and you wish you understood other people better; if travel posters and train whistles bring on a severe attack of wanderlust; if you spend minutes, or hours, before a mirror, experimenting with new hair styles or trying on new clothes; if you wonder intermittently, sometimes wistfully, how and where you could find some new friends -- relax. You are normal.

Cardinal Spellman celebrated a solemn pontificial mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for the intention of the fortieth annual fund appeal of New York Catholic Charities. The appeal began yesterday and will continue through April 29.

The chairman of a special state committee investigating alleged strike-breaking in the newspaper industry disclosed yesterday that the committee had met with Industrial Commissioner Martin P. Catherwood.
Following is the text of a speech by Secretary of the Treaury Robert B. Anderson at the annual luncheon of The associated Press yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:
BOSTON, April 20 -- On the way to Fenway Park yesterday Charles Dillon Stengel, the well-traveled man, indicated various points of interest with the glibness of a barker on a sight-seeing bus.

George Meany said yesterday that the fight against discrimination in this country had not been won. He urged that it be waged vigorously as an essential of the nation's leadership of the free people of the world.
Teddy Brenner, who has been promoting boxing programs at the St. Nicholas Arena, became Madison Square Garden's matchmaker yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., April 20 -- Stockholders of General Development Corporation today approved an increase in the authorized common stock from 2,800,000 to 15,000,000 shares and ratified two distributions of common stock to share-owners.

WITHIN the last five years, small shops dedicated to good fashions have sprung up all over the city. Two of the newest are in the vicinity of Fifty-ninth Street, but each is well entrenched on its own side of town.

HAVANA, April 20 -- The Haitian revolutionary front here denied today any connection with a small armed expedition that had attempted to leave Oriente Province for Haiti and was arrested yesterday by the Cuban Navy.
INVESTIGATIONS by Congressional committees were examined last night in a forthright and enlightening telecast by the American Broadcasting Company.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 20 -- Premier Castro came to this college town tonight to begin his crusade to reach American public opinion outside the national capital.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 20 -- President Francois Duvalier opened a new session of Congress today with a defense of his rule under dictatorial powers.
Major league baseball attendance to date is down 15 per cent with all except three clubs under last year's figures.
Negotiations between the publishers of ten New York newspapers and their union printers were broken off yesterday for the fifth time in a six-month effort to reach a new contract.

KENNEWICK, Wash., April 20 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey attacked Administration power policies tonight and proposed a "giant" power grid to link atomic, hydro and steam producing facilities for the whole country.

ALGIERS, April 20 -- European extremists, divided among themselves, appear to have lost some ground in Algeria. This is indicated by the final results announced today for the first day of municipal elections yesterday.
Arthur Godfrey will take a "temporary leave" from his radio and television programs at the end of this week "to undergo a medical examination."
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points (40 cents a bale) up to 2 points (10 cents) off yesterday.

Your editorial of April 16 entitled "Africa Freedom Day" gives rise to the unfortunate inference that Israel was excluded from the Africa Freedom Celebration at Carnegie Hall on the evening of April 15. On the contrary, representatives of the Israeli Government were present in the audience both as box holders and as guests of the American Committee on Africa, under whose auspices the Carnegie Hall celebration was held.

HOUSTON, April 20 (AP) -Jackie Burke Jr., playing a course he tramped nearly every day as a boy, beat Julius Boros by five strokes today in an 18-hole playoff for first prize in the $30,000 Houston invitation golf tournament.
Mayor Wagner left the door open yesterday for consideration of the pleas of policemen, firemen and some other employes for larger pay rises than the $200 a year now planned.
LONDON, April 20 -- Prices of a wide range of industrial stocks advanced today. They were spurred by some cheering company statements and Friday's strength on Wall Street.

GENEVA, April 20 -- A Soviet spokesman said today that President Eisenhower had sent a message to Premier Khruschev on the question of banning test of nuclear weapons. The spokesman later retracted his statement.
ALBANY, April 20 -- The state Health Department has been studying radiation levels in the lower Hudson Valley with an eye to protecting the area after atomic power plants begin operating there.
Private brand marketing has come in for considerable attention recently from the advertising industry as its share of the food market has increased substantially.

Underwriters led by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Stone Webster Securtities Corporation and Mitchum, Jones Templeton late yesterday put 800,000 shares of General Telephone Electronics Corporation common stock on the market at $71.25 a share.
TRENTON, April 20 -- The State Supreme Court ordered the Susquehanna Railroad today to negotiate for the transfer to Hoboken of its present Jersey City terminal operations.
THE era of Al Capone was evoked last night on Channel 2's "Desilu Playhouse."
Two researchers at Goldwater Memorial Hospital have found to their surprise that the antibiotic neomycin reduced by 21 per cent the cholesterol in the blood of twenty-two patients.
Detroit Edison Company and its subsidiaries yesterday reported gains in gross revenues for the three and twelve-month periods ended March 31.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The United States and Canada announced today a cooperative research program for exploring the ionosphere over the Arctic with rockets and satellites.
Christopher T. Chenery's 1958 champion 2-year-old, First Landing, who was second in last Saturday's Wood Memorial, was shipped to Louisville by train yesterday for the Kentucky Derby on May 2.

Maurice Evans, who was last seen here in George Bernard Shaw's "The Apple Cart," is considering the leading role in another Shavian work, "Heartbreak House." The part that has been offered to him is that of Captain Shotover.
Reflecting a sharp upturn in sales, production and employment, earnings of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company rose to $17,152,379 in the first quarter, from $3,785,406 a year earlier.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 20 (AP) -- The Government announced today that Oscar Unzaga de la Vega, a Rightist leader, had committed suicide after the failure of his uprising in this capital yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP) -- Charley Neal's ninth-inning home run, his first of the season, made Don Drysdale's three-hit pitching pay off for a 2-1 victory for the Los Angeles Dodgers' over the San Francisco Giants tonight.
Your April 13 editorial "The Fair Trade Bill" presents an oversimplified view of the fair trade problem.

SUGGEST canned fruits as a possibility for desserts and most families will show a remarkable lack of enthusiasm. All too often, the products are thought of as something dished out of a can to serve as the easiest possible conclusion to a slap-dash dinner.

The Eaton Howard Funds reported yesterday a new high in net assets as of March 31. The combined assets of the two mutual funds increased $86,839,444 in the last twelve months. This raised the total to a new high at $346,625,146 as of March 31.
A youth nicknamed Knowledge, who conceded he could not spell the word, testified yesterday that he had seen seven teen-agers advance on the man they are accused of fatally beating.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 (UPI) -- Augie Nischwitz, who runs bowling lanes in Edwardsville, Ill., eliminated Don Carter of St. Louis tonight from the American Bowling Congress Masters tournament.

Mayor Wagner continued his search for Park Commissioner Robert Moses yesterday. He wanted to discuss the future of admission-free Shakespeare in Central Park. At the end of the day the Mayor's quest was still unrewarded.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York named Lawrence A. Wien president-elect last night.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- Rain over the week-end had a bearish effect today on rye and new-crop wheat futures on the Board of Trade. But other grains and soybeans attracted moderate demand.
BOSTON, April 20 (UPI) -Eino Oksanen, a detective from Finland, overtook favored Johnny Kelley with less than a mile left and won the sixty-third annual Boston Marathon today by 300 yards.
Mayor Wagner last night summoned officials of a union that has threatened a strike at six voluntary hospitals to an emergency conference at City Hall today.
NORWALK, Conn., April 20 -- Representative Donald J. Irwin of this city said today he was seeking a three-way investigation of the New Haven Railroad commuter problem.

In laying down, as he did yesterday, the fundamental tenets on which the Administration's present fiscal and monetary programs are based, Secretary of the Treasury Anderson elected to do so before an audience that could hardly have been better selected from the standpoint of understanding and responsiveness -- the assembled representatives of The Associated Press.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated John R. Bartels, a Brooklyn lawyer, to be a United States judge for the Eastern District covering Brooklyn, Queens, Richmond, Nassau and Suffolk.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 20 (AP) -- Fresh-faced members of West Point's Corps of Cadets saluted today an Army veteran who retired long before any of them was born. The occasion was the old soldier's ninety-ninth birthday.
An all-male jury was unable last night to reach a decision in the case of former Deputy Inspector Dominic J. Masella. He had been charged with illegal wiretapping.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare declared today that the mentally ill of the country were receiving "disgracefully inadequate" care and treatment.
LONDON, April 20 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd declared today that Britain shared the United States view that Allied aircraft could fly to Berlin at any altitude.

LISBON, Portugal, April 20 -- After three months of diplomatic asylum in the Brazilian Embassy here, Lieut. Gen. Humberto Delgado was rushed to Lisbon Airport tonight and put aboard a plane bound for Rio de Janeiro.
Wilson Parkhill, who is retiring after twenty-five years as headmaster of the Collegiate School, appealed yesterday for more attention to the needs of private or "independent"

THE aim of the Composers Showcase, as Charles Schwartz, its director, puts it is to present the best in contemporary music. Because of this it, does not care, particularly, if it presents premieres. And, though it takes the young into account, the series is not dedicated to introducing new talents.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review the validity of a four-year sentence for criminal contempt imposed on Robert G. Thompson, Communist leader.

The recently published annual reports of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and the Port of New York Authority serve as useful reminders of the great benefit accruing to the public from the financial strength, the expert direction, the foresightedness and the vigorous initiative that make the influence of these authorities increasingly felt.

Wool prices rose yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, reflecting higher prices at the Australian auctions and strength in London. Increased consumption of wool in this country and abroad also influenced the market.

YONKERS, April 20 -- Two college freshmen and a Motor Vehicle Bureau stenographer were accused today of defrauding a motorist by promising for $80 to get a light penalty for the driver who had been charged with many violations.
NEW DELHI, India, April 20 -- India, is heading for disaster unless she can increase her food output by 57 per cent during the next seven years, a Ford Foundation team reported today.

RYE, N. Y., April 20 -- The Town Board rezoned 356 acres of land for light manufacturing tonight and made it possible for the United Aircraft Corporation to build a $6,000,000 plant here -- if it wants to.

AINTREE, England, April 20 -- The scene was Saturday's 200-mile international automobile race here. As the starter's flag fell, twenty-nine Grand Prix-type cars surged ahead in one writhing mass. The noise was deafening, a high-pitched crescendo.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -- A pedestrian's right to cross the street was upheld today by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that it was a violation of Federal law to promise donations to a political party in return for help in getting a Federal appointive job.

" THE WORLD OF OCTAVE LANDUYT" (as Landuyt's first New York exhibition at the Landry Gallery, 712 Fifth Avenue, is called) is a world screened by the morphologist's eye: What matters to Landuyt are the form and structure of animal, human and plant life, which he describes with the accuracy of a medical illustrator.
LONDON, April 20 -- The Conservative Government defeated today a Labor party attack upon its failure to increase pensions.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that the widow of a seaman killed in a boat collision on the Mississippi might sue in Federal court for damages from his employer.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The International Chamber of Commerce opened its fortieth-anniversary meeting today with two new proposals for help to underdeveloped nations.
ROME, April 20 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth and Princess Margaret of Britain arrived here tonight for a private visit that has assumed political overtones.

MONTREAL, April 20 (CP) -- A vice president of the New York Central Railroad today described the St. Lawrence Seaway as a giant drain on tax dollars and said American Railroads would cut freight rates to compete with it.
The mass feeding industry, said to represent investment of $14,000,000,000, plans a special promotion this year at the National Hotel Exposition at the New York Coliseum on Nov. 2 to 6.
MEXICO CITY, April 20 -- A United States draft declaration for freedom of information was attacked today at a session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council here.

BEL AIR, Md., April 20 (AP) -- A longhaired dachshund, Champion Roderick von Nidda, owned by Mrs. Osborn Howes of Chestnut Hill, Mass., today won best-in-show honors at the eighth annual Harford County Kennel Club fixture.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- The ritual of the movie press conference, which permits the mighty to bask in the confusion of interviewers, was staged here today on the traditional wall-to-wall carpet.
Seven boats in the city's flotilla of ferryboats will soon be equipped with radar navigational aids designed and built by a British company.
The United Parcel Service strike provides a reminder that increased union democracy sometimes can have its painful side for employers and the public.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Senator Styles Bridges, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, called on Congress today to restrict Federal spending to the "highest priority" items as a means of maintaining a balanced budget.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senate took up the first amendment to the Kennedy-Ervin labor reform bill today and headed into a possibly long and heated debate about labor law in general.
Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut endorsed yesterday a proposal for a tri-state transportation commission.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 20 (Reuters) -- The Israeli Army announced today the appointment of a new Chief of Operations and a Chief of Intelligence. Their predecessors were ousted in the wake of protests against a dramatic military call-up broadcast on April 1.
The Board of Higher Education approved plans yesterday for admitting out-of-city students to the municipal colleges in the coming academic, year.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Representative James E. Van Zandt, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that on the basis of the announced St. Lawrence Seaway tolls there was not one chance in a thousand that the Federal Government would recover its investment.
Prices of United States securities continued to retreat yesterday in apprehension of the market impact of the Treasury's $4,500,000,000 refinancing operation, due next month.
A 16-year-old Staten Island youth was arrested yesterday as a suspect in ten arson and burglary cases that have baffled the police since last November.
ALBANY, April 20 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller called on New York citizens to join in the campaign to help retired persons overcome "enforced inactivity."
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 20 (AP) -- The British hard courts tennis championships opened here today with the top-seeded player, Luis Ayala of Chile, stranded in Houston, Texas.
The United Parcel Service, whose deliveries have been halted by a walkout of 3,000 workers, said last night that it expected the strike to be a long one.
BOSTON, April 20 -- This was a gloomy day for the New York Yankees.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower called on the Daughters of the American Revolution tonight to look to the future and "contribute to the ever-enlarging traditions of our country."
ALBANY, April 20 (UPI) -Governor Rockefeller today proclaimed May 2 as Loyalty Day.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's April 13 letter to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev on a suspension of tests of nuclear weapons:
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted, 12 to 3, today in favor of Justice Potter Stewart's nomination to the Supreme Court.
HARTFORD, April 20 -- The cause of residents of Connecticut who pay income taxes to New York and Massachusetts on money earned in those states was pressed here today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court today ruled that Federal criminal antitrust prosecutions could be pressed even though the defendant concern had been dissolved under state law before it entered a plea to the charges.

GREENFIELD, Mass., April 20 -- Two of the first three days of trout fishing hereabouts have been cold, raw and windy. However, the fishermen have run closer to form and type than admirals or television jollyboys.
NEW DELHI, India, April 20 -- Authoritative Indians asserted today that the Indian-Chinese border was well defined and not subject to negotiation with Peiping.

NEWARK, April 20 -- Six-hundred stockholders of Public Service Electric and Gas Company were told here today that first quarter net earnings had increased to $1.07 a share from 88 cents a share on fewer shares in the first 1958 quarter.
RICHMOND, Va., April 20 -- The Virginia House of Delegates turned down today a segregationist bill that would eliminate public schools.

Plans have been completed for Fashions Around the Clock, a luncheon and fashion show to be held in the Terrace Room of the Plaza tomorrow. Mrs. Joseph A. Grazier, Mrs. Leonard B. Leeming and Mrs. Herbert L. Wisner head the committee for the event, which will benefit the Children's Health Service.
PANAMA, April 20 -- Dame Margot Fonteyn, Britain's leading ballerina, was arrested today on suspicion of revolutionary activity against the Panamanian Government.
CAIRO, April 20 (Reuters) -The Soviet Ambassador in Cairo handed a message from Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to President Gamal Abdel Nasser at a two-hour meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- A Republican move to award a Congressional Gold Medal to John Foster Dulles was reported snagged in the Senate today.

NEW HAVEN, April 20 -- Adlai E. Stevenson and Carmine G. DeSapio, leaders of different elements of the Democratic party, agreed tonight that the race for the Democratic Presidential nonmination next year would be wide open.
Eddie Thompson, a Queens middleweight, gained a split decision over Benny (Kid) Paret in the feature ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
RYE, N. Y., April 20 -- The story of a sleep-destroying woodpecker that prefers to drum his love calls on a television antenna instead of trees had sequels today.

Major crime here increased 8.7 per cent in the first three months of this year compared with the similar period last year. Rape offenses and the theft of automobiles increased by more than double that figure.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 -- William Heikkila, 53-year-old draftsman, was again ordered deported to his native Finland today. His deportation a year ago stirred international comments.
Issues of local governments of California held the center of interest yesterday in the market for new tax-exempt interest bonds.

Eugene S. Duffield has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Popular Science Publishing Company. He becomes publisher of Popular Science Monthly, Outdoor Life and many other publications of the parent company.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., April 20 -- An agreement setting up a two-year technical college at the W. Tresper Clarke High School was signed here today.

ORANGE, N. J., April 20 -Tony Galento, his wife Mary and three other persons were fined on gambling charges by Magistrate Ovid J. Colalillo here today as the aftermath of a 2 A. M. raid at Mrs. Galento's home here.
The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has received $45,646,329 in gifts and pledges, it was disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting of the center's directors. The goal is $75,000,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 20 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will discuss the Berlin situation this week with Acting Secretary of State Christian A. Herter.
HONG KONG, April 20 -A Peiping commentator denounced today a statement issued Saturday in Tezpur, India, in the name of the Dalai Lama
Following is the text of the report of the board of directors of The Associated Press, read at the annual membership neeting yesterday:

" AFTER breakfast," the story said, "the general agreed to go back up to Suribachi so that cameramen could get the picture they had missed the day before. He rode in a Chevrolet sedan to the foot of Suribachi, and then climbed out to transfer to a Jeep for the steep climb up the dusty trail cut out of the side of the hill.
The main effort of Soviet strategy is concentrated at the moment in the Middle East, rather than in Germany, many Washington observers believe.

Russian Church choral music will be performed a cappelia by the Russian Synod Cathedral Choir conducted by Boris M. Ledkovsky at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, on Thursday evening.

Net earnings of E. I. duPont de Nemours Co., Inc., were $2.17 a common share in the quarter ended on March 31, compared with $1.51 a share in the 1958 period, the company reported yesterday. Of the earnings, $1.53 a share was realized from operations, a rise of 76 per cent higher from the 87 cents a share in the year-ago period.
" Jonas," a German-made drama with English narration, will have its premiere at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, April 29.

GOOD cutlery can be one of the most satisfying and worth-while investments for the home. This is the belief of Richard Williams, a buyer in Altman's houseware section, who recommends that it should be selected with the same care and understanding given to flat silver.

Harry S. Truman is about the last person in the world likely to suggest that somebody dedicate a shrine to him. However, the State of Missouri, with the cooperation of the United Auto Workers of America, has just done this. The Auto Workers bought the house in Lamar, Mo., where Mr. Truman spent the first eleven months of his life, and Missouri has accepted this modest building as a place of pilgrimage.
A new $600,000 exchange point between the IND and IRT subways in Queens was opened yesterday morning when a high-speed escalator was put into service.
Elaine Lee, violinist, was a Walter H. Naumburg Foundation award winner last year and her prize was a debut recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 20 (AP) -- Peter Green, an 18-year-old University of North Carolina freshman from Franklin, Mich., and Dave Smith, an automobile dealer from Gastonia, N. C., shared the medal today in the North and South amateur golf tournament.

British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Derick Heathcoat Amory, Robert B. Anderson, United States Secretary of the Treasury, and W. Randolph Burgess, United States Permanent Representative to the North Atlantic Council, are to speak at the sixth annual monetary conference of the American Bankers Association May 5-8 in London.

Packages of assorted seeds, dispensed in the backyard during the winter, bore the provocative legend: "Feed the little birds and they will repay you a thousand times over in song." The record shows that many of these prospective songsters arrived and lingered to dine luxuriously, but departed leaving a substantial tab.

PRESIDENT HERNAN SILES ZUAZO of Bolivia is a man who did not take his father's advice. Thirty-three years ago, when the elder Siles assumed the Presidency, he counseled his 12-year-old son never to follow his footsteps.
Advice from newspaper editros and publishers will be an important guide to wire service coverage of news during the coming year, United Press International editors were told yesterday.

IT was some nine years ago that "The Innocents," William Archibald's adaptation of Henry James' novel "The Turn of the Screw," glowed balefully on Broadway. Last night, as it was revived at the Gramercy Arts Theatre on East Twenty-seventh Street, the weird thriller had not lost a single horror effect.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- C. Canby Balderston, vice chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, called today for "wisdom and restraint" in Government spending as a way of fighting inflation.
LONDON, April 20 -- A sixteenth-century first edition of Jacques Cartiers "Shorte and Briefe Narration" of his first two voyages to Canada was sold at auction here today for 4,200 ($11,760).

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 20 -- Long Island Sound Internationally One-Design Class sailors were an unhappy and soggy lot when they put ashore at the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club today at the start of Bermuda's annual International Race Week.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board will start hearings May 11 on a petition for a representation election here among pier and packinghouse workers of the American Sugar Refining Company.
PRETORIA, South Africa, April 20 (Reuters) -- A three-judge court quashed today an indictment against sixty-one defendants of three racial groups at South Africa's third mass treason trial.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The United States gave more economic aid to foreign countries last year from sources outside the foreign aid law than from the program itself.

CLEVELAND, April 20 (UPI) -- Terms of an agreement between the United Rubber Workers Union and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company were made public today with the signing of new contracts here. These called for substantial improvements in
HARTFORD, April 20 (AP) -The Internal Revenue Service attached ninety liens today on slenderella reducing salons throughout the country. It said the organization owed more than $1,000,000 in taxes.

WOODFORD, England, April 20 -- Sir Winston Churchill, who will be 85 years old Nov. 30, told his constituents here tonight that he would "offer himself" once again as a Conservative candidate for the House of Commons in the coming elections.
PANAMA, April 20 (Reuters) -- After arriving here Dame Margot went to the home of a friend and telephoned her mother in Britain. Then she disappeared.

The understanding between the United States and Israel rests on a firm foundation that should not be disturbed, Edward B. Lawson said last night. Mr. Lawson is retiring as United States Ambassador to Israel after four years' service there.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has struck a blow at savings and loan association "give-away" programs in which the association acts as seller's agent for a silverware or other premium company.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 20 -- President Eisenhower has made a personal appeal to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to help save the Geneva negotiations on a ban on tests of nuclear weapons.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 20 -- The Texas Senate by implication gave Lyndon B. Johnson unanimous endorsement today for the Democratic nomination for President next year.
A new generation of Brooklyn Heights residents is trying to get the city to act under a never-invoked state law to preserve the architectural charm and family-life advantages of the community.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the short interest dropped in the month ended on April 15 by 281,781 shares to 3,511,794 shares. This was the lowest level since Jan. 15 of last year when it was 2,832,740 shares.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The international problems which Christian A. Herter has inherited from John Foster Dulles present enormous difficulties and hazards for a Secretary of State as the President's agent in the conduct of United States foreign policy.

The nation's steel-makers continued to increase their output last week, pushing raw steel production to a record as consumers sought to build inventories against possible strikes this summer after steel labor contract expire.

Don Carter, who never grandstands, caused more comment in the St. Louis Armory Sunday night than any showman could have. It wasn't his bowling that did it, for high-grade bowling is expected of him. It was the all-white ball he used.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The' Supreme Court agreed ,-today to rule whether 'pickeUng to win immediate .rec-j ognitlon for a union that did not represent a majority of em-I ployes, tn a,brgaining unit wasJ a violation o! the Taft-Hartleyj Act.
Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson called on newspaper leaders yesterday to campaign against inflation -- both for the nation's own growth and as an example for new democracies abroad.

YONKERS, April 20 -- Patience and a barrel of money were all a fellow needed to catch up with the 8-8 daily double at Yonkers raceway. That combination finally clicked tonight and was worth $163.30 for $2, but anyone who had been playing it nightly since it last scored did not even approach the break-even mark.
The attempted revolt in Bolivia on Sunday was crushed with impressive speed. The move came from the Right-Wing Falange Socialista Boliviano and met a complete lack of popular support.
DETROIT, April 2O (AP) -- Spurred by continuing high level retail demand, the auto industry is maintaining a strong production tempo.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP) -- A charge of unfair labor practices against the striking Newspaper Guild was dismissed today by the local office of the National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Supreme Court held today that the Taft-Hartley law barred state courts from awarding damages against a union for peaceful picketing, even if the picketing violated the Federal labor law.

Our town is not really full of editors and publishers this week. It merely seems that way. The meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, with related meetings by the press agencies, has brought us only about twelve hundred guests. But these twelve hundred represent, in the A. N. P. A. alone, 846 newspapers with a total circulation of more than fifty-two million.

Members of the Metropolitan section of the Professional Golfers Association voted for a change yesterday. At their annual session at the Park Sheraion Hotel they elected a new slate of officers that included Claude Harmon as president.

Allen Dulles, in his speech reported on April 9, clearly intended to alert the American people to the danger of the Russian economic challenge. He warned against the spread of "comforting illusion(s)" which serve as "false tranquilizer(s).''

Chancellor Adenauer clinched his election as West German President on Sunday when his Christian Democratic party made new gains in two German state elections, improving its absolute majority in the state parliament of the Rhineland-Palatinate and strengthening its dominant position in the coalition regime of Lower Saxony.
Ruth Lakeway, soprano who made her debut here in February, 1958, returned to offer a song program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

If there are any doubts whether or not trading on the New York Stock Exchange is a big business, some impressive statistics should put them at rest. The figures are contained in the exchange's latest "Fact Book," issued yesterday. Some of the data follows:

Aluminium, Ltd., reported yesterday it had successfully performed an unusual blasting job that had attracted widespread interest among construction men. Engineers at the company's $150,000,000 hydroelectric power project at Chute-des-Passes, Quebec, 150 miles north of Arvida, set off thirty tons of high explosives on Sunday to remove a 13,000-cubic-foot rock plug between the bottom of the Peribonka River and the entrance to a six-mile tunnel that will carry water to a huge subterranean powerhouse downstream.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that union printers had made demands on two Massachusetts newspapers in violation of the Taft-Hartley Law. It said the union thereby had refused to bargain as required by law.
CHICAGO, April 20 (UPI) -- One of the nation's leading heart specialists predicted today that within ten years physicians would be able to spot 80 per cent of potential heart attack victims.
ALBANY, April 20 -- New York City will receive $2,650,000 in state aid for education through legislation that was approved today by Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- President Eisenhower sent his nomination of Christian A. Herter as Secretary of State to the Senate today. Speedy approval is expected. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has invited Mr. Herter to appear before it at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow. No other witnesses are scheduled.

HAZARD, Ky., April 20 -- Two National Guard battalions were demobilized today after Gov. A. B. Chandler had received pledges from both sides in eastern Kentucky's coal mine strike that they would keep the peace.

DETROIT, April 20 (UPI) -- Support of United States foreign aid in principle, but criticism in practice, were voiced today by Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -The Treasury bill rate moved up slightly this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,000,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills was 3.105 per cent, compared to 3.075 per cent last week, and the average on $400,000,000 of 182-day bills was 3.361 per cent, compared to 3.351 per cent last week.
Favorite players among 20,681 Jamaica fans got the only warmth out of a raw, damp and clammy day yesterday as seven public choices won.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CAIRO; April 20 -- Lebanon proposed to the Arab petroleum congress here today that the Arab oil-producing countries and the companies operating in them should lend 5 per cent of their annual profit to the proposed Arab development bank at 2 1/2 per cent interest.

A number of top Broadway stars played second fiddle yesterday to a group of featured actors. The purpose was to demonstrate that more Negroes could be hired for plays and musicals without disturbing the integrity of a production or the author's intent.
A 31-YEAR-OLD Italian, who never designs shoes for just one season, has completed his first collection for I. Miller. He feels his classic styles can easily span years.

Guests of honor at the Ninetieth Anniversary Ball for the New York Foundling Hospital will be the Archduke and Archduchess Josef Arpad. They will fly from Austria for the fete, which will take place in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East on May 5.

Passover -- the Jewish festival that commemorates the Biblical Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt more than 3,000 years ago -- wil be ushered in at sundown tomorrow in Jewish homes here and the world over.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., in the first quarter of this year had the highest sales of any three-month period in the 110-year history of the pharmaceutical and chemical producer. Earnings, however, dipped below last year's level because of higher operating costs and declining prices for some drugs.

Ground will be broken late next month for an International Synagogue and Jewish Center at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. The $250,000 center will complement a Roman Catholic chapel already in use and a Protestant chapel now under construction.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba indicated today that the next big stage in the Cuban revolution would be agrarian reform.

HARTFORD, April 20 -- The Insurance Committee of the General Assembly voted a favorable report today on a bill that would enable Connecticut life insurance companies to compete with major New York banks in writing pension, retirement and profit-sharting contracts.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -President Eisenhower returned to Washington today after a fifteen-day golfing vacation at Augusta, Ga. He scheduled a meeting tomorrow morning with Republican legislative leaders.
Frank King, creator of the comic strip "Gasoline Alley," was named cartoonist of the year last night by the National Cartoonists Society.

Net income of the Federal Paper Board Company, Inc., is expected to exceed $4 a share in 1959, compared with $3.79 a share in 1958, despite a 10 per cent decline in earnings in the first quarter, John R. Kennedy, president, said yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -Another good advance in corn futures prices carried some oldcrop contracts close to new highs for the season again today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- The Teamsters Union today accused an investigator for the Senate rackets committee of having acted for Esso Standard Oil Company in an effort to keep an independent union of refinery workers from affiliating with the teamsters.

EVANSTON, Ill., April 21 (UPI) -- The Northwestern University faculty committee on athletics tonight voted against continuation of the Rose Bowl agreement between the Big Ten and the Pacific Coast Conference. This means that the contract probably will not be renewed after the next New Year's Day football game between teams from the two Conferences.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -Title VI, which the Senate refused to strike from the KennedyErvin labor bill today, contains the following provisions:
The nation's newspaper publishers yesterday took up ways of meeting spiraling costs by such methods as special advertising campaigns, neighborhood supplements and new mechanical processes.

PARIS, April 21 -- At present the main task of American diplomacy is not so much to prepare a sound bargaining position for coming negotiations with Russia as it is to heal the disturbing breach in the ranks of our own alliance. For it is unfortunately true that never since the calamitous Suez war have there been so many divisions among the Western Governments.
LONDON, April 21 -- Sir David Eccles, President of the Board of Trade, announced today that he would lead a mission to Moscow next month in an attempt to expand British trade with the Soviet Union.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 21 (AP) -- Walt Blum clinched Gulfstream Park jockey honors for the season by registering his fourth triumph of the afternoon aboard Charlie's Song in the featured seventh race today.

LONDON, April 21 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has written to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev "warmly recommending" President Eisenhower's appeal to the Soviet leader for his help to save the Geneva negotiations to end nuclear weapon testing.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP) -- Western Union expects its earnings in 1959 to be the highest in the company's 108year history, an executive of the company said here today.
In an office hung with a score of watercolors, Lucille Lazar held a combined one-man art show and retirement party yesterday.

LONDON, April 21 (UPI) -- The citizens of Longford, who insisted they had the right to undisturbed sleep, have chalked up a victory in their battle against Pan American World Airways' planned 1:30 A. M. jet flights to New York.
Grants totaling $2,350,000 to help higher education and to open "new frontiers of basic knowledge" were announced yesterday by the United States Steel Foundation.
Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba came to New York yesterday. Volatile Latin-American admirers, nervous policemen and a friendly Dr. Castro combined to make his entrance a wild affair.
Kermit Bloomgarden has added "The Gang's All Here," the Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee drama, to his Broadway production schedule for next season.
BEING both a noted horseman and a noted gambler, Col. Edward Riley Bradley had some fixed ideas on the inherent frailty of horseflesh. What's more, he was quick to wager on his opinions.

SOFU TESHIGAHARA, a distinguished master of the art of flower arrangement, is also one of Japan's best known avant-garde sculptors. His fierce, knobby, spiny, proliferous sculptures -- along with apposite flower arrangements -- are on view at the Martha Jackson Gallery, 32 East Sixty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Two Washington, D. C., insurance companies today registered their variable annuity insurance policies with the securities and exchange commission as ordered by the Supreme Court.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 20 -- The American farmer is a "superman" to the Communist governments in Eastern Europe, and especially to Hungarian officials, who are trying to raise production through land collectization.
Tulsa, Okla., municipal and county bond issues totaling $8,722,000 were placed on the market yesterday by syndicates headed by the Northern Trust Company.
The Board of Education postponed action yesterday on its proposal to fingerprint teacher candidates.
PARIS, April 21 -- A trend toward moderation in the current balloting in Algeria was noted today by Paul Delouvrier, the Government's Delegate General there.
The Transit Authority suggested yesterday that life underground in New York may be safer than life above ground.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 21 -- A Communist bid for an overt voice in the Government of Iraq appears imminent, according to reports from Baghdad.

Manny Duell, builder, has purchased the two five-story apartment houses on plot 40 by 100 feet at 18 and 20 East Eightythird Street. The seller was Lois Hall Herrick, who had owned the property twenty years. William A. White Sons were the brokers.

A theatre party to "Destry Rides Again" on May 2 will benefit the La Guardia Memorial House. The new musical, starring Dolores Gray and Andy Griffith, is scheduled to open at the Imperial Theatre tomorrow.

LONDON, April 21 -- Derick Heathcoat Amory, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today that he did not see "any cause for alarm or action" because of foreign investments in this country.

A jurisdictional dispute between union sheet metal workers and iron workers threatened yesterday to halt construction on the new $49,000,000 Time-Life Building at the Avenue of the Americas and Fifty-first Street.

Likening the exodus of Jews from eastern Europe to the ancient Exodus from Egypt celebrated at Passover, David Ben-Gurion urged Jews in this country yesterday to renew their aid to those emigrating to Israel.

Man o' War, the thoroughbred that became a legend of the American sports scene, at long last will have a big race named for him. John W. Hanes, the president of the New York Racing Association, disclosed yesterday that a highlight of the forthcoming meeting at the new Aqueduct race track would be the $100,000 added Man o' War Stakes on Saturday, Oct. 24.

LONG BEACH, L. I., April 21 -- An 11-year-old sixth-grade pupil at the Lido Elementary School here walked into the science room today, picked up a microphone and spoke with his father 1,200 miles away on a ship off Florida.

City officials joined with representatives of the Federal Public Housing Administration at a ground-breaking ceremony yesterday for the Samuel J. Tilden Houses in the Brownsville district of Brooklyn.

BUENOS AIRES, April 21 -Terrorists wounded a policeman guarding the closed offices of the Communist party early today and exchanged fire with another policeman outside the suspended Communist newspaper La Hora.

There is more than purely scientific importance and interest in the United States-Canadian agreement announced yesterday for cooperative exploration of the ionosphere by means of rockets and satellites. Even looked at narrowly, the agreement provides procedures under which Canadian scientists will plan, provide instruments for and do important space research, even though their country does not produce the vehicles needed to bring their instruments into the volume of space they wish to study.
GENEVA, April 21 -- President Eisenhower's letter to Premier Khrushchev was read into the conference record today.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy told 610 policemen and women yesterday to use force when necessary to combat crime at parks, pools and beaches this summer.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- The Soviet Government announced tonight that the foreign ministers of the Warsaw Pact and of Communist China would meet in Warsaw next Monday to draft plans for the Geneva conference on Germany.

A CHICAGO columnist once noted that most people who used the word conversant were not conversant with its pronunciation. The same can be said of herbs. Most people who use the fresh, delicately spiced herbs soon to reach the market are in doubt as to the sound of the names. Does basil rhyme with hazel or dazzle?
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -Glen Hobbie of the Chicago Cubs allowed only three batters to reach base today in a onehit, 1-0 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -Lower Government payments and higher production expenses are expected to reduce the net income realized by farmers this year by about $1,000,000,000, the Department of Agriculture said today.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -Some experts think the new chief of the Soviet secret police may be playing an important role in planning the International Youth Festival in Vienna this summer.

NORWALK, Conn., April 21 -- With the support of similar groups in Darien, Fairfield, Weston, Westport and Wilton, the Norwalk Town Committee of the Mid-Fairfield Child Guidance Center is sponsoring a dance, the Mimosa Ball, on Saturday evening at the Shorehaven Golf Club.

LONDON, April 21 (Reuters) -- The formation of a new company aimed at widening American investment in Britain and the British Commonwealth and in the countries of the European Common Market was announced here tonight.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 21 -- A bit of smart downwind sailing by Vincent Learson of the Larchmont Yacht Club on the last leg of a Gold Cup course enabled the Long Island Sound team of International One-Design Class sailors to gain a victory over the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club team today.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- The Government reported today that half of the nation's families had incomes above $5,050 in 1958 -- a $20 increase from the previous year.

BOSTON, April 21 (AP) -- A Boston Red Sox official today vigorously denied charges that the Boston baseball club had discriminated in the handling of Jerry (Pumpsie) Green. Green, an infielder, was optioned to the Red Sox' Minneapolis club before the season opened.
MILWAUKEE, April 21 (AP) -- The league-leading Milwaukee Braves defeated Cincinnati, 7 -- 4, today on Henry Aaron's hitting and Warren Spahn's pitching.

A man described as a major East Harlem narcotics distributor was arrested yesterday in his fifth-floor apartment at 124 East 127th Street after a struggle in which he, a Federal agent and two policemen were cut by glass.

BANDUNG, Wednesday, April 22 (Reuters) -- In an apparent allusion to the growth of Communist China, President Sukarno said today that "the conflict between the old and new giants will become so sharpened and strained that there will not be sufficient elbow room for us if we ourselves have not yet secured firm consolidation in every field."
ATAMI, Japan, April 21 (AP) -- Japan has started building a super-railway to be so fast that trains will need radar-operated brakes.
The American Smelting and Refining Company (Asarco), one of the largest miners and processors of lead and zinc, yesterday called for a world-wide cut-back in production of those metals.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, April 21 -- Malaya and the United States signed an investment guarantee agreement today under the United States Mutual Security Act.

Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, appealed last night for support of the Administration's $3,900,000,000 mutual security program. He said it was an undertaking of enlightened national self-interest.

Yesterday it became a distinct probability that Ingemar Johansson, the Swedish heavyweight, would pitch his training camp on a large parking lot on West Fifty-first Street between the west wall of Toots Shor's restaurant and the Avenue of the Americas.

It is almost impossible to believe that Edward Johnson was in his eighty-first year when he died on Monday. His zest for life remained undiminished to the end. His carriage was youthful, his walk jaunty and his outlook vibrant. He never lost his passion for the operatic art he served so long and so honorably in so many capacities -- as singer, manager and counselor of new generations of performers.

NEW DELHI, India, April 21 -- Defense Minister V. K. Krishna Menon accused Pakistan today of having bullied and harassed two wounded Indian airmen to wring from them a "concocted confession" of spying on military targets.

OTTAWA, April 21 (Canadian Press) -- Commodity imports into Canada in the first quarter of 1959 rose an estimated 5 per cent to $1,244,000,000, compared with 1958, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -The Senate decisively checked today the opening drive to alter the Kennedy-Ervin labor reform bill.

A banquet scene from a Rubens painting was brought to life last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza for the Bal Baroque Italien, which was held for the benefit of the Madonnina del Grappa, an orphanage in Rifredi, Italy.

Stimulated by heavy customer buying in anticipation of a strike that started last April 9, the net income of the United States Rubber Company rose in the first quarter to a record of $10,200,000 from $3,891,000 for the period a year ago.
The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service intervened yesterday for the second time in an attempt to prevent a strike by union printers against ten New York newspapers.
LOS Angeles, April 21 -- The State Supreme Court upheld today the legal right of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team to acquire a 300-acre tract in Chavez Ravine for a new stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- Assistant Secretary of State Walter S. Robertson told Congress today that Communist China was becoming dangerously overconfident and was displaying increasing arrogance.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 21 -- John H. Hulsen, Huntington Republican leader, and his nephew, James W. Weber, a Huntington lawyer, were convicted today of extorting $5,000 from sand and gravel operators in Huntington in the guise of legal fees that were paid to Weber two years ago.

Planning for the Vacation It is the time of year when the powersthat-be in many families across the nation are beginning to plan for the summer vacation. No matter what the course of action will be for the respite, it takes planning by the whole group to work out details for the summer's fare.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, Wednesday, April 22 -- President Sukarno urged Indonesia today to carry out socialistic reconstruction and "guided democracy" and to eliminate capitalism as much as possible.
The Philadelphia Orchestra, conducted by Eugene Ormandy, closed its New York season last night in Carnegie Hall with a concert version of the Berlioz "Damnation of Faust."

THERE are only three kinds of biographies worth reading: those of people more important for their minds than for their actions; those of people more important for their actions and for the outward circumstances of their lives than for their minds, and those of people whose thoughts and deeds seem almost equally important.

A new book by Arthur Koestler, his sixteenth since publication of "The Gladiators" in 1939, will be issued on May 19 by Macmillan. In "The Sleepwalkers: A History of Man's Changing Vision of the Universe,"

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "For a World of Law" (April 15) comments on Vice President Nixon's proposal to elevate the International Court of Justice to a real Supreme Court of the World. Conceivably the court could acquire broader international functions. But under present conditions it is not likely to become a true world supreme court.
WASHINGTON, April 21-President Eisenhower is expected to name Brooks Hays of Arkansas, former Democratic House member, as a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

The 1958-59 appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund brought a record total of $493,736.09. This total, announced yesterday, compares with $449,286.11 for the 1957-1958 appeal and $477,756.73 for the previous high total, in the 1956-57 appeal.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -Responding handsomely to the taunts of Casey Stengel that they weren't scoring enough runs to suit the master, the Yankees opened fire on Cookie Lavegetto's unsuspecting Senators tonight.
The bond markets had another nervous day yesterday. United States securities and other prime-risk obligations made a show of some assurance at the close after weakness in early trading.

COLOR, which been creeping into china and earthenware patterns for the last few years, is very much in evidence in a presentation of 1959 tableware designs that opens today on Altman's fourth floor. The display includes a great diversification of china, earthenware and glassware designs from eleven countries.

A church in Brooklyn will start working with teen-age gangs and housing problems in June as part of a $30,000 pilot project. The project was voted last night by the Board of Home Missions of the Congregational Christian Churches.
RICHMOND, Va., April 21 (AP) -- The United States Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals today affirmed a Tax Court ruling that William O'Dwyer and his former wife owe $8,242 in back Federal income taxes.
The dance and the press have reunited the conductor of the Bolshoi Ballet, Yuri Faier, with a brother he last saw fifty-two years ago in Russia.

Billy Haughton of Brookville, L. I., the country's top harness racing driver for the last six years and the leading money-winner for the past seven years, was honored yesterday at a luncheon in Danny's Hideaway.
BEIRUT, April 17 -- An American professor recently expelled from Iraq believes that campus life at the University of Baghdad is approaching anarchy.
A 19-year-old New Jersey youth was stabbed last night in a street brawl on Seventy-sixth Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues. Roosevelt Hospital reported his condition as critical.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- A former law partner of Illinois' Attorney General Latham Castle charged today that Mr. Castle had once improperly used his Dekalb County, Ill., judgeship.
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Fundamental Investors, Inc., reported yesterday record net assets of $537,656,164, equal to $18.55 a share on 28,991,117 shares outstanding on March 31. All figures are new highs. The number of shareholders also hit a new high of 99,890 compared with 97,877 at the end of 1958.
BONN, Germany, April 21 -Finance Minister Franz Etzel was reported today to have withdrawn from the race for the Chancellorship of West Germany in favor of Ludwig Erhard, the Economics Minister.
The cotton futures market moved irregularly yesterday, to close 10 points lower to 4 points higher than on Monday. The market held in a narrow range all day. (A point equals 5 cents a bale).
LONDON, April 21 (AP) -Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said here today that he would have favored closer study by the West of the Rapacki plan for military disengagement in central Europe.
GREENFIELD, Mass., April 21 -- All is not quite rosy in the project to reclaim and improve the Deerfield River, a fine brown-trout stream, and most of its forty miles south from the Vermont border.
YONKERS, April 21 -- Opinions vary on the relative merits of harness racing drivers. But any fan is entitled to a choice, and at Yonkers Raceway the choices are many.
A $250,000 repair job on the ceiling of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel will begin early in June, officials of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority said yesterday.
DETROIT, April 21 (AP) -- Salaries and payments of supplemental compensation to top executive officers of the Ford Motor Company in 1958 were substantially unchanged from those of the preceding year.
Seven film imports are now being prepared for American release by the Embassy Pictures Corporation.
Fifty upstate farmers gave away 12,000 eggs yesterday in front of the New York Mercantile Exchange to protest the low price of eggs.
MOSCOW, April 21 (AP) -The Soviet Union warned West Germany today that its position as a nuclear arsenal of the West in any war would be "militarily hopeless."
MEXICO CITY, April 21 -- A resolution to put the United Nations Economic and Social Council on record as favoring freedom of information was tabled for further consideration here today.

A strike of nonprofessional employes at six voluntary hospitals, scheduled for 6 A. M. today, was deferred last night for two weeks. The union agreed to put off action while the hospital boards of trustees considered a fact-finding formula.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- Joseph Campbell, Controller General, who acts as "watchdog" over Government spending for Congress, accused the Navy today of withholding information from his agency's auditors and investigators.
The Clean Government, or regular organization, ticket won a sweeping victory in yesterday's Republican primary election in Essex County.
The Ford Motor Company is literally putting a show on the road.

In announcing the appointment of Wayne Hardin as the successor to Eddie Erdelatz, Capt. Slade Cutter, Navy athletic director, said of the new head football coach: "Hardin typifies the type of person we want in charge of midshipmen * * * a top-flight coach who knows the problems at the Academy and who sympathizes with them."
Doubling of the city's 1-centa-pack cigarette tax was approved unanimously yesterday by the City Council.

Fines of $275 were levied yesterday for violations of the multiple -dwelling law in three tenements owned by Sidney J. Ungar. Meanwhile, Mr. Ungar's trial for violations in a fourth tenement continued.
WARSAW, April 21 (Reuters) -- The Polish Communist party newspaper Trybuna Ludu accused Polish Jesuits today of tax evasion.

The discrimination claims leveled against American shipping policies by traditional maritime powers of Europe apply to only 3 per cent of all United States cargoes, a leader of the American merchant marine declared yesterday.
HARTSDALE, N. Y., April 21 -- A state-wide committee to survey future financial needs of all school districts was urged tonight by State Controller Arthur Levitt.
The International Transport Workers Federation has given the orphaned American long-shore union a significant assist toward respectability, it became known here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Democratic Advisory Council named today a seventeenmember advisory committee on science and technology. It will be headed by Dr. Ernest C. Pollard of Yale University.
ALBANY, April 21 -- The state will help Long Island to preserve its South Shore wetlands as a sanctuary for fish and game and a recreation area under a bill aproved today by Governor Rockefeller.
LONDON, April 21 -- Reports of the police interrogation in Panama of Britain's leading ballet star have aroused both official and public concern here.
The first two cases of poliomyelitis to afflict New York City residents this year were reported yesterday by the Health Department. Neither victim had received Salk vaccine.
Evidence was presented here last night that heart damage following a rheumatic fever attack depended upon an inherent susceptibility of the individual rather than upon the virulence of the infection.
Benjamin M. McKelway, editor of The Washington Star, was re-elected president of The Associated Press yesterday.

HONG KONG, April 21 -- Although the Chinese Communist defense budget for 1959 calls for a 16 per cent increase, the share of defense costs in the total budget is slightly smaller than in 1958 according to the Peiping radio.
CONAKRY, Guinea, April 21 -- The Polish ship Wroclaw was unloading today the third cargo of "gifts" to this new African republic from countries behind the Iron Curtain.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -The Daughters of the American Revolution are speaking this year with a southern accent.

COME rain or come shine, summer starts at Gimbels on Monday morning. With the official opening of the thirty-floor Beach Shop, the store will salute the young with a frolicsome group of summer separates in misses and junior size.
A new report on strontium 90 shows that the concentration of the radioactive substance in the bones of American children doubled between 1955 and 1957.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -President Eisenhower imposed import restrictions on woolen goods for the third straight year today. But he changed the restrictions slightly to meet objections of Britain and of American importers.

The Long Island Lighting Company has announced the election of Charles Kiel Jr. as vice president, operating services. Mr. Kiel was formerly manager of the operating services department. He joined the company in 1933.
ELIZABETH, N. J., April 21 -- Relief payments hereafter will not be made to mothers for more than one child born out of wedlock.

IN the fanfare surrounding the French and Italian haute couture the smaller, out-of-theway designer is likely to be overlooked. Bergdorf Goodman remedies this with a gay collection of sportswear newly imported from England, France, Italy and Switzerland.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -The business men of forty-four nations attended a sales meeting today.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, April 21 -- Tyrone Guthrie's production of the rarely given "All's Well That Ends Well," which came into the repertory at the Memorial Theatre here tonight, sets the comedy in the Edwardian period, but not very rigidly.
ALBANY, April 21 -- State financial assistance for communities that want to participate in the Federal urban renewal program was authorized today by Governor Rockefeller.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York City chapter of the National Association of Social Workers, composed of 2,300 social workers in this city, is grateful for your editorial of April 16 on the situation existing in six voluntary hospitals -- specifically, the impasse between the hospitals and the unions which are seeking recognition.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 21 -- Herbert W. Voorhees, president of the New Jersey Farm Bureau, was killed last night when his automobile crashed into the rear of a standing bus on Route 27 in near-by Franklin Township.

IN its first change of program of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Bolshoi Ballet last night gave us another of its great ballerinas, Maya Plisetskaya, in the most famous of all Russian ballets, "Swan Lake." As to Plisetskaya, there can be no question of her greatness; as to the ballet, it is far from the best version of the old masterpiece that has been seen hereabouts.
STRASBOURG, France, April 21 (UPI) -- John Edwards, 54-year-old British Socialist, was elected president today of the fifteen-nation Council of Europe.

THIRTY-FIVE years ago Margaret Hookham, then 4 years old, made a curtsy at Miss Bosutow's dancing and deportment school in London and said "thank you" for the pink silk sash that marked her as the girl who had made the most progress.
PEIPING, April 21 -- Communist China announced today a 1959 budget calling for a 16 per cent increase in defense expenditure and a 40 per cent rise in the value of industrial and agricultural output.
ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP) -John (Junior) Powell of Toledo continued his strong play in the American Bowling Congress Masters tournament today, lifting his average to 226 for sixteen games.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Upon reading Homer Bigart's article on the alleged reformation at Parris Island I discover that perhaps I too have "poor hostility control."

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- The Government produced today a $1,600 check in the conspiracy trial of Richard A. Mack, former Federal Communications Commissioner. It contends the check was used to help buy Mr. Mack's vote in a 1957 Miami television case.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- A gift brought to this country by a Soviet scientist has enabled United States geologists to identify a mineral found in Wyoming, the Government disclosed today.

The short interest on the American Stock Exchange stood at a record 1,382,137 shares last Wednesday, the Exchange reported yesterday. The latest total compares with 897,313 shares on March 13 and from 735,138 shares on April 15, 1958.

Many of the leading sports car drivers in the East are entered for the New England region. Sports Car Club of America, races at Lime Rock, Conn., on Sunday. The Briggs Cunningham team, headed by Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N. J., will compete in the feature race with Lister-Jaguars.
The State Department wants no part of the Soviet Army in the United States.

The city is going to refund at least $100,000 -- and possibly a good deal more -- to licensed electricians as the result of court decisions declaring illegal the $250 fee they have been paying for license renewals.
A peace-making committee appointed by Mayor Wagner will seek tomorrow to end the four-day-old strike of 3,000 United Parcel Service employes.

The New York State Power Authority passed the half-way mark in the permanent financing of the $720,000,000 Niagara Project yesterday. It sold $200,000,000 of long-term serial and term bonds at an interest cost of 4.206 per cent.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 21 (AP) -- One co - medalist was eliminated and the other forced to the nineteenth hole today as favorites generally survived the opening round of the North and South amateur golf tournament.
The American Machine and Foundry Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the quarter ended March 31 were the highest for any quarter in its history.
IN "Single Man at a Party," which opened at the Theatre Marque last evening, one of the characters feels uncomfortable when he sees things getting away from the conventional.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The NATO nations have met in Washington and have stated their position on the Berlin crisis. It is most surprising, however, to note how great was the influence of West Germany on the conference and the decisions arrived at. The more moderate and constructive suggestions of Mr. Macmillan were subordinated to those of von Brentano's.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -The Cuban Government is considering a law to require that 50 per cent of import cargo be carried in Cuban-flag ships.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., April 21 (AP) -- Two convicts escaped from San Quentin Prison today and held off pursuers for six hours from the end of a long fishing pier by threatening to kill a woman hostage.
Executives of United Press International told annual business meetings here yesterday the American public was showing growing interest in outer space and in Latin America.
PARIS, April 21 -- The program to unite Western Europe through economic communities will soon be subjected to an important test in the European Coal and Steel Community.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is negotiating with Sam Levenson to take over Arthur Godfrey's morning television program while Mr. Godfrey undergoes a medical examination.

The trend to higher short term interest rates was accentuated yesterday as the major sales finance companies raised the rates they would pay on their own commercial paper. The increases were 1/4 of 1 per cent on shorter term notes and 1/8 of 1 per cent on longer maturities.
Sales of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., for the twenty-six and fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 31 were the largest for such periods in the corporation's history.
Blood will be given to The Red Cross today at the Texas Company, 405 Lexington Avenue, and the Associated Hospital Service, 80 Lexington Avenue.

THE trend toward high style in moderately priced drapery fabrics is being furthered by the debut of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company's fabrics made of glass fibers. This concern asked four top fashion designers, Ceil Chapman, Vera Maxwell, Adele Simpson and Pauline Trigere, to select the drapery designs for its new collection.

An agency of the Republic of Italy is borrowing $50,000,000 in the United States. The financing includes $20,000,000 in bonds, on the market today, the first public offering of Italian debt in this country since the Nineteen Twenties.
DETROIT, April 21 -- The Chrysler Corporation's firstquarter sales and earnings topped those of any quarter in 1958, L. L. Colbert, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting today.

Stocks moved confusedly yesterday, rising by some market yardsticks, falling by others. More stocks showed losses than gains and only two of the major groups -- steels and industrial chemicals -- had more plus than minus signs.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -Senator Warren G. Magnuson denied today that the Senate Interstate and Foreign Committee was stalling on the nomination of Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -The Senate staged an extraordinary demonstration of bipartisan support for Christian A. Herter today by confirming him unanimously as Secretary of State in four hours and thirteen minutes.
Several men were questioned yesterday after police raids on three sites in Brooklyn and Manhattan in which 2,100 reels of pornographic motion pictures and 22,000 books were seized.
HARTFORD, April 21 (AP) -- A top insurance executive today became the first chancellor of the University of Hartford.
Sharply higher sugar futures and spot prices were the features of commodity activity in the New York market yesterday. Increased interest in actuals sent prices climbing.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 21 (AP) -- Top-seeded Luis Ayala of Chile arrived today after two sleepless nights and a 6,000-mile trip from Houston and won his first two singles matches in the British hard courts tennis championships.
GREAT NECK, L. I., April 21 -- Paintings valued at about $2,000,000 will be displayed at the North Shore Art Festival, which will open at the Ice Skating Rink here on May 2.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -Harry Bridges, West Coast longshoremen's leader, invoked the Fifth Amendment today "for the first time in my life."
The Diamond State Telephone Company yesterday raised $5,000,000 on thirty-five-year debentures at an increase cost of 4.66 per cent.
