The extraordinary doings in Panama resemble a Hollywood version of Latin-American activities far more than they do the general revolutionary wave that has been sweeping over the hemisphere since the Bolivian revolution of 1952. This effervescence in Panama does not have the basic characteristic of the serious drive for social justice which is the dominant feature of the Latin-American scene today.

PANAMA, April 21 -- The Panamanian Government announced last week that it feared an invasion. Special precautions were taken after a small band of rebels seized ammunition from a country store and fled to the hills.
Actors Equity last night entered the dispute over whether free Shakespeare in Central Park this summer is to be or not to be.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -Aurelio Fabiani, impresario, announced plans today for the "most ambitious opera season in Philadelphia since the Nineteen Twenties."

Amber Morn of the Cain Hoy Stable stayed on the inside almost all the way and this ground-saving tactic enabled him to take the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. The event, a mile-and-a-sixteenth test for 3-year-olds, attracted a field of a half-dozen.
If New Yorkers will persist in moving to the suburbs, the City Housing Authority will compromise: It proposes to bring the suburbs to them.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office reported today that the Air Force had used $242,890 in appropriated funds to build a golf course at the service's new academy, thereby violating an Air Force understanding with Congress.

LONDON, April 21 -- Britain's proposal for a zone in Central Europe where the arms and forces of East and West would be under inspection, control and eventually limitation has now been coupled with the larger plan for the reunification of Germany.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 21 -- Yale sent Columbia to its first defeat, 3 -- 2, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game today.

LONDON, April 21 (Reuters) -- Two major British insurance companies with important American interests announced plans today to merge and form a $770,000,000 colossus in what is said to be the biggest insurance deal ever recorded here.

A good deal of excitement -and trading -- has been stimulated in recent months by a rash of stock splits. Some of the biggest names in their respective fields have proposed or put through splits. The biggest, of course, was that of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
PANAMA, April 21 -- The Panamanian Government was reported tonight to have ordered the expulsion of Dame Margot Fonteyn, the British ballerina, for involvement in revolutionary activities.
A partial listing of reports made to the Securities and Exchange Commission by companies and persons involved and made available by the New York and American Stock Exchanges follows:
The question "Why is this night different from all other nights?" was asked in Jewish homes here and the world over at sundown yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- Defense attorneys served notice today that they intended to subpoena Sherman Adams, former principal Presidential assistant, and Gerald O. Morgan, White House counsel, to testify at the conspiracy trial of Richard A. Mack.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democat or Illinois, said today that the armed services were seeking to purchase 538,440 pounds of butter even though the Government had 17,000,000 pounds of surplus butter in storage.

DURING a recent television interview, a good-humored complaint was registered by Gabby Hartnett, the Hall of Fame catcher, to the effect that Rogers Hornsby received more fourth strikes than anyone else in baseball.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended, Wednesday, April 15:

LONDON, April 22 -- The differences among the occupying powers on the negotiation of new arrangements that would preserve their rights in West Berlin have narrowed in the last week, Allied diplomatic sources said today.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -Organized labor's demand for a Federal law liberalizing unemployment compensation benefits was rejected today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- A wave of selling reduced the price of May wheat by more than 2 cents today on the Board of Trade but short interests considered the setback a bargain. Their buying helped wipe out about half the loss.

Stocks thrashed about yesterday, falling in the morning, rising in the early afternoon and slumping at the close. They ended with a net loss for New York Stock Exchange market values of about $1,800,000,000.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- The Soviet Union has charged that plans by the United States to arm West Germany and other countries of the Atlantic alliance with atomic weapons were aimed at torpedoing the coming Big Four foreign ministers' conference in Geneva.

Never out of the money in nine previous starts, Miss Royal, a fast filly from New England, took the twelfth running of the $28,700 Prioress Stakes at Jamaica yesterday, beating eight other 3-year-old distaff racers.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Stockholders of the Inland Steel Company authorized today a three-for-one stock split and heard a warning from the company president that higher wages would open the door to foreign steel made by cheap labor.
Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger was honored yesterday on her retirement from the Cooperative Education Commission. The group cited her at a luncheon meeting at Washington Irving High School.

CHICAGO, April 22 (UPI) -Spider Webb, a highly regarded middleweight contender, blasted Neal Rivers with a steady twofisted barrage tonight before Referee Joey White stopped their scheduled ten-rounder after 2:49 of the fourth round.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -Christian A. Herter was sworn as Secretary of State today as President Eisenhower, at his side, assured him of his full confidence and support.

THE Bolshoi Ballet last night gave its second presentation of "Swan Lake" at the Metropolitan Opera House, and with a cast that was different virtually throughout. Since the first-night cast was also a brilliant one, it would be manifestly unfair to attribute the vastly superior results last night entirely to this cause.

LONDON, April 22 (Reuters) -- The Royal Dutch Petroleum and Shell Transport and Trading companies announced today that they have offered to buy the Canadian Eagle Oil Company, Ltd. Royal Dutch and Shell made a share exchange offer of more than u100,000,000 ($280,000,000) for all the assets and business of Canadian Eagle.
Plans for a seven-story addition to the Jesuit community's residence hall at Fordham University were announced yesterday by the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president and rector of the university.

The German-American League All-Stars, paced by Siegfried Gudzenties with three goals, blanked the Casual Touring Club of Port of Spain, Trinidad, 6 -- 0, in a socer match at Eintracht Oval, Astoria, Queens, last night.

THERE is much more to buying a fur than simply writing a check for it. A man with thirty-eight years of experience behind him, Leo Ritter of Ritter Brothers, believes that the selection of an appropriate fur and the fit and style are crucial considerations.

ROME, April 22 (Reuters) -A Vatican decree warning Roman Catholics against voting for political parties supporting the Communists was interpreted by a priest today as applying only to "free elections."

Three major stockholders of Bayuk Cigars, Inc., filed suit yesterday in Federal Court here to enjoin three officers of the corporation from using proxies at the annual meeting scheduled for May 6 in Philadelphia.

The Committee on Civil Rights in Manhattan has been celebrating its tenth anniversary -- and the celebration is well deserved, for the decade has been one of quiet, but effective, accomplishment. And this has been done by a handful of volunteers, with Mrs. Edna A. Merson as chairman, who have a mission and a boundless supply of energy.

W. SOMERSET MAUGHAM'S acrid, humorous worldliness lights the pages of his new book, "Points of View."* He says it is his last. We hope not. And we are glad to see, at a time when sudden change rampages almost everywhere, that these essays are, essentially, the Maughamian mixture as before.
Members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association received a report yesterday on the industry's new "total selling" advertising program.

New England's six railroads, which already have commissioned the Arthur D. Little Company of Cambridge, Mass., to conduct marketing and sales studies for them as part of broad corporate merger surveys, are planning to hire still another engineering concern, according to E. Spencer Miller, president of the Maine Central.

Seats for the theatre party at next Monday's performance of "A Majority of One" at the Shubert Theatre are still available. Tickets for the play starring Gertrude Berg and Sir Cedric Hardwicke may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe, 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.
The day of the small combination passenger-cargo ship has ended, the top executive of American Export Lines declared yesterday.
Dr. Donald M. Brown, a botanist, left yesterday for Kenya, where he expects to uncover some of the trade secrets of African witch doctors.
" Mrs. Dodge wanted to do something for dogs other than purebred, so she started St. Hubert's Giralda," said Edwin J. Sayres at this month's Twin Brooks Kennel Club show in West Orange.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named Gen. George H. Decker, now commanding United States forces in Korea, as Vice Chief of Staff of the Army today.
The primary purpose of this country's free press is to give complete information so the people can make their own decisions, the American Newspaper Publishers Association was told yesterday.

AN art exhibition and sale on a grand scale is being held in the Empire Room of the New Yorker Hotel through this week for the benefit of the Emergency Civil Liberties Committee. About 150 well-known national and international painters and sculptors are represented by an unusually diversified group of work, tempting alike to visitor and buyer.

Two big manufacturers of heavy equipment, half a world apart, have joined forces for a producing-distributing venture. They are the E. W. Bliss Company of Canton, Ohio, and Henschel-Werke, G.m.b.H., Kassel, West Germany. In Canton yesterday the two signed papers to form a new corporation, Bliss-Henschel, with Bliss holding a 75 per cent interest and Henschel 25 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -The Yankees, with Whitey Ford going all the way, brought down a stubborn band of Senators, 1 to 0, on a fourteenth-inning home run by Bill Skowron tonight.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 22 -The Communist press of Baghdad is waging a determined attack on the Iraqi Foreign Ministry, presumably as a prelude to demanding a frankly pro-Soviet foreign policy.
HENDERSON, N. C., April 22 (AP) -- A woman worker was wounded tonight as strikers gathered at the gates of the Harriet-Henderson cotton mill.

YONKERS, April 22 -- Those who follow the numbers system as they strive to "hit the double" at Yonkers Raceway fared all right tonight. The winning combination was 5-1, one of the season's better-regarded items. It returned $81.60.

The Texas Company reported yesterday record earnings for the three months ended on March 31. The consolidated net income was $91,220,181, or $1.56 a share, Augustus C. Long, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting. These results, the highest of all first quarters, were also the second highest of any quarter of the company's history, he said.

PANMA, April 22 -- Panama National Guard authorities tonight showed newsmen a considerable quantity of arms the officers said had been uncovered on the beach at Santa Clara where Dr. Roberto Arias is reported to have gone ashore Sunday night.

The flood of first-quarter earnings reports is rising rapidly and it promises to engulf any painful remaining memories of the recent business recession. Day after day, companies of all sizes and all types of activity are reporting good to striking profit gains.

Dame Margot Fonteyn arrived in New York yesterday after having been expelled from Panama. Weary but good-humored, the ballerina refused to discuss Panama, which accuses her husband of revolutionary activities.

DETROIT, April 22 (UPI) -Jim Piersall, Rocky Colavito and Gene Leek hit home runs today in leading the Cleveland Indians to their eighth victory in nine starts, a 10-1 decision over the Detroit Tigers.

LONDON, April 22 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan assured Labor party questioners today that atomic fuel manufactured by any private company in Britain would be made under government license and would remain government property.
MUSSOORIE, India, April 22 -- the Dalai Lama denied today Communist Chinese allegations that a statement issued in his name at Tezpur last Saturday was something less than genuine
Approval of the proposed merger of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and Guaranty Trust Company was announced late yesterday by G. Russell. Clark, State Banking Superintendent.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 22 -- The possibility of Communist domination in Iraq has put new life into the Baghdad Pact secretariat, now seated in Ankara.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The activities of a Secretary of State as the President's agent in the conduct of foreign policy, even when he enjoys the fullest measure of Presidential confidence and support, can be seriously hampered by an unfriendly Senate, or by a Senate which merely doesn't "cotton" to his personality.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The revolutionary regime of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba can limp along a few more months, but a day of decision is coming, several United States government economists said today. That day -- when Cuba's gold and dollar reserves reach the vanishing point -- will come in September or October, the economists said.

Sales and earnings of the Reynolds Metals Company declined in the first quarter of 1959 from the 1958 level, Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president, reported at the annual meeting in Richmond, Va., yesterday.

The special gifts committee of Cardinal Spellman's Committee of the Laity, reported yesterday that it had raised $621,545 thus far in the annual New York Catholic Charities appeal. This year's goal is $1,250,000 in special gifts.
ALBANY, April 22 -- Legislation extending the "freeze" on bank holding companies until Feb. 15, 1960, was approved today by Governor Rockefeller.

Futures and spot prices of sugar continued to climb in New York yesterday. The markets have been strong all week. The spot price of domestic sugar (for sale in this country) climbed 10 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) to 6.1 cents for a gain of 35 points this week.
THE "wickedest woman of the Twenties," who remembers Rudolph Valentino for the wonderful scent he used, is now in the perfume business herself.
ALBANY, April 22 -- The Public Service Commission gave the New York Central Railroad permission today to abandon all passenger service on its West Shore Line.
TRENTON, April 22 -- A special State Senate investigating committee was told today that every garbage contract in New Jersey had been "rigged."

The effectiveness of the Federal mandatory controls on imports of crude oil and products was demonstrated in the week ended last Friday when arrivals averaged only 1,114,600 barrels a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute. For the preceding week imports were 1,405,600 barrels a day and 2,285,700 a day in the week ended April 3.
WHITE PLAINS, April 22 -- Democratic leaders who protested last month when the City Council voted pay rises for itself and the Mayor are considering a civil action to upset the increases.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -The possibility of a collapse in the wheat price support program was foreseen today at a meeting of the Senate Agriculture Committee.
PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -Lew Burdette outpitched Robin Roberts tonight as the Milwaukee Braves downed the Phillies, 2 -- 0, and maintained their position at the head of the National League standings.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., April 22 -- A $3,000,000 program of public improvements is under way in this resort community. For the first time since 1929, major new construction is being carried out along the boardwalk.
Cotton futures moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices at the close were 9 points off to 26 points up from Tuesday's final levels.

Though a personal subscriber to The New York Times, I overlooked your editorial of April 2 entitled "Newfoundland's Dilemma." I prefer, however, to go along with you, sight unseen, rather than with A. Martin of the Bowater's Newfoundland Pulp and Paper Mills, Ltd., whose letter appeared in your April 11 issue.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -Secretary of State Herter has had ample warning at the very beginning of his administration of the dangers of clumsy or poorly planned public relations in the conduct of foreign policy.
A Boeing 707 jet airliner was damaged on a training flight last week when it touched down just short of the runway, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 22--The nation's highest advisory committee on radiation protection revised substantially downward today its estimates of the danger posed by radioactive strontium 90.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -Following is the text of amendments to the Kennedy-Ervin labor reform bill accepted by the Senate tonight with a tie vote broken by Vice President Richard M. Nixon:
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 22 -- This is an angry island.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 22 -- The Patriarch of Constantinople made it known today that the Eastern Orthodox Church would take part in the ecumenical council called by Pope John XXIII only if the entire Christian world was invited to send representatives.
Two auxiliary bishops of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn were consecrated yesterday during the celebration of a votive mass of the Holy Spirit.
HONG KONG, April 22 -Speakers in Communist China's National People's Congress assailed today India's actions in connection with the Tibetan revolt and the flight of the Dalai Lama from Lhasa.
A TEEN-AGER who has won national recognition for her work in the oil-coloring of photographs expressed enthusiasm recently over the importance of self-expression.

Milton Berle Novelist Today's most interesting bit of literary news belongs as much among the television notes as it does in the columns devoted to the doings of the book trade. For this is the day that "Earthquake," a novel jointly by Milton Berle and John Roeburt, is published.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Korea, Japan, Taiwan, the Philippines and Southeast Asia "are prizes coveted by the Sino-Soviet bloc," the commander of the Navy's Pacific Fleet told Congress today.

CLEVELAND, April 22 -- A courteous but inconclusive discussion of employment security for General Electric Company workers between Ralph J. Cordiner and James B. Carey occurred here today. Mr. Cordiner is chairman of the company, the nation's largest electrical manufacturer. Mr. Carey is president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, the electrical industry's biggest union.
Five transit unions agreed yesterday to a representation election among 31,000 hourly rated employes of the Transit Authority on or before June 15.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -The Soviet demand that the United States stop giving missile weapons to its allies is "hypocritical" and "propaganda," the State Department said today.
A revised master plan of arterial highways and major streets in lower Manhattan was brought out yesterday by the City Planning Commission. A public hearing on it was set for May 6.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 22 -- As a soft spring moon rose over Mount Zion tonight, the people of Israel gathered in their homes and settlements for the Seder, the joyous feast that marks the beginning of the Passover.

The agreement reached at City Hall on Tuesday night was a victory for reason and common sense over rigidity and economic force. To Mayor Wagner and Labor Commissioner Felix go the thanks of the people of New York for having averted, at least for two weeks, the calamity of a hospital strike. It was no easy task.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 22 -- Six thousand elementary and high school students in Union Free School District 3 "evacuated" twelve schools for their homes here this afternoon at 2 o'clock in a successful Civil Defense drill.
Carlos Victor Aramayo, a Bolivian millionaire, denied Tuesday any connection with a revolutionary uprising last Sunday in La Paz, the Bolivian capital.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., the chief American distributor of the Italian Fiat-Abarth, disclosed at a luncheon in the Friars Club yesterday that his "Team Roosevelt" would compete in all Sports Car Club of America national races this year.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, warned the Senate today that it might deny future ambassadorships to past politicians if it rejected the nomination of Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut because of partisan Republican statements she once made.
ALBANY, April 22 -- An emergency program to prop up the state's crumbling commuter transportation system was signed into law by Governor Rockefeller today.
The effective removal of small particles from industrial wastes appeared yesterday to be the newest concern of air pollution experts.

The story of Dunkirk, the most dramatic military withdrawal in modern history and a turning point of World War II, is told by David Divine in "The Nine Days of Dunkirk." The account is based on material from many sources, enemy and Allied, official and personal.

ROME, April 22 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth and Princess Margaret of Britain had an audience this morning with Pope John XXIII. The Pontiff received his visitors in his private library, and chatted with them alone in French for twenty minutes.
CONCORD, Mass., April 22 -A special riot squad of the Massachusetts State Police tonight put down a mass attempt at escape from the Concord State Reformatory.

Harry Horwitz, realty operator, who recently bought the ten-story loft building at 733-35 Broadway, near Eighth Street, has resold it to a syndicate of investors. Albert Friedlander was the broker. The building is 54 by 100 feet and is occupied largely by hat manufacturers. E. Louis Gothelf was the attorney for the seller.
Russell Brown's letter, published April 15, defending the new restrictions on oil imports, deserves a critical appraisal.
A garden filled with daffodils is drawing an admiring audience to a brownstone church at the corner of Madison Avenue and East Thirtyfifth Street.
Prominent Republicans in Essex County, N. J., moved yesterday to heal the breach in their ranks that has cost the party severe losses over the last six years.
PINEHURST, N. C., April 22 (AP) -- The defending champion, Dick Chapman, Bill Hyndman 3d, Dale Morey and Peter Green were victims in today's two rounds in the North and South amateur golf tournament.

BUENOS AIRES, April 22 -- President Arturo Frondizi is reported to be under mounting pressure from his military secretaries to make major changes in his official family and clarify Government policies.

BERLIN, April 22 -- Walter Ulbricht listed today the cessation of nuclear tests, the discontinuance of the atomic armament of West Germany and the conclusion of a non-aggression pact between the North Atlantic alliance and the War
PITTSBURGH, April 22 (UPI) -- Rccky Nelson's single to right in the ninth inning tonight scored Bill Virdon and enabled the Pittsburgh Pirates to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 9 -- 8.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- William Buffalino, teamster official, asked the Senate today to expel rackets committee members who accused him of an alliance with racketeers.
MONTREAL, April 22 -- An elderly Canadian freighter will be the first commercial ship in the St. Lawrence Seaway, which begins its official functions on Saturday.
A panel of its own choosing told the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday that the churches had a major responsibility to work for better housing in the city.
Before sailing aboard the Queen Mary for London yesterday, Noel Coward verified a rumor that he had completed a new play.
ALBANY, April 22 -- Governor Rockefeller vetoed a bill that would have permitted teachers to use "reasonable force" on their pupils when they thought it was necessary "to restrain or correct" them.
JERSEY CITY, April 22 -A plan to merge all Lutheran Church organizations in the United States and Canada has been extended to include Alaska and Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- A group of pilots warned Congress today that foreign airlines were threatening to overtake United States supremacy in international air travel. They accused the Eisenhower Administration of being unconcerned.

WEST KILL, N. Y., April 22 -- April is about as cranky as usual in this part of the Catskills, which means that nobody can clock the trout fishing from one day to the next. It is mild today and everything looks fine, but that is not the whole story.

NEARLY two years have gone into the preparations for the Gauguin exhibition that opens to the public today at the Metropolitan Museum and the time spent has been more than justified. For the big show, including seventy-four oil paintings, forty-four water-colors and drawings, seventy-four prints and eleven pieces of sculpture, covers the full range of the artist's work and is one of the most engaging events the Metropolitan has staged.
Two new moves were announced yesterday in efforts to avert a printers' strike against ten New York newspapers.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit in Cook County Circuit Court today to end what it called the "massive" and unauthorized censorship of foreign mail arriving in this country.
BOSTON, April 22 -- The Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination will investigate charges that the Boston Red Sox are biased in the hiring of players and other personnel.
Officers of the Westchester Country Club were named in a $2,600,000 damage suit filed yesterday in New York Supreme Court.
A COMPASSIONATE and realistic drama about men confined to a tuberculosis sanitarium was presented last night on "The United States Steel Hour" over Channel 2.
A training class for volunteers to aid the American Red Cross blood program will begin at the New York Chapter House, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, on May 5.

Mrs. Otto Crouse of 120 East Eightieth Street, chairman of the dinner dance at the Plaza on May 5 for the benefit of the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement, will be hostess tomorrow at a meeting of the benefit committee.
The Board of Estimate decided yesterday to grant the city's 38,000 uniformed policemen, firemen and correction officers pay rises of $300 a year, to be made effective in two steps.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 22 -- At the end of two races in moderate to fresh winds on Great Sound today, the International One - Design Class teams of Long Island Sound and the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club remained tied in their Race Week competition for the Amorita Cup.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- A new baby boom apparently is under way. Marriages are on the increase, too.
Arthur D. Little, Inc., research, engineering and management consultant, leased a floor in the new building at 529 Fifth Avenue, corner of Fortyfourth Street.
ATLANTA, April 22 -- Statesupported colleges and universities removed their ban today to applicants over 21 years old, but under stringent regulations aimed at preventing the enrollment of Negroes.

Roosevelt Raceway has brought suit in State Supreme Court to upset a 1957 tax ruling of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. If the suit is successful the state may find itself, in effect, paying $40,000,000 in Federal income taxes for Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways over the next ten years or so.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- Gordon Scott, the eleventh in line of Tarzans, arrived here today from Africa with a touch of bronchitis and news that "they have changed the whole concept of Tarzan."

Unionized hospital workers face one of the most embarrassing decisions any union ever has been called on to make -- the possibility that they will have to strike to win the right to negotiate a contract in which they permanently foreswear the right to strike.
Robert Moses is apparently operating under a strange illusion. He acts as if his patronym made him a supreme lawgiver.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) Governor John Patterson of Alabama said today race relations in his state "have deteriorated to a sad state" as a result of Federal interference.
Mayor Wagner carried the defense of his administration's fiscal policies to the lower East Side yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- Free elections in Cuba now would risk the return of "oligarchy and tyranny," Premier Fidel Castro said today.
ALBANY, April 22 -- Governor Rockefeller issued a public warning tonight that there was no room in his Administration for officials who could not live up to the state's code of ethics.
Deficit spending by the Federal Government and wage demands by unions are the basic causes of inflation, the chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation suggested yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -The Daughters of the American Revolution voted opposition today to cultural interchange programs with the Communist bloc. There were thirteen dissents.

RICHMOND, Va., April 22 (UPI) -- A former member of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that three air traffic controllers on duty when an airline collided with a military jet almost a year ago had been unable to return to duty.

NEW DELHI, India, April 22 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today that Communist China's reply to India's representation about the circulation of maps by Peiping showing large parts of India as belonging to China "was not very adequate."
LONDON, April 22 -- Industrial price movements were small and irregular in the stock market here today.

Lee Petty, the 45-year-old winner of the 500-mile stock car race at Daytona Beach, Fla., in February, is one of the big business men who will help open the racing at the Polo Grounds next Saturday night.

Columbia University's Bancroft Prizes for 1959 were awarded last night to Dr. Daniel J. Boorstin for "The Americans: The Colonial Experience" and to Dr. Ernest Samuels for "Henry Adams: The Middle Years."

THE word-of-mouth report that someone a little out of the ordinary in the tenor line is about to turn up is usually sufficient to draw a crowd. Last night the crowd gathered at Carnegie Hall, where the tenor Giovanni Consiglio was making his recital debut.

Willi E. Huber, chief of the passenger department of the German Federal Railroad, advised Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey commuters yesterday that their problems and those of their commuter railroads were world-wide.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower became an alumnus of a nonexistent college today. He com-commented that it was a unique occasion.
The bond market made its first impressive stand in weeks yesterday.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 22 (UPI) -- Two South Africans scored upsets in the British hardcourt tennis championships today, eliminating Ulf Schmidt of Sweden and Mike Davies, Britain's No. 1 player.

BONN, Germany, April 22 -Herbert Blankenhorn, West Germany's Ambassador to France, was convicted today of premeditated slander and of having falsely accused a civil service colleague of having accepted bribes. He was sentenced to four months' imprisonment.

STRASBOURG, France, April 22 (Reuters) -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister of the Economy, urged the seventeen members of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation today to create a European free-trade area without delay.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -Average consumer prices held steady again in March, the Labor Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association has asked the Federal Communications Commission to reduce the rates for private-line teletypewriter service.

Kidder, Peabody Co. and associates are offering 40,000 shares of the Brockton Edison Company $50 par preferred stock today. The stock has a dividend of $2.80, and is priced at 51 3/8 to yield 5.45 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -Western delegates to the International Chamber of Commerce meeting pressed today for the adoption of an international code of "fair treatment" for private capital investment.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 22 -- After studying South Africa's tangled race problems for six weeks, Hodding Carter said tonight, "I have never been so confused in my life."

Portions of the steel skeleton that will support the new forty-one-story building of the First National City Bank of New York have emerged above street level at Park Avenue between Fifty-third and Fiftyfourth Streets.

Michael P. Grace, who sponsored outdoor musicals in Central Park two years ago, proposed yesterday that no stage two weeks of jazz concerts in the park this summer to help to finance the New York Shakespeare Festival.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -President Eisenhower announced tonight his intention of nominating former Representative Brooks Hays of Arkansas to be a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority. He would succeed Dr. Frank J. Welch, dean of the College of Agriculture of the University of Kentucky, who has resigned.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 22, (UPI) -- President Francois Duvalier announced a new Cabinet today.

CLEVELAND, April 22 (AP) -- C. M. White, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, reported today that the company's profit for the first quarter had tripled that in the first three months of last year.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -For more than three decades Dr. Lauriston Sale Taylor has acted as the nation's principal protector and selfordained gadfly against the dangers of radiation.
Justice Saul Streit of the New York Supreme Court yesterday floored Sugar Ray Robinson, something few of his ring rivals accomplished.

NEW DELHI, India, April 22 -- Defense Minister V. K. Krishna Menon declared in a speech to an agitated Parliament today that India would try to force down any Pakistani military aircraft that violated her airspace.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- The Air Force said today that this country's "man-in-space" program was delayed for months by moves transferring the work from one agency to another.

WASHINGTON April 22 (UPI) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers said today two recent Government setbacks in the courts on civil rights issues might improve chances for Congressional approval of the Administration's proposals to strengthen laws in the field.
A new political leadership for a South that is becoming industrially developed and urban will come in time, Ralph McGill, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, predicted yesterday.
The speedy and "harmonious" relocation of 1,824 families to make way for the vast George Washington Bridge improvement was all but complete yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 22 (UPI) -- Alex Grammas hit his first home run since the 1955 season and drove in three more runs on sacrifices today to pace the St. Louis Cardinals to an 8-2 rout of the Chicago Cubs.
The Fire Department yesterday ordered Bergdorf Goodman, the woman's specialty store, to make certain repairs during the night or be closed this morning as a fire hazard.
Three new films open at firstrun theatres today.

PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP) -- George M. Humphrey, former Secretary of the Treasury and now chairman of National Steel Corporation, said today he hoped the Federal Government would not intervene in the steel industry's labor negotiations scheduled to begin May 5 in New York.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower and G. O. P. Congressional leaders agreed today that the highway construction program would be in grave danger if the Democratic Congress refused to increase the Federal tax on gasoline.

Governor Rockefeller's television address last night, third and last in a series commenting on the accomplishments of the legislative session, is interesting both for its choice of emphasis on features of his program enacted and for the preview given of administrative work ahead.
LONDON, April 22 (Reuters) -- Following in official translation, is the text of the Soviet note to the United States on West Germany as issued tonight by Tass:
The State of Oregon borrowed $33,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the payment of benefits to war veterans.

August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Bank Trust Company, asserted yesterday that mutual savings banks should continue to be taxed on an equal basis with common trust funds, credit unions, trusteed pension funds and mutual investment funds.

THERE was a time not long ago when fresh, tender-kerneled corn on the cob was an April oddity on the New York market. It was as alien to the season as January watermelon or oysters in July. Today, however, with notably efficient methods of harvesting and handling the crop, the local public can gourmandize to its heart's content on fresh sweet corn from the South.
An ambitious hour-long television series of forty shows is looking for a favorable network time period.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -The Senate wrote a strong "bill of rights" for union members into the Kennedy-Ervin labor reform bill tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A witness who had his passport seized by the State Department and had been deported from Canada on political behavior grounds was found today to have a new passport ready for use.
There is a marked difference between neo-Freudianism and anti-Freudianism, a prominent psychoanalyst and neo-Freudian said here last night.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The State Department prefers to list Christian A. Herter as the fifty-fourth Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Vice President Nixon is not yet waking up nights brooding over the 1960 Presidential election, but he concedes that during his waking hours he does occasionally give the subject a fleeting thought.
BY loyally working together, a regiment of dedicated show people have, indeed, made a Western out of "Destry Rides Again," which opened at the Imperial last evening.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved a bill today that would provide Defense Department assistance to the Boy Scouts of America attending the World Jamboree of Scouting in the Philippines this summer.

The April 9 issue of The Times carried a front-page story with the headlines: "Soviet Won't Top U. S. 1970 Output, C. I. A. Chief Says"; "Allen Dulles Discounts Idea Russians Will Pull Ahead in Total Production."

ALTHOUGH the de luxe illustrated book is usually associated with Europe, there have been a few excellent books published in the United States, as the exhibition at the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue, demonstrates.
PARIS, April 23 -- France has become the first nation in westtern continental Europe to produce electricity generated by nuclear power for commercial purposes.

Partly through reallocation of funds, partly through a convenient upward revision of expected revenue, the Wagner administration suddenly finds that it can improve somewhat on the salary increases for schoolteachers, policemen, firemen and correction officers.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "The Triumph of St. Joan" and "The Medium," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Amato Opera Company, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15.
ALBANY, April 23 -- Legislation setting up a licensing system for pilots who guide domestic and foreign vessels up the Hudson River was approved today by Governor Rockefeller.

NEWPORT, R. I., April 23 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Lloyd Mustin, commander of Destroyer Flotilla 2, said today that the Navy had developed advanced sonar equipment that strips a submarine of its best barrier against detection.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 23 (AP) -- The University of Notre Dame announced today that government officials, churchmen 'and educators from southern and border states would participate May 8-9 in a symposium on i"The Pr'oblems and Responsibill ities of School Desegregation."

LOS ANGELES, April 23 -- Cargo handling at Los Angeles-Long Beach harbors halted today while Harry Bridges tried to avert a threatened revolt by longshoremen against his conduct as president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated.
The Clarence Derwent Awards for best supporting performances by a nonfeatured actress and actor during the current season have been won by Lois Nettleton and David Hurst.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Leopold Stokowski canceled today a date to conduct the New York City Opera in a twin bill at the Academy of Music here on Sept. 29.
Measures designed to curb the practices of independent investment advisory services will be submitted to the Legislature at Albany next year, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Granny Hamner and Gene Freese of the Phillies erased a victory the Braves had mentally chalked on their record tonight.
AN American woman here has merged her homemaker talents with the expert craftsmanship of three Spanish cabinetmakers. The result may be a flow of fine old Spanish furniture to American markets.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly, to close 13 points lower to 23 points higher. (A point equals 5 cents a bale).

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Witnesses gave little help today to the House Un-American Activities Committee in its search for the reason behind a rash of passport applications by persons it suspects to be Communists.

PARIS, April 23 -- The Bank of France lowered its discount rate today for the third time in six months. It was evidence of the Government's conviction that inflation no longer threatened and that the need now was for expansion of business.
CHICAGO, April 23 (UPI) -- A driving ambition can push a young man right into a heart attack, a physician warned today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Maj. Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, commander of the Air Force Ballistic Missile Division, called today for a major reorganization of the space program with abolishment of the Advanced Research Projects Agency in the Defense Department.
Three women of the Middle East watched several women of New York lighten the load of school teachers and brighten the lives of school children at Public School 129 yesterday.
A reported plot to assassinate Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba led yesterday to the assignment of the biggest security guard ever given a visitor to New York.

HAVANA, April 22 -- A growing number of persons here see a Communist pattern in the development of the revolutionary program under Premier Fidel Castro and fear that Communist influence is rising throughout the island.
NEWARK, April 23 -- A professor at Rutgers University's Newark College of Arts and Sciences has received $336,000 in grants for psychobiological studies in behavior.

The National Association of Investment Companies has issued a sort of "Who, me?" answer to recent charges that such companies have grown so large, in the aggregate, as to control the nation's securities markets.

Bond prices moved narrowly yesterday in the wake of Wednesday's rally, and closed the day at slightly lower levels. The volume of exchanges was moderately large because of continued bargain hunting by institutional investors.
The New York Blue Cross is seeking increases averaging 34.2 per cent in the premiums paid by its subscribers.

BEFORE the Batista regime was overthrown in Cuba, a gay, fun-loving man who operated from a two-room office in Havana gathered almost $1,000,000 from business associates to support the revolution led by Fidel Castro.

Many tickets have been sold for the theatre party at the May 4 performance of "Destry Rides Again" at the Imperial Theatre that will benefit the American Women's Voluntary Services. Some seats still remain and may be obtained through Miss Jessie Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.

Stirred by the impact of "Death of A Man," Lael Tucker Wertenbaker's short book of 181 pages, Garson Kanin has agreed to dramatize Mrs. Wertenbaker's tribute to her husband, Charles C. Wertenbaker. Mr. Kanin's acceptance means he is to stage the work, too.
It is a short step from a deprived child to a "depraved" child, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Administration has decided on a number of top-level shifts in the State Department as a consequence of the appointment of Christian A. Herter to succeed John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State.

Take Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey, and throw in Buffalo Bill and Clyde Beatty's circus, and you'd have a carnival under one big top comparable to the Penn Relays. It's stupendous, colossal, the summit.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 633,546 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) -- Twenty-five Congressmen joined in resolutions today urging a strengthening of the United Nations Charter "as a positive step toward world law."

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution reaffirmed today last year's resolution that the United States should withdraw from the United Nations and that the United Nations should withdraw from American soil.

FANCIERS of canned salmon are in for some bad news. This year's pack will be just about half the size of last year's 4,500,000 cases. (A case contains forty-eight half-pound cans.) Inevitably that means higher prices.
The solution of a problem that has perplexed mathematicians for more than fifty years was reported at a meeting here yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., April 23 (AP) -- Three men were killed today as explosions wrecked the block-long production and storage plant of the Thompson-Hayward Chemical Company.
The politicians at Columbia College are having their troubles. The student governing body has been burning the midnight oil this week, and not over studies.
Some multi - million - dollar questions are expected to be answered today when O. Roy Chalk enlarges on his proposal to negotiate for the purchase of all city-owned transportation.
A bronze woman balancing an equally solid house of cards is a newcomer to the company of stone and metal figures in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art.
The Greater New York Committee Opposed to Fluoridation yesterday challenged as "misleading" a report last week by the State Health Commissioner favoring fluoridation of the city's water system.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 23 -- The Legislature voted today the end of primary cross-filing, long a confusing feature of California politics.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP)-- A Department of Agriculture report on the volume of grains stored in Government loans under the price-support program had a bearish effect on corn futures today in dealings on the Board of Trade.

YONKERS, April 23 -- Harness racing drivers, like ballplayers, are subject to slumps. And the similarity doesn't end there. The unhappy sulky pilots who have misplaced the winning touch cannot pinpoint the reason, either.
LONDON, April 23 -- "The Pleasure of His Company," a Broadway hit, opened at the Haymarket Theatre tonight.
A spokesman for the New York Teachers Guild warned yesterday of the possibility of a new call for a work stoppage by teachers.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower addressed two business groups today on two of his favorite topics -- balancing the budget and expanding world trade. He assigned projects to both groups.
TRENTON, N. J., April 23 -- Sharp criticism of New Jersey's child-welfare program by a national leader in the field was answered today by the State Board of Child Welfare.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 23 (AP) -- Mike Souchak carded a six-under-par 66 today to take a firm lead in the first round of the $46,620 Tournament of Champions.

SIR JOHN GIELGUD, in his dramatic debut in American television, contributed last night a brilliant interpretation of the ailing school teacher in Terence Rattigan's dark and uneven drama, "The Browning Version." The play was seen on the "Du Pont Show of the Month" over Channel 2.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- For the second time in three years The Goshen (Ind.) News won today the F. Wayland Ayer Cup for excellence in typography, make-up and printing.

The spring turns a good many things topsy-turvy, not the least being sleep. At all other seasons there is a fixed routine about sleep. It takes place at night, eight or nine hours, save for that occasional Saturday which builds up dark Sunday regrets.

A 9-month-old girl was killed yesterday when an automobile veered out of control in Brooklyn and mounted a sidewalk.
Bear, Stearns Co. and associates today are offering 500,000 shares of common stock of Bargain City, U. S. A., Inc., at $9 a share.

DOVER, Del., April 23 (AP) -- General Dynamics Corporation, whose products range from jet bombers and guided missiles to atomic submarines, looks for higher earnings in the 1960's, stockholders were told today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 23 (AP) -- Studebaker-Packard Corporation today reported ffirst-quarter profits of $7,754,991, highest since Studebaker and Packard merged in 1954.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- (UP) -- The chairman of a special Presidential study committee told Congres stoday it would be disastrous if any big cuts were made in foreign aid while the Communists were stepping up their economic offensive.

LONDON, April 23 -- Earl Mountbatten of Burma said today that the introduction of nuclear propulsion for submarines was the greatest single naval development in his four years as First Sea Lord and Chief of Naval Staff.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower visited John Foster Dulles today and handed him an official commission as Special Consultant to the President.

A publishers committee charged yesterday that unions "increasingly curb production" on newspapers. It expressed concern that strikes in the industry this year might match the worst record of this century.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Presidential politics that always simmers these days beneath the surface of the Senate has erupted in the fight over labor legislation. It has seared four potential candidates.
WHITE PLAINS, April 23 -- Four thousand persons attended the fourth annual Westchester Science Fair in the first six hours of its two-day show at the County Center today.
ON the surface, the family in "A Corner of the Garden" on Channel 2 last night was well adjusted and happy.

Sam Levenson has reached agreement with the Columbia Broadcasting System to star in a new daytime television show as a substitute for "Arthur Godfrey Time." The Levenson show, which begins Wednesday, will be presented from 10:30 to 11 A. M., Mondays through Fridays.
Long Island University remained undefeated yesterday as it checked New York University, 13 -- 9, at Ohio Field to score its ninth baseball victory. Bob Figliozzi pitched his fourth triumph.

The Union Carbide Corporation cleared $41,581,459, or $1.38 a share, in the first three months of this year, setting a record for any quarter in its history. In announcing the results to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday, Morse G. Dial, chairman and chief executive officer, also noted that first-quarter sales were exceeded only by those in the final quarter of 1958.
Attorneys for Alexander L. Guterma filed a motion yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, seeking to have the 43-year-old financier's fraud trial transferred to Buffalo.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Ezra Taft Benson brushed aside today Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's plan to use surplus farm products in a "food for peace" program.
Mayor Wagner's administration was attacked last night as inefficient and ineffective by Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino, Republican of Long Beach, L. I.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter had a luncheon conference in his office today with Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations. It was Mr. Herter's first major diplomatic contact since he was sworn in as Secretary yesterday.

World sugar futures fell sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, about wiping out the sizable gains registered during the first three days of the week. The active position registered the greatest declines.
Dr. Rufo Lopez Fresquet, Minister of the Treasury in the new Castro Government, predicted yesterday that 1959 would be the most prosperous year in Cuba's history.

NEW DELHI, India, April 23 (Reuters) -- Prince Peter of Greece was asked by the Indian Government to leave India because some of his activities were not considered desirable by the Government, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru revealed today.

MARRIAGES, for better or worse, are chancy and unpredictable. In 1851 it would have been hard to find a more conventional young couple than Robert Pearsall Smith and his bride Hannah. Birthright Quakers both of them, they were conforming to an old American tradition -- for Robert had married his boss' daughter.
The Rockfeller Foundation announced yesterday that in the first quarter of 1959 it had made grants totaling $2,296,466 in the fields of health, agriculture, social sciences and the humanities.
ROSCOE, N. Y., April 23 -- It seemed that a man ought to have been able to do business on the East Branch of the Delaware today; but if a man did, he kept it quiet.

ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) -- The title fight between the world welterweight champion, Don Jordan of Los Angeles, and a former champion, Virgil Akins of St. Louis, will take place in Kiel Auditorium tomorrow night.
ALGIERS, April 23 -- Two French Army jeeps were blown up today by rebel land mines immediately before and during a gala parade before three generals, a prince and a princess.
DETROIT, April 23 -- American Motors Corporation voted a 60-cent quarterly dividend today, its first cash payment since 1954.
Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy declared last night that the United States had defense forces stronger than the Soviet Union and that these were fully adequate to deter a general war.

"John Paul Jones," a historical drama in color independently produced in Europe by Samuel Bronston, will have its world premiere on June 16 at the Rivoli Theatre. The United States Gypsum Company is planning to acquire the assets of the American Rock Wool Corporation through an exchange of stock. The proposal is subject to approval of stock-holders of American Rock Wool at a special meeting scheduled for May 26.
RICHMOND, Va., April 23 -- The Virginia Senate, by a 21 to 18 vote, passed a delayed-action integration bill today permitting local school boards to make pupil placements.
CHICAGO, April 23 -- The Methodist Church's Board of Social and Economic Relations adopted today a resolution calling on Christians to take a position on labor-union corruption.

BONN, Germany, April 23 -- A Social Democratic deputy said today he would raise a parliamentary inquiry about the sale in West Germany of a United States-made recording of the history of Nazism in speeches and songs.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 23 (AP) -- Janet Hopps of Seattle, a member of the United States Wightman Cup tennis team, gained the semi-finals of the British hardcourt tennis championships today. She defeated Pat Ward of England, 7 -- 5, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 23 (UPI) -- Attendance and betting at South Florida's three horse tracks dropped slightly during the past season despite a near-record tourist season.

The Ashland Garage at 178 to 194 Ashland Place and 98 De Kalb Avenue in Brooklyn has been leased by the Twin City Realty Corporation to the Ashland Parking Corporation, which will operate it as a parking garage.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The management of Bayuk Cigars, Inc., asserted today that the company already had enough proxies to defeat an insurgent group of shareholders at the annual meeting here on May 6.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The chairman of President Eisenhower's Council of Economic Advisers today laid the major blame for the most recent period of inflation on excessive wage increases.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 23 -- The Nationalist regime here has tightened its control over "job reservation," the system of specifying what jobs are open to people of different races.
TOKYO, April 23 (AP) -- The case of the United States Air Force colonel charged with bumping from a plane seven servicemen on emergency leave was officially closed today.
LONDON, April 23 -- The Government announced today a five-year plan of financial assistance to Britain's hard-pressed cotton textile industry.

In a move designed to bring the best thoroughbreds to New York for the 215-day season in progress, the New York Racing Association announced yesterday a program of eighty-nine stakes carrying a total of $3,760,000 in added money value.
ATLANTA, April 23 -- Southern Presbyterian leaders began marshaling forces here today to cope with a form of ecclesiastical secession.
The Harris County, Tex., Ship Channel Navigation District borrowed $12,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the expansion of facilities for the handling of bulk cargoes.

LONDON, April 23 -- Stock market interest remained centered on oils with a one-for-one bonus issue by Burmah following yesterday's announcement of the Shell-Royal Dutch bid for full ownership of Canadian Eagle Oil.

In its first official statement under Secretary Herter, the State Department has promptly and properly denounced as hypocritical propaganda the latest Soviet note on East-West talks.
