VALLEY STREAM, L. I., April 23 -- An $800,000 indoor-outdoor swimming pool area is being built for the residents of this South Shore community.
CAIRO, April 23 (AP) -- The first Arab petroleum congress ended today on a note of moderation.
MADISON, N. J., April 23 -- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, tonight called for an overhaul of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today the nomination of Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer to be Army Chief of Staff. It acted after the general had supported the National Guard and Army Reserves.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., had the highest sales in its history in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, Bruce A. Gimbel, president, reported in the annual statement issued for publication today. Earnings were slightly higher than those the year before.
The five-story building containing ten apartments at 113 Washington Place near Sheridan Square has been sold by the 113 Washington Place Corporation to an investor.

An increase of 4 per cent in construction costs for the country as a whole by April, 1960, was predicted yesterday by Myron L. Matthews, manager-editor of the Dow Building Cost Calculator, a service of the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson said today that the Soviet Union had charted the Pacific Coast of the United States "right up to the coastline" in an apparent search for information that could be used in an underwater missile attack.

The United States sold $100,000,000 in gold to foreign countries in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The sales were the largest since the week ended Sept. 17, 1958.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 23 -- Officials of Montclair announced today that they had begun planning for an urban renewal program covering approximately 180 acres.

It is welcome news that the New York Blue Cross has added three leading labor union officials to its board of directors. The Associated Hospital Service, with some seven million subscribers, has become one of the institutions essential to the health and welfare of the people of this city -- one watched by them with deep concern.

DETROIT, April 23 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians, paced by Billy Martin's three-run homer walloped an ex-teammate, Ray Narleski, and the Detroit Tigers 10-4, today. It was Cleveland's ninth victory against one defeat.

The Fire Department closed the north building of Bergdorf Goodman yesterday because of fire hazard. The building was not allowed to reopen until 3:35 P.M. At that time Deputy Assistant Chief Thomas J. Hartnett ruled it reasonably safe for customer and employe occupancy.
The annual reception and luncheon of the New York Society of Kentucky Women will be held on Monday in the Crystal and Carnival Rooms of the Sherry Netherland.

The relation of Passover, known also as "the Festival of Freedom" and the "Feast of Unleavened Bread," to the present-day struggle for freedom was noted yesterday in synagogue services on the first day of Passover.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 3 -- The only contest of Bermuda's fourth day of Race Week was held this morning and it dropped the Long Island Sound team of International One-Design Class sailors behind the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club in the standings for the Amorita Cup.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Foreign business men made an open showing today of their apprehensions that the current trend of United States foreign trade policy was protectionist.
Grant's Tomb, which last year attracted almost 300,000 visitors, will become a national shrine next Friday.

THE things that went on at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, when the Bolshoi Ballet gave the first of its "Highlights" programs, cannot possibly be believed without being seen, and not very easily even then.

Lehman Brothers, the big Wall Street banking firm, has offered to buy the Railway Express Agency from its sixty-six railroad owners. Frank Manheim, a partner in Lehman (there are twenty partners), said last night his concern made a firm offer to directors of the agency about three weeks ago.
PARIS, April 23 -- President Charles de Gaulle made his weight felt today in the august French Academy, preventing an election and a possible political explosion.
PARIS, April 23 -- Andorra, the minuscule autonomous Pyreneean republic, renewed today its pledge of fidelity to France and made its biennial rent payment on one of the biggest bargains in the world.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- A noncontributory player benefit plan was adopted by the National Football League today.

TOKYO, Friday, April 24 -- Early returns indicate that Premier Nobusuke Kishi's Liberal-Democratic party held its lead over the Socialist Opposition in yesterday's elections for prefectural (state) governors and assemblymen.

Eighty-three leaders of Protestant denominational organizations in the twentytwo-county metropolitan New York area 4-ill take part in an ecumenical conference today mud tomorrow to discuss practical ways of furthering church unity in this region.
LONDON, April 23 (Reuters) -- A heliport built by a British aviation company to publicize its product was opened today on a bank of the Thames River in central London.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce as Ambassador to Brazil by a vote of 16 to 1. The dissenting vote was cast by Senator Wayne L. Morse, Democrat of Oregon.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey outlined tonight a broad program of what he called new perspectives in foreign policy.
PANAMA, April 23 -- The Panamanian Government accused Dame Margot Fonteyn today of having knowledge of a plot to overthrow the regime.

LONDON, April 23 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tonight envisaged the coming summit conference as "the beginning of a period of negotiation" leading to better relations between the Communist bloc and the nations of the West.

CONAKRY, Guinea, April 23 -- Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana arrived in this capital today for a three-week state visit that is regarded here as a major step in the Pan-African movement. Dr. Nkrumah came by sea from his capital, Accra.

HONG KONG, April 23 -- A Lhasa dispatch broadcast by the Peiping radio tonight said Chinese troops had dispersed rebel forces over a wide area in southeast Tibet and had effectively sealed Tibet's Himalayan frontier.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 -- Tomy Lee beat down two strong rivals, one after the other, to take the $32,550 Blue Grass Stakes today. The performance turned in by the colt owned by Mr. and Mrs. Fred Turner Jr. was a thriller and the crowd of 10,099 applauded Tomy Lee warmly.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Federal Communications Commission proposed five major changes in its rules today aimed at giving local television stations more freedom from network control of the programs they can carry.
GENEVA, April 23 -- The United States urged the Soviet Union today to address itself to the key issues at the conference for banning tests of nuclear weapons.

The Shell Oil Company reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a consolidated net income of $34,466,922, or $1.14 a share. This was 13 per cent more than the $30,500,036, or $1.01 a share, cleared in the similar period of 1958.

An analysis of the Communist threat in terms of strategy and tactics is planned for May 27 publication by Harper. The volume will be titled "Protracted Conflict." Originated and developed by the Foreign Policy Research Institute at the University of Pennsylvania, the book has been written by Robert Straus-Hupe, William R. Kintner, James E. Dougherty and Alvin Cottrell.
William Kino Mackay, a Briton, yesterday sued three brokerage houses, a customers' man and the New York Stock Exchange for damages of $809,680.
ALBANY, April 23 -- A program to help localities combat the high cost of school construction was authorized today by Governor Rockefeller.

Following is the text of an address by Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy to the dinner of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night:
ALBANY, April 23 -- A bill extending residential rent control for two years and tightening some of the provisions of the law was signed today by Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Senate liberals sought a way today to strike out of the controversial labor reform bill the McClellan "bill of rights."

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has it in his power, by mere stroke of the pen, to make extra funds available for additional teachers' salary increases without using any of the unpopular taxes the city is authorized to impose and without reallocating money within the school budget, which is, after all only a euphemism for larger classes fewer new teachers and impairment of other essential services.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Showing surprising bounce for a club that had suffered a fourteen-inning, 1-0 defeat at the hands of Whitey Ford the night before, Cookie Lavagetto's Senators tripped the Yankees, 3 -- 2, in the series finale today.
MEXICO CITY, April 23 -- A privately owned mining railroad between Saltillo in the State of Coahuila and Zacatecas in the State of Zacatecas has been requisitioned by Presidential decree.
Foote, Cone Belding has been named as the agency for the canned meat line of Armour Co., with billings estimated at $3,500,000 a year, according to an informed source.

THIS soon in the season, Macy's already is shouting: "Last one in is a square!" On Monday Macy's - by - the - Sea departments will be inundated with swimsuits, shorts and play costumes that would make anybody but a wet blanket want to frolic in the surf and on the sand. The store's invitation to summer is particularly lively this year, for high colors brighten many fashions.
THE woman with the junior-size figure has a real ally in Saks Fifth Avenue. The store's new Safinia collection for summer includes among its pretty wares some genuinely sophisticated styles.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 23 (AP) -- A Thor intermediate-range ballistic missile hit the target today in a 1,500-mile test aimed at improving accuracy.
NEWARK, April 24 -- An Essex County grand jury has urged legislation to "reduce and eliminate monopolistic practices" in the bidding on garbage collection contracts.

The goings-on in the Senate during the last few days have shown that labor reform legislation is now subjected to stresses and strains that may completely break it down. Senator McClellan's amendment to the Kennedy bill has been a case in point. The bitter controversies it let loose have endangered the entire measure. And they have shown how urgently needed is a sense of proportion and accomodation.
An employe of the Manufacturers Trust Company for thirty-one years who had been suspended as an assistant branch manager was arrested yesterday on a charge of misappropriating $63,000.
The first large-scale purchase of turbine-powered air freighters was reported imminent yesterday.
PANAMA, April 24 -- Dr. Roberto Arias, who had been sought for a week by the Panamanian Government on charges of revolutionary activity, received asylum today in the Brazilian Embassy.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- Catnapping in a chair was said today to hold the possibility of death for elderly people afflicted with some type of heart trouble or arthritis of the neck.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 24 (AP) -- Christine Truman and Angela Mortimer today set up an all-English final in the women's singles of the British hard-courts tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter has asked the ranking members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to accompany him to Geneva for the foreign ministers' conference next month.

CLEVELAND, April 24 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians scored two unearned runs in the eighth tuning tonight and defeated the Chicago White Sox, 6-4, in the opening game of a four-game series at Municipal Stadium. The Indians stretchced their American League lead to three and a half games.

NEW ORLEANS, April 24 (AP) -- A fire in the engine room of a strikebound Canadian vessel, the Bestwood, was brought under control early today after it had caused damage estimated at a total of $50,000.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Honorary awards by Queen Elizabeth to six United States citizens for services in promoting British - American friendship and understanding were announced by the British Embassy today.
The city's prison population has reached a new high, the Department for Correction announced yesterday. It reported a total of 8,613 inmates, an increase of 881 over the same date last year.
Robert K. Christenberry, New York's acting Postmaster, reported yesterday that parcelpost shipments had risen 10 per cent since the start of the department-store delivery strike last Saturday.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- Montgomery Ward Co., mail-order house, got a new president today and lost a director, one who had often figured prominently in the news, by retirement.
The bond market, exhausted after a grueling fortnight of price declines, reached a virtual standstill yesterday. Little business was done.

PARIS, April 24 -- The Allied foreign ministers will be confronted by unresolved differences when they meet here next Wednesday to discuss strategy and tactics for the forthcoming talks with the Soviet Union at Geneva.
The Federal Reserve Board put the final stamp of approval yesterday on the merger of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., with the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Senate adjourned in an uproar tonight after a bipartisan group had offered a substitute "bill of rights" amendment to the labor-reform bill and asked for its immediate consideration.
ODDLY enough, American names sell British stockings. This has been the experience of Ann Ford, fashion director for Howard Ford Co., Ltd., one of Britain's leading hosiery manufacturers.

If I may correct the usually accurate New York Times, I would like to point out that a statement made in The Times of April 9 is not true. In a Canadian Press dispatch the statement occurs that the McIntosh apple "is the only apple in the world to have a monument erected in its honor."

Bond issues totaling $6,710,000 were sold by Michigan and Wisconsin universities yesterday to the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency because no other bidders were willing to lend the money at 2 7/8 per cent and 2 3/4 per cent.

LOUISVILLE, April 24 (UPI) -- Silver Spoon, the unbeaten filly that won the Santa Anita Derby, risks her perfect record and gets a chance to qualify for the Kentucky Derby in the $5,000 Stepping Stone purse at the opening of Churchill Downs tomorrow.
CHICAGO, April 24 (UPI) -- Three Little Rock, Ark., high schools, closed since last fall to preserve their all-white enrollment, dropped out of the accredited list today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Psychoanalysts were told today of apparently successful results from family group therapy in treating mental illness.
Those much-publicized warnings against speculation and ill-informed investment activity apparently have had little dampening effect on the stock market as a whole -- at least so far.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Booth Fisheries Corporation announced today it planned large-scale production by May 1 at the fish processing plant at Fortune Bay, Newfoundland, it has acquired from the provincial Government.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The American Philosophical Society was told today that many main conclusions of Charles Darwin had been amply confirmed by a century of exploration and discovery.

This is the spring, but it also is the house-cleaning, season. The spring is for poets, but what chance have poets during the cleaning? The poetry of spring speaks of the soft air, the swelling buds, the meadows turning from the brown of winter into limpid green.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Bernard A. Schriever today rated the United States and the Soviet Union "about even" in the race for space.

AMHERST, Mass., April 24 (AP) -- Tom Darling, a University of Pittsburgh senior, successfully defended his swinging rings title tonight while four new champions were crowned in the opening day of the national Amateur Athletic Union gymnastic championships for men. Darling ran up 9 points.
LONDON, April 24 -- Share prices continued to gain ground in the stock market today despite a slackening of demand.
EDGEWATER, N. J., April 24 -- With most shad still lurking in ocean waters waiting for warmer weather to temper the Hudson River, fishermen expect their best shad catches are yet to come.
ALBANY, April 24 -- Legislation increasing the number of district court justices in Nassau County from ten to sixteen was approved by Governor Rockefeller today.
A refuge in a Tibetan museum on Staten Island has been offered to the Dalai Lama, who has fled to India from Communist tyranny in his homeland.

FIFTEEN floors above Thirty-fifth Street is a narrow room rampant with danger. Anything that enters is likely to be scorched, frozen, dipped in acid, guillotined, electro cuted, ripped, pounded or rubbed to pieces.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., April 24 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that Gen. Earle Partridge, 58 years old, commander of the North American Air Defense Command, would retire July 31 after forty-one years in uniform. His headquarters are here.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, April 24 (AP) -- Ambassador John Hay Whitney of the United States struck back tonight at some acid British criticism of American trade policy. He said a lot of it had been "short-sighted and consequently unfair."

" RECIPES for making yeast breads at home usually direct that the dough, after kneading, be placed in a warm location and left to rise until double in bulk. But they give no indication of how long it will take for the dough to rise that much.
RIDGEWOOD, N. J., April 24 -- Edward Dana, general manager of the Metropolitan Transit Authority of Boston, tonight called for Federal help to maintain commuter railroads.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI) -- Three Democrats on the Senate Armed Services Committee criticized today President Eisenhower's policy of limiting the chiefs of the individual military services to two-year terms.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 24 (AP) -- Archbishop Joseph Groesz, acting head of the Roman Catholic Church of Hungary, took a Government-required oath of loyalty to the Communist Constitution today.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ALGIERS, April 24 -- Reports that President Charles de Gaulle had commuted the death sentences of thirty nationalists convicted as terrorists provoked a violent reaction here tonight among conservative European politicians.
LONDON, April 24 -- Dame Margot returned to London today.
Labor groups announced their opposition yesterday to the proposal of the New York Blue Cross to increase its rates by an average of 34.2 per cent.

ROME, April 24 (AP) -- Les Miserables, the novel Victor Hugo wrote a century ago, has been taken off the Roman Catholic Index of banned books and will be published in full with ecclesiastic authorization.

OMAHA, April 24 (AP) -- Two Omaha men and one Denver man have been notified that they were secretly indicted by a Federal grand jury here on twenty-one counts of stock swindle and using the mails to defraud.

Financial difficulties threaten to curtail the newly developed career of Boston's first repertory company. Officials of Boston Repertory, Inc., said yesterday that unless public subscriptions materialized the company would be unable to complete its planned sixteen-week season.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today that the first meeting of the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space would open here May 6.
A dentist whose gross annual business was $650,000 has filed a petition in Federal Court under the bankruptcy laws to settle $1,500,000 in debts.
DENVER, April 24 (AP) -- Playing the stock market is poor business "for the casual, the careless, the get-rich-quick devotees or people who can't afford the risks."

A letter published recently asks whether we are not encouraging new German aggression by "vowing to protect Germany" against the Soviets. The answer may be that up to the Molotov-Ribbentrop deal in 1939 Hitler was guilty of crimes mainly against his own people, who tolerated his regime and the Anschluss grabs.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad reported yesterday a net deficit of $2,457,793 for the three months ended on March 31. This represents some improvement over last year's figures which showed a net loss of $3,613,458.

IF books about America's duties in the world go on multiplying, what is going to happen? Well, in the first place, we'll soon be able to build out of them a staircase to the moon. This will save at least some of the rockets with which so many of these books are properly concerned. Others may attract materialists for use in constructing enormous bomb shelters against the death the books prophesy from the overcontinental sky.

A GROWN-UP industrial designer here makes a business of playing with doll-sized houses. He is Ray Barger, head of Model Producers, the shop responsible for making four of the twenty miniature model rooms designed by members of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Decorators.
ST. LOUIS, April 24 (UPI) -- Don Jordan shrugged off the best punches and bulling tactics of Virgil Akins tonight to gain a unanimous decision and retain the world welterweight boxing championship.
Bolivia has asked the Organization of American States to make an impartial investigation of the death of two rebel leaders during last Sunday's unsuccessful revolt in La Paz.

" Plain Talk From A Campus," by John .. Perkins, takes a look at the educational problems in this country. Mr. Perkins is president of the University of ]Delaware and formerly was lffnder Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
The capture of a bomb-carrier at last night's tumultous rally for Fidel Castro was the result of extraordinary police precautions.
At 2 A. M. tomorrow the city and much of the nation will move their clocks ahead one hour for daylight saving time.

WESTON, Conn., April 24 -- A proposed building code that would be administered by a building inspector was voted down at a town meeting last night. Opponents argued that there was not enough for a full-time inspector to do.

With ten prospective starters, the $28,900 Excelsior Handicap probably will have its final running at Jamaica today after a history going back to April 27, 1903, when it was the first stakes run at the then-new track.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 24 (AP) -- A brilliant half-mile anchor leg by Jamaican George Kerr today gave Illinois' sprint medley relay team an American collegiate record of 3 minutes 17.8 seconds.

Oils and aircrafts showed little enthusiasm but every other major group joined yesterday in a broad stock market advance. The aggregate market value on the New York Stock Exchange rose about $1,700,000,000.
TOKYO, April 24 -- Conservative forces retained their dominant hold on the Japanese electorate in nation-wide local elections yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, April 24 -- The twenty-seventh session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council came to a close here today.
The new capital market will be only moderately active next week as underwriters await anxiously announcement of the terms on the Treasury's next refunding.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 24 -- Liberty must be constantly fought for, Dr. John W. Gardner told more than 350 delegates to the spring conference of the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs at an all-day meeting in the Gramatan Hotel here today.
BONN, Germany, April 24 -- Two days ago a flight of planes bombed a sand bar in the North Sea west of Cuxhaven. The nationality of the bombers remained a mystery today.
IN the last few years, wash-and-wear clothes have been a mixed blessing. Many were sold without tags explaining how to wash and dry them. Many were sold with tags that women mislaid or misunderstood.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. has quit his New York law firm and is devoting full time to running his Fiat automobile distributorship for the southeastern United States.
NEW DELHI, India, April 24 -- The Indian Government moved today to ban dowries.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- John R. Dos Passos, novelist, essayist and poet, is co-inventor of a pistol that blows soap bubbles. A patent for the instrument was issued this week to Mr. Dos Passos and three of his friends.

In an ancient cemetery in the south of Ireland, the grave of the first republican president in Irish history lies neglected and unknown. To find and memorialize the plot, hidden under a tangle of thickets and underbrush, Patrick Mahony sailed on the Parthia yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 24 (AP) -- Izvestia said today that The New York Times and Time and Newsweek magazines were trying to dampen the American public's enthusiasm for the Bolshoi Ballet.
ALBANY, April 24 -- Governor Rockefeller worked his way through more than 250 proposed changes in the state's laws today to end the worst legislative log jam in a decade.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The grain futures market yielded to fairly general selling pressure today on the Board of Trade without showing much rallying power.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Maine business woman who took command of the Daughters of the American Revolution here today quickly made one thing clear.

MUSSOORIE, India, April 24 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that any emissary from Peiping could visit the Dalai Lama in this Himalayan resort and see that the Tibetan god-king was not in India under duress.

GENE KELLY appeared last night in a special program of song and dance over Channel 2. It was an hour of many parts -- familiar melodies with which Mr. Kelly has been identified on the stage and in the motion pictures, samplings of soft-shoe, tap, classical ballet and interpretive dancing, a dance to a poem by Carl Sandburg and a jazz ballet.
ATLANTA, April 24 -- An official of the National Council of Churches cautioned Southern Presbyterians here today against judging the council through the eyes of its detractors.
Educational television on Channel 11 will end this season on May 29, two weeks earlier than originally scheduled, because of budgetary problems.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 24 -- A conference opened here today at Arden House on Protestant efforts to influence the rapidly changing New York metropolitan area.
BACHARACH, Germany, April 24 -- The propaganda chief of the German Reich party paused only a second and then said: "Yes, maybe we are extreme nationalists."
For the second time this year the Industrial Bank of Commerce at 462 Seventh Avenue was the target of a woman bank robber. Yesterday's attempt was less successful than the first.
Jeanette Scovotti made her debut with the New York City Opera Company as Monica in last night's performance of Gian Carlo Menotti's "The Medium" at the City Center.

" Anniversary Waltz," the screen version of the Broadway comedy, is scheduled to go before the cameras on Monday at the Fox Movietone Studios and other locations throughout the city. It stars David Niven and Mitzi Gaynor.
EAST WILLISTON, L. I., April 24 -- Lovely spring weather smiled on the Women's Cross County Golf Association today as it opened its season.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York has leased ground-floor space with a frontage of ninety-five feet on the Fifty-second Street side of the new Tishman Building, 666 Fifth Avenue, for a branch office.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Radio waves emitted from an ordinary radio transmitter caused the death of at least ten monkeys in an experiment at the National Institutes of Health.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities sought today to show that there were discrepancies in the State Department's issuance of passports under a recent Supreme Court ruling.
LIVINGSTON MANOR, N. Y., April 24 -- Fishing started to pick up along the Beaverkill this morning and the week-end anglers ought to be able to do a little business with flies.

Checking account turnover decreased 1 per cent during March in New York City but rose 1/2 per cent in the six other leading financing centers and in 337 lesser cities, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
GENEVA, April 24 -- The West outlined its views today on the policing of the first phase of a step-by-step approach to a total ban on nuclear weapons tests.
An application for the arrest and imprisonment of Banton L. Wyckoff, real estate operator, for contempt was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Irving Saypol.
Members of forty-six patriotic and service organizations will take part in the twenty-fourth annual observance of St. George's Day tomorrow at 4 P. M. in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.
ROME, April 24 (AP) -- A hysterical woman with a baby bundled in her arms grabbed Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain today and screamed "bread and work, bread and work."
HONG KONG, April 24 -- A member of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party charged today that "Indian expansionists" were openly supporting the Tibetan rebellion.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Government accused today a St. Louis mutual fund of illegally failing to tell its 22,000 shareholders about paying more than $1,500,000 to a New York brokerage house.
ALBANY, April 24 -- Two measures designed to help increase the revenue of New York City's Transit Authority were signed by Governor Rockefeller today.

Events today: Concert for Children, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Joseph Wolman, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 3; Robert S. Williams, bass, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Wuthering Heights," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Erica Morini, violinist, Sylvia Marlowe, harpsichordist, Christine Stavrache, harpist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Andres Segovia, guitarist, Town Hall, 8:30.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Penn State romped off with the distance medley relay by a ninety-yard margin today, thereby passing on schedule the first cheek-point of its run at four major titles in the sixty-fifth annual Penn Relays.
A New York port official minimized yesterday the probable effects of the St. Lawrence's Seaway on New York. He said that other Eastern ports faced more severe losses of foreign trade.

The annual spring appeal for articles to replenish the stock of the Opportunity Shop of the Community Service Society is under way. Miss Carolyn Davey heads the volunteer committee, which is initiating the campaign by addressing and mailing 75,000 postcards.
ALBANY, April 24 -- A bill that would have created special pension privileges for Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson was vetoed today by Governor Rockefeller.
New York University has announced the appointment of Dr. William C. Spencer as a special adviser on school organization and teacher training for a United Nations project in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today a modified bill for higher taxes on life insurance companies under a permanent new formula. The measure, as revised by the committee, would increase the industry's 1958 income taxes by about $180,000,000.
Four newspaper editors told TV audiences yesterday that it was difficult not only to get news from official sources, but also to induce the public to absorb it after it had been obtained.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Navy has an official flag for the first time in its 184 years.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Public health officials see no immediate danger in current levels of radioactivity in milk but predict rising contamination until 1970 to 1975.
RICHMOND, Va., April 24 -- The Virginia Legislature ended its special sessions on schools today after completing a new program to minimize integration.
MEXICO CITY, April 24 -- An unfinished mural by David Alfaro Siqueiros was boarded up this week.
Five pacifists chose yesterday to go to jail for ten days rather than pay $25 fines for refusing to take cover during the Civil Defense test last week.

PARIS, April 24 -- The director of Roman Catholic chaplains in the French Army has condemned the torture and summary execution of Moslem rebels in Algeria as "gravely tarnishing the honor of the army and the nation."
THE sonata series at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art came to an end last night, not with sonatas but with chamber music for various combinations of instruments.

The five - story apartment house for twenty families at 810 East 181st Street in the Bronx has been sold by Ernest De Maria to a client of Samuel Hollander, attorney. The deal was for cash over mortgages amounting to $46,500.

THE harpsichord and the harp are among the most delicate of instruments. Any composer who uses those two in a solo role, backed by the resources of the full symphony orchestra, necessarily must be the most confident of technicians.
A 23-year-old man carrying a homemade bomb was seized by the police while Fidel Castro was addressing a huge rally on the Mall in Central Park last night.

The first phase of the typical business expansion is now complete, according to Albert T. Sommers, director of business analysis of the National Industrial Conference Board, "and the second phase is beginning."
I should like to comment briefly on Paul Ross' excellent letter recently published in The Times regarding the condition of the state Democratic party.

O. Roy Chalk submitted to the city yesterday a firm offer for the acquisition of all municipally owned transit. The New York and Washington financier computed the bid of his investment group at $615,000,000.

WASHINGTON April 24 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright moved today to take the Development Loan Fund out of the annual political battle over foreign aid and give it authority to lend $7,500,000,000 over the next five years.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Mrs. Ashmead White of Lubec, Me., was installed today as president general of the Daughters of the American Revolution for a three-year term.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants, kept in the game on a throw to home plate by Felipe Alou that cut off what would have been the winning run, beat the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 3, today on Daryl Spencer's eleventh-inning sacrifice fly.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, West Va., April 24 -- Advertising men were chided here today for failing to become more active in political campaigns.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 24 (AP) -- The Government charged today that troops and resistance forces of the United Arab Republic's Syrian region penetrated Jordanian territory yesterday and fired on civilians near the border town of El Mafraq.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The index of average primary market prices was unchanged at 119.9 per cent of its 1947-49 average during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Wool prices registered sharp advances yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The executive board of the New York Teachers Guild recommended last night that the local go ahead with plans for a work stoppage by city teachers.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- With increasing use of jet planes the United States soon will be five hours wide and two hours deep.

About 4,000,000 persons a year are helped by the Greater New York Fund, 11 West Forty-second Street, through its network of 425 health and welfare agencies. The sick are nursed in Fund hospitals and health agencies where every person, regardless of race, religion or economic means, knows he will receive the best in medical care.

The directors of the General Dynamics Corporation elected Earl D. Johnson as president at a meeting here yesterday. Mr. Johnson, formerly executive vice president, succeeds Frank Pace Jr., who was elected chairman. Mr. Pace remains chief executive officer.

Soltzer-Lampert, realty operators who recently bought the fifteen-story apartment house at 390 Riverside Drive, at the northeast corner of 111th Street, have resold it to an investor. The Philip Fogel Company was the broker in both deals.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 24 -- A Protestant churchman who directs a church agency on international affairs proposed today that the United States and the Soviet Union sign a nonaggression pact and set up a buffer zone in which armaments would be withdrawn under international control.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 24 -- Two British warships stood by late today and permitted an Icelandic Coast Guard vessel to arrest a British trawler.

IF Seong Moy's painting has not exactly undergone a sea change, it has, at any rate, developed in two ways since he last showed. The recent work is divided into oils more colorful than ever and black-and-white scroll paintings. This dual exhibition is being held at Grand Central Moderns, 1018 Madison Avenue.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 24 -- Officials of Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties and the Long Island Rail Road met here this afternoon to mark the 125th anniversary of the railroad and unofficially open Suffolk's $7,000,000 county center in near-by Riverside.
PARIS, April 24 -- A rose is a rose is a rose ad infinitum. Or so it seemed today under the vast concrete vault of the new exhibition hall outside Paris.

NOW that spring is here, many New Yorkers find themselves the week-end guest of a country resident. To help assure a return invitation, it might be wise to give the hostess a well-chosen gift for the home.
PARIS, April 24 -- According to Peiping, the Tibetan revolt has now been crushed, which may or may not be true. In any case, it is time for us to ponder the lessons of this Himalayan tragedy.

The Budd Company sharply increased its earnings in the first quarter of this year. It reported yesterday profits of $7,214,000, or 94 cents a common share compared with $793,525, or 15 cents a share in the 1958 quarter.

YONKERS, April 24 -- For the second straight Friday night, the world record handle at a harness racing track was shattered tonight, when 34,950 fans wagered $2,607,787 on the nine-race program. One week ago, 34,303 bet $2,531,060.
HARTFORD, April 24 (UPI) -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff advised Connecticut residents today to speak up if they wanted to avoid tax increases. He said:

SEVILLE, Spain, April 23 -- This capital of southern Spain is virtually bursting at the seams with Spaniards, tourists and international celebrities. This is the week of the annual "Feria," or fair, when no one goes to bed before dawn.
HAVANA, April 24 -- The United States warned today that any of its citizens who serve in the Cuban armed forces face possible loss of citizenship.
THE many-man's land lying between realism and abstraction is occupied this week by four painters.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 12 points (25 to 60 cents a bale) yesterday.
This year, more than ever, stocks are being recommended for purchase because they "look good on the chart." Thus, the market is being influenced more and more by its technicians.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 24 -- Carmine G. De Sapio gave his own definition of a political "liberal" to a group of Princeton University students tonight.
WATKINS, Colo., April 24 (AP) -- Col. John P. Stapp, "the fastest man on earth," parachuted to safety but the pilot died today in the crash of a T-33 jet trainer.

PEIPING, April 24 (Reuters) -- Observers here regard the increasingly heavy fire being turned on "Indian expansionists" as part of a gradually mounting propaganda offensive likely to stir up public wrath.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 24 (UPI) -- Gov. A. B. Chandler sent 2,000 Kentucky National Guardsmen into southeastern Kentucky's coal fields today. Their mission is to end the dynamitings and shootings that have taken two lives since the United Mine Workers union went on strike forty seven days ago.

Through music, dance and authentic costumes, visiting natives of several Asian countries depicted the "Modes and Mores of the Orient" in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor last night. It was the third annual pageant of its kind to be presented by the Pan Pacific and Southeast Asia Women's Association.
Interstate Department Stores, Inc. operator of a chain of forty-nine stores, yesterday acquired White Front Stores, Inc., which operates two large stores in Los Angeles, Calif.

THE singer who calls herself Odetta filled Town Hall with a warming and often electrifying glow last night with a program of folk songs that spanned a wide area from prison songs and the blues to the amiable nonsense of "The Frozen Logger."
MONTREAL, April 24 -- The St. Lawrence Seaway will be opened tomorrow.

GERTRUDE BERG wears a kimono every night in the Broadway hit, "A Majority of One," in which she plays an American tourist in Japan. However, when she goes home, she slips into a "Molly Goldberg Original."
E. J. Hanley, president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, told stockholders yesterday that he felt there should be no rise in employment costs in the forthcoming labor pacts.

One of the nation's outstanding football attractions will be staged in New York next fall when Army meets the United States Air Force Academy at Yankee Stadium on Saturday, Oct. 31.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation got into a lengthy wrangle with two Senators today over steel profits and the role of Government in relation to the prices set by big business.
TRENTON, April 24 -- There is no lethargy in New Jersey hen houses this spring.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 -- The annual meeting of the American Association of University Professors voted unanimously today to censure two universities for violations of academic freedom or faculty tenure.

One hundred thousand marchers are expected to participate today in the Loyalty Day Parade on Fifth Avenue. The parade will start at 1 P. M. at Sixty-third Street and move south to Thirty-eighth Street.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 24 -- Bermuda's team of International One-Design Class sailors have the Amorita Cup. They stowed it into a Royal Bermuda Yacht Club trophy case by beating Long Island Sound today for the fourth time.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower approved today new routes for Japan Air Lines from Tokyo to Seattle and Los Angeles.

The Friendship Fund of The Lighthouse will benefit from a preview of the eleventh national exhibition of Amateur Needlework of Today at The Lighthouse, 111 East Fifth-ninth Street, tomorrow afternoon. Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower is honorary chairman for the exhibition, which be opened to the public from Tuesday through May 9.

A SAGE and veteran observer of the world scene, Edgar Ansel Mowrer has some very definite views upon that scene as well as upon the scene at home. These views he sets forth here with vigor, giving to them a persuasiveness they could hardly hope to attain if they were the expression of another pen, or another mind.

EDWARD JOHNSON, who died last Monday, had a personal elegance and courtliness that reflected the culture and leisure of the Old World. He could also move and speak with a breeziness that was distinctive of the New. For the manager of an opera house like the Metropolitan this was a happy combination of qualities.

ALBANY, April 25 -- New York horseplayers set a new record for absent-mindedness during the 1958 campaign. Winning pari-mutuel tickets worth $366,758.85 went uncashed at the state's thoroughbred and harness-horse tracks, it was reported today by the Taxation and Finance Commissioner, Joseph H. Murphy.

THIS first novel by Rachel Cecil, who is the wife of Lord David Cecil and the daughter of Desmond MacCarthy, paints a pleasant and vivid picture of London society in the Twenties -- chronologically close, yet an era as distant and passe as the society comedies of another century.

WE Americans are a people in quest of ourselves. Ever since our birth as a nation we have been trying to find a mirror in which to see our true image. And this anxious uncertainty about the kind of people we are still distinguishes us among the nations of the world.

BURR FULLER, the center of attention in Herbert Gold's fourth novel, is one of today's schizoid Americans who at mid-life find themselves split between an urge to make slow but steady progress and a compulsion to keep speeding frantically ahead.

NOTORIOUS speed traps in parts of Georgia that have made the territory a motorists' nightmare are being eliminated in part, according to an on-the-spot survey by the American Automobile Association.

These are the men of six law-enforcement agencies of the United States Treasury Department, whose functions Harry Edward Neal, former assistant chief of the Secret Service, describes here.

ROSCOE, N. Y., April 25 -- The advancement of the trout season opening this year certainly has diminished the early season fishing pressure, if it has done nothing else. This trend may have been helped along by a noticeable lessening of early pressure in the last couple of years for no apparent reason.

Proceeds from a benefit called "Music for Haiti," to be held on the evening of May 13 at the Colony Club, will be used to buy a new organ for Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Cathedral in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. A supper party will be held later at Sardi's East.

THE period from the end of April to early May still offers opportunity for home lawn improvement. The owner should give some thought to his lawn's needs. Mistakes in some phases of lawn care at this season, especially in mowing, can be very damaging.

Deeply as we regret the situation which confronts the Mannes College of Music, and warmly as we welcome Howard Taubman's article last Sunday in behalf of higher musical education in our city, we beg to bring to your attention that Mr. Taubman's article overlooked the fourth music college in New York City that offers a degree in training music students for professional careers.

MENDOZA, Argentina, April 25 -- The most important election since President Arturo Frondizi took office a year ago will be held here tomorrow. The outcome is being watched throughout Argentina as an indication of the Government's current standing with the public.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 25 -- Premier Emil Jonsson denounced the British today as the "best allies those Icelanders who are enemies of NATO could have."
The men's clothing industry expects a good year. Spring and summer orders were above those of 1958 and early fall bookings indicate a sizable increase over last year's sales.
ATLANTA, April 25 -- An interestate nuclear development agency for the South moved toward realization this week with the approval of a compact providing for its establishment.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 25 -- Edmund Rice Hall, a $900,000 student brothers' residence and chapel at Iona College, was blessed and dedicated today by Cardinal Spellman. Msgr. Edwin B. Broderick, secretary to the Cardinal, was master of ceremonies.

WARSAW, April 25 -- The Soviet bloc has organized a preview, a sort of road company try-out, for its role in the big Geneva foreign ministers' show. It will open here on Monday for a one or two day stand.

WARSAW, April 25 -- The Soviet threat to sign a separate peace treaty with East Germany if negotiations for an over-all German pact fail was reported today to have caused some deep worry in the Communist alliance.

ATLANTA, April 25 -- The general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) will be asked Monday to disapprove a report by a study conference of the National Council of Churches urging United States recognition of Communist China and its admission into the United Nations.

SPRING is the ideal season to plant, divide and transplant many perennials, because the soil is light, loose from frost action and easily prepared. Some perennials, though, should not be disturbed under any circumstance since this may discourage or prevent bloom or destroy the plants.

The Yorkville Youth Council at 1458 York Avenue will benefit from a showing of D. W. Griffith's 1922 motion picture "Orphans of the Storm." The picture will be shown on May 5 in the Einhorn Auditorium, 137 East Seventy-sixth Street.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 25 -- Two junior equestriennes qualified for national riding finals at next fall's National Horse Show as the Boulder Brook Club's spring horse show opened a two-day run today.

IT is almost a commonplace that, come spring and summer, the male bird dons brilliant plumage. But this season men will be enlivened more by pattern than by color. Pattern dominates the new turn-out of men's clothes, especially in sportswear where it ranges from the smallest checks to the boldest plaids. Even in suits it is making a hesitant comeback, adding variety, if not color.
Dr. Linus Pauling, 1954 Nobel Prize-winning chemist, and Representative William H. Meyer, Democrat of Vermont, will discuss atomic fall-out at Brooklyn College tomorrow.

AS a public school teacher, I find the conclusions of Fred Hechinger's book, "The Big Red Schoolhouse," ex tremely refreshing. His attack upon the "old cliche" that we must have complete local option in schooling is particularly welcome.

ALTHOUGH the Broadway history of "Epitaph for George Dillon" was a mite doleful, its movie prospects are exceedingly bright. WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Children of Presidents of the United States, perhaps as many as ten, will gather here next Thursday.

If you forgot to put the clock one hour ahead before going to bed last night, it is somewhat later than you think. In fact, it is an hour later than you think. Daylight Saving Time went into effect at 2 o'clock this morning, and from tonight until Oct. 25 there will be an extra sixty minutes' sunshine for all.

Iron ore mining, one of the great industries of Minnesota and the Ninth Federal Reserve District, opened in mid-April under much more favorable conditions than existed a year ago. The industry predicted ore shipments from the Lake Superior district will be from 25 to 50 per cent greater than they were during the 1958 Lake shipping season.

ANNUALS are some of the most satisfying of all types of garden flowers. They have a long blooming season which surpasses biennials and perennials. With some care during dry periods and consistent removal of faded flowers, annuals will provide three months of bloom or more.
A mobile X-ray service for aircraft has been opened by Lockheed Aircraft Service-New York, a maintenance concern at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

BONN, Germany, April 25 -The Defense Ministry reported no progress today in solving the mystery of the bombing of a goose sanctuary in the North Sea.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., April 25 -- Multiple fund-raising drives conducted every year by various health and welfare agencies may be easing in this area.

THE annual reckoning of color photography's achievements and discussion of its potentials finds Popular Photography's 1959 Color Annual (New York: Ziff-Davis. 170 pages. $1.25) exultant that the "color revolution" is now in full swing.

Scripps, Albert Einstein, Ernest Hemingway, Edna Millay, George Santayana, Pablo Casals, Leon Trotsky, Sigmund Freud, Bertrand Russell, Charlie Chaplin, John Dewey and Annis Ford Eastman, the well-known Congregationalist minister who was the author's mother.

VINES trained on tall posts or other uprights will give a needed third dimension to plantings. This device is becoming increasingly popular with gardeners whose home grounds are restricted in area, or where tall shrubs and evergreens would occupy too much space and completely dominate other landscape effects.

IN the city of Szczecin, on the Oder River near the Baltic Sea, there is a man who calls himself the Director of Tourism. This is certainly one of the most poignantly hopeful titles to be found in Europe, because it is likely to be a long, long time before tourists find much to attract them in this raw and half-gutted port town that the Germans once called Stettin.

Yet if the Cantiques Spirituels attributed to Marchand in a manuscript of the Paris Conservatory and issued on a recent Westminster disk are authentic, Marchand must have been a great composer.

What may prove to be one of the greatest oil developments is taking place in the desert sands of North Africa. Just getting fully under way, the exploitation of the Sahara promises to have an important impact on the world oil markets.

STRASBOURG, France, April 21 (Religious News Service) -- Christian lay leaders from several European countries heard a member of the French Parliament deplore the love of sensation that, he said, is "one of the most important characteristics of the popular press."
DETROIT, April 25 -- The Michigan Legislature will meet Monday night in the face of a warning that payless paydays for state employes and suspension of state welfare payments are near.

CINCINNATI, April 25 -- The Cincinnati Reds overcame two jinxes at once today. They knocked Warren Spahn out of the box and beat the Milwaukee Braves, 7 -- 6. The Braves threatened to pull the game out of the fire in the ninth when Eddie Mathews hit a two-run homer. They had two more men on base when Del Crandall flied out ending the game.
ALBANY, April 25 -- The state's annual four-month siege of law-making ended today as Governor Rockefeller announced he had disposed of the last of the 1,202 bills left him by the Legislature.

A campaign to attract capable high school graduates and college students to careers in the various health fields is being sponsored by the National Foundation (formerly the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis).

Shipyards in the United States were affected more than yards in other shipbuilding countries by the gradual decline in world-wide ship construction activity in the first three months of this year, Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported yesterday.
Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba left New York yesterday. Police officials began to breathe regularly again.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, have agreed that there appeared to be no need at this time for the committee's ranking Senators to attend the Foreign Ministers' conference at Geneva.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 25 -- The annual spring horse show at Rice Farms on Lawrence Hill, scheduled for May 3, will benefit the North Suffolk County Chapter of the American Red Cross.

Art and politics have become fast friends in the Executive Mansion at Albany. Governor Rockefeller is installing some ninety-four examples of modern and avant-garde painting and sculpture brought from his New York home. His action is not without precedent.

CLEVELAND, April 25 (UPI) -- The professional tennis champion. Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles, and Lew Hoad of Australia scored semi-final victories tonight in the world professional tennis championship.
BOSTON, April 25 -- Richard Cardinal Cushing of Boston plans to build a home for children born blind. He said it would be known as "Lux Mundi-Lux Aeterna." "Light of the World and Light of Eternity."

KANSAS CITY, April 25 (UPI) -- Kansas City staved off a Detroit rally in the ninth inning tonight to beat the Tigers, 8 -- 7. It was Detroit's fifth loss in a row and its eleventh defeat in twelve starts.

Shaw's play appeared in 1912, but W. S. Gilbert's "Pygmalion and Galatea" had been a sensational success in London and a moderate hit in New York over thirty years before.

AN adhesive mending material which was primarily designed for repairing plastics can also be used on wood, metal, leather, china and fabric. Packaged in a tube with special applicator cap to simplify spreading, this product can be used for sealing rips in vinyl wading pools, seat covers and inflatable toys.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 25 -- The Union of South Africa took further steps this week along the road to complete apartheid or separation of races which since 1948 has been its goal.

The opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway for navigation is a historic event both for our country and for our friendly neighbor, Canada. Ocean vessels from all over the world will now be able to proceed directly to Great Lakes ports deep in the heart of this continent. The resultant savings in costs should spur international trade and commerce.

The Medical Center Nursery School at 625 West 165th Street will be the beneficiary of the second annual Mother Goose Ball, Dr. Virgil G. Damon and Mrs. Hamilton Southworth are honorary co-chairmen of the fete, which will take place in Bard Hall of Columbia University on May 9.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A labor federation economist said today that the nation seemed to be facing the danger that unemployment might not drop substantially despite recovery from the recession.

NEARLY everyone whose work entails occasional comment on the nature of our contemporary world sooner or later comes up with a tag to describe it. Whether or not he coins one, he is sure, now and then, to employ one.

THE Emmy awards of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences are in danger of becoming an annual joke. While the prize-winners to be announced on May 6 undoubtedly will include many thoroughly deserving talents, the business of distributing the Emmys patently is becoming a promotional free-for-all.

STANTON, Del., April 25 -- Ch. Cote de Neige Sundew, a Pembroke Welsh Corgi owned by Mrs. William Long of Concord, Mass., took the best-in-show honors at the eighteenth annual Wilmington Kennel Club show today at Delaware Park.

Cuyahoga County building permits amounted to $47,100,000 in the first quarter of this year, representing a gain of only $400,000, for less than 1 per cent above the total for the year-ago period. Permits for one and two-family dwellings advanced to nearly $23,000,000, against $19,000,000 for the corresponding period last year.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- Sight-seeing places no strain on the visitor to this interesting old city, where history goes back 350 years into the days of Spain's great New World empire. Most of the points of historic and esthetic interest here are near enough to each other to be encompassed in a leisurely stroll.

LISSE, the Netherlands, April 24 -- A million tulips, daffodils and hyacinths waved their colors on the lawn of Keukenhof Castle here today as a hint to visitors that the Netherlands has flower bulbs for sale.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 25 -- The Bell Ringers Ball, a buffet supper dance featuring professional night-club entertainment, will be held on May 22 at the Glen Island Casino here.

Harry Partch's "The Bewitched" was an event of considerable importance to the musical world. His line of thought is highly relevant to a deep problem in contemporary music, and his work well worth investigating. For accustomed though we are to the use of brake-drums, road drills, typewriters and other novel noisemakers in contemporary music, the difference between these and Partch's work represents the difference between centrifugal and centripetal force.
GARDENERS should begin to plan now for a brilliant chrysanthemum display in fall. Spring is the time to study beds and borders and bring the garden up to date with some of the new varieties.

Healing cults were criticized yesterday in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman. The preaching of miraculous cures, he said, presents false hopes to the afflicted and distorts religion.

THE New York-Washington run of the Pennsylvania Railroad, long one of the fastest tracks in the country, will be even faster starting today, as daylight saving time commences.

The Wagner administration faces a decision on traffic policy "that will affect the relief of traffic congestion for the next thirty-one years," according to Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

PRISTINA, Yugoslavia, April 13 -- A land so poor that peasant houses frequently are made of woven sticks plastered over with mud and then whitewashed -- yet rich enough to be the site of Yugoslavia's biggest dollar-earning industry.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., April 25 -- Grant B. Schley, a member of Moore Schley, stockbrokers of 100 Broadway, Manhattan, was found dead tonight in the garage of his estate here. He was 35 years old. The police said he was a suicide.

THE home handyman who would like to build an outdoor fireplace, retaining wall, or other brick structure will need to master elementary techniques if he wants his finished project to have a neat, professional looking appearance.

S. 1555 is the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959, otherwise known as the Kennedy bill for its chief sponsor, Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. Yesterday the Senate passed S. 1555 after the hottest Congressional debate of the current session -- a debate with political overtones that could affect the Presidential race of 1960.
The NATO treaty was born of collective insecurity, and much of the energies of the member nations have been directed primarily to strengthening their defense against aggression.

Tom Hall's first juvenile may want to swap a baseball mitt for a tombo stick -- at any rate they will enjoy reading about Toru, an uncomplaining Japanese boy who wanted to spend his summer vacation catching dragonflies (tombos) and other insects instead of helping his father cultivate the rice paddies.

Industrial activity continued to mount in the Kansas City Federal Reserve district. Manufacturers of durable goods report that operations have returned to the former high levels experienced prior to the decline that took place in the fall of 1957.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 25 -- Gen. John B. Grier of Rockland, Del. broke eighty-five straight targets today at Travers Island to win the New York Athletic Club's singles trap-shooting title.
PANAMA, Sunday, April 26 -- The Government said early today it had reports that about thirty men had made a landing on Panama's Caribbean coast.

WHEN Alice went tumbling down the hole, she should not have stopped in Wonderland. One more spin and she might have reached Indianapolis where things really get "curiouser and curiouser." If she didn't encounter the White Rabbit, the Cheshire Cat and the Mad Hatter, she at least would have met Cus D'Amato and marvelled at the machinations of this Machiavelli of Maul in his handling of Friday's fight between Floyd Patterson and Brian London.

An eleventh-inning pinch single by Chico Carrasquel, a former White Sox shortstop, lifted the Orioles to a 2-1 victory over the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday and dropped Casey Stengel's men into fourth place in the American League.

THERE is a certain type of mind (such as mine) which is peculiarly captivated by learning that a corpse discovered in Parliament can be sat upon only by the Coroner of the Royal Household, with a jury of Officers of Her Majesty's Household such as, for instance, the Senior Silver-Stick-in-Waiting.
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., April 25 -- Steel and concrete had given form this week to Long Island's most serious housing development, the $13,000,000 Suffolk Bomarc Missile Base.

Department store sales in the Twelfth Reserve district for the week ended April 18 were 4 per cent above the similar period a year ago. Undoubtedly, the over-all district average for the week was pulled down by the performance of the Los Angeles stores.

MEXICO CITY, April 22. -- The Mexican Foreign Ministry has made official inquiry of the Dominican Republic as to the whereabouts of Alfredo Perena Pamies, a naturalized Mexican citizen who disappeared in Ciudad Trujillo last February.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 15 -- "What, no Turkish coffee in Turkey?" This question, put by visitors in tones of horrified surprise, is a standing joke along the Bosporus. The Istanbul waiter is pretty tired of it. For, invariably, he has to reply "Kahve yok," -- no coffee -- and smile.

Under the leadership of Sir Carol Reed, a mobile band of forty-six artists and technicians has set up headquarters here and launched the production of "Our Man in Havana."

To acquire them the Founding Fathers would probably have predicted nothing but war with the great powers, or purchases beyond our dreams in the days of a financially tottering treasury.

MONTREAL, April 25 -- The St. Lawrence Seaway, after fifty years of talk and five years of building, opened for business this morning.

THIS latest book by Alan Villiers, Australian sailing master of grain-boat fame, is divided into two parts. The second, in which he describes the 1957 crossing, under his command, of the Mayflower II, will very likely have the greatest interest for most readers.

THE Juilliard School of Music will present four evenings of dance in its Concert Hall on May 8, 9, 11 and 12 for the benefit of the scholarship fund the school is establishing in memory of Doris Humphrey.

ON Manhattan's First Avenue one afternoon last week, a woman screamed as she entered the living room in her third-floor walkup apartment. Crouching near a window was a prowler, a tall man in a black jacket.

SINGAPORE, April 25 -- The powerful Left-wing People's Action party offered the largest number of candidates in nominations today for the general elections May 30. On that date this British colony will elect a fifty-one-seat Legislative Assembly and attain internal self-government.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 25 -- The main activity of what was to have been the final day of the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club's annual race week today was around a protest table.

Loosely yoked together, and occasionally stepping in each other's tracks, artists working in the two major plastic arts run a swerving course between varying degrees of realism and abstraction.

Some of the inflation psychology apparently disappeared from the stock market last week. Stocks eased Wednesday and Thursday under profit taking amid indications of an impairment of the market's technical position.

TOKYO, April 11 -- Unlike New York and other great centers, Tokyo draws the bulk of its commuters -- and the commuter problem -- from within the city itself. Tokyo now lays claim to being the most populous city in the world.

THROUGHOUT the years when West Germany has been shaking off the dust of ruin and growing its glossy new coat of success, the rotund figure of Ludwig Erhard has stood for economic wizardry. His grin and his cigar have been for Germans as specific an image of the country's economic state as a shop window full of wares or an autobahn crawling with new cars.

LATE April is the time to start treatment for gorgeous fall rose blooms, so that they are not marred by mildew, aphids or blemished foliage. This month also marks the time to insure good bushes for the following year.

Founded as a permanent organization in 1944, the United Negro College Fund, Inc., is a federation of independent, accredited colleges and universities joined together to seek financial support through a single yearly appeal for contributions. The federation's primary purpose is to improve opportunities for higher education for Negro youth.

ST. LOUIS, April 25 (AP) -George Crowe blasted a home run into right center today, his first of the season, enabling the St. Louis Cardinals to gain a 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. Crowe connected in the eighth.

GLYNDON, Md., April 25 (AP) -- H. R. Fenwick's Fluctuate stayed just off the pace most of the way then came on to win today the sixty-third annual Maryland Hunt Cup by two lengths.

IN 1851 a founding father of Punch published a massive sociological work entitled "London Labour and the London Poor." In the words of its compiler, Henry Mayhew, it was an attempt to record "the history of a people, from the lips of the people themselves, giving a literal description of their labour, their earnings, their trials and their sufferings," and it painted an appalling picture of poverty and squalor in the midst of Victorian plenty.
POPLARVILLE, Miss., April 25 -- A lynch mob of masked white men broke into the county jail here early today, beat an accused Negro rapist in his cell, and dragged him to a waiting car.

The City Gardens Club of New York will benefit from two spring showings of private city gardens on May 5 and 12. Funds realized will go to the club's conservation education program, which includes the awarding to ten city teachers of two weeks at the Audubon Camps of Maine or Connecticut.

Resident offices report that sportswear is becoming very scarce and that manufacturers have closed their summer lines to begin production of early fall merchandise. This indicated, they said, the probability of the best sportswear season in years.

ALBANY, April 25 -- Governor Rockefeller issued an economy order today aimed at eliminating the official use of "high priced cars." Of the 2,252 state-owned cars, however, only eight fall in the high-priced category, and four of those are not covered by the order.

I have followed with great interest the developing public position of the Administration favoring greater use of the International Court of Justice, as foreshadowed by the President in his State of the Union message in January and by Vice President Nixon in his most commendable address before the Academy of Political Science on April 13.

Pennsylvania's varsity heavyweight crew won the Childs Cup for the second successive year on the Harlem yesterday and remains undefeated for its test with Yale on the Schuylkill in Philadelphia next Saturday.

LAGOS, Nigeria, April 23 -- In response to a Nigerian Federal Government request, the Carnegie Corporation has agreed to meet the cost of a survey of Nigeria's needs in the field of higher education over the next twenty years.
A two-year campaign by the city to bring a substantial amount of moving-picture-making back to New York has begun to bear fruit, a city department reported yesterday.

NANCY MITFORD wrote this novel in 1939 during Britain's "Great Bore War," and it became, in the author's words, "an early and unimportant casualty of the real war which was then beginning." STAMPS to mark the friendship and collaboration between two cities, Rome and Paris, were issued by the Italian postal administration recently and copies of them reached dealers here last week. The stamps, horizontals in red and blue, are in the denominations of 15-lire and 25L. They bear the inscription Roma Gemellaggio Parigi (Rome twinship Paris) in white capitals along a blue strip at the bottom.

ONE of the big news stories of 1959 will be the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway when man's centuries-old dream of ocean ships in the Great Lakes will at last become a reality. Appearing in good time for the opening on June 26 are two well-written and excellently illustrated books that effectively set forth the story of the new waterway.

At the wholesale level also, volume is at a record, but the final evaluation must await the effects of the build-up of inventories and their eventual liquidation.

SYRACUSE, Sicily, April 25 (AP) -- Britain's Stirling Moss, driving a Cooper-Borg-ward, today won the 188-mile Grand Prix of Syracuse automobile race. Moss covered the fifty-five-lap course in 1 hour 53 minutes 6 seconds for an average speed of 99.4 miles per hour.

Peiping's attempts to suppress rebellion in Tibet have raised that inaccessible, mountain-girt land to the summit of attention throughout Asia. Since coming to power almost ten years ago, the Chinese Communists have sought to annex Tibet, which holds the northern approaches to India.

ALTHOUGH we both agree that the best way to travel is by air, when our plane landed in New York this past month my husband and I heaved a sigh of relief. This was our 102nd flight in ten months of traveling -- around the world, around Africa and around South America.

THE men and women who present concert artists across the nation have decided they must do more to aid young American artists. TELEVISION'S private-eye programs, which this season have become musical detective shows, continue to find new ways to add music. CEDAR GROVE, N. J., April 25 -- A proposed master plan for Cedar Grove was made public today. A highlight of the program is a proposal for rezoning to permit construction of garden apartments, office buildings and industrial plants.

AIR travel to Miami and other points in Florida from the East and the Midwest, and between other cities in the East will become 25 per cent cheaper for persons willing to travel night coach, on Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays between the hours of 10 P. M. and 4 A. M.

A 27-year-old narcotics addict attempted a hold-up in a Brooklyn drugstore yesterday with a .38-caliber revolver that he had stolen from a Treasury Department agent a month ago. He and an accomplice were captured.

The National Committee on Radiation Protection and Measurements, the nation's highest advisory committee on radiation protection, issued a new handbook last week on the maximum permissible concentrations of radioactive materials in the human body and in air and water.

Announced investment in new industries and expansions in the Baltimore area in the first quarter of 1959 amounted to $56,779,000. Expansions of two textile manufacturing plants in North Carolina also have been announced.

One of the world's greatest test-tube detectives, Dr. Alexander O. Gettler, is retiring Thursday after forty-nine years of tracing crime through chemical analysis. He is chief toxicologist of the Chief Medical Examiner's Office of New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Seven weeks ago, when the news broke that Fidel Castro had accepted an invitation to address United States newspaper editors here, the State Department was at pains to make clear that the visit would be unofficial.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 25 -- Juscelino Kubitschek, President of Brazil, believes his country has survived the worst economic crisis in her history and is on the road to recovery. He stated the belief in an interview this week.

BONN, Germany, April 25 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano criticized Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union today for saying that the German people could live without reunification.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25 -- Glenn Davis, an Olympic champion and 440-yard world record holder, today smashed the Drake Relays special Amateur Athletic Union quarter-mile mark with a 46.5-second clocking.

BALBOA, C. Z., April 25 -- The Panama Canal Company is inviting bids on one of the two principal contract jobs required for the fixed bridge across the Canal at Balboa, where approach work is already under way.

HOME fruit growing brings bountiful rewards in fall. The many new varieties available and better spray materials are making this possible. But as any fruit grower knows, a rigorous upkeep schedule must be followed to bring the plants to full fruition.

The Moscow radio announced yesterday that the Soviet Union had rejected President Eisenhower's solution of the deadlock over halting nuclear bomb tests. As a result the Geneva negotiations, which started off rather promisingly last October,-seem to have come to a dead end. In fact, it now appears that if an agreement on any phase of the disarmament question can be reached this year, it will develop only at a summit meeting.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Fifty of the finest privately owned Impressionist paintings in the United States went on public exhibition today at the National Gallery of Art.
VIENNA, April 25 -- Austria's general election campaign entered its final fortnight today without having aroused anything more than a mild interest among the electorate.
Recent changes and increases in state income tax laws in New York and Massachusetts are giving fresh impetus to a longstanding national campaign to bar any state from taxing residents of another.

THE last of Japan's annual literary prizes, the Yomiuri Prize, is awarded each year in January, so that the judges can be sure that all the evidence from the year before is in. Poets and critics received prizes for 1958, but no novelist. Earlier, a single novel had been awarded two major prizes. These facts would suggest that, unless something important waits to be discovered, 1958 was rather a dull year for the Japanese novel.
THE Gramercy Park Association's thirteenth annual Flower Show, which opens on Wednesday, will pay tribute to Henry Hudson on the 350th anniversary of the Dutch explorer's trip up the Hudson River.

Although cool rainy weather last week washed out some bloom in the metropolitan area, spring's flower pageant still advances. In fact, dogwood are showing color about a week ahead of schedule. Blossoms have opened on the showy Kwanzan cherries, late magnolias, flowering plums and crabapples. Amelanchier, early rhododendrons and tulips also brighten the landscape.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Nine American veterans of the 1945 Elbe River link up with Soviet soldiers plan to fly to Moscow Monday for a celebration of the fourteenth anniversary of the World War II allied meeting.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 25 (AP) -- A Cubana Airlines plane was seized at Varadero Beach, Cuba, tonight by four of its twelve passengers and was diverted here.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 25 -- Indications are that the 1960 United States Census will show a count of 180,000,000, according to Dr. Conrad Taeuber, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of the Census. The 1950 Census total was 150,697,361.

LOS ANGELES, April 25 -- For the first time in nearly half a century it is impossible for California political aspirants to masquerade, in greater or lesser degree, as adherents of a rival political party.

THE Khedive Said, a tyrant of Egypt in the fun-loving dynasty which finally spawned the fat and disastrous Farouk, once strewed gunpowder a foot high along a palace path to refute rumors of cowardice. Lighting his pipe, and commanding his reluctant courtiers to light theirs and follow him, the jolly monarch strolled down the explosive trail in a cloud of smoke and lethal embers.

Both "towhee" and "chewink" are supposed to represent the first two notes of the bird's characteristic call; and, as further proof of the fallibility of words in transcribing bird calls, Thoreau set down the same notes as "hip-you" and Seaton heard them as "chuck-burr." Few other bird calls have been so variously interpreted.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- When a Federal budget balances or is in the red, the main reason is not decisions of the President or actions of Congress. It is events in the national economy in general and on the nation's farms in particular.

The 125th anniversary of Woodycrest, a Bronx child-care institution, will be celebrated on Thursday at a tea-dance in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East. Plans for the event were completed recently at a meeting held in the home here of Mrs. James Talcott Van Norden, chairman of the junior committee.
HAZARD, Ky., April 25 (AP) -- Fire, described as arson, destroyed a nonunion coal operation today, as National Guard motorcades converged on eastern Kentucky's strike-bound coal fields.

ALBANY, April 25 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller appointed Robert P. Aex, City Manager of Rochester, today as director of the state's new Office of Local Government.
