The Baltimore Orioles defeated the Yankees, 2 -- 1, in eleven innings at the Stadium yesterday. Johnny Kucks, who pitched to only one batter, was the losing pitcher. In other games, the Chicago White Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 8 -- 6, with five unearned runs in the ninth, and the Cincinnati Reds downed the Milwaukee Braves, 7 -- 6.

TOKYO, April 20 -- A Government White Paper made public this week predicts a serious shortage of Japanese hotels to accommodate the growing number of foreign tourists, which is increasing 30 to 40 per cent annually.

An outstanding instrumentality of this kind is the New York Community Trust, which received its first fund -- $1,000 -- in 1924 and its 100th in 1948.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley accused the Fifth Avenue Coach Company yesterday of "spending substantial sums of money" in a propaganda campaign against the extension of one-way avenues in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- Five winners of National Academy of Sciences awards were announced today by Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, academy president.

ALBANY, April 26 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that he had chosen Francis K. McCune, General Electric executive, to head the state's new General Advisory Committee on Atomic Energy.

The New York Central's first and only Woman director will not seek re-election at the annual meeting this year. Mrs. Lila Bell Wallace's decision became known when the proxy statement for the meeting was mailed to stockholders yesterday.

LAGOS, Nigeria, April 26 -- Shell-British Petroleum, which has been exploring for oil in Nigeria since 1937, expects crude production in eastern Nigeria to reach a rate of 500,000 tons a year later this year, it was announced today.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., April 26 -- The Smith College Scholarship Fund will benefit from the second annual Smith Scholarship Fair to be held May 15 and 16 at the Eddy Barn, 990 Hulls Farms Road here. The fair is being conducted by the Smith College Club of Eastern Fairfield County.

PANAMA, April 26 -- The Government said tonight that three armed members of an invasion party had been caught and had named Dr. Roberto Arias, the husband of Dame Margot Fonteyn, the British ballerina, as their supreme leader.

Former President Harry S. Truman arrived here yesterday to deliver three lectures on the Presidency today, tomorrow and Wednesday at Columbia University. He was accompanied by Mrs. Truman.

Personal interest in the welfare of fellow men was defined yesterday as the meaning of "real charity." The Rev. Thomas Gibbons of the Maryknoll Fathers made the observation at the 10 A.M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 26 -- A big syndicate of Dutch banks has taken over the $64,000,000 outstanding balance of the Dutch 1947 3 1/4 per cent World Bank loan that originally was $190,000,000. This loan will thus be subject to anticipated redemption.

Premier Khrushchev now confirms the Soviet rejection of the American-British proposal for an immediate ban on all nuclear weapons tests that cause a dangerous fall-out. He has thereby dashed the hope for an early first step to minimize a potential health hazard to mankind and has brought the Geneva test conference to the brink of a breakdown.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Senate investigators are working on legislation to help cope with a sharp increase in school delinquency.
The Court of Appeals has relieved lending institutions of any concern with respect to the recording of mortgage extension agreements containing a clause releasing the original obligor.

The Grand Union Company set a record in earnings in the year ended Feb. 28, while sales exceeded $500,000,000 for the first time. Lansing P. Shield, president of the Eastern food chain, which operated 472 markets at the fiscal year-end, made the disclosure in the annual report released today.
The steamship charter market was off slightly last week, both in volume and rates. The weekly survey found grain still the dominant cargo but unable by itself to sustain the market.

RANGOON, Burma, April 26 (AP) -- Army officers who are conducting a widespread campaign to rid Burma of Communists have no political ambitions and will not contest the next elections, according to a high official.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower will appear before an audience receptive to his budget-balancing campaign tomorrow when he welcomes delegates to the forty-seventh annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
BOSTON, April 26 -- Premier Castro left for Montreal by plane by 12:45 P. M. today, ending a twenty-one-hour visit to Boston and Cambridge.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 -- An unexplained effort is under way to drop a curtain of secrecy over experiments in nuclear rocket propulsion, which have been reported in detail for a year.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 26 (UPI) -- Lew Gerrard of New Zealand beat the defender, Billy Knight of Britain, 3 -- 6, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, 9 -- 7, today and won the British hard court tennis championship.

RYE, N. Y., April 26 -- Barnard-in-Westchester will sponsor a scholarship benefit house and garden tour in the Rye area next Saturday afternoon. Tea will be served at Brookside where those taking the tour will be the guests of Mrs. Ricardo Gonzales.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Skin-diving oceanographers, equipped with color cameras, will be sent to the bottom of the ocean this summer to gather information on what happens to radioactive waste materials dropped in shallow waters.
A Methodist minister asserted yesterday that "we Americans waste millions each year not because we give too much to other nations but because we do so with the wrong motives."
About 2,500 members of forty-six patriotic organizations took part yesterday in the observance of St. George's Day at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 26 -- The main towns of Cyprus were placed out of bounds to British troops today as thousands of Cypriote workers staged May Day parades and rallies. The day was observed ahead of time because May 1 this year coincides with the Greek Orthodox Good Friday.

Five hundred members of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and their families attended the vesper service yesterday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian. Church at Fifty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Air Force announced a discovery today that may reduce the circuits of a pocket radio to the size of the head of a match.
ATLANTA, April 26 -- The Southern Presbyterian church is pioneering in a project calling for "high level" discussions between physicians and ministers.
BUENOS AIRES, April 26 -- President Arturo Frondizi's Governmental housecleaning moved today toward the Cabinet level.
Two youths riding on the roof of a West Side IRT subway train as a prank were found crushed to death last night when the southbound six-car train pulled into the 168th Street station.
A two-year contract covering sixty nonprofessional employes was signed yesterday by the Brooklyn Women's Hospital and Local 144 of the Hotel and Allied Service Employes Union.
THE opera that Hugo Weisgall, composer, and Denis Johnston, playwright and librettist, have made out of Pirandello's "Six Characters in Search of an Author" is no more conventional than the play.

LAST night's two-hour version of "Meet Me in St. Louis," which was presented over Channel 2, was a tuneful and sentimental slice of Americana, circa 1904. In its warm and engaging respect for old traditions, manners and values it was a most touching program.

The Procter Gamble Company, which has been the sole sponsor of the "Loretta Young Show" since its television debut in 1953, has decidednot to renew for the 1959-60 season. The N. B. C. network expects to continue the program, possibly in its current time period of 10 to 10:30 P. . on Sundays.
A horse named George who was pulling an empty hansom cab and perhaps dreaming of more exciting days bolted yesterday and added a Western flavor to sedate Central Park South.

Popular extracts from drama, opera, operetta and ballet have been assembled for the City Center's annual Showcase benefit tonight at 131 West Fifty-fifth Street. The program has been dedicated to Tallulah Bankhead, who will appear with Sandy Campbell in a scene from "A Streetcar Named Desire."
While most people used the week-end to relax, there was considerable activity in the advertising business.

PARIS, April 23 -- Last Nov. 16 this column suggested that Khrushchev might be deliberately fomenting a Berlin scare in order to divert our own attentions from the Middle East and to divert world attentions from the recent Communist fiasco in the Taiwan Strait. The argument presented was as follows:
LIME ROCK, Conn., April 26 -- Rain washed out most of the sports car racing program on the 1.5-mile Lime Rock course today.
Considering that a normal twenty-four-hour day has 86,400 seconds, one must conclude that yesterday was badly shortchanged when one-half of the nation's population turned the clock one hour ahead.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- The grain futures market seldom has had so few significant commercial influences as it experienced last week but the volume of trading probably was the greatest in several months.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The initiative of Senator Henry M. Jackson, as reported in The New York Times of April 17, in planning to investigate the policy-making processes of the National Security Council, deserves wide popular support. Upon its success or failure may well depend the fate of this country.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- A Defense Department official has told Congress that the department is studying whether there was a "breach of security" in the release of information on the secret Argus atomic test project.
A play Eugene O'Neill thought he had destroyed shortly before his death will be produced next season, but anyone who wants to see it will have to be in Sweden.

More than 500 persons, crowded into an L-shape Greenwich Village basement, listened yesterday afternoon in almost total darkness as four loudspeakers simultaneously poured forth a montage of scraps of sound. Among other things suggested were lions roaring, canvas ripping, pigs grunting, dogs barking, air bubbling up through water, crashing furniture, airplane motors, riveting, police whistles and Bronx cheers.

On April 24, 1775, an express rider galloped at full speed through Lawrenceville, N. J., en route to Philadelphia bearing the news that the firing had started at Lexington. The American Revolution had begun.
PEIPING, April 26 (Reuters-Communist China's Parliament met in private today and approved a candidate for chief of state, the position now held by 65-year-old Mao Tse-tung.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am sure Homer Bigart in his article "Virginia Integration Splits State Leaders" which appeared in the April 19 issue of The New York Times did not intend to give a misleading impression concerning my editorial which appeared in the March, 1959, issue of the Virginia Journal of Education.

Mathematicians made news twice last week as the solution of two historic problems was announced at a meeting in this city. For most of us, no doubt, the subjects of these two problems, automorphic finite groups and Latin squares, are rather remote. But we are willing to take the word of professional mathematicians that two important new steps have been taken across the mathematical frontiers.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The reliability of the Navy, in view of obsolescence of ships and reportedly inadequate maintenance and repairs of the fleet, was questioned at recent hearings of a House Appropriations subcommittee.
ALBANY, N. Y., April 26 (AP) -- The State Tax Department reported today that 877 persons had voluntarily revealed this month that they owed a total $77,535 in overdue income taxes.
A statement to help Americans avoid heart attacks and strokes has been endorsed by 101 scientists engaged in research related to arteriosclerosis.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Measurements in the hands of United States scientists support repeated speculation that the intensive Soviet nuclear tests of last fall have resulted in a substantial increase in fall-out over the Northern Hemisphere.

PARIS, April 26 -- France's "grand electors," voting in indirect Senatorial elections, gave the Fifth Republic today its first Senate, with a conservative majority closely resembling that of the upper chamber of the old regime.
Two cousins were accused by the police yesterday of holding up six Queens supermarkets in the last six months for a total of $40,000.
President Eisenhower's proposal to settle the problem of suspension of nuclear tests in phases was endorsed yesterday by panelists in The New York Times Youth Forum.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 26 (AP) -- Mike Souchak withstood a challenge by Art Wall Jr. today and won the $46,620 Tournament of Champions golf tournament in a dramatic wind-up.

LONDON, April 26 -- Planes of four countries are searching for a British aircraft that vanished near the Turkish-Soviet border Thursday while carrying secret equipment to Australia for the Woomera rocket range.

Domestic cotton prices ended mixed last week for the fourth consecutive week. At the close of trading Friday active futures contracts traded on the New York Cotton Exchange were 18 points (90 cents a bale) off to 65 points ($3.25 a bale) up.
HAZARD, Ky., April 26 (AP) -- National Guardsmen with fixed bayonets patrolled trouble spots in the eastern coal fields today, as more dynamite blasts occurred.

Last January Mayor Wagner assured the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association that the city would cooperate with the redevelopment plan for downtown Manhattan that the association had proposed the preceding October. Now the city has given tangible evidence of that cooperation through the action of the City Planning Commission in bringing out for public discussion a revised master plan of arterial highways and major streets in lower Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- In six new cases the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is asking the Supreme Court to stop what it terms "stratagems" by Southern states to put it out of business.

DURING the first four months of 1959 I read only two novels that I expect to remember long, only two that seem to me worth enthusiastically urging others to read. The first is "The Watch That Ends the Night," by Hugh MacLennan, which was published last February. The second is "The Rape of the Fair Country,"* by Alexan der Cordell, which was published last week.

Sales and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company in the twelve weeks ended on March 22 exceeded those of any similar period in the company's history, T. J. Hargrave, chairman, disclosed in the quarterly report released today.
THE state's atomic power future has been put in the hands of a champion of faster development of atoms for peace.
New York City has "reasserted its position of importance in the operation of waterfront facilities," Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, declared yesterday.
The State Labor Department reported yesterday that factories employing metal-trades workers in the state were lagging in training programs.
More than 100 members of the Bolshoi ballet relaxed in the Bronx Zoo yesterday.

In 1870 the first train robbery in the West occurred on the Central Pacific Railroad. Between that year and 1933, when one man held up the Sunset Limited and got shot for his pains, millions of dollars in gold, silver, currency and valuables were rifled from mail cars by desperadoes.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 26 (AP) -- Economics Minister Ibrahim Kubba said today Iraq and the foreign-owned Iraq Petroleum Company had agreed to increase the production and export of Iraqi oil.

MONTREAL, April 26 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba received a revolutionary hero's welcome to Montreal today. He was greeted at the airport by a crowd shouting "vivas" and about 5,000 French-speaking Canadians hailed him in and around the Queen Elizabeth Hotel on his arrival downtown.
LONDON, April 26 -- The stock market was relatively quiet last week but the general trend of prices was upward.
CHICAGO, April 26 (UPI) -- Jack Sanford checked the Chicago Cubs on four hits today in pitching the San Francisco Giants to a 3-2 victory, his third of the season.
A prompt and thorough analysis of the city's 1959-60 expense budget by the Temporary State Commission on Governmental Operations of New York City was urged yesterday by Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs.

BONN, Germany, April 26 -- The British Government, in a major revision of its plan to limit arms and forces in Central Europe, has proposed a zone for aerial inspection extending from Paris to Moscow, qualified diplomatic sources reported today.
MENDOZA, Argentina, Monday, April 27 -- President Arturo Frondizi's Intransigent Radical party suffered a sharp defeat in yesterday's Mendoza Province elections, returns early today showed.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- The three executives who founded the investment banking house of Blyth Co., Inc., here in April, 1914, played a top part in marking the company's forty-fifth anniversary over the week-end.
A $1,700,000 contract to develop a radar system to supply altitude data on aircraft automatically to air traffic controllers was announced yesterday by the Federal Aviation Agency.

The twin four-story apartment buildings at 2539-41 Forty-fourth Street, Astoria, Queens, have been purchased by a syndicate of investors headed by George Kraslow, Joseph R. Ruffino of the Kraham Realty Company, Kew Gardens, was the broker.

HENDERSON, N. C., April 26 (UPI) -- Mayor Carroll Singleton outlined a seven-point program tonight aimed at curbing strike violence, but union leaders in the twenty-four-week dispute here turned him down on most points.
Federal mediators will make new effort today to resolve the deadlock in contract negotiations between union printers and the Publishers Association of New York City.
The largest exhibition of contemporary Eskimo sculpture ever shown outside Canada opened in New York yesterday -- a consequence of an Air Force chaplain's tour of duty in Japan eleven years ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 25 -- India's government-administered railway system will bring into the national treasury an estimated net profit of $500,000,000 during the country's second five-year plan, ending in 1962.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Department of Commerce announced today that the national income rose to a record annual rate of $374,000,000,000 in the last quarter of 1958.
PARIS, April 27 -- President Charles de Gaulle and the Government struck back at critics of their Algerian policy today by demanding that all persons "with common sense" get behind it.
Representatives of two major teacher organizations will meet today to consider possible work stoppages' to reinforce their demands for higher salaries.

BOSTON, April 27 (AP) -- A surgeon removed almost eight square inches of skin from the thigh of John Thomas, the world record-holder indoors in the high jump, today. Then he shaped and stitched it, closing an unhealed wound on the top of the athlete's left foot.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 (AP) -- The Government dropped charges today against one of eighteen men charged with defrauding newspapers in puzzle contests.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- The other day a movie producer here received a letter from a man who said he had done time in twenty-seven jails. This, said the writer, qualified him to do publicity for the producer's movie.

Nat Gluck, a New York stockholder in the General Realty and Utilities Corporation, has sent a letter to all shareholders in the real estate concern soliciting their support in pressing a stockholders' suit against the management.
GENEVA, April 27 -- David A. Morse, director general of the International Labor Organization, reports that the likelihood of major depressions is receding.
The National Broadcasting Company television network was off the air for two hours yesterday morning when technicians refused to handle a Dave Garroway program that had been recorded in Paris.
European industrialists are viewing the Common Market much as "racing cyclists before the start of the famous Tour de France," premier speed and endurance race.
Although they were miles away from their Alpine town, school went on for thirteen Swiss boys yesterday almost, but not quite, as usual.

THE final, installment of "the Untouchables," the story of the campaign of Treasury Department agents to break up the Al Capone mob, developed as expected last night: A succession of violent killings and gunplay that ultimately culminated in the conviction of the gangster for income tax evasion.

THERE is only one man in New York who can keep women waiting while their hair drips and not provoke a mutiny. He is Enzo da Perugia, an Italian hairdresser. He commands such loyalty among his clientele that even the most imperious customer, waiting her turn, has fretted about, but never forsaken, his salon.
The trend of bond prices was mixed yesterday as the public market for fixed-income securities strove for adjustment to the setbacks of the last fortnight.

The two-story building at 38 East Fourteenth Street has been purchased by Simco Shoe Stores from 5th and 14th Realties, Inc. Helmsley-Spear, Inc., was the broker. One unit of the retail shoe chain has been a tenant in the building at the corner of University Place.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Senate floor amendments to the Kennedy-Ervin bill were encouraging principally because they reflected the Senate's sense that it has become politically necessary to acknowledge that union leaders have abused the social-economic monopoly of organized labor.

NEW DELHI, India, April 27 -- The Government has permitted individual newspapers to enter into bilateral arrangements with any foreign news agency for distribution of foreign news in India, it was announced today.

TRENTON, April 27 -- The Republican majority in the State Senate today voted unanimously to withhold the approval of legislation on commuter transit until after a barter talk with Governor Rockefeller of New York.

Sparkling performances by electronic, drug and rubber issues gave the stock market a bright tone yesterday. Although more stocks fell than rose, The New York Times combined and industrial stock averages pushed through to new historic highs.

ATLANTA, April 27 -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) formally disapproved here tonight the recommendation of a National Council of Churches study conference urging United States recognition of Communist China and its admission to the United Nations.

Before they criticize the new format of the Penn Relays, metropolitan track coaches were urged yesterday to discuss recommendations for revising the set-up. George T. Eastment, Manhattan College coach, made this suggestion at the gathering of track writers at Leone's.
BOSTON, April 27 (AP) -- Ivy League football coaches agreed today to seek changes in the positioning and assignment of officials and permission to attend all clinics.
POPLARVILLE, Miss., April 27 -- Gov. J. P. Coleman indicated today that progress had been made toward a solution of the kidnapping from a jail of a 23-year-old Negro by a masked lynch mob.
The Case of the Confused Robin confronted ornithologists here yesterday.
SEATTLE, April 27 (AP) -- A silver and orange 600-mile-an-hour jet will be turned over to the Air Force Thursday. It is the first of three identical planes for the President and other high officials.
The British will experiment with bold, luminous paint markings on commercial planes next year to combat the hazards of poor visibility and traffic congestion.

Governor Rockefeller has among his most immediate tasks the initiation of the commission study of the New York City government. This inquiry was spawned by the controversy in Albany over the fairness of state aid to the city, and the nature of taxing powers to be granted. It will be made by the Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York, composed of nine members.
The annual grants of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, usually conferred on fifteen recipients who have distinguished themselves in the arts, will go this year to eighteen persons.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- The Independent Bankers Association opened its twenty-fifth annual convention today by taking issue with a proposal of the American Bankers Association.
The reorganized Debutante Cotillion Versailles Ball has announced its Paris and American committees for the event, which will take place at Versailles, France, on July 3.

At the twenty-ninth annual luncheon of the Musicians Emergency Fund and its auxiliary organizations, the Hospitalized Veterans Service, Artur Rubinstein, concert pianist and vice president and trustee of the fund, will receive an award for the many services he has contributed in the past.
NEWARK, April 27 -- The New York Central Railroad sought permission here today to discontinue its West Shore passenger service.

Consolidated earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the first quarter of 1959 were 14 per cent higher than they were in the period of last year, Eugene Holman, chairman, reported yesterday.
An expense budget of $2,174,946,957, the highest in the city's history, was unanimously adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The nation's teacher shortage is easing somewhat in science, mathematics and foreign languages, the National Education Association reported today.
CLIFTON, N. J., April 27 -Two armed men robbed the Rizzuto-Berra Bowling Alleys of $6.000 in week-end receipts early this morning.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 27 (AP) -- Joseph Barbara Sr. sat silently in a wheelchair today as his attorney pleaded him innocent to charges of evading $14,600 in Federal income taxes.
Twenty-two foreign police officials started a two-week course in instruction techniques yesterday at the City Police Academy, 7 Hubert Street.
Both new orders and shipments of the machine tool industry increased last month, continuing an upward trend that began last fall and persisted since, except for setbacks in November and January.
YONKERS, April 27 -- Three armed robbers held up the Greystone branch of the First National Bank in Yonkers today before the 10 A. M. opening. They escaped with $49,093 in cash.

Sol Steinhardt, described by the police and the District Attorney's office as the top jewel fence in the United States, was sentenced yesterday to five to ten years in prison for receiving stolen jewels.

LONDON, April 27 - Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd said today that the process of reunification of Germany might well include greater scope for contact between the Eastern and Western regions of the country.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter set out today on his first major mission as a Cabinet officer -- a Western conference on diplomatic strategy in Paris.

WAR IS A PRIVATE AFFAIR,"* by Edmund G. Love, is the finest book of its kind since "Tales of the South Pacific." And it is funnier. It should make an even better musical comedy than the adaptation of George Bernard Shaw's Cinderella charade, "My Fair Lady."

A counseling service designed to help communities in Northern New Jersey attract industries and commercial enterprises has been set up by a group that includes representatives of the real estate field, banking, construction and other industries.
Negotiations to avert a printers' strike against ten New York newspapers were recessed yesterday until tomorrow.

IF a pianist wants to "go for broke," let him put his best foot forward by opening his recital program with the Bach-Busoni Chaconne, followed by Reger's Variations and Fugue on a Theme of Bach, Op. 81.
ROME, April 27 -- Pope John XXIII appealed tonight for world-wide players to the Virgin Mary for the forthcoming Ecumenical Council of the Roman Catholic Church.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 27 (AP) -- Floyd Patterson and Brian London neared the end of heavy training today for their heavyweight title bout Friday night.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -The moon, long viewed as a cold, dead satellite of the earth, was pictured in a new theory today as an active body with a hot interior and an erupting, shifting surface.

Steel production declined slightly last week from the record level of the week before. But an increase to a new peak was scheduled for this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Yesterday's news that Liu Shao-chi is. Communist China's new head of state, succeeding Mao Tse-tung, was really notice only that a formality had been observed. The selection was not made by the "parliament" now meeting in Peiping, but by the small group of Chinese Communist party leaders who met in secret session several weeks ago.

ARLES, France, April 27 -- The French are ill at ease with bullfighting. From Marseille to Bordeaux there is a fight in one French town or another every Sunday. Like the fight held here yesterday, they are identical to fights in Spain.

The Peacock Ball of the Lila Motley Cancer Foundation, Inc., will be held in the Terrace Room and Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Saturday. It will benefit the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center. A highlight of the dinner dance will be the coronation at midnight of Hermione Gingold, British comedienne, as queen of the ball.

BONN, Germany, April 27 -- West German officials are at Chancellor Adenauer's retreat at Lake Como, in Italy, to make the vital decisions on Bonn's attitude toward the Big Four foreign ministers' meeting.
The New York Coliseum has been visited by more than 6,000,000 persons since it opened three years ago.

New York City's Hudson Celebration Committee announced yesterday the appointment of Jean Dalrymple as coordinator for its performing arts program and special events. The celebration marks the 350th anniversary of the discovery of the Hudson River.

Assured of the full confidence and accompanied by the hopes and good wishes of the whole American people, Secretary Herter has flown to Paris on his first major mission as administrator of American foreign policy. He will, of course, work under the general direction of President Eisenhower, who bears the constitutional responsibility for all decisions and will have the seasoned advice of Mr. Dulles as his special consultant.
YONKERS, April 27 -- C. J. McKlyo, Joe Hylan's once-a-weekgelding -- so-called because he paces and wins once a week here -- captured the featured Class A pace in the rain at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -Are there monsters who prowl the ocean depths, too evasive for capture by present-day trawls? Some of the world's leading oceanographers believe this may be the case.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The same problem of Soviet bloc representation that scuttled the United Nations approach to the problems of outer space now threatens the scientific group that was working toward similar ends.

Former President Harry S. Truman urged a better understanding of the Presidency yesterday. He gave a lecture based on his experiences as President to 1,200 students and faculty members at Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Eisenhower vetoed his first bill of the current session of Congress today. In doing so, he raised the possibility of a Democratic attempt to override his action.
In comparison with what Celeste Holm has tackled previously, her next stage appearance will be somewhat different.
The State Industrial Commissioner last night reversed his decision to end a special state investigation into reported strike-breaking activity in the newspaper industry.

Giovanni Scalise, who had been held as a material witness in the murder of his brother Frank in June, 1957, was discharged yesterday. He was escorted by immigration officials to a plane that departed for Paris from New York International Airport, at Idlewild Queens.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce named five men and two women as "great living Americans" tonight.
HAVANA, April 27 -- Premier Fidel Castro will speak to the Cuban people by radio tomorrow morning from his plane as he flies over the island on his way to Buenos Aires.
When a Soviet city wants to blow its horn these days, it outlaws horn blowing on its streets.

Twentieth Century-Fox Film corporation has entered into an agreement to sell its movie studio property in Los Angeles a subsidiary of Webb Knapp, Inc., for a sum that would eventually total about 6,110,000.

Pacific Light Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday that one of the warmest winters on record in its southern California service area had adversely affected first quarter gas sales and revenues. Operating expenses were 11 per cent above the year-ago level, but the rise in gross revenues was "primarily due to new customers and higher rates," according to Robert W. Miller, chairman.

Washington Gas Light Company today is offfering to holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for 100,386 shares of $4.60 cumulative serial preferred stock at $100 a share on the basis of one share for each fourteen common shapes held of record of April 27.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Treasury bill rate dipped sharply this week, in advance of the Treasury's refunding announcement due on Thursday, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- Senator Humphrey said after conferring with Senator Johnson: "We'll do everything in our power to override," and declared:

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration warned the public today to avoid using a contact-lens cleanser that the agency said was contaminated with a potentially dangerous form of bacteria.
CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Southern Pacific Company reported yesterday a net income of $18,182,062 for the first quarter of this year, up from $12,023,488 a year earlier, and a gain in gross revenues of $14,203,472. The gross was $162,606,893, compared with $148,398,421 in the 1958 period.
The Institute of Pacific Relations lost two motions in Federal Court yesterday in its suit to regain a tax-exempt status as an educational organization.

Whether there is any significant permanent increase in moving-picture making in New York City is something for the future to determine, but it is interesting to learn from a report by the city's Department of Commerce and Public Events that there is considerable film making here and that last year the industry spent $100,000,000 for production and processing in New York.
RICHMOND, Va., April 27 (AP) -- The police obtained warrants today against nine young white men said to be involved in the shotgun shooting of six Negro boys.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 (UPI) -- The league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers opened an Eastern swing with a five-run outburst in the first inning tonight and coasted to a 9-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. Don Drysdale held the Pirates to six hits.

The Henry Street Settlement is sponsoring the second annual Blue Chip Ball, to be held on Saturday at Oscar's Delmonico, William and Beaver Streets, which opened in 1834 as the first Delmonico Restaurant in New York.
Ceremonies on the steps of the Forty-second Street Public Library will usher in New York's second annual Salute to Spring at 7:30 o'clock tomorrow night.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Children who kill usually give warning of their intentions, a leading child psychiatrist said here today.
For the first time since 1918, New Yorkers may spend a summer without concerts at Lewisohn Stadium.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., April 27 (AP) -- The Air Force has approved plans of the Air Force Academy Foundation, Inc., to build a 40,000-seat football stadium at the Academy.
Carmine G. De Sapio said last night in the course of a debate with Thomas K. Finletter that voting machines would be used in contested primary elections this September.
Construction contracts in March, buoyed by an increase in single-family homes, soared 23 per cent above the like month of a year ago to a record, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 27 -- The twenty-ninth Festival of American Music, organized and directed by Dr. Howard Hanson, director of the Eastman School of Music, opened in the Eastman Theatre tonight with a performance of two one-act operas.
The Senatorial elections in France were settled in advance. There could be no surprise about them. This is really the only important feature of the elections for outsiders to understand.
The seventy-three-day American Bowling Congress tournament, which ended last Sunday in St. Louis, was a tough one for many bowlers. To Bill Pace it was strictly a hard-luck affair.

Record sales and a 68 per cent increase in earnings were achieved by the Allied Chemical Corporation in the first quarter of this year, Glen B. Miller, president, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, April 27 -The Communist party, and its front organizations were outlawed by the Government today.

LONDON, April 27 -- Industrials continued to advance in the stock market today pushing the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary stocks to a new peak at 226.7, a gain of half a point on the day.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, took strong issue last night with those who would concentrate education "upon the adjustment of the individual to society."

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 27 -- The Icelandic Government has warned the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that it cannot guarantee Iceland's continued support of the alliance unless Britain halts her armed defiances of this country's twelve-mile fishery limits.
An experimental training program to broaden the executive ability of top aides to city department heads was adopted at City Hall yesterday.
The outstanding statement of Prof. Wilbur J. Cohen concerning welfare laws which appeared in The Times recently raised a question in my mind which Mr. Cohen does not comment on.

Harold McCracken, author of "George Catlin and the Old Frontier," which will be published next October, was incorrectly identified yesterday in these notes. His publishers, Dial Press, in announcing his book, said that he was director of the Whitney Museum of American Art. Lloyd Goodrich is director of that museum.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Defense Department objected today to any easing of the renegotiation law for recovering excess profits on Government defense contracts.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The American Bar Association told Congress today that it was strongly supporting the fight to strengthen internal security laws, but it denied that it was an enemy of the Supreme Court and its controversial decisions in the security fields.

Events today: Handel's "Judas Maccabaeus," presented by the National Orchestral Association and the Oratorio Society of New York, Carnegie Hall 8; Mario Miranda, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Arthur Tennent, tenor, Carnegie Recital Hall 8:30.

Prices of wool tumbled yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops fell 1.8 to 3 cents a pound and grease wool dropped 1.6 to 2.5 cents. The market attempted to rally during the day but closed near the lows.
Concern was expressed in shipping circles yesterday over whether the Public Health Service would be able to continue to assure proper sanitation in this country's merchant marine.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, ill with cancer, is no longer getting X-ray treatments. He is receiving pain killers.
President Eisenhower will speak here May 14 at a dinner during a three-day symposium on how this country can strengthen its support of basic research.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 27 -- The Soviet Union charged today that the United States had "deliberately" called a meeting of the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space "on the eve" of the foreign ministers conference in Geneva May 11.
TEIJI TAKAI, a Japanese painter who came to the United States in 1954, is having his second one-man show here at the Poindexter Gallery, 21 West Fifty-sixth Street.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 27 -- Belgium and the Netherlands began to argue today before the International Court of Justice their conflicting claims to thirty-five acres of land along their joint border.

Today's new film is "Aparajito" ("The Unvanquished"), which follows "Pather Panchali" as the second part of a trilogy produced and directed by India's Satyajit Ray, at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, at Twelfth Street.

Dr. Linus Pauling, a biochemist and winner of a Nobel prize in chemistry, estimated last night that the United States had a stockpile of 75,000 nuclear weapons. He said this was twenty times the number of bombs that were needed to annihilate all the inhabitants on the earth.
Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday a gain of 32 per cent in its March 31 share value over that of a year earlier.
MONTREAL, April 27 (UPI) -- Four members of the Stanley Cup champion Montreal Canadiens and two New York Rangers were named today to the 1958-59 National Hockey League all-star team.

The foreign policy of the United States is shaped and determined so largely by our needs for security and preservation of world peace that no abrupt change, even in the person of the occupant of the White House, could result in a significant change in that policy today.

There seem to be daily announcements these past few weeks of new functions and achievements for The Machine. At first such accomplishments produced public reactions of satisfaction and pleased anticipation -- soon all the unpleasant tasks would be performed by gadgets, leaving humans more time for the pursuit of happiness.

THE meetings of the American Institute of Decorators, now holding its national conference here, are closed to the public. But there is hardly a place on land, sea or air where Americans are not confronted with the work of institute members and that of their nonmember colleagues.
An inquiry into the validity of the new state law creating five more City Court justices in Brooklyn has been ordered by Mayor Wagner. Corporation Counsel Charles H. Tenney is making the study.
The unusually cold, open and windy winter is being blamed by horticulturists for the worst winter kill of ornamental shrubs, plants and trees in "thirty to thirty-five years."

The Post Office was accused yesterday by the New York Civil Liberties Union of applying a "test of obscenity by inference.'' The department had barred from the mails an advertising postcard reproducing a Goya painting.

It was a gray day at the Jamaica race track yesterday. There was a sprinkle of cool rain throughout the afternoon. There were no puddles on the mile course except on the outside where horses aren't supposed to run.

LOUISVILLE, April 27 -- The Derby Trial, for the first time in its history, will be run in two divisions tomorrow. Wathen R. Knebelkamp, president of Churchill Downs, made the decision today to present two sections of the one-mile test in response to requests by several trainers.

HONG KONG, April 27 -- The election of Liu Shao-chi to succeed Mao Tse-tung as chief of state of the People's Republic of China today further emphasizes the position Mr. Liu has long occupied as Mr. Mao's closest collaborator.
IT is not possible to set inflexible rules for collecting a good library of cookbooks. The cook's own predilection in the culinary field is the best guide.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 (UPI) -- Mitchell Ostwind, 27 years old, who, with Earl Belle. controlled a financial operation once represented as worth millions, surrendered to Federal authorities today. Ostwind had been in Rio de Janeiro since July 4 when the paper financial empire he and Belle controlled began to crumble.
GENEVA, April 27 -- The Soviet Union formally adopted as its own today a British suggestion for ending the stalemate over a ban testing on nuclear weapons.
The New York Board of Rabbis yesterday took issue with the head of the American Council for Judaism Philanthropic Fund for his criticism of the United Jewish Appeal.

From The Times of April 23 I learn that the National Committee on Radiation Protection and Measurements of the United States Bureau of Standards has doubled its recommended maximum permissible amount of strontium 90 in the bones of a human being.
NEW DELHI, India, April 27 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from a statement on Tibet in Parliament today by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru:

WOMEN who do not live in Hawaii have delicious daydreams about it. Women who do live in Hawaii pluck orchids for the breakfast table, swim twice a day and collect Orientalia without pinching themselves to make sure it is not a dream.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Eisenhower took his appeal for the foreign aid program to business men today.
The Actors Fund collected 320 pints of blood on the opening day yesterday of its 1959 blood bank drive at the Astor Hotel.

DETROIT, April 27 (AP) -- The nation's auto industry has produced 2,086,847 cars so far this year, compared with 1,508,150 in the comparable 1958 period. The industry built 134,418 cars last week, compared with 135,934 in the preceding week, and 58,664 in the 1958 week.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 27 -- Prof. John E. de Quay, of the Catholic party, after trying for a month to form a Cabinet, asked Queen Juliana today to be relieved of the task.
LONDON, April 27 -- An Egyptian note extending recognition to a British property commission is believed to fall far short of the British Government's expectations.
BUENO AIRES, April 27 -Representatives of the twenty-one American republics meet here tomorrow to consider the progress made in inter-American economic relations in the last year.
WARSAW, April 27 -- The foreign ministers of the Communist bloc took just three and a half hours today to whip through a "review" of some of the world's most important political problems.

The Florida Development Commission is planning to borrow $4,750,000 in the bond market on May 20 through the sale of road and bridge revenue bonds. The securities will come due serially from 1961 to 1988.
PARIS, April 27 -- The Cabinet decided today to submit to Parliament the first major reform of the Napoleonic Code since it was promulgated in 1804.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- A House committee gave a cool reception today to anti-nepotism proposals that would put the spotlight on legislators who carried relatives on their Congressional payrolls.
Emile Griffith, an undefeated West Side welterweight, recorded his eleventh professional victory last night by winning a unanimous decision over Mel Barker of Austin, Tex., at St. Nicholas Arena.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa charged last night that the proposed $500,000,000 school bond issue for the city was a "hoax."
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -A House Agriculture subcommittee tentatively approved today a bill increasing the price support level for wheat but cutting production.
A LOUD "brava" for Shirley Sudock.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 27 -- The State Supreme Court ruled, 4-3, today that the Legislature had not exceeded its police powers when it provided for the closing of public schools to avoid integration.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -The Secretary of Labor urged the House of Representatives today to add restrictions on picketing and secondary boycotts to the labor reform bill.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 27 -- A bill to help Lyndon B. Johnson in next year's political campaigns won the approval of the Texas Legislature late today.

Representatives of the major steel companies and their 500,000 unionized employes will open this year's most crucial wage negotiations here next Tuesday. There will be no chair in the conference room for Uncle Sam, but he is likely to play as vital a role in the proceedings as any of the direct participants.

The Olympic Rowing Committee has voted to hold the Pan-American trials for eight-oared crews on Onondaga Lake, Syracuse, the week-end following the championships of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association there on June 20.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- The Department of Africulture announced today that 1959 premiums in price support rates for high-grade cotton would be slightly narrower than those of last year, and that discounts for lower grades would be wider.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 27 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba arrived here amid cheers today and decided to stay overnight, apparently to confer with his brother.

The election of Ellmore C. Patterson as a senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York has been announced by Henry C. Alexander chairman. Mr. Patterson was formerly a vice president of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., whose merger with the Guaranty Trust Company became effective over the week-end.

OSLO, Norway, April 27 -- Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange charged today that the Soviet Government was interfering in Norway's internal affairs. He said it was trying to make the Norwegian people "distrust the honesty of their Government."
The former chief of the Manhattan complaint bureau of the Department of Buildings was indicted yesterday for conspiracy and for taking $20 in bribes.

BACK in the old days, when baseball clubs depended exclusively on gate receipts for revenue, they shared the box-office loot in rather equitable fashion. The visiting team was content to collect 30 cents on each ticket. The stronger its appeal as an attraction, the greater was its collection. It was a fair arrangement and there were no complaints.

A complaint that the visiting bullpen at the Stadium puts the Yankees' rivals at a disadvantage came to light yesterday. Casey Stengel, the manager of the Bombers, reported that visiting clubs had objected to the facilities for relief pitchers, claiming that the Yankees' bullpen is superior.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Senator Wayne Morse and five other Democratic liberals today forced a delay until tomorrow on a final Senate vote on the nomination of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce to be ambassador to Brazil.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- The Giants were rained out of their scheduled Eastern opener against the Phillies tonight. The postponement allowed Bill Rigney to give an interested audience a complete rundown on the San Francisco club.
The annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies last week managed, as usual, to be non-controversial. However, David Ogilvy offered an idea that created interest.

While members of the junior board of the George Junior Republic dance at the annual benefit ball in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Friday night, young "citizens" of the Republic will have their own party at the school in Freeville, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The United Steelworkers cited today an "enormous error" in the Labor Department's calculation of the steel industry's productivity.
NEW DELHI, India, April 27 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru reproached Communist China today for resorting to "the language of the cold war" in its current campaign of vilification against India.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Railroads operating west of the Mississippi River told the Interstate Commerce Commerce today that they would have to have an increase in pay for hauling mail.
PEIPING, April 27 -- Liu Shaochi, a leading theoretician of the Chinese Communist party, was elected today to succeed Mao Tse-tung as Communist China's chief of state.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The State Department announced tonight that the United States was supplying Panama with small arms to help her repel invaders.

In a letter in The Times of April 17 State Senator William T. Conklin stated that "the charge that the 'State Legislature continues to deprive the people of the City of New York of * * * an equal voice in the government of the state' has its basis in fact and can only emanate from a partisan voice."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points up to 11 points off yesterday, with the far months showing same easiness. A point is 5 cents a bale.
THERE is disagreement even in official biographies about the age of Liu Shao-chi, Communist China's new chief of state. The year of his birth is usually given as 1898, and sometimes as 1905.
BOSTON, April 27 (UPI) -The Democratic National Chairman urged Congressional Democrats today to vote more foreign aid for under-developed nations than President Eisenhower had asked.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Port of New York Authority asked Congress today for $8,450,000, almost $3,000,000 more than was budgeted by President Eisenhower, for twelve harbor and canal improvement projects.
THE circling and raucous calling of press agents, like gulls over a school of bait, has indicated in the last few days that certain things are going on in hunting and fishing.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- A veteran educator predicted today that by 1970 "an acute shortage" of college instructors would force drastic changes in both teaching and study methods.

This is go-to-annual-meeting day for a sizable segment of the business community. No fewer than sixty companies whose shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange will make, in person, their yearly report to stockholders.
Joseph Jarkowsky, an 18-year-old eyewitness to the fatal beating of Julio Ramos on May 30 in Jefferson Park, yesterday placed all the defendants at the scene of the slaying.

First-quarter earnings of the Armstrong Cork Company were 62 per cent higher than those of the same period of last year, and set a record high for any quarter in the company's history, C. J. Backstrand, president, reported yesterday.
Ingemar Johansson, fishing boat operator, sports car enthusiast, golfer and excavation contractor, arrived here yesterday for his heavyweight title fight June 25 against Floyd Patterson.
Mayor Wagner ordered an investigation yesterday to determine whether unauthorized persons were making use of courtesy cards issued by the city to representatives of foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message on the veto of a bill to permit the Rural Electrification Administration to make loans without the approval the Secretary of Agriculture:

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Eisenhower expressed the hope today that there would be "swift apprehension of the guilty persons" in the case of the abduction of a Negro prisoner from a jail cell in Poplarville, Miss.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Bernard Goldfine came back to Washington today for a legal replay of "electronic eavesdropping."

LONDON, April 28 -- Industrial shares were irregular on the stock exchange today, mainly as a result of increased selling at the end of a profitable account period. Demand became more selective, but the steady buying of leaders lifted prices again in late dealings after the profit-taking had been absorbed.
POPLARVILLE, Miss., April 28 -- Hope was running out here today for a quick solution of Parker's abduction and suspected lynching.

NEWARK, April 28 -- The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad received permission today to discontinue eighty-two non-rush-hour and week-end trains. The trains serve areas in Essex, Morris, Union and Somerset Counties.

After an ownership of a week, the five-and-a-half-story apartment building at 2545 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been resold by Harry Horwitz, realty operator, to an investor. The building contains six stores and forty-two apartments and is on a plot 102 by 100 feet.

Tomorrow brokerage concerns all around the nation will be thinking of three little words, signified by "G. T. C." These apply to "good-till-canceled" orders carried on stock specialists' books. These orders to buy or sell stocks at a fixed price are good indefinitely, or until a prospective investor says, "call it off."
The city is following a policy of spend and repent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared last night in attacking the expanding capital budgets.
ALREADY the misanthropic surf fisherman, distrustfully avoiding all human society, is pursuing his lonely and uncomfortable sport along the beaches of Long Island and New Jersey.
LOUISVILLE, April 28 -- C. V. Whitney, owner of Silver Spoon, decided today that he would run the filly in Saturday's Kentucky Derby.
Does anybody remember Quemoy and Matsu? If not, is it a good idea to have forgotten, even in the tension of the Berlin crisis?
" New Yorkers can tour the Soviet Union for half a dollar this summer," in the words of a Russian describing plans for the Russian Exposition to be held at the Coliseum from June 30 to Aug. 10.
Several weeks before the announcer at the Aqueduct race track sounds the familiar "the horses are on the track," a $500,000 advertising and promotion program will have started.

The Philco International Corporation leased a large space in the new building at 630 Third Avenue, corner of Forty-first Street, for its New York office. Now at 420 Lexington Avenue, the company will move Friday. Arthur Collins Jr. of Collins, Tuttle Co., was the broker in the deal.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- The Reading Company reported first-quarter earnings of $232,796 today, compared with $34,141 a year ago.

The Macy newspaper chain protested yesterday the decision of Martin P. Catherwood, State Industrial Commissioner, to authorize the resumption of a special investigation into alleged strike-breaking activities in the newspaper industry.
The Phoenix Theatre, currently engaged in a precarious struggle for survival, yesterday launched a subscription drive for the 1959-60 season with an "On Stage" luncheon at its home downtown.

LANSING, Mich., April 28 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams said today that Michigan would be unable to meet its legislative payroll this week because of the state's cash shortage. The Supreme Court payroll and the state's share of circuit court salaries, due to be paid on Friday, will also be delayed, he said.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Republican leaders, from the White House down, dispelled any doubt today about the rocky future of the Kennedy labor reform bill. The bill was sponsored by John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Moves toward a Federal program for the prevention of juvenile delinquency took place on both sides of Capitol Hill today.

The coolness of United States labor leaders toward Fidel Castro was reflected last week in a brush-off of efforts by associates of the Cuban Premier to arrange a meeting between him and New York union chiefs.
ATLANTA, April 28 -- Following is a statement on "Christian Harmony in Race Relations," which was approved here today by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern).
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- Neele E. Stearns resigned today as president of the Crane Company and Thomas M. Evans was elected chairman and chief executive officer.
Mario Miranda, a Chilean pianist who has won awards in Europe, made his debut last night in Town Hall.
The National Broadcasting Company filed a $500,000 damage suit against a technicians union yesterday because of a work stoppage that began Monday.

Prices of high-grade corporate bonds took another slide in the secondary market yesterday. The slim margin by which Monday's values had been maintained gave way following the bidding for $20,000,000 of call-protected bonds of the Public Service Company of Colorado.
THE modern American woman now displays not the three faces of Eve, but four.
A 67-year-old retired newspaper and magazine mail handler was sentenced yesterday in Federal court to six months in prison and fined $10,000 for income-tax evasion.
A FESTIVE dinner for six can be prepared at a total cost of $8, if advantage is taken of foods that are now reasonable in price.
A bill to increase the city's tax on restaurant checks of $1 or more from 3 to 5 per cent was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council. The vote was 23 to 0.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senate voted 64 to 29 today to override President Eisenhower's first veto of the session.
IN its production of "Giselle," which had its first presentation at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, the Bolshoi Ballet has given us another superb piece of choreographic art.

IF the world does not fall apart within the next month or so, 700,000 Americans are expected to tour Europe this year. More than half of them will be women -- some in groups, some in pairs and the smallest number traveling alone.
Barnard College awarded fellowships and prizes to twenty-eight students at its annual honors assembly yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, the president, officiated.

EVEN if Brazilian dramas were less rare, "And the Wind Blows," which opened at the St. Marks Playhouse last evening, would be worth paying attention to. It gives the impression of being a genuine portrait of life in an obscure Brazilian village.
HAVANA, April 28 -- Premier Fidel Castro said today that the presence of Cubans in the rebel landing in Panama was damaging to the prestige of Cuba and her own revolution.

WASHINGTON, April 28, (AP) -- The House agriculture committee approved today a bill to put the price supports for oats, rye, barley and grain sorghums above the level announced for 1959 by Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson. The supports would still be below the levels of 1958.
A FULL-SIZED gale of energy from Alaska named Lorene Harrison blew into New York yesterday, and she had plenty to tell about women and the forty-ninth state.
WARSAW, April 28 -- Roman Catholic leaders here are charging that the Polish Government has started a war of taxation against the church.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The United States and nineteen other American republics promised today to help Panama put down a Cuban-based rebellion against the Government of President Ernesto de la Guardia Jr.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 28 -- Floyd Patterson, the champion, and Brian London of Blackpool, England, the challenger, finished training today. The two fighters will meet for the world heavyweight boxing title in the Fairgrounds Coliseum on Friday night.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Democratic majority leader, told the United States Chamber of Commerce today that if there was any "real" issue involved in the budget, it was how to balance it, not whether, to balance it.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 28 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia's Communist leadership called today on the Soviet Communist party for "constructive, comradely discussion" in an apparent new move to ease tension between the two countries.
A Republican State Committee reorganization that may hasten a change in the leadership of Manhattan's Ninth Assembly District was reported agreed upon yesterday.
Senhora Juscelino Kubitschek, wife of the President of Brazil, was guest of honor at the fourth annual Heart of America Ball last night. She also attended a reception given for her before the ball.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower is expected to announce soon an easing of controls over oil imports from Canada and Mexico.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- The Senate sidetracked today a proposal to curb the purchases of scientific equipment made in Communist countries.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce was confirmed by the Senate today as Ambassador to Brazil.
Net income of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, rose to $106,585,303, or $1.86 a common share, in the first quarter of this year.
A search for underworld influences in the city's juke-box industry will be conducted soon by the Police Department.
BARTLESVILLE, Okla., April 28 (AP) -- Increased sales, higher prices and reduced oper-
SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., April 28 -- The Rockland Business and Professional Women's Club tonight named Mrs. Mary Bianchini, a practical nurse of South Nyack, as Rockland County Woman of the Year.

The Association of American Indian Affairs urged Congress last night to set up a "general assistance" category of Federal welfare aid. The new category would help low-income states provide assistance to all needy persons regardless of race and length of residence.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- The annual convention of the Independent Bankers Association was told today that there was no limit to the ambition of big banks. R. E. Gormley, president of the association, made the charge at the first general session of the three-day meeting in the Sheraton Hotel here.

LOUISVILLE, April 28 -- The Meadow Stable's First Landing and the Elkcam Stable's Open View were the winners of the divisions of the thirty-second running of the Derby Trial Stakes today. The triumph of the former was generally expected by the crowd of 15,000, as shown by his return of $2.80. Open View's score was a mild surprise, and was worth $18.60 for $2 to his backers.

No one who has followed Prime Minister Nehru's policies as head of the Indian Government can believe that it was easy or pleasant for him to make the statement on Tibet which he delivered on Monday to India's Parliament. He has based his foreign policy on the conception that friendly and peaceful coexistence with Communist nations, especially that powerful neighbor of India's, Communist China, was both possible and desirable.

Louis Schwartz said that yesterday was the happiest day of his seventy-two years. The reason for his joy was that he had been invited to the chambers of his favorite judge, Mitchell D. Schweitzer of General Sessions.

Mrs. Thorne Lanier, chairman of the Women's Council of the Seaman's Church Institute of New York, has announced that tickets are still available for the council's annual spring luncheon and card party. It will be given tomorrow at the Institute, 25 South Street.
Mayor Wagner and the City Council took the first steps yesterday in what may develop into a major review of the city's role in the treatment of adult narcotics addicts.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Allen W. Dulles, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that the situation in Iraq was "the most dangerous in the world today."

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee approved today President Eisenhower's nomination of Judge Lester L. Cecil of Dayton, Ohio, to be a judge of the United States Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.
WILTON, Conn., April 28 -- One of Wilton's most familiar figures goes into retirement Thursday.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has resumed his campaign against the $500,000,000 liberalization of New York City's legal debt limit for school construction with three speeches, made or planned, in three days, one of them last night being delivered before a taxpayer organization honoring him for service performed. But Mr. Gerosa is not performing a service to the people of New York in his opposition to the constitutional amendment which will appear on the November ballot.
Three teacher organizations moved yesterday to continue their fight for improved salary conditions, but none voted the walkout that had been threatened.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Governor Rockefeller took issue with the Eisenhower Administration today on the subject of curbing water pollution.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States gave $1,000,000 to the National Academy of Sciences tonight for a new wing to the academy's building here.
The appointment of Mrs. Aida Casanas O'Connor as assistant counsel in the State Division of Housing was announced yesterday by State Housing Commissioner James W. Gaynor. The salary is $10,000.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates will offer today $20,000,000 of the Public Service Company of Colorado's 4 5/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1989, at 101.22 to yield 4.55 per cent.

LONDON, April 28 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told Parliament today that the Soviet Union's high-altitude nuclear tests last fall were probably responsible for the continued heavy fall-out of radioactive strontium 90 in Britain.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy was reported dissatisfied yesterday with the detective investigation of the case of 14-year-old Michael Kelly Jr., found dead Sunday in a swamp in Flushing, Queens.
First-quarter sales and earnings of Merck Co., Inc., set new records for the manufacturing chemists, John T. Connor, president, told the annual meeting in Rahway, N. J.

BUENOS AIRES, April 28 -- The economic branch of the Organization of American States opened a meeting here today and heard an estimate that the security of the free world was dependent on the rapid economic development of Latin America.

ALBANY, April 28 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller asked for a "full accounting" today in the case of a deputy tax commissioner who has been collecting state expense money while staying at his wife's apartment in New York City.
ONE of the most powerful voices in the New Jersey Legislature is that of Senator Walter Henry Jones.

TEANECK, N. J., April 28 -- Gerald J. Driscoll, 46-year-old former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and police commissioner of Dumont, N. J., tonight was elected chairman of the Bergen County Democratic committee. He received 245 votes, to 222 for Mayor Joseph F. Regan of Edgewater and 49 for James B. McCoy of Carlstadt, N. J.
Banton L. Wyckoff pleaded not guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to ten informations alleging a total of 188 Multiple Dwelling Law violations in eight tenements.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- Have the Yankees had it? Is their stumbling start an extension of last year's second-half slump?

Why do they do it? This question, currently being asked of the seven young volunteer astronauts from whose ranks will come the first American to ride a spaceship, is the same question that has been asked of adventurers from the beginning of time.
The State of Tennessee borrowed $15,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance road construction. The bonds are general obligations of the state and are secured specially by road taxes.
Two of the South's major crops are moving overseas today at transport costs much lower than those prevailing ten years ago, two representatives of the steamship industry testified yesterday.
A pretty, brown-haired girl sat enraptured for ninety minutes yesterday while several hundred circus artists wont out of their way to put on a good show.
Prices of cotton futures moved 5 points up to 4 points down yesterday, with fluctuations narrow all day. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- Field Marshal Montgomery, bare headed and in mufti, flew into Moscow tonight to meet some of his old wartime allies in the Soviet army and for two days of unofficial talks with top Kremlin officials.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Advisory Board on National Parks recommended today that eight new areas be included in the national park system.
HACKENSACK, N. J., April 28 -- Hackensack Hospital was preparing today to submit to the Zoning Board of Adjustments new plans for a six-story extension to relieve a chronic bed shortage.
A gala Celebrity Cocktail Party in the St. Regis Roof on May 26 will benefit the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.

Cine-Panorama, the first Soviet-made motion-picture system comparable to the American Cinerama process that started the wide-screen "revolution" in 1952, is slated to be unveiled here publicly late in June, it was learned yesterday.

The city prepared yesterday to convert its once scandal-ridden Bureau of Real Estate into a full-fledged city department on Friday. In a City Hall ceremony, J. Clarence Davies Jr., now director of the bureau, was sworn in as Commissioner of the new Department of Real Estate.

Following is a statement issued yesterday by Henry R. Luce, editor in chief of Time, Inc., and its affiliated publications, on criticism of Mrs. Lute and Time, Inc. in the Senate debate on her confirmation as Ambassador to Brazil:

GENEVA, April 28 -- The Soviet delegate to the conference seeking a ban on nuclear weapon tests said today that the new Soviet proposal includes no right of veto on inspecting suspected sites of such tests.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- Galina Ulanova, prima ballerina of the Bolshoi Theatre ballet company, told her hometown admirers today that the reception the Soviet troupe has had in New York "surpasses all our expectations."
Former President Harry S. Truman urged students at Columbia University yesterday to read and study the Constitution as a means of safeguarding their liberties.
Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday new highs in operating revenues and net income for the three and twelve months ended March 31.

Despite cold and rain, the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches got under way yesterday. More than 650 golfers took part in matches all over the district as teams in Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island were trying to become winners in their own series.

A lone Western traveler across the vast stretches of Siberia has many hours to wonder what kind of people the distant Russians are. Nearly all have grown up in turbulent circumstances under evolving communism, shielded from "bourgeois" ideas and ideals, and disciplined, coaxed and persuaded to take pride in being cogs of the powerful machine of state that is the Soviet Union.
George Lewis' Jeff's Uh Oh, seventh in the early running, squeezed through a narrow opening on the rail and won the $7,500 Great Neck Purse by a head at Jamaica yesterday.

PARIS, April 28 -- Perhaps the weakest and most divided team of Western diplomats since the start of the cold war begins meetings here tomorrow in an effort to devise common approaches to a new negotiation with Russia. The atmosphere is not cheerful.

ATLANTA, April 28 -- Nearly 900,000 Southern Presbyterians were called upon here today to defend the freedom of Negroes and white persons to "meet voluntarily in unhampered assembly and genuine fellowship."

LOUISVILLE, April 28 -- Gray clouds hung so low this bleak, raw day that it almost seemed that they would be impaled by the twin spires of Churchill Downs. Only the bright greenery and the vivid coloring of the flower beds hinted that this was spring. It felt much more like the start of a football season.
A proposal before the United States Golf Association may strike a death blow to big golf tournaments with Calcutta pools, such as the Tournament of Champions last week-end at Las Vegas, Nev.

The important economic meeting which began in Buenos Aires this week is part of a pattern that holds much promise for Latin America. This is the second conference of the so-called Committee of Twenty-one of the Organization of American States. The first was held in Washington at the end of 1958 and in between a working group of fifteen countries met continuously to prepare concrete recommendations for Buenos Aires.

Wool prices registered one of the sharpest declines in several years on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Top quotations dropped 2.5 to 4.6 cents a pound and grease wool tumbled 3.5 to 4.8 cents. Trading was heavy. The market closed at or near the lows of the day.
The Transit Authority will run morning rush-hour "skip-top" service beginning June 15 on the elevated BMT Jamaica line between 168th Street in Queens and Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn.

BONN, Germany, April 28 -- The three major West German banks have taken another leaf from the American banking book. They have decided to go into the small loans business for the first time in the history of German banking.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that equal time on the air, to balance a broadcast by an election opponent, has to be offered only once to a political candidate.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A Harvard Law School faculty member told Senators today that pending legislation to deny passports to Communist suspects was "unwise and unconstitutional."

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he and New York legislative leaders were "ready and anxious to deal on an equitable basis" with the situation of out-of-state residents who are subject to the New York income tax.
The Maritime Association of the Port of New York elected Edward J. Barber yesterday as president for the coming year.

The ugly duckling of college athletics is taking to the water in increasing numbers. More eight-oared shells are skimming over rivers, lakes, lagoons and estuaries than have competed in rowing regattas in many years.

The Long Island Rail Road had a small net income last month, but because of deficit operations in January and February reported a net loss of $624,267 for the first quarter of this year. This was sharply below the $1,462,327 deficit sustained a year earlier, when the company had to spend an extra $750,000 for snow removal.
Mayor Wagner met yesterday at an informal, off-the-record luncheon with ninety labor, industry and municipal officials to discuss New York's economic future.
Revlon, Inc., has signed to sponsor twenty television shows over the Columbia broadcasting System network next season.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senate provided a sad and even ridiculous demonstration today of how to take the wrong road to the right goal.

LONDON, April 28 -- Sir David Eccles, president of the Board of Trade, conceded today that he "dropped a brick" when he criticized the British press at the Hanover trade fair in West Germany last Sunday.
For her work in helping to beautify the city's parks, Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt received the 1958 citation of merit yesterday from the Park Association of New York City.
A Federal housing official proposed yesterday that local housing authorities remove earmarks from public housing projects, including tall flagpoles.

THE NATIONAL ORCHESTRAL ASSOCIATION and the Oratorio Society of New York made a joint contribution to the city's Handel Festival last night. It was a performance at Carnegie Hall of the composer's "Judas Maccabaeus."

A collection of 778 paintings and sculptures, including old masters and moderns, will be on exhibition and sale at the seventh annual spring art festival of the Women's Division, American Friends of the Hebrew University.
Two national Mercedes-Benz owners' clubs, with a combined membership of more than 1,000, have been merged. Dr. Kenneth A. Bartlett Jr. of Cedar Grove, N. J., is president of the new group.
A "very smooth ride" along a four-and-a-half-mile section of the New York Central in the Bronx is in prospect for commuters.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- New York Congressional leaders reached agreement today on a plan they hope will mean more defense contracts for the state.
PARIS, April 28 -- Gaston Monnerville, a 61-year-old native of French Guiana in South America, was elected President of the French Senate today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, served warning today that the House was in for a battle if it attempted to water down the defense contract renegotiation law.

YONKERS, April 28 -- So Long's Lad waited until the final sixteenth then moved strongly past the pace-setting and favored Adios Mont and won the Class A pace that headed tonight's program of harness racing at Yonkers Raceway.
PARIS, April 28 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter arrived today to iron out with the United States' allies differences of substance and tactics for the meeting with the Russians in Geneva.
