WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The chairmen of the Republican and Democratic National Committees joined today in calling on business men to plunge into politics and to urge their employes to wade in, too.
WARSAW, Wednesday, April 29 -- The Communist world issued today a "moderate" interpretation of the world situation as a prelude to high-level negotiations between the West and the Soviet Union.
The second high-ranking National Maritime Union official to develop a recent sudden yearning to go back to sea has resigned his $12,000-a-year post.

Blood will be given today to the Red Cross Blood Program at the New York University College of Dentistry, 421 First Avenue; the Masonic Temple, 317 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, and the New York Telephone Company, 7 Washington Avenue, Lynbrook, L. I.
The Waterfront Commission has gone to the Court of Appeals in an effort to upset an Appellate Division decision nullifying its ouster of four brothers who worked as checkers in Brooklyn.

Two Russian women, completing a month's tour around the United States, said yesterday that the friendliness they had met everywhere was one of the strongest impressions they would take back with them.

From the report of the Slum Clearance Committee it appears that the Title I projects cost the city to date $46,000,000, which will be returned eventually by a tax increase of $6,500,000 over the present levy. That means, including construction time and running debt services, it will take eight or nine years for the city to get its money back.
Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery severely criticized the United States' post-war world leadership in a television program seen here last night.
Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson yesterday approved a trustee's plan of reorganization for the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company.

The flourishing state of Soviet-American exchanges in the cultural field these days is evident to anyone visiting the Metropolitan Opera House during a performance of the Bolshoi ballet company. But in another important field, exchange of scientists, a mysterious snag appears to have been struck. Three months have now gone by since the National Academy of Sciences presented a detailed exchange program to its Soviet counterpart, but as yet there has been no answer.

Mrs. George Hamlin Shaw, chairman of the subscription committee of the New York Philharmonic, gave a tea at her home yesterday to open the annual subscription drive. Andre Kostelanetz, the orchestra conductor, was guest of honor.

PEIPING, Wednesday, April 29 (Reuters) -- The Panchen Lama said in a speech here today that under present circumstances he saw "no necessity" of accepting Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's invitation to go to India to meet the Dalai Lama.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 28 (AP) -- The Eastern Kodak Company looks for a continued good level of business in the rest of 1959, but foresees smaller gains over similar periods of 1958 than was the case in the first quarter, Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman, said today at the annual meeting.

The annual day of reckoning arrived yesterday for hundreds of America's top industrial and business leaders. They faced their company's stockholders -- that is their bosses -- in annual meetings all over the country. According to the New York Stock Exchange, sixty of its more than 1,100 listed companies staged their yearly board elections, and reviewed for shareholders their 1958 performances.
Directors of McKesson Robbins, Inc., wholesale drug concern, proposed yesterday a 2-for-1 split of the common stock. They also announced plans to increase the dividend on the new stock.
A poet named Judith Lieberman, who says she wrote doggerel at 8 years, very bad poetry at 12, and mediocre poetry at 14, was honored yesterday for becoming a good poet at 15.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senator Stuart Symington flatly contradicted today Administration assertions that intermediate-range ballistic missiles were now operationally ready at British bases.
A technique to visualize the light-sensitive "sandwiches" of protein and phosphorous-containing fats in the retina of the eye was described here yesterday.
The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday that its net income for the first quarter of 1959 rose to $66,673,000 from $60,668,000 for the corresponding period of last year.

LAST night's conversation with Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery was an extraordinary television program -- utterly absorbing in its provocativeness, refreshing in its candor and fascinating in its personalization of history. For a farewell production before he begins his leave of absence, Edward R. Murrow could not have done better.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- A broad recovery movement in grain futures today canceled some of the setbacks of yesterday and almost wiped out a few others.

Stocks generally settled a little lower yesterday, although a dozen or so of them put on wildly acrobatic performances, rising and falling. Volume was 3,920,000 shares, the highest since March 19, against 3,850,000 on Monday.
Burlington Industries, Inc., world's largest textile producer, has sharply increased earnings on record sales and raised the quarterly dividend to 25 cents a common share.

PARIS, April 28 -- Diplomats gathering here today moodily discussed the prospect that the meeting of Western foreign ministers beginning tomorrow might be prolonged. There is no better indication of the gaping holes in the Allied front toward the Soviet Union.

Dick Clark, the television star, is scheduled to make his screen debut in "Harrison High," a new novel by 22-year-old John Farris. The announcement was made yesterday through the Drexel Film Corporation, which will produce the picture for Columbia release.

LONDON, April 28 -- The Most Rev. Geoffrey Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, said today that the secrecy of confessions made to priests could not be sanctioned in the canon law of the Church of England until Parliament changed the laws of evidence.
The Department of Justice denied yesterday that it was engaged in a "politically inspired fishing expedition" in its antitrust investigation of the General Motors Corporation.

The battle over the "fair trade" bill seems in many ways to generate more heat than light. Thus it was good to read your April 18 editorial "The Fair Trade Bill." This editorial certainly illustrated the position of your organization that you serve the people and not just this or that special interest group.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- The Soviet Union warned Italy today that by permitting the establishment of United States rocket bases on her territory she would "become a target that would be destroyed in retaliation" in an East-West conflict.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The House Appropriations Committee asserted today that the Eisenhower Administration had sought to cut back promising medical research in an effort to portray the budget as balanced.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Judicial Conference of the United States has abandoned its support of a controversial bill to limit the habeas corpus power of lower Federal courts.
MIAMI, April 28 (AP) -- Tropical Park today asked the Florida State Racing Commission for authority to stage its 1959-60 horse race meeting at night.

BONN, Germany, April 28 -- West Germany will stand pat on two of the major issues to be threshed out in the conference of United States, British, French and West German foreign ministers opening in Paris tomorrow.
The construction of a ten-story art museum at Broadway and Fifty-eighth Street will begin late this summer, the architect, Edward D. Stone, said yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 28 -- A festive night aboard a cruise ship will provide the decorative theme for a dinner dance at the Stamford Yacht Club on Saturday. It will be given by the Stamford branch of the American Association of University Women to augment its scholarship fund, which annually sends a Stamford High School graduate to college.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., April 29 -- Charles H. Stoll, a 71-yearold lawyer who will complete fifty years of practice soon, sat behind his desk and gazed reflectively at the walls of his office here today. He was wondering where he could find space for a polar bear head and skin.

LONDON, April 29 -- A new three-week Stock Exchange Account started cheerfully today as far as industrial shares were concerned. Changes were somewhat irregular but rises predominated and were enough to lift the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary shares 0.7 point to 227.5, setting a record for the third consecutive day.

So much has been said about the Iron Curtain, Soviet travel restrictions, tapped telephones, the ire of the camera-shy, window dressing and general suspicion of foreigners that the freedoms, such as they were, of a lone traveler to Siberia ought to be recorded, too.

IT is sometimes facetiously said that a painter paints one painting in all his life, or that the writer writes the same book again and again. A more generous way of saying the same thing is that inherent temperamental predilections keep reappearing throughout a man's life.
For the first time in its long and distinguished career, Tiffany's is offering cultured pearls for sale.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -Don Demeter of the Dodgers has mixed feelings about the spectacular splurge that has placed him at the head of the major league runs batted in table and among the home run and batting leaders.

An interesting Town Hall recital was sung last night by Gudrun A. Simonar, described as the "foremost Icelandic soprano." It was her debut here, although she has appeared widely in Europe in concert and opera.
Efforts were resumed yesterday to avert a printers' strike against ten New York newspapers over disputed terms of a new contract.
A water main break flooded the IRT subway for six blocks last night in the tunnel under Southern Boulevard, near Leggett Avenue, the Bronx.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29 -- Dr. Norbert Wiener, the father of cybernetics, has been appointed an Institute Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He has been a member of the Mathematics Department forty years.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A Washington lawyer told for the first time today of his counter-intelligence moves to keep Bernard Goldfine's Hotel suite from being "bugged."
WASHINGTON, April 29 -An increasingly edgy Senate Commerce Committee continued to wrangle today over the nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will collect blood today at B. Altman Co., department store at Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Six high school students, selected from finalists in a nation-wide competition, were awarded four-year college scholarships today by the merged labor federation.
The battle over whether free performances of Shakespeare's plays will be presented in Central Park this summer gathered new fury yesterday.
The General Motors Corporation made a sharp recovery in the first quarter. Sales set a record for the period and earnings soared 53.8 per cent above the 1958 level.

LOUISVILLE, April 29 -- A fugitive sun escaped from hiding today and the barn area at ancient Churchill Downs reflected the warming glow of the return of spring. The Kentucky Derby colts seemed to move in more sprightly fashion. The trainers shed their pessimism along with their topcoats.
LONDON, April 29 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared tonight that he was trying to reduce world tension "not by appeasement but by open-minded and bold negotiations."

Deposits in the nation's 518 mutual savings banks increased $313,000,000 to $34,300,000,000 in March, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. The increase compared with one of $337,000,000 in March 1958.

NEW DELHI, April 29 -- The Indian Government announced currency reforms today in an effort to smash a vast gold and rupee smuggling operation based in the Persian Gulf. The smuggling has drained this country of hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign exchange.

Events tonight: "Six Characters in Search of an Author," City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein conducting. Adele Addison, soprano, John McCollum, tenor, Suzanne Bloch, lutenist, Rutgers University Choir, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
Cotton futures were 2 to 16 points (10 to 80 cents a bale) higher than Tuesday's close. The new crop months showed the most strength.

" Goodbye, Charlie" is about to be completed by George Axelrod, creator of such diversions as "The Seven Year Itch" and "Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?" Joshua Logan already has taken the comedy in tow for the purpose of giving it his combined ministrations as producer and director.
HAVANA, April 29 -- Panamanian rebels are plotting to seize the Panama Canal symbolically, according to information received here.
GREENLAWN, L. I. April 29 -- Joseph W. Cermak, Suffolk County Coordinator, was elected by the Huntington Republican Committee tonight to replace John H. Hulsen as Huntington Town Republican leader.
A blind newsdealer fell to the tracks in a Queens subway station last night but was saved by the quick action of a subway clerk.
LONDON, April 29 -- The Ministry of Defense took issue today with Senator Symington's complaints about the security of the ballistic missile bases in Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -Two Southern members of the Senate Judiciary Committee filed a report today opposing confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart on the principal ground of his having served as a recess appointee.
Net income of the Socony Mobil Oil Company in the first quarter of 1959 rose 22.5 per cent above the 1958 level.
LANSING, Mich., April 29 -The state of Michigan faced financial chaos today.
The National Broadcasting Company yesterday filed suit for $100,000 against four leaders of the technicians union, which has been involved in a work stoppage for the last three days.

NEW ORLEANS, April 29 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association's policy-making council ended its spring session today by assessing penalties against the University of Cincinatti and Gustavus Adolphus College.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower denied today that his delay in naming Christian A. Herter as Secretary of State reflected any doubts over whether Mr. Herter was the best man for the job.

A plot of thirty lots at Forty-fifth Drive and Oceania Street in Bayside, Queens, has been purchased by Walter Schwab, builder, for improvement with one-family dwellings. The buyer said his plans had been approved for financing through the Veterans Administration.

Alberta Municipal Financing Corporation, an agency of the Province of Alberta, Canada, yesterday registered a $50,000,000 issue of twenty-five year sinking fund debentures with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, April 22:

NAPLES, Italy, April 29 (UPI) -- Karol Fageros of Miami gained the third round of the women's singles play in the Naples international tennis tournament today by defeating Maria Ballanti of Italy, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0.
Low-price electronics issues moved ahead yesterday in a stock market in which every other major group was down but none unanimously so.
MOSCOW, April 29 (AP) -The Soviet Government today glorified its security police in a 500-page volume honoring the Cheka and justifying the use of terror against enemies of Bolshevism.
ALBANY, April 29 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the State Investigation Commission tonight to hold public hearings on the conduct of George P. Monaghan as State Harness Racing Commissioner.
A special state committee investigating alleged strikebreaking activity in the newspaper industry reported yesterday that it would renew its inquiry May 8.
Clifton W. Phalen, general chairman of the Greater New York Fund's 1959 appeal, yesterday inspected two of the 425 institutions that will benefit financially from the fund this year.
A house and garden party on Tuesday afternoon will benefit the Willoughby House Settlement.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -Girls exposed to X-rays three months before they are born may turn out to he sterile in later life, the National Academy of Sciences was told today.

Commodity prices moved generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Copper, lead, potatoes, burlap, tin, the world sugar positions, wool and cottonseed oil rose; hides declined, and rubber, zinc, coffee and cocoa were mixed.

Passover, the festival celebrating the deliverance of the Jews from bondage in Egypt, ended last night for those of Reform affiliation. For Orthodox and Conservative Jews, the week-long holiday will end today at sundown.
An official of the country's largest deck officer union charged yesterday that shipowners were partly responsible for ship collisions.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday asked Federal Court here to compel Guild Films Company, Inc., to file an annual report for the year ended Nov. 30, 1958. The action also sought, information on certain transactions.

In a letter to The Times, published on April 23, Michael Walpin asked how Puerto Ricans can "expect the ultimate and desired acceptance in the general community if they cannot meet the ordinary conversational requirements." His letter was prompted by the city's recent appropriation for additional funds for teaching English to those members of our community with Puerto Rican backgrounds.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery discussed world issues for more than two hours today with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev and, at his own request, was granted another interview tomorrow. Treaty Organization, arrived here yesterday for a self-appointed Moscow "reconnaissance" of three days.
LONDON, April 29 -- A British newspaper commented today that Viscount Montgomery was "dead right when he says that soldiers should stay out of politics."

Boys who had been looking forward this spring to their sandlot ball games in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have discovered that their vacant lot is bristling with thick railroad ties and looks like an Army tank trap.
The city took formal title yesterday to the property along the Seventh Avenue approach to the proposed Narrows Bridge linking Brooklyn with Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Internal Security Administrator of the State Department declared today that the international situation demanded prompt Congressional action to deny passports to Communists.
Former President Harry S. Truman conducted his umpteenth sidewalk marathon yesterday and, within the next seven hours, commented on probably more subjects than any man since Will Rogers.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The B-47 has developed structural weaknesses that make the jet bomber's operating lifetime uncertain.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Casey Stengel remarked today, "Just a few hits in the right places ought to have us moving again." Then the Yankees went out and delivered three such hits -- right into the seats for homers.
Slenderella Systems, Inc., filed a petition in Federal Court yesterday to arrange to settle its debts with creditors. The corporation operates more than 100 beauty salons over the country.

BLACKPOOL, England, April 29 (AP) -- A British bowler and "brolly" brigade left Brian London's home town today to cheer him on in his world heavyweight championship fight against Floyd Patterson at Indianapolis Friday night.
The local law doubling the city's 1-cent-a-pack cigarette tax was signed by Mayor Wagner yesterday after a brief public hearing in his office at City Hall.
Price deterioration proceeded further in the bond market yesterday, with Treasury securities under special pressure.
TRENTON, April 29 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called on a House committee today to help alleviate a severe recession in the New Jersey egg industry.
PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP) -- Billy Mazeroski hit his second home run of the season tonight to help the Pittsburgh Pirates gain a 3-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

SEOUL, Korea, April 29 -Rear Admiral Ira H. Nunn, senior Allied delegate to the Military Armistice Commission in Korea, said today some success had been achieved in propaganda warfare against the Communists at Panmunjom.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

FRESNO, Calif., April 29 (UPI) -Gordon Pirie, a 26-yearold Olympic distance runner for Great Britain, withdrew today from the West Coast Relays May 9. In a telegram from E1 Segundo, Calif., Pirie advised the director, J. Flint Harmer, that he was returning to England. Pirie had been entered! in the 5,000-meter run.

For young students the pleasant days of spring are reminders that the school term is ending and that summer vacation is near. But many students look forward to summer not merely as two months of fun but as a time when they can earn money toward their college tuition or gain job experience in their chosen fields.
The small war that flared recently on Fifth Avenue as a result of a controversial fashion show has been snuffed out.
YONKERS, April 29 -- Around Yonkers Raceway tonight the word was that if Shell Bomb "stayed flat" he could win the Goshen, the mile trot that topped the card. It was a sound appraisal.
The first quarter's net income of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation increased 12 per cent above that for the like 1958 period despite a sales decline of 2 per cent.
RUSSEL CROUSE'S unions are in a dandy state.

Today's new film is "Warlock," a Western drama in color, with Richard Widmark, Henry Fonda, Anthony Quinn, Dorothy Malone and Dolores Michaels, at the Paramount Theatre, Broadway and Forty-third Street. Edward Dmytryk directed and produced the Twentieth Century-Fox presentation, from a screen play by Robert Alan Arthur and a novel by Oakley Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- A Miami insurance executive testified today that Richard A. Mack's account with his company had been continuously overdrawn while Mr. Mack was a Federal Communications Commissioner.

" Spaceport, U.S.A." Martin Caidin's fifth book, will be published May 22 by Dutton. It is an account of Cape Canaveral and the Air Force Missile Test Center. The author outlines the history of the center, its operations and the achievements of its people in a scientific and technological "wonderland" developed from what was a near wilderness a few years ago.

The Scholarship Fund of Sarah Lawrence College will gain by the second annual ball, to be held tomorrow in the Crystal and Carnival Rooms of the Sherry-Netherland. The ball, which will have "The Rites of Spring" as its theme, will honor Dr. Harold Taylor, retiring president of the college.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Following are the highlights of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

BUENOS AIRES, April 29 -The United States listened today to new Latin-American arguments for big inter-American plans to hasten economic development and not just a "small solution" for periodic problems.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Manufacturers new orders rose again in March to a near-record level, the Department of Commerce reported today.

LONDON, April 29 -- The Soviet Union dismissed as "devoid of legal foundation" today a United States note rejecting Soviet protests against high-altitude flights by United States aircraft in the Berlin air corridor.

The Goodwill Industries of New York, Inc., which trains severely handicapped persons to do remunerative work according to their abilities, will be the beneficiary of a dinner at the Yonkers Raceway Tuesday evening.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- Twelve out of twenty Latin American Republics showed trade deficits in 1958, the Economic Commission for Latin America reported today in its annual survey of economic conditions. Others achieved a balance of payments only by cutting imports drastically.

The way every country in the Organization of American States rallied to the defense of invaded Panama is one of the most heartening developments for hemispheric peace in recent years. There is no question that the O. A. S. has been greatly strengthened, and a menace that seemed to hang over the Caribbean area due to a belief that Cuba might help revolutionaries has been dissipated.
The new $8,300,000 Brooklyn Pier 1, in the Fulton Terminal area, went to work yesterday afternoon.

In a letter published in your issue of Jan. 24 we called attention to the latest law of nationalization enacted on Dec. 26, 1958, by the Government of Yugoslavia. By this law all apartment houses and building lots, including those of American citizens, have been nationalized.

Members of the Bolshoi Ballet saw a modern and very American version of a tale they have often danced -- Romeo and Juliet -- yesterday. Half of the company attended a matinee performance of the musical, "West Side Story" at the Broadway Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Kennedy labor reform bill passed by the Senate "very much disappointed" President Eisenhower. He said he hoped the House of Representatives would strengthen it.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- A Dutch freighter cruised far in front today in the race from the rebuilt St. Lawrence Seaway to Chicago.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers told Congress today that the Defense Contract Renegotiation Act should be allowed to die.

The Toomey-Fountain Mortgage and Abstract Company of Hackensack and Paterson, N. J., has established a department to find and process land for residential, industrial and commercial development. The service will include appraisals, land mortgages and construction and permanent loans.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -There are probably no complete intermediate-range ballistic missile installations in Britain, with weapons, launching platforms and trained crews ready to fire, it was indicated at the Pentagon today.
OWASSO, Okla., April 29 (AP) -- Little Richard, a blue tick coon hound, was brought out alive today from the limestone crevice where he had been trapped for nearly six days.
LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) -- Britain's aircraft industry reported booming business for the first quarter of this year today.
A record field of 2,400 submitted entries for the fiftyninth annual United States Golf Association's Open championship, which will be held at Winged Foot, in Mamaroneck, N. Y., June 11 through 13.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -State Department officials said today that the new Soviet proposal in the conference seeking a ban on nuclear weapon tests was "vague" and contained "sleepers."'
NEW DELHI, India, April 29 -- The tragedy of Tibet has shaken India's confidence in the security of her northern frontier and given rise to demands for a reconciliation with Pakistan.
AT the close of its first decade, Players Incorporated is making its first appearance in New York. It acted Sophocies' "Oedipus Rex" at Carnegie Hall Playhouse last evening.

MICHIGAN'S financial embarrassment was described a couple of days ago by its Governor, Gerhard Mennen Williams, as "a disaster of the first magnitude." The Republicans who oppose him hope that it will be disastrous -- to his political career.
A REPORT appeared in this newspaper a few days ago relating to the non-U foods of England.

JERSEY CITY, April 29 -- A privately financed $7,500,000 construction project combining twin twenty-three-story apartment buildings, 70,000 square feet of retail shops and a twolevel basement parking garage will be started June 1 at Journal Square.
Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday a gain of 24 per cent in net asset value for the twelve months ended March 31.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- United States policy in the Middle East is to try to please everyone, President Eisenhower indicated today.
GENEVA, April 29 -- The Soviet. Union pressed today for Western acceptance of the principle of a quota on inspections of suspected nuclear explosions.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- The legitimate theatre, often regarded here with suspicion, derision or indifference, now has proof it is no longer beneath contempt.

TOKYO, April 29 -- Larger crowds than have usually appeared on such occasions in recent years turned out at the Imperial Palace today to cheer Emperor Hirohito and members of his family on the Emperor's fifty-eighth birthday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The antics now going on in Washington are bizarre enough to suggest that this year the scent of the apple blossoms and the sight of trees bursting into leaf have stirred the political sap to the point of explosion.

Five three and five-story buildings containing stores and apartments at 481-87 Second Avenue and 239-45 East Twenty-seventh Street have been sold by Hugh K. McGovern, realty operator. The property, fronting 100 feet on the avenue and 150 feet on the street, at the northwest corner, was purchased by an investing client of Adele Kirsch, broker in the deal.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 29 (UPI) -- Cus D'Amato and Don Nesseth, managers of the heavy-weight champion, Floyd Patterson, and the welterweight champion. Don Jordan, respectively, signed an agreement today to pool their managerial interests in an undisclosed fashion, an authoritative source reported.

TORONTO, April 29 (AP) -- First quarter earnings of International Nickel Company, Inc., are expected to be above those of a year ago and the company looks forward to a satisfactory year, John F. Thompson, chairman, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, declared today that the Congressional drive to override President Eisenhower's veto of a rural electrification bill was "largely a political move to embarass me and the President."

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa and the Board of Education, who have been at odds over the desirability of the proposed $500,000,000 school bond issue, clashed again yesterday. This time the cause was the desirability of an elementary school in the Bronx.
GREENLAWN, L. I., April 29 -- Edwin F. Brooks, who resigned last Wednesday as chairman of the Huntington Town Zoning Board of Appeals, was found dead in his car today at 12:20 P. M.

PARIS, April 29 -- French war veteran organizations extended an invitation to foreign veterans today to join them in a gathering in Lourdes, Aug. 30 to Sept. 5, to reaffirm their desire for peace and reconciliation.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming testified today against Senate acceptance of a House Appropriations Committee proposal to add $181,400,000 to the budget of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

BONN, Germany, April 29 -- The public prosecutor of Nuremberg ordered today the confiscation of United States-made phonograph records of the history of Nazism in speeches, songs and music. On police orders dealers surrendered seven records.
A leader in the Democratic reform faction in New York County challenged Carmine G. Sapio yesterday to demonstrate his devotion to political reform by concrete action.

Secretary of the Treasury Anderson's speech before the publishers pointing out the danger of inflation is a repetition of speeches made by our President, by heads of labor, distinguished economists and others in high positions in and outside of the Administration, but all to no avail.

Dedication yesterday of a new three-berth $8,300,000 pier in Brooklyn, built by the Port of New York Authority, is one more step in fulfillment of that agency's vast waterfront modernization program that raises again, and with increasing urgency, the question why the Wagner administration doesn't join forces with the authority instead of going it alone.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -Senator Lister Hill today asked Secretary Arthur S. Flemming to prepare testimony on a Senate proposal to forbid purchase of high school equipment from Communist countries through National Defense Education Act funds.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -President Eisenhower has deferred until next fall a decision on whether to ask Congress for $400,000,000 more in foreign military aid funds.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Eisenhower today found justifiable provocation for Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce's attack on Senator Wayne Morse. He thus cleared the way for her to assume the Ambassadorship to Brazil.
Private power companies in a hurry to set up large-scale atomic plants may be wasting million of dollars, according to Earle J. Machold, president of the Niagara Mohawk Power Company.
ABOARD THE SANTA REGINA IN LAKE ERIE, April 29 (AP) -- The captain of the first United States ship to pass through the Seaway expressed reservations today about the water route.
American marketers were warned yesterday that they had not recognized fully how competitive export markets were. They were told that they must do a better selling and advertising job in that area.
The dramatic effectiveness of antibiotics and other direct means of treating specific diseases has almost eclipsed another highly important field, a prominent German physician said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- Congress overwhelmingly approved a bill today providing for increases in pension and unemployment benefits to the nation's railroad workers. Pensions would go up 10 per cent and jobless benefits by 20 to 140 per cent.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday: "Our transit system is not for sale."
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI ) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

The Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance indicated yesterday it was willing to consider substituting cooperative housing for the luxury type of rental apartments it had proposed last week for the $18,000,000 Cadman Plaza redevelopment in Brooklyn Heights.

PARIS, April 29 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany proclaimed official optimism today on their efforts to find a common ground from which to confront the Russians in Geneva May 11 but clamped a secrecy rule on their deliberations.

ANIMAL, mineral or vegetable? Natural or synthetic? These questions even puzzled professional decorators at the preview of a fabric and carpet exhibition now at the Design Center For Interiors, 415 East Fifty-third Street.

Running over a super-fast sloppy track, Charfran Stable's Crafty Skipper scored a four-and-one-half-length victory in the $27,850 Jamaica Handicap yesterday, with Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's Jet Fuel a well-beaten second.
LAST Tuesday was an important day in the lives of twenty-one seniors at the Parsons School of Design.
Mayor Wagner yesterday proclaimed May Day tomorrow as Union Square, U. S. A., Day.
LONDON, April 29 -- The clergy of the Church of England reaffirmed today the doctrinal principle that priests are bound to keep secret any sins disclosed to them in confessions.
New York opened its second Salute to Spring last night with a ceremony on the steps of the Public Library at Forty-second Street.
Reduced rail rates on export grain shipments were announced last night by Eastern Railroads, to meet the threat of competition from the newly opened St. Lawrence Seaway.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- The presidents of Colgate University and Bryn Mawr College urged Congress today to kill a provision in present law calling for loyalty oaths from students getting Federal scholarships.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 29 -- The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States rejected for the second time today a proposal that it lease space in the new Interchurch Building on Riverside Drive at 120th Street.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday disclosed that a holding company controlled by Maurice E. Olen, former president of H. L. Green Company, Inc., had sold 27,800 shares of Green common stock this month. The holding company was still listed as holding 131,028 shares of Green, a variety chain, and Mr. Olen reports direct ownership of 1,000 Green shares.
TULSA, Okla., April 29 (AP) -- Striking members of the Transport Workers Union will go back to their jobs at American Airlines jet maintenance center tomorrow under a Federal Court order.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -West Germany's defense Minister said emphatically today that the arming of his country was proceeding despite plans and proposals for its demilitarization, including some proposals being considered by the west.
The nation's production and inventories of petroleum products declined slightly last week while imports showed a small increase, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

A seventy-three-ton steel assembly was gently lowered yesterday onto a concrete foundation jutting out of the East River. Thus began the construction of one of the two towers that will support the main suspension span of the $90,000,000, Throgs Neck Bridge connecting the Bronx with Queens.

Many city motorists cooperate with New York's efforts to reduce air pollution from exhaust pipes, but there are still large numbers of drivers who do not. Consequently, Air Pollution Control Commissioner Greenburg has felt it necessary to repeat his appeal to motorists to maintain and operate their automobiles properly.

LOUISVILLE, April 29 -- The field for the eighty-fifth running of the Kentucky Derby was reduced to a possible seventeen starters today. The list was pruned following reflections by several owners and trainees that their charges would have little chance of performing creditably in Saturday's famous $125,000 race.

The American Opera Society will present a full-length performance in concert form of Berlioz' "Les Troyens" as a feature of its 1959-60 season. The announcement was made yesterday by Allen Sven Oxenburg, director.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The failure of bankers to prepare younger men to succeed them in top-management positions, is a prime reason for bank mergers, according to Karl R. Bopp, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. Mr. Bopp made that observation today in an address before the twenty-fifth annual convention of the Independent Bankers Association at the Sheraton Hotel.
The Board of Education's reallocation of school budget funds for 1959-60 came in for internal criticism yesterday -from Francis W. H. Adams, a member of the board.
Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, proposed yesterday that the purpose of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization be broadened to counter the Soviet economic as well as military threat.
PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -Our first man in space will have his feet on the ground.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce modified its traditionally liberal stand on foreign trade today as a result of pressure by protectionist groups.

The production last year of textiles made from cotton, wool, man-made fibers and silk dropped 4.1 per cent in this country from the year before and 7.2 per cent compared to the average from 1948 through 1957.
The 171-man wage policy committee of the United Steelworkers of America will meet here today to set the union's asking price in negotiations for a new steel labor contract.

The police caught up with the thieves who have been raiding a lower East Side supermarket since last Thursday. They seized ten youngsters, between 10 and 14 years of age, who had spurned all wares except bubble gum and candy.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- National Merit Scholarships were awarded today to 850 high school seniors. They headed the list of 480,000 students who took part in the nation's largest scholarship competition.

The directors of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad and the Erie Railroad announced yesterday that they favored a merger of their lines to form a consolidated system that would rank among the first ten in the industry.

WHITESBURG, Ky., April 29 (AP) -- Snipers and guards at a nonunion coal mine skirmished today. In a neighboring county, dynamite wrecked another coal loading plant in eastern Kentucky's bitter coal strike.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., April 29 -- The General Motors Corporation withdrew its offer today to buy all or part of Westchester's Kingsland Point Park on the Hudson River for expansion of its Chevrolet and Fisher Body plants.
LONDON, April 29 (AP) -- A woman was accused in court today of having frightened a mouse.

A new approach to the education of women that would waste little time on frills and concentrate on intellectual maturity was offered yesterday by Alvin C. Eurich, director of the Fund for the Advancement of Education.

Chadbourn Gotham, Inc., will offer today to holders of its common stock the right to subscribe for $3,000,000 of 5.90 per cent convertible subordinated debentures that are due in 1971. The offering will be made on the basis of $100 of debentures for each sixty-eight shares held at par. Chadbourn Gotham manufactures hosiery, work clothes and sportswear.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- The Government Accounting Office declared today that poor supply conditions had "seriously impaired" the combat readiness of American Army forces in Europe. It called for decisive action by the Army to correct the situation.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- A House Agriculture subcommittee today approved a bill designed to reduce the nation's wheat surplus. It would slash planting allotments by 20 per cent and raise Federal price supports by 10 per cent for two years.
PANAMA, April 29 -- The mission of the Organization of American States said tonight that it had found no evidence to indicate that any foreign power was involved in the invasion of Panama.
BONN, Germany, April 29 -Soviet sources here said today that any action on Moscow's part to alter Berlin's status during the Geneva conference of foreign ministers starting May 11 "can be ruled out."
PORTLAND, Ore., April 29 (AP) -- Yama Bahama, using a steady left hand, defeated young Phil Moyer tonight in a ten-round fight.
Scholastic Magazines, Inc., publisher of classroom magazines, has purchased twenty-seven acres on Route 9-W, three miles north of George Washington Bridge, in Englewood Cliffs, N. J.
The Onondaga County Water Authority in New York borrowed $2,630,000 yesterday on serial-revenue bonds that are due over forty years at an interest cost of 4.177 per cent.

Minority Leader Stanley Isaacs, in his letter printed April 27, attempts to make it appear that the sole justification of "the huge city expense budget" presented by those of us in the majority at City Hall is that the state budget is also over $2,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -The Supreme Court heard argument today on the long-debated constitutionality of the so-called membership clause of the Smith Act.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Eisenhower suggested today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon might replace him briefly at a summit meeting this summer -- if one were held and if it dragged on.
HARTFORD, April 29 (AP) -- The General Assembly's Transportation Committee favorably reported a bill permitting the state to establish compulsory automobile inspections.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -Project Argus has shown that atomic explosions in space of megaton size can create radiation shells perilous to space travelers, according to the man who proposed the experiment.
BOKE, Guinea, April 28 -- President Sekou Toure says he asked President Eisenhower for rifles for Guinea's 2,000-man army before there was any question of getting weapons from Communist countries.
PANAMA, April 29 (UPI) -Another invasion ship was reported on the way to Panama today.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 29 (UPI) -- Haiti's Presiential palace, a white colonial mansion in the heart of Port-au-Prince, has been transformed into a fort.

A DOZEN years have passed since Robert Lowell won a Pulitzer Prize in poetry with "Lord Weary's Castle." He should win another for his new book, "Life Studies,"* a volume of poems silhouetted against a prose memoir of his Boston childhood among Beacon hillbillies.
VIENNA, April 29 -- West German industrial capitalism has lost a silent struggle to gain control of a large segment of Austrian industry.
HAVANA, April 29 -- Major Ernesto (Che) Guevara, a leader of the Cuban armed forces, has announced that "an armed workers militia" will parade in the May 1 labor celebration here.
The Soviet Union has canceled its plans to send a delegation to an international oil meeting here next month because the members would be unable to visit certain parts of the country.
LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) -- The British Government said today it would keep under review the possibility of building nuclear-powered ships to replace the liners Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 28 -- The speck of Atlantic coral that is Bermuda may never be a world center of purebred dog activity, but there has been stage-by-stage progress since the Bermuda Kennel Club was reorganized four years ago.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -Neither the White House nor the State Department would comment tonight on the report of the message sent by President Toure to President Eisenhower.

BERLIN, April 29 -- Bishop Otto Dibelius, nominal head of the German Evangelical Church, in an open letter to Premier Otto Grotewohl of East Germany lashed out today against Communist pressure on Christian believers "designed to suppress the churches and pave the way for atheism."
SOONER or later atomic power had to hook up somewhere with fishing, and it seems to have done so now, in a tentative sort of way.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 29 (AP) -- Iraq's Communist party demanded today full membership in Premier Kassim's Government.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- Prostitution continues to flourish in Central and Eastern European countries behind the Iron Curtain, despite Marxist claims that economic equality would wipe out such abuses, according to a United Nations report released today.

ONE of the busiest, most distinguished and progressive architects in America told an audience yesterday to "beware of progress," "don't be modern" and "don't work too hard." Edward D. Stone, a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects, titillated members of the American Institute of Decorators with his views on American life in a speech at the Plaza Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -The Phillies, who don't do too many things too well, cashed in on their principal asset again tonight. On two pinch singles in the ninth inning, they snatched a victory from the Dodgers.
THE "Armstrong Circle Theatre" presented on Channel 2 last night an hour-long drama entitled "The Sound of Violence: The Juke-Box Rackets."

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- The House Select Committee on Aeronautics and Space Exploration tentatively approved today the Administration's civilian space program for the twelve months starting July 1. It made few changes.
Former students, colleagues and friends joined last night at Columbia University to honor Dr. Mark Van Doren "as a teacher, a father and a friend."
The Allied Stores Corporation achieved record sales of $643,778,283 in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31. This was $10,964,769, or 1.7 per cent above the $632,813,514 volume of the year before.
The formation of a committee to support President Eisenhower's Mutual Security Program was announced yesterday by Dr. Henry M. Wriston, former president of Brown University.
Banks were urged yesterday to let guards concentrate on being guards and to use dummy bundles of money to cope with an upsurge of robberies.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 28 -- A controversy has developed here over a Government plan to have open, circular fireplaces as part of new segregated colleges for Africans.
" O City sitting by the Sea! How proud the day that dawned on thee, When the new era, long desired, began . . ."
BERLIN, April 29 -- A military delegation from Communist China and two British Labor members of Parliament arrived in East Berlin today to inspect the East German Army.

An unemployed Harlem man, father of three children, fatally shot his mother-in-law last night and then killed himself with his revolver, the police reported. A few minutes earlier he had threatened to kill his 21-year-old wife.

State Superintendent of Insurance Thomas Thacher has been handed a hot and intricate problem by the Associated Hospital Service in its request for permission to increase local Blue Cross rates. Its seven million subscribers -- most of whom surely have to watch their pennies -- measure the public concern as to what Mr. Thacher will do.
Governor Rockefeller was reported yesterday to have settled on two members of the state's "Little Hoover Commission," created this year to look into the administration of New York City.

The scholarship fund of the Holton-Arms School in Washington will benefit from a luncheon to be given by its New York alumnae on May 12 at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League. A tour of the new galleries of French Co. will follow the annual event.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 4 pr cent above the level of a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower has not received a letter requesting arms from President Sekou Toure of Guinea. Nor has the United States decided what to do about requests for economic as well as military aid from that newest of the independent countries of Africa.
ANY theatregoer who is stone deaf might imagine himself having a good time at "Come Play With Me," which opened at the York Playhouse last evening.
Progress was made yesterday in settling the dispute that has threatened to cancel the Lewisohn Stadium concerts this summer.
A lifelong incentive of President Franklin D. Roosevelt was finding more work to do.In the midst of World War II he was concerned over the lack of fertility in the Middle East deserts.
A group of fifteen goodwill ambassadors from West Berlin arrived yesterday -- bringing good manners, thirty pairs of soccer hoots and a determination to make a good showing.

MOSCOW, April 30 -- The Kremlin's official newspaper Izvestia published in full today the first dispatch in the series on Siberia by Max Frankel, a correspondent of The New York Times. The article first appeared in The Times Monday.

BERLIN, April 30 (AP) -- East Germany intends to take over control of Western lifelines to West Berlin regardless of the results of coming East-West negotiations, its Communist leader said in a speech published today.
A kind of black snow fell on the city last night.

Joseph Papp, whose plans for a summer program of free Shakespeare in Central Park are being upset, again failed to get a hearing at City Hall yesterday, but he got a pat on the back from the school system.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- Members of the board of Loew's, Inc., which controls Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, produced a script today that promises a happy ending for moviegoers and stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Maybe the Emperor Caligula was not the first to put the horse in politics when he made his steed Consul in ancient Rome. But the incident is renowned enough to begin the history of the equine as a political issue of which the latest chapter has just been written jointly by the United States Ambassador to Brazil, Clare Boothe Luce, and Senator Morse of Oregon.
New York's teamsters have decided to honor the picket lines set up by the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians around all National Broadcasting Company installations.

While earnings of the Union Pacific Railroad from transportation operations continue to show good gains over the year-ago level, the company's revenues from oil and gas operations and from its investment portfolio continue to lag behind those of 1958.
A $15,000-a-year job that has been vacant for a year was filled yesterday with the appointment of Donald C. Bolles as assistant to the chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (UPI) -- Insurance companies today modified their "safe driver" insurance plan to help motorists who can prove they are blameless in accidents.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- The report of tods.y's livestock markets here by the] Department of Agriculture follows:
SEVENTEEN suburban women gathered here yesterday with one experience in common: All had lived in a centrally air-conditioned home for at least one year.

SPARTANBURG, S. C., April 30 (AP) -- "Intercollegiate football is as obsolete as the tail of the dinosaur. If it were not for some of the more thick-headed alumni, it would disappear overnight from many American colleges," declared an educator-librarian, Dr. Louis B. Wright today.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -The Treasury came up with another surprise package today for handling jointly its difficult multibillion-dollar cash and refunding problems for May.

In the absence of its regular star, the "Jack Paar Show" on Channel 4 has been conducted this week by Eddie Albert, who has been appearing on the program with his wife, Margo. Although the strike of National Broadcasting Company technicians has caused problems during the program, the Alberts, an amiable couple, have provided many enjoyable moments.

A single grade for all firemen other than probationary men, with all those above the starting group getting the equivalent of today's top grade, was proposed yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
Following is the text of a statement on contract goals issued yesterday by the Wage Policy Committee of the United Steelworkers of America:
A $4,100,000 special promotion budget is being raised by the Pan-American Coffee Bureau in an attempt to get people to use more coffee in their coffee.
DETROIT, April 30 (AP) -Bill Fischer led a band of Detroit cast-offs to a 9-1 victory over the Tigers today as the Washington Senators laced four Tiger pitchers for seventeen hits.
Seven passengers were struck by glass yesterday morning when a New Haven Railroad commuter train was stoned in the Bronx. The police said none of the injuries were serious.

MOSCOW, April 30 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery said today that he had received an oral message from Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev for Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain. He declined to disclose the nature of the message after his second meeting in two days with Mr. Khrushchev.
Ambassador Aziz Ahmed of Pakistan declared yesterday that "a special responsibility" rested on the United States in resolving strife between his country and India.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 30 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, indicated tonight that the Federal Government hoped to maintain a hands-off policy on labor-management wage negotiations.
Morgan Stanley Co. and associates are offering today $20,000,000 of Alabama Power Company 4 7/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, due 1989, at 100.393 to yield 4.85 per cent.
The Federal Government said yesterday it would accept the city's word on the truthfulness and adequacy of relocation survey reports filed for slum clearance projects.

Football coaching is looked upon as one of the most hazardous occupations but the brethren who teach most of the other college sports rarely have to worry about keeping meat and potatoes on the table.

BOSTON, April 30 -- The United States will attempt to rocket four mice into orbit and back in about a month. If they return alive it will be the first time a living, presumably after several days, has survived an orbital journey.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., April 30 -- The pupils at South Orange Junior High School have it on good authority that Latin is a worth-while subject.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The United States announced today that it had agreed to sell fifty old-style combat aircraft and ten turboprop transport planes to Indonesia.

YONKERS, April 30 -- Fresh from two blistering, sub-two-minute miles at Santa Anita, Widower Creed showed his heels to four of the five other pacers in the $25,000 free-for-all event at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

ELIZABETH BERRYHILL'S play, "The Cup of Trembling," which received the first of three scheduled performances at the Union Theological Seminary on Broadway and 120th Street last night, is more of a dramatized narration than a play.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- The Yankees, playing without Mickey Mantle, tonight fought the White Sox for more than three and a half hours only to blow their series finale when their ace relief specialist, Ryne Duren, failed them again.

FORT WORTH, April 30 (AP) -- Lionel Hebert, one of the golfing brothers from the Evangeline Country, finished late with the least today and took the first-round lead in the $27,300 Colonial national invitation tournament.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., April 30 (AP) -- State Supreme Court Justice Howard A. Zeller today ordered Joseph Barbara Sr., who was host of the Apalachin gangland meeting, to testify before the State Crime Commission.

A dispatch from New Delhi indicates that leaders in both Pakistan and India are drawing closer to a discussion of their differences because of the Chinese Communist attack on Tibet. If this attitude materializes it can be one of the most important by-products of the Communist assault. At this point, at least, some good can come out of evil.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he had "asked" and "advised" George P. Monaghan to resign as Harness Racing Commissioner.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 (UPI) -- Clifford F. Hood, president of U. S. Steel Corporation, will retire soon in compliance with the company's policy which calls for the company's three top officers to step down upon reaching the age of 65, it was reported today.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 30 -- Afternoon and evening programs today carried on the twenty-ninth Festival of American Music of the Eastman School of Music, directed by Dr. Howard Hanson.
MOSCOW, April 30 -- Moscow donned a holiday garb of scarlet today on the eve of what promised to be the gayest and largest May festival the Soviet capital has enjoyed in many years.

Every time the public wins a battle to save parkland from being sold away to industrial or other use the principle is strengthened, for future battles wherever they may be, that land once dedicated to recreational use shall not lightly be given up.
Pan American World Airways stock clerks have ratified a two-year contract recently negotiated by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the union reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON April 30 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter will make a radio-television report to the nation next Thursday night on the Western position for the Geneva talks with the Soviet Union starting May 11.

IF there is anyone else who has served as Fire Commissioner and Police Commissioner of New York City and as Harness Racing Commissioner of New York State, only he can match the record of George Patrick Monaghan.

Stanch opponents of the fluoridation of community water supplies were described yesterday as hostile persons with personality defects causing them to rebel easily and oppose such proposals just for the sake of opposing something.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Republicans won a significant but narrow victory for President Eisenhower today as the House of Representatives sustained his first veto of the session.
The zoning ordinance for the city proposed by Voorhees, Walker, Smith Smith to the Planning Commission has been meeting with opposition on the part of certain groups in public hearings.

LONG ISLAND waters are in the process right now of changing over from Spring to Summer fishing, and Summer fishing means game fish. But the change has not been made yet: there are only a number of indicators.
Ten New York newspapers submitted a new offer yesterday in an effort to avert a printers' strike over a contract dispute.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -Space scientists talked hopefully today of discovering planets of distant stars, of solving the mysteries of the moon and perhaps finding the original center of the universe.

The opening date and theatre are set for "The Gang's All Here," starring Melvyn Douglas, The Jerome Lawrence-Robert E. Lee play, dealing with an undesignated President of the United States in the Nineteen Twenties, is scheduled to arrive Sept. 24 at the Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Foreign-aid supporters in the Senate easily beat off attempts to slash the Development Loan Fund today. They then voted the fund added lending authority of $200,000,000 for the present fiscal year, which ends June 30.
Nuclear - powered aircraft armed with ballistic missiles on continuous nomadic patrol in the skies of the world may provide one of the nation's invulnerable deterrent systems of tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Duke Snider, battling to regain regular status in the outfield he once ruled, paced the Los Angeles Dodgers to a series-squaring 6-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies before 11,547 spectators at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.
HONG KONG, April 30 -- Communist China published today the text of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's statement on Tibet in India's Parliament last Monday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 30 (Reuters) -- Hungary warned the United States today it might have to expel diplomats in Budapest whose activity was incompatible with diplomatic practice, American sources said tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- The Defense Department announced today that it had a dozen contractors working on the problem of devising death rays, anti-gravity machinese and other bizarre means of defending against ballistic missile attack.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Adele Addison, soprano, John McCollum, tenor, Suzanne Bloch, lutenist, Rutgers University Choir, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Concert of Handel Chamber Music, Manhattan Savings Bank, Madison Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, 5; "Regina," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15; Mike and Elaine, satirists, Town Hall, 8:30 and 11:15; Mikulas Grosz, violinist, Otto Herz, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
" The Rain in Spain" will not be sung in the Russian plain in any pirated version of "My Fair Lady" if the authors of the musical have their way.
Local authorities are planning the sale of $104,000,000 of public housing bonds backed by subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration. The tentative date of sale is May 26.
The steamship clerical division of Local 153, Office Employes International Union, now has its first contract in the freight-forwarding industry.
Arthur Godfrey was operated on yesterday for the removal of a malignant tumor in his left lung. The upper lobe of the lung, which contains two lobes, was removed, in addition to the cancerous growth.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that the American Bar Association had left itself open to a charge that it has unjustifiably criticized recent Supreme Court decisions on internal security cases.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Douglas Dillon to be Under Secretary of State. Mr. Dillon will move into the number two diplomatic post vacated by Christian A. Herter, Secretary of State.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 647,282 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's net income for the first three months this year was almost double that of the 1958 period, but well below the record achieved in the first quarter of 1957.

Plans to construct a $30,000,000 recreation area in the Baychester section of the Bronx were announced at City Hall yesterday by William Zeckendorf, president of the real estate firm of Webb Knapp, Inc.
One hundred and twenty-five surgical patients were moved to safety in beds and wheel chairs yesterday when a fire broke out in Bellevue Hospital. No one was injured.

SOMETIME in the year 1837 a humble village school teacher in the Chinese province of Kwang-tung fell into a trance that lasted for forty days. Hung Hsiu-ch'uan was a bright student of the Confucian classics who had not been bright enough to pass the higher examinations that would have assured him a career in government service.
LISBON, Portugal, April 30 -- An important NATO naval command, formally approved seven years ago, has not yet been organized.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- None of the intermediate range ballistic missiles sent to Britain is ready for immediate combat use, Neil H. McElroy confirmed tonight.
When the International Council of Women opens its executive meeting in Vienna on May 6, its members will take another giant stride toward mutual understanding among women the world over.
PARIS, April 30 -- The fading scroll said: "Christian A. Herter, tres bien, hors rang."

The prospect of payless pay days is never a pleasant one for those affected. This prospect becomes particularly unpleasant, however, when the employer who becomes delinquent is a major unit of our Federal Union, the great State of Michigan. And if Michigan can find itself in such a plight the uncomfortable thought must intrude that other states could some day face similar misfortune if they do not learn the lessons taught by Michigan's woes.

PARIS, April 30 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the communique issued today by the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany at the end of their preparatory talks on the May 11 East-West conference in Geneva:

WASHINGTON, April 30 -The National Geographic Society and the Smithsonian Institution announced today that they would sponsor an expedition this summer to explore the ruins of Port Royal, Jamaica, toppled into the sea by an earthquake on June 7, 1692.

NO matter how provoked he has been in the past, this is the year when the American man will smile approval on women's fashions. One glimpse in Saks 34th Street should reassure him that summer dresses this year will be pure peaches-and-cream.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Evening-up operations in some old-crop contracts accounted for the major volume of business in grain futures on the Board of Trade today.

Loans to business by the larger New York banks declined $10,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a drop of $8,000,000 in the like week a year ago.

" The Canal Builders," a new book by the prolific writer, Robert Payne, will be published by Macmillan on May 12. It is a history of canals and the story of the builders from the Arabian achievements in the Dark Ages.
KUWAIT, April 30 -- Arab nationalist sources here report that friction is developing between, two factions of the Communist party in Iraq.
The United Steelworkers of America set its sights yesterday on a wage contract embodying the most substantial gains in its twenty-three-year history.
BUFFALO, April 30 -- Governor Rockefeller announced here tonight that his administration had started a sweeping study of the state's tax system.

For the first time since the anti-jaywalking campaign started last Aug. 8, pedestrian deaths have increased over the previous year, according to a Police Department report for the first four months of 1959.
The Port of New York Authority tightened its anti-noise restrictions on jet aircraft yesterday. It apparently acted out of dissatisfaction over compliance with its existing regulations.

LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- On-and-On is in again. The Calumet Farm's lone survivor among the Kentucky Derby eligibles was virtually withdrawn from the rich race yesterday, when his trainer, Jimmy Jones, said, "I won't run him in the Derby. He just isn't seasoned enough."
WASHINGTON, April 30 -The existence of life on Mars has been established almost beyond question, according to a leading authority.

The second program of "Highlights," switched on at the Metropolitan Opera House last night by the Bolshoi Ballet, proved to be lit even higher than the first one, if that seems at all credible. Almost everybody in the company appeared at one time or another, in bits and pieces ranging from classic ballet excerpts through character dances to specially devised exhibition numbers.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 30 -- One of the nation's top rocket experts challenged the Soviet Union tonight to permit international observation of its next space rocket or satellite launchings.

PARIS, April 30 -- The Western powers may have to lift their proposals for Berlin's future out of a four-power package and offer them to the Soviet Union as a separate subject for negotiation, United States and British diplomats indicated tonight.
The sale of the city's subway power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company moved closer to realization yesterday.
The Community Service Society has undertaken a study to uncover trends and conditions in which family problems originate.
DOVER, Del., April 30 (AP) -- Delaware's Legislature, concerned by an increase in the crime rate, has passed a bill making whipping mandatory for persons convicted of robbery.
Machine tool, business equipment and drug stocks held fairly firm yesterday against a gentle but general decline in the stock market. Every other important group showed more losses than gains.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved in Supreme Court yesterday to dissolve two trade associations for their allegedly monopolistic practices in the juke box and coin-operated amusement machines industry in New York.

Under the heading "Newfoundland Dilemma" you carried an editorial on April 2 dealing with the labor dispute currently affecting the logging operations of the pulp and paper industry of Newfoundland. Subsequently, on April 11, you published a letter from A. Martin, vice president and general manager of one of the two companies concerned, in which he stated "the scale of pay in the Newfoundland woods is higher than in any other east of Ontario."

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 30 -- Informal proposals by the United Arab Republic regarding the passage of Israeli cargo through the Suez Canal were conveyed here today by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Under Secretary, to the Israeli Foreign Minister, Mrs. Golda Meir.

LONDON, April 30 (UPI) -Bobby Hull and Ed Litzenberger, who were "borrowed" from the Chicago Black Hawks, each scored a goal to help the New York Rangers defeat the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 2, tonight in the second game of their European tour.
Plans have been completed for the second annual benefit tea dance of the New York Society of Colonial Wars. It will take place at the Union Club on Thursday.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 30 -- Three hundred and fifty high school students representing thirty-six states gathered here today to discuss the atom and its impact on the world of today and tomorrow.
Maritime interests and Government officials paid tribute yesterday to Thomas C. Gibney, chief of the entry and departure section of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in this district.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 30 (AP) -- The chief of Britain's atomic research program said today the "fantastic amounts" spent by the United States and the Soviet Union in trying to put a man into space could be better employed in medical and biological research on earth.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -The Justice Department came out today against several proposals for tougher internal security laws.
PARIS, April 30 -- President Charles de Gaulle created a sensation today by describing his policy in Algeria as one of integration with France.
TUCKAHOE, N. Y. April 30 -- Thirty-four teams ushered in another tournament season for the Westchester section of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association today.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Senate voted unanimously today to halt a reduction in the Marine Corps ordered by the Pentagon in defiance of Congress.

There recently were several warm days in a row. They were warm enough that topcoats came off, even suit coats came off, and at lunch time the photographers found no trouble locating park bench philosophers sitting in shirt sleeves.
The number of blind persons who can use dog guides may be limited and there may be more than enough schools to meet the demand, The Seeing Eye reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower today lifted the controls on oil imported from Canada, effective June 1.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Mrs. Rita Brandenburg is a Lakewood, N. J., poultry farmer's wife. She arose at 4:30 A.M. today to join more than 100 poultry farmers and wives for a bus ride to Washington.
The West Side Branch of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York City at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, described as the world's largest Y. W. C. A., was dedicated yesterday.

When a would-be pleasure boatman can't afford to buy a craft, why not lease it? That's the rhetorical question posed by the Welin people over in Perth Amboy, N. J., where 26-foot steel cruisers are being made.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., April 30 (AP) -- Officials of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway told an annual meeting of stockholders today that earnings in 1959 should exceed the $6.36 a share cleared last year.
Young men and women of other countries are asking for American pen friends. They live in such divers places as India and Egypt, Indones and England, Japan and other par of the free world.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce will see President Eisenhower at the White House tomorrow morning.

Trading volume in potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange reached 1,962 car lots yesterday, the largest for the year. The previous high was established on April 15, when 1,659 cars were traded.
A majority of the faction-torn Queens Democratic executive committee designated Borough President John T. Clancy last night as its candidate for his present office.
The Eisenhower Administration is not spending enough money on cancer research. Senator Richard L. Neuberger charged yesterday.

BONN, Germany, April 30 -- The President of the West German Bundestag (Parliament) said today that Germany's continued division was preferable to any reunification that could possibly be negotiated with Communist East Germany.

Lumber production last week was 249,052 thousand board feet, compared with 255,666 thousand the week before, according to reports by regional associations. Production was 10 per cent higher than a year ago, and shipments were also 10 per cent higher, but orders dropped 7 per cent from the level of 1958.

BUENOS AIRES, April 30 -The United States said today that fear of the Soviet economic system was not the reason it was cooperating with the other American nations to promote the economic growth of this hemishpere.
WHITE PLAINS, April 30 -- The annual scholarship benefit of the Skidmore College Alumnae Club of Westchester will be a breakfast fashion show at B. Altman Co here next Wednesday morning.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -The United States is sending two naval vessels to patrol Panama's coast and help intercept any further invasion of the tiny republic by Cuban-based rebels.
OTTAWA, April 30 -- Canada and the United States are engaged in extending and strengthening the Pine Tree Radar Line, according to a White Paper on defense issued today.

Gefuellte fish (with horse radish) and cheese blintzes (with sour cream) are the pleasantest memories and realities of a visit to Birobidzhan, in the Soviet Far East. The capital of that much-publicized, little-known colony called the Jewish Autonomous Province is the object of pride in Moscow and concern abroad.

WHEN the World Trade Fair opens at the Coliseum on May 9, the Swiss exhibit will include a "revolutionary" micrometer for measuring one-ten-thousandths of an inch, an "ingenious" shower valve, which prevents sudden scalding, and musical dolls.
PANAMA, April 30 -- Four members of a force that invaded Panama's Caribbean coast last week-end were flown here tonight amid indications that they were ready to talk surrender terms.
Almost no one wants war, yet we compete with the Soviets for allies raw materials and markets and in so doing play a cold war game which has repeatedly brought us to the brink of atomic war.
Stock offerings rose sharply here in April and bond flotations fell below the 1958 level.
" WOMEN could learn a great deal from nature when coordinating color schemes in fashions."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points (30 cents a bale) up to 6 points off yesterday. Prices fluctuated in a narrow range and lacked a trend.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- The Internal Revenue Service advised taxpayers today who have paid Federal income tax on strike benefit payments to file claims for refunds pending Supreme Court review of whether such payments are taxable.
Robert D. Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, last night warned against anyone's viewing the coming negotiations on Berlin from a standpoint of fear.

THE models galloped, minced or stalked stiffly down the runway before an enthusiastic audience of their peers. The youthful gravity with which they performed pointed up the seriousness of the occasion.
TRENTON, April 30 -- The Republican and Democratic parties convened here today in their annual state conventions. Tax crises at local and state levels were the predominating issues.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Chicago, 800 miles from an ocean, became a deep-draft seaport today.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The House today raised by $50,000,000 the amount President Eisenhower had asked for medical research in the coming fiscal year.
SOESTDIJK, The Netherlands, April 30 -- The Netherlands joined Queen Juliana today in celebrating her fiftieth birthday.
The Major League Baseball Players Association has appointed Frank Scott, a players' agent, as director of its central office, which will be established in New York.
A neat bit of historical joinery, almost a perfect fit, saw one time and place serve two useful purposes here yesterday.
CINCINNATI, April 30 (AP) -- Frederick John Kasper's conviction for contempt of Federal court was upheld for a second time today by the United States Court of Appeals.
AKRON, Ohio. April 30 (AP) -- Seiberling Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers Union agreed tonight on a contract involving 1,600 Ohio workers. The old contract expired at midnight.
WAYNE, N. J., April 30 -- An attempt by fifteen high school youths to set up a "Nazi regime of America" has been thwarted.
Six days a week they are civilians but one night a week they are soldiers of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The United States has tentatively decided to send no more high-altitude planes to West Berlin for the next few weeks.
LANSING, Mich., April 30 -A financially embarrassed Michigan encountered an array of operating problems today as the 144 legislators missed their first pay checks.

PARIS, April 30 -- The United States, Britain, France and West Germany proclaimed today their "complete agreement" on strategy for the May 11 meeting with the Soviet Union at Geneva. But the tactics of negotiation were left to be defined later.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Lewis I. Strauss charged today that Senator Estes Kefauver had been guilty of "the technique of trial by innuendo" in his opposition to Mr. Strauss' nomination to be Secretary of Commerce.

Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 12 per cent in first quarter sales of electricity. Operating revenues and net income for both three and twelve months ended March 31 showed sizable gains over the like 1958 periods.

LONDON, April 30 -- Widespread gains among the industrials in the stock market today kept the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary stocks on its record-making run. The level rose a half point to 228, its fifth peak in as many days of trading.
