MONTREAL, April 30 (AP) -- Aluminium Ltd. expects lower sales and earnings in 1959 than in 1958, Nathanael V. Davis, president, told the annual meeting today. Mr. Davis said Canadian production is being reduced to the previously announced annual rate of 500,000 tons.
WHITESBURG, Ky., April 30 (AP) -- A Federal court today forbade mass picketing for five days in the Eastern Kentucky coal strike.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 30 -Floyd Patterson of New York will risk his world heavyweight championship in a so-called "tune-up" match when he faces Brian London of Blackpool. England, at the Fair Grounds Coliseum tomorrow night.

Artur Rubinstein received a scroll of merit and the symbolic "keys to the city" from the City of New York at the annual meeting and luncheon of the Musicians Emergency Fund at the St. Regis Roof yesterday afternoon.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 30 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that small nations as well as great powers were competent to take part in settling important international issues.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products held unchanged between mid-March and mid-April. This left the farm price level 5 per cent below that a year earlier.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Two popular myths were shattered by statistics here today.
An American engineer says that Europeans are making better iron horses than are made in this country.
The Continental Can Company has agreed to acquire the Fort Wayne Corrugated Paper Company through an exchange of stock with a value of $23,000,000.
Former President Harry S. Truman led former Gov. W. Averell Harriman on a twenty-five block walk to breakfast yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Sons and daughters of Presidents of the United States regaled a ballroom sprinkled with White House descendants today with funny stories about their fathers.
The bond market was weak again yesterday.
Twenty girls set about yesterday to prove -- as Maeterlinck said in his play "The Blue Bird" -- that happiness is found in one's own back yard.
" THE EDUCATED WOMAN" took an examination last night on Columbia Broadcasting System radio with Edward R. Murrow as the proctor.
Friends of David M. Heyman honored him last night for his contributions to the community, especially in the field of medical care, at a testimonial dinner in the Pierre Hotel.
Off at even money, Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps' High Bid had an easy time at Jamaica yesterday defeating seven other 3-year-old fillies in the $7,500 Greenport Purse at a mile and a sixteenth.

A device capable of simulating the effects at a distance from an atomic or hydrogen bomb explosion was demonstrated here yesterday in a parking lot at Fifty-third Street and the Avenues of the Americas.
The Chrysler Corporation made a strong comeback in the first quarter of this year. Sales rose 29 per cent. Net earnings of $15,236,000 contrasted with a net loss of $15,100,000 in the 1958 period.

The image of Siberia as a frozen, desolate waste populated only by political exiles, their guards and a few natives has long been engraved in the consciousness of the West, but it is time that this image be replaced by a more accurate picture. That is the lesson driven home by the colorful articles on his visit to Siberia presented in these pages by Max Frankel of this newspaper's staff.

Leon A.E. Mollet, operator of hat check concessions in hotels and restaurants over the country, was indicted yesterday on a charge of attempting to evade $42,517 in withholding taxes and Social Security payments.
PARIS, April 30 -- Following is the address of Secretary of State Herter at the Ecole Alsaeienne today, together with an English translation:
St. Luke's Hospital failed yesterday in an attempt to evict fifty-nine tenants from a twenty-story apartment building it wants to reserve for the use of hospital employes.

Sol Hurok, the impresario, announced yesterday that he would present a Festival of Russian Music and Dance July 7-18 at Madison Square Garden. The company of 200 artists, which Mr. Hurok said would be the largest entertainment group yet to come from the Soviet Union, will give daily performances at night, except Sunday, July 11.
Stock prices moved to new highs last month under the leadership of electronic, pharmaceutical and special-situation issues.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower's policy of barring new starts on reclamation projects was attacked today in both houses of Congress. Both Democrats and Republicans assailed it.

The New York community's largest charitable appeal on behalf of programs for safeguarding human rights and promoting better intergroup understanding is the Joint Defense Appeal of the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, 300 West Forty-third Street, New York 36. The Joint Defense Appeal's two constituent agencies are the nation's oldest organizations dedicated to better understanding among all Americans regardless of race or creed.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 1 -- Floyd Patterson termed Brian London "the gamest challenger I've fought" as he faced a battery of photographers and reporters in the Fair Grounds Coliseum dressing room tonight.
Arthur Kill, one of the port's busiest shipping arteries, will be closed to deep-draft traffic for six days beginning May 24 to permit the installation of a 560-foot bridge section.

HE has to fight through quicksands of footnotes and the anxious, critical moments of scholarship's ambuscades. But in John E. Sunder's admirably precise "Bill Sublette, Mountain Man"* you see him emerge as one of the buckskinned immortals who blazed this country's way West.
LONDON, May 1 (AP) -- New Zealand gained the second round while England, Spain and Sweden, the advance favorites, scored opening sweeps today in the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition.
A group of securities dealers have been ordered to appear in State Supreme Court June 1 with any records bearing on a charge of conspiracy to manipulate stock in a North Dakota mining company.

Events today: Barbara Keenan, harpist, Eleanor Otto, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 2:15; National Music Orchestra, Town Hall, 2:40; Anabel Hulme Brieff, flutist, Igor Kipnis, harpsichordist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30.
CHICAGO. May 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
TOKYO, May 1 -- Election analysts here have conceded Premier Nobusuke Kishi's conservative supporters an overwhelming victory in yesterday's balloting for Mayors and other local offices.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 1 (UPI) -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown said today his present intention was to be a favorite son candidate for President in 1960. Senator John F. Kennedy, at the same time, hinted strongly that he would not run against the Governor in the California primary.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 1 -- Lieut. Col. Sir John Dring has been appointed administrator for the plebiscites to be held in the Cameroons to decide the territory's future
GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 1 -- Nearly 900 men and women who process and package fish for sixteen companies went on strike today. They asked for higher wages and changed working conditions.
GENEVA, May 1 -- The prospects for European exports to the United States "look good," Henry J. Heinz 2d, the United States delegate, told the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe today.

CONAKRY, Guinea, May 1 -- Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana and President Sekou Toure of Guinea signed an agreement tonight "immediately to lay the foundation" of a Union of Independent African States.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 1 (UPI) -- The State Public Utilities Commission criticized the New Haven Railroad today for causing commuter delays through Stamford, Conn.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee wound up seventeen days of hearings on Civil Rights legislation today preparatory to starting work on a bill.

NORWALK, Conn., May 1 -- Youthful fishermen who for years have been forced to yield to older anglers, are finally coming into their own. Shortly before noon tomorrow a city-owned pond in Riverside Park will be opened for children under 16 years old.
SYRACUSE, May 1 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted eight men today in an alleged ticket-refund racket that reportedly cost the New York Central Railroad an estimated total of $10,000 in one year.
The head of the country's unionized steelworkers served notice yesterday that they expected a "good share" of the industry's near-record profits.
Round Hill, the metropolitan champion, increased its lead in the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's inter-club team matches yesterday.
A serious shortage of school textbooks was reported yesterday by the executive secretary of the American Textbook Publishers Institute.

THE problem of keeping a coffee maker "sweet" and clean has perplexed many a home cook. Should the morning brew begin to taste differently, a stale or unclean utensil is generally the culprit, not the coffee blend.

The formula for the Treasury's pending $5,300,000,000 financing operation was accepted yesterday by the bond market as a constructive bit of news. Prices of all types of top-risk fixed-income investments showed improvement except in the short-term area, where the major impact of the Treasury's refunding and cash borrowing will be felt.
MONTREAL, May 1 (UPI) -- Ralph Backstrom, tabbed as the next superstar of the talent-laden world champion Montreal Canadiens, was named "rookie of the year" today in the National Hockey League.

The first Saturday of May holds a special significance in the world of sport. It's Kentucky Derby Day, and this year the excitement runs higher than ever in Louisville, for there is no clear-cut favorite in the venerable classic. Pre-Derby trials have proved that any horse in the large field can win the Run for the Roses, and many candidates that earlier had raised the hopes of their owners have been weeded out.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 1 (AP) -- The Tennessee Court of Appeals upheld an agreement today under which control of the Life and Casualty Insurance Company of Tennessee would be transferred to Clint Murchison, Texas financier, for about $40,000,000.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 1 (AP) -- A shopping center, built on land acquired from the Harry S. Truman family changed hands today in a multi-million transaction.

PERTH, Australia, May 1 -- The death toll resulting from Wednesday's explosion in the engine room of the Norwegian tanker Farmand rose to nine today with the death on the liner Australia of one of the six injured men transferred to her.
HARTFORD, May 1 -- Governor Abraham A Ribicoff sent to the General Assembly today the nomination of forty-four lawyers to be judges of the new State Circuit Court.

Canadian Pacific Airlines has reported 4,000 advance reservations on the new turbo-propeller Britannia service across Canada. The service begins Monday. The British-built airliner will establish the fastest air service in Canada between Vancouver, Winnipeg, Toronto and Montreal.

LONDON, May 1 -- Take a square mile called the City of London. Populate it with 4,000 permanent, or night-time, residents. Add during the daytime hours about one hundred times that many clerks, waiters, merchants, bankers, lawyers, tradesmen, fishmongers and barrow boys.

UNITED NATIONS, May 1 (AP) -- Diplomatic sources said tonight that three leading national exporters of lead and zinc, in private session here, had agreed in principle to cut their production of these metals 10 to 20 per cent to stabilize prices.
BERLIN, May 1 -- One in every four West Berliners went to the Square of the Republic today to give meaning to the city's single May Day slogan: "Berlin will remain free."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The General Accounting Office accused the Air Force today of spending more money on its new academy at Colorado Springs, Colo., than it had originally estimated and Congress had authorized.
LANSING, Mich., May 1 -- The Republican majority in Michigan's Senate today put off until next week any possible solution to the state's fiscal crisis.

DETROIT, May 1 (AP) -- The nation's auto industry, basking in a surging spring demand, has built 2,179,182 passenger cars so far this year. In the 1958 recession period the factories turned out 1,555,295 passenger cars.
Two All-Star games instead of one may be played each year, Ford Frick, the commissioner of baseball, announced yesterday.
The Hertz Corporation was charged yesterday with having made acquisitions and mergers that could lessen competition or tend to create a monopoly in the renting of motor vehicles.

The cookout season is again at hand, and the coals are rosy in the charcoal grill. Into the soft spring air smoke rises from ten thousand times ten thousand yards and terraces, drifting lazily up and up. Badly burned are ten thousand times ten thousand fingers, and scorched are just as many races.
Cotton futures advanced 1 to 9 points (5 to 45 cents a bale yesterday, with the far months strongest.
Members of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs were urged yesterday to obtain evidence of pornography and report it to authorities.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce resigned today as Ambassador to Brazil.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Organization of American States will maintain its air and sea alert along the Panamanian coast despite today's surrender.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday the selection of Robert MacCrate of Port Washington, L. I., to succeed Roswell B. Perkins as the Governor's counsel. Mr. Perkins is resigning in about a month.

NEWMARKET, England, May 1 (UPI) -- Prince Aly Khan's stable completed an unusual "double" today when Petite Etoile carried the Prince's colors to a one-length victory over Rosalba, owned by John Jacob Astor of New York, in the One Thousand Guineas Stakes at Newmarket.

TRENTON, May 1 -- The Appellate Division of Superior Court granted the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad today the right to discontinue twenty-eight more passenger trains of its remaining total of forty-four.
HONG KONG, May 1 -- Peiping newspapers said today that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India had misrepresented the situation in Tibet and had interfered in Communist China's internal affairs.
THE parents of a high school boy were disturbed to learn that he cheated regularly on his examinations. But their initial anger was checked by another discovery.

Manhattan, New York University and Fordham each produced a winner yesterday as the twenty-sixth annual metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships opened with the staging of three field events at Ohio Field.
The long-awaited conversation between Mayor Wagner and Park Commissioner Robert Moses over free Shakespeare in Central Park is expected to take place today.
Children seemed to be jumping all over the place yesterday. One explanation came from the Children's Aid Society, which announced that it was observing Youth Fitness Week beginning tomorrow.

Although volume dropped to the lowest level in three weeks, prices on the New York Stock Exchange rallied appreciably yesterday under the somewhat hesitant leadership of steels, motors and electronics.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. last night urged Negroes in New York to support a new drive for passive resistance to segregation laws throughout the South.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Fifteen companies received more than $2,000,000 each from the Government last year for storing surplus farm crops.
A new word game that is designed to help children create sentences and help them read is called the "Rolling Reader."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Boring through the earth's crust may cost $5,000,000 or $10,000,000 and cannot be achieved within less than two or three years, according to planners of the project. Still, they believe the rewards will be incalculable.
The previously announced policy of respecting technicians' picket lines around the National Broadcasting Company was rescinded yesterday by New York's teamsters.
HOUSTON, Tex., May 1 (AP) -- Residents of suburban Aldine rioted at a school board meeting last night during a dispute over the school system's lack of funds.

Harvard's baseball team scored its first Eastern Intercollegiate League victory of the season yesterday, vanquishing Columbia, 8 -- 6. The contest at Baker Field was marred by loose fielding. Each team was charged with seven errors.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 -- President Arturo Frondizi said today that Argentina was still searching for "full and effective national peace." Dr. Frondizi began today on the second year of his Administration.

MAHUSEKWA, Southern Rhodesia, May 1 -- After two nights naked and unarmed in a lion-haunted secret cave surrounded by the mummified bodies of his ancestors, a 45-year-old African master farmer, Willie Samuriwo, was "crowned" today chief and supreme head of the Va-Mhani clan of the Varozwi tribe.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 1 (AP) -- "I'm coming back to the States and learn to fight."
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa's Teamsters Union has withdrawn under fire from the International Transport Workers Federation.
The sun suddenly burst out bright and warm yesterday and before anyone could shout "harugakita!"* the Japanese cherry trees were in bloom at Brooklyn's Botanic Garden.
Scare psychology was depicted yesterday as hurting campaigns that urge people to get periodic cancer check-ups, to drive carefully, or to "do something" toward the abolition of atomic warfare.
" WOULD you please send me a recipe for making hot potato salad?" Mrs. Marjorie Tulinsky, Brooklyn.

The Panamanian "invasion" ended ingloriously yesterday. This was fitting for a fantastic adventure whose whole conception was false from the beginning. Moreover, the episode was anachronistic; it was a throwback to the days of "banana republics" and opera bouffe revolutions. Nevertheless, the weakness of the Government of President de la Guardia was such that it might have succeeded.
THE Japanese invasion of the Western world's nonobjective painting has been powerfully supported by remarkable decorative gifts, about which Western artists are inclined to be condescending.
Directors of the General Transistor Corporation voted yesterday to split the common stock two for one.

Louisville, Ky., borrowed $1,000,000 in the bond market yesterday on serial obligations due from 1959 to 1966. The securities were bought by a syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. and Equitable Securities Corporation. The price was 100.01 for 2.6 per cent bonds, equal to an interest cost of 2.597 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields scaled from 2 per cent to 2.7 per cent.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Michigan officials asked Congress today for $39,500,000 for work on the Great Lakes connecting channels and a score of harbor projects.

" Modern Times," the 1936 feature starring Charlie Chaplin, will begin a revival engagement today at the Plaza Theatre. The comedy, which features Paulette Goddard and Chester Conklin in supporting roles, satirizes the contemporary industrial system. Mr. Chaplin portrays an employe in a toy factory.
WASHINGTON, May (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Edgar C. Erickson, chief of the National Guard Bureau for six years, will retire at the end of this month.
ALBANY, May 1 -- The cost of education will rise but its quality may not keep pace, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, warned here today.

The stage is being set abroad for what looks like the last act of an international financial drama smacking of Hans Christian Andersen. The start goes back more than thirty years to the short-lived "new freedom" era that followed World War I.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Loyd Wright, chairman of the former Commission on Government Security, told Congress today that it had a right and a duty to override what he called Supreme Court misinterpretations of laws against subversion.
CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- Grain futures activity on the Board of Trade today was guided almost entirely by speculative positions in the May contracts where about half the volume of business was done.
M. J. Frankovich has been elevated to chairman of Columbia Pictures, Ltd., of Great Britain and Ireland and Kenneth N. Hargreaves has been appointed to succeed him as managing director.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today that Americans must "sacrifice, dig into our pocketbooks and [use] our intelligence" to help achieve world peace.

The appearance of Mike Nichols and Elaine May at Town Hall last night broke new ground for concert hall attractions. Miss May and Mr. Nichols are satirists whose perceptive and bitingly humorous sketches are normally seen in intimate night clubs and occasionally on television.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Justice Department joined steel management and labor today in opposing a bill to require advance notification and public justification of price increases in "concentrated" industries.
FORMBY, England, May 1 (AP) -- Michael Bonallack and Guy Wolstenholme saved face for the British Walker Cup team selectors by reaching the final of the English amateur golf championship today.
" Law Day, like Mother's Day," a trial lawyer said here yesterday, "now has one day a year designated for its celebration. Both deserve daily observance."
LONDON, May 1 (AP) -- British fans listened to the radio tonight and glumly heard another of their hopes for the world heavyweight title bite the canvas.
SHELVES are the best seller in furnishings today, according to a recent poll of the staff at the Design Center for Interiors, 415 East Fifty-third Street.

GUATEMALA CITY. Guatemala, April 30 -- The Government today imposed a surcharge of 100 per cent on tariffs on goods imported from Mexico and 27 other countries with which Guatemala had an unfavorable trade balance last year.

MUNICH, Germany, May 1 (AP) -- An official West German counter-espionage organization said today that an East German spy ring in West Germany had been cracked with the arrest of several agents, including a woman secretary of the United States Embassy in Bonn.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 1 (AP) -- Premier Abdel Karim Kassim said in a May Day-eve speech here that he was opposed to political party activity in Iraq in the immediate future.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A German-born engineer received a patent this week for a device to help students conjugate irregular English verbs. A night school teacher of English, the inventor says he has used it effectively himself.

It seems to us that Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce has followed a wise course in offering the President her resignation as Ambassador to Brazil. What is of most importance in this matter, outranking all personal considerations, is the maintenance of close and confident relations between this country and its great neighbor to the south.

SEOUL, Korea, May 1 -- A leading Opposition daily newspaper, Kyunghyang Shinmun, was closed by the Government Information Office last night on the ground that it had printed editorials and news articles of a false nature.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that the charges against Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan "go beyond" those disclosed by Mr. Monaghan. Mr. Monaghan, who has refused a request by the Governor to resign, had reported two charges brought against him in a report by the State Investigation Commission last March.
Changes in the top management of the Electric Auto-Lite Company were announced yesterday by the manufacturer of automotive electrical equipment.

A Tibetan shrine on Staten Island has sent directly to the Dalai Lama an invitation to use the facilities of the shrine. The United States State Department had said the department could not forward an official invitation to the exiled ruler of Tibet.
THE closing Friday afternoon concert of the New York Philharmonic's 116th season paid tribute to Handel.

NEW ORLEANS, May 1 (UPI) -- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals today took under consideration a request by the Justice Department to reinstate a suit against the State of Alabama. The suit involves a charge of discrimination against Negro voters.

LONDON, May 1 -- The saying that woman's place is in the home is the notion of "angry young men, or frustrated old women in a Moslem community," a career woman and mother said today. A good response, Dr. Alice M. Stewart of Oxford University suggests would be to say, "man's place is behind a wheelbarrow.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- Moscow's May Day panegyric to peace opened today with a declaration in Red Square by the Defense Minister, Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky, that the Soviet armed forces were "ready at any instant to render a crushing rebuff to any aggressor."
ITHACA, N. Y., May 1 (AP) -- The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation today reported first-quarter earnings equal to $1.34 a share at the annual meeting.
Most public thinking about our city's rapid transit system is as untidy as the stations, tunnels and trains comprising it. The reason for this kind of thinking is historic and apparent.
Smoke from a basement restaurant fire poured from the fifty-fourth-floor vent of the sixty-story Woolworth Building yesterday.
Officers of New York Typographical Union No. 6 (Big Six) announced yesterday they were opposed to the new contract proposal made Thursday by ten New York newspapers.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, May 1 -- The United States Army is telling its soldiers in West Germany to be ready to defend West Berlin.
A Queens father pushed his 4-year-old son out of a sixth floor window early yesterday and then jumped out himself. Both landed on a rain-softened lawn and survived, but the boy was seriously injured.
Once again the May Day festival which for centuries has hailed the magic of returning spring has been used by the Communist chieftains for a demonstration of their power.
ROME, May 1 -- Pope John XXIII warned Roman Catholic workers today not to become allies of communism in their legitimate quest of social justice.

Representative Emilio Q. Daddarrio, in a letter to The New York Times published April 9, made the commendable effort of giving as objective a picture as possible of the difference of opinion between Austria and Italy concerning the South Tyrolean problem.
More than 5,000,000 Eastern Orthodox churchgoers in the United States will observe their Holy Day of Easter tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The volume of consumer installment credit outstanding rose to a new post-recession peak of $33,943,000,000 in March, the Federal Reserve Board estimated today.
OKMULGEE, Okla., May 1 (AP) -- Strikers' wives defied hot weather and the threat of jail by blockading the Phillips Petroleum Company refinery again today.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Department of Justice has decided to take no action against the merger of J. P. Morgan Co. and the Guaranty Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Lewis L. Strauss charged today that a physicist's criticism of his nomination as Secretary of Commerce had violated scientific regard for "objectivity and truth."

SIXTY black-salmon, or fish that had spawned and were on their way back to sea after a winter in fresh water, were caught on the Pleasant River in Maine last week. This is the first spring in which black-salmon fishing has been permitted in Maine.
PANAMA, May 1 -- Virtually the entire invasion force that sought the overthrow of the Panamanian Government surrendered today. The invaders were said to number eighty-seven.

The Bobbs-Merrill Company, book publisher, leased office space in the new Corning Glass Building at 717 Fifth Avenue, corner of Fifty-sixth Street, and has moved from 468 Fourth Avenue. Harry N. Masson and Newton Blakeslee, vice presidents of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting agent of the building, negotiated the lease.

OTTAWA, May 1 -- A Conservative Member of Parliament charged today that the United States had barred Canadian trucks from transporting goods of Chinese origin in bond from one province to another across United States territory since Feb. 19.

Harry Shapolsky, the real estate operator described by the New York County District Attorney's office as "the front man for high Building Department officials," was fined $4,000 yesterday in Special Sessions Court for rent gouging.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 12,247 pints of blood last month, compared with 11,291 pints in March.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Average wholesale prices at the primary market level declined 0.1 per cent to 119.8 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

MOSCOW, May 1 (Reuters) -- A Soviet scientist asserted today that the two moons of Mars were probably artificial satellites put into orbit by beings who lived on the planet two thousand or three thousand million years ago.
MADRID, May 1 -- Spain's 30,000 Protestants meet severe legal handicaps in getting married, educating their children and burying their dead.
The twenty-two-day strike of 26,000 employes of the United States Rubber Company was ended yesterday by an agreement between the company and the United Rubber Workers Union.

A ready acceptance of 267 May delivery notices firmed potato prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The May position was up 1/2 cent a pound, the daily limit. Final prices were up 2 to 48 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

Earnings of the Dynamics Corporation of America in the first four months of this year rose 20 per cent, orders more than tripled and backlogs nearly doubled those of a year ago, Raymond F. Kelley, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
NEWARK, May 1 -- Alternative plans designed to save the New York Central's West Shore service for some 3,000 riders were proposed today by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

Brookmeade Stable's strapping Big Effort will carry actual high weight of 122 in Jamaica's $28,550 Bed o' Roses Handicap today, but the high weight on the scale is Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Hope Is Eternal, who will tote 109 in the field of ten fillies and mares.
HAVANA, May 1 -- Cuban labor staged a mammoth May Day celebration in Havana today.
JOSEPH PAPP, whose running battle with Park Commissioner Robert Moses over free Shakespearean performances in Central Park has had political repercussions, is a young entrepreneur of awesome energy.
WARSAW, May 1 -- The big May Day parade in Warsaw turned out to be more like a stroll. The whole day was that way -- organized but almost casual.

The apparent failure of the Geneva Atomic Conference calls once again for a reappraisal of our diplomatic methods. In your editorial of April 22, "Salvage at Geneva," you point out the enormous propaganda value Communist Russia has derived from shouting for complete suspension of atomic bomb tests.

The wives of the men working at Cape Canaveral, Fla., may never see a launching pad, and the work their husbands do is a forbidden topic of conversation. But they are getting to known about the unclassified aspects of life on a missile base by proxy.

PARIS, May 1 -- There is a fundamental difference between the two types of negotiation that just took place on both sides of the Iron Curtain as a preliminary to the grand negotiation this month in Geneva. Here in Paris, Western foreign ministers sought as equal allies to formulate an agreed position for presentation to the Russians as the basis for a Berlin settlement.

Twelve Paulists were ordained as priests yesterday by Cardinal Spellman. The ceremony took place at the Mother Church of the Paulist Fathers, the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
WHAT room cannot be enlivened by the addition of a new accessory? The object can be functional or purely decorative, but it must be a cherished one so as to reflect the homemaker's taste.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- The Department of the Interior said today that thirty-two whooping cranes were headed for their Canadian nesting area after wintering in the Aransas, Tex., wildlife refuge.

Guild Films Company, Inc., yesterday filed its annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission revealing a net loss of $4,061,143 on gross film rental income of $3.273,380 in the fiscal year ended Nov. 31, 1958.
LONDON, May 1 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery said on his return from Moscow today that he thought he now saw "a gleam of light at the end of the tunnel.
APPLETON, Wis., May 1 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, left an estate valued at $179,942, from which his widow, Jean Kerr McCarthy, will receive approximately $127,000.
The Port of New York Authority has renewed its campaign to acquire a part of the city-owned waterfront for terminal operation.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators started a series of baseball lectures today for an all-female audience.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 1 -- The consultative committee of the projected African-Asian Economic Cooperation Organiaztion was reported today to have reached a decision that would bar the Soviet Union from joining the group.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- A facility scheduled to become the nation's foremost space center was named today in honor of the nation's pioneer of rocketry. Dr. Robert Hutchings Goddard.
Investors Mutual, Inc., reported yesterday a new high in net assets, shares outstanding and shareholders at the end of the first quarter.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 1 -- It took much longer than expected. but Floyd Patterson finished off Brian London with one dramatic flourish in the eleventh round tonight.

CLEVELAND, May 1 -- The Yankees, still bearing an enfeebled, not to say "dismantled," look, invaded this turbulent metropolis tonight to see for themselves what was making these strange front-running Indians tick. They wound up making a painful discovery.
The new capital market begins a three-week period of less than normal activity on Monday.

The property at 341 to 353 East Seventy-third Street, between First and Second Avenues, has been purchased by the Kashan Realty Corporation, for improvement with an apartment building. It consists of five residential and two commercial structures on a plot 175 by 102 feet. It was sold by the Sax Realty Company, broker, for Walter Samuels.
CHICAGO, May 1 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox today acquired an outfielder, Del Ennis, from the Cincinnati Reds in exchange for an outfielder, Lou Skizas, and a left-handed pitcher, Don Rudolph.
YONKERS, May 1 -- Two noses separated the first three finishers in the free-for-all handicap one-mile trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 1 -- The "devil theory" that seeks to explain the post-war rises in prices and living costs by singling out labor or management as the villain was challenged at Arden House here today.

" Why People Buy: Motivation Research and Its Successful Application," by Louis Cheskin, will be published May 19 by Liveright. It deals primarily with the behavior of people in the market place, particularly women who do about 80 per cent of the buying. The author discusses products and sales, based on tests confirmed by sales records.
MONTREAL, May 1 (CP) -- In the first six days of its operation the St. Lawrence Seaway showed 128 ships, 76 upbound and 52 downbound, passing through the St. Lambert Lock at its eastern end.
An anti-Communist May Day celebration was held yesterday in Union Square Park, where a crowd of 500 persons listened to patriotic speeches.

On April 22 Governor Rockefeller signed into law the Speno bill which for the first time in the history of the state recognizes the educational needs of the mentally ill child. The bill provides for state aid for school districts willing to set up services for mentally ill, or as they are commonly referred to emotionally disturbed children, provided the Commissioner of Education approves the particular type of service.

LONDON, May 1 (Reuters) -- Britain's merchant officers said here today they viewed with the "gravest concern" the slump in the world demand for shipping services and the growth of "flags-of-convenience" fleets.
VIENNA, May 1 -- A package deal for Berlin, Germany and armament controls has been worked out in Vienna.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., May 1 (UPI) -- Republican task forces wrestled today with the problem of how to define the party's philosophy in terms that the voters will understand.

The Standard Oil Company of California plans to spend more than $400,000,000 for expansion and exploration this year. R. G. Follis, chairman, made the announcement yesterday in the company's report on first-quarter operations.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 28 -- Fishery officials here warn of a new threat to Iceland rising in the East.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 -- Ion propulsion of space vehicles appears much closer than has been generally believed.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration abandoned today its plans to shoot two rocket payloads to the vicinity of Venus in June.
Radar in the hands of a properly trained deck officer can be a potent and valuable anti-collision device, a leading Government maritime official said here yesterday.

The Lewisohn Stadium concerts are back on this summer's agenda of musical events after the settlement of a contract dispute between Stadium Concerts, Inc., and Local 802, American Federation of Musicians.

In the merry month of May the stock market often -- but not always -- has been very merry. A backward look shows that during the past twenty years, The New York Times combined average rose thirteen times and fell seven during the month.
If June 1 is a hot, muggy day in New York, the public will at least have a measure for its discomfort, a meteorological-psychological balm confirming just how tough a day it is.
Arthur Godfrey's recovery from his operation progressed "so well" that he was briefly out of bed twice yesterday afternoon, according to a hospital report.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Three makers of watches and clocks were ordered by the Atomic Energy Commission tonight not to distribute any luminescent dials containing strontium 90.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 (AP) -- Wedlock and Hidden Talent won the sections of the eighty-fifth running of the Kentucky Oaks today at Churchill Downs. The Oaks, as old as the Kentucky Derby itself, was split in two divisions when sixteen 3-year-old fillies were entered.
REDDELL, La., May 1 -- (UPI) -- A white woman was raped, stabbed and beaten to death in a grocery robbery today and the police arrested Negro youth in connection with the crime.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce to President Eisenhower resigning as Ambassador to Brazil:

PARIS, May 1 -- The West will go to the Geneva conference of foreign ministers prepared for a certain flexibility of negotiation within limits, according to authoritative diplomatic sources. The limits will be an unswerving devotion to the goal of Germany's reunification.

What will the city be like ten years from now? The Community Service Society has set itself the task of coming up with some answers The purpose is to adapt its services to the changing times. The agency believes it could do so more readily after studying the trends and conditions within the city that affect the well-being of its families.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 1 (AP) -- The Kaiser Bauxite Company has made Jamaican history by handing the Government a check for $4,338,417 (1,549,434) for corporate income taxes. This is the largest amount ever paid by any one company to the Jamaican Government in any income tax year.

LONDON, May 1 -- Cancer investigators have obtained "unequivocal" proof that the growth of tumors can be arrested under laboratory (but not clinical) conditions by a biochemical substance called royal jelly, a milky-white secretion produced by bees.
SEATTLE, May 1 (AP) -- A state agency's attempt to force sale of a house in an all-white neighborhood to a Negro family brought a few threats and some name-calling today.

The nation's big common carrier trucking lines expect their future growth to result from an expanding economy rather than from a siphoning off of bulk traffic movements from the railroads, according to Neil J. Curry, chairman of the Executive Committee of the American Trucking Associations.

Tom Mboya, Kenya political and labor leader, urged this country yesterday to adopt a "more enlightened policy" toward Africa. Americans should remember, he said, that every person in the world does not own a refrigerator or a pair of shoes.

STRATFORD, Conn., May 1 -- The performance of "Romeo and Juliet" at the Shakespeare Festival Theatre here on May 29 has been chosen by the Manhattanville Club of Lower Connecticut. It will be a benefit for the building fund of a new chapel at Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in Purchase, N. Y.
VINCENT CAPRARO, we are told, was a captain in the Marines, a champion basketball star and a movie actor before he became a painter.

Phillip P. Zipes, realty operator, has contracted to sell the group of three apartment buildings occupying a plot 100 by 88 feet at 218-22 East 188th Street and 2453 alentine Avenue, the Bronx, to a client of Hyman Bettigole, lawyer. The houses contain thirty apartments and two stores and are assessed at $100,000.
MOSCOW, May 1 -- Hula hoops and fantastic balloons turned Moscow's Red Square May Day parade into a holiday fete in bright spring sunshine today.

National Housing Administrator Norman P. Mason was asked yesterday by a civic group to overrule Walter S. Fried, the regional administrator, Mr. Fried has decided against checking on the accuracy and veracity of reports made to the Federal Government by Robert Moses, chairman of this city's Committee on Slum Clearance.
PARIS, May 1 -- Philibert Tsiranana, the political leader of Madagascar and a stanch supporter of France, was elected President of the Republic of Madagascar today.
NEW DELHI, India, May 1 -- The exodus of anti-Communist refugees from Tibet into India now totals 7,000 persons, official sources said today.
LONDON, May 1 -- The stock market ended a record-breaking week with new records still being set and trading active.
In the first week of its campaign to "bring riders back to the rails," the Pennsylvania Railroad has increased the number of fast trains on its New York-to-Washington route.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- A cliche can make a man an expert in these parts, on the eve of the eighty-fifth running of the $125,000 added Kentucky Derby. A common phrase is heard on all sides and, curiously enough, it has pertinence relating to the event that will attract a crowd or 100,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2 -- In thousands of remote villages in the Colombian Andes, a prayer in Spanish and a strain of familiar music signal the start of school each day. This is school by radio, carried to 40,000 classes, many of them scattered through the snow-covered mountains of the Cordillera.
JAKARTA, Indomesia, May 2 -- Communist China was reported today to have bitterly attacked a decision that would bar the Soviet Union in a projected Asian-African economic cooperation organization.

HALF a million people in Britain have signed a petition requesting that Parliament exempt from the normal copyright laws the series of works by W. S. Gilbert and Arthur Sullivan known as The Savoy Operas. The music copyright expired nine years ago, fifty years after the death of Sullivan.

FROM time to time, when positive errors of fact or possible errors of judgment have occurred in this column, I have customarily acknowledged them in a later issue. Occasionally, when the matter in dispute seemed of sufficient general interest, I have devoted a column to the conflicting claims.

The Graham School at Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., will benefit from a Moonlight Carnival to be held aboard the Hudson Belle on June 11. The Wilson Line ship will depart from Pier 40 at 7 P. M. for a fourhour cruise on the Hudson River.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- The popularity of Florida's twenty-two state parks among visitors and residents alike is attested by the fact that last year they had a total attendance of 2,870,000, and in the past three years, a total of about 8,000,000.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 2 -- Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Talent Show nipped Deak Duncan, a 20-1 shot, by a head in the last stride to win the $27,500 Valley Forge Handicap at Garden State Park today.
Twenty librarians have been elected to the "Hall of Fame" of the Special Libraries Association, it was announced yesterday.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 2 -- Six records fell today as a sprinter, Steve Snyder, and a hurdler, Jim Carney, paced Yale to a 96-44 track victory over Princeton in Palmer Stadium.

A high school girl in New Jersey has touched off an interesting discussion by writing to more than a hundred prominent persons to ask an evaluation of the study of Latin. Almost all the replies, including those of the Vice President, two Supreme Court justices and several college presidents, gave a warm endorsement to the usefulness of classical language study.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 2 -- Floyd Patterson said today he was going right back to work for his next title defense against Ingemar Johansson of Sweden in New York on June 25.
Evidence that the "cult of personality" is being built about Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev is given in an official biography made public by the Soviet Embassy in Washington.

The Republic of Panama is 480 miles long, between 37 and 110 miles wide, covers 28,752 square miles (five-eighths of them uninhabited jungle) and has 960,000 people, the smallest population of the twenty-one American republics.

At the year-end the steel industry envisioned a sparkling first-half performance this year, with production and profits spurting smartly from the depressed levels of 1958. But that was four months ago.
A new catalogue of regulations and procedures affecting seamen has been postponed for six months by the Coast Guard.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 2 -- The Women of St. Barnabas Protestant Episcopal Church will sponsor a horse and pony show on May 10 at Clifton Farm, the home of Mr. and Mrs. C. Soutter Edgar on Round Hill Road, for the benefit of the church's building fund.
This is a thumbnail sketch of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, who last Tuesday was confirmed by the Senate and on Friday resigned as Ambassador to Brazil:
LOUISVILLE, May 2 -- Tomy Lee won the eighty-fifth running of the Kentucky Derby today after surviving the second foul claim in the history of the event.
MOSCOW, May 2 -- The eternal pageant of Christ's Resurrection and Russia's traditional Easter festivities preoccupied the Soviet capital today.

Prospects for a wider free-trading area in Europe continue uncertain, although studies and negotiations are continuing toward that end, according to Jean Rey, commissioner in charge of external relations of the European Economic Community.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- An employer's right to lock out his employes as a defensive measure does not include the right to a part lockout to deprive them of unemployment compensation.

A BILL that would have suspended for a one-year trial period the legal surcharge of $1.25 on theatre tickets purchased through brokers failed to reach a vote at the recent session of the State Legislature. It arrived in Albany too late to make the legislative hopper -- which carried no fewer than 1,200 bills. Next year, its proponents hope, it will make the hopper and come out as law.

Tomy Lee, ridden by Willie Shoemaker, survived a claim of foul lodged by Bill Boland, the rider of the second-place Sword Dancer, and won the $163,750 Kentucky Derby at Louisville. Tomy Lee's margin was a nose and he paid $9.40 for $2.
The High School of Performing Arts presented six of its students at Town Hall yesterday afternoon as soloists with the National Music Week Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Julius Grossman.

ON the title page of "Picasso: His Life and Work" Roland Penrose quotes a statement by the French writer, Georges Ribemont-Dessaignes, "Nothing one can say of Picasso is exact." At several points in his account Penrose stresses Pablo Picasso's "predilection for ambiguity."
Sir Winston Churchill, who is due in this country tomorrow, may number among his many American cousins some New York State Indians.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Thirty-five professors at Columbia, Cornell, Harvard, Pennsylvania and Yale Law Schools joined today in opposition to proposals for toughening internal security laws.

The demand for automobiles and trucks has accelerated sharply in the past three weeks. Sales of new cars recording a 40 per cent year-to-year gain for the period, against a 26 per cent rise in the January-March quarter.

GENEVA, May 2 (Reuters) -- New proposals were made today by a Japanese Red Cross delegation that is holding talks here with North Korean Red Cross representatives on the repatriation of 600,000 Koreans in Japan.

Leaders in psychiatry have generally agreed that the best available approach to the treatment of schizophrenia is the method known as insulin shock therapy. In this procedure a massive dose of insulin produces a state of profound coma by suddenly depriving the brain of sugar, the brain's fuel.
Americans who wait for the first heat wave to buy room air conditioners may swelter for days before the equipment is delivered.

Retail trade continued its upward climb last week, and the percentage gains in the district continued to outdistance the average for the country as a whole. A seasonal improvement in factory production and a high level of construction whittled down the unemployed total.
William Hersey Kendall is a new-model railroad president who has turned up as the president of an old-model railroad.

The knitwear industry's biennial knitting arts exhibition will open tomorrow in Atlantic City. It will show a complete range of circular, flat-bed and full-fashioned knitting machinery for outerwear, underwear and hosiery, and equipment for pressing, sewing, dyeing and packaging the products.

ROBERT DHERY, whose Gallic, "La Plume de Ma Tante," has been jamming them in at the Royale Theatre while capturing the New York Drama Critics' "Best Musical of the Year" award, is, strangely enough, looking toward different entertainment horizons.

MILWAUKEE, May 2 -- The San Francisco Giants battered four Milwaukee pitchers for seventeen hits, including a pair of homers by Willie Kirkland and one by Hobie Landrith, for an 8-5 victory over the Braves today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- In a beautiful display of oarsman-ship between two of the best eights of the year, Yale defeated Pennsylvania by a second, less than a deck, to win the Blackwell Cup for the fourth successive time today.
An all-African musical rooted in "township jazz" -- the irrepressible rhythms of the urban Negro slums in a strictly segregated country -- is the theatrical sensation of the Union of South Africa.
Stores in this country looking for "plus" business that lends itself to promotional events are making plans to put on "import fairs" in the months ahead.

New York University sprang the cinderpath upset of the decade yesterday. Coach Joe Healy's fire-up squad, paced by the versatile Mike Herman, broke Manhattan's nine-year hold on the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field title.

THE most intimate form of music? Some might say the string quartet or trio. Some might say a family singing hymns or Gilbert and Sullivan in the parlor, Mom at the piano, Dad filling in the bass and the kids carrying the melodic line.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 2 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham continues to draw tens of thousands of people to his Australian crusade meetings and has become the main topic of conversation in this city.
IZMIR, Turkey, May, 2 (AP) -- A mob tonight attacked the offices and printing plant of the anti-Government newspaper Demokrat Izmir, causing extensive damage to the equipment.

Larger-than-expected gains in department store sales that began during Easter persisted last week as the eleventh Federal Reserve bank reported sales in the metropolitan area 20 per cent above the 1958 levels. New car registrations in the four largest metropolitan areas reflected substantial month-to-month and year-to-year gains.
In the popular mind the noun "importer" almost invariably is preceded by the adjective "wealthy."

LONDON, May 2 -- Nottingham Forest, playing brilliant soccer, held on to a 2-1 victory over Luton Town in the English Football Association Cup final today despite the loss of a key man because of a cracked shinbone.

New York City, once a favorite of teachers, today cannot recruit enough of them. The suburban communities are more attractive. Their salaries as higher and teachers there need not cope with the problems of educating underprivileged children of slum areas.

AT the end of the last page of William Peters' fine book on the problem of desegregation in the South one feels as if one had just read, in excellent reportorial style, an exhaustive diagnostic report on a patient, including the psychiatric findings.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Another tramp of hikers led by Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas has marked another skirmish in the battle to save the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal from the encroachments of civilization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2 -- This was a day that Harvard oarsmen will like to recall. Crimson crews swept all the honors in a six-race regatta along the Charles. And the sturdy Can-lab varsity set a record for the mile-and-three-quarter course just to add a fillip to Harvard's bowl of cheer.

CONAKRY, Guinea, May 1 -- The two-and-a-half-mllion people of this West African country have survived their first six months of independence without bloodshed or famine. Nor has their nation become a Communist satellite.
The Rev. Dr. Maurice J. Bloom warned his congregation yesterday against adopting ways that would "cut you off from your people."

CINCINNATI, May 2 (AP) -- Frank Robinson and Vada Pinson paced another slugging outburst for Cincinnati's Reds today that sealed a 16-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. The triumph lifted the Reds into the National League's No. 3 spot.

SEOUL, Korea, May 2 -- Walter C. Dowling, the United States Ambassador, has protested to the South Korean Government that its information director refused to confer with two American diplomats inquiring about the closing of a newspaper here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Times did a vivid job of reporting the details of former President Truman's three lectures at Columbia University. These lectures were stated by you to be a part of an annual series in memory of a Columbia student, William Radner, who died in 1951 at the relatively early age of 43.

Jay Lustig, a Brooklyn Tech senior, successfully protested a judge's decision and went on to win the Public Schools Athletic League individual fencing championship yesterday at Washington Irving High School. Thirty-six foilsmen competed from nineteen schools.

SINCE the war America has witnessed a phenomenal upsurge of sculpture. As startling as the constant output of new works are the unorthodox ideas they express. To explore recent trends and uncover promising talent, the Museum of Modern Art took an unusual step last year -- it invited all American sculptors to submit entries for an exhibition it was planning.

The board of Moore-McCormack Lines has named Robert C. Lee to succeed Emmet J. McCormack as chairman. Both are senior men in the New York shipping industry and have been partners for many years in building up the company's freight and passenger services.

Artistic as well as commercial products will be featured in the Italian pavilion at the World Trade Fair. Original Italian Renaissance furniture will be displayed, as well as a number of paintings in a pavilion designed by Oreste Michelotti of the Italian Institute for Foreign Trade.
DETROIT, May 2 -- The tail-spinning Detroit Tigers traded Billy Hoeft to the Boston Red Sox today for Ted Lepcio and Dave Sisler.

The Popular Price Shoe Show of America, which will open here today, is expected to seethe with activity. The price of leather has about doubled since the beginning of the year. Many footwear manufacturers are expected to announce price increases on fall lines at the event following the lead of others who announced price rises last month.

AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France -- This ancient city, now twenty-one centuries old and just as picturesque as when the Provencale troubadours first hailed it in song, is about to bow to the needs of modern times. Within the near future, buses are to be introduced as a means of local transportation.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 2 -- Ways to contain inflationary pressure without sending the economy into stagnation or decline were studied today by Columbia University's fifteenth American Assembly.

THIRTEEN penthouse terraces and gardens on Manhattan's East Side can be visited during the annual two-day spring showing of the City Gardens Club. Visiting hours will be from 2:30 to 6 P. M. on Tuesday and on May 12.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., May 2 -- Dr. Peter Sammartino, president of Fairleigh-Dickinson University, reported to the board of trustees this week that $7,000,000 had been spent for capital improvements in the last five years.

For many persons, the abduction of a Negro from the Pearl River County jail at Poplarville last week rekindled the fear that the region's current racial troubles might revive this old ritual of white supremacy.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 2 -- Vast areas of Suffolk County's 960 square miles remain to be opened for housing development. The county's 810 miles of shore frontage are proving to be much less elastic for new boating facilities.

LONDON, May 2 -- The Governments and peoples of the Western alliance might well be proud of the picture of the foreign ministers' meeting here this week that has been given the world by the public relations officers. Here is the West as all would desire it, united, vigilant, far sighted and fully prepared to do diplomatic battle with the hosts of darkness from beyond the Elbe.

THE Garden Club of Virginia is currently restoring the seventeenth-century garden at the Adam Thoroughgood House near Norfolk, Va. Since there are few seventeenth-century gardens in this country, the style and patterns developed in this restoration will be of interest to garden designers and owners of Colonial style homes.

An increasing number of business concerns are building new plants in the state of Washington, according to Gov. Albert D. Rosellini. He said that in the last two years about forty out-of-state concerns had opened plants.

The seventh annual May Fair of All Angels Protestant Episcopal Church, West End Avenue at Eighty-first Street, will take place on Saturday. The theme chosen this year is "To Broadway with Love -- A Century of Memories," to celebrate the founding of the church 100 years ago.

LANSING, Mich., May 2 -- For the first time in its 122-year history, Michigan failed to meet a state payroll this week. Steel production in the Chicago area set a mark for monthly output in March when 2,160,000 tons were produced, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. PARIS, May 2 -- All roads lead to Paris and that is the trouble.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, May 2 -- A regional conference on medical care problems of the aged, which may set a pattern for nation-wide action, will open here next Friday.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 2 -- Kentucky Democrats are in the midst of a bitter, name-calling fight over nominating a candidate for Governor in the May 26 primary. A new device used in holding automobiles safely during ocean crossings and in lifting them at the end of the voyage has successfully completed three months of tests. It is a lug arrangement that can readily be fastened to the wheels of automobiles.

LOUISVILLE, May 2 -- The fight mob doffed turtleneck sweaters in Indianapolis this morning and climbed into hunting jackets before setting out for Louisville and the Kentucky Derby. The boys were still arguing at trackside, not about the merits of the starters in the mint julep classic, but about the heavyweight championship bout last night between Floyd Patterson and Brian London. They agreed on virtually nothing.

The Japanese exhibit at the trade fair will show 596 products in a 2,232-square-foot pavilion. Most of the products will be presented under the auspices of the Japanese Government. The pavilion will be fashioned as a typical Japanese setting by Kiyoshi Seike, one of Japan's leading architects.

The New York Coliseum will be turned into a twelve - day bazaar beginning next Friday. On that day the United States World Trade Fair will be host to thousands of exhibitors from scores of countries. Hundreds of thousands of business men and curious visitors are expected to tour the building.

THE cuisine of Brazil is nearly as varied as its terrain. In the southern sector, where cowboys ride the range, barbecues are as prevalent as in America's southwest. The Brazilian barbecue, known as a churrascaria, differs from the Texan version in that the food is seldom sauced.

Prime Minister Nkrumah of Ghana and President Toure of Guinea have just signed an agreement that purports to lay the foundation for an eventual Union of Independent African States. The tone of the document is openly "anti-colonial" and thus is suspect, since the signatories themselves are the best witnesses to the fact that the colonialism to which they object has already gone.

The evolution of nationalism in the Middle East is proving to be one of the most interesting phenomena of the contemporary scene. An eight-year study of the 2,500,000 men who were either rejected or prematurely discharged by the Army in world War II for mental or emotional defects has been completed by researchers at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter returned from Paris today and promptly reported to President Eisenhower on what the Secretary described as a successful meeting of Western foreign ministers.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The reactivated House Special Subcommitte on Legislative Oversight is expected to resume its hearings around June 15. It will then emphasize problems that are common to all government regulatory agencies.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The heavy outflow of gold from the United States has resumed. The situation has caused some concern, though not alarm, among American and international financial officials.

THE number of United States citizens traveling abroad has been on the increase this past winter and in this spring of 1959. PANAMA, May 2 -- Two Colombian vessels joined two United States minesweepers today in the patrol of Panama's coastlines. Military planes assigned to the Organization of American States by the United States, Colombia and Ecuador also pressed the search for invasion craft.

A CASH-MINDED enterpreneur is trying to dike up the flood of credit cards that has been threatening to make money obsolete. DETROIT, May 3 -- Yankee followers were busy tonight trying to recall when the New Yorkers last had reached so low an estate in the American League. With a double loss to the last-place Tigers, the Yanks were imbedded in seventh place after nineteen games.

The Chemical Corn Exchange Bank and D'Agostino Brothers Food Markets have leased all the street-floor commercial space in a store and apartment building to be constructed at the northwest corner of First Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -Legislation creating a 9,000,000-acre wildlife refuge in northeastern Alaska has been transmitted to Congress by Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Dr. Otto Struve of the University of California was appointed today director of the new National Radio Astronomy Observatory.

PITTSBURGH, May 3 (AP) -- Milling players who raved but struck no blows delayed the second game of a double-header today between the St. Louis Cardinals and the Pittsburgh Pirates after the Pirates had won the ten-inning first game, 4 -- 3.
EACH year, the women of Mexico seem to be getting a better break.

Sunday window-shoppers on Broadway at Thirty-fourth Street saw six display windows at Macy's take on the character of tropical islands with characteristic flowers, shrubs and sailing vessels of Hawaii, Bali, Madagascar, Japan, New Zealand and the Philippines.

Stephen S. Scopas, who resigned as magistrate over the week-end, has been ordered to appear today at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. He will be questioned on his involvement in the adoption of Greek orphans and their immigration into the United.

LONDON, May 3 (AP) -Three South American nations qualified today for the second round of European Zone Davis Cup competition. Chile's victory over Austria in Vienna was marked by boos and bottle throwing.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 3 (AP) -- Daniel S. Feidt, Minneapolis lawyer and Minnesota State Senator, has been named chairman of the Twin City Rapid Transit Company, operating buses in Minneapolis and St. Paul.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Three New York high school seniors and one from Connecticut were among thirteen children of veterans who won four-year college scholarships in the Amvets eighth annual nationwide contest.

ALBANY, May 3 (AP) -- The State Conservation Department today nominated the "fishiest fifty" trout streams in the state.
Senator Jacob K. Javits voiced the belief yesterday that it was "definitely" possible for a Roman Catholic to be elected President in 1960.

ZURICH, May 3 -- Impressive because it was symptomatic was the sharp setback in the Swiss long-term bond market last week, especially in Government and industrial bonds. Prices in some cases were as much as 2 per cent lower. The average was about 1 per cent.

BOSTON, May 3 (AP) -Unitarian and Universalist churches and fellowships have approved by a 3-1 margin a proposal to merge the American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America "at the earliest feasible date."

HOME, where the heart is, apparently is also where the hazards lurk.

Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald warned yesterday that traditional thinking would worsen the current educational crisis, not solve it.
Government fiscal policy, always a popular subject of debate, is if anything, a wider and deeper one today than it was in the days before World War II.

With the coming of milder weather, windows are being left open and apartment dwellers are becoming increasingly conscious of air pollution emanating from the 11,000 apartment house incinerators in the city. It is therefore appropriate that Air Pollution Control Commissioner Greenburg has called upon both apartment house superintendents and tenants to cooperate in the fight to reduce smoke from these offending devices.
EVERY twenty-seven years the light of the star Epsilon Aurigae, in the northern constellation Auriga, fades by half, then regains its brightness.

News of the suppression of a large and strong opposition newspaper in the Republic of Korea has some disconcerting aspects. It raises at once the question as to whether the danger to the state through possible subversion in the opposition press -- if that is even involved in this case -- is great enough to warrant what the Korean Newspaper Editors Association calls an unjustified infringement of freedom of the press.

SEOUL, Korea, April 30 -The South Korean Army is waging a campaign against corruption in its ranks.

The Scalamandre tradition is to do difficult things the hard way. This has been demonstrated for thirty years by Franco Scalamandre, head of a silk weaving company bearing his name. With silk practically abandoned by almost all textile manufacturers, Mr. Scalamandre has been expanding his silk output and sales in New York, where few weavers would even dare to maintain a mill.

The Twentieth Century Fund noted yesterday in an annual report that living space was shrinking but problems were increasing under the impact of technological advance, population growth and modern life.

CLEVELAND, May 3 (AP) -The Washington Senators scored three unearned runs in the ninth inning and defeated the Cleveland Indians, 3 -- 1, in the second game of a double-header today. The Indians won by 5 -- 0 in the opener, which was interrupted by a fight between the teams.
" Primer on Geneva," a thirty-minute telecast on Channel 4 yesterday, offered a well-rounded study of the background and possibilities of the foreign ministers' meeting scheduled for next Monday.
Perry Lafferty, producer, and Norman Jewison, director, are expected to head the new production staff for Garry Moore's television show next fall.

EAST BERLIN, May 3 -- Divided Berlin must remain the world's most dangerous cockpit as long as Germany stays divided and, since reunification still lies far off, this former capital has accustomed itself to permanent cold war. Here the power blocs clash head on and each side recognizes that if one or the other yields, the global strategic balance will be changed.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter drove to Walter Reed Hospital today to brief John Foster Dulles, his former chief, on the proposals the Western powers have decided to put to the Soviet Union at next week's foreign ministers' meeting in Geneva.
CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- A heavy volume of grain futures trading last week virtually canceled all the gains and losses of the previous week on the Board of Trade, except in wheat.

TOLE artware, now enjoying a renaissance in home accessories, probably came into being because of the frugal habits of French housewives.
RANGOON, Burma, May 3--A Soviet diplomat convoyed by forty husky Russian guards was hustled out of Rangoon by plane today after he had tried to escape from a hospital.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Eighty-sixth Congress, approximately at midpoint in its first session, is hauling in the trial balloons and knuckling down to at least three final months of hard work.

TOKYO, May 3 -- The famous Imperial Hotel, which withstood Tokyo's worst earthquake and thereby helped make a worldwide reputation for its architect, the late Frank Lloyd Wright, will not survive economic attrition much longer, its manager said today.
CONCORD, Mass., May 3 -Forty-one home owners of this historic town want to find out their rights if the Federal Government zones their homes into a Minute Man National Historic Park here.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission forbade Drug Research Corporation of New York City today to advertise that dieters could lose a predetermined number of pounds by taking its Regimen weight-reducing tablets.
WHITE PLAINS, May 3 -More than 400 paintings were viewed by 900 visitors today at the opening of the Hudson Valley Art Association's thirty-first annual exhibition.
To Fred Marcussen, bowling means a lot. Apparently he will go a long distance and put up with a lot of trouble just to knock down more of those ornery tenpins.

FORT WORTH, May 3 (UPI) -- Bantam Ben Hogan missed a 3-foot putt on the eighteenth green today and tied Fred Hawkins for first place in the Colonial invitation golf tournament. Each finished with a five-over-par 285 for seventy-two holes.

Whittaker Chambers, whose charges about a pre-war Soviet spy ring sent Alger Hiss to prison for forty-four months for perjury, contends the former State Department official has not yet "paid any effective penalty."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Senator Herbert H. Lehman were among ten prominent New Yorkers who called yesterday upon six voluntary hospitals to accept fact-finding to avert a threatened strike.

Ways in which democracy can be subverted in this country are recounted by Virgil T. Blossom, former Superintendent of Schools, Little Rock, Ark., in "It Has Happened Here." In 1955 he was voted "Little Rock Man of the Year."

FREMONT. Neb., May 3 (AP) -- A vehicle equally at home in the air, on the highway and in the water has been unveiled here by Ogden L. Martin, former airplane pilot and now an aircraft maintenance man.

The seven and eleven-story building formerly occupied by the Railway Express Agency at 214 East Fortyfourth Street has been leased to Skyway Chain, operator of garages, parking lots and gasoline stations in Manhattan.

Fred Turner Jr.'s English-bred colt, who won the Kentucky Derby in an exciting closing duel with Sword Dancer yesterday, will fly to Baltimore this week to prepare for the second part of racing's triple crown for 3-year-olds on May 16.
The eye and brain perceive colors in a manner far more subtle than that dictated by long-accepted theories, an article in the May issue of Scientific American states.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, asked the Department of Justice today why it doesn't use the Sherman Antitrust Act to block the merger of J. P. Moragn Co and the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

The colorful Benny Howarth is retiring as football coach at St. Mark's School in Southborough, Mass. At 57, Howarth is far from an old man by boarding school standards, but he has been coaching for thirtyfive years. He feels it's time to ease up.
LONDON, May 3 -- The stock market was unusually busy last week and the heavy demand for industrials was reflected in a steady rise in prices.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2 -- Long-term prospects for the coal-mining industry are "not unfavorable," the International Labor Organization declared this week despite existing crucial situations in a number of countries.
Fifteen thousand members of New York's Spanish-speaking community swung up Fifth Avenue under balmy skies yesterday in the fourth annual United Puerto Rican-Hispanic Unity Day Parade.

For the first time since Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1, was organized in 1886, the stagehands group held its annual election the first Sunday in May rather than the second. Members demanded the switch to avoid interference with Mother's Day next Sunday.

Directors of the Penn-Texas Corporation at their organizational meeting today following the company's annual meeting are expected to elect David Karr as president to succeed Alfons Landa, according to a company spokesman. Mr. Landa, who early this year confirmed reports that he planned to resign as president this year will remain as a director and is expected to be nominated at the organizational meeting for the post of chairman of the executive committee.

Domestic cotton prices held to a narrow trading range last week but made moderate net gains. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 3 to 22 points (15 cents to $1.10 a bale).

The whole American nation joins President Eisenhower today in extending a hearty welcome to Sir Winston Churchill, the Olympian Man of the Century, who at the age of 84 and at a time of new crisis is paying another visit to the special partner in an alliance on which he bases his hopes for world peace and freedom.

His out-of-town tryout a matter of undistinguished record, Floyd Patterson, the heavyweight champion, returned home yesterday to rest and to ponder his New York performance against Ingemar Johansson in June.

Governor Rockefeller sent a radio message yesterday to the people of Poland, who are forbidden by their Communist regime to celebrate their original Constitution Day. The American Foundation for the Blind is celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of one of its most important and useful projects. This is the provision of "talking books" for the blind in the form of special recordings.

Senate Majority Leader Lyndon B. Johnson told the United States Chamber of Commerce that Congressional appropriations will be held within the $77 billion for which the Administration has budgeted for the next fiscal year, which ends June 30, 1960. This statement by the Senator from Texas is a striking reminder of the fact that the new Congress, with its lopsided Democratic majority, hasn't begun to fulfill the expectations of its spending-minded wing.

NEW FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 3 -- Campfires burned bright at the Squantz Pond State Park here this week-end as several score of adults and young folk from Greenwich began training for a series of six summer canoe trips in northern Canada.
