KING OF PRUSSIA, Pa., May 4 (AP) -- American Phosphors Company is awaiting Atomic Energy Commission permission to send back to Europe a small quantity of strontium 90, the company said today.
The State Investigation Commission announced yesterday that it would hold public hearings here starting May 21 in connection with its inquiry on Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan.
WASHINGTON May 4 -- The Supreme Court refused today to hear a claim by three Negro doctors that their exclusion from a Wilmington (N. C.) hospital on racial grounds was unconstitutional.
Many subscribers have been reported for the Ethel Walker School theatre benefit, which will take place at the May 14 performance of "First Impressions."

Now is the time of year when those of us who are particularly concerned with the children of this great city face the problem of what we are going to do about the summer vacation time when a million or more energetic youngsters are turned out of schools for two months of freedom.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) -- The American Telephone Telegraph Company today asked the Federal Communications Commission for a 4 per cent increase in leased teleprinter service rates. The A. T. T. said it suggested this as the next step toward its ultimate goal of earning 10 per cent on net investment for these services.
BOSTON, May 4 (AP) -- Joe Cronin, the American League president, fined the principals in yesterday's brawl between players of the Cleveland Indians and Washington Senators.

A pilot project on a oncegray section of Worth Street has bedecked some sidewalks with the splashy colors of tulips and the verdancy of evergreen trees and long trailing ivy. But this is only the beginning.

FOR the final premiere of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Bolshoi Ballet last night presented "The Stone Flower," based on an old fairy tale, with music by Serge Prokofieff, choreography by Yuri Grigorovich, and settings by Simon Versaladze.

General Telephone and Electronics Corporation announced yesterday new highs in net income and revenues for the March quarter and for twelve months ended March 31. This was the first report released under the new name, following the merger into the company of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.
Following are brief sketches of the winners of the Pulitzer Prizes:

Akron, Ohio, borrowed $6,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds due from 1960 to 1979 to a syndicate headed by Northern Trust Company and First Boston Corporation.

BUENOS AIRES, May 4 -The United States delegation to the Inter-American economic conference here has decided to forgo a direct answer to the call of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba for massive new aid by Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the Fur Products Labeling Act required a retailer to put on each sales slip all the information about the fur article required in the act.
GENEVA, May 4 -- The Soviet bloc abstained today when the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe approved a resolution on the issue of "subregional groupings" like the European Common Market.
Two policemen clinging to the sides of a taxi fired seven shots at a station wagon fleeing through the crowded theatre district last night.

MOSCOW, May 4 -- Music and words from "My Fair Lady" have already been heard throughout the Soviet Union via Moscow Radio. And, according to an ambitious young Moscovite, a complete version of the Broadway musical success, newly translated into Russian, is going to be presented to select Soviet audiences whether its authors complain about piracy or not.
BAYONNE, N. J., May 4 -As anyone who reads Dick Tracy knows, no two sets of fingerprints area like. As many bowlers should know, according to Jimmy Bernotas, "No two finger spans or grips are alike."
NEW DELHI, India, May 4 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru ruled out today any defense arrangement with Pakistan.

The Coca-Cola Company had record first-quarter sales and increased earnings, William E. Robinson, chairman, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Wil mington, Del. Consolidated net profit for the period rose to $5,240,240, or $1.24 a share, from $4,699,923, or $1.11 a share for the first quarter of last year.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (UPI) -- A wider, deeper and straightened Chesapeake and Delaware Canal is needed to accommodate ships of the present era, the president of the Pilots Association for the Bay and Delaware River said today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Douglas Dillon testified today that the State Department would not object if Congress voted for a greatly increased, long-range development loan fund in the foreign aid program.

A $234,000 out-of-court settlement has been reached in a negligence suit growing out of a Capital Airlines crash in Michigan a year ago. The settlement figure is believed to be the highest ever reached in a single death case.

INDIAN givers have presented the new world with some of its most unusual dishes. This is a thought that was brought to mind twice in the last week, most recently at dinner with a representative from the United Nations.

MOSCOW, May 4 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev walked under the nearly completed aluminum dome of the United States exhibition in Moscow's Sokolniki Park today. He pronounced it "very interesting, very good" and worth copying many times in the Soviet Union.
The appointment of Frank D. Doyle, 51 years old, a Deputy Commissioner of Sanitation, as his executive secretary at $20,000 a year was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Treasury's decision to auction, and on very short terms, $4.9 billion of its I O U's this week is the direct consequence of the most serious fiscal and economic problem now confronting the Government of the United States.

WHITE PLAINS, May 4 -- The Pembroke College Club of Westchester County, is sponsoring a scholarship benefit spring fashion show tomorrow at 9:15 A. M. at Saks Fifth Avenue store here. Coffee and pastries will be served.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 4 -- The head of the United Nations Special Fund anounced today that he had recommended its first technical aid projects.

A stevedoring concern was given its choice yesterday of paying a $750 fine or having its operating license suspended for five days for failure to observe Waterfront Commission rules in hiring longshoremen.

LONDON, May 4 -- The steady loss of gold by the United States was front-page news in several British newspapers today. Some commentators predicted that the United States would have to take strong action to stop it.

Air transportation, which has already brought about great changes in commerce and industry, is also changing many concepts of real estate ownership and management, especially among the younger realty practitioners.
CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Mortgage bankers from throughout the country were told here yesterday that urban renewal would have to be tackled as a national project rather than as scattered, community efforts if it was to keep pace with the expansion of cities.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Treasury bill rate rose this week, but not to the peak of earlier this year, the Treasury disclosed tonight. Thus the market appeared to have "digested" the announcement of large cash offerings of bills coming later this week without great difficulty.
Regino Sainz De la Maza, Spanish guitarist who made his debut here in 1952, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last night under the auspices of the Society of the Classic Guitar.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 4 (AP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People charged today that the Arkansas school-closing law had been designed solely to keep a handful of Negro students from continuing at Little Rock's Central High School.

NICE, May 4 -- The roads of Europe are swarming with bicycle races. The Tour of Spain is in its eleventh day, has covered 1,200 miles and has already lost a third of its cyclists via one accident or another.

The Sunset International Petroleum Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif., has purchased Warren-Bradshaw Exploration Company of Tulsa, Okla., in a $6,000,000 transaction, Morton A. Sterling, president of Sunset International, announced yesterday.

NEWARK, May 4 -- Dr. Raymond J. Saulnier, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, declared here tonight that this country could not meet its housing needs, even for the next fifteen years, if it slipped into a "boom-and-bust" economy fed by inflation.
NEW DELHI, India, May 4 -The head of the Karachi Bar Association has attacked Pakistan's military dictatorship for delaying general elections and popular government.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 4 (UPI) -- Gov. A. B. Chandler recalled today National Guard troops from the eastern Kentucky coal fields after a Federal court order restraining the striking united mine workers union from violence and mass picketing was extended indefinitely.
IF "The Voice of Firestone" continues its present pace, the demands of viewers for its continuance next season may grow rather than subside.
ALBANY, May 4 -- The State Education Commissioner urged citizens today to support the best possible educational programs in their communities.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 4 -Total sales in the hosiery industry during the first quarter of this year were up 10 per cent over the like period in 1958, W. F. Williamson of New York, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, reported today.
CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -Pressure in the grain futures trade appeared to be shifting again today to the short side of the market, especially in the May contracts on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said that a body found in the Pearl River in Mississippi today was identified as that of Mack Charles Parker, who was forcibly removed from a jail at Poplarville, Miss., April 25.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., May 4 (UPI) -- Two "little old ladies" who unwittingly walked off with an Army Engineer's briefcase at a bus station returned it today and were relieved to learn they had taken nothing secret.
Five of the eight winners of Pulitzer Prizes in journalism this year started at the bottom as copy boys and, in the case of one winner, a copy girl.

The election of Joseph S. Myers and Harry W. Powell as vice presidents of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation was announced yesterday by Robert E. Harvey, president. Both were formerly assistant vice presidents.
KANSAS CITY, May 4 -What's gone wrong with the Yankees? And what are they going to do about it?

The twenty-five members of Congress who are sponsoring a resolution urging a strengthening of the United Nations, as reported in The Times on April 24, are performing a valuable service to the U. N., their country and the world.

Alexander L. Guterma, the indicted financier, charged yesterday in a Federal Court motion that "a barrage of publicity of the most violent character" had made it impossible for him to receive a fair trial in this area.

JUAREZ, Mexico, May 4 (AP) -- Sidney Franklin, Brooklyn bullfighter, was described by a physician today as gravely wounded. A dying bull gored Mr. Franklin, 55 years old, twice, yesterday, in the Plaza Monumental ring.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 4 (AP) -- A live animal, probably an ape, will be fired into space in the nose cone of a Jupiter missile within sixty days, Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris, Chief of the Army Ordnance Missile Command, said today.
LONDON, May 4 -- Industrials continued to forge ahead in the stock market today. Most gains were small but several issues rose a shilling (14 cents) or so.
Governor Rockefeller gave further assurances to New Jersey officials yesterday that 1960 would bring tax relief to nonresidents working in New York State.
Four old buildings in the slum clearance project area near Gramercy Park have been purchased by a real estate concern that plans to raze them and build a fifteen-story luxury apartment house.
The new president of the Society of the Silurians, an organization of present and former New York newspaper men, is C. Norman Stabler, financial columnist of The New York Herald Tribune.

The question of economic and financial aid to Latin America by the United States sometimes resembles a tug of war and sometimes a process of shadow boxing. On one side there are underdeveloped Latin-American nations which need more capital than they are getting. On the other is the United States with its global responsibilities and the limits on its ability to provide capital.
Representatives of the Long Island potato industry were present yesterday as futures trading in local spuds began on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Supreme Court held today, over strong dissent, that health inspectors may enter a private home without a warrant to search for unsanitary conditions.

John C. Sample, a veteran of almost thirty-nine years in the petroleum industry, has retired as a vice president, director and member of the executive committee of StandardVacuum Oil Company, it was announced yesterday.
ABOUT this time of year, a trunk begins to look like Pandora's box. Nothing attractive seems to come out of it.
HOBOKEN, N. J., May 4 -Stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation were assured here today that their management would exert every effort to avoid wage and price increases this year.

The upsurge in corporate profits is showing up in the most tangible way -- in the form of dividends. Last month, according to the Standard Poor's Corporation, statistical and investment advisory organization, there were seventy dividend increases and eleven resumptions of payments.

O. Roy Chalk, who tried unsuccessfully last month to buy New York's transit system, held "exploratory talks" last week on the purchase of a 23.16 per cent interest in Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., but no agreement was reached.

The Utica Daily Press and The Utica Observer-Dispatch won their Pulitzer honors yesterday for a vigorous campaign against local vice and corruption despite official retaliatory measures, including an attempt to levy a 5 per cent tax on newspaper advertising.

ROME, May 4 -- A two-day strike of Italy's metal workers started this morning, heralding a new wave of labor unrest. Most of the nation's steel mills and shipyards and many mechanical industries were paralyzed by the walkout.
NEW HAVEN, May 4 -- Three New Haven clergymen asked a Superior Court ruling today on the constitutionality of Connecticut's seventy-nine-year-old birth control law.
ZAGORSK, U.S.S.R., May 4 -- Religion appears to be holding its own in the Soviet Union against a new and more strident propaganda drive for atheism.
The Metropolitan Educational Television Association may soon curtail all program production and reduce its personnel drastically because of a shortage of funds.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Six members of school safety patrols who saved the lives of schoolmates in the last year received gold medals today from Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower.
PARIS, May 4 -- Outwardly unconcerned by the union of the independent African states of Ghana and Guinea, the French Community's Executive Council met here today under President Charles de Gaulle.
THERE is one odd thing about James Dey's "The Redemptor," which opened last evening at the Cricket Theatre.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 4 -- Neither India nor the United Arab Republic will attend the first meeting of the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, reliable sources said tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, May 4 -- An unusually large and varied collection of furniture is a feature at the Eastern States Antiques Fair, now being held at the Westchester County Center. This event long has endeared itself to people who are "just looking" as well as to the purposeful home decorator and collector.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) reported yesterday that its reserves had risen $51,000,000 in the nine months ended March 31 to $400,600,000.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court set aside today the conviction of Wadelmiro Arroyo, president of a labor union in Puerto Rico, on a charge of violating the TaftHartley Act. He was accused of the misuse of $15,000 received from two sugar corporations.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The drive to repeal the constitutional ban on Presidential third terms were supported today by the one man in the United States to whom it does not apply -- Harry S. Truman.

The bond market went through a quiet trading session yesterday. The little business that was done smacked of professional moves to adjust accounts. Treasury obligations moved down by slight fractions of a point, but top-grade corporate bonds were firm.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The National Committee on Radiation Protection and Measurements is preparing for the first time to establish permissible radiation exposures for the general public.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Congress was told today that the Bureau of the Budget had assented to an appropriation to combat juvenile delinquency.

DETROIT, May 4 (AP) -Jimmie Dykes signed a contract as manager of the Detroit Tigers today twentyfour hours after he had shaken the ball team out of a three-week slump that produced fifteen defeats in its first seventeen games.

Mayor Wagner expressed confidence last night that he could "work something out" between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Joseph Papp, theatrical producer, in the dispute over free Shakespeare this summer in Central Park.
RANGOON, Burma, May 4 (AP) -- The Burmese police cordoned off the Soviet Embassy today to stop forty Burmese newsmen from throwing vegetables at the building.

Representatives of steel management and labor will open today the year's most consequential contract negotiations. The outcome will influence the national level of wages and prices. It will also determine whether steel production is cut off by a strike when present agreements expire June 30.
DETROIT, May 4 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers have built more than 600,000 more passenger cars than in the comparable 1958 period.
Seats are still available for Friday's performance of "Destry Rides Again" at the Imperial Theatre. Tickets may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshaw, 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.

The future of "Rashomon," starring Claire Bloom, Rod Steiger, Oscar Homolka and Akim Tamiroff, is to be decided next Monday. Five of the seven reviewers endorsed the Fay and Michael Kanin play, which opened Jan. 27 at the Music Box.
A sleek, nine-story building was dedicated yesterday as the new home of the Fashion Institute of Technology.
KUWAIT, April 30 -- Twenty years ago a Kuwait man bought a bit of land for 30 rupees ($6.33) and a donkey. Last year he sold the property to the state for 100,000 rupees ($23,370).
Plans for a huge cargo-ship replacement program were outlined here yesterday by United States Lines. The program would create more than a halfbillion dollars in new shipbuilding work.
PHOENIX, Ariz., May 4 (AP) -- Representative Hale Boggs, Democrat, Louisiana, said today that Congress would not tamper with the petroleum industry's percentage depletion law.

ALGIERS, May 4 -- The French Army reported today that 2,000 nationalist rebel soldiers were executed by their commander during a threemonth period last fall and that a new purge was under way in the rebel army.

Steel production dipped last week for the second consecutive week and was well below expectations. But the industry scheduled operations this week that would send output to a record high if maintained.

FORT WORTH, May 4 (AP) -- Ben Hogan won another golf tournament today. His pin-point approaches and clutch putting resulted in a four-stroke play-off victory in the $27,300 Colonial National invitation over Fred Hawkins.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- It's the Rose, 6 to 1, Representative Jessica Weis told the House of Representatives today. That was the upstate New York Republican's report on her personal poll to help select a national flower.

The tourist influx to Russia is expected to begin this month and continue through September. It is estimated that 6,000 tourists, or double the number of two years ago, will visit the Soviet Union this year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 4 -- Landlocked Afghanistan has become the first state to ratify the International Convention on the High Seas.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the National Labor Relations Board, not state courts, had jurisdiction in a labor dispute involving construction for Door County, Wisc.
BREMERHAVEN, Germany, May 4 (AP) -- A quarantine that had been imposed on the United States luxury liner America for suspected smallpox was lifted tonight.
Cohoes, a 5-year-old son of Mahmoud, returned to competition at Jamaica yesterday to take the $7,500 Sandy Point Purse by two lengths from the Wheatley Stable's Misty Flight.
As the sociologist has been at pains to tell us, the urbanization of modern man has given rise to a whole new set of problems that must be solved if we are to survive in a healthy and happy state.

THE Yankees did not lose a ball game yesterday. They had the day off. As yet, no one has reached for the panic button. But fingers are starting to get itchy and it won't take much for stunned bewildermen to change to hysteria. Here is a team that was supposed to make a runaway of the pennant race.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 4 -- A little-known substance from the human liver has been found capable of inhibiting virus growth in tissue-culture experiments.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., May 4 -Most of the trout water from here eastward for seventy-five miles or so is in good fishing condition, for fishermen who dote on cold, fast water. But fly hatches are sparse and there is something less than the normal bragging in the country beer joints.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 4 -The Turkish Government gave the Royal Air Force permission today to bomb Suphan Dag, a peak in eastern Turkey, to destroy secret war material scattered there last week in the crash of a British transport plane.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Appeals by four major oil companies for changes in oil import regulations were dismissed today without hearings.
Hopes for the Phoenix Theatre on lower Second Avenue are high for the first time in its shaky six-year history.

LOUISVILLE, May 4 (UPI) -- Tomy Lee, the Kentucky Derby winner, will not run in either the Preakness or the Belmont Stakes, remaining jewels in racing's triple crown, his owner and trainer announced today.

The American Museum of Natural History has adopted a new policy under which its director will be enabled to resume full-time scientific research after fifteen years of administrative service, or upon reaching the age of 60.
Carol Heiss, the women's world figure skating champion and a New York University undergraduate, yesterday became the first N. Y. U. student to receive the University's Presidential Citation.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries had the highest sales for any quarter in its history in the first quarter of this year. Earnings rose 56.5 per cent over those of the 1958 period. The results were announced by E. J. Thomas, chairman, after a board meeting yesterday in Gadsden, Ala.

Where is the tax money to be found for the adequate support of education? This question has been asked with unusual frequency and urgency in the last few days, with the New York State Commissioner of Education, the New York City Superintendent of Schools and the taxpaying home owner among those asking it.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) -- A Missouri Congressman said today that former President Harry S. Truman's criticism of the House Committee on Un-American Activities had been directed at "past actions of certain individual members."
Banton L. Wyckoff pleaded guilty yesterday in Special Sessions to eighteen criminal informations charging 672 violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law.

A most unusual success story was climaxed yesterday with the election of David Karr as president of the Penn-Texas Corporation following the annual meeting at the Plaza Hotel. Mr. Karr's route to the top position in the $141,000,000 concern was through public relations.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -The health insurance companies of the nation were told today that they were asking for trouble unless they liberalized their coverage of so-called poor-risk cases.

A SELECTION of French nineteenth- and twentiethcentury art at the Schoneman Galleries, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, includes paintings by Rouault, Jawlensky and Monet, and drawings by Picasso, Klee, Signac and Pisarro, among others.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The House Space Committee will demand that a magazine writer offer proof of his assertion that the Soviet Union's sun probe was "the biggest hoax in history."
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- New construction activity increased in line with seasonal patterns in April, setting records for the month and for the first four months.
Columbia University awarded an honorary Doctor of Laws degree yesterday to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher and chairman of the board of The New York Times.

In several recent dispatches from Colombo you have given much prominence to Prime Minister S. W. R. Bandanaraike's views on the need for reforming the political institutions of Ceylon and on the shortcomings of cabinet government which Ceylon has been using since independence.
The great defense debate that will continue in committee rooms and on House and Senate floors this week involves not only partisan politics but also major Pentagon problems.
Prices of all cotton futures but one on the New York Cotton Exchange declined yesterday. Losses were 1 to 9 points (5 to 45 cents a bale). The nearby May contract was unchanged.

Cottonseed oil, potatoes and rubber futures were strong in heavy trading yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Cottonseed oil registered the largest volume since July 15 and potatoes and rubber had the third most active day of the year.
The Department of Commerce has published a fact-filled 135page book that provides a capsule view of international advertising and marketing.
ROME, May 4 -- Pope John XXIII disclosed today that he was working on his first encyclical and that it would deal with the press." "Above all, the truth" will be its theme, the Pontiff said.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Former President Harry S. Truman turned down another invitation to the White House today. He sent regrets that a previous engagement would prevent his attendance at a dinner being given Wednesday by President Eisenhower for Sir Winston Churchill.

One important voice hitherto silent in the whole Berlin crisis has now been raised to back the cause of peace. This is the voice of the United Nations, and it has been raised by Secretary General Hammarskjold, who makes some constructive suggestions on the problems involved.
Stephen S. Scopas, the city magistrate who resigned Saturday night at the request of Mayor Wagner, was arrested yesterday and accused of selling Greek children here in a black market for babies.

The Greater New York Fund will seek $11,000,000 this year for the 425 agencies it helps to support. A thousand volunteer fund-raisers attended luncheon yesterday marking the start of the twenty-first annual campaign.

It is discouraging to learn from Police Commissioner Kennedy that for the first time since the city's anti-jaywalking campaign opened, last Aug. 8, pedestrian deaths have increased over the previous year. There were 159 pedestrians killed since last Jan. 1, compared with 153 in the equivalent period of 1958 -- before the anti-jaywalking law took effect.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Defense Secretary told Senators today he would soon disclose to them "quite spectacular" improvements in precautions against an enemy attack. He said he would do so in closed session and under full security.
YONKERS, May 4 --If anyone staged a contest to determine the least-known trainer-driver at Yonkers Raceway, Fred Spencer might be the winner.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Sir Winston Churchill arrived today for a three-day visit with President Eisenhower.
GENEVA, May 4 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have welcomed the support expressed by the United States Senate for a controlled ban on nuclear weapons tests.
LONDON, May 4 (Reuters) -- The annual monetary conference of the American Bankers Association opens here tomorrow.
A beautification program on West Eighty-sixth Street was begun with public ceremony yesterday.
DETROIT, May 5 -- A pile up of St. Lawrence seaway traffic waiting to unload cargo in Detroit reopened an old fight today about this city's port facilities.
A scene simulating a spring night at Estoril, a seaside resort near Lisbon, Portugal, was the setting last night for the Ninetieth Anniversary Ball, a benefit for the New York Foundling Hospital.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A high Argentine official announced today that loans, contracts and other arrangements totaling about $350,000,000 had been negotiated recently with United States businesses and the Government here to aid his country.

HAMILTON, May 5 (Canadian Press) -- Delays piled up on the Welland Canal today and basic steel manufacturers became alarmed about the prospect of obtaining sufficient supplies of coal and iron ore for next winter's operations.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -Hanns Ditisheim today took the reins of the sprawling operations of the United Stockyards Corporation.
A French remedy for chronic inflationary "budgetitis" was recommended yesterday for possible adaptation in the treatment of United States fiscal ills.
The Metropolitan Educational Television Association will suspend all of its programing and production activities on June 30.
ROME, May 5 (AP) -- Karol Fageros of Miami put a withering service on display at the Italian national tennis tournament today and defeated Ulla Hulcrantz of Sweden, 6 -- 1, 16 -- 3.

Having read carefully the article by C. L. Sulzberger from Paris under the caption "Danger Signs in the Middle East," which appeared in your issue of April 27, it is my duty to give a brief explanation.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -Wheat futures, with broad setbacks, led a general decline in grains today on the Board of Trade while soybeans moved slightly ahead on scattered support.

Joint efforts by interested community groups, including the elderly themselves, are required to make effective programs for the aging, speakers on "Mobilizing Resources for Older People" agreed yesterday.
At a Senate subcommittee hearing last July, Casey Stengel was asked whether he intended "to keep on monopolizing the world's championship in New York City."
A Rockland County banker was arraigned in Federal Court House here yesterday on charges of having embezzled about $60,000.
Containership, Inc., of Brooklyn has applied to the Federal Maritime Board for mortgage insurance not to exceed $7,250,000 for the construction of two vessels, it was announced yesterday.
Nasco, a younger brother of Bold Ruler, scored a tidy three-and-a-half-length victory in the $7,500 Harrison at Jamaica yesterday.
LONDON, May 5 -- Stock market prices continued to advance today, although the trading volume slackened and some of the recent buoyancy was missing.
State Housing Commissioner James W. Gaynor announced appointments to four major administrative posts in his department yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -President Eisenhower appealed anew today for support of his $3,930,000,000 mutual security program as "a tool in our battle for a lessening of tension and some advancement toward peace."

commander of Iraq's civil militia, said today about 300 rebellious Kurdish tribesmen were opposing Government forces in northeast Iraq.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5 -- The Soviet Union promised foreign tourists today fine hotels, good eating and splendid hunting.

Some progress toward a new working agreement covering about 900 scow captains was reported here yesterday. However, the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York and the Deck Scow Captains Union were still said to be divided on wages.

NEWARK, May 5 -- Adlai E. Stevenson told 500 business leaders tonight that a "shoulder-to-shoulder, two-fisted attack" by private enterprise and Government was needed to get the urban renewal and housing the country needed.
LONDON, May 5 -- The head of one of Britain's large aircraft companies issued a gloomy report today on the future of the British aircraft producing industry.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -Cabinet-level delegates from the five biggest wheat-exporting countries opened today a twoday conference on using "food for peace."
The Soviet Union has invited the State Department to send an American production of "My Fair Lady" to Moscow and other Russian cities.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Officials here are now talking seriously about the possibility of a visit to the United States this year by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union.

Dick Savitt, William Talbert and other players of' prominence will appear in exhibition matches Saturday at Upsala to help raise funds for the expansion of the college's tennis facilities. The goal is the construction of a tennis grandstand and additional courts on the campus in East Orange, N. J.
KUWAIT, May 1 -- The Arabs of booming Kuwait are wondering whether Communists will soon strike at their treasure house of oil.
SINGAPORE, May 5 -- Communist China re-entered the local rubber market here today. The moe was a surprise that created the wildest trading in recent years, dealers reported when trading ended.
There is plenty of room in the nation's engineering colleges, a survey of 151 of the 223 such institutions disclosed yesterday.

FOR its second presentation of the new ballet, "Stone Flower," at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, the Bolshoi Ballet cast different dancers for both the ballerina roles. Nina Timofeyeva was the Mistress of Copper Mountain and Ekaterina Maximova was Katerina, the sweetheart of the fairy-tale romance.

President Eisenhower warned steel labor and management yesterday that the Government could not "stand still and do nothing" if they failed to exhibit statesmanship in their crucial wage negotiations this year.

LUXEMBOURG, May 5 -- Officials of the six states of the European Community, conferring here about excess production and unemployment in the coal mining industry, ended their meeting today without agreement on a remedial program.

The National Broadcasting Company, currently involved in a dispute with the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians, sent a telegram to the union yesterday saying that its contract was rescinded.

An improved high-speed color film negative designed to provide "new artistic freedom and major economic advantages" for theatrical and non-theatrical movies and filmed television was unveiled here yesterday by the Eastman Kodak Company of Rochester, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- In an opening statement, Chairman McClellan described the union as democratic and "said to be noted for the frequency with which its membership overrides the policies of its officers."

A SMALL, sophisticated tugof-war is going on in Italy. The battlegrounds are Rome and Florence. The weapons are pins, needles, sketches and spurts of Italian temperament. The troops are the couturiers, the new struggling ones and the famous well-established clique.
SINGAPORE, May 5 -- The Chief Minister of Singapore, where extreme Leftist and conservative parties are struggling for control, said today he had received a death threat.

Don and Flo Blackburn, who have taken over organization of the nationally famous Rip Van Winkle Rally, to be run in the fall, had a delightful tuneup last week-end in the Yankee Monte Carlo Rally in the Berkshires.
The National Institute of Arts and Letters will give its 1959 award for distinguished service to the arts to Elizabeth Ames, executive director of Yaddo.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- Subtle chemical changes in the basic structure of the thyroid gland hormone may promise new drugs with major therapeutic applications for human disease.
THEY say of Richard Conrad Cooper that he is as tough as the product that his company produces -- steel. Yet he speaks so softly that sometimes his hearers have to lean forward to catch his words.
Several years ago a New York taxicab driver's heart stopped beating, and he slumped to the floor of his cab. It plunged into a crowd of pedestrians.

Textron, Inc.'s $30,000,000 offering of 5 per cent subordinated debentures, due 1984, with common stock purchase warrants attached was put on the market yesterday at par by Blair Co., Inc., Scherck, Richter Co., G. H. Walker Co. and The First Cleveland Corporation.
KANSAS CITY, May 5 -- The embattled Yankees struggled on two fronts today and finally managed to emerge on top on one of them.

Events tonight: "The Telephone" and "The Unicorn, the Gorgon and the Manticore," Horace Mann Auditorium, Columbia University, 8:30; All-City High School Chorus and Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Juilliard String Quartet, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.
PARIS, May 5 -- The French Community, grouping France and twelve autonomous African republics, took several important steps today to organize its internal relations.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 1 to 7 points (5 to 35 cents a bale) yesterday. The market opened 5 points lower to 1 point higher, and held in a narrow range all day. There were three May notices issued, and reported stopped by a leading spot firm.
Approval of higher school budgets appeared to be the pattern in annual school district elections last night in Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The elections will continue tonight.
Former Gov. W. Averell Harriman declared last night that neutralizing West German would be "a decisive victory" for the Soviet Union.

Federal Judge John M. Cashin yesterday denied a motion made here by the Bayuk Cigars, Inc., insurgent stockholders group to postpone the annual meeting scheduled for noon today in Philadelphia. The group had claimed that the management cigar concern had violated the law by sending false and misleading statements to stockholders in its proxy material.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Senate confirmed Potter Stewart as a Supreme Court Justice today by a vote of 70 to 17.

AN asset to any good cook's repertoire are cold dishes that pique the appetite when the weather is warm. Three possibilities are a chicken mousse with almonds and two soups, one with shrimp and the other a rich, refreshing combination of cucumbers and cream.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on a bill raising railroad retirement benefits 10 per cent. The measure now goes to the White House for action by President Eisenhower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5 -- Six Hopi Indians came to this tall house of glass walls today to warn the nations of the world that they were fast approaching a great struggle between the forces of good and evil.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A Post Office hearing examiner ruled today that advertising postcards showing Goya's painting "The Naked Maja" are obscene and non-mailable.

Net income of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the first quarter of this year dipped to $4,112,000 from $5,076,000 in the 1958 period, despite larger sales, Robert E. Gross, chairman, reported to the annual meeting yesterday in Burbank, Calif.
Mayor Wagner repeated his hopes yesterday that there would be a satisfactory settlement in the dispute over free Shakespeare shows in Central Park.

A group of thirty-five professors at five of our most distinguished law schools -- Columbia, Cornell, Harvard, Pennsylvania and Yale -- has issued a public protest against six bills now being considered by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee. We are happy to associate ourselves with their opposition to these bills, which are intended primarily to revise Supreme Court decisions in the area of internal security.

Thomas J. McLees, white-mustached and courtly and dedicated in appearance and manner to the tradition of customer service, walked out of Stern's department store yesterday for the last time, after seventy-five years of service.
Every once in a while one of Mrs. Veneta Buckner's five foster children will quietly approach her and ask, hesitantly, "Mommy, where is my real mommy?"
OWEGO, N. Y., May 5 (AP) -- A Tioga County court jury last night convicted Roy Carlisi, a 49-year-old tavern owner from Buffalo, on fifteen counts of criminal contempt of court.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- An old ship pilots' union has asked labor's high command to keep a new pilots' union out of its jurisdictional waters.

BALTIMORE, MAY 5 (AP) -- Survivors of an airline pilot and co-pilot killed when a Maryland Air National Guard jet trainer rammed a Capital Airlines Viscount in the air filed suits totaling $1,030,000 today against the Federal Government and the jet pilot.

CALGARY, May 5 (Canadian Press) -- A German immigrant who washed dishes in a Calgary Hospital for two years has turned out to be one of Germany's top wartime missile experts, according to The Calgary Herald.

" The present demand for copper is good and we expect it to continue so throughout the year," Charles R. Cox, president of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, reported yesterday at the company's annual meeting at the Statler Hilton Hotel here.

Mayor Wagner has asked for suggestions to help him find ways to meet the city's expanding budget. Evidence points to more effective operation of the city's maintenance and repair departments as a source of considerable saving. I have in mind, specifically, the department concerned with street repair.

CONCORD, N. H., May 5 -Trout streams in southern New Hampshire are in surprisingly good shape after the cold, swift waters of the Catskills, eastern New York and western Massachusetts. And the fishing for the moment is better.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Nine distributors of newspapers in New York and New Jersey, refused today to say whether they had made systematic pay-offs totaling more than $425,000 to officials of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union.
One hundred and fifty stagestruck neophytes -- singers, dancers and comedians -- passed in review yesterday at the St. James Theatre in Broadway's annual mass audition.

PARIS, May 5 -- Premier Michel Debre and Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville will fly to Bonn tomorrow for a visit designed primarily to sound the views of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on current European questions.
The American Banner Lines has petitioned for an amendment to its operating-differential subsidy contract to permit calls at Southampton, England.
LITTLE ROCK, May 5 -- The Little Rock School Board today deadlocked, 3 to 3, over the hiring of teachers for the next school year.
YONKERS, May 5 -- Battle Front, a contender all the way, was strongest in the stretch and won the Class A one-mile pace that topped tonight's harness racing card at Yonkers Raceway.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- President Eisenhower formally nominated William B. Franke today to be Secretary of the Navy. He is now Under Secretary.
The National Steel Corporation registered yesterday a proposed $80,000,000 issue of first mortgage bonds, due 1989, with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
RICHMOND, Va., May 5 (AP) -- A Federal Appeals Court pushed the reluctant state of Virginia farther along the school integration road today.

IN the confusion of the double defeat of the Yankees by the Detroit Tigers on Sunday an exceptional batting feat received less acclaim than it deserved. Charley Maxwell clouted four home runs during the afternoon.

A blue banner fifty feet long was unfurled yesterday to cover the prow of the Navy transport Patch and to symbolize the interest of the Military Sea Transport Service in the crusade of the American Cancer Society.

POPLARVILLE, Miss., May 5 (AP) -- Mack Charles Parker, kidnapped from his jail cell in this tiny Mississippi sawmill town, died of bullet wounds at the hands of masked terrorists, a coroner's jury ruled today
Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, the Army's Vice Chief of Staff, received the Distinguished Achievement Medal last night from the Grand Lodge of Masons of the State of New York.

The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously reversed a temporary injunction issued by the State Supreme Court last month. The writ had halted two restaurant unions from continuing their two-year-old picketing of the Stork Club, at 3 East Fifty-third Street.
The Sales Executives Club of New York, which usually sticks to business at its weekly sessions, took time out yesterday for a sentimental program.

WEST BERLIN, May 5 -- Recently a British Member of Parliament met a Soviet officer here and, as might have been expected, began to discuss the Berlin situation. "We only have 10,000 Allied troops," said the Englishman, "but we can give you a rough time for at least two hours if you start anything."

The forty-second season of summer Stadium Concerts at Lewisohn Stadium will begin on Monday, June 22, with Leonard Bernstein conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra. The season will run for six weeks, through Saturday evening, Aug. 1, and will include twenty-eight concerts.
The New York Chamber of Commerce predicted yesterday that this city's budget would rise in a few years to $3,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) -- Three Democratic Senators and a Republican colleague opened a drive today to water down a phase of the seniority system that has governed the Senate for years.

There are all sorts of insecticides on the market that are excellent, but they have one drawback. They require some effort on the part of the gardener. He must measure, mix and spray -- and, unless he has an electrically driven sprayer, the gardener finds pumping a sprayer handle arm-wearying work, which is probably why he sprays rose bushes and flowers less often than he should.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- After less than four months in Baghdad, Ambassador John T. Jernegan returned today for consultation on the steady advance of communism in Iraq.

MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, May 6 (UPI) -- Hank Aaron hit a 400-foot double in the sixteenth inning early today to score Eddie Mathews from first base and lift the Milwaukee Braves to a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers in the major league's longest game of the season.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 6 -- The rights and wrongs of "mercy" killing became a front-page issue in Britain today. The debate followed a disclosure by a physician that a woman incurably ill with cancer had died after he gave her sleep-inducing drugs.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

VIENNA, April 22 -- The Czechoslovak Communist regime has indicated that it has no intention of going along blindly with the Soviet bloc's trend toward close conformity with Moscow's idea of orthodoxy.
LONDON, May 5 -- Britain gave a resplendent welcome today to Shah Mohammad Riza Pahlevi of Iran upon his arrival here for a three-day state visit.
A stage version of John Dos Passos' famous trilogy, "U. S. A.," is Broadway-bound. The adaptation has been made by Mr. Dos Passos and Paul Shyre.
" ONE NIGHT STAND" brought ninety minutes of nostalgic entertainment to WNTA-TV (Channel 13) on Monday night.
DETROIT, May 5 (AP) -- Four persons were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of fraud in connection with an international attempt to fix newspaper puzzle contests.
NEWARK, May 5 -- The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad's conditional public announcement on April 10 of total abandonment of suburban commuter service was voided today.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, April 24 -- Yugoslav industries are drawing up new wage schedules -- a process somewhat resembling a man arguing with himself.
Frank Safford, who was refused a license last month to drive in harness races here, was accused under oath yesterday of betting against himself on a number of occasions in 1957.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -President Eisenhower said today that a summit meeting was a "foregone conclusion" if there was any hope that it could ease world tensions.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters may take over the Bakery and Confectionery Workers' International Union soon.

t Herman Phillips, New York ] hotel operator, and (lorta 1 Vanderbilt have purchased the Ivanhoe Hotel at 101st Street and the ocean in Hal Harbour, Fla. The purchase price was not disclosed but the property was reported to have been held for $2,500,000.
Plans to form a 109-man parking inspector bureau to enforce regulations at the 50,000 meters under Traffic Department control were announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 5 -- Eight competitive projects offering reactor designs for Britain's first nuclear-powered merchant ship are to be given urgent technical examination, the Admiralty announced tonight.
HARRISBURG, Pa., May 5 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson declared tonight it was imperative that the Democarts win the Presidency next year to end the prolonged division in government.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Red Cross announced the appointment of Palmer Simpson today as assistant manager of the Midwestern area, with headquarters in St. Louis.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -P. Henry Mueller, vice president of the First National City Bank of New York, stressed today that non-durable goods had been leading the recovery in output and since last August have been regularly meeting new production records.

" Skyrocketing demands" for the services of the Better Business Bureau of New York City will require a budget of $500,000 next year, Hugh R. Jackson, president, told the organization's annual meeting yesterday.
A union of nonprofessional hospital employes yesterday renewed its threat to strike six voluntary hospitals. The walkout was set for "any time after midnight" today.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 5 -- A construction concern halted work today on a $4,250,000 high school here in a highway dispute.
The Transit Authority indicated yesterday that it might be able to maintain the 15-cent fare through 1960.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 5 (AP) -- Judy Eller of Old Hickory, Tenn., continued below-par shooting in the Southern women's amateur golf tournament today when she scored a 7-and6 victory over Mrs. Harry Henderson of Alexandria, La., in the first round.

JERSEY CITY, May 5 -- The City Commission today abolished its nineteen-member Law Department, consisting of the Corporation Counsel and eighteen assistant corporation counsels. The commission also appointed a magistrate to a disputed Municipal Court post, and three men now hold the job.

Following are excerpts from the reply yesterday by the voluntary hospitals to a request of Mayor Wagner. He had urged that they reconsider a proposal that all questions on wages, working conditions and labor-management relations be submitted to a board of fact-finders.
LANSING, Mich., May 5 -Confusion grew in Michigan's fiscal muddle today.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that a small group of floor traders on the nation's stock exchanges apparently bear some responsibility for recent erratic swings in market prices.
IN most homes, a television set is either a big, dark box dominating the room or an extravagantly expensive builtin unit or console model.
ROME, May 5 (AP) -- Hans Winkler, Germany's Olympic champion, triumphed in the Grand Prix of the Rome Horse Show today.
BONN, Germany, May 5 -Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev indicated today that the Soviet Union would reject the Western allies' proposals at the foreign ministers' conference opening in Geneva Monday.
The Yorkville Youth Council, now in its twelfth year, will benefit from the Yorkville Ball, which will he held in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East on May 14.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The United States and Great Britain have created nearly three times as much radioactive debris by testing atomic weapons as the Soviet Union has done, the Atomic Energy commission disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -Sir Winston Churchill paid a hospital call today on two friends who, like himself, used to help shape world events. Accompanied by President Eisenhower, Sir Winston drove through spring sunshine to Walter Reed Army Hospital to visit John Foster Dulles, former Secretary of State, who has cancer.
SYRACUSE, May 5 (AP) -- The state's new Motor Vehicle Commissioner disclosed today that he intended to start a stagger system for vehicle registrations next year.
George Alpert, president of the New Haven Railroad, yesterday praised the relief New York State recently granted to commuter railroads and said, "I wish there were more Rockefellers in this country."

President Eisenhower said yesterday that anyone had a right to turn down a personal invitation from him. An aide of former President Harry S. Truman confirmed that the latter had a New York engagement for tonight.

Formal processes to oust Robert Battipaglia as Democratic county leader of Queens after only eight months in the post have been stared by a majority of the borough's fiftysix Democratic district leaders.

The Railway Express Agency has begun moving away from the passenger train, the traditional mover of express shipments. The agency announced yesterday that between Philadelphia and Chicago it had begun daily long-haul use of the Pennsylvania Railroad's TrucTrain or piggy-back freight service.

LONDON, May 5 -- Eugene R. Black cautioned tonight that the "cold war" eventually might be overshadowed by a growth of tension resulting from the wide disparity in the living standards of the developed and underdeveloped countries.

AFTER twenty years "Family Portrait" makes the same impression that it did originally. As acted at the Seven Arts Center last evening, it is an undistinguished drama with some profoundly moving moments.
Traffic on the Queensboro Bridge is expected to be slowed for the next two months while repairs are being made on two Manhattan ramps.
BUENOS AIRES, May 5 -- A Cuban proposal that the United States provide $30,000,000,000 for Latin-American development will be rejected, United States sources said today.

For last night's program in the city's Handel Festival, the auditorium was contributed by Town Hall and the performers by the Concert Artists Guild. Altogether there were nine artists, two singers, two violinists, an oboe player and four pianists.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Eisenhower came strongly to the defense today of his nominee for Secretary of Commerce and seven hours later Lewis L. Strauss himself hit back at his critics.
A New Englander who worked nights as a laborer in a wire mill to put himself through college was elected president of the nation's largest steel company yesterday.
CONSTANTINE, Algeria, May 5 (UPI) -- Crowds of opposing Arab and French youths rampaged through the streets of this panicky city today in the second straight day of violent disturbances.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A Democratic program for $251,000,000 in loans and grants to economically depressed communities was approved today by the House Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -John Moors Cabot, a Foreign Service career officer, will be named Ambassador to Brazil. He will replace Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, who resigned last week, three days after her confirmation by the Senate.
Mrs. Bernard Freeman led her team-mates to victory yesterday as Inwood defeated The Creek, 9 to 6, in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub golf matches.

The Radio Corporation of America reported record first-quarter sales and earnings at the annual meeting yesterday and then the management adroitly quelled trouble between stockholders. One woman stockholder took offense at a remark made by another. The offended woman replied with a sharp slap.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today he did not feel "too strongly" about the two-term limit on the Presidency. He said he was willing to let the American people decide whether it should stay or go.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 5 (AP) -- Twenty-eight young violinists from fifteen countries face the big tests of their careers starting tomorrow in the seventh post-war Queen Elizabeth of Belgium Music Competition at the Conservatoire music school.
SEOUL, Korea, May 5 -- The Opposition newspaper Kyung Hyang Shinmum sued the Government today for closing the paper last week.
Pan American World Airways, Inc., may turn to its own stockholders for $50,000,000 to help finance the company's financing of its new jet aircraft fleet.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Kenneth H. Tuggle, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, urged Congress today to give to the commission regulatory authority over all surface transportation between Alaska and the rest of the United States.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 5 -- A wave of violent demonstrations has swept Turkish internal politics to a new pitch of bitterness.
The Little Gardens Club will hold its annual tour of gardens in the Washington Square-Greenwich Village area tomorrow afternoon.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

AMMAN, Jordan, May 5 -Samir el-Rafai, the pro-Western strong man behind King Hussein's often shaky throne, resigned as Premier today. The action, ascribed to ill health, may foreshadow restoration of closer relations with the United Arab Republic.
A Greenwich Village tenant who says "rent-control laws are for people and not for cigarstore Indians" has taken his fight against eviction to Supreme Court.
Manhattan has become a place where only the rich or the poor can find housing, J. Clarence Davies, the city's newly appointed Commissioner of Real Estate, said yesterday.

LONDON, May 5 (AP) -Per Jacobsson, chairman of the International Monetary Fund, said today the recent outflow of gold from the United States "represents a warning about the trend of costs and prices in that country."

Cardinal Spellman received $20,000 yesterday from the Columbus Citizens Committee for 100 college scholarships. This sum is earmarked for graduates of Roman Catholic high schools in the Archdiocese of New York.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York suffered her first setback in the women's world chess challengers' tournament at Plovdiv, Bulgaria, yesterday according to a news report from Sofia. Mme. Raunka Todorova of Bulgaria defeated Mrs. Gresser after thirty-one moves.

4:30 P. M.: "Children of Japan," a film, will be shown at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. Other films will be shown at this hour tomorrow, Friday and Tuesday. An all-day program on Saturday will include films at 11 A. M. and at 2 and 4 P. M.

" PECK'S BAD GIRL," which had its debut at 9 o'clock last night over Channel 2, is another situation-comedy series on family life and a further reminder of the sustained superiority of "Father Knows Best."
LONDON, May 5 -- John Osborne's "The World of Paul Slickey," a savage satire labeled a musical comedy, received a stormy first-night reception in London's West End tonight.

Overhanging business signs would be prohibited in the Avenue of the Americas between Thirty-second Street and Central Park South under a bill passed yesterday by the City Council. The ban also would apply to a stretch of Fourth Avenue.

Sales of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company passed the $5,000,000,000 mark in the fifty-three weeks ended on Feb. 28, setting a new record for the century-old food chain.

Trading continued active yesterday in rubber, potatoes and lead but most other commodities on the New York exchanges were dull.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Army spokesmen told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today that the ground forces wanted more men and money than the pending Administration budget requests.
HARTFORD, May 5 (UPI) -Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff's highway construction program was approved tonight by the Connecticut House of Representatives. The vote was 202 to 65.

Electronics, cigarettes, rubbers and chemicals were higher yesterday in an inconclusive session of the New York Stock Exchange. Other important groups were mixed. Steels, non-ferrous metals and oils were generally lower.
A pattern of peaceful labor- management relations that has endured for twenty-six years was maintained yesterday by the Cloakmakers Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

In 1910 the first secretary of the National Consumers League, Florence Kelley, introduced in the United States the concept of minimum-wage legislation. Mrs. Kelley's dream became a reality as of the adoption of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 -An eighteen-story, 1,200-room hotel providing ramps up which motorists may drive their automobiles to their own bedroom floors was announced for downtown San Francisco today.

Gary Gubner, DeWitt Clinton High junior, yesterday became the first New York City schoolboy to exceed the sixty-foot mark in the twelve-pound shotput, Gubner threw the iron ball 61 feet 3 inches in the Brooklyn Automotive High track and field meet at McCarren Park in Brooklyn.

PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., May 5 -- Governor Rockefeller expressed "deep concern" over the state's mounting school problems today as he announced that his administration had started a top-to-bottom survey of New York's educational system.

The present Soviet policy of economic aid for Communist China, Eastern Europe and underdeveloped non - Communist countries encountered high level opposition in Moscow during the 1953-1957 feud between Nikita S. Khrushchev and the "anti-party group."
Solomon Chodorov, former agent for the Boyd-Wyckoff Management Corporation, obtained a postponement yesterday of several cases pending against him.

Business picked up in the bond market yesterday and with it came a general improvement in sentiment. Price changes were narrow in the market for Government securities, but the over-the-counter market for prime corporate bonds had the best undertone in many days.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- New methods of earthquake recordings, which greatly improve chances of detecting underground atomic blasts, were described today.

The Continental Oil Company has offered to acquire the capital stock of the Coastal Oil Company, which distributes fuel oil in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Continental Oil is a producer and has marketing facilities in twenty-six states.

In your editorial of April 13 you pronounce a harsh and unfair indictment against proposed Federal legislation commonly referred to as "fair trade." You refer to the Harris bill, although at the present time there is another bill before Congress seeking similar relief but in a different form, designated as the Boykin bill.
A converted ice cream truck was pressed into service yesterday to carry to the public the message of the Greater New York Fund.

Marie J. Leary of Greenwich, Conn., one of the leading, authorities in the breed, says that some German shepherds being sent o this country and elsewhere from Germany are too hot to handle. She made the comment during the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island specialty last weekend in Freeport, where she was a judge
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 6 -- A coroner ruled today that eleven Mau Maus had been beaten to death by African guards at the Government's prison camp in Hola.
An overly ambitious robin that started nine nests on nine successive steps of a Bronx Zoo fire escape has finally concentrated on one and laid an egg in it.
CHICAGO, May 6 -- W. R. Main, assistant vice president of the New York Central Railroad, testified today that his company lost $32,000,000 last year on its passenger operations.

United Artists Corporation has made arrangements for the private placement of $15,000,000 of 6 per cent participating promissory notes, due 1974, the company announced yesterday. The sale was arranged by F. Eberstadt Co. and the Prudential Insurance Company of America has agreed to buy the greater portion of the notes with the remainder to be taken by the Puritan Fund, Inc., of Boston.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The new issue of $2,000,000,000 of 340-day Treasury bills -- the first of three special short-term Treasury offerings this week -was auctioned today at an average yield of 3.835 per cent, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, May 6 -- The lunch bag and the vacuum bottle have become the mark of the Argentine bureaucracy.

ROME, May 6 (AP) -- American riders placed in the top ten of the two feature events today in the Rome international horse show.

Postmaster General Summerfield's sunny announcement that he is instituting next-day mail delivery service in metropolitan areas is hardly comforting to those of us who are exasperated by the incredible inefficiency of the New York Post Office.

PORT WELLER, Ont., May 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Welland Canal's biggest traffic jam in memory continued to grow today despite official assurances that it would be cleared by tomorrow.

TRENTON, May 6 -- The population of New Jersey increased 18.7 per cent from 1950 to 1958 compared with a 15 per cent rise for the nation, according to a report submitted today to Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 6 -- "The Mikado," Gilbert and Sullivan's operetta of court life in Japan, will be given an unusual interpretation starting Friday when the Port Singers present the musical play in the style of the traditional Kabuki theatre.
CAIRO, May 6 (AP) -- The press in the Egyptian region of the United Arab Republic criticized today the appointment of Premier Majali of Jordan.
