ALGIERS, May 6 -- Gen. Maurice Challe, French military commander in Algeria, warned the population tonight against being provoked into "blind vengeance" by rebel acts of terror. He said he would "not tolerate reprisals" from any side.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Eisenhower took his White House guest, Sir Winston Churchill, on a guided tour of his 200-acre farm outside Gettysburg, Pa., today. Then they boarded a helicopter to look over the terrain of Pickett's famous infantry charge, which marked the turning point of the Civil War.
Four tenements managed by Banton L. Wyckoff and vacated as hazardous have been sold to a corporation that intends to remodel them into "high class" apartments.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Joey Giardello, his face bloodied, finished strong tonight for a ten-round split decision over Holly Mims.

LIKE all wide-eyed tourists who go rubber-necking in the land of make believe, the New York Yankees will take in today whatever sights Los Angeles and environs have to offer. Then they will cap their swift venture beyond the Rockies by examining with open-mouthed wonder tonight the most startling man-made creation since Disneyland.

Smith, Barney Co., investment bankers and stockbrokers, leased space for a new uptown branch in the new building at 529 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-fourth Street. The branch will be moved in July, from 522 Fifth Avenue.

The 700 Park Avenue Corporation took title yesterday to the former Arthur Curtiss James mansion at 7 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Sixty-ninth Street. The house was bought in October from the James Foundation.
The Newspaper Guild of New York voted its Page One Award yesterday to former President Harry S. Truman.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 (AP) -- The United Nations Lead and Zinc Committee reported today that member countries had volunteered curtailments in supplies that would cut the world surplus of lead by half and zinc by four-fifth in the second half of 1959.
YORKTOWN, N. Y., May 6 -- Plans were filed here today for the new Wiltwyck School for Boys campus off Illington Road.
State Supreme Courts in Manhattan and Brooklyn issued orders yesterday staying a walkout of nonprofessional employes at six voluntary hospitals, scheduled to start at 6 A.M. tomorrow.

YONKERS, May 6 -- Adios Mont, a 4-year-old son of Adios, owned by Max Hempt and Royal Cleveland of Camp Hill, Pa., earned 4 points toward the $50,000 national pacing championship by winning the Cooper Distributing Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
LONDON, May 6 -- The British controversy over "mercy killing" shifted today from the question of right or wrong to the question of how it is done.

NEWARK, May 6 -- Business leaders at the national conference of the American Council to Improve Our Neighborhoods were told that only a determined public could get American cities rebuilt to meet the needs of the future.
CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- The report-of todaY's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- In the Senate debate that preceded the vote which confirmed the President's recess appointment last fall of Potter Stewart to the Supreme Court, in whose decisions, however, he has been participating as an unconfirmed judge, this Administration's practice of creating such a dubious situation was critically reviewed. The prevailing judgment was expressed as follows by Senator Hart of Michigan:
ROME, May 6 (AP) -- Gerard Pilet of France upset Italy's Orlando Sirola, 9 -- 7, 4 -- 6, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 2, in the second round of the Italian tennis championships today.

NEWARK, May 6 -- The Central Railroad of New Jersey faces "financial disaster" unless it abandons its passenger service "entirely" or raises its intrastate commutation fare, the carrier's president testified here today.
The steel industry disclosed yesterday that it was considering a mutual-aid pact to share profits if the United Steelworkers of America used a "divide and conquer" strike strategy this year.
Laurance S. Rockfeller yesterday received the Clement Cleveland Award of the American Cancer Society's New York City Cancer Committee.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 6 -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim will head a new Economic Planning Board under a new disposition of ministries, the newspaper Zaman reported today.

Any decision by the twelve principal steel companies to adopt a strike-aid plan would present legal complications that do not apply to the mutual assistance pact signed last October by six major airlines.
CHICAGO, May 6 (UPI) -A Negro union leader and ex-Communist said today it was an "outright lie" that the Communists fight for Negro rights.

Net income of the Boeing Airplane Company in the first quarter of this year fell to $1,539,275, or 21 cents a share, from $9,499,190, or $1.29 a share, a year earlier. The drop resulted from continuing costs of the commercial program and reduced military sales, William M. Allen, president, explained at the annual meeting yesterday in San Francisco.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 6 (AP) -- Four white men were indicted by an all-white county grand jury today for the rape of a 19-year-old Negro student at Florida A. M. University.
Following is a statement on the current hospital dispute made yesterday by Leo J. Davis, President of Local 1199, Retail Drug Employes Union:
TOKYO, May 6 -- Neutralization of Japan is now the primary goal of the international Communist movement in Asia, according to qualified Western analysts in Japan.

IT is extraordinary that a fat purse almost invariably demands an expensive cut of meat. While there is no denying that a porterhouse steak, a choice Chateaubriand or a fine filet mignon has enormous appeal for the palate, they are not really more delectable than some of the less costly specialties of the butcher's block.

The Greater New York Hospital Association has rejected the request of Mayor Wagner for an impartial committee's review of labor-management relations in the city's nonprofit hospitals. Unfortunately, this leaves the public without the benefit of such an impartial review on which to form an opinion -- one which, in the long run, may well determine the pattern of hospital labor relations.

An enchantment of flowers has come over this city. Park Avenue's malls are radiant with tulips, a vivacious broad ribbon of lovely color. The esplanade before the Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street is a garden of azaleas and pine. Fifth Avenue itself, from Thirty-fourth to Fifty-ninth Street, is lined with blooms. Thus, the traditional harsh rectangles and parallels of New York are tenderly and gaily softened.

Postoffice inspectors yesterday seized mailings of the new Grove Press edition of D. H. Lawrences romance, "Lady Chatterley's Lover." They acted in preparation for a test of whether the book fell under the ban of the obscenity sections of the postal laws.
Events today: Ralph Kneeream, organist, St. Paul's Chapel. Columbia University, noon; Betty Hwang, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; New York Pro Musica, La Maison Francaise, 16 Washington Mews, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Rising imports and declining exports reduced the United States export surplus to the unusually small total of $271,000,000 in the first quarter of 1959. In the first quarter of last year the surplus was more than three times greater.

IF Bonnie Prudden had got hold of the late Robert Benchley -- that stanch defender of man's right not to exercise -- she probably would have him doing knee-bends and push-ups and, incredible as it may seem, liking it.

IN its twentieth annual exhibition at the Riverside Museum, 310 Riverside Drive, the National Serigraph Society combines an international section representing thirteen countries with an American group.
For men who do not want to glow in the dark, a successor to the radium-dial watch has been found.

In Manhattan yesterday, women strode by in their summer dresses, tops of convertibles were down, and elbows stuck out like fins from the open windows of buses. At 3:05 P. M. the temperature at the Battery was up to 82.8 degrees. It was the hottest day of the year.
LINCOLN, N. H., May 6 (AP) -- The wreckage of a long-missing plane was spotted in a mountain wilderness here today.
Whitewall Laboratories will award an $8,000,000 advertising account to Tatham-Laird, Inc., Chicago.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- A scientist said today that radio-relay satellites might soon make it possible to telephone any point in the world for 20 cents.

Two runaway boys, missing since Monday, were found yesterday camping out in a cove on the Hudson River at Cold Spring, N. Y. The Coast Guard here said the search for them had covered about 1,000 square miles.

SANBORNTON, N. H., May 6 -- Well, it turned out that there is something peculiar about these landlocked salmon and lake trout here in Lake Winnisquam. They are the unfortunate victims of some kind of mob hysteria and the F. B. I. ought to look into it before somebody gets hurt.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -The Government's civilian space agency awarded a $33,500,000 contract to the General Dynamics Corporation today for development of a space rocket that would stand as tall as a ten-story building and weigh more than 147 tons.
An American production of "My Fair Lady" moved a step closer to Moscow yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -The Administration lined up today behind a Congressional drive to give business men a tax break on their foreign investments.

The credibility of the State Harness Racing Commission's only witness against Frank Safford was attacked yesterday at the continuation of a hearing on Safford's appeal for reinstatement as a harness driver.
The bond market was largely a Treasury affair yesterday.
Governor Rockefeller formally initiated the latest in the recurring series of state investigations of New York City government yesterday.
VIENNA, May 6 (UPI) -- Rumania has lifted emigration bars on non-Jewish citizens with close relatives in the United States and other countries outside Europe, informed sources said today.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 6 -- Angry parents rallied today to the side of forty-four school teachers who were dismissed yesterday by three members of the Little Rock School Board.
THE new president of Rutgers University, Dr. Mason Welch Gross, is known on the campus at New Brunswick, N. J., as a man of unflagging ability. He has demonstrated it in many ways.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, April 29:
Prices of all cotton futures but one of the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 12 points yesterday. The New October contract declined 3 points.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 6 -- A campaign in southwestern Fairfield County to raise $452,600 for a projected branch of the University of Connecticut was announced today.
One of twenty-three men rounded up as suspicious characters last Sunday was sent back to prison for two years yesterday by Kings County Judge Hyman Barshay.
MONROE, N. C., May 6 (UPI) -- A Negro leader here, charging that members of his race cannot obtain Justice in the courts, threatened last night to "meet violence with violence."

Alfred P. Sloan, honorary chairman and a director of the General Motors Corporation has sold or given away all of his direct holdings in the company's common stock. He still retains an indirect interest in 1,185,156 shares, according to a report issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 6 -- One fisherman was drowned but three companions were rescued today when their rowboat struck Buoy 13 and overturned off Southfield Point in Long Island Sound.
The question of free Shakespeare in Central Park remained unsettled yesterday.
Eight of the nine horses that contested the season's first stakes for 2-year-old colts at Jamaica yesterday had been timed in 59 seconds or less for five furlongs.
A public hearing at City Hall on the proposal to revise the master plan of arterial highways in lower Manhattan developed yesterday into a clash between big and little business.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 5 -A United States proposal for customs tariff reduction among the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade received the backing of the Council of the European Economic Community here today.

Up to last year, and perhaps even up to the present time, the international trade fair in this country still had some things to learn from such long-established counterparts in Europe as those held at Milan and Paris.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter will make his first major foreign policy report to the people tomorrow night.
KUWAIT, May 1 -- Lounging in the Kuwait Club one evening, a dozen white-gowned Arabs began talking about what makes an Arab nationalist.

MONROVIA, Liberia, May 6 (Reuters) -- President William V. S. Tubman won another four-year term in yesterday's Liberian elections, returns showed today. There were few incidents, aside from some arrests in this capital for disorderly conduct.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 2 -- South African turf history will be made soon when the unbeaten 3-year-old Capetown colt, Royal Affair, arrives in New York.

Tulips by the thousands are adding fresh grace and color to midtown Fifth Avenue. They are blooming in new cast-concrete planter tubs that form a chain of small garden plots along the city pavement from Thirty-fourth to Fifty-ninth Street.

BONN, Germany, May 6 -- Michel Debre, the French Premier, flew into Bonn today for a one-day consultation with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on Western positions at the Geneva conference of foreign ministers opening Monday.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 6 -- The Turkish capital will receive tomorrow its first state visitor from Greece in six years and is taking pains to provide a cordial welcome.
Voter resistance to rising school costs brought rejection of many proposed budgets in annual school district elections completed last night.

The Municipal Bond Club of New York has announced the nomination of E. Barron Rockwell for president. The club will hold its annual meeting and election of officers on June 12 at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, in conjunction with its annual outing.
Students and staff members of the Baruch School of Business Administration of City College will give blood to the Red Cross today.

More golfers will seek to qualify on May 18 at Rye, N. Y., for the United States open championship than at any other site. This is the first step for many toward ultimate participation in the title tourney that will be held, June 11-13, at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y.
HONG KONG, May 6 -- Formal disapproval of the views on Tibet of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India was expressed in Peiping today.
Maj. Robert E. Tiffany and Petey Scalzo, a former world featherweight champion, were added to the staff of the New York State Athletic Commission at a special meeting yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower today appointed Gen. Lawrence S. Kuter to head the North American Air Defense Command.

Space-age stocks staged an eye-catching performance on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Beneath the pyrotechnics of missile, electronic and fuel stocks, however, more stocks were falling than rising.
Discrimination is "intolerable, not only for moral but for economic reasons as well," Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said here last night.
BRUSSELS, May 6 (Reuters) -- The joint ministerial council for the six-nation Common Market and Euratom approved yesterday a $29,540,000 budget to cover the two communities' expenditure in 1959.
LONDON, May 6 -- An early Picasso nude was sold at auction here today for 55,000 ($154,000), said to be the highest price ever obtained for a Picasso painting at a public sale.
The full slate of officers of the Park Association of New York City was re-elected yesterday at a meeting of the membership and the board of directors in the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- A House Banking subcommittee today approved a bill to ease the reserve requirements of commercial banks. Reserves are the percentage of deposits the banks are required to keep in cash with their district Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Lewis L. Strauss today began an itemized rebuttal of charges made against him by Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico. He promptly ran into a drumfire of criticism from some Democratic members of the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.
MILWAUKEE, May 6 (AP) -- Wes Covington's pinch single in the eighth drove home Eddie Mathews with the winning run today as the Milwaukee Braves beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Lehigh Valley Railroad was authorized today to discontinue six of its main line passenger trains.
RABAT, Morocco, May 6 -- King Mohamed turned forty Spanish prisoners over to the Spanish Ambassador today in a brief ceremony at the Royal Palace here.
PRETORIA, South Africa, May 6 -- The Union of South Africa has renewed its claims to the British protectorates of Bechuanaland, Swaziland and Basutoland.
BUENOS AIRES, May 6 -- A plan for a study of needs and possibilities in the economic development of each Latin-American country was adopted today by the inter-American conference in session here.
A blueprint for the high school of the future with classes up to 200 pupils taught by "master teachers" was put forth yesterday by John W. Studebaker, former United States Commissioner of Education.
Two newsmen and a former diplomat were cited for distinguished service to journalism last night by the alumni of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism.
VIENNA, May 6 -- A strong United States delegation was on hand today for the formal opening of the conference of the executive committee of the International Council of Women.
BONN, Germany, May 6 -- A television crew took camera and microphone into scores of West German classrooms recently and what they recorded was reverberating through the Federal Republic today.

Sugar Ray Robinson, who was stripped of his world middleweight title last Monday by the National Boxing Association, said yesterday that he was weighing offers from four N. B. A. states and a $500,000 Madison Square Garden proposition plus a percentage to defend his crown.
As the Greater New York Fund's annual drive gets under way in May, officials remind us that there is no public solicitation or door-to-door campaigning for the fund.
Should parochial schools get public support? Does religion have any place in the public schools?

ALBANY, May 6 -- The State Education Department announced today the names of eleven young scientists as recipients of the 1959 Graduate Student Honorariums of the department. The winners will undertake original research on laboratory or field problems this summer in New York State.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The National Guard Adjutants General Association, winding up its annual meeting here today, criticized the Defense Department for failing to support the guard at full manpower strength.

The apartment house for twenty-seven families at 3235 Hull Avenue, southwest corner of East 207th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Morel Fuchs and Daniel and I. Irving Braff. The buyer was 3235, Inc., Morris Podoshen, president.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of April 17 you profess to find an inconsistency between the policy of free tuition at the four-year municipal colleges and the policy of charging tuition for one-third of the operating costs of the community colleges.
Salary increases ranging from $280 to $510 for the city's 40,000 teachers and up to $1,000 for administrators were proposed yesterday by Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.

The Rockefeller Institute, which has recently been transformed into a graduate university, announced yesterday that it had received a bequest of about $1,000,000 from the estate of the late Sophie D. Fricke.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Senate investigators were told today that three New York newspapers had paid thousands of dollars in tribute to assure that labor troubles would not block delivery of some of their Sunday supplements from a commercial printing plant.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- Bette Davis and Gary Merrill will star in "An Evening of Carl Sandburg," which will begin a national concert tour Oct. 5 on the Eastern Seaboard. The offering will proceed West, winding up in Los Angeles at an undetermined date, after which a Broadway engagement is planned.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- The United States urged the United Nations space agency today to take a "businesslike" approach to "the practical, technical, non-political job which we have been given to do."
A Citizens Committee for Modern Zoning was announced yesterday to support a comprehensive rezoning plan for the city.

American Telephone and Telegraph Company expects to do no major financing in the immediate future. This was reported yesterday by William C. Bolenius, executive vice president, in a talk to the New York Society of Security Analysts.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A joint Congressional atomic energy subcommittee was warned today that if atomic testing was resumed at the intensive rate of the last five years, atomic fall-out would begin to rise to dangerous levels.

A Democratic district leadership fight brought out yesterday an insurgent's charge that he had been forced to resign as counsel to the Department of Licenses because of his political activity. The job paid $11,000 a year.

BENNINGTON, Vt., May 6 (AP) -- Bennington College will return Federal aid it has received under the National Defense Education Act, and withdraw from the program because of a requirement that students accepting loans sign loyalty oaths.

Twenty-three hundred production and maintenance employes went on strike yesterday at Brooklyn and New Brunswick, N. J., plants of the E. R. Squibb Sons division of the Olin-Mathieson Chemical Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The five-nation "food and peace" conference established a committee today to plan to use wheat for feeding the world's hungry people and promoting economic development.

The San Diego County Water Authority, California, has sold $8,000,000 of serial bonds to help finance construction of an extension to the Colorado River Aqueduct. The money was borrowed at an interest cost of 3.98 per cent.

SUFFERN, N. Y., May 6 -- A 36-year-old television executive was stabbed by his wife here early today, the police reported. The executive, John J. Brennan of Airmont, was in good condition at Good Samaritan Hospital, where he was treated for a two-inch flesh wound in the back.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- Bacteria that used to be considered relatively harmless for humans are now, in an age with the wide use of antibiotic drugs, causing serious diseases and deaths.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -An insurgent group of stockholders today lost its fight to gain control of Bayuk Cigars, Inc., one of the country's largest cigar manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- Congress revealed testimony today showing how a bad guess by the Army on its housing needs cost taxpayers $550,958.
A $104-hotel bill incurred by Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan at Orlando, Fla., in March, 1958, was paid by Roosevelt Raceway.

Myron C. Taylor, former special Presidential envoy to the Vatican and former board chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, died of pneumonia yesterday at his home, 16 East Seventieth Street. He was 85 years old.
ROME, May 6 -- President Giovanni Gronchi paid a ceremonial call on Pope John XXIII today, it was his first visit to the new Pontiff.
Fred Astaire waltzed off with nine Emmy awards last night.
KANSAS CITY, May 6 -- The Yankees provided an emphatic reply tonight to the burning question of "what's wrong with the Bombers?"

BALTIMORE, May 6 -- Stockholders of the Alleghany Corporation were told here today at their annual meeting in the Southern Hotel that dividends could not be expected on the common stock in the near future. David Wallace, executive vice president and secretary, who was chairman of the meeting, said:
The Maritime Administration indicated yesterday that the idea of a nuclear-powered commercial submarine tanker had not been abandoned.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- James G. Cross, president of the Bakery and Confectionery Union, said in a statement tonight that "newspaper reports of his union's imminent merger with the teamsters were so much nonsense."

The Bushmen of Africa, a primitive, gentle and peaceful people, are described in a book by Elizabeth Marshall Thomas entitled "The HalTnless People.'' The author was a member of an expedition of the Peabody 1Vfuseum of Harvard that went three times to the Kalahari Desert where the Bushmen live. Her book tells how she, her parents and her brother lived with several family groups and won their friendship.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- Gloria Wood can afford to violate the Beverly Hills commandment that a swimming pool belongs with a house. She has a pool table instead.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- On Aug. 24 in the year 79 a woman in Pompeii, at the foot of Mount Vesuvius, placed a loaf of bread in her oven. Hours or minutes later the volcano exploded. The city was buried in hot ash and the bread was burned to a crisp.

AREN'T we all a little tired of the Nineteen Twenties? The golden age of wonderful nonsense is becoming a bore. But if anyone speaks a word against it I will rise to defend its incomparable glories. And so will my betters.
The 105-ton "fire box" for the Savannah, the world's first nuclear-powered merchant ship, is en route from Ohio to Camden, N. J., where the vessel is under construction.

ONE of the larger events in the art world encountered each spring is the annual exhibition at the National Academy Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue, of the National Association of Woman Artists. The present show, the sixty-seventh in succession, opens today and will remain on view, from 1 to 5 P. M. daily including Sundays, until May 24.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 6 (AP) -- The Army fired its eighteenth Jupiter rocket tonight on the start of a 1,500mile test flight on reliability and accuracy.

Heretofore, Alfred Drake has been concerned primarily with Broadway either as a star, director or producer. For the first time, he is turning his attention to the off-Broadway sector. Not in the acting department, but rather as director, co-author and co-sponsor.

Directors of the General Foods Corporation raised the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday for the second time in nine months. The declaration of 65 cents a share, payable June 5 compared with 60 cents paid in previous quarters.

The situation in the Middle East continues to shape up more and more as a defense on the part of Arab nationalism against communism. By the same token we are seeing, from the Communist side, a converging thrust upon the whole area from the eastern Mediterranean to the Gulf of Bengal.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Eisenhower Administration's official position on the proposed repeal of the Twenty-second Amendment took on aspects of a minor mystery today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N, J., May 6 -- Dr. Mason Welch Gross was inaugurated today as the sixteenth president of Rutgers, the state university. In his address he said that the Soviet Union was making far more effective advances with the peoples of Africa and Asia than the United States because it had taken greater pains to understand their respective cultures.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 -- American President Lines expects to go ahead with construction of a twenty-two-story headquarters building in this city after a virtually unpublicized disagreement with the Maritime Administration over financing.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, urged Congress today not to quibble over continued foreign aid funds while negotiations with the Soviet Union in Geneva are impending.

Government lending to non-governmental enterprises -- more than seven times as large as it was at the end of World War II -- threatens the long term growth and economic stability of the country, the American Bankers Association said yesterday.
Maurice Chevalier will star in a Paris-made radio show over the Columbia Broadcasting System network some time in September.
The All-City High School Chorus and Orchestra presented its tenth annual concert last night in Carnegie Hall. Dr. Peter J. Wilhousky conducted the chorus and Raymond LeMieux led the orchestra.
LONDON, May 6 -- A contraction of business volume and some profit taking turned stock market prices irregular today.
An offering of $25,000,000 of shares in Eurofund, Inc., a closed-end investment company that will specialize in European Common Market securities, is on the market today.
LONDON, May 6 (Reuters) A columnist for The Daily Herald called on English gentlemen today to doff their bowlers for good.
Edward O. Cerf, an assistant managing editor of Life magazine, was found shot dead in his home at 410 East Eighty-fifth Street yesterday. The police termed it an apparent suicide.
A stolen Amati violin that had been insured for $7,500 was turned in yesterday at a Harlem pawnshop in exchange for $10 and a pair of second-hand shoes.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 6 (AP) -- The Columbia Broadcasting System's television network is increasing its cultural broadcasts, its president, Frank Stanton, announced tonight. But he added that too much culture on the air can be as bad as too little.
Basic fixed - income investments moved irregularly yesterday as the Treasury passed the halfway mark of its $5,300,000,000 financing operation.
A bronze monument to Alice and some of her companions in Wonderland was unveiled in Central Park yesterday.

The United Steelworkers of America formally called on Federal authorities yesterday to investigate an alleged conspiracy by the twelve biggest steel companies to violate the anti-trust and labor laws.
Shop stewards of Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union said last night after a one-hour closed meeting that plans to strike at six voluntary hospitals here this morning had not been changed.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Justice Department, with President Eisenhower's support, called today for reversal of a ruling that political candidates must be given equal time on radio and television news programs.
Maine is planning to borrow $9,500,000 in the bond market on obligations secured by general taxation. The issue will be put up for sale on June 3.

THE major virtue of the Emmy awards is that their fundamental silliness is usually relieved by one or two deserving commendations. Such was the case once again Wednesday evening when "An Evening With Fred Astaire" and James Costigan's lovely drama, "Little Moon of Alban," won the most prizes. There can be no quarrel with either choice.
Directors of Seeman Brothers, Inc., distributor of White Rose and Premier brand foods, yesterday voted to split the common stock two for one.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) --The United States signed an agreement today for transfer to Britain of non-nuclear parts of atomic weapons and for Britain's purchase of fuel for her atomic submarine. A more limited military atomic agreement was reached with France. Under it the United States agrees to supply enriched uranium for a development reactor the French are i working on. The French are trying to build an atomic submarine too.

First-quarter earnings of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) were 42 per cent above the corresponding period of 1958, Frank O. Prior, chairman, reported at the annual meeting in Hammond, Ind., yesterday.

The record of the Interstate Commerce Commission's regulatory activities over coastal and intercoastal shipping was described yesterday as "almost catastrophic."

WESTBURY, L. I., May 7 -- One workman was killed, four others were injured and nine men escaped with minor bruises today in the collapse of an one-story building under construction at the Westbury Industrial Park.
A substantial increase in member bank lending in small cities has forced the Federal Reserve System to make a significant upward revision in its figures on required reserves for April.

SANBORNTON, N. H., May 7 -- A reliable informant has come in with the information that an angler using shiners caught a nine-pound rainbow and a six-pound brown trout a couple of days ago in the Ammonoosuc River north of here.

Newly painted and redecorated passenger cars -- three of them a week -- are in store for the New York Central commuters.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Senate, which looks upon itself as great deliberative body, is getting altogether too disorderly.

YONKERS, May 7 -- Darn Safe trotted the fastest mile of the meeting at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 2:02 4/5 clocking for the pride of the Hayes Fair Acres Stable of DuQuoin, Ill., brought the 8year-old brown gelding his first triumph of the year after three setbacks.

BONN, Germany, May 7 -- The commander of the United States Army in Europe said today that Western military forces in Germany would suffer no strategic or tactical disadvantage if they were to withdraw west of the Rhine and the Soviet Army were to withdraw from East Germany.
LONDON, Friday, May 8 -- Incomplete results of local elections held throughout Britain and Wales yesterday showed early today a swing toward the Conservative party.

Commodity futures closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, lead, zinc, copper, cocoa and soybean oil declined; the domestic sugar months, rubber and wool rose, and price movements for the world sugar contract, potatoes, cottonseed oil, hides and burlap were mixed.

Two brothers who agreed to answer the same list of questions concerning their attendance at the gangland convention in Apalachin, N. Y., got different grades yesterday for their answers. One was ordered to stay in jail and the other was told he would be released.

Photography has been recognized as a fine art in an exhibition opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Eighty-five prints that the museum helped select will be on view as examples of creative art.
A confirmation of studies that suggested an association between cigarette smoking and the development of lung cancer has been reported in the current, March-April, number of Cancer.
