Although it denied complaints that it often takes letters as long as four days to go from one part of the city to another, the New York Post Office said yesterday it would welcome such complaints for investigation.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- Jerry Walker pitched a fivehitter and the Baltimore Orioles slammed three home runs to snap a three-game Washington Senators' winning streak, 10 -- 1, tonight.
Representative Charles A. Buckley, Democratic leader of the Bronx, called upon his party last night to purge itself of "independent Democrats" and break off its association with the Liberal party.

The man most likely to suffer a heart attack in early middle age may be identified by mathematical analysis of data on his physique, blood chemistry and heredity, a medical report indicated yesterday.
Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said yesterday that there was "no possibility of the Soviet Union's outstripping the United States in industrial production by 1970."

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Following is the text of a statement prepared for the Atomic Energy Commission by its General Advisory Committee on the committee's review of problems presented by radioactive fallout:
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation was accused today of having submitted plane cost figures to the Air Force that the company knew were $4,110,600 too high.

Myron Taylor was a man of extraordinary abilities and world-wide interests, in the law, in business, in industry, and finally diplomacy, for which he received deserved Presidential tribute for serving "faithfully and well wherever duty called him." He had several careers, in all of which he won distinction, achieved from a combination of talent and the integrity of his character.

Three plays, each written by Joseph Hayes, have been earmarked for Broadway next season. Two of them, "The Midnight Sun" and "Calculated Risk," have been made known previously. The third one, "Belle Denise" (temporary title), is the newest entry.

Events tonight: University Glee Club, Town Hall; Joan Lauro, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall; Elmo Russ, program of his songs, Sky Room, Carl Fischer Hall; Concert of Chamber Music, Otto Herz, pianist, Napoleon Cerminara, clarinetist, Joseph Singer, horn player, Bernard Robbins, violinist, Otto Deri, 'cellist, New York College of Music; Maria Cleva, soprano, Greenwich House Music School, all at 8:30 o'clock.

FORT SAM HOUSTON, Tex., May 7 -- The United States A squad captured team honors in the 1959 international modern pentathlon concluded at Fort Sam Houston with a rugged 4,000-meter cross-country run today.

THE fourth floor of the New York Coliseum has been converted into a vast, exotic grocery for the United States World Trade Fair. Shoppers can purchase all sorts of foods from abroad, often at bargain prices. But they do not have to buy.
NEW DELHI, India, May 7 (Reuters) -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru exonerated today his former special assistant, M. O. Mathai, of charges of improperly using his official position.
Substantial amounts of land held by city departments are being inventoried to determine what can be sold, Mayor Wagner was told yesterday.

Foreign nations purchased an additional $75,000,000 in gold from the United States Treasury in the week ended Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday. This brought the monetary gold stock to $20,255,000,000, some $279,000,000 below its level at the beginning of the year.
Salary increases are in store for the more than 2,200 faculty members of this city's college system. But the amounts have not yet been determined.
TUNIS, May 7 -- President Habib Bourguiba said today that he had intervened several times with French and Algerian rebel officials for cessation of clashes along the Algerian-Tunisian frontier.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 -- Edward Dmytryk had just finished directing a scene from "The Blue Angel" when he mentioned the second dirtiest word in the movie business -- "remake." The dirtiest, of course, is "Communist."

A revival engagement of Charlie Chaplin's 1925 comedy, "The Gold Rush," will begin today at the Inwood Theatre in Forest Hills, Queens, with no immediate prospect of the distribution dispute that curtailed a revival of "Modern Times" at the same showcase last month.

Speculation on the state's "Little Hoover Commission" inquiry into the affairs of New York City has turned on the question whether this investigation would take the "high" road of trying to bring about constructive reform or the "low" road of unearthing sensational evidence detrimental politically to the Wagner administration and the city's Democratic delegation to the Legislature.
The new frontiers are no longer "roads to the West" but are in "the minds and souls of men," Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said yesterday in accepting a Horatio Alger award.

To combat a proxy fight threatened by a dissident stockholder, the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad plans to seek a three-week adjournment of its annual meeting until May 29. The meeting had been called for today in Chicago, but in a proxy letter received yesterday by stockholders, David O. Mathews, president, disclosed that the company would seek the adjournment.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said tonight that the American people should expect no quick and easy end of the "cold war."
NEW DELHI, India, May 7 -- India's Finance Minister wants to sit down with the Finance Minister of Pakistan and settle accounts dating back to the partition of British India twelve years ago.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- Sir Winston Churchill leaned on his gold-headed cane, puffed on his big black cigar and listened to the applause.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Thor intermediate range missiles capable of blasting parts of the Soviet Union from bases in Britain are now on launchers there available for use in an emergency.

In a letter printed April 17 Walter Millis criticized Gen. Thomas S. Power's testimony before the House Appropriations Subcommittee of Defense. He quoted parts of one sentence from General Power's thirteen-page opening statement which I quote here at greater length so as to show the context:

Cardinal Hayes won the New York division title and St. Francis Prep and Bishop Loughlin tied for the Brooklyn-Rockville Centre crown yesterday in the sectional track and field championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association.
MILWAUKEE, May 7 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association promised today that every contender for the world middleweight championship would get a shot at the crown it stripped from Sugar Ray Robinson.

ROME, May 7 (UPI) -- RioI of the Mantua StablesI day won ttie seventy-sixth I nning of the Italian Derby at e CapaneUe Hippodrome, beat,g eleven other entries. I The $33,600 race was held in[ rfeet spring weather' before crowd of some 40,000. Rio Marin, ridden by Saverio ifici, covered the 2,400 .ter course (about one and e-half miles) in 2:30, defeatSongkoi by three-quarters a length. Chemo finished l-d.
Archduchess Marie of Austria told the police early yesterday that an antique gold, pearl and ruby pendant, which she described as a "priceless" Habsburg heirloom, was missing.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Harold Gross and another union official accused of exacting payments from New York area newspaper and printing concerns invoked the Fifth Amendment today as Senate investigators tried unsuccessfully to make them talk.
The Great Lakes inland canal system was under attack yesterday as shipping slowed in canal bottlenecks and harbor jams, according to The Canadian Press.
A nine-man golfing team of United States amateurs left yesterday to defend the Walker Cup in Scotland. The Americans will face a British squad in the biennial series at Muirfield May 15-16.

A three-foot sycamore sapling played the central role in an Arbor Day ceremony in Chelsea yesterday. It was planted on the lawn fronting the Hudson Guild to the piping songs of children and some folk dances.
LISBON, Portugal, May 7 -- Col. Arnaldo Schulz, Portuguese Minister of the Interior, said today that a Communist-inspired attempted uprising in March had been put down by the Government.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The House of Representatives challenged President Eisenhower to a showdown today on a major public-versus-private power issue.
CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- A late burst of selling hit rye futures hard today on the Board of Trade. Other grains and soybeans finished generally little changed.
NORWALK, Conn., May 7 -The Board of Education released five-year capital improvement budget today. It calls for the expenditure of $5,611,000 between now and 1964.
The first major union voice was raised yesterday against the Kennedy labor reform bill.
" How would you like to be in the movies?" a stranger asked.

Paired with Mme. Valentina Borisenko, one of the best women players in the Soviet Union, Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York registered a third draw yesterday in the women's world chess tournament at Plovdiv, Bulgaria, according to a report received through Bulgarian news sources.
PARIS, May 7 -- President Charles de Gaulle said today that the pacification of Algeria, permitting a profound transformation of the country for the benefit of all its peoples, was "in sight."

Your editorial of May 1 concludes that maneuvering for political advantage is the major cause of Michigan's fiscal crisis. You profess an inability "from this distance" to assign major blame either to Democratic Gov. G. Mennen Williams or Republican State Senators.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 7 (Reuters) -- Ceylon's three-year-old coalition Government of Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike faced a crisis tonight after repeated attempts had failed to heal the breach between Leftists and Rightists in the fifteen-man Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- A Houston, Tex., member of the boilermakers union testified today that an official of his local was replaced on the spot for refusing to turn over $10,000 of the local's money to Joseph McCollum, an international vice president.

Initial plans are being made by members of the Woman's Auxiliary of St. Vincent's Hospital of Westchester in Harrison, N. Y., for a benefit luncheon and fashion show at the Apawamis Club in Rye on Oct. 15.
ROME, May 7 -- The Government is under strong pressure to disown one of Italy's most controversial newspapers, in Giorno of Milan.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- The Postmaster General, Arthur E. Summerfield, asked Congress today to raise the cost of mailing a first-class letter from 4 cents to a nickel to help balance President Eisenhower's budget.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A trial examiner recommended today that the National Labor Relations Board find that an employer committed an unfair labor practice when he sought a state court injunction against picketing.

Anyone who followed the Kennedy labor bill in the Senate must agree with your editorial of May 2 that Senator McClellan deserves public appreciation for his achievement on the "bill of rights" amendment. It was an act of genuine statesmanship on his part.
Luther H. Gulick and Simon H. Rifkind were appointed by Mayor Wagner yesterday to the nine-member state commission that will investigate the government and finances of New York City.
A second harness track acknowledged yesterday that it had paid hotel bills for state racing officials who attended qualifying races at Orlando, Fla.

LINCOLN, N. H., May 7 (UPI) -- Notes left by two Dartmouth College doctors disclosed today that they had conducted survival studies and had lived four days after their plane crashed in a gully of the White Mountains during a snow storm.
TRENTON, May 7 -- Three New Yorkers were arrested tonight at a hotel here with nearly a million dollars worth of jewelry and furs stolen from the hotel suite of Mrs. Mary G. Roebling.
A taxpayer revolt in school elections Wednesday night was attributed yesterday to resentment against increasing school costs and rising taxes generally.

LONG before Rome became a mighty power the Romans learned in the humiliation of defeat that to the victor belong the spoils. Some time later they learned another valuable lesson: that if the victory is as complete as victories often were in antiquity the victors can write the history with no worry about the dissenting opinions of the vanquished.
LONDON, May 7 -- In an uncertain world where even the New York Yankees can land in seventh place, it is a pleasure to report that everything in London is the same as ever, if not better.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7 (AP) -- The business upswing will continue through mid-1960 at least, despite foreseeably slower gains this summer, Commerce Department experts predict.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said last night that the economic interdependence of the non-Communist world demanded cooperation with the United States as well as cooperation by the United States.
Harold Gross, a convicted labor extortionist, will be dropped from the payroll of a metropolitan area printing concern, a company official said last night.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Colin P. Kelly 3d made it the hard way. He won appointment to the United States Military Academy in a competitive examination that he could have bypassed by accepting a Presidential appointment.

President Eisenhower and ex-President Truman have joined forces on an issue of vital importance to the nation by urging Congress to give speedy approval of the Administration's $3.9 billion Mutual Security program. The President, in numerous statements on the subject, calls the program an essential factor in our battle for peace and national safety. Mr. Truman warns that it would be playing with dynamite to cut the program.
The president of the American Trudeau Society reported progress yesterday in classifying organisms that produce diseases closely resembling tuberculosis.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 7 -- The high percentage of young men in the South African police force has caused increasing public uneasiness.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The forty-four members of New York's Congressional delegation introduced legislation today designed to increase the state's share of defense procurement contracts.
OTTAWA, May 7 (AP) -- Canada's capital has a new $4,500,000 air terminal that will be ready for occupancy within the next six weeks. It replaces outgrown facilities more suitable to a prairie town.

Reginald N. Webster's 3-year-old Princequillo filly, Quill, the top 2-year-old in her division last year, made an unimpressive return to racing at Jamaica yesterday. She finished a dull fourth among seven in a mile-and-a-sixteenth allowance race. She was second choice at 8 -- 5.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7 -- The United States said today that liability for injury or damage caused by a man-fired satellite crashing to earth should have first consideration among the legal problems of outer space.
HONG KONG, May 7 (Reuters) -- Mao Tse-tung, leader of the Chinese Communist party, received the Panchen Lama of Tibet today, the Hsinhua (New China) News Agency reported.

Apparently the world of do-it-yourself, developed in the post-war era as a counter to skyrocketing costs for personal services, and which has made of us a nation of carpenters and wallpaper-hangers, is in for some competition.

SEVENTY-FIVE years ago today, on May 8, 1884, John Truman, a horse-and-mule trader of Lamar, Mo., nailed a horseshoe over the front door of the little white cottage where he lived. The horseshoe was in honor of the birth of his first son, Harry.
A 74-year-old retired house painter, who admitted he had $19,273 in savings banks, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to a charge of accepting relief funds illegally.
A proposal for an $11,250,000 office building and a $3,500,000 luxury apartment development for Brooklyn's $200,000,000 civic center was advanced yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore.
The vacancy rate in Manhattan loft buildings last month was 3 per cent, compared with 2.8 per cent a year ago, the Real Estate Board of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Lewis L. Strauss declared today that he had "never knowingly, willfully and deliberately withheld any information" from the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee when he was chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Van Heflin has been assigned starring role as the dishonest labor leader in Rod Serling's original drama, "The Rank and File." It will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Playhouse 90" on May 28 from 9:30 to 11 P. M.

ARTHUR DANTO, whose recent woodcuts are on exhibition at the Berryman Gallery, 2852 Broadway, is among the few American artists carrying forward the tradition of the black-and-white woodcut. It is obvious that he relishes the profound black masses and the sharp white highlights that so inspired such predecessors as Vallotton and Munch.
A LOT of people, particularly men, think that fashion is pretty funny. Last night, though, it was the women who had the last laugh.
Working control of Webcor, Inc., has been purchased by the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, Benjamin Abrams, president, announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 7 -- An investigation has been ordered into the deaths of eleven prisoners at a Mau Mau detention camp in Kenya March 3, allegedly as a result of beatings.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Congressional hearings on bills to liberalize the wage and hour law opened today with organized labor asking for a minimum of $1.25 an hour and coverage for 7,500,000 more workers.

During World War II the German Foreign Office had an idea for using Eire against the British Commonwealth. It sent a spy named Goertz to train the Irish Republican Army for an invasion of Eire. In "The Jackboot In Ireland" the author, Sean O'Callaghan, tells the story of the Irishmen who collaborated with Germany against England and Eire and the manhunt after the Irish police got "the scent."
Forty ground-service employes of Linea Aeropostal Venezolana, the Venezuelan Government airline, went on strike yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
The new 38,000-ton Netherlands liner Rotterdam will offer trans-Atlantic passengers two innovations when it enters service in September.

John D. Rockefeller 3d, Henry C. Alexander, chairman of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and W. Alton Jones, chairman of Cities Service Company, were elected yesterday to four-year terms as vice presidents of the New York Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of the Johns Hopkins University, today called human health "an especially fruitful field for international cooperation with almost the certainty of success."

After serving nearly seven months on the Supreme Court as a recess appointee, Justice Potter Stewart has been confirmed by the Senate. The overwhelming vote, 70 to 17, was gratifying recognition of Justice Stewart's outstanding personal qualities and professional record. But the confirmation process in his case also had some less gratifying aspects.
Homeowners reported widespread infestation of trees by tent caterpillars in the metropolitan area yesterday. As usual, that meant it was too late to do much about it.
Following is the text of .the broadcast by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter from Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
PARAMUS, N. J., May 7 -- Gimbels and Macy's signed a pact in New York today that will carry their rivalry to New Jersey.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7 -- The voluntary commitments made toward reduction of production and exports of lead and zinc, announced yesterday at the close of the conference on those metals, are recognized here as informal gentlemen's agreements.
HARTFORD, May 7 -- Connecticut's historic form of county government was ordered abolished tonight by the General Assembly.

The World Rehabilitation Fund, Inc., announced the establishment of the Smith Kline French Fellowship in Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation yesterday. The fellowship will enable a Mexican physician to take post-graduate training in the United States.
The news that Ambassador John Moors Cabot is to be transferred from Bogota to Rio de Janeiro strikes a happy note -- presuming that a replacement of equal excellence is found for Colombia.
LONDON, May 7 -- A book described as a member's-eye-view of factional strife and personal feuds within the Labor party will appear on British bookstands tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, May 7 -- Cuba withdrew today Premier Fidel Castro's proposal for a $30,000,000,000 Latin-American development fund. The withdrawal was a victory for the United States at the inter-American economic meeting here.

Unaudited consolidated net income of the Phelps Dodge Corporation rose sharply to $13,106,370, equal to $1.29 a common share, before deduction for depletion of mines, in the first quarter this year from $6,833,044, or 67 cents a share, for the like period last year, the big copper producer estimated yesterday.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 7 (AP) -- Young Tommy Jacobs shot two eagles and four birdies and took the first-round lead today in the $25,000 Oklahoma City open tournament. He carded a six-under-par 66.

The State Commission Against Discrimination reported yesterday that its investigation into the State Labor. Department's Division of Employment had "largely substantiated" allegations of discrimination.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Defense Department, in touch with General Eddleman, tonight issued his explanation of suggestions made earlier in Bonn.
Market values on the New York Stock Exchange dropped about $3,500,000,000 yesterday as investors took profits in the most spectacular speculative favorites of recent sessions.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The nation's department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 8 per cent above the level of a year ago.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 7 -- The Greek and Turkish Premiers exchanged pledges here today to lead their neighboring countries to "new horizons" of productive cooperation.
CHICAGO, May 7 (UPI) -- With a few words, Joseph A. Poskonka today ended fifteen years of masquerade as a Communist.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Atomic Energy Commission's principal advisory committee presented a reassuring picture today of the dangers of atomic fall-out. It commended the commission's handling of the radiation problem.
LOS ANGELES, May 7 -- This extraordinary metropolis, which specializes in doing everything on the grand scale, rocketed baseball to a new and almost fantastic high tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon told the President's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped today that it represented an American ideal more valuable than weapons in winning the "cold war."
Who lost money when stock values dropped more than $3,500,000,000 yesterday? No one really knows.

Former President Harry S. Truman, still vigorously active and a peppery figure on the political scene, celebrates his seventy-fifth birthday today. Fifty thousand guests are expected to attend birthday dinners in his honor across the country.
ANY woman planning a trip to Asia is likely to get more advice on what to pack than if she were en route to the South Pole.

JELLICO, Tenn., May 7 (UPI) -- Dynamite blasts destroyed two coal tipples and shattered windows and store fronts along the main street of this little mining town today in apparent extension of recent coal-field violence.
Union printers on three New York newspapers have adopted resolutions urging rejection of the latest proposal by the publishers for a new contract.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 7 -- Three gardens in the Wheatley Hills section of the North Shore of Long Island and the formal garden on the campus of C. W. Post College, known as the President's Garden, will be open to the public on May 21 for a benefit pilgrimage for the scholarship fund of the college.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., May 7 -- The animal trail was opened here today with nearly every animal to be found in Bear Mountain - Harriman State Park represented.
The harvest of a discriminating art collector, the late Mrs. Byron C. Foy, will be on public exhibition beginning tomorrow before being auctioned next week.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Tariff Commissioner William E. Dowling indicated today that the Singer Manufacturing Company might have weakened its rights to seek protection from sewing machine imports by licensing Sears, Roebuck Co. to import foreign machines under Singer patent specifications.
Leaders of New York's organized labor movement yesterday feted Dr. Jose Figueres, former President of Costa Rica, who has been visiting this country on a lecture tour.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to approve a compact setting up the New York-New Jersey transportation agency.

SAN FRANCISCO, May. 7 (AP) -- A substitute first baseman, Norm Larker, belted a two-run homer in the fourth inning today, enabling Stan Williams and the Los Angeles Dodgers to post a 2-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
The Bolshoi Ballet will open its regular working rehearsal at the Metropolitan Opera House today to New York's professional dance world. Admission will be by ticket only.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Treasury tonight set a 4 per cent coupon with a discount of 0.05 on its exchange offering of $1,800,000,000 of certificates for an issue maturing May 15.

MONROE, N. C., May 7 (AP) -- The head of the Union County branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People challenged today the right of the national organization to suspend him for having urged Negroes "to meet violence with violence."
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Rocky Colavito drove in all of Cleveland Indians' runs and Cal McLish went the distance on the mound tonight in defeating the Chicago White Sox, 3 -- 1.

LOS ANGELES, May 8 -- Regardless of how the sophisticated East may feel it was apparent today that baseball received several revitalizing shots from the extravaganza that this sprawling metropolis staged last night honoring Roy Campanella.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 8 (AP) -- Four white men charged with raping a Negro college girl pleaded not guilty at their arraignment today.

A two-story industrial building with a one-story rear extension at 840 Barry Street, near Longwood Avenue, in the Hunts Point area of the Bronx, was leased to the C-Mor Company, manufacturer of venetian blinds and folding doors.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 8 -- Art Silvestrone, a 27-year-old public links golfer, whisked around the Seawane Harbor Club course in a two-under-par 70 today to head the qualifiers in the William D. Richardson Memorial tourney.
Frederic R. Coudert Jr. announced yesterday that he had submitted his resignation as Republican leader of the Ninth Assembly District on Manhattan's East Side.
Helen Hayes, whose dramatic artistry over the years has won for her the title of First Lady of the American Theatre, may appear on Broadway next season in a musical.

All six hospitals involved in yesterday's strike had operating losses in 1958, according to the following table issued by the United Hospital Fund. The total of patients includes those admitted to the hospital and treated in clinics or on an emergency basis.

Encouraged by the ease with which the heavy selling on Thursday had been absorbed, the stock market rallied vigorously yesterday and won back between a half and two-thirds of the losses of the preceding day.
CHICAGO, May 8 -- Mr. Kern said in an interview following the adjournment that he intended to file a libel suit against the directors.
Two major hospitals have had strikes here in the last twenty-two years. The most spectacular was an eighthour sit-down strike by 132 employes of the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn on March 15, 1937.
Keyed to the theme of "Power for Peace," Armed Forces Week will be celebrated here and throughout the country beginning today.
A brawl outside an East Side restaurant early yesterday cost the life of David Burke, a national sales account manager for an appliance company.

GENEVA, May 8 -- Another round of tariff-cutting negotiations is expected to be scheduled by the member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) during their fourteenth session starting here Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The shift of a television channel from Springfield, Ill., to St. Louis was set aside by the Court of Appeals here today because of "private approaches" to members of the Federal Communications Commission.
A united Protestant evangelistic rally will be held for three nights, beginning Wednesday, at St. Nicholas Arena, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street.
LIKE the measles, fads in the New York area break out in an epidemic. Three are now enjoying a fever of popularity.
Two men, so similar in appearance that a detective said "they could be twins," have provided Queens authorities with their second "wrong man" case in six years.

BONN, Germany, May 8 -- Germany is coming to the end of one era and the beginning of another as the great East-West negotiation approaches, a negotiation whose first phase is the Geneva ministerial meeting but whose ultimate form and duration cannot be predicted.
A stock boy who began in the Lynchburg, Va., store of the S. S. Kresge Company became president yesterday of the retail variety chain with annual sales of $385,000,000.

CAIRO, May 8 -- Panic-stricken passengers of a leaking pleasure steamer scrambled to one side of the vessel as it neared shore today, causing the ship to keel over within feet of the bank. Officials estimated that as many as 200 persons were drowned.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- The Secretary of the Navy assailed tonight what he called the policy of concentrating on a strategic nuclear weapons build-up at the expense of the nation's capacity to deal with limited wars.
Vertex, a horse of distinction among the Eastern handicap acers, picks up top weight of 130 pounds for today's $85,750 Grey Lag Handicap, the closing feature of Jamaica's forty-day meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Western Allies will warn the Soviet delegation at Geneva next week that any pressure to force them from Berlin would lead to collapse of the East-West foreign ministers' talks and prevent a summit meeting.

General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries have reported that first-quarter kilowatt-hour sales of electricity by the domestic subsidiaries ran 9.5 per cent higher than a year ago and revenues increased by 7.5 per cent.
THE most valuable collection of furnishings to be offered at auction in this country will go on public view today at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

The new 4 1/4 per cent convertible debentures of the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company, due in fifteen years, rose to a premium yesterday following the offering to stockholders of the $19,925,500 issue at par.
A lost miniature brown dachshund, valued at more than $1,000,000 by 5-year-old twin girls, was returned yesterday, bringing smiles to the saddened mistresses.
The California Packing Corporation announced yesterday a two-for-one stock split, plans to raise the quarterly dividend and sharply higher sales and earnings for its fiscal year ended with February.
LONDON, May 8 -- Iraq has asked Britain for enough arms to re-equip virtually her whole army, according to authoritative information made known today. The arms would be purchased over three years.
Commodity prices moved generally higher yesterday in dull trading. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee ordered today a 41 per cent slash in President Eisenhower's civil defense budget. It refused to put up any funds for creation of 4,000 civil defense jobs at City Halls throughout the country.

GENEVA, May 8 -- The United States announced today that it was ready to examine carefully a Soviet proposal for a fixed number of on-site inspections where it was suspected that nuclear weapons had been tested.

The Yankees returned to New York by jet plane yesterday following their exhibition victory over the Dodgers at Los Angeles Thursday night. The flight from Los Angeles to New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, took 4 hours 15 minutes.

A syndicate represented by Maurlce Epstein has bought the apartment house at 327 East Forty-ninth Street through Stanley Russell Associates, broker. The group already owned the property at 329-35 East Forty-ninth Street and now controls a plot 100 by 100 feet. The plot will be held for investment.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today reported the 1958 cotton crop totaled 11,512,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each, and had a farm value of $1,907,000,000.
HARTFORD, May 8 (AP) -- Six teen-agers were picked today as the top prizewinners of the National Science Fair.
A modest hero was the talk of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn last night.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Government for the second time rejected all bids today for the purchase of Ellis Island in New York harbor.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- An inventor of furnaces and airconditioning systems received a patent this week for equipment to heat or cool an individual. The equipment circulates water of an agreeable temperature through a pad that the user can sit on, or lie on or under.
TRENTON, May 8 -- A proposed state program of college scholarships was defended and criticized today at a public hearing presided over by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.
YONKERS, May 8 -- R. G. Yeager's Easy Adios scored his first victory of the season in 2:03 2/5 with Stanley Dancer at the reins in the Glendale Pace before 32,344 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

The counsel for the eight-paper Macy newspaper chain in Westchester County challenged yesterday the jurisdiction of the special state committee investigating alleged strikebreaking in the newspaper industry.
LANSING, Mich., May 8 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams urged Republicans and Democrats today to put down "the clubs and hatchets" and attempt immediately solve the state's fiscal crisis.

Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge of Greyston, Riverdale, the Bronx, gave a garden party last night at her residence to begin the Centennial fund drive for Wells College in Aurora, N. Y. The college was founded in 1868.
BUENOS AIRES, May 8 -- A meeting of American Presidents as the crowning ceremony of the eleventh Inter-American Conference in Quito next year was proposed today by Ecuador.

ALBANY, May 8 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 418 persons who passed the examination for admission to the New York State Bar held last March 12 and 13. A total of 882 applicants took the test.

Birthday candles burned brightly across the nation last night as Democrats honored Harry S. Truman on his seventy-fifth birthday. At sixty-six parties in cities from coast to coast, the former President was hailed as a great leader of his party and a distinguished President.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Partisan politics has produced a major crisis in the infant "bipartisan'' organization of Senators and Representatives from New York State.
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets by the Department of Agriculture follows:
New York's third annual United States World Trade Fair opened at the Coliseum yesterday with a display of international amity as well as of products from sixtythree nations.
BUFFALO, May 8 (AP) -The Niagara Frontier Port Authority purchased the Ford Motor Company's waterfront assembly plant for $1,950,000 today.
The volume of new capital issues, and of stocks in particular, scheduled for offering next week is somewhat greater than it has been for several weeks.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A new bill to revise habeas corpus procedures in the Federal courts won support today from the Justice Department and other sources.

An investigation of "persons, places and things" and embracing this state, Massachusetts and New Hampshire is being continued by the New York State Harness Racing Commission. This was divulged yesterday by Deputy Commissioner Michael Monz during a recess of Frank Safford's appeal for reinstatement as a sulky driver.
MOAB, Utah, May 8 (AP) -- Most of the major concerns suporting the Uranium Institute of America withdrew their memberships yesterday after a reorganization attempt failed.
Sir Winston Churchill flew to New York from Washington yesterday to close a private visit to the United States with a quiet week-end at the home of an old friend, Bernard M. Baruch.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- President Eisenhower eased Government secrecy regulations a little today.
LONDON, May 8 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran denied today that a revolt against his regime was possible.
The Rheem Manufacturing Company has arranged to sell its facilities at Downey and Riverside, Calif., to the Aerojet-General Corporation, A. Lightfoot Walker, president of Rheem, announced yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 8 -- Greek and Turkish leaders are confident that their talks in progress here will speed the transfer of Cyprus from British control to independent status.

PITTSBURGH, May 8 (AP) -- A South Carolina white man who lost his life in a vain attempt to save an 11-year-old Negro schoolboy from drowning was one of twenty-three persons cited for heroism today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.
CORINNE, Utah, May 8 -- "The last rail is laid -- the last spike is driven -- the Pacific Railroad is finished."
At 7:20 o'clock yesterday morning, former President Harry S. Truman blew out twenty-five candles on a store-bought birthday cake.
A PERTINENT, timely and strongly editorial briefing on Berlin's role in current history scored two impressive points in addition to its message on Channel 4 last night.

NEW DELHI, India, May 8 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru cautioned Communist China today against trying to intimidate India through "warlike speeches." He said it would be a mistake for Peiping to interpret New Delhi's restraint over the Tibet issue as a sign of weakness.
The Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation showed substantially higher sales and earnings in the March quarter of this year than in the three months of 1958, the report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Following is the text of a United States note to the Soviet Government, as made public today, denying that the United States is jeopardizing the forthcoming foreign ministers' meeting:

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Senator Lister Hill predicted today that Congress this session would set up a national institute for international medical research and provide it an initial appropriation of $50,000,000.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 8 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Globe-Democrat and the St. Louis Newspaper Guild reached "tentative agreement" today on issues that have kept 322 guild members on strike since Feb. 21.

Three American Cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church, in a solemn ceremony yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, formally welcomed to this country Archbishop Egidio Vagnozzi, newly appointed Apostolic Delegate to the United States.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 8 -- Sixty scientific workers are virtual prisoners inside the sprawling E. R. Squibb Sons plant in near-by North Brunswick, which has been closed by a strike for three days.
Union and management negotiators reached agreement last night on terms to end the three-week strike of 3,000 United Parcel Service employes.

Joan Lauro, soprano, shared her debut recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall with Mario Viggiano, tenor. Frank Baselice was the piano accompanist in a program largely devoted to Italian songs, arias and duets by Pergolesi, Mozart, Bellini, Donizetti, Verdi, Tosti and Cilea.
The first round of contract negotiations in the steel industry ended yesterday with union and management leaders bickering over whether stockholders were poorer than steel workers.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 (UPI) -- Mayor George Christopher also said today he would seek a Carnegie medal for Miss O'Neill. The medal is civilian equivalent of the Medal of Honor.

Prices of United States Government securities generally lost ground yesterday. The declines followed the squeeze experienced by the Treasury on Thursday in executing the second phase of its $5,300,000,000 financing.

Thirty-five motion picture short subjects have been chosen to represent the United States at the international film festivals to be held in Venice, Italy, starting July 2, and Edinburgh, Scotland, beginning Aug. 23.
ART, one of the most potent French exports, finds its rightful place in the World Trade Fair now at the Coliseum.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney called upon all Americans today to make sure they had a smallpox vaccination.

Organized labor in New York has endorsed a standard of giving for the 1959 campaign of the Greater New York Fund. Union leaders observe that employes each year are served by the Fund's 425 participating hospitals and health and welfare agencies.

In 1958 the United States lost $2,300 million in gold to the rest of the world, the biggest net total in a single calendar year to date. The monthly decline in gold stocks gradually declined, however, in the late months of the year, and as 1959 opened opinion among Government officials as a whole tended to agree that the movement would be reversed.

If a visitor were to walk into an adult education class of amateur artists he would find a varied group of people. Here intellectual caste has no standing. For a few happy hours a business man, a scientist, a clerical worker, a housewife, a mathematician, are brought together by a common interest and have found a haven from the mounting pressures of the day through the medium of art.

The Habsburg heirloom reported missing early. Thursday by Archduchess Marie of Austria has been found. The police reported yesterday that Baron Theo von Roth, who arranged the Archduchess' visit to this country, had notified them of the brooch's recovery.

Leaders in social work here will portray great persons in the history of that field in a pageant entitled "From Jane Addams to the Present Day." It will be given in the Bowman Room of the Biltmore next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The British have posed a new and tougher "buy-American" test in the recurrent issue on purchases by Government agencies of heavy electric power equipment.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8 -- The concern of American industry about foreign sales and foreign competition was reflected here today in an unusual meeting of the nation's business leaders.

The one-story taxpayer on a lot 24 by 54 feet at 6 and 8 Main Street, Hempstead, L. I., has been sold by Frederick Brown to an investing client of Irving L. Gartenberg, lawyer. It is occupied under lease by Father and Son Shoe Stores, Inc., a subsidiary of Endicott Johnson Co. The Kersey Company was the broker.

Van Norman Industries, Inc., which last month gained working control of the American Pulley Company, has offered to purchase from shareholders an additional 16,000 shares, or 16 per cent of the outstanding Pulley stock.

Events today: Deanne Garcy, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 3; Music Education League, annual concerts for auditions winners, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30 and 8:15; Morning Freiheit Concert, Carnegie Hall, 8:15; Glee Club of Fordham University, Town Hall, 8:30.

An unscheduled appearance by the Bolshoi Ballet took place yesterday at noon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The company and its American impresario, S. Hurok, were hosts to a houseful of dancers, teachers and students from various schools, companies and musical shows at what was called a regular working rehearsal.
The Brookings Institution has published a new and up-to-date study of the now-chronic railroad problem, written by James C. Nelson, long one of our leading students of the subject.
VIENNA, May 8 -- As Austria's National Assembly comes to the end of its mandate -- it is to be replaced in Sunday's general election -- a little-known aspect of its personality has come to light.
WHITE PLAINS, May 8 -- The White Plains Community Church, Unitarian, will dedicate its new $400,000 church and Sunday school building at Rosedale Avenue and Sycamore Lane tomorrow.
Four unions are involved in trying to organize nonprofessional employes in metropolitan New York's eighty-one voluntary hospitals and its proprietary hospitals.

NEW YORK as George Washington knew it was a very tidy town. Or at least that is the way it appears in an exceptionally interesting exhibition of American prints at the Kennedy Galleries, 785 Fifth Avenue.
LOS ANGELES, May 8 -Wilmington Local 13 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union today widened its breach with Harry Bridges, its international president.

Nurses' aides, orderlies, porters, elevator operators, kitchen workers and other "housekeeping'' employes went on strike at six private hospitals yesterday. However, the walkout caused no immediate distress to 2,700 patients.
HAVANA, May 8 -- Thousands of Cubans at the airport here today welcomed Premier Fidel Castro back from a twenty-three-day trip abroad.
LONDON, May 8 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said today that the results of the local elections in England and Wales yesterday were "very encouraging."
RABAT, Morocco, May 8 -- The prospect of a meeting between King Mohamed V of Morocco and President Charles de Gaulle of France to seek a way of ending the Algerian war is fading fast.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Pilots of small United States planes returning from Canadian and Mexican points on Sundays and holidays are protesting charges they must pay customs and immigration inspectors for overtime work.
The thirty-fifth anniversary dinner of the Blue Hill Troupe, amateur performers of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, took place last night in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East.
An hour-long study of lonely hearts clubs and marriage agencies will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on Thursday, June 4.

ROME, May 8 (AP) -- United States horsemen scored a surprising and spectacular victory in the Grand Prix of Nations event in the Rome horse show tonight. Three American riders went over the hurdles in faultless style in a jump-off after having deadlocked with Italy in the regular competition.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A spokesman for the nation's automobile dealers testified today that his organization was vigorously opposed to proposed changes in the minimum wage law.

TRENTON, May 8 -- For the first time in twenty-five years the Republican party in New Jersey is widely split on taxes. This breach, it became apparent tonight, is certain to produce a sharp clash between the opposing factions when the party's annual state convention reconvenes here on Thursday to adopt a Republican platform for 1959.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Donald A. Quarles, deputy secretary of defense, died in his sleep today. He was 64 years old.
A tentative agreement on a new two-year contract was reached yesterday afternoon by the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York and Local 335, United Marine Division of the National Maritime Union.

MONTREAL, May 8 (AP) -Tom Johnson of the Montreal Canadiens broke Doug Harvey's four-year stranglehold today by winning the James Norris Memorial Trophy as the National Hockey League's outstanding defenseman.

The faculty of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism announced yesterday the establishment of a Meyer Berger Memorial Award. It will be given to a New York reporter who has less than five years' experience.
Francis G. Barrett, president of New York Typographical Union 6 (Big Six), said last night he did not think there would be a printers' strike.

WASHINGTON, May (8) (AP) -- The Senate rackets committee said tonight that a lie dector test had cleared Joseph P. McCollum, Texas labor leader, of the allegation that he had sought to raise money to have a union member killed.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 (UPI) -- Daryl Spencer collected four hits in four at bats tonight and drove in three runs in leading the San Francisco Giants to a 9-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. The winners moved to within a half-game of Milwaukee, the National League leaders.

The Illinois Athletic Commission notified Ray Robinson by telegram yesterday it would be willing to break with the National Boxing Association and recognize a Robinson-Carmen Basilio bout as a middleweight championship fight.

I was astonished to read in your editorial of May 3 "Union in West Africa" that colonialism "has already gone" merely because Ghana and Guinea have won their independence. The logic of this conclusion is obscure, for the facts do not bear it out.

A dispatch from Beirut published in your paper on April 22 carried an interview with Dr. Charles McKinley, an American professor recently expelled from Iraq. Dr. McKinley made many unfounded statements concerning the University of Baghdad.
WOULD you be so kind as to give a recipe for a macaroni salad like the ones that are sold in delicatessens?" Mrs. J. B. Keene, Saratoga Springs, N. Y.
The salesman who goes calling on one of the country's biggest buyers is in for a pleasant surprise.
The oil scout, a euphemism for the adventurer hired by oil companies to spy on the prospecting activities of their competitors, is going modern.
LONDON, May 8 (UPI) -A dream came true today for 11-year-old Veronica Martineau of Methuen, Mass. She saw the Queen.

The writer of a letter printed in The Times of April 25 assumed "that the only reason Herbert Lehman, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt and Thomas K. Finletter formed a separate committee was solely because the old-line, politicians who have been in power for over twenty years did not want them to have a voice in party affairs."
WARSAW, May 2 -- A heroine in Poland is Ewa W., a woman from Katowice who does not like to be pushed around.
The ten-day strike that has paralyzed the Krug Baking Company of Jamaica, Queens, was conditionally settled last night.

The United Nations' twenty countries' committee studying problems of the lead and zinc industries has received the enthusiastic support of another major producer in the drive for voluntary reduction of world supplies of those metals.
Hospital and union representatives disagreed as to whether yesterday's walkout was legal, in view of court orders to stop or postpone it.

Following is the text of Dean Acheson's talk from Washington to the Truman celebration here last night. Mr. Acheson's opening remarks were in answer to this question by Melvyn Douglas: "What was President Truman like to work for when the going was rough?"
MOSCOW, May 8 -- The Soviet Union has changed mightily in the last five years, but its press has changed comparatively little. It does not mirror the color, spirit and pace of the new Russia.

A 59-year-old ex-convict, who was described by Government authorities as a wealthy business man in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, was held in $75,000 bail yesterday on a charge of selling 102 ounces of heroin to Treasury agents.
With only one more match to be played, two close contests developed in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's inter-club team matches yesterday.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 8 -The weather was clear and the track moderately fast here today for enthusiastic improvers of the prospects of automobile salesmen.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 8 -- The three-day Amateur Trapshooting Championships of America started at Travers Island today and when the firing was over more than fifty had tried out their "shooting eyes," some 9,000 clay targets had been shattered and 34-year-old Ken Hard of Brookhaven, L. I., had toted off a handsome silver trophy.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 8. -- Herbert J. Cummings, director of the United States Trade Mission to Nigeria, announced yesterday that his mission would help Nigerian business men to get in touch with American concerns interested in establishing trade ties with Nigeria.
The once-luxurious apartment house at 380 Riverside Drive that is now crowded with single-room families was in the courts again yesterday.

Half of the nation's railroad freight may one day move in loaded highway trailers and containers "piggy-back" on railroad flat cars, according to the railroads' No. 1 spokesman, Daniel P. Loomis, president of the Association of American Railroads.

TOKYO, May 8 -- The Government decided today on an extraordinarily firm rebuff to Soviet demands that Japan bar nuclear arms from the country, banish United States military bases here and adopt a policy of neutrality.

PITTSBURGH, May 8 (UPI) -- Gene Conley, making his first start of the season, doled out six hits as the Philadelphia Phils gained an 8-1 victory over the Pittsburg Pirates tonight. But Conley had to leave the game when he was hit by a batted ball in the ninth inning.

" I WON the Nobel Prize for Literature. What was your crime?" That is the caption on a cartoon by Bill Mauldin that won this year's Pulitzer Prize. It showed two men at work under guard in what may just have been one of the Soviet Union's harsher landscapes. If it had appeared a little sooner it might have been included in Gerd Ruge's new book, "Pasternak -- A Pictorial Biography."
SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -- A college co-ed risked her life yesterday trying to save a youth attacked by a 500-pound killer shark just outside the Golden Gate.

The broadcast speech that Secretary Herter made on Thursday evening to the American people was an admirable foreword to the Geneva conference. Mr. Herter left yesterday for the foreign ministers' meeting on Germany and European security.
NORFOLK, Va., May 8 -- Federal Judge Walter E. Hoffman upheld today the validity of the Norfolk School Board's Pupil Assignment Plan.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.2 per cent to 119.6 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

A biography of Sir Alexander Fleming, discoverer of penicilin and winner of a Nobel Prize, has been written by Andre Maurois. It will be published May 28 by Dutton and will be called "The Life of Sir Alexander Fleming."

About two years ago a wonderfully preserved Greek manuscript on papyrus was reported seen in Alexandria, Egypt. It was the first virtually complete play to be discovered from the prolific works of Menander, star writer of the New Comedy of the Greece of 2,200 years ago.
State Industrial Commissioner Martin P. Catherwood denounced yesterday the "laxity" of personnel in the Labor Department's employment division regarding the state law prohibiting discrimination.

Your editorial of April 28 on the impending inquiry by the state study commission into the management of the city government validly emphasizes the urgency of the need for thorough examination of the city's fiscal problem. Your reference to Councilman Isaacs' proposal that the examination delve into the 1959-1960 budget, now in process of adoption, is also to the point.
Pickets marched yesterday at the six struck hospitals, displaying signs that protested low wages and the refusal of the hospitals to recognize their union.
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- From its high of the season only five weeks ago, May wheat today hit a new low for a season on the Board of Trade. A decline of almost 24 cents a bushel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8 -- Twelve women in black began a vigil and fast outside the United Nations this morning.

The strike against six voluntary hospitals in New York City should never have occurred, must not occur again and must be promptly ended. The union's contemptuous disregard of court orders has made an already ugly situation worse. Whatever public sympathy the union may have developed has now been largely wiped out.
LONDON, May 8 -- Industrial shares turned downward in the stock market today.

CHICAGO, May 8 (UPI) -- Bill Veeck today was elected president of the Chicago White Sox. The board of directors filled the job for the first time since the death of Mrs. Grace Comiskey in December, 1956.

Any designer might covet the windows of Bergdorf Goodman as a showcase. The man who "made it" this week is a fashion designer, but his clothes are not shown. However, the seventeen vivid impressionist paintings behind the clothes are his.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Dr. Willard F. Libby, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, suggested to Congress today that a "promising" technique for reducing atomic fall-out would be to test nuclear weapons in outer space.

BONN, Germany, May 8 -Secretary of State Christian A. Herter will be received here tomorrow by a Government that has come to feel much better in the last twenty-four hours about the change in the management of United States foreign policy.
Patients were admitted, operations performed and babies born about as usual yesterday at the six struck hospitals. Medical services were performed without disruption.
NEWARK, May 8 -- New Jersey's ban on Sunday sales in some stores was declared unconstitutional today.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A staff attorney of the Senate Commerce Committee was disclosed today to have helped prepare testimony opposing Lewis L. Strauss' confirmation as Secretary of Commerce.

SYRACUSE, May 8 (UPI) -Rudell Stitch outpointed Gaspar Ortega of Mexico tonight in a ten-round welterweight bout that was as one-sided as their first encounter was close. The Mexican gained a one-point decision over Stitch in New York last Feb. 6.
From Cape Lisburne to the Pribilof Islands an unusual military organization, composed chiefly of Eskimos, guards the coastline of Alaska -- the closest American territory to the Soviet Union.
Salary increases for the more than 2,200 faculty members of the municipal college system were discussed at two meetings yesterday, but no decision was announced.
ALGIERS, May 8 -- Many Frenchmen in Algeria found it difficult today to understand the optimism expressed by President Charles de Gaulle yesterday about an early peace in Algeria.
The backlog of unmarketed new issues of local government bonds stands to be swelled by $220,000,000 as the result of financing decisions just made by Pennsylvania and California.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A Senate staff study has credited Soviet missile experts with testing a manned rocket bomber planned for a range of 12,000 miles at altitudes up to 100 miles.

SANBORNTON, N. H., May 8 -- A few hundred feet upstream from the mouth of Black Brook here are four concrete raceways that help the State of New Hampshire maintain landlocked salmon and lake trout populations in fifteen or twenty lakes.
LIKE many business men, Chief Walking Turtle was disturbed by the knowledge that he was not spending enough time with his son.

MOST union presidents achieve prestige by displays of energy and oratory. Leon Julius Davis, president of Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union, has never been so much in the public mind as he has been since his disappearance from public sight. Mr. Davis van ished and his oratory in behalf of 35,000 nonprofessional workers in eighty-one voluntary hospitals has been stilled since Wednesday.

THROUGH last night's dance program at the Juilliard School of Music hovered the spirit of Doris Humphrey, the dancer-choreographer who died last Dec. 29 at the age of 63. The concerts -- there will be additional ones tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday -- are being presented as a memorial, and proceeds will go to the Doris Humphrey Scholarship Fund of the Juilliard School of Music.

The Commissioner of Real Estate makes clear in a report to Mayor Wagner that the city has learned at least some of the bitter lessons furnished by the scandals that shook the old Bureau of Real Estate beginning in March, 1958. J. Clarence Davies Jr. became head of the bureau on Aug. 1, 1958, and on May 1 of this year the bureau became a department.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- Former Gov. W. Averell Harriman of New York accused the Eisenhower Administration today of a "lack of leadership" in drumming up public support for the foreign aid program.

FOUR children sprawled about the living room In postures only children can assume. Outside the rain swirled round in sheets, but they, Lost in their books, had traveled far away. Susan beside a crystal pool at dawn Was watching through the ferns a milkwhite fawn. A lovely creature poised upon the bank, It looked around then bowed its head and drank.

THE filming of the Joseph Fields-Jerome Chodorov stage play "Anniversary Waltz" here in Manhattan provides still another measure of the new and expanded freedom being enjoyed by the motion-picture medium today.
TRENTON, May 9 -- A record number of pleasure boats are likely to cruise New Jersey waters this summer.

THE best way to travel through a country in Europe is to rent a house. It may sound impossible, but it works. In our case, we had to be in Brussels, but also to make trips to Amsterdam, London, Antwerp, Salzburg, Bayreuth and Paris over a period of three months. Which would be preferable, renting a house or staying at a hotel?

ONCE the gardener has seen fragile native orchids in the woodlands, he may want to try growing some of the species at home. Most of these lovely wildlings are safely transplanted shortly after flowering.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The now perennial drive for legislation to undo Supreme Court decisions in the internal security area has began in the Eighty-sixth Congress with intensive House and Senate committee hearings over the last few weeks.
Hal Griggs, a 30-year-old native of Hickory, N. C., yielded only two hits to the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium as the Senators scored a 7-0 victory.

MANCHESTER, Vt., May 9 -The State Department hereby is advised that it may adopt an even firmer position at the foreign ministers' meeting: The junior fishermen around here have shown that we are in a stronger position than anybody thought.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Senator John L. McClellan called today for antitrust legislation to deal with labor racketeering in the transportation field.

A SET of eight wood boring drill bits which comes packaged in a plastic case will bore holes from 1/4 inch to 1 1/4 inches in size. Made of hardened tool steel, the eight bits come with a single universal shank which will hold each one.

Steel production has been pacing Cleveland's business recovery for several months and now automobile sales are regaining pre-recession levels. Vigorous end-of-the-month activity pushed new car sales up to 2,188 units in the week ended May 2.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 9 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority reported this week that sales of its electricity were 425 per cent greater in 1958 than in 1946.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -The new Pennsylvania Boulevard Bridge over the Schuylkill will be opened to traffic in June, more than two months ahead of schedule.

"To this place, and the kindness of these people, I owe every thing. Here I have lived a quarter of a century, and have passed from a young to an old man. Here my children have been born, and one is buried.

READERS who became acquainted only recently with Mary Renault through her magnificent historical novel, "The King Must Die," may be surprised to learn that she has seven earlier works of fiction to her credit. Since the Thirties, she has had a large English audience for what might be called "psychological romances" placed in contemporary settings.
New measures to strengthen Soviet-Iraqi ties in the medical scientific and cultural fields have been revealed by the Baghdad radio.
NEW YORK STATE'S "Year of History," now being celebrated, actually leaps into the present and offers at least one glimpse of the future, as well as the storied past.

BOSTON -- In an era when science is blazing new paths for tourism in outer space, New England's contrast as a vacation land whose greatest attraction is the relaxing atmosphere of its bucolic bypaths seems even more marked.

REALIZING that folk tales always have a special kind of allure and that cats do, too, Natalia Belting has compiled a book of sixteen cat folk tales that are as varied as the thirteen countries from which the stories originated.
One can only and sadly concur with Mr. Schneider that the Americanization of Paris est arrive: But is it a jour de gloire?
NEW DELHI, India, May 9 -- Across the sweep of India, waiting anxiously for the monsoon rains to save the parched fields from ruin, men squat in the dust and join in this summer's great debate.

LOS ANGELES -- Southern California is famous in song and postcard for some of the nation's most beautiful beaches. A million or more summer visitors will be welcome to view them. But they should be prepared for frequent encounters with both barbed wire and bureaucracy when it comes to using them.

At 3 P. M. tomorrow in the sprawling Palais des Nations in Geneva, the Big Four Foreign Ministers will begin the first round of fateful negotiations on the future of Germany and Europe. This was the mood of the two sides on the eve of the talks, as cabled by correspondents of The New York Times from Geneva:

A year ago last week the Presbytery of New York dissolved the old Labor Temple and turned over the large Fourteenth Street building to the New York City Mission Society for a social gospel ministry to the lower East Side.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., May 9 -- Nine Morris County homes -- ranging from a pre-Revolutionary saltbox to a remodeled garage -- will be opened for a benefit tour on May 19.

ON Jan. 30 of this year there died in a small country cottage in England an elderly recluse who had written nothing for thirty years but whose handful of early books had assured her of a place in South African literature.

MADISON, Wis, May 9 (AP) -- A favored University of Wisconsin crew surged ahead in the final seconds and defeated Massachusetts Institute of Technology by a half-second in a quadrangular rowing regatta over wind-swept Lake Mendota today.
Mike Herman scored 29 points yesterday to pace New York University to a 96-44 track and field victory over Rutgers. The dual meet was the first one held on N. Y. IL's 'Ohio Field iin fourteen years.

THERE has probably never been a period in history when the air was so thick with different musical theories. Paul Fromm, who has extended help to composers of many different persuasions, has felt for a long time that the various theories should be jointly subjected to critical scrutiny by experts meeting together.
CHICAGO, May 9 -- The Chicago White Sox scored eight runs on only four hits in the second and third innings for a 9-5 victory over the first-place Cleveland Indians today.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower put the emphasis on golf and bridge today midway through a stag week-end of relaxation in the country.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, urged today that the State Department promise arms if necessary to protect Panama or any other friendly American nation from aggression.

ATLANTIC CITY -- A building boom seems to be sweeping the whole New Jersey shore. In the nearly three-score resorts that dot the coast from Sandy Hook down to the mouth of Delaware Bay, new motels are springing up everywhere.

The International Garden Club will conduct a "GardenGourmet-Gracious Living Tour" on Wednesday for the benefit of the maintenance fund of the Bartow Mansion Museum, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. The club has its headquarters in the museum.
CHICAGO, May 9 -- Life in the Antarctic can be just one long headache, but it isn't the cold, it's the humanity, according to a Navy psychiatrist.

BERLIN, May 9 -- Thousands of West Berliners gathered today in the center of the large traffic circle at the lower end of the Kurfuerstendamm, the city's main shopping boulevard, to watch Evangelical Bishop Otto Dibelius and Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia, grandson of the last Kaiser, lay the cornerstone for the new Evangelical Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church.

At the request of teachers in a suburban high school, Boston University has launched an experiment intended to keep them abreast of advances in knowledge. University officials think they have thereby fashioned a plan to answer one of the main criticisms of teacher training -- the isolation of the liberal arts from the education faculties.

As days lengthen into soft summery nights, the shirtwaist appears in a new guise -- that of a frothy evening confection. Sheer silk organza, light as a meringue glacee, is printed, dotted, checked and contrasted in colors that look good enough to eat. Interest rises with larger, more important collars and, occasionally, puffy sleeves.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 9 -- Warner Willcox, at the tiller of Stardust, won the second race of the International Class Stanley Trophy series today. A fleet of forty-three sailed in the Pre-Yacht Racing Association regatta staged by the Larchmont Yacht Club.
The Music Education League presented winners of its 1958 and 1959 auditions in two concerts yesterday at Carnegie Recital Hall.

A four-day, thirty-two-hour work week every fourth week is one of the pivotal demands the United Steelworkers of America intends to press in its streamlined contract negotiations with the steel industry, opening here tomorrow.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 9 -- The cold ocean breeze that blew over the Seawane Harbor Golf Club course failed to cool Arthur Silvestrone's game today. Silvestrone, who won the medal yesterday with a sub-par 70 in the William D. Richardson Memorial tourney, was sharper in winning two matches to gain the semi-final.

Legislation to halt the expansion of savings and loan holding companies seems likely to be revived in the present session of Congress.

Retail business continued to push ahead of a year ago by a wide margin and gains of 5 to 15 per cent were general. The movement of hardware, house-hold goods and major appliances has been characterized as "brisk."
Edward Stone was convicted last week of driving while intoxicated for the eighty-first time.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 9 -- The commuter crisis harassing New York and other sprawling metropolises has not reached Stockholm -- yet.
A volatile salesman-turned-cost-reduction-expert through necessity has nursed his faltering company to glowing financial health in less than two years.

THE second spring season of opera made in America, which ended at the City Center last Sunday, was not compounded of faith, hope and charity. It rested on solid achievement. Of the twelve works it brought forward not one was without a just claim to attention.

Writing in The New York Times Magazine seven years ago, Arnold Toynbee said, "The twentieth century will be chiefly remembered as an age in which human society dared to think of the welfare of the whole human race as a practicable objective."

CAIRO, May 9 (AP) -- Officials arrested the captain of the river boat Dandara today and charged him with negligence in the sinking of the boat in the Nile River yesterday with the loss of possibly 150 lives.

Three important findings on the role of hormones in the cause and control of disease were reported last week at the annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Investigation at Atlantic City, N. J., by Drs. Leon Hellman, H. L. Bradlow, Barnet Zumoff, David, Fukushima and T. F. Gallagher of the Sloan-Kettering Institute.
Harold A. Felix, the city's Commissioner of Labor, asserted yesterday that his department had established an enviable record of community service in its five years of existence.

Too few people recognize the dilemma facing the female in America today. The old saying that "woman's place is in the home" has been thrown out the window. With this concept of womanhood gone, we now have women confused as to what they should be.

ATTEMPTS to put scientists and writers into some sort of communication with one another have small success. They are separated by the abstruse specialization of the former and by the ignorance of the latter. Or, more accurately, there is a failure of two kinds of memory to meet: the mathematical and the allusive.

SOMEWHAT more than thirty years ago Avrahm Yarmolinsky published what was then the fullest and most authoritative life in English of Ivan Turgenev (1818-1883). Since that time, a good deal of biographical and even critical material has appeared, mostly, of course, in Russian.
ACCRA, Ghana, May 9 (Reuters) -- Ghana's drive to catch up with modern civilization brought heartbreak and tears today to the 12,000 inhabitants of a mud-walled shantytown near here.

Man's progress to date in penetrating space has well outstripped the development of international law to handle the problems and conflicts likely to arise from this breakthrough into a new area of human activity. So it is welcome that the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space has begun a discussion of the legal questions involved, a discussion which may eventually lead to an agreed code of space law.

WHAT makes a stereo or bad? In this relatively new extension of recording technique, it seems probable that sound engineers are constantly making hit-or-miss discoveries that are not in the book, and are carefully filed for future reference.

BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) -- One-Eyed King, carrying the top weight of 120 pounds, romped home in record-equaling time over a mile and three-eighths on the grass today in winning the $29,250 Dixie Handicap at Pimlico.

IN the spring young boys' fancies are apt to turn to thoughts of playing hooky, but few will ever do so with the success Mike and Cal Hunter enjoy. The two brothers, unhappy at their new school because unaccepted by the other students and upset when Mr. Hunter spanks Cal because of his low grades, decide to play hooky and hide out along the river bank every day.
A COUNTRY'S primary export is its knowledge. Books are primary vehicles of knowledge. That is why books are in the vanguard of the export trade of all the great exporting nations of the world.
