URBANA, Ill., May 2 -- A new managerial class has emerged from the American agricultural revolution: the professional farm managers.

ANTIAGO, Chile, May 9 -- United States Ambassadors serving in ten South American republics reported today that an "intensified-effort" was being made by international communism to undermine the unity of the Western Hemisphere.
WHEN "H. M. S. Pinafore" is presented this afternoon on "Omnibus" over the National Broadcasting Company television network, something new will be added.

IT is good to welcome Ruth Suckow back into the company of practicing American novelists. A quarter of a century has elapsed since she offered "The Folks" to a delighted and appreciative audience. In all that time illness had stilled her writing hand, and if, as I think, there has been inevitable attrition, "The John Wood Case" still is a novel of warmth, substance and considerable vigor.
Soil from five world battlefields will be scattered on the City College campus Saturday as part of the ceremonies dedicating a Remembrance Rock to the college's war dead.

The mail-order catalogue, a king-size paperback once designed only for country folk, has become an urban "best-seller." In fact, major mail-order companies say the city resident now ranks as their most important customer.
Although there is concern over the continued lag in United States exports, general sentiment among foreign traders remains optimistic about an eventual upturn.

THE twenty-eight tales in this collection fall into three categories: the creation myths telling how Japan came into being; the epic legend of the Heike, the traditional warriors of Japan whose exploits are still re-enacted in the Japanese theatre; and the folk and fairy tales of the common people.

THE fifth and sixth volumes in the series of Covenant Books for Jewish youngsters describe the lives and accomplishments of a man and a woman who are remembered not because they were adventurous but because they were scholarly and kind-hearted.

DOUGLAS, Alaska -- Jack London, Rex Beach and Robert Service immortalized the glamour and romance of the northland a number of years ago. However, it has only been in recent times that the tourist has discovered Alaska.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- A plan to put members of racial minority groups in touch with landlords willing to rent or sell homes to them in white neighborhoods was started here this week.
GENEVA, May 9 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, called today for liquidation of the Allied occupation of West Berlin at the foreign ministers' conference opening here Monday.

GROTON, Conn., May 9 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Frederick B. Warder, Atlantic Submarine Force Commander, presented letters of commendation today to two officers and six enlisted men who participated in the transpolar cruise of the submarine Nautilus.

The Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce recently issued a report of great import to every TV viewer in the United States. As far as I can learn, this report has been all but ignored by the metropolitan press.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A report issued today by the National Education Association urged the modernization of geography instruction and its restoration to this country's school system.

THE sun shone on the annual meeting of the American Daffodil Society held in Philadelphia last month. The show was held later than in previous years. As a result many midseason and late midseason varieties which had never been shown were displayed in almost perfect condition.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- The tour buses have already worked through deep snow to the top of Pike's Peak and motorists will be driving soon on the dramatic Trail Ridge Road which crosses Rocky Mountain National Park. But the main fact of life in the high country these days is that Coloradans are rediscovering their history.

TICONDEROGA -- The lustre of America's early history in the northeastern parts of New York State and adjacent Vermont begins to shine its brightest these days, and will continue glistening in pageants and commemorations as well as quite modern entertainments, for tourists to enjoy, all this summer.

THE original cast recordings from Broadway thus, far this season have provided lean fare for the home listener. It was a season when the musical theatre retreated to a level that seemed relatively routine after the stimulation of "West Side Story" the previous year or, before that, "The Music Man" and "My Fair Lady."

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 9 (UPI) -- A small group of pickets staged a protest today over the hanging of a portrait of former United States Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, at the Indiana University Law School.

A trio of tropical plants -cannas, caladiums and castor beans -- will provide a quick color effect on the property in summertime. These old-fashioned favorites can be planted as soon as warm weather arrives.

A HOUSE that caters to the needs of every member of the family is a homeowner's dream. Mr. and Mrs. William Meyers, who live in the Riverdale home shown here, helped make their dream come true by taking a series of practical steps before building.

OXFORD, Ohio, May 9 (UPI) -- A Miami University freshman today shot and seriously wounded his rival for a co-ed's affections and killed another student who tried to block his escape. He then fatally wounded himself in a telephone booth in another dormitory.
"MATADOR," Barnaby Conrad's fine novel, which first flashed into prominence when John Huston took an option on the property in 1952, is back on the movie horizon, it became known last week.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The House Committee on Science and Astronautics called on the Administration today to establish a "more definite" policy toward international control and use of outer space.

ONE morning not long ago a distinguished professor at one of our large urban universities phoned for advice about a good private school for his teen-age daughter. He was apologetic about the inquiry because he had been known for his eloquent speeches on the importance of the public schools as the foundation of American democracy.

THE girls who dote on horse stories, who have horse pictures pinned up on their walls, and think and talk horses all the time, but know they can't have a horse, will revel in this story with its new twist to a favorite theme.

AMONG the more pleasing signs of spring are the annual Edgar Allan Poe awards of the Mystery Writers of America, calling our attention once again to some of the outstanding contributions to crime in the year just past.
NEWARK, May 9 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called tonight for the election of a Democratic Legislature in November.
Department store sales in the nation were 8 per cent above the 1958 level in the week ended May 2, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. The figures exclude the New York district.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The United States last year lost a record total of $2,300,000,000 of its large stock of gold to foreign countries. In the first quarter of this year the outflow slowed to a trickle -- only $92,000,000 in the three months. Then in April and the first week of May the outflow picked up sharply again, totaling $186,000,000 for the five weeks.

On Thursday prices broke sharply,I wiping out paper values of someI $3,500,000,000. On Friday, stock prices, as measured by the av-I erages, regained about 60 perI cent of that loss.
The price of raw sugar for delivery to the United States registered one of the sharpest peacetime rises late last month. It has inched up a bit more this month.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- With the opening of the Southside section of the city's new $100,000,000 expressway system this week-end, motorists passing through Jacksonville will now be able to bypass at least part of Jacksonville's downtown congestion.
BONN, Germany, May 9 -- West German industry associations are waging a better-business battle against abuses of mail-order sales at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Eisenhower has sent another urgent appeal to Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet Premier, for progress toward an agreement on banning nuclear weapons tests, informed sources said today.
ST. PAUL, May 9 (AP) -Prodded by a State Supreme Court decision, Gov. Orville L. Freeman ordered all of Minnesota today to go on daylight saving time on May 24 for a five and one-half week period.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- There is a real danger that the unemployment figure will remain at 3,500,000 to 4,000,000 according to Economic Trends and Outlook, published by the Economic Policy Committee of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of International Organizations.

YONKERS, May 9 -- Mighty Choo Choo, owned by Samuel Chinitz of Livingston, N. J., equaled the stallion record of 2:00 1-5 in winning the Monitor junior free-for-all pace before 35,815 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

GENEVA, May 9 -- As a place for a foreign ministers' meeting or a newspaper picnic, Geneva is a perfect spot. It has a view of a summit -- Mont Blanc. It is the home of John Calvin, who believed in the natural wickedness of man long before Nikita Khrushchev or John Foster Dulles.

With the fifth anniversary of the Supreme Court's decision on segregation coming up on May 17, reports from the South and border states indicate considerable progress in its implementation, although there has been no desegregation in the public schools of six Southern states.

SEOUL, Korea, May 9 (AP) -- The nation's largest pro-Government newspaper accused the United States Embassy today of trying to influence the Government in the growing debate over press freedom in South Korea.

IT was a scandalous occasion that brought Theophile Gautier into public notice in his nineteenth year. And, indeed, the manner was also scandalous. The date was Feb. 25, 1830. The occasion was the opening night at the Theatre-Francais of Victor Hugo's verse tragedy, "Hernani."
PARIS, May 9 -- Next Wednesday, May 13, Algeria will observe the first anniversary of an uprising that demolished government by Parliament in France.

A number of leading industrial companies with plants in Massachusetts have lately sent open letters to their employes protesting the high level of taxation and generally unfavorable business climate in this state and threatening to move elsewhere if the Legislature does not halt spending.

A NEW class of miniature carnations is being featured in florist shops across the country. Instead of having one large flower on a single stem, the new type looks more like a pompon. Graceful sprays with clusters of four, five or six miniature blossoms make these carnations exceptionally good for use in arrangements.
HANOVER, N. H., May 9 -Dartmouth Medical School announced this week the receipt of a $150,000 grant from the Fannie E. Rippel Foundation of Newark.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 9 -- The Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Rockville Centre reported today that it had served about 75,000 persons last year. The report made made public by the Rev. Charles E. Bermingham, executive director.

GENEVA, May 10 -- The quality of common sense is not a glut on the world market today, but even so there is little likelihood that the Big Four foreign ministers' meeting here is going to break up over the participation of the East Germans.
Sir Winston Churchill paid a call yesterday on an elderly cousin by marriage who, by having a son, once blocked him from possibly becoming Duke of Marlborough.
The Sidney Hillman Foundation announced yesterday the awarding of $25,500 in grants to sixteen educational institutions in the United States, Puerto Rico and Israel.
The New York Hotel Trades Council said yesterday it would appeal the revocation of a $1-an-hour minimum wage for hotel workers in the state outside of New York City.

GENEVA, Monday, May 11 -- Round table, square table or lots of little tables, the United Nations officials here said stanchly this morning that they would be prepared for the foreign ministers' conference. ROME, May 10 -- Ancient Roman walls, stairways and mosaics newly unearthed between the River Tiber and the Vatican have been identified as the remains of Emperor Nero's infamous gardens.
Zionist leaders appealed to Western nations yesterday to safeguard Israel as a democratic state.

CAIRO, May 10 -- A bearded 57-year-old priest who has spent most of his life in a monastery was crowned today as Patriarch of the Coptic Orthodox Church and Pope of Alexandria. He chose the name of Kyrollos VI.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 10 -- "Draw the lady with the cigar," the children clamored, and then giggled with delight at the absurdity of the drawing of "la dame avec un cigare."
A young mother who knows the Chelsea area and the problems of some of its juvenile inhabitants has been working quietly and successfully to keep her own and other children from the path of mischief.

Everything dropped last week in the steamship charter market -- volume, rates and the index.

LONDON, May 10 -- The stock market gave a display of its firmness and the confidence of British investors last week when it reacted only mildly to Thursday's marked Wall Street decline.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- The Americans for Democratic Action said today that the Eisenhower Administration's "obsession with inflation and budget balancing" had hurt the nation's economy all down the line.
LOS ANGELES, May 10 (UPI) -- Alex Olmedo, the Davis Cup star, lost twice today as upsets marked the finals of the seventy-third annual Southern California sectional tennis championships.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 10 -- Margaret Hausman, 10 years old, of Great Neck, L. I., rode her Cinnamon Sugar to two blues for 10 points and the small-pony championship of the St. Barnabas Church Horse Show today. She is a pupil of Mr. and Mrs. Al Fiore at Sandalwood Farm, Goldens Bridge, N.Y.

Lester Osterman, investment broker and Broadway producer, is about to purchase the Coronet Theatre. Negotiations leading to his acquisition of the playhouse at 230 West Forty-ninth Street are going on with the present owner, the City Investing Company, it was learned yesterday.
Virginia ports handled 29 per cent less foreign trade tonnage last year than they did in 1957, the Virginia State Ports Authority reported yesterday.

Although George W. Weed retired two years ago as Peddie's track coach after three decades of service, his fame at the Hightstown (N. J.) school has not dimmed. A few weeks ago, he received the Peddie Bowl for "distinguished service" to the school.
Mayor Wagner has been requested to intervene in the dispute over a candidate for Borough President that has divided the Democratic organization in Queens.
Questions about how the private sponsors of five major slum-clearance projects were chosen were raised yesterday by the Citizens Union.

GENEVA, May 10 -- The old Greeks told us that the fox knows many things, but the hedgehog knows one big thing. This is the position of East and West as they get set for grand negotiation. In bargaining with the Western hedgehog, the Soviet fox has multiple advantages.

The private offices here of eight prominent figures in finance, industry, diplomacy, hunting and the theatre were opened to visitors on Saturday for the benefit of The New York Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund.
EVERY bride wants to be beautiful, a hope that Abraham Straus virtually guarantees. Its Minetta collection for fall, designed by Mimi Boyer, is blue chip from start to finish.

ROME, May 10 (AP) -- Sandra Reynolds of South Africa upset Brazil's Maria Ester Bueno, the 1958 winner, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, today in the women's singles semi-finals of the Italian tennis championships.

ALBANY, May 10 -- The State Department of Labor reported today that in March, for the first time in eighteen months, the number of employed in the state topped that for the comparable month of the previous year.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Consolation, the United States' goodwill hospital ship, is expected to start bringing medical help to southeast Asia by next September, starting with Indonesia.

The forty-second season of Guggenheim Memorial summer concerts by the Goldman Band will begin Wednesday, June 17, on the Mall in Central Park. Harry F. Guggenheim, president of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, made the announcement yesterday.

IT was on a triumphant note that "Omnibus" ended its seventh season on the air yesterday afternoon over Channel 4; the program's production of "H. M. S. Pinafore" is the best possible reason for an eighth year.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., May 10 -- Castle's Bonus Boy, an orange-and-white English setter owned and handled by Edwin Castle of Brewster, N. Y., won the Amateur Shooting Dog Stake that completed the Southern New York Field Trial Club's two-day spring trials at the Goldens Bridge Game Farm today.

NEW DELHI, India, May 10 -- Mrs. Indira Gandhi, president of the ruling Congress party, accused the Communist regime in the State of Kerala today of exploiting the power of office to advance party interests.

Thanks to the generosity of many thoughtful people, hundreds of blind boys and girls discover a new world every summer at Camp Wapanacki in the Green Mountains of Vermont. Here they learn to swim, hike, ride ponies, fish, tent out in the woods and participate in games and sports adapted for them.

In the years before the outbreak of World War I an officer of the Austro-Hungarian General Staff sold out to the Russians and, by doing so, nearly destroyed the military strength of his country, which was demoralized by the scandal.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 10 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon has broad support for the 1960 Republican Presidential nomination in an influential group of business executives who might be expected to lean naturally toward Governor Rockefeller of New York.

Two powerful unions are in the labor news today. One is the one-million-member United Steelworkers of America, which is moving into the decisive stage of its pattern-setting wage negotiations with twelve big steel companies at the Roosevelt Hotel here.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers has submitted an "urgent" plea to Congress for funds to build a new maximum security prison for hardened criminals.
MOSCOW, May 9 -- The twenty-one American students doing postgraduate work in Moscow and Leningrad Universities are unanimously agreed that it has been a rewarding experience.
The motorship Prins Willem Van Oranje is scheduled to arrive in Chicago today to start first-class passenger service between the inland port and Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
A store has been leased by Dan's Supreme Supermarkets, a Brooklyn and Long Island chain, in the one-story taxpayer under construction at 181st Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

Mother's Day added a touch of color to the hospital strike yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. Many pickets turned up outside the institution on Stuyvesant Square with bright red flowers pinned to their lapels and dresses.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 10 -- The South African Jewish community dedicated today a memorial to the 6,000,000 victims of Nazi Germany's anti-Semitism.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 10 -- Opposing factions raced one another today in drives to collect enough signatures on petitions to force a school board recall election.

As a veteran newsman I can only envy Max Frankel, whose journey into Siberia produced some splendid reporting, and pay my respects to your newspaper for the type of enterprise that has made The New York Times just about indispensable.
The number of Americans familiar with the facts of the Berlin crisis has increased sharply in the last six weeks, according to the results of a national survey made public yesterday.

The American Nurses Association said yesterday that provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act and various state laws exempting voluntary hospitals from bargaining with employes were largely responsible for the hospital strike.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 10 (AP) -- Tornadoes slashed across Iowa today, injuring one man, leveling several farm homes and a rural community and killing seventy head of livestock and more than 5,000 turkeys.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 10 (AP) -- Hazza Majalis, new Premier of Jordan, said today his country would steer clear of military pacts with either East or West.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- Steven Marlo may say some day, with justice, that he pioneered in a new aspect of movie business. For the young actor has learned and spoken Marlon Brando's part in "One-Eyed Jacks," but will never be heard in the film.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 10 -- Harry Powell's Three Belles, sailed by Owen Torrey, won the third race of the International Class spring series for the Stanley Trophy and Stanley Ogilvy with Flame triumphed in the second race of the six-part Star Class series off the Larchmont Y. C. today.

REEDSPORT, Ore., May 10 (AP) -- Six persons were killed when a light plane struck a power line and crashed into the Umpqua river thirteen miles east of this southern Oregon coastal town yesterday. The bodies of three were recovered today.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 10 -- Three months ago Don Grossman, a 20-year-old lithographer from Wappingers Falls, N. Y., used a trap gun for the first time. Today at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island traps, with the same gun, he took the national handicap trapshooting title.
The last few days have been extremely prosperous for Chicago agencies.
GENEVA, May 10 -- In thirty-nine years of international conferences here, Geneva's security measures have limited delgate casualties to one slapped face.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Several times last week grain futures dealers thought they were doing business at bargain prices on the Board of Trade but the market generally extended its decline.

HAVANA, May 10 -- Illegal seizure of property in Oriente Province by groups of landless persons and the failure of the Government to take action against them are causing great concern to the land owners.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Behind the Senate battle over the "bill of rights" amendment to the labor reform bill was a not-so-friendly duel between a professor and a former student who had learned too much, or perhaps not enough.
The way the Treasury's short-term financing operations just squeezed through last week is likely to revive talk about the feasibility of resuming long-term financing.

IF seagulls start dropping clam shells on Oppenheim Collins this week, do not be alarmed. The seashore is the setting for the store's new Sportswear Floor (the fourth), where the sound of rolling surf and gliding gulls provides a suitable background for a bright, young collection of summer clothes.

" MUSIC in Our Time" ended its fourth season last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. Max Pollikoff, its guiding spirit, was again present to speak of the works, to introduce the composers who were present, and to serve as the violinist of the evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 (AP) -- Clem Labine for the second day in a row saved the day for Los Angeles and the Dodgers beat the San Francisco Giants, 3-2 today. The Dodgers took the four-game series, 3-1.
The Seventy-second Street lake in Central Park saw an adaptation of piracy on the high seas yesterday. The police called it robbery in a rowboat.
Fourteen older horses have been named to contest the $25,000 Toboggan Handicap, traditional opening-day feature of Belmont Park, when the remodeled track opens today for a fifty-four-day stand.
" Mrs. Bridge," Evan S. Connell Jr.'s novel that has climbed up and down the best-seller list during the last twelve weeks, is Broadway-bound.

Aside from one disturbing development, the Yankees experienced their best day of the season yesterday. Casey Stengel's athletes, winning twice in a day for the first time this year, downed Cookie Lavagetto's Washington Senators, 6 -- 3 and 3 -- 2, the second game in overtime.
Roman Catholics were told yesterday that it was their duty to "labor for the salvation of souls." The Rev. Oscar V. Lynch made the reminder at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Eastern Air Lines has named Dr. Francis N. Kimball general director of medical activities, with headquarters in New York. Dr. James Hutson of Miami has been appointed director of the line's medical department at its Miami base.

WASHINGTON, May 10 ( UPI) -- The Democratic national chairman, Paul M. Butler, predicted today that the 1960 Democratic platform would contain "the strongest statement that's ever been written on human rights."

The question before the New York Times Youth Forum yesterday was: "Does Youth Understand World Issues?" It was answered affirmatively by the five young panelists.

It is pleasing that the first trip outside of Belgium to be made by King Baudouin since he ascended the throne should be to the United States. The 28-year-old King of the Belgians arrives today, on President Eisenhower's invitation, for a three-week visit.

LONDON, Monday, May 11 -- The London Daily Telegraph reported from Teheran today that Soviet army units had entered Afghanistan and had taken up positions at Herat, straddling the main road between Iran and the Afghan capital of Kabul.
Two vocalists who escaped from Communist-controlled countries made their debuts at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon under the auspices of "Der Ring." a recently formed concert organization.

Galen Van Meter Co., investment advisers and financial research specialists, leased office space in the new building at 630 Third Avenue, corner of Forty-first Street, through Howard Katz of Pease Elliman Inc., broker. Collins, Tuttle Co. is the agent for the building.
Arraignments and fines in the city's Magistrates' courts in 1958 increased over 1957, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh reported today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 10 -- A top Communist described Fidel Castro and his movement in Cuba today as the best example of "progressive bourgeoisie'' with which Latin-American Communists should collaborate.

Now that we have a greater stake in the weather than we did in the winter our interest in what the Weather Bureau says about it is also on the rise. The forecaster has, in many ways, a thankless task. People complain bitterly when a seemingly firm promise of "sunny and mild" is followed by a day both rainy and cold. But when the elements redeem a pleasant promise the forecaster rarely gets any praise.
Opening up the moldy archives of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries has provided a rich repertory for the talents of a fine amateur choral group like the Brooklyn College Chorus.

Though facing an initial snarl, the East-West conference of foreign ministers is scheduled to start in Geneva today amid expressions of hope by both sides that it will be crowned with success and will achieve enough progress toward real peace to justify another summit meeting. This hope will most certainly be shared by all mankind.
GENEVA, May 10 -- There are plenty of men in the news at the Geneva conference, but the main thing is the country in the news: Germany. be round or square?

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- A special group of lawyers assigned by the Justice Department to step up the campaign against crime syndicates is on notice from members of a Congressional subcommittee to produce some convictions or face oblivion.
MOSCOW, May 10 -- A census report putting the Soviet population at 208,800,000 was issued here today.

Mrs. Marion Ladewig and Mrs. LaVerne Carter retained the national championship in the Bowling Proprietors Association of America women's doubles competition last night at the Hollywood Lanes in Rego Park, Queens.

Memphis, Tenn., is planning to borrow $10,000,000 in the bond market on June 2 to finance public improvements. The bonds will be dated July 1, 1959, and will come due serially on Oct. 1 from 1960 to 1989.

A contract for the purchase of the twenty-seven-story office building at 20 Broad Street, next to the Stock Exchange, has been signed by the New York Life Insurance Company, which holds the mortgage on the property. The assessed valuation is $11,500,000.

The first government-sponsored Soviet-American student exchange program is nearing the end of its initial academic year and officials in both countries have begun evaluating the program's results to date.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 10 -- The stock market showed great strength in the first half of the week partly on Wall Street's influence. Thursday's marked reaction in Wall Street had only a little influence, so that prices of most industrials, except Royal Dutch, closed the week at fresh highs.

THE number of working women in Japan has nearly doubled in the last ten years. More than 6,000,000 Japanese women are now gainfully employed, of whom an estimated 30 per cent are married. This compares with 27 per cent in the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission has awarded the Guaranty Trust Company of New York $886,457 on a claim of $11,600,000 against the Soviet Union.

A SIMPLE French dressing would seem the easiest thing in the world to make, but more spurious concoctions are offered in its name than almost any other food product. And talk about what is a good French dressing brings out almost as many different opinions as there are individuals in the discussion.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 10 -- Two all-day events of similar concept but distinctive variation will be notable attractions in this area on Saturday. One will be the Nottingham Fair of the First Presbyterian Church, and the other the Country Fair of the Low-Heywood School, both in Stamford.
Lower sales and heavy research and development costs reduced first-quarter earnings of the General Dynamics Corporation to $5,925,385, from $9,872,366 in the 1958 period.
JUNE, the traditional month for brides, brings forth a rash of weddings and, with them, inevitable questions of procedure and protocol.

The salubrious effects of the Cyprus settlement earlier this year are being felt in an ever wider radius. The first impact of the accord was the restoration of normal tranquillity and security on Cyprus itself. Then last month the Greek municipal elections resulted in a landslide victory for the party of Premier Karamanlis, who had negotiated the Cyprus agreement, and a smashing defeat for the Communist-backed Union of the Democratic Left.
CHICAGO, May 8 -- How does Konstantin Ivanovich Nesen of Kiev like the student exchange program?

HEWETT HARBOR, L. I., May 10 -- Art Silvestrone, a 27-year-old public links golfer from Mineola, L. I., captured the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament today by defeating Billy Edwards, the 1958 winner, 3 and 1.

The Venerable Richard E. McEvoy, Archdeacon of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, called on Christians yesterday to be "witnesses unto the Gospel." He spoke at Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street.

FOR the want of a tie, a designer was born. And no one is more amazed than the designer herself. This is the story behind Mr. Field, Inc., a whimsical tie business that has captured the imagination of men and women over the country.
The storm warnings against market speculation may prove a blessing in disguise for the mutual funds.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 10 -- The leaders of Greece and Turkey relaxed today following their conference on problems between the two countries. Premiers Konstantin Karamanlis of Greece and Adnan Menderes of Turkey watched a soccer match here between Turkish and Netherlands teams.

JUNEAU, Alaska, May 8 -- The guardian of Alaska's budding petroleum industry announced today that the new state would offer some 3,000,000 acres of offshore land for oil and gas drilling within ninety days.
ALBANY, May 10 -- Upstate New York continues to outstrip New York City in population gains, the State Health Department's annual statistical survey revealed today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A suggestion that President Eisenhower call in steel industry management and unions, now trying to negotiate a wage contract, "and really talk turkey to them" came today from Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York.

Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon issued a statement yesterday explaining that his visit to the opening of the World Trade Fair at the Coliseum Friday was as President of the United Nations General Assembly and not as a representative of his country.

The National Education Association has rendered a signal service by calling attention to a weak spot in our school system with its report on the need for more and better teaching of geography. The actual making of maps, globes and photographs is better than ever. The collection of data is more comprehensive and accurate. The field has enlarged in scope and importance with the "shrinking" world.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- A New York physician has reported the case of a middle-aged woman who apparently has recovered from leukemia, which is known as cancer of the blood and is usually considered fatal.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Did Nazi Germany have access to secret United States State Department papers in 1941?
Justice Nathaniel Kaplan of the Domestic Relations Court declared yesterday that too much installment buying was one cause of family problems that produced juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- Mrs. Maurice L. Goldman, vice president of the American Council for Judaism, said tonight that Zionists were gaining increased domination of Jewish organizations in the United States.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 8 -- Eight Soviet students, including a young woman, Miss Alexandra V. Zhuravchenkova, arrived on the campus of the University of California last Thanksgiving. They, their professors and their fellow students are highly satisfied with the results of their more than five months' residency at the University.

MOSCOW, May 10 -- This burgeoning Soviet capital is an auto salesman's dream -- unlimited demand, customers eager to pay almost any price and a market for almost any kind of car in almost any condition.
MONTE CARLO, May 10 -- Jack Brabham's Cooper-Climax won a spectacular Grand Prix de Monaco automobile race today. Only five of the sixteen starters finished under their own power.
LONDON, May 10 -- Britain and other European countries outside the six-nation common market have made considerable progress in developing a plan for forming their own trading association.
The members of New York Typographical Union No. 6 (Big six) yesterday voted to reject a proposal of ten New York newspapers in a dispute over a new contract. The vote was 704 to 443.

LEEDS, England, May 10 (UPI) -- The Home Office disclosed today that Klaus Fuchs, atomic spy, and a group of convicts had staged a protest against British H-bomb testing. A newspaper said Fuchs had organized a one-meal "hunger strike."

THE final performance by the Bolshoi Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday night was full of excitement on both sides of the footlights. Galina Ulanova made her second appearance in "Giselle." with an absolutely top-drawer cast supporting her and with Yuri Faier conducting.

An arbitration meeting seeking to end a labor dispute between the National Broadcasting Company and the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians ended early yesterday after a continuous session of twenty hours.
Carol Lee Eshak is only 21 years old, but she made her local piano debut nine years ago. So she is something of at recital veteran.
VIENNA, May 10 -- Chancellor Julius Raab's conservative People's party narrowly escaped defeat at the hands of the Socialists today in Austria's fifth general elections since the end of the war.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 10 -- This week or next may find the nations of Latin America crossing the threshold of the regional common market that has been under consideration for more than a year.

The centers, kindergartens and playgrounds of the Children's Aid Society were used by 119,435 persons last year, according to the society's annual report, issued yesterday. At the centers, 105,285 luncheons were served.
There were two mystery guests last night on the television show, "What's My Line?"

SITTING in his attractive bedroom in Will's and Beryl's house, Billy Ashted spent most of his time thinking and writing about the past. Billy was 76, a widower, a little old man dismayed and defeated by his loss of independence, by his position as a guest in his successful son's house.
In an attempt to convince the city's leading retailers of the benefits of one-way traffic on major avenues, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley has begun a letter-writing campaign.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Sterner treatment of youthful lawbreakers, including disclosure of their identities has been urged before Congress by J. Edgar Hoover.

CINCINNATI, May 10 (UPI) -- Lieut. Kurt Franz Rossmeisl, 52 years old, who escaped from a German prisoner of war camp at Camp Butner, N. C., Aug. 4, 1945, gave himself up today to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
May I add a few remarks to those made by Prof. Alfred E. Kahn regarding the limitation of imports of petroleum.

PARIS, May 10 (AP) -- An American veteran who talked with Nikita S. Khrushchev quoted the Soviet Premier yesterday as having said: "We are playing with the idea that at some future time we will allow any national to leave Russia at any time."
MINNEAPOLIS, May 10 -- India's foreign policy is "neutrality with a differenc -- an active and dynamic effort to seek a moral solution to world tensions," the Maharajah of Mysore said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- A nation-wide survey of the newspaper buying habits of the American public will be made next week by the United States Census Bureau.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8 -- The Soviet Union has some lazy students, too, Anatole D. Glushchenko, a 28-year-old graduate of the University of Kiev, reported here.
The winners of the five annual college scholarships awarded by the Welfare Plan of the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic and Gulf District, were announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 10 -- Diplomats here said they saw nothing new emerging from Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery's recent talks with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev in Moscow.

CAIRO, May 10 -- Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, discussed today with officials of the United Arab Republic possible help by the bank in widening and deepening the Suez Canal.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 10 -- President Mohammed Ayub Khan said today he was "very keen to resolve outstanding disputes with India."

PITTSBURGH, May 10 -- Fresh steel order volume was off last week, but the significance of this market factor was not too great since most mills already have all they can handle -- and more -- in trying to meet promised delivery dates before June 30.
The African cousin of Rikki-tikki-tavi, the Indian mongoose of Kipling's "Jungle Book," has arrived at the Bronx Zoo.

Liberia, whose economy has been benefiting from tree crops such as rubber, palm oil, cocoa and coffee, is now trying to build up markets for wood products. About onethird of the land area of the West African republic is composed of timberland, most of which never has been commercially exploited.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- A Congressional report said today that United States scientists hoped to have a world-wide satellite communications network operating within four years.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 10 (AP) -- A tornado smashed through a residential and industrial district on the northern edge of Austin today. It left damage estimated at $250,000, but no one was injured.
Cotton prices in the domestic market held to a narrow trading range last week, but closed on mostly firmer ground.
MIAMI BEACH, May 10 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which for years frowned on strikes, has decided to raise a $5,000,000 strike fund.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 11 -- Donald Norbury, a 21-year-old junior at the University of Pennsylvania, won the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association championship today with a 3-and-2 victory over Michael Phillips of Yale at the Springdale Country Club.
MANAMA, Bahrein, May 7 -- Some of the Arabs of Bahrein are beginning to wonder what happens to an oil sheikdom when it runs out of oil
The crucial stage of wage negotiations in the steel industry started yesterday with the union urging that priority be given to "practical measures" to spread employment.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to approve United States membership in a billion-dollar development bank and fund for Latin America.
Vincent Rao, one of the sixty delegates to the Apalachin gangland convention, appeared before the State Investigation Commission yesterday but refused to answer questions.
A system of daily hiring of longshoremen on the basis of seniority is expected to be tested on the Hudson River luxury liner piers next month.
MIAMI BEACH, May 11 -- David Dubinsky offered a political slogan today for labor in 1960: "Veto the veto."

TODAY'S books run to the extravagant in humor. One is "My Brother Was an Only Child,"* a paarboiled causerie by Jack Douglas, who does much to make the Jack Paar television shenanigans perpetually impromptu. The other is Muriel Spark's new novel, "Memento Mori," which seems designed to show us what the Angry Young Men and the Beat Generation may be up to three or four decades from now.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The ranking Republican on the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee charged its Democratic majority today with having turned confirmation hearings on Lewis L. Strauss into a political tune-up for 1960.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 11 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer made his putts when they counted today and won the Oklahoma City open golf tournament. The former Masters champion had a final 69 and a 72-hole total of 273.

Directors of the Philadelphia and Reading Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday they had agreed in principle to set up a jointly owned corporation to produce chemicals from anthracite mining waste and residue products.

NEXT month is traditionally the time of roses and weddings. It also is the season of bitter tears in the kitchen, for it is when many young brides first turn their hands to the culinary art. Weep not, for mishaps happen to the best of chefs. This is a column on the various pitfalls that occur in cooking and on how they occur.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 11 -- The thought of a prolonged visit from twenty-three youngsters and five adults would cause most housewives to shudder in dismay and then quickly check the linen supply and the contents of the freezer.
The bond market declined further yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The elimination of cut-rate fares to school children and other relief measures have been asked by the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, and its wholly owned subsidiary, Surface Transit, in petitions to the Board of Estimate.
OAK HARBOR, Wash., May 11 (UPI) -- Nine of ten men aboard a Navy patrol bomber were killed today when the plane crashed and burned shortly after takeoff from the Whidbey Island Naval Air Station.

GENEVA, May 11 -- The foreign ministers' conference finally opened this evening after a delay. East Germany and West Germany were present as advisers, as the West desired, rather than as full participants, as the Soviet Union had proposed.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 (AP) -- Aluminum Company of America reported today it was increasing its production rate to about 82 per cent of capacity by restarting potlines at Point Comfort, Tex., and Vancouver, Wash.

SUNNYVALE, Calif., May 11 (AP) -- Barnes-Hind Laboratories, Inc., of Sunnyvale said today that its wetting solution for contact eye lenses had been given a pink tint to distinguish it from a former product. It is also sterile.

W. R. Grace Co., international trading, shipping, banking, paper and chemical enterprise, is joining forces with two petroleum companies to explore for oil in Libya. J. Peter Grace, president, made the disclosure to stockholders in the Biltmore Hotel here yesterday.
Blood will be given to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today at the New York Telephone Company, 221 East Thirty-seventh Street, and at the Consolidated Edison Company, 4 Irving Place.
DETROIT, May 11 (AP) -- The auto industry, which built nearly 579,000 cars in April, is heading for another such month.

Demolition With Discipline Sidewalk superintendents may have to look twice these days to tell whether a building is going up or coming down in booming midtown Manhattan. For if demolition was always an art it is now also a science and wreckers are learning to undo the work of builders more neatly and efficiently.
Eight special television shows starring Art Carney are expected to be televised next season by the National Broadcasting Company. The schedule calls for one show a month, beginning in the fall.
The Government opposed yesterday a motion in behalf of Alexander L. Guterma to have the fraud trial of the 44-year-old financier transferred from Brooklyn to Buffalo.
STUDENTS and stock brokers, "beatniks" and ballet dancers, socialites and salesmen all seem to prefer a common means of locomotion these days. They go by motor scooter.
The foreign ministers' conference opened in controversy in Geneva last night against a background of threats and warnings from Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.

GENEVA, May 11 (Reuters) -Following are the texts of the welcoming address by Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, at today's opening of the foreign ministers' conference, and the reply by Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd, who presided:
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- A new data processing center, designed to balance electronically the inventories of some 482,000 spare parts needed for naval aircraft, was dedicated today.

We, members of the supervisory staff of the New York State Employment Service, are moved to respond to the report made by the New York State Commission Against Discrimination which states that placement interviewers in the State Employment Service did not believe "supervisory personnel to be entirely committed to the policy of non-discrimination."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11 -- U. Thant, Burmese delegate to the United Nations, said tonight that "only peaceful coexistence between the Arabs and Jews could offer any hope of reconciling these two great peoples in the Middle East."

With their prospects brightened considerably and their critics less voluble, the Yankees will play host to the league-leading Cleveland Indians tonight at the Stadium. Casey Stengel's Bombers will open their stand against the Western teams encouraged by a double triumph over the Senators on Sunday and hearten by the fact that only four games separate the sixth-place Yanks from the Indians.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- American factories are producing a rocket fuel that has three times the energy of present fuels, the Air Force disclosed today.
MOSCOW, May 11 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that the Soviet Union might soon "begin to reduce the production of rockets."

Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has assembled a plot at the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street. He reported that a resale was pending to an institution planning an office building there.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 11 -The United States Export-Import Bank and a group of New York banks are preparing to lend Chile up to $100,000,000.

MONTREAL, May 11 (AP) -- Andy Bathgate of the New York Rangers, a right wing who scored forty goals although playing with two damaged knees, won the Hart Trophy today as the National Hockey League's most valuable player in the 1958-59 season.

BAUDOUIN I, King of the Belgians, is a young monarch who arrived in Washington yesterday on a familiar quest of royalty. He yearns to see people as they are when a king is not around. He is 28 years old, unmarried, an inch under six feet tall and lean, hard and athletic.
ALGIERS, May 11 -- Shouts of "De Gaulle to the gallows!" rang out here tonight from a jostling crowd of 500 French demonstrators.
Steel production declined again last week, and for the third consecutive week failed to reach the level scheduled by producers, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
A spectator at the women's national doubles bowling tournament over the week-end said, "This seems to be a know-nothing competition."

The New York City Housing Authority will receive bids on May 19 for $29,240,000 of short-term loan notes to finance Luna Park Houses, a City-subsidized 1,575-unit project being built in Brooklyn. The notes will be dated June 10 and will come due on Jan. 26.

The New York Board of Rabbis said yesterday it had not sent any communication to the Court of Special Sessions concerning Harry Shapolsky, a convicted rent gouger who received a suspended sentence in that court on May 1.

Tick Tock, Howell E. Jackson's game little sprinter, made good time over the six furlongs of Belmont's Toboggan Handicap yesterday and took the $29,200 opening-day feature by a half-length. Greentree Stable's Cohoes, the favorite and top weight under 125 pounds, was second.

Net income of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and subsidiaries, was $16,984,000, equal to $1.16 a common share, for the first three months this year, the company reported yesterday. That compared with $12,213,000, or 83 cents a share, for the like period last year.

" The Years With Ross," James Thurber's account of his "hilarious and fascinating" career with Harold Ross, editor and founder of The New York magazine, will be published May 28 by Atlantic-Little, Brown. Mr. Thurber tells of the magazine and of the people who made it famous, among them Robert Benchley, Alexander Woolcott, John McNulty, Charles Addams and Dorothy Parker.

Chemical Corn Exchange Bank has established the first fully centralized bank book-keeping set-up in a New York branch system bank and one of the few in the country, in three floors of the new building at 2 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The House of Representatives approved today appropriations totaling $6,457,657,800 to run a score of independent agencies through the fiscal year starting next July 1.

ALTHOUGH born in Utah, Matsumi Kanemitsu has spent considerable time in Japan and his paintings at the Widdifield Gallery, 818 Madison Avenue, reflect the skill with which the Japanese handle black inks.
GENEVA, May 11 -- For an hour and ten minutes today the strange ways of international politics turned a quiet, tree-shaded street in Geneva into the shouting, shoving diplomatic center of the world.

Mayor Wagner backed Park Commissioner Robert Moses yesterday in Mr. Moses' insistence that admission be charged for any Shakespeare plays produced this summer in Central Park. The Mayor noted the broad powers on park management and operation conferred on the Park Commissioner by both city and state law.

The Bond Club of New York has announced the nomination of William B. Chappell for president. Mr. Chappell, a vice president of the First Boston Corporation, was formerly vice president of the club. As president he will succeed Harold H. Cook, a partner of Spencer Trask Co.

CINCINNATI, May 11 -- A four-year effort to unionize the principal hotels and motels in the Miami Beach, Fla., area has been won, Ed S. Miller, president of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes and Bartenders International Union, said at the union's headquarters here today.
ROME, May 11 (AP) -- Neale Fraser of Australia and Chile's Luis Ayala won their semi-final singles matches in the Italian tennis championships today.
As soon as Joshua Logan discovered that his film commitments would prevent him from producing and staging "Goodbye, Charlie," the comedy by George Axelrod was acquired by Leland Hayward.
Mortgage financing has entered the jet age. A New Jersey broker embarked yesterday on an eight-day tour of seventeen states to buy and sell property loans.
The United States World Trade Fair at the Coliseum marked its first business day yesterday with large buyer attendance.

The first-quarter net income of the Flintkote Company rose to $1,515,963 from $471,331 in the initial three months of last year. This was reported yesterday by I. J. Harvey Jr., chairman, at a special stockholders meeting in Boston.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has been whipping up a storm in Esther Williams' swimming pool. At last count the tempest was costing about $100,000, involving airplane propellers, hydraulic rockers, water chutes, hoses, wind machines and other entraptions.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon urged religious leaders today to "mobilize the moral support of the American people" in the fight against racial discrimination in employment.

The annual Spring Party of the Army Young Men's Christian Association at Governors Island on the afternoon and evening of May 20 will honor the Veterans of the Seventh Regiment, who are this year celebrating their organization's hundredth anniversary. Proceeds from the event will go toward the support of the Y. M. C. A.'s Armed Services Program.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- A good demand for soybean and old crop corn futures sent all these contracts well ahead today on the Board of Trade. May wheat again was under general selling pressure and went to another new low for the season.
SPRING having definitely arrived, some attractive people have declared a pleasant holiday at the Phoenix.
Military bands began giving concerts here yesterday in celebration of Armed Forces Week, which will culminate Saturday in a parade down Fifth Avenue.
A "policy of opposition to violence in racial disputes" was reaffirmed yesterday by the board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

LONDON, May 11 -- The British Government announced today its approval of substantial arms sales to Iraq, including tanks and jet bombers, to prevent that country from turning to the Soviet Union for weapons.

A syndicate managed by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co., jointly, today is offering $5,500,000 of Southern Nevada Power Company 5 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due 1989, at par to yield 5.25 per cent.

Mrs. Katherine Brownell Oettinger, chief of the United States Children's Bureau, yesterday called for an end to proxy adoptions of children from abroad. She also urged Federal legislation to safeguard all intercountry adoptions.

The problems of homeless children, whether they be new born or a few years old, are not simple ones. How to make them feel wanted, stay healthy physically and mentally, and grow up to be pro ductive citizens are challenges that the Greater New York Fund agencies specializing in these problems face every day.

Six new governors were elected to the Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange for three-year terms yesterday while four governors were re-elected and Edward C. Werle, chairman of the board, was re-elected to serve a second one-year term as chairman.

THE lordly Cleveland Indians, the league leaders since the start of the season, will visit their less fortunate brethren tonight and tomorrow. This corporal work of mercy will take place in the Stadium, when the compassionate Clevelanders soothe the fevered brows of the bruised and battered New York Yankees.

The American School of Appeasement enjoys a longevity worthy of a better cause. Prof. Nathaniel Peffer's letter in your issue of April 29 is but the latest twist in a long line of thinking that has not significantly changed its direction since it contributed so materially to the tragic surrender of the Chinese mainland to communism.
PASSERS-BY peering into Richard Camp's recently opened shop at 306 East Fifty-third Street more often than not inquire:

Many persons entertained at cocktail parties before the sixth annual May Festival Ball last night. The event was held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of Just One Break, Inc., a nonprofit organization dedicated to finding employment for physically disabled persons who are unable to obtain jobs in competitive industry.
Elizabeth Eenson auy, Canadian soprano, sang a debut performance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 11 -- One of the nation's leading planners said today that the American public was demanding a "new diversity" in community facilities and services that must be met.

Members of society arrived early at the Turf and Field Club enclosure at Belmont Park yesterday to have luncheon in the mezzanine dining room before the first post of the opening program of what is expected to be the biggest season of the racing association since its inauguration in 1905.
DALLAS, May 11 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson has been offered at least $500,000 and perhaps an oil well to defend his middleweight championship against Joey Giambra this fall, a promoter said today.

The manager of a swimming pool at Menands, N. Y., a suburb of Albany, was sentenced to a five-day jail term for contempt yesterday in Albany Supreme Court and fined $200 under the state's anti-discrimination law.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- Government auditors testified today that a nickel and cobalt contract with a Freeport Sulphur Company subsidiary could cost the Government $248,210,000.
A masked bandit with a sawed-off shotgun held up the cashier and the security officer of the Manhattan Hotel yesterday and escaped with $29,000 -- $12,000 in cash and $17,000 in checks.

The Salute to the Seasons Committee is to be commended for the imaginative and enchanting way some of the main avenues of our city have been decorated with spring flowers and shrubs for the enjoyment of all. Those local committees, corporations and private citizens who so unselfishly have contributed to this most attractive program of beautifying these important thoroughfares, are deserving of the same recognition.

Another conference is opening in Geneva today. It will not be controversial, except as its members try to find ways to do a good job better. This is the annual Assembly of the World Health Organization, and its twelfth meeting.

Mayor Wagner reported early this morning that five struck hospitals here have postponed, at least for a day, their plans to seek a Supreme Court injunction today enjoining the union from continuing the strike of nonprofessional workers.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- President Harlan H. Hatcher of the University of Michigan said today it was time that Americans realized the Stalin era was dead and that Russians recognized that the age of the robber barons was past.

YOUNG ladies between the ages of 11 and 14 lead lives fraught with problems. Their figures are developing and they are beginning to have their own ideas about what they want to wear -- ideas that often are at variance with those of their mothers.
THERE was as much truth as science-fiction in "Man in Orbit," last night's drama on the Desilu Playhouse over Channel 2.

TRENTON, May 11 -- The state Senate adopted a bill today that would direct the Port of New York Authority to finance and build a link between the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the Hudson and Manhattan tubes.
An attempt by the International Longshoremen's Association to acquire control of a tug-boatmen's union "substantial" treasury was frustrated yesterday by a court decision.
Ticket Corner, a cut-rate theatre ticket agency designed to restore the show shopping habit that prevailed on Broadway some thirty years ago, opened for business yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The interest rate on ninety-one-day Treasury bills fell noticeably this week, but the rate on 182-day bills rose to the highest level since the bills were first offered last December, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 11 -- A plan to divide the state into several regions for education planning, consultation and research is being considered by the State Education Department.

The appointments of two administrative vice presidents in the production department of United States Steel Corporation were announced yesterday by Harvey B. Jordan, executive vice president production.

In the coming months New York will mark its Year of History celebrating the 350th anniversary of the discoveries of Hudson and Champlain. Would this not be an appropriate time to renovate and restore some of the local historic landmarks ?
Jack Lang, president of Weber Heilbroner, announced yesterday that it would open a new store today at 726 White Plains Post Road, Eastchester, N. Y., in the Lord Taylor Shopping Area.

Yale's defending varsity champions, Harvard, Syracuse and Pennsylvania were seeded in that order yesterday for the sprint regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges. The races will be held over a 2,000-meter course Saturday on Princeton's Carnegie Lake, with thirteen colleges participating.
ST. CATHARINES, Ont., May 11 (AP) -- Canada announced today that foreign ships without proper equipment for canal transit had been barred from passage in the St. Lawrence Seaway.
The Air Force has decided to buy "limited numbers" of a modified civil jet transport for troop and cargo carrying.

COLRAIN, Mass., May 11 -- Clinical tests conducted here today proved that angleworms of the South and Mid-West are intellectually and emotionally more sensitive than those of New England but do not necessarily catch more fish.

The combined report of the Departments of Labor and Commerce yesterday revealed the second almost spectacular monthly improvement in the employment picture in succession. After the number of unemployed had risen to 5,437,000 in June last year the situation brightened steadily through October, by which time the total had fallen by 1,632,000 to 3,805,000. Then came an interruption in the trend.

The tactic of the "kiss of death" is one of the most effective in the Communist armory. It takes various forms, such as announcing support for a political candidate without being asked, praising a man or movement, and claiming credit for a victory whether the Communists had anything to do with it or not.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The familiar blue stamp with the picture of Dewitt Clinton will soon disappear from cigarette packs.
A swarm of well-dressed persons descended on a Park Avenue mansion yesterday.
Accounting for the bout's only knockdown thirty seconds before the finish, Victor Zalazar, an Argentinian middleweight, scored an impressive victory at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The article by Leo Egan in The Times of April 28 concerning the De Sapio-Finletter debate put into proper perspective the reason why the reform which the Tammany leader announced -- that of using voting machines in primary elections -- was made.
MOSCOW, May 11 -- According to Premier Nikita S. Krushchev, "many Jews are finding themselves in difficulties in Israel."

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Government forecast today this year's winter wheat crop at 956,614,000 bushels. This would be 19 per cent less than last year's record harvest, and 17 per cent more than the 1948-57 average.
A fire in the stereotype room at The New York Times last night interrupted production of the first edition of today's paper for about fifteen minutes.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP) -- A new appraisal of the modern American nurse was made today at the convention of the National League for Nursing.
Encouraging although temporary results with radical new treatments for leukemia and other forms of advanced cancer were reported yesterday from Boston.
THE place was the Metropolitan Opera House, but, as John W. Bubbles remarked in the midst of an elegant soft-shoe number, it seemed more like the Loew's State. And indeed it did.

A $2,000,000 loan to Yonkers Raceway by the Harry M. Stevens catering concern has caused George P. Monaghan, Harness Racing Commissioner, to reverse a decision to permit the track to charge off $400,000 in restaurant equipment to a state fund.
A roof-mounted heating and air-conditioning system designed for retail stores has been developed to enable store owners to allocate the maximum floor space to sales purposes.

Today will be "ex-dividend" day on the New York Stock Exchange. No less than seventy-six common stocks listed on the Big Board will be quoted in that way. The list runs from the Aeroquip Corporation to the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.
LONDON, May 11 -- Increased profit taking in the industrials slightly outweighed selective buying in the stock market today and minor falls predominated in most shares groups.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 11 -- The inseparable Sanfilippo twins of Sarah Lawrence College will be separated for an extended time next fall for the first time because of their studies. Janet, the older by ten minutes, will enter the University of Strasbourg in France to study psychology under a Fulbright grant.

For more than ten years the United States has had no effective treaties with our neighbors to the north and south to regulate radio broadcasting. In 1949 the North American Regional Broadcasting Agreement, known as NARBA, expired and only a "gentlemen's agreement" among the countries has prevented complete chaos in the broadcasting field.

An Israeli archaeologist reported yesterday that excavations of the biblical city of Hazor in Israel's Galilee had disclosed "the best picture to date" of the material culture of the ancient Canaanites and Israelites.
GENEVA, May 11 -- For the benefit of historians and students of the decline of diplomacy, it is now possible to report what is going on here and how the momentous news reaches the outer world.
