MONTE CARLO, May 11 -Time was when Italian, German and French machines crowded the road-racing circuits of Europe. Many were driven by princes. counts and marquises, others by wealthy types grown tired of the humdrum world of yachts and servants.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- A new Vertol helicopter, with two turbine engines and a capacity of twenty-four passengers, was given its first public demonstration today.
Members of the spring graduating class of the Police Academy were urged yesterday to be vigilant in protecting citizens' civil rights.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregualrly yesterday. Gains were 3 to 11 points (15 to 55 cents a bale. Two contracts were unchanged and one, the near October, dipped 1 point.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co., reporting profits running some 20 per cent ahead of a year ago, increased its regular quarterly dividend today by 5 cents a share to 30 cents. Sears' fiscal year ended with January.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 -- George Champion, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, New York City, today lashed out at supporters of "creeping inflation" who hold that "a little bit of inflation may be a good thing."
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Government reported today that an increase in jobs and a drop in unemployment were twice what could be expected for seasonal reasons alone.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Representative Charles A. Buckley, Democrat of the Bronx, challenged New York Republicans in the House today to show how the Tennessee Valley Authority had hurt New York's industries.

LOS ANGELES, May 11 -- An emotional crowd of several hundred packed the City Council chambers for hours today protesting the evictions of two families from Chavez Ravine to make way for a proposed baseball park for the Los Angeles Dodgers.

Good economic and corporation news helped the New York Stock Exchange to a strong advance yesterday. The aggregate market value rose about $1,100,000,000, with almost every important group irregular but higher on balance. An exception was drugs, which were mostly lower. Aircrafts were mostly higher.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Eisenhower will fly to New York via Newark Airport on Thursday. During his one-day visit he will help dedicate, the new Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, look in on the World Trade Fair at the Coliseum and address a scientific seminar in the evening.
The New York City Ballet performed yesterday before one of the most critical audiences it has ever faced -- the Bolshoi ballet.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The round table at Geneva, which on Soviet Russian insistence was substituted for the rectangular board preferred by the Allied foreign ministers, may help to achieve part of the objective for which it was designed by Merlin the sorcerer in the first famous use of this type of furniture.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Retail sales rose again in April after a big jump in March, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy is proposing a substantial showing of United States assistance to Euratom, the joint nuclear power program of six European nations.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, won bipartisan praise in the Senate today on his record of thirty-five years in office. Senator Styles Bridges described Mr. Hoover as "a towering bulwark of integrity, courage and bravery."
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- New York State's railroads have urged President Eisenhower to veto a bill that would add millions of dollars to their pension and unemployment insurance costs.
Volunteer hospital workers were praised yesterday for their "dedicated service," especially during the present strike in six hospitals.
ROME, May 11 -- The remains of two Roman Catholic saints who were friends in their lifetime were carried across Rome tonight and venerated in St. Peter's Square by Pope John XXIII.

GENEVA, May 11 -- The Russians gave in today, even with a certain amount of grace, on the question of the two Germanys' representation in the foreign ministers' confer ence. By the time they did, however, they had made a point that was certainly one of the major purposes of their exercise in tablesmanship.

Striking ground - service employes of the Venezuelan Government airline, Linea Aeropostal Venezolana (L. A. V.), announced yesterday that they would picket the Venezuelan Embassy in Washington, beginning today.
GENEVA, May 11 -- The United States urged its trading partners today to remove barriers against dollar imports they no longer required.
In a twin ceremony marked by traditional academic ritual, the city and state yesterday dedicated a new college and inaugurated its president.

Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was dull and featureless in most markets. Cocoa, the domestic sugar contract, copper, lead, zinc and wool rose; the world sugar months, coffee and rubber declined, and price movements for potatoes, cottonseed oil and hides were mixed.
MEXICO CITY, May 11 (AP) -- William G. Bonelli, once-powerful California politician, walked free today from the prison cell he had occupied seven months awaiting extradition action.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A bill to set up a National Institute for International Medical Research was sent to the Senate floor today with more than enough backing for passage.
The Northam Warren Corporation and Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., have decided to go their separate ways after only a year together.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 (AP) -- San Francisco overpowered Pittsburgh, 14 -- 4, tonight with a twenty-hit attack and help from the shaky Pirate infield before 13,789.
FIBERGLAS drapery fabric, although a product of modern times, does not restrict itself to contemporary designs.
FORT PILLOW, Tenn., May 11 (AP) -- About 150 convicts seized two guards at the state prison farm here tonight. They demanded a personal conference with Gov. Buford Ellington.
A man leaped 135 feet from the Brooklyn Bridge into the East River yesterday and was pulled from the water in critical condition.
The city moved yesterday to enlist the direct participation of responsible community groups in its "massive attack" on slum conditions.
Widening a street two feet can provide enough room for another lane of trucks up to eight feet wide, according to engineers in Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack's office.
If you thought the weather was rushing the season yesterday, you were right.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- Bob Buhl checked the Chicago Cubs today and the league-leading Milwaukee Braves gained an 8-1 victory. Johnny Logan and Eddie Mathews slammed homers for Milwaukee.
NEW ORLEANS, May 11 (AP) -- The New Orleans Opera House Association was involved today in an attempt to keep the Metropolitan Opera out of this onetime stronghold of opera.

BERLIN, May 11 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former United States military governor in Germany, discounted today the idea of breaking a new Soviet blockade of Berlin by means of an armored convoy to the city.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The appropriations bill passed by the House today would give the Office of Civil Defense $43,735,000, a cut of $31,235,000 from the President's request. It provides $10,000,000 for Federal contributions to states and localities for civil defense programs.
LONDON, May 11 -- Sir Winston Churchill returned to London today after a weeklong private visit to the United States with "some of my old comrades of wartime days."
International Railways of Central America still does not know whether it will be able to continue operating in Guatemala, the annual report mailed yesterday declared.
The Kings County Grand Jury investigating crime in Brooklyn public schools issued a presentment yesterday criticizing some actions of the Board of Education.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, May 8 --"Fidel Castro will fall before the year ends," according to his bitterest enemy, former President Fulgencio Batista.
HAVANA, May 11 -- Premier Fidel Castro declared today that cases pending against "war criminals" and other members of the Batista regime would be turned over to civil courts.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- State Department experts warned today that continued foreign aid to Africa and the Far East was necessary to block Communist aspirations and meet the "increasing arrogance" of Communist China.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 11 -- A revolt with the help of Cuban arms against the Paraguayan strong man, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, was discussed here in February by Paraguayan exiles and representatives of Premier Fidel Castro.

LONDON, May 11 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has urged Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to let the Soviet delegation at the conference on banning nuclear tests discuss scientific matters relating to the inspection of explosions.
GENEVA, May 11 -- Following are salient facts on the Big Four foreign ministers' conference, which opened here today:

THERE is more music in Handel's "Ezio" than in a dozen operas that hold the boards year in and year out. And yet this work, which had its premiere at the Haymarket Theatre in London in 1732, has not been performed in this country before, if the Actors' Opera archivists are correct.

PARIS, May 12 (UPI) -Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union may have opened the floodgates when he urged the Soviet people to dress more smartly in Western-type clothes. The Christian Dior fashion house will show them how.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has approved a mortgage application for a $5,000,000 limitedprofit cooperative in the Bronx to provide 292 apartments.
Support of a modernized judicial system and examination of the financing of public education were two main objectives laid before the New York State League of Women Voters yesterday.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 12 (AP) -- A Capital Airlines four-engine Constellation, landing at Kanawha Airport late today, slid down a 200-foot embankment near the end of the runway and burst into flames. Two persons were killed and six were hospitalized.

The first of two vital decisions on the city's traffic improvement future may be reached today by the Board of Estimate when it is scheduled to consider the question of recapturing the busfranchise right to make Third Avenue one-way northbound. It is the essential first step leading to the larger question of making all remaining Manhattan avenues -- except Park Avenue -- one way.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 12 -- Governor Rockefeller was joined today at his Monte Sacro farm by Oscar Ruebhausen, his legal adviser on South American business and philanthropic activities.
NEWARK, May 12 -- Plans for Newark's $5,600,000 underground parking garage at Military Park moved closer to reality today.

Queen Elizabeth has named a United States citizen, Rev. Dr. Cuthbert Aikman Simpson, to be Dean of Christ Church, Oxford, a post that combines the deanship of the Anglican cathedral and head of the college of the same name at Oxford University.
CLIFTON, N. J., May 12 -There's a bongo in the hoosegow here.
New low prices for Treasury securities were registered again yesterday.

Four six - story apartment buildings at 1439 to 1445 Boston Road, the Bronx, have been sold by the Boat Realty Corporation to investing clients of Budner Budner, lawyers. The houses, containing eighty-eight apartments and eight stores, were sold in a deal negotiated by Roche Panoff, brokers. Hyman Greenberg was the lawyer for the seller.

ALBANY, May 12 (AP) -Governor Rockefeller has appointed Keith S. McHugh, State Commerce Commissioner, to the New England Interstate Water Pollution Control Commission, the Governor's office announced today.

The creation of a government board of strategy with authority to use all Federal facilities to put the United States on the offensive in the "cold war" was advocated last night by Preston J. Moore, national commander of the American Legion.
PANAMA, May 12 -- Cuba's plea for the return of ninetythree persons who invaded Panama last month for trial in Cuba was tentatively rejected today by Panama's Foreign Minister, Miguel A. Moreno.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 12 -- On the eve of Israel's eleventh anniversary Premier David Ben-Gurion envisaged tonight a future "alliance of equals" between Israel and the Arab nations.
Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education since 1955, was re-elected yesterday to another one-year term.
GENEVA, May 12 -- The Russians in Geneva are playing for the headlines.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -Senator J. W. Fulbright told Ogden R. Reid today that to win confirmation as ambassador to Israel he must "rebut the presumption" that he is unqualified for the post.

PARIS, May 12 -- Premier Michel Debre acclaimed tonight the anniversary of the uprising by Frenchmen in Algeria on May 13, 1958. He said it marked a break with the past, and a beginning of fraternization of the Algerian European and Moslem populations and of national recovery.

Eddie Arcaro had four mounts on the nine-race card at Belmont Park yesterday. After he had won with the first three, the crowd of 18,038 had the idea he could make it four in a row. So they made him the favorite in his final shot.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- An atomic - powered airship three times as large as the blimps now in use is envisaged in a project that has been submitted to the Navy.

We deplore the fact that another well-qualified professional nurse has been forced to leave nursing because of grossly inadequate salary. Reference is made to the news item in the May 4 issue of The New York Times regarding the resignation of Mary Culkin, R. N., from her position at Bellevue Hospital.
Preliminary plans for the Department of Correction's new $7,000,000 workhouse on Rikers Island were announced yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 12 -- Leonel Brizzola, Labor party Governor of the State of Rio Grande do Sul, signed today a decree preparing for the expropriation of the local power company, which represents a United States investment.

The initiative in the negotiations for a new contract covering printers on ten New York daily newspapers shifted yesterday to the executive council of the International Typographical Union in Indianapolis.

A dress manufacturer who, the Government says, paid Johnny Dio $10,000 annually to prevent unionization of his shop, was ordered yesterday to surrender today to serve a fifteen-month sentence for contempt of court.
The Transit Authority approved contracts yesterday for the private operation of parking fields on its unused properties adjacent to outlying subway stations in Brooklyn and the Bronx.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Prices were 11 points lower to 10 points higher than on Monday at the close.
TEGUCIGALPA, May 12 -A group of armed civilians made an unsuccessful attack last night on the army garrison of Gracias, a town in northwestern Honduras and capital of Lempira state.
IN his first one-man show at the Robert Isaacson Gallery, 22 East Sixtieth Street, Thomas Clark is exhibiting paintings and drawings that place him in the old European figurative tradition.
MOSCOW, May 12 (UPI) -W. Averell Harriman arrived today for a month's stay in the country where he once served as Ambassador.

Stockholders of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company yesterday approved an increase in the authorized common shares to 6,000,000 from 3,000,000. This paved the way for the 100 per cent stock dividend formerly proposed by directors.

LAST year, when one of the finest books ever written about life and letters in the eighteenth century, "The Search for Good Sense," by F. L. Lucas, was published it failed to achieve the critical acclaim and popular attention it so richly deserved. An equally distinguished sequel to that book, "The Art of Living: Four Eighteenth Century Minds -- Hume, Horace Walpole, Burke, Benjamin Franklin," is now published.
A rifle bullet fired from a near-by rooftop by a boy smashed through a window in a Bronx junior high school yesterday. A 12-year-old girl student was slightly wounded.
Maintenance, service and clerical employes of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company will vote tonight on whether to empower their union's contract negotiating committee to call a strike.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, said today that the South would neither "accept nor submit to" attempts to carry out by force the Supreme Court school integration decision.
ANCIENT Peru and modern Brooklyn are in the news today. A stunning group of hand-printed textiles based on old Peruvian designs goes on sale this morning at the Brooklyn Museum's Gallery Shop.

ACCRA, Ghana, May 12 -The opposition United party petitioned the acting Governor General, Sir Arku Korfah, today to institute a public inquiry into allegations of bribery involving Government members. The allegations were made by a former Parliamentary Secretary, S. Iddrissu, who subsequently lost his post and was expelled from the governing convention People's party.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Senate passed today the California San Luis project bill after having eliminated a controversial section dealing with irrigation acreage limtation.
ALGIERS, May 12 -- Algiers approached a historic anniversary tonight in a mixed mood of excitement and bitterness.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Southern opponents of civil rights measures today won a two-week extension of Senate hearings on the legislation.

Large outlays for engineering and development reduced the first-quarter net income of the United Aircraft Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries from year-ago levels, the annual report, issued yesterday, showed.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 12 (AP) -- Three American violinists competing for the Queen Elisabeth Prize were among twenty-four musicians who advanced today to the second round of the international competition. Thirteen entrants were eliminated, including three Americans.

CANTON, Ohio, May 12 (AP) -- Negotiations with the striking United Rubber Workers were broken off today by the B. F. Goodrich Company because of what the company called mass picketing at its plant in Riverside, N. J.
Traffic was blocked off for a half hour on Broadway between Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets yesterday as firemen fought a one-alarm blaze on the top floor of a four-story building.

WHEN Charles Howard Silver was a boy on the lower East Side around the turn of the century, there were two professions that were held in particularly high esteem by the Jewish immigrants who then largely inhabited the area.

GENEVA, May 12 -- Delegates to international conferences and their camp followers are unpredictable and sometimes inconvenient guests, but how much inconvenience can you put up with for $50,000 a day?

WASHINGTON, May 12 -The Federal Reserve Board announced today the adoption of its proposed rules to tighten stock market margin regulations, but with some important modifications to meet industry objections.
VIENNA, May 12 -- Chancellor Julius Raab submitted the resignation of his Conservative-Socialist coalition Government to President Adolf Schaerf today.

Dr. Cecily Cannan Selby was honored last evening at a reception at the Lenox School, ,170 East Seventieth Street. About 400 persons, including parents, members of tlle board of trustees and faculty members, attended.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Republican Congressional leaders told President Eisenhower today that the sharp April drop in unemployment would be a major factor in the Administration's drive for a balanced budget.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which was offered use of the Bolshoi Ballet for the Ed Sullivan show if it would solicit $1 donations for a paytelevision company that controls TV rights, has declined the offer.

YONKERS, May 12 -- With a 29 4/5-second final quarter, Hal Frost, handled by Marcel Dostie, scored a three-quarterlength victory over Bachelor Hanover in 2:03 in the Putnam Pace before 17,957 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- The United States advised the United Nations today to consider the admission of Alaska and Hawaii as states of the Union in connection with charges of racial discrimination in America.

Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. The domestic sugar months, coffee, rubber, burlap, copper, zinc and platinum rose; hides and wool declined, and price movements were mixed for cocoa, the world sugar contracts, potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and lead.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -The nation's first astronauts, before soaring through space in a capsule, will be tumbled about on earth in a "disorientation" device resembling a cement mixer.
Negotiations for ending the hospital strike reached an impasse last night on the issue of workers' grievances.

The Public Service Commission yesterday authorizes the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to invite bidding on May 15 on $75,000,000 of 30-year refunding mortgage bonds. If the commission approves the terms of the offering, the securities will be offered to the public May 26 or May 27.

The major league baseball season opened this year on the breeze of Vice President Nixon's right-handed toss from his box seat in Washington's Griffith Stadium. No Who's Who personality was on hand, however, when the Christopher Street boys took the street against the Grove Street boys for Nineteen Fifty-nine's first nine innings of Greenwich Village stickball.
Only one district title changed hands as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were completed yesterday.
LONDON, May 12 -- With the exception of May 1957, British exports last month were the highest for any month, the Board of Trade said today.

An erroneous impression is conveyed by your editorial of May 6 on the "Tragedy in Algeria," as you imply that the world must sit helplessly by and watch a war raging for nearly five years with great losses of life and treasure.

Walter L. Jacobs, president of the Hertz Corporation, said yesterday that the company would continue to grow internally and through acquisition of existing businesses, despite the Government's antitrust suit filed May 1. Hertz is the nation's largest car and truck renting and leasing concern.
Crude oil production in Saudi Arabia in 1958 exceeded 1,000,000 barrels a day for the first time, according to the annual report of the Arabian American Oil Company.

In July, 1717, King George I of England and a royal entourage floated down the River Thames on a procession of royal barges to the accompaniment of George Frederick Handel's "Water Musick," written for the occasion and conducted by the composer.
BOSTON, May 12 (UPI) -Al Smith's two-run homer in the top of the twelfth inning gave the Chicago White Sox a 4-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight in a game that lasted 4 hours 23 minutes.

George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, appealed yesterday to members of the New York Sales Executive Club to sell an idea -- of his -- to their legislators. The Alpert idea is payment by the Government of a subsidy to commuter railroads.

More than 45,000 Westchester and Connecticut commuters were delayed during the morning rush hour yesterday when a tangle of wire cables fell across the New York Central Railroad's tracks in the lower Bronx.

MIAMI BEACH, May 12 -The Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell, denied today an accusation that the Eisenhower Administration was persecuting the International Ladies Garment Workers Union for political purposes.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, May 12 (Reuters) -- A Federal court here has ruled that Otto Strasser, one-time associate of Hitler, should be compensated for an Interior Ministry decision that refused to return to him his German citizenship, it was announced today.

CALIFON, N. J., May 12 -Three men were captured today less than an hour after the Hunterdon County Trust Company had been robbed of $14,617.

THE Dessoff Choirs, who sang Handel's "Israel in Egypt" two years ago to celebrate their twentieth year under the direction of Paul Boepple, last night at Carnegie Hall sang the great oratorio to honor the 200th anniversary of Handel's death.

ALBANY, May 12 (AP) -- Rules governing travel allowances for state employes were changed today so that a deputy tax commissioner no longer will be able to collect expense money from the state for staying at his wife's apartment.

The election of Donald C. Luce as a director of the Prudential Insurance Company of America was announced yesterday by Carrol M. Shanks, president. The election of Robert W. Harvey as a vice president also was announced.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- (UPI) -- The Department of Justice filed a motion in Federal District Court today asserting that the courts had no right to force Congress to open its payroll records.
Non-daily newspapers in this country continued to increase their circulation last year, according to a report by N. W. Ayer Sons.

GENEVA, May 12 -- Diplomats speak an argot whose euphemisms and circumlocutions are sometimes understood only by themselves. Since the meaning of words depends on the wit to connect sound with purpose, for those of us semantically blocked if not phonetically defective the language of negotiation is hard to follow.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 12 -- Sieglinde Klapprott and David Warner pleaded guilty today before County Judge C. Conrad Schneider to having had roles in the shooting of two policemen in Englewood on Jan. 29.
Herman Shumlin added a third play yesterday to his hectic production schedule for next season.
The sunny sides of the streets took on a strange, deserted look yesterday as the temperature soared to a sizzling 86.3 degrees here to mark the hottest day of the year.

Mr. and -Mrs. Michael H. Ross of Brooklyn have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, M.iss Judy Joy Ross, to Dr. Ivan Kenneth Goldberg. He 'is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Goldberg, also of Brooklyn.

OTTAWA, May 12 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government will demand proof of financial responsibility and definite work programs before permits are assigned for gas and oil exploration in Canada's Arctic islands, Alvin Hamilton, Northern Affairs Minister, said last night.

The United Printers and Publishers Corporation, which occupies a floor in Canada House at 680 Fifth Avenue, corner of Fifty-fourth Street, has leased additional space there through Cushman Wakefield Inc., renting agent.

NEWARK, May 12 -- New Jersey's eighty-two-year-old law restricting the sale of contraceptives was declared unconstitutional today by Essex County Judge Walter H. Conklin.

BOSTON, May 12 (UPI) -- The world record-holder for the high jump, John Thomas, who underwent plastic surgery on his injured jumping foot fifteen days ago, has dropped out of Boston University.

ALTHOUGH the physical production is slight, the point of view is sharp in "The Nervous Set," which opened at Henry Miller's last evening. In both words and music it has a shrewd slant on contemporary attitudes.

The steel industry produced 11,272,000 tons of raw steel last month -- more than in any other April, and second only to the record of 11,567,745 tons poured in the longer month of March of this year.

The City Health Department reported yesterday a sharp increase in infant mortality. It directed its nurses and physicians to visit homes and hospitals where young babies have died this year to determine the causes.
The picketing of a Queens cafe by a Teamsters Union local over the removal of two coinoperated devices is being investigated by Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor.

One unpleasant thought to contemplate as the vacation season is about to begin is still another increase in the gasoline tax. Yet such an increase in the Federal tax is much the best way out of the impasse that now threatens the huge Federal-aid highway program.

Joseph Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, barred by Park Commissioner Robert Moses from giving free performances in Central Park this summer, may take his company outside of New York City.
The two fatal crashes of Capital Airlines planes yesterday came after a year of flying by the line without a fatality.

Cincinnati borrowed $26,900,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. Of the bonds sold, $2,950,000 were secured by unlimited taxes and will come due from 1960 to 1984. The balance of $23,950,000 is secured by limited taxes, with the maturities running from 1960 to 1989.

AN exhibition entitled "Recent Sculpture, U. S. A." will open to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art. The display, organized by the Junior Council of the museum, has been installed in the ground floor galleries adjoining the garden with a few pieces on the terrace.

LONDON, May 12 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran chided 150 correspondents here today for failing to ask him any difficult or embarrassing questions. Then he kept the news conference in session at the Iranian Embassy until he got what he asked for.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -Baudouin I, King of the Belgians, met the Congress, the Cabinet and the Supreme Court of the United States today. They appeared to like him tremendously.
Members of the gifts commit-! tee for the twelfth annual Sal-I ute to Summer tea dance next Monday met yesterday afternoon in the home of Mrs, E. Richard Ebe at the Sherry-Netherland.
State Controller Arthur Levitt refused yesterday to sell $50,000,000 of New York Thruway revenue bonds on terms that would have incurred an interest cost of 4.3029 per cent.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 12 -- Regulations restricting move-I merits of foreign nationals in' Indonesia "in the interest of preserving 'internal security" were issued today by Lieut. Gen. Ahdul Haris Nasution, Army Chief of Staff.

RABAT, Morocco, May 12 -After having forbidden a concert in Casablanca, whose proceeds were to go to public schools, the Moroccan Government permitted the Westminster Singers from the United States to sing here in the capital last night at a suburban theatre.

CLEVELAND, May 12 (AP) -- Subsidiaries of the Southern Company, big utility holding company, plan $514,000,000 in capital expenditures for 1959 through 1961, Harllee Branch Jr., president, told the Cleveland Society of Security Analysts today.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 12 (AP) -- Directors of the American Fletcher National Bank and Trust Company and the Fidelity Bank and Trust Company voted today to merge under the national charter of the Fletcher Bank.
FORT PILLOW, Tenn., May 12 (UPI) -- Rebellious convicts surrendered without bloodshed today after a fourteenhour riot at the state prison farm here.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 12 (UPI) -- Petitions asking for the recall of all six members of the Little Rock School Board were filed today.
Wheat moved briskly ahead in a surprising flurry of broad support on the Board of Trade here today. Profit taking turned corn and soybean futures prices back in late dealings.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -The Justice Department appealed to the Supreme Court today a Georgia Federal judge's decision that held unconstitutional the voting-rights provisions of the 1957 Civil Rights Act.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 (UPI) -- Fred Astaire asked the Television Academy of Arts and Sciences today to take back the controversial "best actor" Emmy voted him by members.
A criminal contempt conviction against Harry J. Shapolsky, who was fined $4,000 last Friday for rent gouging, was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 12 -The National Planning Conference was warned today that the nation faced a critical and growing shortage of open space for recreation.
LONDON, May 12 -- Britain announced today plans for a space research program that would begin with the development of an earth satellite that might be launched with a United States rocket.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -The House Judiciary Committee approved today a states' rights bill that the Justice Department has attacked as "the most hazardous'' measure before Congress.
" Something to drink?" said the Wall Street capitalist to the Russian dancer who sat in the shade under a penthouse awning yesterday.

As planes overhead streaked to and from La Guardia Airport and other fields, a group of boys worked busily on the ground yesterday preparing for the day when they will take their place in aviation.
LANSING, Mich., May 12 -Gov. G. Mennen Williams has made a surprising switch regarding payless paydays for state employes.

Four four-story store and apartment buildings at 814 to 822 Second Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-fourth Street, have been sold by Harry Horwitz, realty operator. They front 100 feet on the avenue and were purchased by an investor through Emanuel Schwartz, broker. E. Louis Gothelf was the attorney for the seller.
GENEVA, May 12 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, never much of a clotheshorse in his United Nations days, has blossomed out suddenly as the most clothesconscious of the foreign ministers in Geneva.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -The United States officially welcomed today the move by Britain to cooperate with this country in the scientific exploration of space.
The powerful Democratic organization of Mayor George E. Brunner lost control of the Camden city government yesterday for the first time in twenty-four years.
A Navy vessel appeared yesterday to have cured a common disease of tankers -- "eight-year rust."
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- A legislator who is a former Army colonel questioned today why the White House should have sixty-two enlisted men assigned there as chauffeurs and messboys.
HENDERSON, N. C., May 12 (AP) -- National Guardsmen moved into Henderson today under orders to stop violence in the strike at the Harriet-Henderson cotton mills.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The State Department lifted today the ban on travel to Bulgaria by United States citizens.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department Agriculture follows:
The city's cultural needs must rank in importance with more material features of life, Mayor Wagner said last night.

BERLIN, May 12 -- On the tenth anniversary of the end of the Soviet blockade of Berlin, Western military and political leaders reaffirmed today the West's determination to defend the freedom of the city.
A CONCERT devoted to the memory of Erich Itor Kahn was presented last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -Following is the text of the speech in English by King Baudouin of the Belgians before a joint session of Congress today:
GENEVA, May 12 -- The threepower conference for a ban on nuclear weapons tests agreed today to recess until not later than June 8.
CAIRO, May 12 (AP) -- The Communists in the Sudan are looking for their own version of Iraq's Communist-backed Premier, Abdul Karim Kassim, to spearhead plans for seizing power.
Robert Mitchell, a scenic designer of 16 Minetta Lane, lost his battle yesterday against what he had called a collection of "cigar store Indians."

Southwestern Electric Power Company, subsidiary of Central and South West Corporation, borrowed $16,000,000 yesterday on thirty-year first mortgage bonds at a net interest cost of about 5.09 per cent.
Frank Gifford, who reached football stardom several years ago as a halfback, will try for the quarterback post when the Giants begin training this summer.
NEW HAVEN, May 12 -Aristide Maillol's sculpture, L'Air, a monumental figure symbolizing flight, was put on display today in the new outdoor sculpture court of the Yale University Art Gallery.
The Board of Education yesterday denied charges by the Kings County grand jury that it had permitted the illegal distribution of insurance applications.
Dudley B. Bonsal was re-elected last night for a second one-year term as president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
Missile and electronics stocks fell out of favor yesterday, but the market as a whole pushed forward, and the industrial average made a new historic high.
Employes of Eastern Air Lines will meet today at the organization's reservation center, 50 West Forty-fourth Street, to donate blood to the Red Cross.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday the consolidation of the youth squads and the Juvenile Aid Bureau task force into one patrol within the police Youth Division.

THE New York City Ballet returned to the City Center last night to open the third and last section of its tenth anniversary celebration. The company was in high spirits, so was the repertory, and so, in fact, was the audience, which made a fine evening of it all around.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today that the company expects to show a "very decided im provement" financially this year, compared with 1958.

Come late November, the Army and Navy football teams will fight like Kilkenny cats to beat each other, but yesterday their new young coaches met face to face for the first time and all but fell into one another's arms.

EASTCHESTER, N. Y., May 12 -- A new suburban store of Weber Heilbroner was opened here today at 726 White Plains Post Road. It is in a rapidly growing shopping area adjacent to a Lord Taylor department store.
The Roxy Theatre has announced its schedule of feature attractions for spring and summer exhibition.

S. W. Cantor, president of Interstate Department Stores, believes he has solved the problem of discount house competition. He announced yesterday that Interstate would open eight new stores by the end of 1960 selling a range of soft and hard lines at substantially lower mark-ups than the conventional department store.
ALAMEDA, Calif., May 12 -The Federal Government seized the 650-passenger liner Leilani at her berth at the Todd Shipyards Corporation's plant here today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower proposed today the shifting of certain land-management responsibilities from the Interior Department to the Agriculture Department.
BALTIMORE, May 12 -- A Capital Airlines plane disintegrated in the air during a thunderstorm north of here today. Twenty-seven passengers and the crew of four were killed.
Striking hospital workers picketed Roosevelt Hotel last night during the annual dinner of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
The job of general chairman of the 1959 United States Open golf championship has brought Walter Kolb many interesting experiences. "But I wouldn't take it again for $100,000," he said yesterday.
Cardinal Spellman presented gold cups yesterday to four winners in the annual essay contest of the Catholic Youth Organization of the Archdiocese of New York.

NORTH MASSAPEQUA, L. I., May 12 -- Twenty-four faculty members at the Southedge Elementary School wore white gloves to cover their blisters in demonstrating the ancient art of bell ringing here tonight. They took part in the school's Fine Arts' Festival.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 (UPI) -- A left-hander, Danny McDevitt, aided by his own hitting and that of Norm Larker, led the Dodgers to a 2-1 victory over the Phillies tonight. The triumph enabled Los Angeles to take a halfgame lead over the Milwaukee Braves in the National League.

Two gala previews of an exhibition called Forms from Israel will be held this evening and tomorrow afternoon at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts under the patronage of Mrs. Vanderbilt Webb, president of the American Craftsmen's Council and founder of the museum.

EGGPLANTS, plump and handsome with their glossy, purple-black skins, are now arriving in quantity from Florida. Hence, home cooks might find this an opportune time to experiment with some of the many marvelous dishes based on this vegetable.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -Secretary Arthur S. Flemming sent to Congress today drafts of two bills that would substantially reduce school aid in areas having large Federal installations.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 12 -- In unmistakable terms, Stamford's garbage collectors called attention today to a situation they have long protested.

VAROUJAN KODJIAN, violinist, made his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. An Armenian from Beirut, Lebanon, Mr. Kodjian graduated at 16 from the Paris Conservatory and then was sent by the Lebanese Government to study at the Cartis Institute in Philadelphia.
The Association of Casualty and Surety Companies elected a new president yesterday, and voted to join the proposed Insurance Information Institute.
The second day of strippeddown negotiations for a new steel wage contract ended yesterday with no apparent headway toward an agreement.

An abortive attempt to start a proxy contest at the annual meeting of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad was made yesterday by a half dozen irate stockHolders opposed to the company's plans to merge with the Erie Railroad.
New York University held cornerstone ceremonies yesterday for Nichols Hall, the new home of its Graduate School of Business Administration at 100 Trinity Place.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 12 -- Jim Iverson, a Columbia senior, won the Metropolitan Golf Association's intercollegiate individual title for the second straight year today with a par-equaling 72 on the Seawane Harbor Club course.
The Waterfront Commission is seeking to revoke the registration of a longshoreman being questioned about missing jewelry.

Abba Eban, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, was honored last night at a reception in the Commodore Hotel by the American Zionist Council Mr. Eban leaves for Israel shortly to take up new duties.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -Surgeons removed part of the left lung of Gen. Nathan F. Twining today.
A tentative agreement for exchange of professors has been reached between Harvard University and Leningrad State University.
Two high city officials differed sharply last night over the plan now pending before the City Planning Commission for comprehensive rezoning of the city.

THE dressiest window blinds in the world -- those made by Dorothy Liebes -- are now available in stores. Formerly made-to-order through decorators, a new collection of the blinds designed for Edward Fields, rug manufacturer, can be ordered here at Lord Taylor.
The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will hold a special convention, probably in January, to elect a second Suffragan Bishop to assist the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan.

PITTSBURGH, May 12 -- Dr. Henry Steele Commager, historian, called today for the establishment of international universities along the lines of UNESCO, the World Court or the World Health Organization.

New savings that individuals channeled into securities fell to $600,000,000 during 1958, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported yesterday. This was $6,300,000,000 less than in 1957 and the lowest amount since 1954.
PRATICA DI MARE, Italy, May 12 -- The long-lost sanctuary of Lavinium, linked with the mythical origins of Rome, is believed to have been rediscovered here.
A strong plea for continued exemption of deep-sea shipping from the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 was made yesterday by a shipping industry leader.
A Bronx lawyer dissolved his fifteen-year-old law partnership yesterday to qualify for election to the City Council.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A five-man steering committee evolved a peace formula today for ending partisan bickering in the infant bipartisan organization of Senators and Representatives from New York State.
GENEVA, May 12 -- Sir John Charles, leader of the British delegation, was elected president of the Twelfth World Health Assembly that began a three-week session here today.

THE average salesgirl will rarely argue if a customer wants to buy the most unflattering dress in the world. More eager to make a sale than to educate the woman on what to wear, she will understandably hold her tongue.
The election of Rufus T. Burton and Willem Holst as directors of the StandardVacuum Oil Company was announced yesterday by H. F. Priorleau, president.
LONDON, May 12 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said today he thought some compromise agreement for stopping nuclear tests would be worked out in the next few months.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -The juvenile delinquent is being used by frustrated adults as a handy target for aggression." a report issued by the National Education Association aid today.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The glowing reports over the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway have nearly hidden the fact that most Great Lakes and St. Lawrence river ports in the United States will not be able to handle fully loaded big ships Engineers calling for work to bring United States harbors up for several years.
The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will hold a special convention, probably in January, to elect a second Suffragan Bishop to assist the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan.

PITTSBURGH, May 12 -- Dr. Henry Steele Commager, historian, called today for the establishment of international universities along the lines of UNESCO, the World Court or the World Health Organization.

New savings that individuals channeled into securities fell to $600,000,000 during 1958, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported yesterday. This was $6,300,000,000 less than in 1957 and the lowest amount since 1954.

BUENOS AIRES, May 13 -- President Arturo Frondizi bowed to military pressure today and severed official relations with Rogelio Frigerio, his chief negotiator in the past for Peronist support and more recently for United States capital.

The Karen Horney Clinic will benefit from the theatre party to be held by friends and members of the board of the clinic at next Wednesday's performance of "A Raisin in the Sun" at the Barrymore Theatre.

An appeal for a more scientific approach to marketing, and less reliance on instinct, hunches and guesses, was voiced yesterday by Everett C. Drake, president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., textile concern.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- A Federal grand jury today indicted a seafood plant to which Government agents had traced shipments of spoiled flounder. Just before Easter the flounder had caused an epidemic of sickness, a widespread scare and allegedly the death of a child.
PARIS, May 13 -- There were not many persons on this hot, sunny day in Paris who observed the first anniversary of the May 13 uprising by Frenchmen in Algeria.

TORONTO, May 13 (Canadian Press) -- An insurance company, in an "underworld" deal, has bought back $1,409,787 worth of stolen bonds at 10 cents on the dollar, Attorney General Kelso Roberts of Ontario, said today.

LOS ANGELES, May 13 (AP) -- The Arechiga family, which has refused to move off land earmarked for the Los Angeles Dodgers' new baseball stadium and recreation park, today was revealed to own considerable property.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa approved a mortgage of $3,950,000 for a $4,465,000 cooperative in the Flushing-Hillcrest section of Queens yesterday. It was the second mortgage application for a limited-profit cooperative to be approved by the city in two days.
Probation services in the city's Domestic Relations, Magistrates' and Special Sessions Courts have been found in a new survey to be "totally inadequate to meet existing needs."
LANSING, Mich, May 13 -- Michigan's 27,000 payless state employes received a temporary respite today. They will get their checks tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

This might almost be called a continued story from last week's column on German shepherds. The column dealt with comments by Marie J. Leary of Greenwich, Conn., a leading authority, on undesirable characteristics in some of the dogs brought from Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, May 6:

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. is forming a new company to develop advance systems and to produce equipment for the safe recovery, tracking and location of missile and space vehicle components and payloads.

Just when Hedley Woodhouse vas "going good" he had the misfortune to fall off the favorite in the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. The jockey had won two races earlier in the day, and the crowd of 17,192 was confident that he could take the six-furlong main event with Colin McLeod Jr.'s Besomer.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today defnded the use of military personnel as White House and Pentagon chauffeurs and waiters. He said it would cost the taxpayers a lot more money to replace them with civilians.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 13 (Reuters ) -- The United States' "protectionist and discriminatory" shipping policy was attacked today by H. Van Lennep, chairman of the Netherlands Shipowners' Association. He ranged over a wide area of complaints against American policy at the association's annual meeting.

A sweeping denial was made yesterday by Johnny Edmunds, a 29-year-old harness racing trainer-driver, of charges that he and Frank Safford, his former employer, ever had "injected" a horse. Edmunds, now training and driving his own stable of standardbreds, had been subpoenaed to appear at Safford's hearing of an appeal for reinstatement as a driver here.

The retiring Israeli Ambassador to this country, Abba Eban, will be honored this evening at Madison Square Garden by thousands of volunteer workers for the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York. Ambassador Eban has not only served his country well as a diplomat, but through the years has made innumerable friends here for himself and for Israel.
New facilities and new approaches to the problems of chronic disease and disability will be needed all the more now that the number of older persons is increasing. Dr. Howard A. Rusk said yesterday.

Sales of the eight major department stores and their branches in the New York area gained 2 per cent in April over the 1958 month, to achieve a record sales volume for the month, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The public "is becoming offended, damaged and hurt" by the noise of modern aircraft, E. R. Quesada, head of the Federal Aviation Agency, said last night.
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by Lbe Department of Agriculture follows:

PRINCESS GIOVANNA CARACCIOLO OF CAROSA revises the old Italian saying, "See Naples and Die," to "See New York and Live." Five days in Manhattan have convinced this Italian fashion designer that, to make clothes for the present generation, it is necessary to know New York.
The Bayanihan Dance Company from the Philippines will be presented in a New York season at the Winter Garden Theatre beginning Oct. 13 under the auspices of S. Hurok.

A blind spot in the labor law put the State Labor Relations Board in the unhappy position yesterday of thwarting the efforts of Kings County District Attorney Edward S. Silver to stop mobsters from using a union "front" to seize control of a $10,000,000-a-year industry.
Mike Wallace will be the host of a live panel show scheduled to start on the National Broadcasting Company television network July 2 and be seen Thursdays at 8 P. M.
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Merger talks between the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers and the International Chemical Workers Union collapsed today.

LONDON, May 13 (Reuters) -- Tass, the official Soviet press service, denounced today the ceremonies marking the tenth anniversary of the Berlin airlift and contended that they had been an attempt "to exert definite pressure" on the East-West foreign ministers' conference.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Eisenhower prodded Congress in a special message today to deal quickly with critical problems in three fields.

In flagrant violation and disregard of a temporary restraining order a union purporting to represent certain hospital employes has nevertheless declared and is now engaged in a serious and heartless strike. By reason of the enjoining order this strike is illegal and in violation of existing law.
A milestone in the city's cultural annals will be reached today when President Eisenhower breaks ground for the $75,000,000 Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Rubber prices dropped on the Commodity Exchange of New York yesterday, following reports that Communist China had completed her purchasing program in Malaya. The London and Singapore markets also were easier. Consumption figures are expected to decline because of strikes in this country.

While waiting to get a big enough Broadway house for his prospective musical, "Viva!," Paul Gregory has become immersed in "The Pink Jungle." The latest development regarding the latter is the signing of Ginger Rogers to star in Leslie Stevens' satirical treatment of the beauty industry.
WILLIAM CONGDON's recent paintings at the Betty Parsons Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, refer to many picturesque places, among them Egypt, Guatemala and Italy.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 13 -- Israel celebrated her eleventh birthday with an abbreviated display of her military strength today and a recounting of her accomplishments as one of the world's youngest nations.

May 13, 1958, is one of the outstanding dates in contemporary French history, for that was the day the curtain rose on the drama that led to the return of General de Gaulle. Anniversaries are convenient mileposts from which the observer can look back and take stock, as France, Algeria and the rest of us did yesterday.

In recent weeks Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of Stadium Concerts, received thousands of letters urging continuance of the concerts when she was in conflict with the Musicians Union over the new 1959 contract for the Stadium Symphony Orchestra. Now the labor difficulties have been resolved, but Mrs. Guggenheimer needs help of a more tangible kind if New York's famed symphonic series is to be presented this summer at the Lewisohn Stadium.

PARIS, May 13 -- The American authors of "My Fair Lady" called on all other American authors, composers and artists today to join in common action aimed at forcing the Soviet Union to adhere to international copyright treaties.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, announced yesterday it had started on a $375,000,000 program for capital improvements between now and 1963 -- the largest for any comparable period in the company's history.

Net income of the International Paper Company in the first quarter was 11 per cent higher than in the 1958 period. Sales rose 9 per cent, John H. Hinman, chairman, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.
" COSI FAN TUTTE," as done at the Hunter College Playhouse by the Hunter College Opera Association last night, proved to be delightful.
Stocks rose to a new historic high yesterday in moderately, active trading. Steel, chemical, electronic and motor issues pushed the market onto new ground.

The Bank of Nova Scotia, Toronto, announced yesterday an agreement with Samuel Montagu Co., Ltd., London bullion merchant, for the issuance of interchangeable gold certificates. The step, which will facilitate trading in gold, is expected to link Canadian gold production more closely to the world's principal market for the metal.

WEST MILFORD, N. J., May 13 -- Two youths who were killed and three others who were seriously injured in a car crash on Warwick Turnpike Sunday were drinking in New York State before the accident, the Jersey State Police said today.

HENDERSON, N. C., May 13 (AP) -- The North Carolina National Guard took strong measures tonight to stop recurring violence at the struck Harriet-Henderson cotton mills. The Guard had powerful backing from a Superior Court judge.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission sustained today its chairman's ruling that patent history should not be explored to determine whether imported automatic sewing machines infringed domestic patents.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Administration asked Congress today to authorize a limited program for the preservation of the nation's vanishing shoreline.

SIR ARTHUR WING PINERO'S seventy - four - year-old farce, "The Magistrate," not seen here professionally since 1897, was revived arena-style last evening in a converted night club once called the Old Rumanian.

CROTON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., May 13 -- The reconstructed Van Cortlandt Manor House and its subsidiary buildings on Albany Post Road will be ready for exhibition next month. The house, begun in 1680, is reputedly the oldest remaining structure of its kind in the nation.
Ottawa, May 13 (CP) -- Priority is to be given to Canadians and United States bulk carriers passing through the Welland Canal, Transport Minister George Hees said today.
GENEVA, May 13 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter will present to the Big Four foreign ministers' conference tomorrow what is officially called "the Western peace plan" for Germany and Europe.

Thomas D. Zumbo of United Press International was installed last night as president of the Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City. The ceremony took place at a dinner in the Manhattan Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- Among the mental and spiritual tortures that nurture ulcers in the movie world is the screening. For the screening poses, in an acute form, the problem of how to practice deception without dishonesty.
The State of New Jersey borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the first stage of a new water supply program.

The sixth annual spring men's field hockey tournament will be run Saturday and Sunday at Rye, N. Y., with at least nine teams competing. The tourney is under the direction of the American Field Hockey Association.
DETROIT, May 13 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers today sold Larry Doby to the Chicago White Sox.
The Newspaper Fund, Inc., announced yesterday the award of summer fellowships in journalism to 140 high school teachers from forty-two states.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 13 -- Lieut. Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, the army chief of staff, has asserted that the leaders of the fifteen-month-old rebellion in Sumatra and Celebes have acted to establish contact with the Central Government to end hostilities.
The pitching treat of Bob Turley opposing Herb Score, following Tuesday night's slugging festival, failed to come off at Yankee Stadium yesterday.
LONDON, May 13 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia demanded today admission to the foreign ministers' meeting in Geneva if it were expanded beyond the Big Four."

A jet-propelled American speed boat will be built this summer with the goal of breaking the British-held world record for hydroplanes. At a luncheon yesterday at the New York Athletic Club officials of the Aluminum Company of America introduced Guy Lombardo, Freeport (L. I.) band leader, retired race driver and once a Gold Cup winner, as the possible pilot of the new aluminum-clad craft, which will be christened Tempo Alcoa.
A new effort to help city pupils with serious emotional problems has been started by the Board of Education' Bureau of Child Guidance.
FOOTHILLS, India, May 13 (UPI) -- The first party of Tibetan refugees arrived at the Indian reception center today and told of Communist Chinese brutalities and machine-gunning.

BILLY MARTIN made a mock obeisance as he hurried past the closed door of the Yankee clubhouse, heading for the Cleveland dressing room at the far end of the Stadium catacombs. Behind that closed door Casey Stengel was delivering a blistering oration to his befuddled heroes, not yet aware that yesterday's game with the Indians had been postponed.
The shotgun bandit, who held up the Manhattan Hotel Tuesday and stole $29,000, turned out to be a former employe of the hotel, the police said yesterday. Most of the money was recovered.

AS spokesmen for 4,000 organized employes in private, nonprofit social and community agencies in New York City, we wish to congratulate The New York Times for its editorial of May 9 questioning the exemption of nonprofit hospitals from the provisions of the state Labor Law.

GENEVA, May 13 (UPI) -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko predicted today that the forthcoming Moscow visit of Vice President Richard M. Nixon would be a "most favorable factor" in helping East-West negotiations.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 13 (AP) -- The Tennessee Valley Authority disclosed today that some United States manufacturers, primarily in the electrical field, had regularly submitted identical bids on the agency's purchases of equipment and materials.
Rockaway Beach property owners expressed indignation yesterday over the latest delay in taking title to land for two proposed Title 1 housing projects.
Thirty-two crab apple trees -- but no crab apples -- will officially become part of the Park Avenue decor in a ceremony May 26. Many of the trees were planted yesterday.

The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that production of crude oil and condensate in the week ended last Friday averaged 7,200,225 barrels a day, 87,600 more than in the preceding week. Output for the corresponding week last year was 6,249,685 barrels a day.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today on highway taxes, home mortgages and surplus wheat:

The importance of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is signified by President Eisenhower's presence this morning at the ground-breaking ceremonies. The first step toward the building of a new Philharmonic Hall will be taken today, but this is only the beginning of a grand undertaking that should have a wide-ranging and beneficent influence on the artistic life of the city and the nation.
THE three top winners of the General Federation of Women's Clubs second national Fashion-Sewing Contest were announced yesterday after a final national judging at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
MINEOLA, L. I., May 13 -- Two of the five Nassau County school districts that rejected proposed budgets at annual meetings on May 6 have set new dates for considering the budgets.
HONG KONG, May 12 -- The Peiping Government is using an all-embracing system of contracts this year to obtain maximum performance from the newly organized communes.

Directors of the United States Gypsum Company voted yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly 50-cent dividend, both payable July 1. Last year the company paid two extras, one of 35 cents in October and one of 50 cents at the end of the year.
Three New York University professors were named yesterday as the first winners of the Great Teacher Awards of the university's Alumni Federation.

Children's books have come of age. A list of children's bestsellers has appeared in a supplement devoted to children's books that arrived with the Sunday newspaper. There is certainly a good deal of economic sense to this because wise publishers long ago realized that children's books could represent an important part of their output.
A marketing expert urged business men yesterday to "apply more creativeness" in attempting to move goods.
Following are salient 'acts on the foreign ministers' conference at United Nations headquarters in Geneva:
Moving day for the victory statue in the middle of Hillside Avenue in Jamaica, Queens, may come before July 1.

TOKYO, May 13 -- The limit of Japan's salmon catch for this year has been set at 85,000 tons in the northwest Pacific waters regulated by the Japanese-Soviet fishery pact. The ceiling, 23 per cent lower than the 1958 figure, was agreed on here today after four months of negotiations.
State Controller Arthur Levitt disclosed plans yesterday to establish a financial advisory service in his office to counsel state school districts contemplating the sale of bonds.
A 22-year-old truck driver was acquitted on charges of first-degree murder last night by a Kings County jury after eight hours of deliberation.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 13 -- The Netherlands confirmed tonight that it wanted to state its views at the foreign ministers' conference in Geneva if the number of participants was increased.

Blyth Co. Inc., Lazard Freres Co. and First Boston Corporation, jointly are offering today $15,000,000 of first mortgage 5 per cent bonds of Idaho Power Company at 100.777 to yield 4.95 per cent to maturity in 1989.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Eisenhower expressed the hope today that the Soviet Union would quickly abandon its propaganda tactics at Geneva and permit the foreign ministers to begin fruitful negotiations.

CHEESE is milk in its most sophisticated form, but people who drink the most milk eat the least cheese. This is the observation of Jean Mittaine, vice president of the Roquefort Association of France, who visited this country recently as a representative of his industry.
The Brooklyn Heights Association has urged Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate to lease a city-owned waterfront property to the Port of New York Authority.
Four savings banks here made mortgage commitments amounting to $5,320,000 yesterday for permanent financing of the cooperative housing project in the Lincoln Square development.
The rush to lay in substantial steel inventories in advance of a possible strike is not disturbing the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The House Interior Committee approved today the California San Luis project bill, including a section exempting the state-operated portion from Federal restrictions on irrigation acreage.
Twenty-four passengers suffered minor injuries yesterday when a BMT subway train rammed another train that had made an emergency stop in a Brooklyn station.

POLLOCK have moved belatedly into the Montauk Point area and at last there is something to think about besides flounder and cod out there. This is a somewhat neglected game fish. It should provide good sport for three weeks or so.
GENEVA, May 13 -- The conversations taking place here among the four foreign ministers have about the same degree of spontaneity as a television commercial.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 (AP) -- Warren Spahn, Milwaukee's matchless southpaw, tonight wrapped up the 250th victory of his major league career -- a mark reached by only two other National League lefthanders -- by allowing seven hits en route to a 3-2 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday record first-quarter net income, 6 per cent more than that in the 1958 period.
A Riverside Drive rooming house whose owners are charged with 101 housing law violations was involved in another legal maneuver yesterday.
A program to educate tenants as well as landlords in their responsibilities for preventing the spread of slums has been started by the Buildings Department and a Brooklyn settlement house.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The constitutional amendment against more than two Presidential terms is something that should be changed slowly if at all, President Eisenhower said today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The President, saying he finds "rather baffling" some of the Senate tactics against confirming his appointees, told a news conference questioner today he thought the "kind of [Democratic] attacks * * * upon their integrity" were "something that must have some kind of purpose other than mere searching into their competence."

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies were 5.4 per cent better in April than in 1958, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times. For the first four months of 1959 there was a gain of 9.2 per cent.

The stockholders of Black, Starr Gorham, Inc., jewelers and silversmiths, elected four new directors at the annual meeting yesterday. They are Mrs. Ottavio Prochet, John Nicholas Brown, Otis L. Guernsey and Lester F. Morse.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday granted world junior welterweight championship recognition to twelve-round match between Carlos Ortiz of New York and Kenny Lane of Muskegon, Mich. The fight is listed for Friday, June 12, at Madison Square Garden.

There were times during the years 1955-57 when news of a further increase in the volume of installment credit outstanding would have been regarded as grounds for varying degrees of apprehension. HAVANA, May 13 (AP) -- Most of the companies that were confiscated were in the construction business, but a number of engineering concerns and investment companies, two hotels and two airlines also were seized. MYRTLE BEACH, S. C., May 13 -- Three jet fighters, part of a night training flight, suddenly whipped out of formation early today and hurtled seaward, crashing one after another into the Atlantic Ocean. All three pilots were killed.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee moved today to force the Pentagon to choose between two anti-aircraft missile weapons the Army's Nike-Hercules and the Air Force's Bomarc.
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Charley Scott scored a first-round knockdown and went on to gain a split ten-round decision over Ralph Dupas in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

HAVANA, May 13 -- The Government confiscated today the holdings of 117 companies and eighteen individuals. They were charged with crimes against the national economy and with enriching themselves illegally under the protection of the regime of deposed President Fulgencio Batista.

The children's summer vacation program of the Divine Providence Shelter will be aided by the eighth annual Maytime Fashion Festival and Card Party. The event will be held in the Terrace Room of the Statler Hilton Saturday afternoon.

An association of automobile radiator repair dealers was accused in Supreme Court yesterday of violating the state's antimonopoly law by conspiring to fix prices and to intimidate shops and association members.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- John L. Lewis suggested today that Congress file/ and forget all pending labor reform bills. Some of the bills are worse than others, he said, but all are weapons of the rich calculated to oppress the poor. Sugar Ray Robinson offered last night to post a guarantee of "from $200,000 to $250,000" for Carmen Basilio if the challenger would sign for a middle-weight title fight at the Philadelphia Municipal Stadium Sept. 21.

Police Capt. Henry J. Mulhearn, appointed head of the merged youth investigation section on Tuesday, unexpectedly applied for retirement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The State Department is planning to establish a new organization to study all phases of the economic and political offensive of the Soviet Union and Communist China and to work out plans for opposing it.

As a long-time observer of our foreign policy I become more and more discouraged over its outworn concepts and its failure to grasp fundamental needs and aspirations.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower acknowledged today that the Supreme Court's school segregation decision had stirred both acclaim and resentment. He said laws without public support would not end racial discrimination.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 4 -- Baseball in South Africa goes back to 1899. There are team pictures of mustached and side-whiskered players with folded arms, crossed bats and the grim expressions of American stars of the Cincinnati Red Stocking days.

Richard Kinney of Winnetka, Ill., said yesterday that as far back as he could remember he had been told "when in Rome do as the Romans do." So, "now I intend to find out just what it is that the Romans do," he said.

TOKYO, May 13 -- A Pacific and Asian dockworkers' conference called here by Harry Bridges, labor leader on the United States West Coast, adopted a resolution today asking the International Labor Organization to send a committee to investigate labor conditions in Okinawa and Cambodia.

A new move by the Teamsters Union to be certified as bargaining representative for 20,000 taxicab drivers here will be made today at the regional offices of the National Labor Relations Board.

MIAMI BEACH, May 13 -- The leader of 13,500,000 unionized workers invited business today into the political arena.
ROME, May 13 -- The Government promised today to revamp its sprawling state industries, transforming them into a "glass house."

United States securities settled further into a 4 per cent yield area yesterday as professional dealers continued to mark down Treasury issues. The market was almost devoid of bids from the outside.

LONDON, May 13 (Reuters) -- In the House of Commons today Harold Watkinson, Minister of Transport and Aviation, said that "we hope soon to make powerful representations to the American Government" on the subject of flags of convenience.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board urged Congress today to step in and halt "cutthroat" competition among private air carriers bidding for military freight and passenger business.

Cardinal Spellman, a frequent visitor to service men abroad, was honored last night as "an old soldier of Christianity."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 10 to 22 points (50 cents to $1.10 a bale) yesterday. The new July contract showed the greatest loss.

Motorists in thirteen Eastern states began yesterday to get their first look at the new Chevron gasoline identification signs. Properties on York Avenue passed to new control in two separate deals reported yesterday. The site will be improved with tall apartment houses.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- A few little things went wrong on this last day in Washington for King Baudouin of the Belgians, but he seemed to care less than anyone else.

GENEVA, May 13 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of statements by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter of the United States, Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville of France and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union at today's meeting of foreign ministers.

Some of Justice William O. Douglas' most important Supreme Court opinions will be issued next Thursday by Doubleday and will be called "Douglas of the Supreme Court." The opinions cover the major public issues presented before the court during Justice Douglas' twenty years of service.

Several soloists for the 1959 season of summer concerts at Lewisohn Stadium have been announced. They include Gina Bachauer, Dorothy Simpson Smith, Renato Premezzi and Anna Xydis, pianists; Mary Curtis-Verna, soprano; Eartha Kitt, vocalist, and Charles K. L. Davis, tenor.

An employe aboard the liner Constitution changed ships at sea yesterday to join his wife aboard the French Line's Liberte for a long-awaited European vacation. He spent about three hours aboard a pilot ship stationed at Ambrose Lightship between ships.

THE fundamental message of Arnold J. Toynbee's historical writing seems to be that no tree ever reaches the sky. Nations grow, nations wither. We have all suspected as much. And Dr. Toynbee is always ready to tell us, sadly, and with a kind of overwhelming volubility, why this must be so.

The Federal Government obligated itself yesterday to guarantee the repayment of a 5 per cent loan of $934,960 to be made to the Georgia and Florida Railroad by the First National Bank of Atlanta. The guarantee of repayment of both principal and interest to the bank in the event the railroad defaulted was granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission under the Transportation Act of 1958.
