The Board of Estimate approved last night a measure increasing from 3 to 5 per cent the tax on restaurant checks of $1 or more.
Contingents from the services, patriotic societies and other organizations will celebrate. Armed Forces Day with a parade down Fifth Avenue tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- An attorney for the Singer Sewing Machine Company agreed today that automatic zig-zag machines imported by the White Sewing Machine Corporation, Cleveland, did not infringe the Singer patent.
A former chief scientist of the Air Force expressed concern yesterday over the nation's space program.
LONDON, May 14 -- Prices advanced on a broad front in the stock market here today.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. closed a factory building in the east Bronx yesterday and threatened to arrest anyone who entered it. His order left 229 women's clothing workers jobless, at least temporarily.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Army made the nineteenth launching of its Jupiter, an intermediate-range ballistic missile, today and said that the weapon was "ready for operational use."
WITH its presentation of "Episodes" last night at the City Center, the New York City Ballet broke barriers into new esthetic territory.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The House Ways and Means Committee gave organized labor a final "no" today on legislation to liberalize unemployment compensation benefits.

HARTFORD, May 14 -- Dr. Franklin M. Foote of Pelham, N. Y., executive director of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, was nominated by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff today to be State Health Commissioner. The post pays $15,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Government scientists, studying the mass illness among a labor-federation group here last month, may have discovered what causes many mysterious food-poisoning outbreaks in the United States.

After disposing of the usual Soviet propaganda maneuvers the Western powers have now seized the initiative at the Geneva conference of foreign ministers by presenting a comprehensive, concrete and concise "package" plan designed to end both the Berlin crisis and the cold war and to assure peace and security for Europe and the world.
The Greater New York Fund, through its current campaign for $11,000,000, helps the five boroughs of New York City and all who live there.

The 239 East Fortieth Street Corporation has sold the north-west corner of Second Avenue and Fortieth Street to clients of the Cross Brown Company. The property, consisting of seven five-story tenement houses, was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $875,000. Ackman Brothers was the broker for the seller.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit is expected to open up this week-end.
Deputy Police Commissioner James McElroy, in charge of the Division of Licenses, agreed in Supreme Court yesterday to issue a cabaret identification card to J. J. Johnson, a trombonist.
GENEVA, May 14 -- The East Berlin house of Dr. Lothar Bolz, East Germany's Foreign Minister, commands a view of two worlds. The front windows overlook a barracks housing East German policemen.
General Builders Corporation has acquired two parcels of land totaling seventy-one acres in Queens for construction of middle-income cooperative housing.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Imports of refined petroleum products have been cut by more than half as a result of the mandatory oil import control program, the Bureau of Mines reported today.

Frank J. Gavin, who remembers when he used to peer around the corner of a box car to get a look at the "Empire Builder," James J. Hill, founder of the Great Northern Railway, retired yesterday from Mr. Hill's old job -- chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- A market study by the Department of Agriculture showed today that even if farmers had donated their wheat, consumers still would have had to pay 16.9 cents for a pound loaf of white bread in 1958.

Lumber production rose to 256,910,000 board feet last week from 248,622,000 in the prior week, according to reports to The New York Times by regional associations. This is the highest since Oct. 25, 1958, when production was 264,773,000 board feet.

LAKEHURST, N. J., May 14 -- A Navy blimp with eighteen men aboard crashed into a hangar at the Naval Air Station here while attempting an instrument landing in heavy fog early today. An officer was killed and six other persons were hurt, three of them seriously.
GUATEMALA, May 14 -- Agriculture Minister Clemente Marroquin Rojas proposed today the ending of all United States aid to Guatemala and the withdrawal of all United States aid personnel.
A summit meeting for American science opened here yesterday morning with a quick agreement -- there is an urgent need for more men, money and time for basic scientific research.

Business activity in Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Ohio, Maryland and Virginia was described yesterday as being "on a high plane. J. Lee Rice Jr., president of the West Penn Electric Company, told the company's annual meeting at 50 Broad Street that in recent weeks the increase in output of electricity has been more than 20 per cent.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, May 14 -- Israeli officials indicated today there was no evidence that large numbers of Jews in Israel wished to return to the Soviet Union or the Soviet bloc countries.
Justice George Tilzer of the State Supreme Court invoked a week-end cooling-off period in the hospital strike yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Another partial failure of the Treasury to sell its securities and another jump in the money supply pointed up the Government's financial troubles today.

SAN FRANCISCO May 14 (UPI) -- Mike McCormick pitched a three-hitter and Willie Mays clouted his second three-run homer in two days as the San Francisco Giants blanked the Philadelphia Phillies today, 8 -- 0.

Now that New York's litter bugs have been more or less brought under control perhaps something can be done to eradicate some new and growing public nuisances. These are the "twitter bugs," irksome people who insist on chattering through films, plays and even operas as though they were attending command performances for themselves and a few intimate friends and therefore were free to exchange comments on the proceedings without creating a disturbance.
The Republic Steel Corporation announced plans yesterday to build a 56-inch hot strip mill, to cost more than $45,000,000, at its Warren, Ohio, plant.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., May 14 -- David Gilbert, 23-year-old student at the Eastman School of Music, Rochester, N. Y., tonight won the first annual Samuel Antek Memorial Award for conducting.

GENEVA, May 14 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of statements by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd, and of a plan submitted by the Western powers today at the foreign ministers' meeting:
Two United States all-cargo airlines announced orders yesterday for a total of fifteen Canadian turbo-prop air freight planes.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Senate passed tonight and sent to an uncertain fate in the House a bill proposing new Federal barriers to bank mergers.

AUSTIN COATES, adviser to the Government of Sarawak on Chinese affairs, seems to be a member in good standing of that singular company of Englishmen who, the longer they remain in remote backwaters of empire, grow more and more polished and sophisticated. Mr. Coates combines intense sympathy, understanding and knowledge of various Oriental peoples with a literary gloss equal to that of Noel Coward or Evelyn Waugh.

LIMERICK, Me., May 14 (AP) -- A distraught factory worker shot and killed his wife today and then, in a raging shotgun battle with almost 100 officers, killed a police chief and wounded two other policemen before committing suicide.
The Playhouse will receive "The Miracle Worker" on Oct. 19. Anne Bancroft will be starred in the William Gibson drama, to be staged by Arthur Penn and produced by Fred Coe.

The State Investigation Commission yesterday questioned two witnesses in connection with charges that George P. Monaghan, the State Harness Racing Commissioner, had accepted favors and had permitted his aides to do the same.
American motorists will buy a record of 94,500,000 passenger tires this year, an executive of the United States Rubber Company predicted yesterday.

GENEVA, May 14 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translations, are the texts of speeches by Dr. Lothar Bolz, East German Foreign Minister, and Dr. Wilhelm Grewe, West German Ambassador to the United States, at today's session of the foreign ministers' conference:
MIAMI BEACH, May 14 -Tom Mboya, African labor leader, called today for an "international new deal."
PARIS, May 14 (AP) -- The novelist Pierre Benoit shocked "The Immortals" of the French Academy today by resigning.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 14 -- America was a slight choice tonight to win the Walker Cup golf tournament, which starts tomorrow. But speculation was rife that its line-up for the foursomes was defensive.

The vacant blockfront on the north side of West 236th Street from Hudson Manor Terrace to Douglas Avenue in the Riverdale area of the Bronx has been sold by the Eighth Riverdale Corporation. It was bought by builders who plan a seven-story building with 230 apartments on the site.

Earnings of the Aluminum Company of America this year should be larger than in 1958 even in the face of considerably increased depreciation and amortization charges, Frank L. Magee, president, said yesterday.

Sam Minskoff Sons, Inc., builders, have assembled a plot at the southwest corner of Broadway and Murray Street for improvement with an office building. The site, facing City Hall Plaza, was acquired from six separate owners.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 14 -- The Board of Education informed this town's First Selectman today that it would not permit further cuts in its proposed $1,625,900 budget for 1959-60.

NEWARK, Friday, May 15 -- Nearly 5,200 union employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company went on strike early today. The walkout posed a possible threat to electrical service in 80 per cent of New Jersey, but service was maintained by supervisory personnel.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -The Senate sent to the White House tonight a money bill carrying $150,000,000 of the $225,000,000 asked by the President for loans to underdeveloped nations.
President Eisenhower forecast yesterday that "a mighty influence for peace and understanding throughout the world" would grow out of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

HAVANA, May 14 -- Dr. Joaquin Martinez Saenz, who was president of the National Bank of Cuba during the Batista regime, will go on trial before a military court in La Cabana Fortress tomorrow charged with collaboration with the Batista Government and damage to the national economy.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 14 (AP) -- Gov. Earl K. Long, after telling the Legislature about his "income tax investigation," said today that he understood eight Democratic Governors and not one Republican were under similar investigation.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- Federal tax agents arrested thirty-three persons in seven cities today in a series of raids aimed at wiping out a nation-wide gambling syndicate.

Ingemar Johansson, a city boy from Goteborg, Sweden, has decided to train for his heavyweight title bout with the world champion, Floyd Patterson, in the countrified atmosphere of the southern Catskills.
The article in The Times of May 12 concerning Hulan Jack's plan to widen Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets "only a few feet" deserves, we believe, some comment.

Bank clearings for the twenty-six major cities of the nation in the week ended Wednesday totaled $23,026,235,000, Dun Bradstreet, Inc. reported yesterday. This was 12.1 per cent below the prior week's $26,179,084,000 volume, but 6.7 per cent above the $21,570,364,000 turnover for the similar 1958 week.

GENEVA, May 14 -- The Soviet Union and the West have now posted their asking price for Germany, and the net of it is a little as if Macy's and Gimbels were to ask each other to get out of Herald Square.
OTTAWA, May l4 -- A spokesman for the United States Navy dispelled today the secrecy that had hidden an important new device to detect enemy submarines.
Pleasure boating in small craft has led to peripatetic sightseeing trailer-boating, and this in turn is developing for families the additional delight of camping.
CINCINNATI, May 14 -- The Procter and Gamble Company announced here today that it planned to sell its only two subsidiaries in Cuba but would continue sale of its products there.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board, bowing to a Supreme Court ruling, decided 5 to 2 today to take jurisdiction over labor cases involving hotels and motels with a gross annual business of $500,000 or more. Most major hostelries would be covered.

An Aloha Hawaii Dance to be held at the Sheraton-East next Friday will benefit the summer camp fund of the Community Service Society. The agency's Junior Council, of which Miss Ruth S. Proffitt is chairman, is sponsoring the fete.

Lower rubber quotations in London and Singapore depressed prices on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Trading also was influenced by news that the House passed an appropriations bill but did not include funds for purchasing rubber to replenish supplies in stockpiles.
The last phase of a bakery workers' strike that involved 7,000 bakers, clerks and delivery workers when it was begun on Feb. 1 has been settled.
The leader of 1,000,000 union steel workers paid a "social" call on President Eisenhower yesterday in the midst of contract negotiations aimed at averting a national steel strike June 30.

Mrs. Walter C. Baker and Mrs. Joseph A. Neff, co-chairmen for the Five Enchanted Evenings held annually for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund, have announced the first three theatre parties scheduled for the coming season.
Students graduating from Columbia University in June will find jobs somewhat scarce, unless they are engineers or graduate business students.
An agreement to settle an eighteen - day dispute between the National Broadcasting Company and a union representing 1,500 of its technicians was reached here last night.

GENEVA, May 14 -- The two Germanys spoke for the first time today in the foreign ministers' conference. They assumed predictable contradictory positions on how to solve the German question, the basic issue of the conference.
New York City plans to borrow $27,000,000 in the bond market on June 4, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday.
QUITO, Ecuador, May 14 -- The Ecuadorian Communist party is preparing a campaign to discredit and if possible disrupt the conference of American foreign ministers to be held here next February.
MOSCOW, May 13 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, former Soviet Foreign Minister, was quoted today as having confirmed that he had been considered for the appointment as Ambassador to the Netherlands.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Loadings of revenue freight rose for the fifth week in a row in the week ended May 9 and totaled 677,398 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Councilman Louis Okin, Tammany district leader in the Third Assembly District North in Manhattan staved off a challenge to his party leadership last night.

STRASBOURG, France, May 14 (AP) -- The European Coal and Steel Community voted special measures today to ease the coal crisis in Belgium. But it retreated from the supranational principles that inspired the formation of the six-nation community.

The State Labor Relations Board assured Brooklyn bowling alley operators yesterday that it would give "full and proper judicial consideration" to their efforts to fight union racketeering if proper evidence was put before the board.

MADRID, May 14 (AP) -- The liberal Roman Catholics of Spain announced the formation of a political party today. A spokesman said the party was determined to have the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco replaced by a democracy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -- A. Stewart Hallamore of Hamilton, Ont., declared today that he intended to crusade for a simplified and more efficient industrial accounting system adapted to modern conditions.

In reply to a letter published May 2 on the Alto Adige question the Director of the Austrian Information Office insisted that some points at issue needed clarification. I should like to help clarify a number of these points.

Privately owned bus lines in New York City have a just claim on the Wagner administration for financial relief of the burden involved for carrying school children at greatly reduced fares. This claim has been made on the city by Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc.
John A. Brogan of King Features Syndicate was installed last night as president of the Deadline Club of Sigma Delta Chi.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A cultural anthropologist told a conference of juvenile delinquency specialists today that a school program "intelligently geared to the needs and demands of the stabilized lower class" would reduce delinquency.
Net income of the Bendix Aviation Corporation increased in the quarter ended on March 31 to $5,768,937 from $3,835,846 a year before.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address last night at the symposium on basic research at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, as recorded by The New York Times:

The scholarship fund of the Mannes College of Music will gain on Sunday from a benefit concert to be presented by the Interschool Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Arlie Furman and conducted by Anthony Morss.
GENEVA, May 14 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of an announcement by the United States, Soviet and British foreign ministers on their nuclear test talks today:

A judicial officer of the Post Office Department held a nine-hour hearing yesterday to determine if the final version of D. H. Lawrence's novel "Lady Chatterley's Lover" was obscene and hence unmailable.
Led by steel issues, the stock market climbed yesterday to historic highs and added more than $1,900,000,000 to the market value of the New York Stock Exchange list.

SERVICE DELICACIES, 1032 Lexington Avenue, between Seventy-third and Seventyfourth Streets, does just what it says; it provides service for delicacies. A large freezing unit running down the center of the store is a divider between exotic and down-to-earth fare.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -Conservatives staged a tactical retreat under heavy pressure from House Democratic leaders today and lifted a parliamentary blockade against a multibilliondollar omnibus housing bill.
LEMONT, Ill., May 14 -- A laboratory to tame plutonium, the tricky, highly toxic element now used chiefly in nuclear bombs, was dedicated at Argonne National Laboratory today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has made an arrangement with the Province of Saskatchewan that, officials said, goes further than any pre vious United States-Canadian agreement to frustrate the flotation of insecure Canadian securities in this country.

The question of who pays for the building of sewage treatment plants is scarcely earthshaking. But recent developments in this littlenoticed field contain some revealing, if not altogether encouraging, lessons.
President Eisenhower announced last night that he would ask Congress for funds to build an atom-smasher fifty times longer than the largest of its kind known to be in operation today.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- In an atmosphere of heated bickering, the Senate Commerce Committee concluded hearings today on the nomination of Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce.

Russell McPhail, Florida candy maker and investor, settled in Federal Court here yesterday suits filed against him, two others and the McPhail Candy Corporation. He agreed to restore $325,000 to the corporation in satisfaction of claims made in the corporation's behalf by the Securities and Exchange Commission and eleven preferred and common stockholders.
Negotiations to settle the issue of Shakespeare in Central Park broke up in anger yesterday.

A year ago yesterday Patrice Jacobs enjoyed the thrill of seeing her first horse under colors participate in a race. The experience was tempered somewhat by the fact that the horse, Basil Bee, didn't run well at all, and finished out of the money.
The W. S. Walker Advertising Agency of Pittsburgh with billings of $3,700,000 a year has been purchased by Erwin Wasey, Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc.
The city's legal right to establish one-way traffic on Third and Lexington Avenues was recaptured last night.

Private pension funds will own as much as $20,000,000,000 in corporate stock by 1965, a study sponsored by the Fund for the Republic reported yesterday. However, the study discounted fears that banks in control of investment policy for the funds would turn them into an instrument for dominating the national economy.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The bill by Representative Smith of Virginia, by which, only when Congress specifically said so would it occupy an entire legislative area, to the exclusion of state laws that exist or are projected, has been termed by its opponents as a "curb" on the Supreme Court.
Personnel of Mitchel Air Force Base at Hempstead, L. I., will give blood today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
LONDON, May 14 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev reiterated today that "West Berlin must become a free city."

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- Government investigators said today that some New Mexico and Colorado farmers had leased state land for 25 cents an acre and then rented it to the Agriculture Department's Soil Bank for $7 to $9.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 27 points ($1.35 a bale) down for the old July contract to 6 points (30 cents a bale) up for the new October future. The other months declined 2 to 9 points (10 to 45 cents a bale).
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Surgeons found cancer in the left lung of Gen. Nathan F. Twining when they operated on him at Walter Reed Army Hospital on Tuesday, the Pentagon said today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -- Another movie writer has hit the television gold dust buried in the hills of serialized Westerns.

Angered because the Board of Education has insisted on recommending a Harlem school site that he does not want Borough President Hulan E. Jack yesterday assailed Francis W. H. Adams, a member of the Education Board.
PANAMA, May 14 (UPI) -- Economic experts from the twenty-one American republics met here today to draft plans for the creation of a common Latin-American market.
A final decree settling all of the outstanding litigation in the collision at sea of the passenger liners Andrea Doria and the Stockholm was signed yesterday in Federal Court.

No one in Latin America is playing the game of politics and economics with more skill and for greater stakes than President Frondizi of Argentina. This is real-politik at its best. Considering the desperate economic situation left by General Peron one cannot deny that the Frondizi program and his tactics make sense.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee overrode Administration objections today and approved a Federal "fair trade" bill to replace state minimum price laws that have been crumbling throughout the nation.
This country's policy of lowering tariff barriers on wool and wool goods from abroad was warmly defended yesterday by a Government spokesman.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 14 -- The nature of collective bargaining in this country must change or the United States will lose its world economic position, George Romney, president of American Motors Corporation, said here today.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks rose $26,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of the same amount in the 1958 period.

Several dinner parties were held last night preceding the Yorkville Ball held at the Sheraton-East. The dance, a supper party, was a benefit for the Yorkville Youth Council, which aides some 1,400 children during the year.
TRENTON, May 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called on the Legislature today to expand benefits for the unemployed and the temporarily disabled. He termed such action "imperative."
The election of Dr. Gabriel Hauge, James R. MacDonald and William E. Robinson as trustees of the Harlem Savings Bank was announced yesterday by Edward J. Pierce, president.

MILLBURN, N. J., May 14 -- The R. Ted Davis family of 8 Ferncliff Terrace here has been selected as the Typical American Suburban Family, but plans are being made for them to take a summer trip that will be anything but typical. The Davises are going to Moscow.

A TALL tale and a fairy tale provided the subjects for two new operas that had their premieres last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. Peggy Glanville-Hicks employed Lord Dunsany's amusing fantasy for her short one-acter, "The Glittering Gate," and Lou Harrison turned to William Morris' poem "Rapunzel" for his opera in six brief scenes.
A new effort is being made by the Board of Education to solve, or at least ameliorate, an almost paradoxical problem of school utilization.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Defense Department and the Atomic Energy Commission, reversing an earlier position, have agreed to recommend the development of a prototype nuclear-powered aircraft, authorities reported today.

GENEVA, May 15 -- At a Kremlin party not long ago, Foreign Minister Andrei Andreyevich Gromyko was standing at a banquet table. A foot or so away was First Deputy Premier Anastas I. Mikoyan, talking with correspondents about a prospective international conference.

Events today: Concert Artists Guild, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 3 P. M.; Amiram Rigal, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Concert for Benefit of Boys Towns of Italy, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Handel's "Israel in Egypt," choirs and symphony orchestras of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Hunter College and Richmond Choral Society, Hunter College Assembly Hall, 8:30.
The election of John D. Hawke Jr. of Rockville Centre, L. I., as editor-in-chief of the Columbia Law Review for 1959-60 was announced yesterday by Columbia University.

DETROIT, May 15 -- A Federal grand jury today indicted twenty-two Ford dealers in the Detroit area on charges of fixing prices in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act. The Metropolitan Ford Dealers Association called the charges ridiculous.
The National Association of Manufacturers aligned itself with the steel industry yesterday in urging a wage freeze to halt inflation.
OSLO, Norway, May 9 -- Construction of Scandinavia's largest oil refinery is in full swing at Slagen on the western side of the Oslo Fjord sixty miles south of here.

Thomas F. Dougherty, a lawyer of Baldwin, L. I., was elected president of the New York State Elks Association yesterday. The voting took place at the second day's session of the forty-seventh annual convention of the order in the Commodore Hotel.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 15 -- The nine weeks' effort to form a new Cabinet in the Netherlands will end tomorrow when Dr. Jan Eduard de Quay presents to Queen Juliana the names of thirteen new ministers. Dr. de Quay will be Premier.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 15 -- Two veterans of the Battle of Bastogne, one wearing a gray business suit and the other a paratrooper's battle dress, shook hands on a runway at Mitchel Air Force Base here today.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Government moved the nation's center of population today seventeen miles from its old position in Illinois. The move reflected the coming of statehood to Alaska and Hawaii.
TOKYO, May 15 -- Japan has firmly rejected a demand by the Soviet Union that she repudiate her defense alliance with the United States and adopt a neutralist policy.

The Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center is observing its fiftieth anniversary. The first hospital of its kind in this hemisphere, the Neurological Institute has played a leading role in the advancement of neurology through patient care, research and teaching this past half-century.

ALBANY, May 15 (AP) -- The State Education Commissioner today rejected the appeal of Warren B. Austin, who was dismissed from City College in New York on the ground he falsely denied that he had been a member of the Communist party.
CANNES, France, May 15 (Reuters) -- France took major honors at the 1959 Cannes International Film Festival, which ended tonight.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday assigned Capt. James P. Clancy to the Youth Division to command the Juvenile Aid Bureau patrol section.
The Swedish American liner Stockholm has been sold to an unidentified German concern for delivery next year.

GENEVA, May 15 -- Geneva is known for its horological industry as well as for the amenities it offers diplomats. It is therefore apt that at this stage of East-West negotiations both sides should be vying with each other in efforts to set the clock back.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 (AP) -- Mitchell D. Ostwind, an associate of the financier Earl Belle, pleaded not guilty in Federal Court today to an eighteen-count indictment resulting from the collapse of Mr. Belle's financial empire.
CHICAGO, May 15, (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

OTTAWA, May 15 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker announced today that he had established a permanent Canadian committee on space research. He made the announcement at the Royal Military College at Kingston, Ont., where he received the first honorary law degree ever conferred by the college.

LONDON, May 15 -- The Government rejected today Opposition demands for the release of Africans detained under emergency regulations in Kenya and the Central African Federation of the Rhodesias and Nyasaland.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Republican national convention in Chicago next year will have 1,325 delegates with one vote each under a tentative apportionment worked out by the party's National Committee. This is two more than the convention roster of 1956.

The American Waterways Operators, Inc., asked Congress yesterday to continue the exemption of seamen working on shallow-draft vessels over inland waters from wage and hour provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act.

The State Investigation Commission has turned down a request by George P. Monaghan, Harness Racing Commissioner, for a postponement of his hearing next Thursday on charges of violating the state ethics code.
MIAMI BEACH, May 15 -An important segment of the American labor movement got its first look today at Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and obviously liked what it saw.
The May Department Stores Company reported net sales yesterday of $540,982,219 for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, or slightly more than the $533,657,343 volume of the year before.

MIAMI BEACH, May 15 (AP) -Harold Gross, president of Teamster Union Local 320 in Miami, whose state license as a union business agent was canceled early this week, continued his activities as a business agent today and was arrested by the police here.

GENEVA, May 15 (UPI) -- An American-educated African student broke through a security cordon today to give Secretary of State Christian A. Herter a petition demanding "freedom from white oppression" in South Africa.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Britain will probably be the first of the member countries of the I. M. F. to make the additional payment required by the proposal to increase quotas by 50 per cent.

The firmness that bolstered the bond market on Thursday after a week of declining prices vanished swiftly late yesterday afternoon following the rise in the prime commercial lending rate of major banks.

LONDON, May 15 -- The industrials continued their advance in the stock market here today. The Financial Times index of industrial ordinary shares rose 0.7 point to a new high at 232.5. This reflected a gain of 2.1 points for the week.

BERLIN, May 15 -- Walter Ulbricht, chief of the East German Communist party, charged today that the package plan for German reunification and European security presented by the West in Geneva yesterday would result in civil war in Germany and lead to general war.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A House committee said today President Eisenhower at times had used emergency funds for matters not involving emergencies.

LONDON, May 15 -- A 63-year-old United States Air Force master sergeant swung his 220 pounds and a pair of handcuffs against an attempted payroll robbery today and helped save 12,000 ($33,600) in Air Force wages.

KATONAH, N. Y., May 15 -- State highways officials announced a plan today to move traffic through northern Westchester County more quickly without dismembering sumptuous rural estates in the Town of Bedford at this time.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 15 (AP) -- The U. S. Freedoms Foundation presented its freedom leadership last night award to President Chiang Kaishek.

The illegal world of narcotics, the people enmeshed in it and those who seek to stamp it out, are discussed in a new book by John M. Murtagh, Chief Magistrate of the City of New York, and Sara Harris. To be called "Who Live In Shadow," the volume will be published May 25 by McGraw-Hill.

WHEN Admiral Lord Nelson, cruising the Mediterranean in 1800, wanted to do something especially nice for his fleet, he would treat them to marsala. This sweet, dark fortified wine, walnut brown in color, has been made in Sicily since 1773. But although it is an Italian product, it was originated by an Englishman and always has been a great favorite in the British Isles.

Here on Manhattan Island one can lunch with distinction in a variety of styles with an almost unlimited choice of decor and atmosphere, from the grandly austere table d'hote to the intimacy of a neighborhood bistro.

TO be a home, a rented summer cottage usually needs several decorative "pick-ups." They can be anything from a brilliant Mexican rug to a set of gay pottery dinnerware. New York stores, anticipating a mass exodus to the country, are overflowing with all sorts of accessories that are bound to enliven even the simplest shack.

Stores that have special shops devoted to clothing and equipment for campers are listed below, with the services offered by each. All the stores will supply check lists of camping essentials and will order camp insignia.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 15 -- In a setting strikingly dissimilar from the historic one at Pittsfield almost 100 years ago, Amherst and Williams touched off a two-day observance of the centennial of college baseball this afternoon.
Two pairs of gunmen took two Brooklyn payrolls yesterday within an hour of each other. A total of $4,659, destined for fifty employes, was taken.

Frederic W. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, questioned yesterday whether the trend toward term life insurance was good for the business. Term insurance is low-cost coverage issued for a limited period of time and which generally has no cash surrender value.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower urged the National Rivers and Harbors Congress today to use "proportion, responsibility and vision" in promoting development of the nation's water resources.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 15 -- On a rampage down the stretch, the United States shut out Great Britain, 4 -- 0, in the first day's play in the Walker Cup golf foursomes. The visitors need only three victories in the eight singles tomorrow to take the silver loving cup for the sixteenth time in seventeen tries.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Senator Mike Mansfield announced today that he would move to eliminate defense-support and economic-assistance grants from the foreign-aid program. He would do this in a three-year period, starting next year.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) -The General Accounting Office said today that the Cessna Aircraft Company, Wichita, Kan., had submitted to the Government prices for B-52 bomber tail assemblies and tooling that were 37 per cent above costs.

The theme of the Greater New York Fund's 1959 annual appeal is simple enough: "The Greater New York Fund Helps People." But translated into statistics, the complexity of the work that is being done by the fund's 425 agencies becomes apparent.

BALTIMORE, May 15 -- There won't be any triple crowns or jewels kicking around at the Pimlico race track tomorrow, only money. With good weather, which is predicted, the crowd will number 40,000.

CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) -- The Joc-Anna Stable's The Great Man, last most of the way, closed with a rush to win the $15,000 Sportsman's Park Handicapy by a nose today.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 15 -- No. 7 was the big one for a Kerry blue terrier, Ch. Tregoad's Vicky's Victor, today.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, May 8 -- Increasing Communist interest in North African trade has been the most notable aspect of the Casablanca International Trade Fair.
WHITE PLAINS, May 16 -- New programs for the entertainment of old people are growing in Westchester.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 16 -- A cocktail party for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will be held May 24 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Amedee Cole of Quaker Ridge. Mrs. Newton Hoyt Jr, and Mrs. Eric Hager of Greenwich, members of the board of SpenceChapin, are co-chairmen of the benefit.

BOSTON, May 16 -- Rocky Colavito paced a sixteen-hit Cleveland Indian assault with his tenth and eleventh home runs today. The Boston Red Sox were the victims, suffering their fifth straight defeat, 12 to 6.

POLAROID Land pictures taken in any Polaroid camera or camera back are eligible in the Polaroid Land Picture Contest just announced by Modern Photography. Amateurs or professionals may participate, in separate classes, and may submit any number of entries.

PELHAM, N. Y., May 16 -White Plains High and the defending champion, Archbishop Stepinac, today tied for the team title in the eighth annual Westchester invitation track and field meet at Parkway Field.
The use of plastics aboard merchant vessels will be discussed at a dinner-meeting Wednesday of the Society of Marine Port Engineers.

In 1866 America's first hospital for the care and treatment of patients with long-term or chronic illnesses was opened in the Bronx with appropriate ceremonies. Last Wednesday, ceremonies were again held at St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases, to dedicate the nation's newest surgical center for research.

OTTAWA, May 16 -- Major decisions on Canadian defense policy await discussions with Gen. Lauris Norstad, Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, this week-end and Monday when he will meet with Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Cabinet.

EAST HAMPTON, N. Y. -- Sharpies, lobster pots, trawls and purse seines are among a collection of unlikely items going on display this week-end here in Guild Hall, the town's cultural and dramatic center.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 (UPI) -- Orlando Cepeda, roaring out of a slump, drove in four runs today with a homer and a single in pacing the Giants to a 9-2 victory over Cincinnati.

NEW roof coatings which combine aluminum with asphalt enable the home owner to literally brush on a new roof in a single day. Providing an ideal means for adding new life and beauty to an old, worn-out roof (or for greatly extending the useful life of a fairly new roof) these new coatings can be used over practically all commonly used roofing materials. They cannot, however, be used over wood shingles.

Checks drawn in April on Fifth District demand deposits were $8,600,000,000, 21 per cent above the April 1958 level. For the first four months of this year the district showed a gain of 16 per cent. Every district area reflected the economic upturn, with Virginia setting the April pace with a 25 per cent rise.

" MORE than orange ice, even more than two orange ices -- most and best Nu Dang loved to fly his knite." His was the boldest and bravest of all the kites in his corner of Siam, and one day it slipped, as kites will, from his hand and ran away with the wind.
The Quantico Marines defeated Manhattan College's track team, 86 to 54, at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday.
Means o fimproving newspaper management efficiency wil be considered b ytwenty-seven newspaper executive at a two-week seminar beginning tomorrow at the American Press Institute, Columbia University.

FOUR regional conventions are scheduled by the Photographic Society of America for May and June. Features will include lectures on practical topics, print shows and conducted tours. P. S. A. membership is not required to attend.
Five Barnard College students completed their year in one of the few clinical psychopathology courses in the country last week.

HONG KONG, May 16 -- The rigid discipline of life in the communes set up last year in Communist China was eased in the southern provinces last month because of growing unrest, reliable sources reported today.

GREG HARRIS, two years an apprentice on the cargo ship Rigel, had one desire -- to get his mate's license and work up to command of his own ship, any ship that was not a tanker. A mysterious explosion berths the Rigel at a port on the edge of the Arabian oil fields.
MIAMI, May 13 -- A new epidemic of land fever is sweeping Florida. It is unmatched by anything since the boom of the mid-Twenties collapsed in an avalanche of worthless paper.

NEWARK, May 16 -- The clergy and laity were urged today to take greater interest in community activities aimed at promoting intergroup relations at a conference on the church and human relations at Trinity Cathedral.
Antoine Pinay, French Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs, will visit here this week as a guest of New York University.

More than 200 manufacturers will participate in the five-day showing of fall lines presented by the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers. The show opens today at the New York Trade Show Building, norheast corner of Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

THE exhibition entitled "Recent Sculpture U. S. A." at the Museum of Modern Art frankly stresses innovative and experimental work rather than attempting to give a fully rounded survey which would include primarily traditional and conservative pieces.
State Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, the Republican majority leader, denied last night that the investigation of New York City Government authorized by the Legislature had a political purpose.

Prof. William Ernest Hocking's letter printed on May 10 raises some disturbing questions for steelmakers and steelworkers. The public is entitled to know whether labor in its insistence on sharing the profits is also willing to share the losses; and why the companies do not reduce the price for steel in view of the very large profits they are now making.
WINDHOEK, South Africa, May 16 -- Germany, the Netherlands, Britain and Africa all meet there. The result is a capital city unlike any other in the continent or perhaps in the world.
ROME -- Italy has its full share of notable tourist treasures: Rome, Venice, Florence, Capri and the Leaning Tower, to say nothing of that three-star restaurant where everybody speaks English.

ANEW approach to illustrating scientific phenomena is demonstrated in an exhibit of twentyseven photographs by Berenice Abbott, which opens today at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. It will hang for two weeks.

IN the 1959 vacation photography season, more amateur color film is destined to be consumed in still, movie and stereo cameras than in any previous period. To the already phenomenal proportions of amateur color-film activity, there have been added the intriguing possibilities of Ansco's Moviechrome color roll film for 8mm movies at double the traditional speed, and of Kodak's new 25mm Ektachrome High-Speed film at the record daylight index of 160, promised for June.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 16 -- Nineteen cruising yachts hit the line off Execution Rocks tonight at the start of the New York Athletic Club race to Stratford Shoal and back. This event annually opens the distance sailing season on Long Island Sound. Five of the entries failed to appear.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) -- Bob Allison and Jim Lemon poled their eighth homers of the season today and helped the Senators defeat the Kansas City Athletics, 7 -- 2.
Seven hundred union representatives, many of them leaders, marched en masse to Beth Israel Hospital and joined pickets there yesterday after an angry emergency meeting of the Central Labor Council.
ALAMOGORDO, N. M., May 16 -- A solar flare about 100,000 miles in length and 50,000 miles wide has been recorded at Sacramento Peak, Upper Air Research Observatory of the Air Force, near here.
Among the art events this week is an exhibition of preColumbian stone sculpture from New Mexico at the Museum of Primitive Art, opening on Wednesday.

The drab iron ore mining picture of 1958 is changed. The American Iron Ore Association reported that ore shipments from American ports in the Lake Superior region totaled 2,910,070 tons in April, compared with 62,560 tons in the 1958 month.
With variations of sorts the Yankees' alarming descent continues to carry the Bombers deeper into despair.

ON May 18, 1926, the leading fundamentalist evangelist of the glittering Twenties, titian-haired Aimee Elizabeth Kennedy. Semple McPherson, a strong swimmer, went for a dip at a city beach in Los Angeles wearing an abbreviated green bathing suit: wind, three miles an hour; temperature, 68 degrees; sea, glassy smooth.
Directors of the Railway Express Agency, fighting to stay on the tracks, came up yesterday with a new proposal to the organization's owners and customers.

Wild columbines are in bloom, enriching shade-dappled ledges with gold and scarlet and spangling the air with the early butterflies they attract. Unseasonal heat has hurried them past their prime in many places, but where the shade lies deep in the hilly woodlands they will be glorifying the rest of May and even early June.

GENERALLY the combination of author Marguerite Henry and illustrator Wesley Dennis is a very hard one to beat but their latest book, de signed for a younger audience than were the ever-popular "Misty of Chincoteague" and "King of the Wind," is a slight, sentimental affair.

PANAMA, May 16 -- All this month, Latin America's Governments and their economists have been busily reviewing blueprints and schemes designed to propel this vast region, seething with poignant poverty and bitter frustration, into a bright future of new hopes and decent human welfare.

LANSING, Mich., May 16 -Michigan's tangled fiscal affairs, seemingly in a state of crisis since last winter, will become even more desperate in early June when heavy bills fall due. It appears that only a major transfusion on cash from the state's veterans trust fund can save the day.

HUGUENOT refugee Paul Ferrand, late of France, now a loyal citizen of King George's Massachusetts Bay Colony, could handle a sword like the ex-courtier he was. He could also run wilderness trails like an Indian and pin any backwoods bully in a free-for-all wrestling match.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 16 -President Chiang Kai-shek has urged a "sweeping review" of his governing Kuomintang party's policies, the official Nationalist Central News Agency reported today.

WHEN the first volume of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's memoirs was published, it was greeted in France as a great literary event. The literary power of the author was universally admired, but no especial importance was attached, except by the few faithful Gaullists, to the book as a political act. Outside France, the memoirs were treated as an interesting but minor addition to our knowledge of the politics of World War II.

THERE can be no doubt that your critic is right when he states that the managing co-directors of the Phoenix have not been able to give it a personality or a point of view. But that is not all: they have not been able to establish proper and adequate contact with their present and past subscribers -- not to speak of the rank and file of theatregoers from whom they must draw future subscribers.

LOS ANGELES, May 16 -- A municipal cause celebre developed this week over the city's first physical move toward providing the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team with a promised stadium site in Chavez Ravine.

IN one sense, French pancakes are like snails and macaroni -- their reputation rests almost exclusively on the sauces that accompany them. To dine on any of them without further flavor embellishment borders on the unthinkable.

TRENTON, May 16 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner named Dr. Roscoe P. Kandle today to succeed Dr. Daniel Bergsma as State Commissioner of Health. Dr. Kandle is now Deputy Commissioner of the New York City Department of Health.
In spite of his disappointing showing at Santiago, Chile, Bobby Fischer, chess champion of the United States, is expected to be in top form again after a much-needed rest in the West Indies.

"Not at all," the President replied, adding that he and the Congressional leadership could cooperate on the basis of "what is good for the country."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 16 (UPI) -- Johnny Thomson, the Flying Scot from Boyertown, Pa., smashed the one-lap record today. In addition, and, as the fastest of twelve qualifiers, he won the pole position for the forty-third 500-mile Memorial Day auto race.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A new political element has been introduced into the Middle East by the British decision to supply arms to Iraq.
National Broadcasting Company technicians began returning to work in six cities yesterday after settlement of a nineteen-day work stoppage.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 16 -- Winning five titles and scoring in all but three of the sixteen events, Yale's deep and talented track and field squad scored a smashing victory in the twenty-fifth annual Heptagonal championships today.

HUNTINGTON, L. I. May 16 -- Six homes, will be open on Wednesday, rain or shine, for the fifth annual Spring house tour to benefit the Service League of Huntington Township. The houses are all traditional in style and individual in their manner of decoration.

BUENOS AIRES, May 16 -President Artuvo Frondizi began today action to overcome the most serious Government crisis since he took office a year ago, with the reorganizing of his Cabinet along lines satisfactory to the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- "It will kill him, sir, kill him dead," gloated John C. Calhoun after the Senate had rejected Martin Van Buren's appointment as Ambassador to London. "He will never kick, sir, never kick!"

THE listing above gives a good idea of the quantity of music that will be available to North Americans this summer. The list is substantially larger than in previous years, but this is in part because a number of local festivals are bidding for wider attention.

MONTREAL, May 16 -- The Canadian aviation industry is experiencing something of an upsurge this week-end, with the news that Canadair Limited has obtained two orders worth $80,000,000 for fifteen of the new CL-44 cargo planes.
On Wednesday Devereux C. Josephs will step down as chairman of the board of the New York Life Insurance Company. He has reached the company's mandatory retirement age of 65.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A science advisory group to the President suggested today that with huge atom smashers man at last might find the longsought connection between the inner space of the atom and the outer space of the universe.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 16 -- Sam Snead shot one of the greatest competitive rounds in golf history today -- a 59 -- and forged far in front in the third round of the Sam Snead Festival golf tournament.

GENEVA, May 16 -- The West German Government plans to make a formal declaration to the foreign ministers' conference on the question of Germany's borders with Poland and Czechoslovakia.

MATTOON, Ill., May 16 (AP) A train smashed into a carload of eight teen-agers near here early today, killing seven and critically injuring the eighth.

The last of the art collection of the late Mrs. Byron C. Foy will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday. The sale, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, has already broken several auction records, notably for paintings.

HAL HOLBROOK'S impersonation of Mark Twain at the Fortyfirst Street Theatre conveniently reminds us that, although Mark Twain has been dead nearly fifty years, he is still a very live figure in the thoughts of his countrymen.

ASPARK of blue, rarest of all flower colors, enlivens any garden color scheme. In the search for blue flowers to replace delphiniums, which in my garden behave like annuals, I discovered anchusas. Flowers are brilliantly blue; plants are hardy, free-blooming, disease free and not bothered by insects.
Saskatchewan, one of Canada's less populous provinces, is making a bid to become the center of the Commonwealth's international securities market.

IN "The Swan," Helen May has erected a loving tribute to Anna Pavlova, who almost single-handed brought ballet to people everywhere and made them love it. Helen May was one of Anna Pavlova's eight English pupils -- and remained a friend to the day of the ballerina's death.

City College has received a $50,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York to support an experimental program that will allow graduate students from leading universities to teach in the college's next five summer sessions.

THE years of shock treatment administered by the Chinese Communists have rendered virtually impossible any reconstitution of the pre-"liberation" form of Chinese society. Of all the institutions that have been affected, the most important is the family.
LOS ANGELES, May 16 -The City Board of Harbor Commissioners is investigating reports of cargo-handling abuses and inadequacies that are said to be causing shipping to avoid Los Angeles Harbor.
Man may contribute to his destruction by creating machines he cannot control, one of the world's leading mathematicians warned yesterday.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) -- Following in unofficial translation from the Russian, are excerpts from a speech today by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union rejecting the Western package peace plan offered at Geneva.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 16 -- Don Mackenzie with his International sloop, Black Arrow and Herb Hild, with Desiree in the Star race, were winners in the heaviest populated classes as a fleet of forty sailed in the fifth spring regatta conducted by Larchmont Y. C. today.

IN this novel Martin Mayer has taken temporary leave of the civilized sociology that has seemed to be his forte ("Madison Avenue: U. S. A.," "Wall Street: Men and Money"). His vacation into fiction has given us a novel whose true protagonist is the world of opera -rather than the "great American baritone" whose first-person record of a year's work and play provides the frame.

THE impact of the Bolshoi Ballet has been overwhelming, and it will be something of a calamity if we ever allow ourselves to recover. To discuss all its implications -- artistic, technical, organizational -- would require, quite literally, a month of Sundays.

Sloan Foundation.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 16 -- One World War II hero chided another tonight for talking too much.

AN enormous display of lilacs, perhaps the largest in the world, will be held in Rochester, N. Y., during that city's annual Lilac Week. This year the festival has been scheduled for this Wednesday through May 27, when the flowers are expected to be in full bloom.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 16 -- Electricity producers are showing reluctance to invest in nuclear power plants under the joint program of the United States and the European Atomic Energy Community.

Five years ago today the Supreme Court handed down its momentous decision in which it was affirmed that segregation on the basis of race in our public schools was in violation of the Constitution. MANY enthusiastic gardeners look forward to picking delicious red tomatoes, only to be disappointed by disease troubles that develop in July and August. Two diseases -- fusarium wilt and blossom end rot -- are the main hazards for tomato crops, especially in the suburban New York and Long Island areas.

THE stench of dirty politics hangs over every page of Philip Alston Stone's first novel. The central character is Gene Massie, an ignorant, rabble-rousing scoundrel seeking reelection as Governor of Mississippi. Maripausa, a village resembling the author's native Oxford, is the chief setting.

Profits for many firms in the Chicago area have shown a significant increase during April, the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago reported in its monthly survey of business. The upturn took place as production rates, employment, prices and order backlogs remained relatively steady during the month, compared with the prior thirty-day period.

THE amateur continues to lead all other consumer groups in the use of photographic products, according to the 1959 Annual Statistical Report, The Photographic Industry in the United States, compiled by Augustus Wolfman and just issued.

The Commercial Placement Council, the nation's largest association of private, licensed employment agencies, was told today that its member organizations would play an increasingly vital role in the country's expanding economy by helping to fit capable persons into jobs.

Amiram Rigai, playing in Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday at the late afternoon hour, devoted himself mostly to standards of the piano literature. The only novelty was a suite of five short pieces by Paul Ben-Haim.

Its survival had been threatened many times since its founding as King William's School in 1696. But in the mid-Thirties it had, as the price of athletic greatness, lost its standing as an accredited institution.

Arthur H. Christy submitted his resignation as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to Attorney General William P. Rogers yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended May 16:
LUANG PRABANG, Laos, May 17 (AP) -- Laotian troops have surrounded the hard core of the old Communist Pathet Lao army and told it to surrender or face annihilation, military sources said today.

TOKYO, May 17 -- Japan's paunchy athletic idol, Wakanohana, made history today in the 2,000-year-old sport of sumo wrestling. The stars of this esoteric national pastime weigh well over 200 pounds and wear their long hair in topknots.
S. Hazard Gillespie Jr. was sworn in yesterday as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. The district embraces nine counties as far north as Albany.
An airline executive who pens verse as an outlet for business frustrations has published selections of his work in a pamphlet satirizing organization men and sundry aspects of corporate life.
A carload of American culture in the form of a bookmobile is leaving for the Soviet Union today to be shown at the United States exhibition in Moscow from July 25 to sept. 4.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -A leading economist said today that a lessening of inflationary psychology and an increase in the supply of common stocks should have an important bearing on the future of stock prices.
NOW we are about to see how one of these fine old, salty old, honored old saltwater traditions works out. It would be a mortal shame to see it fall apart.

There is scant possibility that the 9.3-second 100-yard-dash clocking attributed to 18-year-old John Mostyn of Bergen Catholic High School of Oradell, N. J., last Saturday, will get world record listing.
Assistant professionals shared some of the spotlight in the metropolitan area's first of two ualifying rounds for the United States open golf championship yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- To an aide who walked into his office in the Pentagon this morning, Thomas Sovereign Gates Jr. made this comment: "I have decided to accept an invitation to be Deputy Secretary of Defense.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The spread in yields between the Treasury's three-month and six-month bills narrowed this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. In direct contrast with last week, the yield on the shorter bills rose while that on the longer bills declined.

Stockholders of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., at yesterday's annual meeting authorized issuance of 2,000,000 additional shares of common stock and the conversion into common stock of $150,000,000 of convertible debentures.

LONDON, May 18 -- Having gratefully accepted the invitation of sunny weather and the long Whitsunday weekend, London motorists were struggling home tonight through one of Britain's memorable traffic jams.

Your editorial of May 14, "A Year of De Gaulle," will seem very cool in tone and more than guardedly reserved even to those who nourish no fanatical admiration for the French President. For once it does not appear fair to repeat that the more things change, the more monotonously the same they remain.

GENEVA, May 18 -- The United States, British and French delegations at the foreign ministers conference insisted today that their package plan for a solution of the German problem could not be broken up into separate parts.
CARLSTADT, N. J., May 18 -- The two young daughters of Patrolman William Lown were asphyxiated this morning in a fire that destroyed their home here.
The conception of New York as one vast slum is about to change through the city's neighborhood improvement program, Charles W. Abrams asserted yesterday.
Top priority will be given by the Board of Higher Education to the task of selecting a chancellor for the municipal college system and a new president for Hunter College.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The House of Representatives approved tentatively today a move to force a reduction in agricultural surpluses that are costing the Government billions of dollars a year. It demanded, in effect, that these surpluses be thrown into the world markets on a competitive basis.
GENEVA, May 18 -- The Big Four foreign ministers have agreed on a translating system at their conference here that gives them plenty of time for maneuver.

The Professional Bowlers Association, formed a year ago, will open a tournament circuit this week in Albany and follow with a similar competition in Paramus, N. J., next week. In between, six of the members, five of whom are national champions, will compete in a one-day tourney at Madison Square Garden.
CHICAGO, May 18 -- A crowded rush-hour elevated train rammed into the rear of another this morning. One hundred and seventeen person were

HAVANA, May 18 -- United States-owned sugar mills in Cuba will be stripped of their cane plantations under Premier Fidel Castro's new agrarian reform law, which was approved by the Cabinet last night and signed by President Manuel Urrutia Lleo.
YONKERS, May 18 -- Eight of the nine favorites won at Yonkers Raceway tonight. And it seemed that eight of every nine spectators wagered on Lucky Eden, the choice in the featured Class A pace.
MOSCOW, May 18 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union today rehabilitated all of its chief literary renegades except one -- Boris Pasternak.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Government appealed to inventors today to develop a rocket device that would permit soldiers to skim over hills, bread that would not grow stale and pajamas that would repel insects.

ARTHUR KOESTLER has always been in there pitching, if sometimes on the wrong side. He has identified himself with the big movements and news stories of the last three decades as active participant or correspondent. Everybody knows the trouble he's seen because much of it is in print -- from the early Thirties, when he was a Communist, to his early awareness of communism as a god that failed.

Many New York apartment buildings now supply free gas for their tenants' cookstoves and ovens. This token of goodwill is a nice gesture, and it would be unfair to look beyond. Naturally, nothing can lurk in the woodpile, when the woodpile is gas. One point may be worth a thought, however -- that, like many gestures, this one has come a little late.

Ray Robinson's world middle-weight crown continued to teeter yesterday but the champion was still very much in the fight when the hearing on his status was adjourned until tomorrow by the New York State Athletic Commission.
MOSCOW, May 18 -- The visit here of Averell Harriman has invoked the aura of his war-time service as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union.
The cotton futures market moved 6 to 15 points (30 to 75 cents a bale) higher yesterday. Near October showed the most strength.
BERLIN, May 18 (AP) -- Australia's Neale Fraser and Sandra Reynolds of South Africa today won West Berlin's international Whitsuntide tennis tournament honors.
Tony DiBiase, a 22 - year - old welterweight from Astoria, Queens, outpointed Curley Monroe of Worcester, Mass., in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
" The Bell Telephone Hour," which presented four one-hour music and dance shows this last season, is considering an increase to twelve for the 1959-60 season.
With $11,000,000 as its goal for 1959, the Greater New York Fund, on its twentyfirst anniversary, is the world's largest network of local charities.

Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell called on industry yesterday to get behind the President's legislative proposals to curb union racketeering. He said it might be the last chance for a while for such labor legislation.
CHICAGO, May 18, (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox to- night stormed into first place in the American League with a 9-2 victory over Washington. Early Wynn pitched a five-hitter and Sherm Lollar and Al Smith hit home runs.
CHICAGO, May 18 (UPI) -- Jim Hearn, once one, of baseball's biggest bargains, received his unconditional release today from the Philadelphia Phillies.

The Automatic Canteen Company of America achieved higher sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended on March 14 compared with those of a year ago, Nathaniel Leverone, board chairman, reported yesterday.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 18 -- A leading religious philosopher of Conservative Judaism asserted here tonight that that Jewishness of American Jews was "only skin deep." He suggested a program to enable Jewish life to recover its spiritual character.
GENEVA, May 18 -- Following are salient facts on the foreign ministers' conference at United Nations headquarters in Geneva:

Robert McEnroe became a Broadway dramatist with "The Silver Whistle," in which Jose Ferrer was starred during the 1948-49 season. Ever since the presentation of the amiable comedy about an old folks' home, theatregoers have been waiting for Mr. McEnroe's second entry.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- W. Averell Harriman has asked the State Department for permission to visit Communist China as a newspaper correspondent.

Those responsible for economic policy in Britain, according to the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Derick Heathcoat-Amory, are watching "with the greatest of interest" the vitally important economic problem that is currently the subject of vigorous debate in the United States -- the problem of reconciling economic growth and stable prices.
The quantity of vilification, denunciation and abuse lately aimed at Commissioner Robert Moses must be appalling to any New Yorker even slightly acquainted with this man's work.

Emile Zola Berman, attorney for Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan, appealed yesterday to Governor Rockefeller for help in obtaining an adjournment of Mr. Monaghan's public hearing before the State Investigation Commission.

BEDFORD CENTER, N. Y., May 18 -- Visitors who tour the six herb gardens in northern Westchester on June 4, will stop with their box lunches at Big Chimneys, the home here of Mr. and Mrs. R. Parker Kuhn Coffee will be served.
DETROIT, May 18 (AP) -- The auto industry is continuing its high level output, apparently anticipating no halt in the swelling demand.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- Futures in corn and oats added to their recent gains, with old-crop contracts in good demand today on the Board of Trade. Wheat and rye weakened and soybeans were mixed.
ALBANY, May 18 -- More babies have died in New York State so far this year than in any other corresponding period in a decade, the State Department of Health reported today.

TULSA, Okla., May 18 (AP) -- An unrestricted flow of oil and petroleum products across the United States-Canadian border to benefit both countries and strengthen continental security was urged today by a Canadian oil executive.
NICE, France, May 18 -- The European basketball championship begins at Istanbul tomorrow.
TO light the way in all potentially dangerous dark spots in the home, Westinghouse has introduced a new safety light that will burn day and night for less than a penny a year.
A half dozen plastic plants that look real have been set out at the State Department's passport office here to make it appear friendlier.
MOSCOW, May 18 (Reuters) -- British officials said tonight British-Soviet trade talks were "going very slowly. We are in great difficulties with the Russians," they added.

ROME, May 18 -- Pope John XXIII granted a private audience today to Giuseppe Pella, Italian Foreign Minister. The Pontiff is thought to have received a report on the Geneva conference during the twenty-minute talk.
Bulging steel stockpiles in Detroit automobile factories have increased the possibility that the United Steelworkers of America may delay its scheduled strike June 30.
LONDON, May 18 (Reuters) -- American-born Nancy Astor, the first woman to sit in Parliament, becomes an octogenarian tomorrow.

ONE of the most intriguing track studies ever offered was the learned analysis made a quarter of a century ago by the knowledgeable Brutus Hamilton of the University of California. Having served as an Olympic coach, he had all the credentials he needed. He spoke with the voice of authority when he prepared a chart outlining the "Ultimate of Human Effort."

WIESBADEN, Germany, May 18 (AP) -- Germany's European champion, Fritz Thiedemann, today edged Hugh Wiley of Towson, Md., and won the $2,500 Wiesbaden Grand Prix, highlight of the four-day international horse show.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- The movie trailer is seeking new ways to baffle its archenemy, the popcorn machine. The hard sell is no longer enough to hold audiences in their seats between films.

GENEVA, May 18 -- The United States and Britain decided today to urge the Soviet Union to accept the full range of their proposals for a conference of scientists on the problems of detecting nuclear tests.
Recent moves in Congress to end Federal protection of Indian tribes have been criticized by the Association on American Indian Affairs. It called them a "timetable of disaster."

A strong cash market in anticipation of light supplies of spring potatoes, strengthened prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Seventeen notices were posted and twelve circulated throughout the day. The poor acceptance of the notices induced liquidation and profit-taking that cut the gains.

Four horses, finishing two noses and a neck apart in a seven-furlong race on the grass, gave the photo-electric cameras a pretty picture at Belmont Park yesterday. In another race the crowd of 23,633 got a thrill when a first-time starter won by fifteen lengths and set a track record for five furlongs.

RABAT, Morocco, May 18 -A half-hour conference of three Algerian nationalist leaders with King Mohamed V of Morocco here today revived speculation on a possible meeting between the King and President Charles de Gaulle of France to seek peace in Algeria.

After edging lower for three consecutive weeks, the nation's steel production turned upward again last week. The industry poured 2,631,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, operating at 92.9 per cent of rated capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The bond market reacted in mixed fashion yesterday to the announcement late last week of the increase in the prime lending rate of major commercial banks.

EXPERIENCED home cooks know how to use their favorite roll recipe as the basis for such mouth-watering products as coffee cakes, buns, doughnuts and fruit and nut breads. But the novice is more confident when she uses a packaged hot roll mix and has specific directions for turning it into similar products.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- New credits were granted to Chile today as part of an economic development and exchange stabilization program that will exceed $135,000,000.

John Berry of Santa Monica, Calif., has received the first annual Macmillan Fiction Award for his first novel "Krishna Fluting." The prize is $2,500 as an outright award and $5,000 as an advance against royalties. Mr. Berry was born and educated in California.
TRENTON, May 18 -- The Assembly voted and sent to the Senate today a bill that would ban Sunday sales of clothing, home and office furnishings and appliances and building materials.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 18 (AP) -- Bob Cortner, Redlands, Calif., and Gene Force, Richmond, Ind., passed driver's tests at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today and will be eligible to attempt qualifications this week-end for the 500-mile race on May 30.
Arab is a fifteen-year-old horse who has seen better days. A handsome sorrel gelding accustomed to carrying people through Brooklyn bridle paths, he was sold Saturday to a man with a plow.
OUTWARDLY "Chic," the new revue that opened last night at the Orpheum Theatre on Second Avenue and Eighth Street, is a well-appointed show that gives promises at first sight of wit and urbanity.
Daniel J. Riesner, secretary of the New York County Republican Committee, declared last night that politics instead of prudence had prevailed at City Hall for too long and at too great a cost.

Joseph Papp went into court yesterday in an effort to force Robert Moses to readmit William Shakespeare to Central Park this summer. The producer obtained an order in Supreme Court in Manhattan directing the Park Commissioner to show in the court tomorrow why he should not be compelled to grant Mr. Papp a permit to stage the New York Shakespeare Festival.

THE extended reflection preceding the execution of a 23-foot mural is traced in an exhibition of preparatory drawings by the Italian painter Afro for his mural for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
WHITE PLAINS, May 18 -A Westchester government free of conflicting interests and dual public jobs was sought today by the county's 3,750-member League of Women Voters.

The United States Freedom Foundation has given its special leadership award to Vietnamese President Ngo Dinh Diem for his effective "resistance to communism." This resistance has, up to this point, been more successful than many persons would have imagined possible. Free Vietnam is still free, and is forging ahead. The tactics that President Ngo has used, therefore, are worthy of analysis. They may work elsewhere.
Spring was in special bloom at the Bronx Zoo yesterday.
r The Rehabilitation Program of the Brooklyn Association for Mental Health will gain from the "Mental Health Party," on Sunday at the Livingston, 301 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn.

LUANG PRABANG, Laos, May 18 (AP) -- A 750-man battalion of the old Communist Pathet Lao army, encircled north of this city for forty-eight hours by royal troops, gave up yesterday in response to a surrender-or-die ultimatum. It yielded a few hours before the deadline last night.
BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Major fires struck property in the United States and Canada at an average rate of about one a day during the last year, the National Fire Protection Association reported today.
Twelve lifeboats representing six nations will compete today in the Twentieth Annual International Seamen's Lifeboat Race in the Narrows off Brooklyn.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 18--Eight eonteniporary homes! in New Canaan will be open for: public inspection on Sunday at l the fifth annual modern house tour to aid the New Canaanl Community Nursery School in meeting capital expenses.
Directors of the Caterpillar Tractor Company increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock and proposed a three-for-one split of the shares at their meeting in Chicago yesterday.

ACCORDING to the calendar, summer starts on June 21, but any shopper knows that it is really in full swing right now. Special shops devoted to carefree beach life are popping up in virtually all department stores. Spring hats, coats, skirts and sweaters have been put aside to make way for bright bathing suits, zany beach hats, colorful shorts, skirts and shirts.

NEWARK, May 18 (AP) -Almost 600 clerical workers for the New Jersey Hospital Service Plan and the Medical-Surgical Plan say they will strike at noon tomorrow unless proposals for wage increases are answered.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- State Department officials said tonight they were not prepared to evaluate the effect of Cuba's new land reform law on the holdings of United States companies there. However, the matter is of high interest and will get immediate study.
CAIRO, May 18 (AP) -President Gamal Abdel Nasser says Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has given him renewed assurances of nonintervention in Arab affairs.
The Oroville-Wyandotte Irrigation District, Calif., has withdrawn a proposed issue of $62,000,000 of power revenue bonds that had been scheduled for sale on June 11.

A new issue of $20,000,000 of convertible subordinated debentures of the General American Oil Company of Dallas will be offered for public subscription today by a banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

TOKYO, May 18 -- Thomas E. Dewey, former Governor of New York and twice-defeated Republican Presidential candidate, is expected to start helping Japan to counter American industries' moves against Japanese goods.
A company searching for oil in Argentina ordered more than $10,000,000 worth of tools for the job yesterday.

A new study to support his one-way traffic program for Manhattan's avenues was released yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley. It showed that last year twice as many pedestrians and motorists were killed on Third Avenue, a two-way artery, as on Second Avenue, one-way southbound.
The Department of Health reported two cases of suspected poliomyelitis yesterday, making a total of four this year.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 18 (Reuters) -- Queen Juliana today gave an hour-long audience to George Adamski, an American who says he has had several rides in flying saucers. The self-styled space expert later announced the Queen was "most sympathetic."

MANILA, Tuesday, May 19 -- Sixteen persons who are closely associated with President Carlos P. Garcia were accused in the Philippine Senate today of having amassed personal profits through "influence peddling."
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The united labor movement's leadership apparently is getting ready to attack the Kennedy labor reform bill as it passed the Senate.
Union officials yielded to Mayor Wagner yesterday and agreed to submit proposals for settling the eleven-day hospital strike to a membership vote.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -President Eisenhower made a short bedside call on John Foster Dulles at Walter Reed Army Hospital today.
