WASHINGTON, May 18 -The Supreme Court held today that the Motor Carrier Act provided no method for shippers to challenge the reasonableness of a trucker's charges for past shipments.
April was a month of feverish activity for incorporators of new businesses. Some 17,554 new companies were started last month, the most for any April on record and third most for any recorded month.
KANSAS CITY, May 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman underwent surgery today for removal of a tumor from her left breast.
Two lady composers who make most of our male composers seem like old fuddy-duddys shared last night's Composers Showcase at the Circle in the Square.
The Appellate Division will set a date tomorrow to hear arguments on whether washing one's own clothes is work.
A plea for American business to welcome rather than reject a return to a more competitive world trade market was made yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.
OWEGO, N. Y., May 18 (AP) -Roy Carlisi, a delegate to the Apalachin underworld conference, was sentenced today to serve sixty days in jail and pay a $3,750 fine for criminal contempt of court.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 17 -- For Governor Rockefeller a vacation is a time for strenuous physical activity.

PANAMA, May 18 -- Latin America's farmlands are no longer producing enough to feed its rapidly increasing population, meet the demands of the rising standards of living and go on paying the bill for industrialization programs.

ROME, May 18 -- A startled Benedictine monk stood before a painting of the Annunciation today in Rome's newest art gallery, in the basement of a church. The painting represented Mary as a young girl, with traces of lipstick and wearing a short skirt, receiving from a barefoot angel Gabriel with a Brigitte Bardot hairdo the announcement that she had conceived the child of God.

GENEVA, May 18 -- The gulf between East and West over the future of Germany remained as deep as ever tonight after the United States and the Soviet Union had rejected each other's proposals for a settlement.
Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock reserved decision yesterday on a motion by the General Motors Corporation to quash a grand jury subpoena in a Government antitrust investigation.
A guide to thirty-seven new office buildings in Manhattan has been issued by a real estate broker to help business concerns evaluate leasing space.
LONDON, May 18 (UPI) -Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery snapped back a reply today to World War II associates who had let it be known they believed he should keep his mouth shut.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Union labor's top spokesmen said today that the steel industry was using "the false face of inflation" to deny its employes a fair share of steel earnings.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -Legislation to bring overseas adoptions into line with approved adoption practices in this country was proposed today by Secretary Arthur S. Flemming.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee released testimony today that Soviet churches were under control of the secret police, and that many priests were secret agents.
Seven hundred and thirty-three litterbugs received summonses yesterday as Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane, 250 sanitation patrolmen and 1,000 field supervisors inspected city streets.
GENEVA, May 18 -- The member countries of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) today sent Poland's application for membership in the trade pact to a working group.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation plans to acquire Stavid Engineering, Inc., according to an agreement made yesterday between directors of the two companies.

POPLARVILLE, Miss., May 18 (UPI) -- State authorities complained today that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were "harassing" citizens in investigating the lynching of M. C. Parker, a Negro.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 18 -Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said here today that he had found common ground between India and Pakistan on their dispute over the waters of the Indus River Basin.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The State Department said today that it would seek "improvement in the Arab attitude" toward Jews whenever it had the chance. But departmental officials saw little hope so long as the Arab-Israeli conflict persists.

AT composers' forums and programs by composers' groups, Dorothy Renzi has proved herself a good friend of composers. She has sung their songs for little, if any, recompense. Last night at Carnegie Recital Hall four composers repaid the friendship by helping to give her a recital.
A Rumanian couple who sheltered two American fliers from the Nazis in Bucharest in 1944 found refuge yesterday in the United States.

The latest revenue-producing program of the New York City Transit Authority deserves commendation. Under the plan, residents of some outlying areas can leave their cars at proposed new parking fields and continue their journeys into the heart of the city by subway. The motorist will pay 75 cents -- 45 cents for the parking fee and 30 cents for two subway tokens.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that all illegally owned weapons might be turned into the Police Department with immunity from prosecution during the next month.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) -- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, proposed new regulations today for "comprehensive and flexible" control of billboards on Federal land.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The $10,000 Guggenheim heim International Art Award for 1958 was presented by President Eisenhower today to the Spanish artist, Joan Miro.
Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann" will be performed at Lewisohn Stadium on the evening of Monday, June 29, in a concert version prepared and conducted by Thomas Scherman. The season opens June 22.

FOR the bride-to-be who wants a simple, inexpensive wedding reception at home, Emily Post recommends the following menu: Tea sandwiches, punch and wedding cake. Such a menu for thirty persons would cost about $62. But even that figure could be pared down a few dollars by cutting some corners.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 18 -Teachers in the northeastern states with qualifications similar to teachers in other regions get more pay because the standard of living is higher, a conference at Arden House was told today.
GENEVA, May 18 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter is getting a good bit of mail these days from East Germans.
A departmental trial was ordered yesterday for Benjamin Cymrot, 49-year-old former executive officer of the city's old Bureau of Real Estate, who has been under suspension since Jan. 31, 1958.
The Underwood Corporation and the William Esty Company, Inc., will end their relationship on July 15.

GENEVA, May 18 (Reuters) -- Following is the offcial text of a statement by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and the text, in unofficial translation from the Russian, of a speech by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union at today's session of the foreign ministers' conference:
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Eisenhower nominated Thomas S. Gates Jr. today to succeed the late Donald A. Quarles as Deputy Secretary of Defense.

The second of three brothers who in succession were presidents of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. retired from the board yesterday. He is the 82-year-old Irenee du Pont, who had been honorary chairman since 1954.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange fell yesterday and stocks moved hesitantly.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to examine the constitutionality of two Arkansas city ordinances requiring the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to disclose its membership lists and to file financial statements.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 18 (AP) -- Troilus, an early favorite for the Kentucky Derby, but a disappointment since winning the Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah in February, died early today on the farm of his owner. Bayard Sharp, at near-by Middle-town.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- An Administration that is accused by capital and labor alike of initiating antitrust proceedings against them for a political motive equally well served in each instance cannot, in common sense, be guilty of the same charge in these two contending sectors.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Justice Felix Frankfurter read his Supreme Court colleagues a lecture today on the need to conserve the court's time and energy by avoiding trivial cases.

GENEVA, May 18 -- When the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, tossed his harpoon into the Western peace plan at the foreign ministers' conference today, the French spokesman remarked: "Molotov is back again."

Thomas V. Jones has been elected president of Northrop Corporation, California aircraft maker. Mr. Jones, 39, was formerly a senior vice president of Northrop. He succeeds Whitley C. Collins, who died last week.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 18 -- Hofstra College has signed a contract to buy twenty-five acres in North Hills for an experimental program, the college announced today. The contract is contingent on the approval of a request for a zoning variance.
NEW DELHI, India, May 18 -- Communist China's actions in Tibet have ceased to be a center of attention in India, Public comment on India's relations with Peiping has almost completely subsided.

May I warmly commend The New York Times for Harrison Salisbury's brilliant reporting on May 12 of his interview in Moscow with Dr. Harlan Hatcher, distinguished president of the University of Michigan. Dr. Hatcher's main point, that the Soviets have been making vastly more scientific, industrial and educational progress than we realize, needs repeatedly to be driven home to the American public.
MIAMI BEACH, May 18 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union served notice today that it wanted a more democratic Democratic party.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Because it rained today, about 200 proponents of Italian immigration got a surprise handshake from President Eisenhower.
The lusty brass of the Goldman Band filled the midtown air yesterday noon to mark the hundredth anniversary of a savings bank.
The trial by recrimination of Lewis L. Strauss ended last week. His nomination as Secretary of Commerce will now be put to a vote by a Senate committee.

It may be that one of the reasons the City of New York is in perennial hot water to raise more money is that it spends more than it should. It is about time that someone took a good hard look at this budget.

In the face of reports about persistent differences among them, the Western powers at Geneva have closed ranks again and have formally reaffirmed their determination to hold fast to the Western peace plan package and to defend it against any Soviet attempts to destroy it by breaking it apart.

" AMERICA PAUSES," a special series of programs that seeks to employ natural outdoor settings as the background for varied musical numbers, boasted the artistry of Marian Anderson last night over Channel 2.
Affably protesting that he did not smoke, Mikhail A. Menshikov, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, stood by genially yeterday while a nine-inch Cuban cigar was hand-made for him.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The United States is now confident that its proposal for a new billion-dollar International Development Association will be ready for approval in principle by the world's finance ministers in September.

Alfred Catino, one of seven teenage defendants on trial in General Sessions Court for the murder of Julio Ramos last May, jumped to his feet in court yesterday and screamed that the witness, Police Lieut. Michael J. Ward, was a "liar."
Communist military strength In North Korea has now reached the high level of 1950, when South Korea was invaded, according to Mayor Huh Chung of Seoul.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 18 -- The two Marxists in the two-party coalition that has ruled Ceylon for three years resigned today. A junior minister of Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike's Freedom party followed them out of the Government.

Market rates on commercial paper and on call and time loans advanced 1/8 to 3/8 of 1 per cent yesterday, following the rise of the prime lending rate of commercial banks major from 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Dr. Homer D. Babbidge is to be named Assistant Commissioner for Higher Education in the Federal Office of Education, it became known today. He will succeed Dr. Lloyd E. Blauch, who is to retire.

MUSSOORIE, India, May 19 -- The Dalai Lama, who has become something of a religious and tourist attraction in this north Indian hill station, posed for pictures today but had not a word to say for publication.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Board of Governors of the American Bar Association urged the Senate Judiciary Committee today to act promptly on nineteen nominations of Federal judges.

Bills calling for five new special city taxes and tax increases for the fiscal year beginning July 1 were introduced in the City Council yesterday. A public hearing on them was set for 11 A. M. May 28.

ROME, May 10 (UPI) -- Avery Brundage, the International Olympic Committee president, said today he was "satisfied" with an official South African statement that there was no racial discrimination in South African sports.

Manufacturers of apparel along Seventh Avenue are preparing their fall lines to show buyers. While there has been some cautious sampling of the new lines by resident buyers, much depends on the reaction of out-of-towners, due here in the next few days.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Supreme Court was asked today to hold that a lawyer engaged in a criminal trial has a constitutional right to make public speeches about the conduct of the trial.
Senator McClellan disclosed May 9 that he had instructed the staff of his rackets-investigating committee to draw up recommendations for special antitrust legislation in the transportation industry.
For the fourth time in his fifty-four years, Ansgar Johansen of Oslo, Norway, was pulled out of the Narrows yesterday.

The Townsend Corporation of America announced yesterday that, subject to approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission, it had purchased all of the outstanding common stocks of Slayton Co., Inc., and Mutual Fund Distributors, Inc., both of St. Louis, Mo.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 -- The United Presbyterian Church may become the first major Protestant denomination to buy nation-wide newspaper display advertising in an appeal for new members.

GENEVA, May 19 -- The Soviet Union, prodded by the United States and Britain, said today it would set down on paper immediately its own proposals for a scientific conference on detecting nuclear explosions.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Administration stood firmly today against any rise in the statutory minimum wage at this time. It favored a relatively minor extension in coverage.

Philip J. Kelly, vice president of the Lynn Baker Advertising Agency, has been elected president of the Sales Executives Club of New York. He will assume his new post on June 23, succeeding John W. Hubbell, vice president of the Simmons Company.

Bert Lahr and Nancy Walker, two of Broadway's funniest comedians, will star next season in a new revue called "The Girls Against the Boys." It will mark their first joint appearance in a New York show.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 19 -- The General Assembly approved a bill today that permits Connecticut life insurance companies to compete with New York banks in the writing of pension, retirement and profit-sharing plans. It is said to be the first such measure affecting insurance companies to be approved in the country.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 19 -- Premier Gaston Eyskens said today that a century-long struggle in Belgium between the partisans of Church and state schools was being ended by legislation now nearing passage.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- The State Department today assigned three college athletic coaches to teach American sports techniques this summer to youths overseas.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- There were more passenger cars on the streets and highways of the United States last year than ever before and the number is still going up, the Government reported today.

Increased offerings of new-crop Brazilian coffee at lower prices weakened futures yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The spot price of Santos 4's (the basic Brazilian grade) declined 1/2 cent a pound to 36 1/2 cents, equaling the year's low.

Political leaders in newly independent Malaya have made it clear that they will not even consider the recognition of Red China. Their experience with Communist-directed terrorism is all too recent for any such policy. Likewise, they have made it plain that they do not embrace the idea of any union with Singapore that would give the Chinese a majority in total voting strength.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower conceded today that his personal system of encouraging good school grades was costing him money.
The public hearing of charges against Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan will go on as scheduled tomorrow, it was decided yesterday.
GENEVA, May 19 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter is using the foreign ministers' conference to get better acquainted with United States ambassadors in principal European capitals.

GENEVA, May 19 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of speeches by Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville of France and Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd of Britain, and of excerpts from the speech of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, at the foreign ministers' conference here today:

LONDON, May 19 -- Prices continued their upward movement in the stock market here today despite profit taking at the end of the bookkeeping account. The predominance of small gains among the industrials raised the Financial Times index 0.9 point to a new record at 233.4.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Senate approved a bill to establish a permanent formula for the taxation of life insurance companies' income at a level that averages 75 per cent higher than what they paid last year.
CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., May 19 (AP) -- A prankish 16-year-old cadet of Valley Forge Military Academy sneaked a girl into a dress parade and got away with it until today.
A month-old plan concocted by the Police Department and New York University has apparently brought an end to bomb hoaxes that periodically emptied a Washington Square classroom building.

The third annual United States World Trade Fair at the New York Coliseum closed yesterday after setting a new attendance record for the exhibition center. The trade fair, which had set Coliseum attendance records in its two previous stagings, drew nearly 552,000 persons this year, according to a preliminary estimate by the show's management.

Although mutual fund purchases in April slipped from the March level, they ran almost $70,000,000 ahead of April, 1958, the National Association of Investment Companies reported yesterday. The official monthly tabulations placed April purchases at $192,018,000 against $197,612,000 in March and $122,206,000 in April, 1958.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 19 -- Four rabbis, whose combined ministries in Conservative Judaism span a century and a half, were honored here tonight on their retirement.
The Film Producers Association of New York last night stole a page from Hollywood's book when it presented its first annual Industry Achievement Awards for the advancement of local film production.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Cyrus S. Eaton, prominent Cleveland industrialist who visited the Soviet Union last year, believes there is $3,000,000,000 worth of business waiting for United States industries in the Soviet market.
BOSTON, May 19 (UPI) -- The successful experimental use of a new inhalant anesthetic -- Fluothane -- was reported today at the annual meeting of the Massachusetts Medical Society.

CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- Short interests in the May rye future showed unmistakable signs of nervousness today as they bid the price up in an effort to buy themselves out of a tight squeeze on the Board of Trade.

Rudolf Uhlenhaut, head of the testing and research division of the Daimler-Benz Company in Germany, is a true cosmopolite. He is at home with a host of friends any place in the world. His job calls for him to visit many of the 136 countries in which Daimler-Benz automotive products are sold.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- By a vote of 9 to 8, the Senate Commerce Committee recommended confirmation of Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce today.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., May 19 (AP) -- A clogged sewer was blamed today for a flash flood that caused severe damage in northern St. Joseph last night.

Sales of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. for the quarter ended on April 30, first of the fiscal year, were the highest for any similar period on record. Bruce A. Gimbel, president, reported the results to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

The Union Carbide Plastics Company believes it has found a way to keep those polyethylene garbage cans and similar containers from becoming brittle and shattering with rough usage at low temperatures.

A group of business men headed by Al Kevelson has announced the purchase of the Central Industrial Bank of Brooklyn, according to Mr. Kevelson, who was elected chairman. He disclosed that about 800,000 of the 1,000,000 shares outstanding were acquired from Samuel Silverman, who will continue as president, and other directors. The rest are held by a number of small shareholders.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 19 -- The Kenya Government announced today that compensation would be paid to the dependants of the eleven Mau Mau captives who died at Hola detention camp in March after they had been beaten.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Neil H. McElroy announced today that he had suspended his plans to resign in the fall, but speculations about the post of Secretary of Defense continued.

An agreement has been reached for the sale of radio station WOV, which specializes in Italian-language programing, to Bartell Broadcasters, Inc. The transfer of ownership is subject to approval of the Federal Communications Commission.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed yesterday to guarantee repayment of a $3,000,000 private loan to the Boston and Maine Railroad.

Mrs. B. Bynum Turner of 620 [Park Avenue and Ms. Robert Bragarnick, co-chairmen for the third annual Asphalt Gariden Party on June 2 for the benefit of the Girls Club of New York, were hostesses yesZ terday afternoon at the home !of Mrs. Turner at a meeting and tea for chairmen and members of their committees.
The New York City Ballet has announced the extension of its season at the City Center through June 14.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (AP) -- Bob Cortner, a 32-year-old race driver from Redlands, Calif, died tonight of injuries suffered a few hours earlier in a crash at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. It was the second death this year during preliminaries for the 500-mile race on May 30.

Only two decisions in eight games of the Jubilee international chess masters tournament were registered in the opening round in Zurich, according to a report received last night through Swiss news sources.
" Conquest," a science series previously televised at infrequent intervals, will be presented each week next season by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Each year the American Merchant Marine Library Association, 45 Broadway, appeals to the citizenry for books and funds to maintain its seagoing library service. Throughout this week, proclaimed American Merchant Marine Book Week by Mayor Wagner, the fifteenth annual campaign seeks to collect a minimum of 500,000 books, 750,000 magazines and an operating budget of $100,000.
New issues of public utility securities totaling more than $25,000,000 will be placed on the market today by investment syndicates.
RYE, N. Y., May 19 -- State officials were chided by residents here today for trying to give this city of 13,511 too much highway construction in too much of a hurry.

To former Governor Harriman belongs the credit for having brought back to prominent public attention the question of getting entry for American press reporters into Communist China. The question, of course, is one that goes far beyond Mr. Harriman's present application to the State Department to validate his passport so he may apply for a Communist Chinese visa to visit Peiping's realm as a correspondent.

The New York City Blue Cross Plan has asked the Insurance Department to approve a new rate increase of 34.2 per cent. No increase in benefits has been proposed, in spite of the fact that Blue Cross benefits available to New Yorkers are the lowest for any large Blue Cross plan in the country.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The House Agriculture Committee challenged the Administration today to let wheat farmers decide by referendum between its farm theories and Democratic proposals. It approved a bill to that effect by 20-11.
Chief Judge Mortimer W. Byers denied a motion in the Federal Court. Brooklyn, yesterday to transfer the fraud trial of Alexander L. Guterma from Brooklyn to Buffalo.

Little reaction to Cuba's agrarian reforms was registered in spot and futures sugar markets yesterday but stocks of American companies with land holdings in Cuba declined sharply on the New York Stock Exchange.

TOperform "Lysistrata" without sex and without humor marks some sort of record. But it is not the record Day Tuttle was striving for when he opened a handsomely refurbished theatre last evening with a new production of the old Aristophanes comedy.
ALBANY, May 18 -- In its first year of legality, bingo has proved to be more popular in New York City than upstate.
PARIS, May 19 (AP) -- An all-morning rain and the upset of Pierre Darmon, the leading French netman and box-office draw, put a damper on the opening of the French tennis championships today.

LONDON, May 19 -- The late King George. V's determination in the early Nineteen Thirties to keep Britain out of war was depicted in German Foreign Ministry documents captured at the end of World War II.
WASHINGTON, May 19, (UPI) -- John Foster Dulles, Former Secretary of State, continues to weaken in his fight against cancer, the State Department announced today.

RICHMOND, Va., May 19 (AP) -- Harry A. De Butts, president of the Southern Railway, indicated today that his company might oppose the proposed merger of the Atlantic Coast Line and Seaboard Air Line Railways.

TRENTON, May 19 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner sharply rebuked the Republican-controlled state Senate today for overriding yesterday his conditional veto of a bill that would establish a program of state scholarships.

A supplemental entry fee of $250 enabled Mrs. Henry Obre to acquire a purse of $8,167.50 in the Belmont National Maiden Hurdle at Belmont Park yesterday. Hustle, competing in the silks of Mrs. Obre, took the event of about a mile and seven furlongs by a head over Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Bureaucracy.

Only about 35 per cent of the liquor distilleries in business when Prohibition was repealed twenty-five years ago are still in existence, W. L. Lyons Brown, chairman of the board of directors, Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, said yesterday.

YONKERS, May 19 -- Herman C. King's High Topper from Sweetster, Ind., with Howard Beissinger driving, was a surprise 2:03 4/5 winner of the one-mile Arcadia pace before 19,699 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight. She paid $21.30 for $2.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., May 19 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa threatened today to seek a nation-wide strike if Congress placed unions under antitrust laws.
Ling Electronics, Inc., has acquired University Loudspeakers. Inc., for $2,300,000.
PARIS, May 19 -- Algerian rebel forces killed twenty-four French soldiers and wounded ten others in heavy fighting southeast of Algiers Sunday.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Mr. Hoffa's taik of a nation-wide strike touched off critical reactions here today.
GENEVA, May 19 -- The Soviet Union has offered the Western powers three alternative methods of settling the Berlin crisis. All are unacceptable to the West.

The New York City Housing Authority sold $29,240,000 of short-term notes yesterday. Proceeds will help finance the development of Luna Park Houses, a Coney Island project subsidized by the forgiveness of certain municipal taxes.

A final draft of management's proposals for ending the hospital strike was submitted to Mayor Wagner late yesterday amid growing indications that the strikers would almost certainly reject the plan in a vote tonight.

GENEVA, May 19 -- Khrushchev may hope to discover at this Geneva conference how far the United States is prepared to go on any deal dividing the world into political spheres of influence. Indeed, diplomats presume he might suggest this kind of deal to Eisenhower when he finally meets the President at the summit.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 19 -- Bishop James P. De Wolfe's opposition to segregation in the diocesan churches was approved unanimously here today by delegates of the ninety-second annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.
Mayor Wagner has asked Robert Moses not to make any more public utterances on the Shakespeare Festival controversy, it was learned yesterday from reliable City Hall sources.
A $30.000,000 contract for the first three new vessels in the fourteen-ship replacement program of the Delta Line was signed yesterday.

Up to February of this year, while no one questioned that the recovery from the 1957-58 recession rested on a sound foundation, it was customary to qualify this by adding that it showed a "lag" when compared with the two other post-war recessions in 1949 and 1954.

Leaders in industry and finance have supported the Greater New York Fund without reservation since its founding twenty-one years ago. They have realized that support of the network of 425 voluntary agencies participating in the Fund is vital to the life of the community and those who work in it, resident and commuter alike.
Seaforth has been told that its Scottish symbols gang aft a-gley.

RABAT, Morocco, May 19 -- An Algerian nationalist leader has charged that the United States has blocked shipments of arms to Algerian guerrilla forces that "certain countries were prepared to give us."
The N. B. C. Opera Company will present four operas during its 1959-60 season. This will mark an expanded schedule for the company, which gave only two operas this season.

CHOCOLATES after breakfast caused a Broadway actress to change careers. She is 24-year - old Margo Green, who owns a small specialty shop, The Clothes Gallery, 1367 Avenue of the Americas, near Fifty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Thirty-five Polish women, victims of medical and surgical experiments in Ravensbrueck, a Nazi concentration camp in World War II, heard their case for compensation from the West German Government pleaded today from the Senate floor.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Jim (Mudcat) Grant, Cleveland's young right-hander, beat Washington tonight for the seventh straight time. The score was 5 -- 2, with Grant getting relief help from Dick Brodowski in the last two innings when his right shoulder stiffened.
MOSCOW, May 16 -- If you want to hear free speech and hot argument, one place to go these days is a rambling old art gallery on Kuznetski Most (Blacksmith's Bridge) in the heart of Moscow.

CAIRO, May 19 -- Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, stopped here briefly today to discuss Suez Canal matters with Egyptian officials. He talked an hour with President Gamal Abdel Nasser tonight.
A new problem has arisen to plague the harried Park Department, the death of young trees that were planted a year ago in Duffy Square, the busy little island in the heart of the theatrical district.

GENEVA, May 19 -- West Germany is seeking to have the expected summit conference later this year confined to the Big Four, without official participation by either the Bonn regime or Communist East Germany.

A BACHELOR'S search for "the perfect girl" is really a quest for a relationship that will make no demands upon him. Its built-in guarantees would absolve him of responsibility for the success of the marriage -- or for its failure.

I have been following with mounting concern the controversy about the production of free Shakespeare plays in Central Park. The performances and their atmosphere were a delight to me and it felt good to be a citizen of a city where such opportunities are given.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board found today that an employer had used race discrimination to discourage union membership.
A picket line was set up yesterday morning in front of Public School 130, Baxter and Hester Streets, by mothers who did not want their children transferred to another school.
For the first time in fifty-five years the exterior of New York's subway cars will be washed.

MENEHUNIS have been at work at Abraham Straus. These Hawaiian versions of leprechauns have filled the store with tropical blooms, graceful palm fronds and all manner of Hawaiian paraphernalia. The occasion is "Aloha Week," Abraham Straus' salute to the new, fiftieth state.

If there was ever any doubt that Premier Castro and his 26th of July Movement intended to make a social revolution in Cuba, it should now be dispelled. The agrarian reform, which has been at the heart of his struggles since student days, has now been spelled out.

The financial problems of Detroit, Mich., caused by rising unemployment a year ago have cleared. The city is now concerned instead about expanding capital outlays, Mayor Louis C. Miriani said here yesterday. The Detroit official spoke at a luncheon at the Bankers Club given by the First of Michigan Corporation and Blyth Co., Inc.

WINDHOEK, South-West Africa, May 18 -- A day after his eighty-eighth birthday, Paramount Chief Hosea Kutako of the Herero tribe pleaded yesterday for immediate United Nations trusteeship over South-West Africa.

" WHEN Wols walked toward you through the hot sunlight of the Midi," writes Kay Boyle, "you saw blazing in his eyes the fire that raged within him." The author knew Wols in 1941 when he was in hiding near Marseilles, along with the many artists and writers who fled occupied Paris. He was then working furiously despite great privations, painting the hallucinated water-colors now on exhibition at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue.
PANAMA, May 19 -- Latin America took the first concrete step today toward fulfillment of its dream of creating a regional common market.
The American Jewish Congress reiterated yesterday that Saudi Arabia's boycott of concerns that do business with Israel has been extended to those that are managed by Jews or employ them.

A one, two finish in the last event, the broad jump, gave George Washington the team title yesterday in the Manhattan Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships at Van Cortlandt Park.

Dr. James B. Conant plans a study of the differences between schools in high-income suburban areas and those in industrial cities. The president-emeritus of Harvard University said yesterday that the study would be part of a larger program to survey the junior high school.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points (35 cents a bale) up to 4 (20 cents) points off yesterday.

The stockholders of the Lefcourt Realty Corporation elected Samuel Friedland a director at the annual meeting in the Plaza Hotel yesterday. Mr. Friedland is chairman of Food Fair Stores, Inc. At a later meeting of the board, Mr. Friedland was elected chairman. The directors also elected Samuel Stein, vice president of the Progress Manufacturing Company, as chairman of the finance committee. Max Fink, elected a director by the stockholders, was appointed secretary.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 19 (Reuters) -- Prof. Jan Eduard de Quay, leader of the Catholic Peoples party, was sworn in today as Premier at the head of a new coalition cabinet, ending a sixty-eight-day crisis in the Government.
A sudden downpour yesterday cut short the fifth annual awards ceremony of the Mayor's Committee on Scholastic Achievement.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 19 (AP) -- Fifteen hundred workers went back to their jobs today "in the interests of national defense" but renewed their pledge of full support for a carpenters strike against contractors at the missile base here.
The chief interest in the bond market yesterday was in dealings in high-grade corporate and local government bonds, rather than in the Treasury market.

THE sign in the corridor outside the hotel elevator was quite explicit about it. It had two arrows, one aimed in the direction of "Odd Numbers." Since James Joseph Dykes is as odd a number as baseball has, the visitor never hesitated. And sure enough, there was the new manager of the Detroit Tigers, smoking a cigar and plotting new tortures for the already tormented Yankees.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower responded to pleas from New England today and set up a special Federal committee to investigate economic problems plaguing the textile industry.
When women from twenty-two countries met recently in Vienna, they renewed their stand on the need for controlled reduction of nuclear weapons.

Most of the franchised bus companies in the city appeared at a State Public Service Commission hearing yesterday to oppose the application of a small Yonkers company to continue serving a group of eighty commuters to mid-Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Carmine de Martino, Italian under secretary for foreign affairs, conferred high Italian decorations today on United States legislators, prominent public figures and a Catholic priest.

Steel industry and union leaders transferred into a joint news conference yesterday the deadlock on basic economics that has kept them from moving one inch forward in two weeks of collective bargaining.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Vincent Sheean has received a United States passport valid for Communist China, where he intends to set up a news bureau for the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company.
The baby buggy brigade will get a break in the Bronx.

First-quarter net income of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation declined to $929,976 from $2,147,711 in the 1958 period. Spyros P. Skouras, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that the earnings were adversely affected by several unsuccessful pictures.

Stockholders of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theaters, Inc. at the seventh annual meeting yesterday elected two directors to fill vacancies. They were Joseph A. Martino, president of the National Lead Company, and Alger B. Chapman, chairman and chief executive officer of Beech-Nut Life Savers, Inc. Mr. Chapman also is a senior partner in Chapman, Walsh and O'Connell, Washington law firm.
KANSAS CITY, May 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Truman's tumor was reported to have been benign by Research Hospital today.

The enigmatic Yankees continued to move in reverse last night. Before 18,341 perplexed onlookers at the Stadium, Casey Stengel's floundering world champions bowed for the third straight time to the Tigers.

Building materials and oils were the only vigorous groups in yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange Golds, drugs and Cuban sugar issues were weak. Other important divisions of the market were mixed.
SPECIAL programing, which has become such a major factor in evening television, came to daytime video yesterday afternoon in the form of an hour-long presentation entitled "Woman!"
GENEVA, May 19 -- Following is the text of the principles agreed upon by the United States, Britain, France and West Germany for a German peace settlement:
TRENTON, May 19 -- Six New Jersey communities elected or installed mayors and other municipal officers today.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Atomic Energy Commission proposed today to turn over to the states some of the responsibilities for protecting the public against radiation hazards.

IN its summer exhibition, opening today, the Museum of Primitive Art, 15 West Fifty-fourth Street, has assembled nearly fifty pieces of stone sculpture from pre-Columbian Mexico. The pieces, most of them not previously shown, include figures, masks, ceremonial objects, pieces large and small in a variety of styles and ranging in time from about 800 B. C. to about 1500 A. D.
The West Berlin All-Stars completed an undefeated tour of this country last night when they blanked the New York Hungarians, 4 -- 0, at Eintracht Oval, Astoria, Queens.

The report that a group of top chemical executives recently celebrated Science Day away from the retorts and test-tubes of their laboratories is a significant one. They appeared instead at a career conference sponsored jointly by the Manufacturing Chemists Association, the American Chemical Society and the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, in cooperation with the New York Board of Education, the Archdiocese of New York and private schools in the area.
I would not curtail the Senate's right to screen Presidential appointees. Yet what we have seen lately looks like the workings of personal animus, both undignified and unrational.
NEWARK May 19 -- The 5,400 striking electrical workers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company won support today from the utility's clerical employes.

The career of the controversial literary figure, Ezra Pound, has raised many questions. Was he a traitor? Was he illegally held in St. Elizabeth's Hospital for twelve years? Should the Bollingen Award, sponsored by the Library of Congress, have been given to a man in a mental institution and under indictment for treason?

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Willis Gale, chairman of the Commonwealth Edison Company told the annual stockholders' meeting today that "current thinking" favored another stock dividend next fall, but that the final decision would be put off until September.

In your editorial "Latin-American Affairs" of May 13 you mention the growing anti-United States and anti-Western feelings in this area with some surprise. Asserting that the Latin-American feelings are more than just "partly justified," we welcome a more positive program for combating communism "by strengthening the material and spiritual bases for democracy."
OTTAWA, May 19 (Canadian Press) -- D. W. Ambridge, president of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, said today his company would not spend 5 cents on expansion in Ontario.

YONKERS, May 19 -- Eight policemen with revolvers drawn tiptoed into the darkened Roosevelt High School at 1:15 A. M. today in search of burglars. They found fifty teen-aged politicians busily putting up posters for a school election.
CLIVEDEN, England, May 19 (AP) -- Lady Astor, the fiery Virginia redhead who brightened the British political stage from 1919 to 1945, celebrated her eightieth birthday today by polishing her golf.

MIAMI BEACH, May 19 -- In a union of table-thumpers, high-decibel orators and aging leaders, Louis Stulberg, a relaxed, quiet and comparatively youthful man of 57 years, would not be expected to make much of an impression.
John Cleary is a circuit golfer who is also an instructor at a Brooklyn driving range. He toured the last two winters and taught during the other months.
ROME, May 19 -- King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece arrived here today for a state visit amid speculation that a Mediterranean pact is being arranged.
The city moved yesterday to meet a sharp rise in Staten Island's water needs that it expects from a population boom in the middle Nineteen Sixties.
BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Massachusetts Lord's Day laws that require kosher markets to close Sundays were declared discriminatory and unconstitutional today by two Federal court judges.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that Congressmen who acclaim the novel "The Ugly American" should remember that there could well be a book entitled "The Ugly Senator." He said the chamber had had its misfits, too.
Robert Battipaglia declared last night that he would go to court to fight any movement to unseat him as Queens Democratic leader.
The long-debated sale of the city's three transit power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company was completed yesterday at a public auction in City Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower signed without comment today a bill increasing retirement benefits for railroad workers by about 10 per cent and increasing their unemployment benefits by 20 per cent, both changes are effective June 1.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and eleven colleagues offered today a "human rights" bill that would ban the poll tax and prohibit discrimination in employment.
Marshall Cassidy, the director of racing for the New York Racing Association, said yesterday that there was no picketing of any of the local race tracks. He added that he hoped there would be none.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Republicans and conservative Democrats won the Eisenhower Administration's public endorsement today of a new economy-slanted omnibus housing bill.

TULSA, Okla., May 19 (Canadian Press) -- Major American oil companies hold the key to Canadian oil markets in the United States, W. Harold Rea, president of Canadian Oil Companies Ltd., said today in an address to the Tulsa Harvard Club.
A second son was born yesterday to Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Daniel. Mrs. Daniel is the former Margaret Truman, the daughter of former President and Mrs. Harry S. Truman.
There need be no limit to the expansion of foreign trade through the Port of New York, Vincent G. Barnett, chairman of the board of the Barber Steamship Lines said yesterday.
Roy Foster, realty investor, has added to his holdings in the Yorkville area with the purchase of the seven-story building at 1262 to 1270 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Eighty-fifth Street.
TRENTON, May 19 -- State personnel and funds have been allocated toward the reclamation of the 14,000 acres of meadowland in the Hackensack River Valley.
STRATFORD, Conn, May 19 -- Fourteen hundred students from five states came here today by bus to start the first annual school program of the American Shakespeare Festival.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19 -- An international campaign for aid to the blind was opened here today. It is called the Helen Keller World Crusade in honor of the American blind and deaf woman whose lifework has been rehabilitation of the sightless.
LONDON, May 19 -- A British shipping company has urged automobile manufacturers here to boycott the port of Los Angeles because of "shocking" labor conditions there.

GENEVA, May 19 -- The Western powers have drafted and agreed upon a set of basic principles for a peace settlement with an all-German government to counter the Soviet-Union's proposal for a peace treaty with the parts of divided Germany.

Two conferences between Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack and representatives of Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Street interests have been set to discuss the projected widening of those streets.

i Geranium Journey, a tour ofl four homes and a garden in Somerset County, N. Jo, on Saturday afternoon, will benefit the !Somerset Hospital. Vlrs. James IRoss, Vfrs. Raymoncl Bateman land Mrs. Peter Townsend are co-chairmen for the fifth anniversary event which, is under the sponsorship of the Ivy Twig, a section of the Woman's Auxiiliary-Board of the hospital.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- A 17-year-old boy who was born in a lifeboat in the North Atlantic has been accepted as a cadet in the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- Robert Frost said today he hoped that the United States, unlike ancient Carthage, would leave artistic traditions for future ages. He suggested that a Department of Arts might be the answer.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company achieved records in crude oil output, refinery runs and marketing operations in the first quarter of 1959, Albert L. Nickerson, president, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- An Administration spokesman said today the Federal Treasury could not afford to advance an estimated total of $4,300,000,000 to buy state-built toll roads for the interstate highway system.
The Bronx robin with a penchant for real estate holdings gave up her career as builder yesterday to become a housewife and mother.

GENEVA, May 19 -- There are three conferences, not just one, going on in Geneva, all of them having a bearing on whether there will be a summit conference with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 19 -- A senior member of the House Ways and Means Committee criticized sharply today commercial bank proposals for inreasing Federal taxes on mutual thrift institutions. All tax legislation must originate from this commitee.
Thirty-four children were killed by automobiles in the city from Jan. 1 to Sunday compared with seventeen in the similar period last year, the police disclosed yesterday.

Automobile liability insurance rates for most trucks in the city will rise 23.1 per cent effective today. Elsewhere in the state, the rate increase will average 12 per cent, so that the average state-wide rise will be 16.1 per cent.

Blood will be given to the Red Cross today at the Israel Center of Hillcrest Manor, 167-11 Seventy-third Avenue, Flushing, Queens. There will also be donations for the second day at Macy's in Herald Square and at United Nations headquarters.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19 -- Chile supported today the righth of states to expropriate or nationalize property owned by foreign investors if they acted in accordance with national laws, did not discriminate and paid proper compensation to the owners.
FEMALE guile is overcoming male truculence in New York's quality men's shops.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower submitted to Congress today agreements to help Britain produce atomic weapons and to help France develop an atomic submarine.
THE dry-fly angler, persecuted and embittered in the early weeks of the season by high, cold, dirty water and no fly hatches, is now throwing his weight about and talking big in the beer joints.
MIAMI BEACH, May 19 -- For the first time in twenty-seven years David Dubinsky relinquished today some of his power as the leader of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 19 (AP) -- Bill Hartack was suspended for the balance of the Garden State Park meeting today for "unbecoming conduct" following the sixth race last Saturday.

Stockholders of Seatrain Lines, Inc., elected the management's nominees for directors yesterday, despite assertions of mismanagement made against the board by Graham M. Brush, a founder of the company.
A strong plea for public support for the proposed $500,000,000 bond issue for school construction was made last night by Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.

WHEN General Foods and General Mills demonstrate their wares at the American National Exhibition in Moscow this summer, they will be carrying into the realm of food the theme of the event: To provide for the average Russian a clear picture of the daily life of his American counterpart.

Plans for merging Pittsburgh's second and third largest banks have been approved by directors, it was announced yesterday. The announcement was made jointly by Frank E. Agnew Jr., president of the Peoples First National Bank and Trust Company, and John A. Byerly, president of the Fidelity Trust Company, the two banks concerned.

NOT too long ago, artifical flowers were scorned by a majority of homemakers. Most of the flowers were made of crepe paper or papier mache and, no matter how pretty they looked when bought, they soon faded and collected dust. Very seldom did they look real.

The choice presented to President Eisenhower by the Railroad Retirement Bill was an exceptionally difficult one. While there were good reasons -- quite apart from the politics of the situation -- behind his decision to sign it, the cost of that decision should not be overlooked.
LONDON, May 20 -- Prices advanced on a broad front in the stock market here today, although the turnover did not expand and most rises were less than a shilling (14 cents).

Man's superiority over the rest of the Animal Kingdom is said to stem from his unique ability to think, and an important aspect of this ability to think is the way in which he can anticipate what is to happen in the future and prepare for it accordingly.

THE first Yankee to emerge from the runway into the dugout yesterday was Hank Bauer. From force of habit he glanced at the bulletin board where Casey Stengel normally posts his line-up card. No card was there. Instead a placard was clipped to the board. It bore the beaming message, "Life is wonderful.
Francis W. H. Adams, a Manhattan member of the Board of Education, yesterday defended its selection of a controversial school site in Harlem.

ALDOUS LEONARD HUXLEY once wrote that because of his poor eyesight he had "never been a soldier, never indulged in bull fighting, or lion shooting, or rock climbing -- except once when I put my foot on something which wasn't really there, fell off and dangled ignominiously at the end of a rope."
BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) -- A group of educators reported tonight that public colleges and universities were endangered by too much "political and bureaucratic intrusion" from state governments.
GENEVA, May 20 -- Following are salient facts on the foreign ministers' conference at United Nations headquarters in Geneva:

A conference of more than 160 Americans called by President Eisenhower will begin discussions in Washington today of what the United States can and should do in connection with the forthcoming "World Refugee Year." The observance, under United Nations leadership, opens in June.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 20 (AP) -- Bill Hartack's suspension for the balance of the Garden State Park meeting was upheld today by the New Jersey Racing Commission.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 20 (AP) -- The Texas Railroad Commission ordered a sharp slash today in the June oil allowable. The commission fixed the state-wide flow at 2,904,414 barrels a day. This is a cut of 282,738 barrels a day -- one of the largest reductions ever ordered by the oil regulatory agency.
Two musical benefits for the Phoenix Theatre fund are being arranged by a committee headed by Mrs. Cannon Hersey and Mrs. Guthrie Lorillard.

The public auction that disposed of New York City's three power plants generating electricity for subway trains lasted only two minutes. But it would be more realistic to say that it took thirteen years or more to make the sale, from the time early in the O'Dwyer administration when the first official admission was made that it was a money-losing proposition for the city to be in the power business.

A survey by UNESCO comes up with some disturbing figures on illiteracy in this hemisphere. In Latin America the percentage is about 40 and the school attendance is not keeping pace with population increases.

Justice Jacob Markowitz of the State Supreme Court yesterday ordered further hearings to decide the amount of compensation the Guaranty Trust Company should receive for its services as trustee of the Petroleum Research Fund.
NEW DELHI, India, May 20 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru conferred today with the Communist Chief Minister of Kerala about a threatening school crisis in that state.

DAVE KING, the British comedian, inaugurated his own summer variety series over Channel 4 last night. Wisely, he did not overexert himself, but in quiet and leisurely style was content to settle for pleasant chuckles. His half hour, from 9 to 9:30, could well prove to be one of the brighter spots of the vacation season.

MILWAUKEE, May 20 (AP) -- H. V. Kaltenborn, news analyst of radio and TV, told members of the Wisconsin Broadcasters Association last night to start editorializing. He also urged them to defy a Federal Communications Commission ruling that equal time be given to opposing political candidates in news programs.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- Controller General Joseph Campbell told Congress today that Boeing Airplane Company had submitted to the Government target costs for B-52 bomber parts that the company knew were $5,022,465 too high.
The Park Association of New York took a day-long tour of Brooklyn's parks yesterday, and like good conservationists, left one of them cleaner than when they arrived.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- E. I, du Pont de Nemours Co. said today that a Government plan to force divestiture of the chemical concern's 63,100,000 shares of General Motors Corporation stock would impose a "brutal tax load" on du Pont shareholders.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 20 (AP) -- Two New Jersey men, one a disbarred lawyer and the other an ex-convict, were sentenced today to serve four to nine years each in state prison after pleading guilty to larceny charges in connection with the looting of Fairfield County homes last year.
GENEVA, May 20 -- The West German Government is prepared to sign treaties of nonaggression with Poland and Czechoslovakia and may make the offer at the for eign ministers' conference.

United States shipping interests were rebuffed yesterday in their efforts to win representation at forthcoming maritime policy talks between the Department of State and diplomatic representatives of the seafaring nations of Western Europe.
GENEVA, May 20 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter accused the Soviet Union today of seeking a permanent division of Germany.

James Stout, who pleaded guilty to an assault charge in an indictment that also involved the taking of lewd pictures of himself, his wife and a 15-year-old girl, was sentenced yesterday to serve two and one-half to five years in prison.

NDOLA, Northern Rhodesia, May 20 (Reuters) -- A group of Africans visited hotels, restaurants and other public establishments today to test the trend toward "racial partnership," which whites here say will be the basic principle of an independent Central African Federation.

SWIMMING pools, once found only in the purlieus of the well-to-do, are making a big splash in an increasing number of suburban backyards. While enhancing family prestige and pleasure, pools are not unmixed blessings. Their presence demands responsibility on the part of individual owners to insure pool safety.

A WOMAN who has a country house named "Poisoned Glen," sees numbers in color, studies Greek philosophy and has all her new clothes blessed with holy water has arrived in New York. She could only be Irish, and she is.
THE home furnishings industry was accused yesterday of ignoring the needs and wishes of teen-agers.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren asked the American Law Institute today to study ways of curtailing the jurisdiction of Federal courts as a possible device to reduce the congestion of their dockets.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill providing for the appointment of public defenders to represent impoverished criminal defendants in Federal courts.

YONKERS, May 20 -- One of the more fascinating chores for the fans at Yonkers or any other raceway is the always intriguing, ever challenging, rarely rewarding search for the correct combination in the daily double.

After considerable deliberation of the issues involved in the current hospital strike eighteen social workers from Mount Sinai Hospital acted with unanimous conviction to honor the picket line surrounding our hospital.
The improved tone that has come into the bond market during the past week continued yesterday to find most emphasis in the over-the-counter exchanges of corporate bonds of high investment rank.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 20 -- The State Supreme Court here has denied a request from the State Attorney General's office for a temporary injunction to prohibit Athletics for the Blind, Inc., from collecting used clothing in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

The one-story taxpayer containing six stores at 1353 to 1367 Castle Hill Avenue in the Parkchester area of the Bronx has been sold by the D. S. Corporation. The structure, on a plot 101 by 104 feet, is near Westchester Avenue and was built in 1948.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 20 -- The Communist party of Iraq was subtly challenged today to choose between Premier Abdul Karim Kassim and continued existence as an independent party.
A seventy-acre section of the Phipps Estate at Old Westbury, L. I., has been turned over to a nonprofit organization as a public botanical garden and arboretum.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 29 -- Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi came ashore here this morning to begin a four-day visit that will point up the political and commercial ties between the Netherlands and Iran.
NEWARK, May 20 -- A series of legal steps was taken today against the striking employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company as efforts at mediation failed again.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Board of Education voted here today unanimously to make permanent a "four-track system" that has been tested in Washington's high schools for the last three years.

A concert of twentieth-century music was played by the Mannes Orchestra, conducted by Carl Bamberger, last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association. No avant-garde music was on the program.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- An Algerian rebel spokesman said today that an Algerian military mission seeking assistance from Communist China had been successful.
Kerr-McGee Oil Industries Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $2,534,733, or 98 cents a common share, for the first quarter of this year.
THE shad run in the Connecticut River is in full swing now and people keep coming around here and bragging about catching their limit. It is getting to be pretty thick.
MOSCOW, May 20 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has declared that the Geneva conference will be successful but only through "a great deal of effort."

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union moved yesterday to end the "racketeer" phase of an antitrust prosecution brought by the Justice Department against the union's New York blouse local and three employer associations.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A dissenting member of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that the board did not fulfill its regulatory responsibility in approving the anti-strike aid pact of six major airlines.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 20 -- Joseph B. Lynch, 22 years old, of 363 Lincoln Avenue, Fort Lee, was found guilty today on two indictments resulting from the shooting of two Englewood policemen on Jan. 29.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- The $35,000,000,000 mutual savings bank industry was asked today to spend $150,000 a year for a national advertising campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- State Department officials said today the Algerian rebels' negotiations with Communist China for a supply of arms explained the charge made by an Algerian leader yesterday that the United States had blocked munitions shipments to the insurgents.
CHICAGO, May 20, (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
James R. Hoffa, with his flamboyanc threats of mass strikes, is doing his cocky best to emulate the role John L. Lewis played twelve years ago in spurring Congress to adopt tough labor laws.

The Icelandic-American String Quartet, formed by Icelanders and snowbound Bostonians in 1956, will make its United States debut Wednesday evening, June 3, at the Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library.

On Tuesday only two dozen stockholders turned out for the annual meeting of American Airlines in Wilmington, Del. But yesterday, it was another story. About 4,000 stockholders thronged the company's jet hangar at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- Mayor Richardson Dilworth of Philadelphia told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today that Independence Hall and other historic buildings in his city were near collapse.

Title to the twenty-story office building at 18 East Forty-first Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, has been taken by a group of investor organized by the J. M. Tenney Corporation, a national realty investment company.
NEWARK, May 20 -- A settlement was reached tonight averting a threatened strike against the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Insurance plans by 586 clerical workers.
The Rockefeller Institute, founded in 1901 as a research institution, will confer its first honorary degree, during a two-day convocation that opens at noon today.
GENEVA, May 20 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a speech by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter at the foreign ministers' meeting today:

Mrs. James F. Burns 3d and Mrs. Maitland T. Ijams, co-chairmen of the junior committee for the Celebrity Cocktail Party on Tuesday, have announced the names of their aides. The fete, an annual event, will be held at the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres today. "Ask Any Girl," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer comedy with David Niven, Shirley MacLaine and Gig Young, is the new offering at the Radio City Music Hall. Joe Pasternak produced and Charles Walters directed, from a scenario by George Wells.

The Empire Commercial Corporation, real estate and construction financing, leased large space in the Tishman Building, 666 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-second Street, and will move its executive offices from the Empire State Building. Ian G. M. Brownlie and Jerry L. Cohen of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas said today he would not make a party issue out of President Eisenhower's controversial nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce.
A bright economic future for France was outlined last night by Antoine Pinay, the nation's Minister of Finance, in a speech at a dinner given in his honor by New York University.

THE Lozano-Fisher Studios is marking the opening of its spacious penthouse showroom today by introducing several new textile ingredients in Matias Lozano's handwoven fabrics and blinds. This imaginative collection is now available at the showroom, 64 East Fifty-fifth Street.
BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) -- Lanky Dick Donovan of the Chicago White Sox pitched a four-hitter that defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5 -- 2, tonight.
WITHIN the last decade, Americans have turned with gusto and relish to that most primitive form of cookery, the barbecue.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 20 (UPI) -- Striking carpenters asked other unions today not to cross their picket lines at the Air Force missile test center. Should the request be heeded, missile operations would be paralyzed.

VERPLANCK, N. Y., May 20 -- Boat owners needing Hudson River moorings and other marine facilities in this area of scarcity will go from rags to riches. Three marinas are planned, the first to be ready next year.
A labor dispute involving 1,400 employes loomed yesterday at the three transit power plants sold by the city Tuesday to the Consolidated Edison Company effective July 1.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- The Kremlin was reported today to have recently stepped up its campaign against the practice of the Jewish religion in the Soviet Union.
The F. W. Woolworth Company expects considerably improved sales and profits during 1959, Robert C. Kirkwood, president, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Watertown, N. Y.
Bob Hope will star in six special television shows next season.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- The Senate overrode the Administration's economy arguments today and voted to authorize $50,000,000 for participation in a world-wide "Health-for-Peace" program.
The cotton futures market declined 2 to 15 points yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale. The far months were relatively weakest.

At the annual meeting here yesterday, S. Ralph Lazrus, president of the Benrus Watch Company, said the company had a loss of $257,897 in the three months ended April 30. That was about $100,000 less than last year.

HONG KONG, May 20 -- The Government of Communist North Vietnam joined with leading official Communist publications in North Korea and Communist China today in denouncing the Royal Government of Laos for its action against former Pathet Lao fighting units.
MOSCOW, May 19 -- Theatre Square in Moscow is not yet Hyde Park or Union Square, but far into the night it often resounds to free-for-all discussions about America and Russia.
Some balm for Robert Moses, who has suffered the slings and arrows of outraged proponents of free Shakespeare, came yesterday in the form of an award from the Municipal Art Society.

Miss Therese Washington, 18-year-old Negro clerk-typist for The Amsterdam News, was selected last night as Miss Page One of the Newspaper Guild of New York. She will reign as Queen of the Page One Ball sponsored by the guild at the Astor Hotel June 26. She is the first Negro to win the contest.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- Thirty-one nations have agreed to make intensive efforts to assist the millions of homeless refugees scattered through Europe, Asia, North Africa and the Middle East.

This week President Eisenhower presented awards of $500 each to four students graduating from college or graduate school this June for outstanding scholastic achievement." One is receiving his Ph. D. degree in higher mathematics at the Masachusetts Institute of Technology. His dissertation is on "Formal Integration by a Digital Computer." "Outstanding achievement" is an understatement. James R. Slagle is totally blind.
A nuclear physicist won an important point yesterday in Federal Court in his fight for compensation from the Government for a secret device he invented in 1941.

" The Return of Lady Brace" is likely to mark the local managerial debut of Herbert Bayard Swope Jr., an executive producer and director in the television field. Mr. Swope's only previous connection with Broadway took place in 1954 as director of "Fragile Fox."

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Following is the text of the statement issued today by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations on the Senate's revised labor reform legislation:
The extreme outsider in the betting got off fast and the favorite halted on leaving the gate in the $58,600 Carter Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
The House That Ruth Built was a house of dejection yesterday.

The topic at the season's last meeting of the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club in the Hotel Manhattan was "Has Obedience a Place in the Average Dog Show?" Nobody disagreed very much with anybody else. The answer by every scheduled speaker was "Yes."

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday May 13:
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House of Representatives rejected a coalition's omnibus housing bill today to give Democratic leaders and liberals a tactical victory in a hard, close battle.
LONDON, May 20 -- Plans were announced today for an integrated housing, shopping and cultural center that would more than double the City of London's resident population within seven years.

TIZI-OUZOU, Algeria, May 20 -- Fifteen French prisoners released by the Nationalist rebels gave evidence today of having been deeply impressed by the "high morale" and "iron discipline" of their captors.

An estimated 1,000,000 Russian women are expected to visit the American National Exhibition in Moscow this summer. The majority of them will be tantelized, if not transformed, by the activities of an American cosmetic company. It plans to send eight experts, all beautiful and all fluent in Russian, to make personal analyses of the make-up needs of Russian women.

The Empire State Music Festival, which opens its four-week season on July 10, will be held this summer in the Anthony Wayne Recreation Area, Harriman State Park, adjacent to Bear Mountain. The announcement was made yesterday by Frank Forest, general manager.
BONN, Germany, May 20 -- The Government announced tonight a "number of individuals" had been arrested on suspicion of acting for East German intelligence.
Francis G. Barrett was re-elected president of New York Typographical Union 6 (Big Six) yesterday.
Kanawha County, W. Va., which covers the state capital of Charleston, was the major borrower in the market for local government bonds yesterday.

A group of reform leaders got an emphatic "no" last night from Carmine G. De Saipo when they asked him to use his influence to get the Democratic county executive committee to do more to democratize the party than was being proposed.

Robert Moses and the other members of the Slum Clearance Committee disclosed yesterday that former Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. had proposed the Manhattantown redevelopment project on the upper West Side.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Transactions in May futures contracts on the Board of Trade expired today with the wheat and rye deliveries under strong pressure but with the feed grains firm. Soybeans declined moderately.

THE special style of casual reporting that frequently appears in The New Yorker magazine is practiced by a small number of its contributors, some of whom eventually put their pieces together in book form. An ace among them, Joseph Mitchell, is so effortless and thorough at the same time that his expectant admirers must wait years between stories and ages for his books.

Aldous Huxley was acclaimed yesterday for "having done the best work of our time in what threatens to be a neglected field, the novel of ideas" as he received an American Academy of Arts and Letters medal for his novels.

GENEVA, May 20 -- Your society reporter at the Geneva conference has an interesting item to report today. Secretary of State Christian A. Herter will give a dinner at the Villa Greta tomorrow night for the foreign ministers of the Soviet Union, Britain and France, and the two principal political assistants of each.
Values on the New York Stock Exchange gave ground grudgingly yesterday as electronics issues, in the morning, underwent a heavy pounding. At the close the losses had been materially reduced.
A change in the garage provisions of the city's 1916 zoning law was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
A plan to speed rush-hour service on the BMT lines between Brooklyn and Manhattan was announced by the Transit Authority yesterday.
HACKENSACK, N. J., May 20 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders today adopted a resolution accusing the Port of New York Authority of making an unwarrantedd entry into private enterprise.
A Federal tax plan that would encourage the production and consumption of low-proof whisky was suggested yesterday by Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman and president of Schenley Industries, Inc.
CHICAGO, May 20 -- The head of American Can announced today that the company would enter politics down to the ward and precinct level.

LOS ANGELES, May 20 (UPI) -- A Hollywood boxing promoter testified today that Eastern boxing racketeers attempted to gain control of the world welterweight championship fight here last December and threatened physical harm when they were turned down.

The Pennsalt Chemicals Corporation plans a three-for-one split of the common stock and increases in the number of authorized shares and the dividend rate. The board of the producer of industrial chemicals and chemical specialties recommended yesterday an increase in the authorized common stock to 10,000,000 shares from the present 2,000,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The United States would like fewer fine phrases and more fine print on the Soviet Union's proposal to limit the number of on-site inspections in policing a suspension of nuclear tests.

Cyrus S. Eaton Jr., a director of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, is reported in the latest "insider's" list issued by the New York Stock Exchange as selling 22,500 shares of the C. O.'s stock on May 15.

IT was a happy idea to end the city's first officially approved music festival, the tribute to Handel, with a free concert in Central Park last night. It was as pleasant an occasion as the free Shakespeare used to be.

BUENOS AIRES, May 20 -- Peronist agitators set off teargas bombs tonight in a meeting at which representatives of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions pledged support for Argentina's democratic unions.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 20 -- President Mohammed Ayub Khan took steps today to avert chaotic rivalry for the succession should his office fall vacant before a new Constitution is in force.

Mayor Wagner yesterday criticized Congress for cutting the requested Federal Civil Defense budget by 41 per cent and declared that "Russia must be amazed" at the thinking and acting of some Washington officials.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 20 -- Two rabbinical scholars examined contemporary religion here today and came up with varying estimates of the future of man's relation to God.
After a stormy two-hour session, the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday adjourned the hearing on Ray Robinson's world middleweight championship until 2 P. M. tomorrow.
Your editorial "One-Way Avenues" in The Times of May 13 prompts reply with respect to the inconvenience and dislocation which the proposed change would cause.
GENEVA, May 20 -- The Soviet Union put forward new suggestions today on limits for a scientists' conference on detecting nuclear explosions.
The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to 3,319,332 shares as of May 15. That was a decrease of 192,462 shares from the 3,511,794 reported on April 15 of this year.
Striking hospital workers last night voted overwhelmingly to reject a management proposal to end a thirteen-day walkout at six voluntary hospitals.

The Board of Hospitals voted unanimously yesterday to integrate all the professional services of Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn with the teaching services of the State University Downstate Medical School.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 (UPI) -- Eddie Machen vaulted back into the heavyweight picture tonight with a unanimous ten-round decision over Rueben Vargas in a nationally televised bout in Cow Palace.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, May 20 (Reuters) -- Malaya's ruling Alliance party won two state elections today in the nation's first major voting in four years.
The Alberta Municipal Financing Corporation, an agency of the Province of Alberta, Canada, plans to raise $50,000,000 in the United States through the sale of long-term debentures.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 -- Film biographers, rummaging through the attics of time from Biblical prophets to jazz musicians, cannot complain, as Plutarch did occasionally, of the shortage of eyewitnesses.
A special committee was appointed yesterday by the Board of Higher Education to study the future needs of the municipal college system.
PANAMA, May 20 -- Land reform, "whenever appropriate," was recommended to Latin-American Governments today as a means for curing the ills of the region's agriculture.

The United States Customs Court is just about the fastest in the Federal system, Webster J. Oliver, Chief Judge of the court, said last night. He noted that a case was generally called for trial in sixty days.
