Looking beyond its plans for achieving a balanced budget in 1960, the Administration has hinted that the next logical expectation would be a reduction in the Federal debt, a tax reduction or both.

Union and company negotiators, in the crucial negotations on a new contract for steel workers, reverted yesterday to their no-information policy about bargaining developments. Their daily briefing session for the press set a speed record of one minute and ten seconds from the time union and industry representatives came in the door until they walked out.

The Deputy State Housing Commissioner, Joseph B. Terbell, made critical remarks about the New York City Housing Authority yesterday. The occasion was a ground-breaking ceremony to start Wilson Houses, a state-aided public housing project at First Avenue and East 105th Street.
The New York Rugby Club and Dartmouth, both undefeated, will meet Saturday at Hanover, N. H., to determine the 1959 champion of the Eastern Rugby Union.
CHICAGO, May 20 -- Advertising directors were urged today to bring their bosses into closer touch with marketing through "better management of top management."

Events tonight: Free concert of contemporary Swiss music, Donnell Library Center Auditorium, 8:15; Oratorio Society of New York, William Strickland conducting, St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, 8:45.
PARIS, May 20 (Reuters) -- Four European airlines decided today to form a Europair pool to meet American and British jet competition across the Atlantic.

Emile Zola Berman, attorney for State Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan, said yesterday he would renew today his request for the postponement of Mr. Monaghan's hearing before the State Investigation Commission on charges of violation of the ethics code.

Twenty-eight cocoa notices were posted yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The circulation of these notices, increased offerings of actuals and continued heavy arrival of cocoa in this country depressed futures.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- The idea of a World Refugee Year began in the spring of 1958 with four Britons who wrote a series of articles for the British political magazine Crossbow. The four were Christopher Chataway, the British track star, and Colin Jones, Trevor Philpott and Tim Raison.

Frederick N. Lowe has been named director of promotion and public relations of The New York Journal-American, Kingsbury Smith, publisher, announced yesterday. Mr. Lowe succeeds Sumner Collins, who was recently advanced to circulation promotion director for all the Hearst newspapers.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House of Representatives voted today to put a limit of $50,000 on individual loan payments under the farm price-support program. The vote, 261 to 165, preceded final passage of the $4,360,000,000 agriculture appropriations bill.
State Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold offered yesterday to medate the dispute between Robert Moses and Joseph Papp over free Shakespeare in Central Park.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The nation's highest civilian award -- the Medal of Freedom -- was bestowed on John Foster Dulles yesterday by President Eisenhower.
PARIS, May 20 -- Supporters of Algeria's integration with France maintain that the area would keep its own tax structure if integration came about. Lower tax rates apply there than in France.
OTTAWA, May 20 (AP) -- A proposal to settle Canadian-United States differences on the employment of the St. Lawrence Seaway pilots has been made by Canada in a formal diplomatic note.

Bobby Fischer, the United States champion, held his own for fifty-seven moves and was still going strong when a second adjournment was taken yesterday in his first-round match of the Jubilee chess tournament, according to a report received from Zurich.
IF we had to deal only with appearances and technique, it would be a pleasure to write about "Fallout," which opened at the Renata in Bleecker Street last evening.

A series of monographs on the peoples, countries and problems of the Middle East is being prepared by the Council for Middle Eastern Affairs. The first in the series, to be published Monday, is "Jordan, A State of Tension," by Benjamin Shwadran.

Your April 13 editorial opposing the "fair trade" bills and the subsequent exchange of opinion between J. A. Goldfarb (May 7) and H. W. Beer (May 15), which appeared in your letters column, have performed a great public service by spotlighting the gravity of the effects of passage of this legislation.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- At a meeting with President Eisenhower today, the board of governors of the American Bar Association reaffirmed its policy that all appointments to the Federal judiciary be submitted for screening to the association's committee on Federal judgeships.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Labor's top command said unequivocally today that it would not support the labor reform bill as it had passed the Senate.
The Phoenix Theatre on lower Second Avenue glowed with optimism yesterday for the second time in a little more than two weeks.

The possibility of a British challenge for the America's Cup before 1961 is remote George R. Hinman, the commodore of the New York Yacht Club, said yesterday. Even if a challenge materializes that year, he added, it is unlikely that the actual match can take place before 1962 or 1963.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley accused the Fifth Avenue Coach Company of "scurrilous tactics" yesterday in warning workers that additional one-way avenue traffic would mean the loss of jobs. The company immediately denied the charge.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- The Public Health Service warned today that paralytic poliomyelitis was rising. The number of cases in the first four months of the year is nearly double that for the same period last year, it said.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- The Public Health Service warned today that paralytic poliomyelitis was rising. The number of cases in the first four months of the year is nearly double that for the same period last year, it said.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 -- James R. Hoffa declared today that there would "never be a nation-wide strike of the Teamsters' Union."
CHICAGO, May 20 -- The University of Chicago erased today the last vestige of Dr. Robert M. Hutchins' controversial undergraduate plan. But it clung to some of his basic education theories.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- John deLaittre, new president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, thinks something should be done to correct the factors that have limited savings banking largely to the Northeast.

" Power Among Men," the first feature produced by the United Nations Film Services, will receive City College's annual Robert J. Flaherty Award for outstanding creative achievement in the documentary-film field in 1958.
Mutual Broadcasting System radio stations throughout the nation this week are being told how to use an established newspaper yardstick to measure their own local impact.
A leading cancer researcher here defended yesterday those who work to cure human disease against the implication, by other scientists, that they are engaged in something inferior to "basic research."

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The statement by Senator Johnson of Texas today that the Senate majority leadership will lay down no party line on the issue of confirming Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce does not change the extreme probability that the issue will be resolved by Johnson's vote on the motion to confirm Strauss.

Directors of Consolidated Natural Gas Company made two executive changes and set the price for the company's one-for-ten subscription offer at the organization meeting following Tuesday's annual stockholders' meeting.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A White House conference on world refugees begins tomorrow.
Harold S. Geneen resigned yesterday as executive vice president of the Raytheon Company to become president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

LOS ANGELES, May 20 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7 -- 5, behind Don Newcombe's six-hit pitching in the second game of a twilight-night double-header before a crowd of 32,252 tonight.

The New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the election of Clarence J. Myers as chairman. Mr. Myers, 62 years old, will continue as president, an office he has held since 1954. As chairman he succeeds Devereux C. Josephs, 65 years old, who is retiring. Mr. Josephs will continue as a director.

ANACONDA, Mont., May 20 (AP) -- Barring protracted strikes in major industries this summer, the copper supply should remain in comfortable balance this year, Clyde E. Weed, chairman of Anaconda Company, told the annual meeting today.

HAVANA, May 20 -- Representatives of American sugar mills will meet tomorrow, reportedly to prepare a protest against the new agrarian law of Premier Fidel Castro that will strip American mills of their cane lands.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- Paul Hoffman, managing director of the United Nations Special Fund, said today that it might be necessary to double the rate of investment in under-developed countries within the next ten years.
John Hawkinson, vice president, treasurer and a director of Central Life Assurance Company of Des Moines, Iowa, has been elected to the board of directors of Douglas Oil Company of California.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- The dispute between savings and commercial banks continued to receive top billing as the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks ended one three-day convention here and the New Jersey Bankers Association began another.
For the first time in at least a decade, New York led the nation's ten largest cities last year in percentage increase of Boy Scout membership.
Wall Street joined other sections of the city yesterday in beautifying itself with plants and shrubs.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 20 -- Sixty delegates to the general assembly of the United Presbyterian Church moved out of a private club here yesterday after a Negro church leader was refused a room.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 20 (Reuters) -- An Israeli who saw his family murdered in a Rumanian concentration camp and spent ten years tracking down their killer, finally shot him to death when they both were fighting for the French Foreign Legion, it was disclosed here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- A little known refugee group consists of seamen. There are about a thousand seamen who have no country to which they can return and no government to protect their rights.

Capital expenditures of the Sinclair Oil Corporation in 1959 are expected to be about $135,000,000, or $4,000,000 more than in 1958, P. C. Spencer, chairman and chief executive officer, reported at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Justice Department announced the completion today of its program for restoring citizenship to Japanese-Americans who renounced it during World War II and later applied for restitution.
BOMBAY, India, May 20 (Reuters) -- Premier Khrushchev was quoted here today as having said that the people of the United Arab Republic had no more sincere and true friend than the Soviet Union.

Has the last stronghold of the male retreat crumbled? For the first time, as far as anyone can remember, a fashion show of fall college clothes for young women was staged right in the middle of a private men's club dining room. This unexpected event took place yesterday at the dignified Princeton Club.
LONDON, May 20 -- Sir Miles Thomas, chairman of Monsanto Chemicals, Ltd., vigorously defended today United States investment in British industry.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- New missile - firing, nuclear - powered submarines will be able to remain at sea so long that they will require two crews, the Navy said today.

After more than two months of delay the House of Representatives is taking up the Housing Act of 1959, S. 57. This legislation has already passed the Senate by an overwhelming majority in a slightly different version. The House bill contains eight major titles dealing with Federal credit aids to housing and urban renewal.
The Ford Motor Company has won a close race with coincidence.

GENEVA, May 20 -- The six-nation European Common Market refused today to acknowledge any obligation to air its policies regularly before the member countries of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

LOUISVILLE, May 20 -- Brooks Hays, retiring president, urged the Southern Baptist Convention today to approve a conference with the two leading Negro denominations to ease racial tensions in the South.
WINDHOEK, South-West Africa, May 20 -- The administrator of South-West Africa asserted today that progress of the territory lay in stronger ties with the Union of South Africa.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries have reported a rise of 5.4 per cent in operating revenues for the twelve months ended April 30. Electric revenues were up 6.7 per cent and net income rose 3.2 per cent.

TALK about a new appetizer travels as fast as scandal. The tidbit that was so delightfully different at last week's cocktail party has been used by so many hostesses in the meantime that it is old hat today.
IN fashion, as in baseball, a well-executed triple play is a fine thing to see. In this case, the players involved are Michel Goma, Boutique Imports, Inc., and Lord Taylor.
Sugar Ray Robinson said yesterday he would "go all the way to the Supreme Court" if the New York State Athletic Commission vacated his middleweight boxing title.

A large share of the responsibility for the hospital strike must be assigned to the studied inactivity of the New York State Department of Labor. This do-nothingness helped to precipitate the strike and now helps to prolong it.
Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly for twenty-two years, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady, N. Y. He was 57 years old.
BONN, Germany, May 21 -- Leaders of the Christian Democratic Union are expected within ten days to choose Dr. Ludwig Erhard to succeed Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

SEATTLE, May 21 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo, the star of the United States 1958 Davis Cup tennis victory over Australia, headed an eleven-man preliminary squad named tonight by the United States Lawn Tennis Association to the 1959 team.
PAT BOONE had a supporting cast of 4,000 last night as he appeared on Channel 7 in a program prepared on video tape at the United States Naval Academy.

Changing patterns of life in America are causing numerous problems for the fire insurance industry, according to speakers yesterday at the ninety-third annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters in the Biltmore Hotel.
PARIS, May 21 -- Serenity returned to the French Academy today. A seat that the much disturbed body was unable to fill a month ago now has an occupant.

PACKING cases and cartons may conceal unwelcome guests, the New York Pest Control Association reports. The cockroach, now becoming increasingly resistant to chlordane, often arrives hidden in crates and boxes and remains in even the most spotless homes.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Labor leaders view the so-called "bill of rights," even in its modified form, as the most threatening amendment inserted in the Kennedy labor reform bill.
The driver of a delivery truck was killed and eight children were injured yesterday when the truck and a school car collided at Burke and Fish Avenues, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson denounced as "propaganda" today suggestions that he would decide the fate of Lewis L. Strauss' nomination to be Secretary of Commerce.
The Federal Government moved yesterday to smash what it called the largest crime syndicate in the United States -- a branch of the Sicilian underworld organization, the Mafia.

HAVANA, May 21 -- Opposition to Premier Fidel Castro's Agrarian Reform Law was expressed late today at a closed meeting of the Sugar Mill Owners Association. All but seven of the island's 161 mills were represented.

THE secret to the shadowy excitement of Baronio Fabric's new line is all in the weave. A printed warp combined with a plain woof produces a wondrous hazy quality in all of the thirty-two upholstery and drapery designs introduced.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Francis Bowes Sayre Jr. went back today to his birthplace, the White House. At his birth it was occupied by his grandfather, President Woodrow Wilson. From then until now, no other child has been born there.

" WHEN we lost the pennant in 1954," once said Charley Silvera, the flippant Yankee bullpen catcher, "it almost broke up my happy home. My wife was so accustomed to seeing those world series checks that she thought I was holding out on her when I didn't get one."

The Aging Men The recent visit to these shores of our old friend Sir Winston Churchill points up how dependent the world has become on the aging men. While the 84-year-old British war leader, in the words of President Eisenhower, shows "some of the wear and tear of advancing years," he still is vigorous enough to have declared his intention of standing again for Parliament.

The election of the first two representatives of the Saudi Arabian Government as directors of the Arabian American Oil Company was announced here yesterday. They are Sheik Hafiz Wahba, Saudi Arabia's Ambassador-at-large to the Arab world, and Sheik Abdullah al-Tariki, Director General of Petroleum and Mineral Affairs for Saudi Arabia.

BERLIN, May 21 (AP) -- An East German farming community demonstrated against its Communist regime last weekend, a West Berlin newspaper reported today. Confirmation was lacking from East German officials.

Following is the text of the recommendations made yesterday by the State Education Commissioner's committee on inquiry into charge sof waste and extravagance in the construction of school buildings in New York City:
In her book about the Henry Street Settlement, "Windows On Henry Street," Lillian D. Wald said: "Settlements correspond more to many needs than any other form of social organization.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 -- President Jorge Alessandri reported today that Chile's economy was now in a far more satisfactory condition than six months ago, when he was inaugurated for the six-year term.

Average borrowings by member banks increased $144,000,000 to $853,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves, on the average, increased $162,000,000 to $606,000,000 from a revised figure of $444,000,000 the week before.

The Geneva conference of foreign ministers has already produced one important result: it has brought about a necessary and enlightening clarification of both the aggressive and dictatorial Soviet designs and the real significance of the Western peace plan. The clarification is an essential first step toward a true appraisal of the situation, and it should dispel a lot of muddled Western thinking that has been playing into Soviet hands.
Colleges and universities that once reflected social conditions must now create culture of their own, a convocation at the Rockefeller Institute was told yesterday.

WOMEN who want to tour Europe, but not on their own, have a variety of specialized itineraries from which to choose. The random sampling that follows is not intended to be a complete list; it shows the broader aspects of travel as it applies to food, fashions, family and furnishings.
Joseph Papp offered "certain proposals" yesterday to settle the five-week dispute over free Shakespeare in Central Park.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art is one of the world's great treasure houses. For nearly seventy years it has had a tradition of being open to the public every day, including Sundays and holidays. For nearly twenty years no one has had to pay a penny to enter its doors.

A joint United States-Canadian commission to work out a major St. Lawrence Seaway problem involving piloting was urged yesterday by Alvin Shapiro, vice president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

ADULTS who set out to show New York to youngsters -- their own or small visitors -- are usually well aware of the city's standard attractions for children: skyscrapers, great bridges, complex construction projects and similar examples of modern American proficiency.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union prepared last night to demand a Federal investigation of the recent beatings of two of its officials.

The bond market's new firmness continued yesterday in a quiet and uneventful trading session. Most issues of Treasury securities made slight gains. Over-the-counter trading in high grade corporate and local government bonds was carried out in light volume, but in an atmosphere of improved sentiment.
A tradition of almost seventy years will be broken July 6 when the Metropolitan Museum of Art closes its doors for one day each week -- Monday.

Consolidated Freightways, Inc., the nation's largest motor common carrier from the standpoint of revenues, plans to acquire the business of Smith's Transfer Corporation. Smith's is one of the leading common carrier truck lines serving the Eastern Seaboard, with routes extending from Charleston, W. Va., to Boston, Mass. Consolidated, through subsidiaries, operates a transcontinental system.
THE cosmopolitan character of contemporary Swiss life is reflected in the music, backgrounds and even the names of the three composers performed last night at the Donnell Library Center.

GENEVA, May 21 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter told Andrei A. Gromyko today that he must abandon "accusation and innuendo" in his speeches at the foreign ministers' conference lest they lead to "very serious tensions."
When United States Customs officials declared in 1926 that a bronze bird by Constantin Brancusi looked more like a kitchen utensil they infuriated art societies.
General Sessions Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer yesterday sent the cases of two boys accused of taking part in the murder of Julio Ramos to Children's Court.
Before a pleasure boating season gets too far advanced the skippers, especially the new ones, their families and shipmates, must practice using ropes.

A "political biography" of India's Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, will be published June 25 by Oxford University Press. Titled "Nehru," it has been written by Michael Brecher, Associate Professor of Political Science at McGill University in Montreal.
The executive council of the International Typographical Union is expected here soon to renew efforts to settle the contract dispute between ten New Yor knewspapers and union printers.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 21 (AP) -- A futuristic intercontinental ballistic nose cone was fired 6,000 miles down the Atlantic today and recovered four hours later.
Many physicians do not appreciate sufficiently the fickleness of the germs that cause common infections, a specialist said here yesterday.
The New York City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., has reported an operating deficit of $16,987.10 for the 1958-59 season.
GUATEMALA, May 21 (UPI) -- The Guatemalan Government reported today that six ships were lurking off the Atlantic coast of Guatemala "after loading armaments" in Belize, British Honduras.
With a few exceptions, main branches of American business and industry are moving toward record and near-record performances, a "summit" assessment of economic prospects found yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The American Law Institute approved today a proposal to permit legal therapeutic abortions, under controlled conditions, for the sake of the mother or the unborn child.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold expressed opposition today to the establishment of a United Nations "garrison'' in West Berlin.
Events today: Alta Rae, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall; Concert of Music by Ralph Shapey and Stefan Wolpe, Carl Fischer Concert Hall; Sabricas, flamenco guitarist, Town Hall, all at 8:30 P. M.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- Peter Ustinov, who has established an international reputation as an actor, playwright and short-story writer, made his debut today as a huckster. He found it disconcerting.

A BRIGHT collection of imported sportswear from Italy, England and France disembarked at Ohrbach's yesterday. From the Italians come uninhibited straight colors of the Mediterranean. French contributions are feminine without being fussy and English exports are classically styled in soft shades that are fresh as an English garden.

Lumber production rose to 262,472,000 board feet last week from 256,910,000 a week before, according to reports by regional associations. Last week's production was the highest since Oct. 25, 1958, when it was 264,733,000 board feet.
The nation's leading electrical engineers were told last night that they had forty years in which to apply atomic energy to automobile, ship and rocket transportation.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y. May 21 -- Tolls may remain on the Westchester parkways even if the state takes over the roads, the State Council of Parks was advised today.
Last Wednesday the Yankees dropped into last place in the American League for the first time in nineteen years.
BUENOS AIRES, May 21 -- A delegation of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions got a view of the Argentine labor crisis today as striking bank clerks staged violent demonstrations.
LONDON, May 21 -- Price changes among the industrials were generally irregular in the stock market here today.
Support of the city Board of Education by a committee of the state Board of Education "is simply one sacred cow hiding behind another," Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., May 21 -- This was John R. Inglis Day as far as the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association was concerned. One hundred and fifty colleagues gathered at the Ryewood Country Club to honor the dean of the district's professionals.
TRENTON, May 21 -- New Jersey will begin on June 1 its first general issue of automobile license plates since 1952.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which announced on Monday that it would televise six one-hour news and information programs in prime evening time, had its hand called yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company. The latter said it was preparing not six but seven such special programs.

LONDON, May 21 -- Rumors and reports that tend to depict the British as "soft" toward the Soviet Union and ready to make a deal with it to safeguard Britain's economic_ interests are causing considerable irritation and disquiet here.
ALBANY, May 21 (AP) -- Lower state equalization rates for New York City, which would increase the city's real estate taxing power and debt limit by millions of dollars, were proposed today.

Two small, over-aged and demilitarized World War II aircraft carriers were towed out of the Bayonne Navy Base yesterday, on the first leg of a journey that might end under the hammers and blowtorches of Japanese shipbreakers.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The House of Representatives ignored the threat of a Presidential veto today and passed a liberal omnibus housing bill.

The two-story building at 2926 White Plains Road, the Bronx, has been sold by Century Products, Inc., to the Melard Manufacturing Corporation, manufacturers of faucet aerators. The structure, containing 25,000 square feet of space, was sold through Morice Haymes Co., broker.

MEMPHIS, May 21 (AP) -- Tommy Veech, a rookie pro from Milwaukee, took the first-round lead in the $25,000 Memphis open golf tournament today with a seven-under-par 63 that equaled the course competitive record.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by McKesson Robbins, Inc., in its fiscal year ended March 31, according to the preliminary unaudited report issued by George Van Gorder, chairman.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Copyright Office has decided not to screen obscene, libelous and otherwise illegal material and deny it copyright registration.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Union labor's highest body today directed one of its members, James B. Carey, to halt a membership "raid" at a Long Island plant.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today set aside an Orlando, Fla., TV award on the ground that off-the-record pleas had been made to the Federal Communications Commission in behalf of the winning applicant.

When children look at the city the things that catch their eyes can be as massive as a skyscraper or as small as a sparrow; as dramatic as a five-alarm fire or as down-to-earth as the corner grocery. A display of 100 paintings by children -- done to the theme "Our Town" -- will run tomorrow through June 12 at the Galerie St. Etienne, 46 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Contracts awarded for heavy construction work throughout the country during the first twenty-one weeks of this year amounted to $7,791,600,000. The total was an increase of 7 per cent over the volume of $7,304,300,000 in the comparable period of last year.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The nomination of John M. Cabot, career diplomat, to be Ambassador to Brazil was sent to the Senate by the White House today. Mr. Cabot is now Ambassador to Colombia.
A variety of water, shore and marsh birds are attracting large numbers of nature lovers to the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge as migration reaches a peak.
The Roman Catholic population of the United States, Alaska and Hawaii increased by 3,481,498 last year, bringing the total to 39,505,475.
MASSENA, N. Y., May 21 -- Two old canalers had a field day today on the world's newest inland waterway.
New York Blue Cross presented its case yesterday for increases averaging 34.2 per cent in the premiums it collects for hospitalization insurance covering 7,109,000 persons.
Sharpen your shears and beware of dull-pointed pins and needles when, sewing lightweight fabrics.

In your editorial of May 18 you make the unqualified statement the "the parks belong to all of us."

RYE, N. Y., May 21 -- Famous women of the past will be impersonated for members and friends of the Westchester Bryn Mawr Alumnae Club at the club's scholarship benefit here on Wednesday. The fete will be held at the Apawamis Club.
Opponents and proponents of increasing the number of one-way avenues fought it out at a long noisy public hearing yesterday.

The Capital of Puerto Rico (San Juan) is planning to borrow $5,000,000 in the bond market on June 2 to finance public improvements. The money will be raised by the sale of serial obligations dated July 1, 1958, and due on July 1 from 1959 to 1978.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today his union would support the International Longshoremen's Association in its drive to organize dockworkers in Chicago and other Great Lakes and St. Lawrence Seaway ports.
An indication that the key sector of business investment in plant and equipment may be stronger than expected this year has come from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.

Trading was dull yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges and prices moved in narrow ranges. The spot May positions, which had been active, have left the board in some markets and in others the holdings have been almost completely cleared.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended last Saturday totaled 694,380 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The cotton futures market moved 3 to 12 points (15 to 60 cents a bale) lower on a modest volume of business yesterday.
OTTAWA, May 21 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada interest rate this week remained at 5.3 per cent, ending a rising streak of nine straight weeks, the central bank reported today.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Defense Department and Atomic Energy Commission officials told Congress today that no firm decision had been made to build an atomic-powered airplane.

Richard K. Mellon's Chambourg won the $14,300 Belmont Spring Maiden Steeplechase to the satisfaction of the favorite players in the crowd of 18,591 at Belmont Park yesterday. The 7-year-old gelding had no trouble with his rivals over the course of about two miles and a furlong.

The Dalai Lama, through his chief secretary, has acknowledged an invitation from a Staten Island Tibetan shrine to make use of its facilities, should the exiled Tibetan ruler come to the United States.

Broadway producers who have been trying to engage Jason Robards Jr. for next season will have to wait or get someone else. The star has agreed to act in Lillian Hellman's untitled drama. This was confirmed yesterday by Peter Witt, Mr. Robards' representative.
The national chairmen of the major political parties urged business men yesterday to participate in politics, but as citizens and not as business men seeking special advantages.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Thirty-two educators who have published research on gifted youth were brought here today by the National Education Association.
Good figures for carloadings and a touch of glamour for the missile stocks checked a stock market decline yesterday, and trading ended with moderate gains.

AN argument (not a very good one) can be made that were it not for poets, playwrights and novelists young people in love would not know how they ought to feel. Today, of course, motion-picture and television script writers may be even more important guides to emotional precedents.

Besides being extravagant and a failure, the farm program is also confusing. Thus two events connected with House approval of the regular Agriculture Appropriations Bill have served to divert attention from the basic flaw of the program while creating the impression that something useful was being accomplished.

PARIS, May 20 -- President Charles de Gaulle is quietly pressing for the appointment of a French admiral to command all the North Atlantic treaty Organization naval forces at and around the mouth of the Mediterranean.
Mayor Wagner's baseball committee yesterday said that within five weeks it would offer a concrete plan for the formation of a third major league.
BUFFALO, May 21 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, the soft-spoken Bostonian, unveiled in New York State today his reasonable facsimile of a pre-convention Presidential campaign.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York made no announcement yesterday of a change in its lending rate to member banks. The rate was continued at 3 per cent, where it has been since March 6.

BOSTON, May 21 (UPI) -- Home runs by Dick Gernert, Jackie Jensen and Jim Busby accounted for all the scoring as the Boston Red Sox blanked the Kansas City Athletics, 5 -- 0, today. It was Boston's second triumph in nine games.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- Failure of any long-absent bullish influences to develop in the grain futures market caused a fast burst of general selling late today on the Board of Trade.
ARE there 500 male adults present who crave to help children fish and who will be hanging around Westchester County with nothing particular to do on Saturday, July 11 ?

The fur garment manufacturing industry expects to achieve a volume of $375,000,000 this year, with another $75,000,000 in fur trimmings, William Kolodney, executive director of the American Fur Merchants Association, Inc., told members at the annual meeting at the New Yorker Hotel last night.

DETROIT, May 21 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today plans to increase its ownership in the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., from 27.5 per cent to 75 per cent. The cost could be as high as $151,500,000.

A children's book about a fuzzy white rabbit marrying a fuzzy black rabbit has been withdrawn from the open shelves of the state agency that serves Alabama's public libraries because of segregationist protests.
PANAMA, May 21 -- Disagreement over leadership in economic planning and development erupted today at a meeting of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America.

The Fabrex Corporation, a textile converter, announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the textile inventories as of May 30 of the Triplex National Corporation, also a converter. The inventories to be acquired are estimated to be valued at $6,000,000.

A splendid recovery from an unpromising beginning enabled the United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer, to show his true form on the third day of the international jubilee tournament in Zurich, according to a report which reached here last night through Swiss news sources.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The announcement by the Executive Council of the A. F. L.-C. I. O. that it will oppose House approval of the Senate labor reform bill as amended on the Senate floor splits every interest concerned except the public interest.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The House Public Works Committee approved legislation today that would permit allocation of Federal highway aid to the states this year.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 21 -- Rumania's Communist Government feels it has a good chance of completing the socialization of the nation's agriculture by 1962, three years ahead of schedule.

Speaking at the Albert Lasker Medical Journalism Awards presentation meeting on April 30 Senator Richard L. Neuberger made an interesting observation. It was that within recent weeks a memorial to the late Senator Robert Taft had been dedicated on the Capitol grounds, Secretary Dulles had suffered a setback in his fight with cancer and Senator Hill's bill to create an institute of international medical research had gained new supporters in and out of the Congress.
ALBANY, May 21 (UPI) -- Lewis K. Sillcox of Watertown, N. Y., a retired business executive, today was named director of the Office of Transportation, a $18,486-a-year state job.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 21 -- A Knoxville pastor who believes integration will move slowly and that a Roman Catholic candidate for President would meet strong opposition in the South was elected today as president of the 9,000,000-member Southern Baptist Convention.
In his letter published in The Times on May 13 Phineas Toby starts from false premises in discussing the Algerian rebellion.
TORONTO, Ont., May 21 -- The Ford Motor Company of Canada announced today it was preparing for the production in its Canadian plants of two lines...
INDIANAPOLIS, May 21 -- The United Presbyterian Church formally proposed today that nine sister denominations in the United States and Canada join it in seeking organic unity.
A new service designed to facilitate depositing in savings banks by trust funds was announced yesterday.
Six struck voluntary hospitals and two threatened by a strike yesterday resumed legal efforts to end the two-week walkout of nonprofessional workers.

THE Albert Loeb Gallery, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, offers the first one-man exhibition in the United States of the work of Constantin Macris. The artist was born in Cairo in 1919, lived in Greece before coming to Paris in 1948, and settled last year in the Netherlands.
An effort by Carmine G. De-Sapio to introduce a measure of reform in New York County Democratic ranks won formal adoption yesterday.
BALTIMORE, May 21 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles sold an infielder-outfielder, Bobby Avila, to the Boston Red Sox today for what Oriole officials said was "approximately the waiver price," $20,000.
A state investigating committee said yesterday that the Board of Education had been the victim of unjustified charges of waste and was suffering extralegal interference from city agencies.

SINCE Ethel Merman is the head woman in "Gypsy," which opened at the Broadway last evening, nothing can go wrong. She would not permit "Gypsy" to be anything less than the most satisfying musical of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A White House conference to work out plans for assisting millions of refugees throughout the world began today. President Eisenhower, in a message read by one of his aides, urged further efforts "to create lasting international understanding of and concern for" the refugee problem.

The establishment of a board of lay trustees for Fordham University, the first in the institution's 118-year history, was announced yesterday by the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of the university.

SANDWICH, England, May 21 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus, a 19-year-old American Walker Cup player, today gained a four-stroke lead in the Royal St. George's Grand Challenge Cup tournament. The event serves as a tune-up for the British amateur golf championship which starts here Monday.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

YONKERS, May 21 -- Trader Horn, last season's glamour boy among the trotters, regained his winning ways tonight. Out of the money in his three previous 1959 outings, the 7-year-old brown horse won the $25,000 Orangeburg free-for-all event that topped the card at Yonkers Raceway.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Stockholders of Smith, Kline French Laboratories approved today a three-for-one split of the common stock.
GENEVA, May 21 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter worked hard on the Russians at the foreign ministers' conference today, but it is still a scoreless tie.

A crashing broadside fired yesterday by the leaders of the nation's two biggest seamen's unions wrecked any chances for a non-controversial Maritime Day today.
PARIS, May 21 (AP) -- America's last two players in the men's singles, Jack Douglas and Budge Patty, were upset today in the third round of the French tennis championship.

The City Council adopted without change yesterday the expense budget of $2,174,946,957 voted by the Board of Estimate on April 27 for the fiscal year starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) -- The House - Senate Atomic Energy Committee released a report today that indicated the ambitious plans of the six-nation Euratom organization for nuclear power in Europe might have become obsolete.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 21 -- The Rabbinical Assembly of America ended its fifty-ninth annual convention here today by voting to publish the first official high holiday prayer book for the Conservative movement.

ASHIYA AIR BASE, Japan, Friday, May 22 (AP) -- The United States Air Force identified a major from New Jersey yesterday as the pilot who was killed guiding his crippled transport plane out of its normal flight path to avoid crashing into Ashiyamachi, a crowded Japanese town near this base.
The Alabama Gas Corporation, Birmingham, plans to sell about $7,000,000 of new securities in 1959 to finance construction and to repay short-term loans.
CHICAGO, May 21 (UPI) -- Ruben Gomez scattered four hits today to help the Philadelphia Phillies snap an eight-game losing streak with a 3 -- 0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

The new sixteen-story office building at 405 Park Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-fourth Street, has been purchased by the Kratter Corporation. It was sold by William Kaufman and Jack D. Weiler in a $5,000,000 deal.
A six-man committee to "be ever watchful" against any effort to restrict the powers of the United States Supreme Court has been established by the New York County Lawyers Association.
A gift of $1,250,000 bequeathed to the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews was celebrated yesterday with a luncheon at which the donor, Miss Amy P. Frank, was the guest of honor.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted funds today to set up a special staff in the State Department to analyze Communist moves and ways to combat them.

Newsprint consumption in April jumped 10.2 per cent over the corresponding month last year, setting a new high for the month, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday. The percentage increase was the largest since July, 1955.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21 -- Major league baseball club owners agreed today to consider "favorably" an application for the establishment of a third major league within the present baseball structure.

The State Investigation Commission yesterday granted Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan a week's adjournment of his public hearing. At the same time it made public five charges against him.

PARIS, May 21 -- An anonymous document declaring that President Charles de Gaulle was surrounded by a clique of "traitors" who wished to abandon Algeria was published in part today by the weekly paper L'Express.
MANHASSET, L. I., May 21 -- Challenge round matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Long Island district interclub tournament were played today over the Plandome course.

Dockers refused to go to work at Pier 88, Hudson River, yesterday in protest of the French Line's assignment of its cargo ships to other sections of the port. The men, members of Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association, had been called in to handle the company's incoming freighter Foulaya.
MOSCOW, May 21 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev expressed new convictions tonight that joint efforts of the world powers would produce a relaxation of the arms race.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- The inhabitants of Rongelap Island have recovered completely from the physical ill-effects of radioactive fall-out but they are suffering emotional and psychological distress.
" A love for humanity, a concern for social justice and a passion for ideas" were cited as touchstones of the liberal spirit by Dr. Harold Taylor last night.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 21 (AP) -- American technical assistance personnel in Iraq are rapidly being displaced by Russians.

NEWARK, May 21 -- James Gallagher, state mediator, said today there was "no basis for calling a meeting at this time" in the week-long strike by employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

GENEVA, May 21 -- West Germany has directed the Swiss Government's attention to East German pamphlets said to slander the Federal Republic's Ambassador to Switzerland and West German delegates to the foreign ministers' conference.

A plastic bag was apparently used as a means of suicide, the police said yesterday, after the body of Theodore Evant, 60 years old, was found in his apartment at 35-36 Seventy-sixth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.
The most southerly ice penetration of North Atlantic waters in more than a decade has forced shipping to swing far to the south of normal traffic routes.

WHITEHOUSE, N. J., May 22 -- Ch. Finetop's Fancy Parade, 16-month-old black and tan dog, won best-in breed honors today at the twenty-second annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Club of New Jersey.
GENEVA, May 22 (AP)-- The two barbers given security clearance to cut the hair of foreign ministers began discreet speculation today on how long the foreign ministers could hold out.

NEWARK, May 22 -- Perry M. Shoemaker, president of the Delaware, Lackamanna and Western Railroad, today laid the carrier's "hazardous" financial condition to New Jersey's "adverse tax policy and its lack of transportation policy."

The first degree of the Rockefeller Institute was presented here yesterday morning to Dr. Giuseppe Gherardo Forni, rector of the University of Bologna, Italy, the oldest university in the Western world. Bologna was founded in 1000.

Events today: "Adventures in Piano Music With Paul Winchell and Jerry Mahoney" with Seymour Bernstein, pianist, Concert for Young People, Town Hall, 11 A. M.; Marven Hayes, bass-baritone, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30 P. M.; New York Estonian Male Chorus, Town Hall, 8; Jazz Concert, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
ALGIERS, May 22 -- The French Army has warned seventeen extremists of European descent to behave or risk being expelled from Algeria or drafted into the army.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Half interest in Independent Grocers Alliance, large voluntary food store chain with headquarters in Chicago, has been sold to a Canadian company, Don R. Grimes, president of I. G. A., disclosed today. The purchase price was not announced.
MUNICH, Germany, May 22 (AP) -- Informed sources said today that the Soviet Union had decided to support Detroit as the site for the 1964 Olympic Games.
MINEOLA, L. I., May 22 -- Two boys accused of being members of a seafaring band that plundered private boats off Westchester and Long Island were arraigned on grand larceny charges here today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) The Government's space agency has tentative plans for forty-seven space shots -- including eleven toward the moon and planets -- within the next two and a half years.

Lutheran World Relief, Inc., a program for the distribution of food, clothing and other necessaries since 1946, yesterday observed passing its $100,000,000 mark in shipments overseas. About half of this amount represented commodities or services paid for by the Government.

YONKERS, May 22 -- Bye Bye Byrd paced a 2:00 mile before 31,749 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The commendable clocking enabled the 4-year-old horse, owned by Mr. and Mrs. R. C. Larkin of Chicago, to win the $25,000 free-for-all feature by three-quarters of a length from Widower Creed.
Alta Rae, a coloratura soprano, made her debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A conference committee dominated by moderate-to-liberal Democrats was created today to settle differences between Senate and House versions of the omnibus housing bill.

TEL AVIV. Israel, May 22 -- Finance Minister Levi Eshkol today told business men from fifteen countries that Israel would liberalize financial and monetary restrictions and would offer better security to foreign investors.

Sharp oral exchanges punctuated the hearing on Ray Robinson's middleweight championship yesterday but nothing was settled. After four hours of testimony, the State Athletic Commission adjourned the hearing until 10 A. M. Wednesday.
A promise to postpone further preparatory work on widening Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets was made yesterday by Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan.
Volume fell but prices rose in an uneven session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. No single major group made a united advance but drugs provided the nearest approximation of one.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The case of the itinerant Red shrimps has been solved.

The pattern of life in New York City shifts with the years, but one vital principle of it remains largely unchanged -- the increasing need of children for aid and understanding. One agency most active and respected in this field is the Children's Aid Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, New York 10. Appropriately, the society has titled its 106th annual report, just issued, "Growing to Meet Their Needs."
VACATION - fishing prospects up and down the East Coast for June are passing fair, if there is virtue in the estimates of official observers.

The Saturday before Memorial Day has come to have a special significance for some 37,000,000 Americans who have discovered the pleasures of boating. The day is called "Going-Into-Commission" Day in yacht clubs along our seacoasts and also on inland lakes and rivers

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Average wholesale prices at the primary market level declined 0.2 per cent to 119.5 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
BUENOS AIRES, May 22 -- Vice Admiral Isaac Rojas, naval hero of the 1955 revolution against the rule of Juan D. Peron. voiced criticism tonight of President Arturo Frondizi's political ethics.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 21 -- The public can now decide for itself whether Macy's or Tass is right. For a likeness of the model house the store is furnishing for the American National Exhibition in Moscow this summer opens tomorrow at Roosevelt Field, near Garden City, L. I.
The United Steelworkers of America told its 1,000,000 members yesterday that all major segments of industry were "ganging up" to help the steel companies defeat the union's drive for higher wages.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 22 -- Israeli techniques can be useful to Belgium in the Congo while Israel herself can find commercial opportunities in the African region, according to an analysis made by Belgian businessmen.

The refusal of longshoremen to work at Pier 88, Hudson River, has been labeled a wildcat walkout by officials of both Local 824 and its parent organization, the International Longshoremen's Association.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- Jazz, one of the United States' most popular exports, has gained a firm foothold on international territory.
KANSAS CITY, May 22 (UPI) -- Roger Maris, who is leading the Kansas City Athletics in hitting, homers and runs batted in, underwent an emergency appendectomy early today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The Office of Education approved twelve more foreign language institutes today under its national defense education program.

The New York State Athletic Commission unanimously disapproved yesterday the application of Harry Davidow to become the manager of Ingemar Johansson, the Swedish challenger who will fight Floyd Patterson for the world heavyweight title here on June 25.

Hide prices moved sharply higher yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. A report of strife in Argentina sparked the buying rally. Final prices were 95 to 135 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on 130 lots.
Six adjourned games, completing three rounds of the jubilee international chess masters tournament in Zurich, were finished yesterday, according to a report received from Switzerland.
Near-record heat and high humidity, punctuated by crackling thunder showers, caused considerable discomfort in the metropolitan area yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Federal Communications Commission heard arguments today on whether something ought to be done to prevent radio broadcasts by WNYC from "jamming" news of interest to Midwest farmers.

PARIS, May 22 -- Khrushchev is partly right when he says few capitals are genuinely interested in pressing for German unity. His diplomats argue that the Germans lived happily disunited until Bismarck brought them together in 1871.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 22 -- President Eisenhower warned today that "we could soon become powerless abroad" through neglect of the domestic economy and of the soundness of the currency.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- Corn and new-crop rye futures met some rallying strength shortly before the close of the Board of Trade today. Other grains and soybeans finished weak in the second selling flurry of the day.

Harry Schweltzer, the 75-year-old former relief recipient who parlayed $9,000 in relief payments into $21,000 in the stock market, received a suspended sentence yesterday in General Sessions Court. He had been permitted to plead guilty to a petit larceny charge.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Government asked the Supreme Court today to resolve the long-standing dispute between Illinois and other states bordering the Great Lakes about the use of lake water.

Thousands of children from more than two hundred parishes and missions in the Protestant Episcopal Diocese in New York will participate this afternoon in the children's Advent Service in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.
The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it had selected Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., to handle the advertising for its forthcoming line of small cars called the Valiant.
A group of leading economists agreed yesterday that prices would continue to rise over the next five years. But they disagreed on the causes and the probable extent of the inflation.

The Cooper-Bessemer Corporation, manufacturer of engines and compressors, has announced the election of Charles G. Cooper as vice president and international director and of J. E. Brown as vice president and treasurer.
GENEVA, May 22 -- Following are salient facts on the I foreign ministers' eon[erence at United Nation8 headquarters in Geneva:
The United States shipping industry and Federal merchant marine officials went all out yesterday in celebration of the nation's twenty-sixth Maritime Day.
BERLIN, May 22 -- The West Berlin police have arrested two more members of a Communist spy ring, bringing the total of arrests in the city to eight, a police spokesman said today.
There will be a sizable increase in new offerings of securities in the capital market next week.

The report of the A. O. Smith Corporation issued yesterday for the nine months ended April 30, shows a net income of $8,480.945 on net shipments of $202,804,501. A year earlier $5,819,082 was cleared on net shipments of $198,662,435.
Justice Charles J. Beckinella reserved decision yesterday on contempt charges against the president, a business agent and eight members of the striking hospital union here.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Maritime Administrator Clarence G. Morse says two superliners will never be built unless the Administration eases its purse strings.
Robert Moses rejected an offer yesterday by Justice Samuel M. Gold to mediate the dispute over free Shakespeare in Central Park.
A COMPOSER and one of his pupils shared the billing last night at Carl Fischer Concert Hall.

RED BANK, N. J., May 22 -- A 3 1/2-year-old dog, Ch. Brogan of Hillaway, was the main winner today in the specialty show of the Irish Wolfhound Club of America. He became best of breed in an entry of sixty-three, of which fifty-four were present, before an English judge, Mrs. Florence Nagle, at the Amory L. Haskell estate.

PANAMA, May 22 -- Several hundred high school students staged an orderly demonstration here today commemorating the first anniversary of bloody street fighting a year ago between students and the national police. At least nine students were killed in the 1958 riots.

I have read with a great deal of interest that the architects for the building that is to house the Philharmonic at the Lincoln Square development have provided for a seating capacity of 360 less than at Carnegie Hall. The reason given is that because of the problems of acoustics a greater seating capacity could not be effectuated.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 22 (AP) -- Big Ten athletic leaders failed to break a 5-5 deadlock, today on renewal of the Rose Bowl football contract. But in a surprise move they authorized Future Rose Bowl play by conference members on an individual basis.

MOVING a block away from their old quarters, the Grand Central Art Galleries are now established in the Biltmore Hotel. Signs of occupancy appear in the hotel lobby, where the amiable landscapes that are the specialty of this gallery are visible everywhere and are all but suspended from the famous clock.
The ten-day Eastern States Contract Bridge championships started yesterday at the Statler-Hilton Hotel with a record field entered in the opening events.
The emergency service division of the Police Department came to the aid of thousands of citizens when members of the division answered 24,179 calls for help in 1958.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., May 22 -- A building permit was refused by the Town of Yorktown today to the Wiltwyck School, a philanthropic boarding institution for 100 emotionally disturbed New York City boys 8 to 12 years old.

LONDON, May 22 (AP) -- World consumption of wool in the March quarter was estimated at 714 million pounds, up 1 per cent from the previous three months, the Commonwealth Economic Committee reported today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower reported to Congress today that $9,000,000 of his emergency funds were used last year to meet disasters in eight states.
Sylvester Cosentino, lawyer for Norbert Belbo, one of the five teen-agers being tried in General Sessions Court for the murder of Julio Ramos, assailed the prosecution's two key witnesses yesterday.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, May 22 -- Leslie C. Hoffman, editor in chief of the Straits Times group of newspapers in Singapore, will fly to Berlin tomorrow to attend the general assembly of the International Press Institute.

The blacksmith strike against the New York Racing Association ended, at least temporarily, yesterday. Larry Gottesheim, president of Local 8 of the Brotherhood of Journeymen Horseshoers, and a co-worker returned to the job for a thirty-day trial period, pending the consideration of his group's demand. They were the only two in the walkout.
BONN, Germany, May 22 -- West German politicians are privately considering what might be the psychological impact on the country if Bonn were to recognize the Oder-Neisse border with Poland.

PARAMUS, N. J., May 22 -- Henry J. Sayres of Mechanicsville, Pa., had the best-of-breed winner in the American Fox Terrier Club's 117th specialty show today in Baros' Briartex Twinkle. The importation, a wire-haired dog was in her first American competition.
BALTIMORE, May 22 -- Edgar Allen Poe's "Descent into the Maelstrom" became little more than a pleasant drop in a scenic railway ride compared with what the Yankees suffered tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate voted today to limit price support payments to any one farmer to $35,000 a year.

Details of a special but unsuccessful effort by former President Harry S. Truman in 1948 to obtain the cooperation of the religious forces of the world to resist communism and preserve peace became known yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 -- A proposal for church unity issued here by the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church ran into procedural difficulties today.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Floyd B. Odlum, chairman of the Atlas Corporation, testified to the bright future for United States uranium producers at a Securities and Ex change Commission hearing today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A White House conference on refugees ended today with an appeal for more vigorous action by the Administration and Congress to aid refugees around the world.
MIAMI, May 22 (AP) -- A transport plane loaded with arms was seized at Miami International Airport today. The nine persons aboard were arrested.

It is encouraging to see Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba facing up to the Communists as he did in his television interview on Thursday night. For the first time he openly linked the Cuban Reds to acts he labeled as counter-revolutionary. He denounced extremist labor agitators who demand wage increases that would raise the cost of essential goods.

PANAMA, May 22 -- Raul Prebisch of Argentina is engaged in a crusade to unite Latin America in a common market. This, he thinks, will propel into the modern age a region that in some ways and places has not changed much since his Spanish ancestors invaded the New World.
TOBAY BEACH, L. I., May 22 -- Bulldozers, cranes and trucks churned the sand here today as the Town of Oyster Bay prepared to welcome summer visitors to an expanding Tobay Beach.
Mrs. Jean Iavarone yesterday interrupted her five-day kidnapping trial in Kings County Court to plead guilty to attempted kidnapping.
GENEVA, May 22 -- The Western powers gave up temporarily today their attempt to persuade the Soviet Union to agree to a scientific conference on detecting nuclear explosions.
ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -- The striking Globe-Democrat unit of the American Newspaper Guild voted unanimously tonight to accept a proposed agreement.
The Wabash Railroad announced yesterday that directors, at a board meeting on a car ferry en route from Frankfort, Mich., to Manitowoc, Wis., on Thursday, had elected Arthur K. Atkinson chairman.

THE dime store has long been a mecca for budgeters on a shopping spree. Today this store has not only practical staples such as can openers, mops and pot holders, but also luxury items such as air-conditioning units, barbecue kits and imported crystals.
PANAMA, May 22 -- The National Symphony Orchestra of Washington scored both an artistic and a popular success last night before a capacity audience in the Rio Theatre here.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Senator George D. Aiken accused the Eisenhower Administration today of trying to put farmers "under the thumbs of giant corporate interests."

BONN, Germany, May 22 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union has told West Germany's Ambassador in Moscow that if no East-West agreement was reached in negotiations he would sign a separate peace treaty with East Germany.

In these days, when it's hard to find a good buying stock, the Ford Motor Company may have found an answer in its own garage. It announced late Thursday it would buy some $150,000,000 of the shares of a close relative, Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd.
PARIS, May 22 (AP) -- Janet Hopps of Seattle and Mimi Arnold of Redwood City, Calif., won, but Jeanne Arth of St. Paul was defeated in the third round of the French tennis championships today.

A building containing fifty-eight apartments at 1454 Grand Concourse, corner of 171st Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by the 1454 Concourse Realty Corporation. The plot is 125 by 100 feet. The Institutional Management Company, broker in the deal, will manage the property.

Gus Tyler, the director of the Political Department of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, is quoted in your account of the I. L. G. W. U. convention as complaining that the results of Democratic control of Congress since 1954 are disappointing compared with the pledges of the Democrats in their 1952 and 1956 platforms.
The New York Blue Cross applications for rate increases were attacked yesterday by spokesmen for labor unions, pension funds and civic organizations.

" The Big Fisherman," a color version of Lloyd C. Douglas' novel, with Howard Keel, Susan Kohner, John Saxon, Martha Hyer and Herbert Lom, will have its world premiere at the Rivoli Theatre at a date to be announced later.
WOULD you let me know how to prevent strawberries from developing mold while refrigerated? Mrs. I. Oder, Brooklyn.
The official in charge of the Board of Education's bureau of construction has submitted his resignation. He is William H. Correale, Superintendent of School Building Design and Construction.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) -- The Railway Labor Executives Association accused the nation's railroads today of "total indifference" to safety in the industry.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) -- A race car that has earned a quarter-million dollars in the last two years -- Jimmy Bryan's Belond Special -- may miss the 500-mile race on Memorial Day. The engine "froze" today while the Phoenix, (Ariz.,) driver was on a practice run. The car won the 1957 and 1958 races.

IF Jules Feiffer,.author of "Passionella and Other Stories,"* does not get sidetracked into drawing pictures for ginand-tonic advertisements or similar nonsense, the chances are good that he will become one of the important American artist-humorists. His second book -his first was called "Sick, Sick, Sick" -shows that he is using a thinking man's pen.

The National Company, Inc., maker of radio receivers, transmitting apparatus and component parts, plans a two-for-one split of its common stock. To provide the required shares a special meeting of stockholders will vote July 10 on a proposal to increase the authorized common stock to 1,600,000 from 650,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Brig. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Jr. of the Air Force to be a major general. He would be the first Negro ever to hold such rank in any branch of the United States armed forces.

The recent capitulation of our Mayor to Park Commissioner Robert Moses' whims regarding free Shakespeare in Central Park has led us, as independent Democrats, along with many others, to wonder who really runs this town. This seems to us another example of the "weak Mayor, strong boss" system of government in New York City.
A five-month coast-to-coast tour will precede the New York opening on Feb. 11 of "A Mighty Man Is He," the new comedy by Arthur Kober and George Oppenheimer.

BROOKSIDE, N. J., May 22 -- A biologist has been ordered to stop medical experiments in the barn on his nineteen-acre estate here within twenty days or face a fine of $50 and additional fines for every day beyond the limit.
The cotton futures market moved 5 to 20 points (25 cents to $1 a bale) higher on all months from July through May, but new July closed 22 points lower and new October 45 points lower.

ROME, May 22 -- King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece had a state audience with Pope John XXIII today. The Vatican attached great importance to the visit by the world's only Orthodox Christian sovereigns and surrounded the event with elaborate solemnity.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 22 -- The man who succeeded Brooks Hays tonight as president of the Southern Baptist Convention is a pastor, an evangelist, a prohibitionist, but not -- and he stresses this -- a politician.
Boxing returned to Madison Square Garden last night after a lapse of almost two months, but the feature bout between Alex Miteff and Wayne Bethea was a poor example of fighting.

Corporate wounds heal slowly. There was evidence yesterday that top management of the Pennsylvania Railroad still felt the blow it received last winter when the New York Central Railroad backed away from merger negotiations between the two roads.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 22 (UPI) -- An attorney for thirty-nine Little Rock school teachers filed a libel suit today that seeks damages totaling $3,900,000.

Frederick Metzger has sold the four-story building on lot 20 by 80 feet at 1463 Third Avenue, near Eighty-third Street. The buyer was a client of Burack Burack, lawyers. Julian E. Gordon Co. and M. Balaban were the brokers in the sale, the first involving the property since 1881.

TOKYO, May 22 -- Delegates from four whaling nations have failed to reach agreement at a conference here on quotas to be allotted for the 1959-60 Antarctic season. Represented at the meeting, which began Monday, were Norway, Britain, the Netherlands and Japan.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) -- The A. F. L.-C. I. O. and three other organizations endorsed today Senator J. W. Fulbright's proposal for a major expansion of the foreign aid program's Development Loan Fund.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 22 -- A resolution commending Brooks Hays and urging greater cooperation between white and Negro churchmen set off an hour-long dispute over integration at the closing session of the Southern Baptist convention today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office said today that McDonnell Aircraft Corporation had overpriced an Air Force contract $5,193,000 because it had not passed along reductions in its costs.
ENCOUNTERS between artists and critics are normally rare, but yesterday forty art critics from more than fifteen countries gathered to meet four American artists for a group discussion.
LONDON, May 22 (Reuters) -- Britain's exports rose more than 9 per cent in April to 295,600,000 ($826,000,000), the second highest total on record, the Board of Trade said today.

A critique of the work of the i ten literary figures who have influenced Israeli culture and ]thouht is presented in "The ]Flowering of Modern Hebrew Literature." It ,will be published June 9 by Twayne. The essays :were written by the late IV[ena{chem Ribalow, Hebrew sch. olar and critic and former editor of Hadoar, a weekly Hebrew magazine in this country.
MANILA, May 21 -- The Philippine Congress adjourned last midnight in revolt against the heavy tax program demanded by President Carlos P. Garcia.

The bond market closed the week on an optimistic note. Even the slowdown brought by Friday afternoon lethargies, customary in the field, failed to check the bounce evident in the market for United States Government securities.

TOKYO, May 22 -- Burma has formally proposed a revision of the terms of the World War II reparations agreement she signed with Japan in 1954, the Japanese Government and the Burmese Embassy confirmed today.
HAVANA, May 22 -- Extremists have no place in the Cuban revolution, Premier Fidel Castro said in a television interview early this morning.
MOSCOW, May 22 -- It is fortunate that Tolstoy is not writing today, in the opinion of Konstantin Paustovsky, a Soviet writer.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address at St. John's College today, including extemporaneous introductory remarks:
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A manufacturer of polarized glass believes a headlight system patented this week may mean the eventual end of night glare on the highways.

GENEVA, May 22 -- Almost everyone in attendance at the foreign ministers' conference is awaiting a major crisis between East and West. In the meantime, the Soviet Union has created a number of minor crises and a new one is on the way.

Joseph Sager Sons, build- have asembled the block- tint on the east side of Third Avenue from Sixty-sixth to sixty-seventh Street for improvement with a twenty-story apartment building for 255 families. The apartments will concern one and one-half to seven rooms.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 22 -- Iraq is engaged in a lively public debate over the future role of the Communist Party.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Air Force has formally presented to the Joint Chiefs of Staff its proposal for a new all-service strategic command. The unit would control all big nuclear retaliatory weapons, including the Navy's forthcoming missile-hurling submarines.

The death of Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the State Assembly, raised a knotty legal question yesterday for which there were no known precedents. The question was this: Can the office be filled on a permanent basis while the Legislature is not in session?
Governor Rockefeller returned yesterday from a vacation in Venezuela to find his supporters making preparations to enter his name in the New Hampshire Presidential preference primary next March 8.

Two kinds of competition are building up for American business in world markets, according to analyses offered yesterday in the concluding half of the two-day annual meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board.
OWEGO, N. Y., May 22 (AP) -- Police Chief Howard Branning and his family are missing and Mayor John Day said he had no explanation.

The Christiana Stable's Endine and Eldon Nelson resumed partnership at Belmont Park yesterday, and the jockey guide the 5-year-old mare to a triumph in a mile-and-a-eenth test. She had a fourteenth margin over the Stone- Farm's Pioneeress.
The delegates to the 1957 Apalachin crime convention have thus far blocked a Federal grand jury's investigation of narcotics trafficking by the Mafia, it was learned yesterday.

POPLARVILLE, Miss., May 22 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation denied today it was abandoning its investigation of Mack Charles Parker's lynch kidnapping, as reported in today's edition of The Memphis Commercial Appeal.
A forty-piece service of porcelain tableware brought $60,000 yesterday from a determined bidder at auction.

All five keels of the first segment of the fifty-three-ship program of the Lykes Brothers Steamship Company have now been laid down at the Pascagoula, Miss., yard of the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation.

DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- Manufacturers continued to build automobiles at a near record 1959 rate this week and Ward's Automotive Reports today forecast a stockpile of one million new cars soon if production schedules are not cut back.
James T. Aubrey Jr. has been named to the newly created post of executive vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

MORE than one triumphant tourist back from the Orient with a suitcase full of treasures has been jolted by the number of Far Eastern shops in New York that sell the identical articles. What the tourist goes 30,000 miles or more to buy can often be found in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A rise of 0.2 per cent in April prices sent the United States Consumer Price Index back to its highs of last year, the Department of Labor reported today.
WASHINGTON May 22 (UPI) -- A church spokesman said today there were signs at the Communists might be attributing obscene literature deliberate effort "to moral-sabotage American youth.
KAMPALA, Uganda, May 22 (AP) -- Gov. Sir Frederick Crawford ruled today that the Uganda National Movement was an unlawful society. He declared the Kingdom of Buganda a disturbed area.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 22 -- The General Motors Corporation officially confirmed today that it had a new, lighter, smaller and cheaper American car on the way.

LOS ANGELES, May 22 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers shot San Francisco out of second place in the National League tonight, beating the Giants, 2 -- 1, on Don Drysdale's six-hitter and Gil Hodges' single with two on in the thirteenth inning.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 22 (Reuters) -- Thunderous applause greeted the West German premiere tonight of Bertolt Brecht's anti-Nazi play "Schweik in the Second World War."

" THE biggest problem in decorating my bedroom is choosing the furniture and agreeing with Mother." This was the opinion of 12-year-old Linda Baxter, a member of Stern's 'Tween-Timer's Club, and an active participant in the club's home furnishings' clinic.
HIGHVIEW, N. Y., May 22 -- The Association of New York Young Republicans met today prepared to press the Rockefeller boom by electing Joseph F. X. Nowicki, a Rockland County lawyer, as its president.
John M. Seabrook, president of the Seabrook Farms Company, said yesterday that he would resign from the company if stock control were acquired by Seeman Brothers, Inc., food distributors.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission today took what it called a first step toward development and publication of detailed safety rules for nuclear power sites.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The State Department agreed today to validate W. Averell Harriman's passport for a visit to Communist China.
ERNIE KOVACS brought a welcome touch of whimsey to hot-weather television last night.
A small army of Congressmen and officials of the House of Representatives with their wives and children arrived yesterday for a three-day whirl in New York.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Mr. Heck was eulogized the Senate today by Senators Jacob K. Javits and Kenneth B. Keating, both New York Republicans.
GENEVA, May 22 -- The United States is ready to resume at any time general negotiations on disarmament with the Soviet Union, Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- when he was an active, and employed, politician, W. Averell Harriman used to criticize the State Department's policy of discouraging travel by Americans to Communist China. In the case of reporters, the former New York Governor said more than once, the policy was depriving the American people of full information on events in an important area of the world. He called the Government's attitude capricious and unsound.

LONDON, May 23 -- The collision yesterday of an Icelandic coastal patrol boat with a British destroyer has brought the "cod war" between the two governments to a new pitch of hostility and potential danger.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 23 (AP) -- Mont Pleasant of Schenectady and Bishop Loughlin of New York tied for first today in the annual Schenectady interscholastic track meet.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23 (UPI) -- Harvard's world-beating crew of 1914 made a sentimental journey down the charles River today, the forty-fifth anniversary of their triumph at England's Henley Regatta.
