SALT LAKE CITY -- By Western standards, the past winter was a light one, with snow a scanty twelve feet deep on many major anges and passes. As a result, oad-builders and highway repair crews have been able to set off to an early start on construction and repair chores in highways the vacationists will be traveling this summer.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 23 -Borrowed equipment proved no deterrent to a spirited Wisconsin varsity crew on the Severn this afternoon. The Badgers, who left their shell and oars back home in Madison, rowed away to a two-length victory over Navy in a mile-and-three-quarters race.

THE long-heralded promise of a continuous ribbon of toll road between Boston and Chicago will become a reality on Tuesday with completion of the final six-mile segment of the $54,000,000 Berkshire section of the New York State Thruway.

The thirty-first annual Eastern States Championships continued yesterday at the Statler-Hilton Hotel with 216 contract bridge players playing the first of two sessions in the blue ribbon Master Pairs Championship.

A man who, in his youth, worked with his father as a blacksmith, has risen to a place of prime importance among Japan's artists. He is Shiko Munakata, and his woodcuts have brought him honor not only among his own people but, in recent years, among those of many countries.

BALTIMORE, May 23 -- "Well," remarked Casey Stengel as he came tramping into his dressing quarters late this afternoon, "who's laughing now?" and, as usual, the Yankee skipper was supplying his own answer, wearing, his broadest grin.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 23 -An unheralded sophomore sprinter led defending champion Illinois to an easy triumph in the fifty-ninth Big Ten outdoor track meet, which produced two records on soggy Ferry Field today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 23 -- The public attitude toward broadening the real estate tax here to increase spending for education will be tested Tuesday. This city of 72,195 will vote on Board of Education proposal to crease the tax limitation from 1/2 to 1 3/4 per cent of the average valuation in the preceding five years.

NORWICH, Conn. -- Fortunately for the Norwich Tercentenary Committee a law in effect here in 1776 which prohibited traveling on Sunday has since been repealed or, at least, is no longer enforced.
PARIS, May 23 (AP) -- Three Australians and Luis Ayala of Chile moved to the quarter-final round of the men's singles in the French national tennis tournament today.

ONE of the oldest baseball superstitions is the unwritten rule that no one is ever to mention that a no-hitter is being manufactured. Only a scoundrel would commit so dastardly a deed because such mention instantly brings the whammy out of hiding. The whammy is a spook with the horns of a jinx that would thereupon direct the flight of the next batted ball and destroy the no-hitter.

American colleges have dissociated themselves from intellect in attempts to provide "whole-man and community" education, in the opinion of Dr. Jacques Barzun, dean of faculties and provost of Columbia University.

The 50 per cent limit on construction differential subsidies paid by the Government to shipowners who build their vessels in the United States may soon prove-inadequate, according to Alexander Purdon, executive director of the Committee of American Steamship Lines.
One of the regular free performances in a city park is put on every fine Sunday afternoon by ballad singers in Washington Square.

Operating revenues of the New York Central Railroad rose by 17.1 per cent last month to $60,148,815, and the company reported a net income of $3,028,215, equal to 46 cents a share. In April, 1958, when the gross was $51,383,994, the company had a net loss of $3,063,598.

The Federal Maritime Board will be urged today not to establish any rules that would deprive ocean freight forwarders of ocean brokerage fees. Such rules, the agencies feel, would lead to a diversion of cargo from the New York-New Jersey areas.

A booted-and-spurred band of young Texas thespians will sail this afternoon for Plymouth, England, aboard the Plymouth Line ship Flandre to demonstrate to British audiences how Shakespeare might have handled "A Midsummer Night's Dream" in Texas in the Eighteen Eighties.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 24 -- Explorations by historians under the lawns, gardens, walks and old buildings of the Philipsburg Manor restoration here have become so extensive and so hazardous to visitors that the grounds will be closed to the public next Sunday night.

The Fifth Avenue Association has renewed a demand that city officials forbid Loyalty Day parades on the avenue on business days.

MECHANICVILLE, N. Y., May 24 (AP) -- A bitter fourmonth strike at the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company plant here has been settled.

A small army of visitors from the House of Representatives -members, officers, employes, families and friends -- spent the final day of a three-day sightseeing fling here yesterday visiting an ocean liner and the American Museum -- Hayden Planetarium.

Americans of all shades of political opinion joined yesterday in expressions of regret at the death of John Foster Dulles and respect for his sincere efforts to serve the country.

The National Advisory Committee on Farm Labor yesterday urged immediate action to improve the substandard conditions of farm workers and especially of migratory workers.
Joseph F. Carlino, Republican majority leader in the Assembly, announced yesterday that he would be a candidate for Speaker to succeed Oswald D. Heck of Schenectady, who died last Thursday.

The New York City Ballet last night gave an all-Stravinsky program at the City Center. This included the season's first presentations of "Apollo," choreographed by George Balanchine, and "The Cage," choreographed by Jerome Robbins.

Human progress is always difficult of achievement and must be guarded jealously. The history of our own times marks men's struggle for economic liberty -- for the right to join together in labor organizations to secure a living wage and decent working conditions.

A $100,200,000 school construction program for 1960 was proposed yesterday by the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- United States business men sought Government permission to ship nearly $22,000,000 worth of goods to Iron Curtain countries during January-March of this year. They were turned down on all but $6,626,000 worth.
PARIS, May 24 -- French officials expressed sympathy today over the death of Mr. Dulles.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -United States hopes for the future of the Euratom nuclear power program in Western Europe are rising once again after a period of pessimism on both sides of the Atlantic.

TELEVISION paid impressive tribute to the late John Foster Dulles last night with two thirty-minute network memorial programs. They were shown by the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company.

An additional appropriation by Congress has enabled the Maritime Commission to order the installation of Sperry Gyrofin stabilizers on the nuclear ship Savannah, Rear Admiral Walter C. Ford, Acting Maritime Administrator, announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -Several grain futures contracts that only a few weeks ago were near high prices for the season finished this week closer to their season lows.

The twelve steel companies negotiating with the United Steelworkers of America asserted today that the union president, David J. McDonald, had been using "distortions of fact" in his weekly advertisements appealing for public support.

RYE, N. Y., May 24 -- It was wet, it was cold and it was a thorough test of sailing for the skippers racing today in the opening program of the American Yacht Club's Memorial Day week-end regatta on Long Island Sound. Races will also be staged next Saturday and Sunday.

Dr. Leo Jung, spiritual leader of the Jewish Center of New York City and president of the Jewish Academy of Arts and Sciences, warned last night that, despite Soviet statements to the contrary, there "appears to be a tragic determination to destroy the Judaism of our brethren behind the Iron Curtain."
MOSCOW, May 24 -- Substantial expansion in mutual trade is expected from a five-year agreement between the Soviet Union and Britain signed here tonight.
James T. O'Connell, Under Secretary of Labor, yesterday advised young people concerned about the competition for jobs to build up their skills and educational background.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 -- Tara, the hollow mansion the movie world built for "Gone With the Wind," is being dismembered here to be reassembled in Atlanta, Ga.

The contract bridge pair of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Levitt of Wilmington, Del., early this morning won the Mixed Pairs Championship of the thirty-first annual Eastern States Championships at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

PARIS, May 24 -- The death of John Foster Dulles and the mortal illness of George Catlett Marshall brings to America not only deep national sadness but the end of a historical era. For together the names of these two Secretaries of State are attached to a basic policy which seems already to be approaching gradual revision.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, retiring Army Chief of Staff, entered the debate on air defense over the week-end by saying it was the Army's mission. He added that the Army was doing it well.
MONTREAL, May 24 -- Six hundred students from New York City ended a two-day visit to Canada early this evening. The tour was sponsored by the Bureau of Community Education.

NO matter how vigilantly the amateur decorator scouts model rooms, there are two kinds of decorating she rarely sees. One is the delicate "old school" decor that has been in vogue for decades with America's wealthy.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 23 -The general expansion of local industry and the more healthy atmosphere for outside capital was reflected here last week in reports that Taiwan textiles had entered international markets.

Patrons have been announced for the June 15 dinner dance that will be held aboard the cruising French liner Liberte. The fete will benefit the New York City Cancer Committee of the American Cancer Society.

PITTSBURGH, May 24--There was a slight surge in new steel orders in the Midwest last week. This pick-up came from steel users who feared a strike and were making sure they were on the books for third quarter steel shipments. If the steel is not shipped early in the third quarter, these steel customers believe--and hope--it will come to them when the strike is over, if there is a strike.

Representatives of some 60,000 seamen, fishermen and workers in allied industries will assemble in Montreal today for the opening of the ninth biennial convention of the Seafarers International Union of North America.

GENEVA, May 24 -- It happens once in a while that the three men who have been writing the first nuclear treaty in Conference Room 8 at the United Nations' Geneva headquarters lean back and think both about their places in the footnotes of history and about each other.

Parents of past and present pupils, and alumni of the Ecole Francaise du Saint-Esprit bade farewell yesterday to Mlle. Mayvonne Le Guillerm, founder and headmistress of the French school at 109 East Sixtieth Street.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh has called for the ouster of Federal Narcotics Commissioner Harry J. Anslinger to make way for sweeping reforms in the treatment of narcotics addicts.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- John Foster Dulles will have an official funeral. This was ordered today by President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., of New York of mailing deceptive advertising material for its antibiotic Sigmamycin. The company denied the Commission's complaint.

Charles H. Wasserman, staff director at Television Graphics, has been elected president of the Screen Directors International Guild, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Howard T. Magwood, who held the office for two consecutive terms.
Haskins Sells, certified public accountants, are moving today into new New York headquarters in the building constructed by Uris Brothers at 2 Broadway, facing Bowling Green.

The late Kurt Weill, whose music is being revived in this country and in Europe, is the subject of a biography by David Drew, an English critic, written with the cooperation of Lotte Lenya, the composer's widow.

AMONG the most welcome arrivals on vegetable counters now are the long, greenstriped squashes known variously as zucchini, Italian squash and cocozelle. They have a juiciness and crispness that are particularly pleasing to the palate at this season.

EAST QUOGUE, L. I., May 24 -- G. Frank Carter celebrated his ninety-second birthday quietly here today at his home on Carter Lane.

Mayor Wagner was urged yesterday to create an interdepartmental cabinet and a planning commission to coordinate the agencies dealing with the city's children.

Hawaii is planning a sale of $15,000,000 of public improvement bonds on June 25. Dated June 15, 1959, the bonds will come due serially on June 15 from 1962 to 1979.

LARCHMONT, N Y., May 24 -- Raymond P. Scott, an automobile dealer from Wynnewood, Pa., who commutes to race on Long Island Sound on weekends, accepted the Edlu Trophy today after his Loki yawl, Seachief II, emerged the correctedtime winner of the Larchmont Yacht Club's fifth distance race to Six Mile Reef.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25 -- The death of John Foster Dulles was mourned today by United Nations delegates.

The American fashion trend for the fall and winter is now being shaped, as Seventh Avenue designers unveil their collections to the press and to store buyers. The showings presently underway are the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July.

BERLIN, May 25 (Reuters) -- A spokesman for the International Press Institute disclosed today that 800 journalists have been arrested in Turkey during the last four of five years.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 25 -- Three New York medical centers, Columbia Presbyterian, New York Hospital-Cornell and New York University-Bellevue Hospital, will receive additional funds for research in cystic fibrosis from proceeds of a house tour in this area. The International Business Machines Corporation has created seven new divisions in a sweeping reorganization of its basic set-up. This was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson Jr., president.

H. Lloyd Jones of Bronxville, Grand Master of Masons in New York State, announced major staff appointments to state Masonic offices yesterday.

Walter J. Mercer, president of the Hudson Shipping Company, Inc., New York, has been elected president of the Customs Brokers and Forwarders Association of America, Inc.

The attention of the bond market is centered this morning on the sale of $75,000,000 of mortgage bonds of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York. Bids for the issue will be received by the utility company at 11 a.m.

DETROIT, May 25 (AP) -Cars are continuing to roll off the assembly lines at the rate of more than 500,000 a month, adding to dealers' stocks, which soon may total 1,000,000 new cars.

Four bowling alleys built for shipment to Europe are being installed in Madison Square Garden for tomorrow's one-day tournament. Since only two days were available to set up equipment, it was necessary to use prefabricated lanes.

OAKLAND, N. J., May 25 -Warner Rosenschein is one commuter who cannot complain about the train he rides, unless he wants to talk to himself. He is the builder and owner of the Ramapo and Western Railroad, a 500-foot-long line connecting Truman Boulevard here with his home atop a hill.
FKANKFORT, Ky., May 25 -Democrats and Republicans will choose their candidates for Governor, all other state offices and the members of the Legislature in their primaries tomorrow.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman yesterday awarded $242,987 to the widow of a freelance writer killed in the crash of an Air Force bomber. The judgment was against the Government even though the victim had signed a waiver.

By contempt citation and by temporary injunction courts in New York City declared yesterday with increased emphasis that the continuing strike against voluntary, nonprofit hospitals is against the law. The first essential, then, coming before all other considerations, is for the strikers to return to their jobs. They were already in contempt of their humane duty to assure proper care of the sick, the helpless.

The directors of General Mills, Inc., have proposed a three-forone split of the company's common stock. They also announced yesterday that the dividend rate would be increased if the split were approved.

The appointment of Thomas M. Green as vice president in charge of the facilities development division of Montgomery Ward Co. was anonunced yesterday by John A. Barr, chairman of the big mail order house. Mr. Green had been vice president in charge of planning and development for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., department store chain.

In April, 1958, Mayor Wagner signed an amendment to the administrative code to allow the annual Loyalty Day parade to march on Fifth Avenue through the retail business district. " Obie" awards, originated by The Village Voice to designate achievement in the off-Broadway theatre, were made yesterday afternoon by the weekly Greenwich Village newspaper at the Village Gate, 185 Thompson Street.

Farm bloc leaders in Congress are engaged in a race against time this week to obtain passage of a new wheat control law that would be even less defensible, if passed, than the law as it now stands. Next Monday is the deadline for such legislation, since Secretary Benson must then announce planting controls under whatever law may be in effect.

In a reversal of usual roles, the track coaches served as handicappers for the track writers yesterday. In listing the probable winner at this week-end's Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America championships, the voting quintet of coaches arrived at one startling conclusion.

LONDON, May 25 -- Queen Elizabeth II formally opened today Britain's most imposing youth hostel.

Trans World Airlines was reported yesterday to have reached an agreement with its pilots on a new contract. The negotiations began approximately a year ago to replace a pact subject to renewal as of last August.

In the future Consolidated Edison will be doing as much digging in Manhattan as ever -- and even more -- but the public will be less aware of it. This is due to a new device that drills holes under streets without tearing up the pavement.

Garry Moore can begin a vacation at the end of June without worrying about the future of his Tuesday evening television variety show on the Columbia Broadcasting System. The same production staff will continue next season, and four advertisers have been obtained to pick up the check.
PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- The heads of the United States, British, French and West German Governments today hailed the North Atlantic alliance as a military success.

Five prominent trustees of the American Shakespeare Festival at Stratford, Conn., resigned early this year to protest the rehiring of a stage manager who had refused to tell a Congressional committee whether he was a Communist.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Supreme Court held unconstitutional today a Louisiana ban on matches between Negro and white boxers. The court acted in an unelaborated two-line order. It affirmed the decision of a threejudge Federal District Court in New Orleans enjoining the State Athletic Commission from enforcing the racial prohibition.
The outgoing president of the Medical Society of the County of New York said last night that doctors were going to have to face increasing governmentsupported centralized health care.

Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union made a last-ditch effort yesterday to upset the sale of the city's three subway power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company.
The "unselfish devotion to duty" displayed by John Foster Dulles "won the admiration of all men of goodwill," Pope John XXIII said yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 -(AP) -- The heroism of miners, mine officials, physicians and other rescuers in the Oct. 23, 1958, mine disaster at Springhill, N. S., was singled out by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission today for a special gold medal citation.
PITTSBURGH, May 25 (AP) -A forty-nine-hour strike against Pittsburgh's three daily newspapers ended today. Papers reached the newsstands within minutes of the announcement.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -Corporation pension funds have been devoting more of their assets to purchases of common stock, but they still bought only $1,200,000,000 worth of stock last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will vote tomorrow on Ogden R. Reid's nomination to be Ambassador to Israel.

The State Banking Board has paved the way for banks to exchange Government bonds for Government guaranteed and insured mortgages.

The West Penn Power Company, Westmoreland County, Pa., borrowed $14,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance construction. The utility sold first-mortgage bonds maturing in June, 1989 to a banking syndicate headed by W. C. Langley Co. The price was 101.1899 with a 5 1/8% interest coupon.

Hollywood turned to Eighth Avenue yesterday for the exploitation of a forthcoming motion picture. The Mirisch Company and the United Artists Corporation purchased the American radio rights to the heavyweight title fight between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson.

The subject of trade with Russia is much in the news. A British trade agreement has been reached with Moscow and a leading American business man, Cyrus Eaton, has predicted that the United States could sell $3,000,000,000 worth of goods to the Soviet Union in the next three years.

TRENTON, May 25 -- The State Senate approved three bills today to permit life insurance companies to issue variable annuity contracts in New Jersey. Gov. Robert B. Meyner is expected to sign the measures.

TORONTO, May 25 (AP) -The case of a Toronto Negro student who reported he was asked to stop dancing with a white girl on a Buffalo, N. Y., television program Saturday stirred protests and a demand for an Ontario Government inquiry today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 (AP) -- Johnny Podres, the Los Angeles Dodgers' southpaw, lost a bid for a no-hitter in the eighth inning today, but he defeated the San Francisco Giants, 8 -- 0. He allowed only two singles. It was the first time San Francisco had been blanked this season.

The Arabian American Oil Company has announced the election of Thomas C. Barger as president. Norman Hardy, who had been president since January, 1958, was elected chairman and will continue as chief executive officer.
NORWALK, Conn., May 25 -Brenda Lewis, Metropolitan Opera soprano, and Benjamin Cooper of Weston and New York, electronics engineer and manufacturer, were married here yesterday.
FREDERICTON, N. B., May 25 -- Lord Beaverbrook, British publisher and benefactor of New Brunswick, celebrated his eightieth birthday here today.
The British Book Center in New York lighted a historic gas lamp in its garden yesterday to celebrate the center's tenth anniversary.

A READER wrote us a poignant tale of woe the other day. It was her contention that New York City stores are bereft of "the just ordinary everyday articles which one would think one could find in the largest shopping center in the world."
Three orchestral programs, a chamber music concert and a recital of fifteenth and sixteenth-century music will make up the fourteenth annual Caramoor Music Festival this summer.

LOS ANGELES, May 25 -West Coast ship owners predicted today they would reach a new contract agreement with Harry Bridges' International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union without a strike this year.

THE largest assortment of labor-saving and labor-creating devices for the home ever shown in a New York store went on view yesterday morning with a bang. As the opening ceremonies for the Livingston Street annex of Abraham Straus proceeded calmly, a series of sharp reports filled the air.

SANDWICH, England, May 25 (AP) -- Charley Coe, the United States champion, and three of his Walker Cup teammates led a ten-man American advance today through the first round of the British amateur golf championship.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein reserved decision yesterday on a petition to compel the Associated Hospital Service of New York (Blue Cross) to give its 7,000,000 subscribers a voice in its management.

PORTLAND, Me., May 25 (UPI) -- The State Supreme Court, by 4-2, ruled today that the city of Augusta had no authority to provide public transportation for parochial school children. The city enacted such an ordinance in June, 1957.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 -The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church voiced the hope here today that Communist China might soon be recognized by the United States Government and admitted into the United Nations.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Tuesday, May 26 -- Two Little Rock school board members backed by Gov. Orval E. Faubus were ousted early today less than two weeks after their purge of forty-four teachers.

JUST at dusk and at low tide several weeks ago, a young couple raking for clams on a Cape Cod sand flat noticed a well-corked bottle bobbing at the water's edge. Many floating bottles have an air of mystery, and this one did.

With the May White Sales at hand, purchasers of Turkish towels will find that a knowledge of weaves and weights is of inestimable aid when shopping. The following tips on buying cotton terry towels are offered by Dundee Mills, a manufacturer:

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -The Samuel H. Kress Foundation of New York has given the Philadelphia Museum of Art the Barberini tapestries, "The Story of Constantine." Their value is "incalculable and can only be estimated as close to $1,000,000," a joint announcement said today.

The New York Employing Printers Association last night elected Donald B. Thrush chairman of its board of directors. The action was taken at the association's annual dinner meeting in the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The old-fashioned theory that the supply of money is the major influence on business and price levels is still true, Congress was told today.

CLEVELAND, May 25 (UPI) -- Four high school boys of "superior intelligence" confessed in Juvenile Court today that they had organized a Nazi-like group and conspired to overthrow the Government by violence.
BOSTON, May 25 -- Delegates to the American Unitarian Association's annual meeting elected three vice presidents and seven directors today.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -Traders in grain futures ignored today the talk about a bullish outlook for soybeans and their selling depressed prices sharply on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- A House subcommittee, going over the heads of policymakers, is discussing plans for a face-to-face appeal to Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev for East-West cooperation in exploration of outer space.
David Dubinsky got assurances of help yesterday from the city's top law-enforcement officials after two more top aides of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union had received death threats.
Antoine Pinay, French Minister of Finance, told a group of bankers and investors here yesterday that France welcomed foreign capital but did not solicit it.

All cocoa futures fell the 1-cent-a-pound-a-day limit yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was active, with 759 contracts changing hands. There were 138 unsatisfied offerings at the close.
HAVANA, May 25 -- The plant of the Communist newspaper Hoy has been guarded since last night by the police because of threats made by labor groups at a national sugar workers congress here.
BUFFALO, May 25 (AP) -The community-owned Buffalo Bisons of the International League today made formal application for membership in baseball's proposed third major league.

A stock sale by Hall Developers, Inc., sponsor of a slumclearance project designated by the city as Pratt Institute Area, Brooklyn, did not violate a Federal law, the city's Corporation Counsel held yesterday.
MOSCOW, May 25 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev began a twelve-day visit to Albania today in a Balkan move that preoccupied the interest of Moscow diplomats.
Justice Charles J. Beckinella ordered two union leaders jailed and fined yesterday for refusing to halt the hospital strike here.

The alleged companion of the gunman slain by a police officer in a gun duel in an auto early Sunday was held without bail yesterday. Two women friends were detained in $25,000 bail each as material witnesses.

The International Harvester Company achieved record sales and earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended on April 30, Frank W. Jenks, president, reported yesterday. He also said that the outlook for this quarter was "unusually favorable."

PALERMO, Sicily, May 25 -In Italian, "targa" means "plaque." Solid gold ones were awarded by the race organizer, Vincenzo Florio, to the first half-dozen winners of the Targa Florio. Back before World War I the solid gold plaques were lovely.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright said today he would ask President Eisenhower to resolve an apparent split within the Administration over financing the Development Loan Fund.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency started an all-out drive today to develop efficient collisionwarning devices for civil and military aircraft.

A salad-sandwich loaf is an ideal entree for a spring buffet luncheon or supper. With tasty salad mixtures between the layers of bread and crisp salad greens, such as radishes, cucumbers and tomatoes, surrounding it, the dish is as beautiful as it is delicious.
Emile Griffith, undefeated West Side welterweight, scored a unanimous ten-round decision over Willie Stevenson of Boston at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
TOKYO, May 25 (AP) -- Communist China asked the Soviet Union and Britain today to stop the Royal Laotian Army from disarming a rebellious Communist battalion holed up in northern Laos.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A spokesman for the Scientific Apparatus Makers Association supported an amendment today to the National Defense Education Act to bar the purchase of Soviet science teaching equipment.

Hugh Baillie, a third-generation newspaper man, has observed the world scene, first as a reporter and later as president of The United Press, for forty-five years. In "High Tension," he presents his personal opinions of the events he has seen and the people he has met.

Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey told Richard M. Nixon an hour before he made his 1952 television defense of the "Nixon fund" that a majority of Republican campaign leaders felt he ought to withdraw as Republican Vice-Presidential candidate.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -The Interstate Commerce Commission urgently recommended today a series of specific steps, including tax relief and revision of working rules, to revive dwindling railroad passenger travel.

Your May 21 editorial on the Rail Pension Bill clearly emphasized the complexities that are related to such a simple desire as the development of adequate unemployment and retirement programs. However, there were several points made which, although not incorrect, could be quite misleading.
A Sanitation Department patrolman who had spent three weeks watching a man suspected of robbing a church poor box, captured his man early yesterday.
The Queens Democratic executive committee voted yesterday to strip Robert P. Battipaglia of his rights as its chairman.

The five-story apartment building at 3195 Decatur Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by a syndicate headed by Harry H. Rifkin to the Eagle Realty Corporation, which bought it for future development. Schiffman Goldkopf were the brokers.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning the sale of $14,804,000 of temporary loan notes on next Tuesday and June 9. Proceeds from the sale will be used to finance projects subsidized by the State government and the Federal Government.

Proxy solicitation material filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by a dissident stockholders' group of the International Railways of Central America has failed to receive approval of the commission, it was announced yesterday by Herman A. Bayless, counsel for the insurgents.
King Baudouin of the Belgians will arrive by air in New York at 5 P. M. tomorrow from Whiteman Air Force Base in Missouri.

Two adjoining apartment houses on the southwest corner of Avenue B and Thirteenth Street have been acquired by the Embassy Holding Corporation, Morris Weinberg, president, from the Callipari Construction Corporation. Eagle Realty Associates were the brokers in the transaction.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -The Treasury bill rate showed little change this week, the Treasury reported tonight. The gap between the yields of ninety-one-day and 182-day bills again narrowed slightly.
GENEVA, May 25 -- Even in death John Foster Dulles has played a part in the Foreign Ministers' meeting.

The Board of Education is preparing its own report on how to improve the administration and operation of the school system. Two recent reports made by other agencies at the board's request will be its guideposts.

" BILLY BUDD," Herman Melville's tale of conflict and tragedy at sea, received a respectful and technically superior production on Channel 2 last night. The telecast on the "The Show of the Month" did not, however, achieve the majestic dimensions of the original story.

GENEVA, May 25 -- The Soviet Union emphasized today that it accepted only one criterion of progress at the foreign ministers' conference here: How far the conference has moved toward acceptance of the Soviet Union's draft peace treaty for Germany.
An informal agreement has been reached to use Washington Arch as a turnaround point for Fifth Avenue buses when Washington Square Park is permanently closed to traffic on July 1.
Why is there not more concern among the American people over the horrors of fall-out from atomic weapons tests?
The States Marine Corporation has cut its last tie with foreign shipping interests in preparation for its forthcoming entry into the ranks of subsidized American steamship lines.
DEEP in every woman's heart is a belief that the right man can make her hair look beautiful. It is only a question of finding him.
CHICAGO, May 25, (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

THE man picked by Mayor Wagner to head the threemember panel of "impartial and competent persons" to seek a peace formula in the hospital strike may be the nation's best known mediator and arbitrator.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) May 25 -- The president of B'nai B'rith, Jewish service organization, declared today that Israel must not characterize United States Jews as "available targets for immigration."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- Movies and real estate were mixed here today by a bulldozer in what may be the beginning of a new era in movies and in Beverly Hills real estate.
TRENTON, Tuesday, May 26 -- The Democratic-dominated Assembly last night overrode, 48 to 6, Gov. Robert B. Meyner's conditional veto of a bill to establish a state scholarship program.

Dr. Vannevar Bush, one of our most eminent scientists, has stated that our program of foreign aid "must continue as long as the Communist threat endures." An arbitrary cutoff date he says, would be a "calamity of the first order."
WASHINGTON, May 25 -President Eisenhower's $1,000,000 personal fund to meet emergencies weathered an attack in the House of Representatives today.

Music of Bartok, Webern, Berg and Stravinsky was presented late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall by faculty and graduates of the Manhattan School of Music with as much ease and aplomb as if the composers were Brahms, Weber, Beethoven and Schubert.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The foreign policy chiefs of the Western world, and at least one from the Soviet bloc, prepared today to come here to pay final tribute to John Foster Dulles.

Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., ha snotified the Securities Exchange Commission of its intention to offer publicly 400,000 shares of common stock. Blyth Co., Inc., was designated to head the syndicate. About $10,000,000 of the proceeds will finance construction and the rest will be added to working capital.
The Reisinger Cup team-of-four championship in the ten-day Eastern States Contract Bridge Championships started last night at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The House Antitrust subcommittee strongly criticized the Justice Department today for some uses of consent decrees to end anti-trust suits.
GENEVA, May 25 -- The thirty -seven member countries of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade today approved a form of associate membership for Yugoslavia.
ST. STEPHEN, N. B., May 25 -- There is a procedure in fishing the St. Croix River when the water is rising and thousands of four-foot pulpwood logs of various diameters are floating downstream.
Two king-size accounts for new small cars were parked yesterday.

The Group Health Federation of America and the American Labor Health Association were merged yesterday at meetings of the two groups here. The new body will be known as the Group Health Association of America.

A year ago today the Yankees were nine games ahead of their closest pursuers at the time, the Boston Red Sox. Casey Stengel's men had just about spread-eagled the American League field, en route to their ninth pennant in ten seasons.
NEW ORLEANS, May 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court's decision met with mixed reaction in Louisiana today.

Burglars entered the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Lewis at Miami Springs, Fla., Sunday night and stole the Distaff Handicap trophy their 7-yearold mare, Happy Princess, had won at Belmont Park last year. Yesterday afternoon Happy Princess went out at Belmont and won another Distaff cup.

Roberto Vergara Herrera, Chilean finance minister, arrived in New York yesterday to complete arrangements for a substantial bank loan. Eleven major banks, led by the First National City Bank of New York, have agreed to provide $53,000,000 in credits to that nation to help it refund obligations and to help with expenditures.
ROME, May 25 -- Alleged ecclesiastic interference in politics is again an issue n Italy.

Syracuse, Washington and Pennsylvania, three of the most favored varsity contenders, will row in adjoining lanes in the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association on Onondaga Lake at Syracuse June 20.
THE most gorgeously hatted and clothed people in New York yesterday were not women but seventeen gentlemen from Japan.
MEMPHIS, May 25 (AP) -Don Whitt won the $25,000 Memphis open golf tournament today in a three-way play-off.
LONDON, May 25 -- The fiveyear trade pact signed by Britain and the Soviet Union in Moscow yesterday has been welcomed here with restrained optimism.

MILWAUKEE, May 26 -Harvey Haddix of the Pittsburgh Pirates pitched twelve perfect innings tonight but lost in the thirteenth. The first hit he yielded, to Joe Adcock, gave a 2-0 victory to the Milwaukee Braves.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 -The Protestant Episcopal Bishop of California charged today that constitutional guarantees of religious freedom were being violated by state laws interfering with birth control.
H. B. Cantor, a hotel man, yesterday unveiled the first model of his proposed 90,000-ton superships. "I will not stop until I build these ships," he said.
The chairman of the American Heart Association's Nutrition Committee, Dr. Herbert Pollack, has developed a simple mathematical formula for preventing overweight.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York sold yesterday $75,000,000 of thirty-year first-mortgage bonds to an investment banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. The price was 100.3291 for a 5 1/8 per cent coupon.
A Chicago lawyer died last night after he had walked through a plate-glass door in an East Side apartment house.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., informed its stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting that the company had signed separate agreements with its three operating unions which assured continued flight of military personnel and cargo during any strike that ever might hit the company.

A new slate of officers and directors of Seabrook Farms Company, grower and processor of foods, was elected yesterday at shareholders' and directors' meeting at the company's headquarters in Seabrook, N. J. The election reflected a change in ownership of Seabrook, which had been acquired by Seeman Brothers, Inc., New York food distributor.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey called on members of the Group Health Institute yesterday to experiment with new forms of organizing, administering and financing medical care.
PARIS, May 26 (AP) -- Upsets continued to rock the French tennis championships today.

GENEVA, May 26 -- The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade announced today it had scheduled for September, 1960, the start of a "very large scope" tariff-cutting conference. The site will be decided later.

BERLIN, May 26 -- Soviet and West Berlin officials have predicted a quiet day for the city tomorrow, the end of the sixmonth period set by Moscow for ending the four-power occupation status of Berlin.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -Rye and old-crop corn futures weakened in late dealings today on the Board of Trade while soybeans firmed slightly on scattered short covering.
Construction contract awards last month set a new high for any April, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee overrode its chairman today and voted to recommend the confirmation of Ogden R. Reid to be Ambassador to Israel.

BONN, Germany, May 26 -Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano told the parliamentary group of the ruling Christian Democratic party today that the Western foreign ministers at Geneva had worked out "certain principles" for the conclusion of a peace treaty with Germany.

NEW HAVEN, May 26 -Another legal action to test the validity of Connecticut's eighty-year old birth-control law was filed in Superior Court here yesterday by two Yale Law School students. Six similar actions are pending in the courts.
DETROIT, May 26 -- The Chrysler Corporation announced a realignment of its sales division today.
DENVER, May 26 (AP) -While a woman near by watched in astonishment, a man looted an armored truck of $164,450 in currency today and escaped with a male partner in an automobile.
Two lawyers were arrested yesterday after an intensive five-month hunt for elusive slum landlords.

Passengers on Northwest Airlines' future jet service may observe that only two of the three engine pods on their plane's starboard wing are in operation. They should not worry, Frank Judd, vice president in charge of operations for Northwest, said yesterday.
Two issues of sewerage bonds totaling $12,667,000 were offered for sale yesterday by the Evergreen and Farmington Systems in Oakland County, Mich.

TORONTO, May 26 (AP) -- An ultra-modern oil refinery costing $27,000,000 and embodying $3,000,000 worth of "good neighbor" features was dedicated by Cities Service Company on the outskirts of Toronto today.
MONTREAL, May 26 -- The end of an old enmity between two hard-hitting American seamen who have decided to make common cause against common "enemies," was dramatically formalized here today.

I am writing to protest the action of the city in reducing the budget of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the point where it finds it necessary to close one day a week. This is an unthinkable situation, particularly when the sum is a mere $35,000.
BUENOS AIRES, May 26 -Foreign Minister Golda Meir of Israel said today her nation was "astounded" that the United Nations was not enforcing free navigation through the Suez Canal.

A strike at seven proprietary hospitals was threatened by a separate union yesterday as the drug union's walkout at six voluntary hospitals here continued despite jail sentences imposed on the strike leaders.
The establishment of a foundation that will encourage children in esthetically creative activities was announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, May 26 (UPI)--The Tass press agency announced tonight that Frol R. Kozlov, a First Deputy Premier, would open the Soviet exhibition in New York next month.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 26 (AP) -- Nasrullah, a stallion whose offspring have netted total American earnings of $6,519,175, died of a heart attack in his paddock at Claiborne Farm today.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 26 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hills Field Club won her second Garden State Women's Golf Association one-day tournament at the Crestmont County Club today.
For a team with barely enough force to man the battlements, Mike Higgins' Red Sox did all right at the Stadium last night before a crowd of 31,966.
GENEVA, May 26 -- Soviet Foreign Secretary Andrei A. Gromyko departed for Washington in a commercial airplane today to attend the funeral of John Foster Dulles.

Setting James Joyce to music would appear to be a hazardous undertaking, what with Joyce's strong, individual and frequently unconventional use of the language. But six composers, in as many musical styles, made the effort in Patricia Neway's program last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, and they showed it could be done.

The Sanitation Department obtained yesterday the dismissal of traffic complaints against two of its employes. The sanitation men had been accused by the police of operating a cleanup vehicle with defective lights and dirty license plates.
Frank Lloyd Wright envisioned "a little temple in a park" when he designed the new home of the Guggenheim Museum, nearing completion on upper Fifth Avenue.

The over-the-counter market in prime risk fixed-income securities took a back seat yesterday as the financial district's bond houses busied themselves with the biggest day in newissue financing in months.

SANDWICH, England, May 26 (UPI) -- Eight Americans, led by Charley Coe and three Walker Cup team-mates, entered the third round of the British amateur golf championship today. But twelve others, including Billy Joe Patton, were eliminated.
BUENOS AIRES, May 26 -- A new inflationary wave threatens to swamp President Arturo Frondizi's economic recovery plans for politically troubled Argentina.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- Nine African states announced today that they would hold a ministers' conference to consider the four-andone-half-year-old conflict in Algeria. The parley will be held in Monrovia, Liberia, early in August and probably will last several days.

TOKYO, May 26 -- The Japanese were jubilant today upon learning that Tokyo had been chosen as the site for the 1964 Olympic summer games. This was the realization of a dream for many Japanese sports lovers.

THE Swedes, who have great taste for cold fruit soups, have recently introduced two to the United States, both for the first time in the form of dry mixes: Timed to arrive at the start of warm weather, the soups are blueberry and a rose hip.

Deaths from leukemia, a form of cancer of the bloodforming organs, are increasing at a faster rate than are deaths from any other type of cancer except lung cancer, the American Cancer Society reported yesterday.

The American fashion trend for the fall and winter is now being shaped, as Seventh Avenue designers unveil their collections to the press and to store buyers. The showings presently underway are the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 26 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey challenged the Democratic party tonight to "show that it deserves to win" in 1960 by "fighting for what it believes is right for country and our people."

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad reported yesterday it had realized a net railway operating income of $70,415 last month. But revenues available for interest on the road's income bonds fell $150,859 short of the month's requirement of $197,834.

TEANECK, N. J., May 26 -Forty years with the Internal Revenue Service has not made it any easier for Richard D. Donoghue, Assistant Regional Commissioner (New York), to pay certain of his own personal taxes.
GENEVA, May 26 -- The United Nations World Health Organization decided today to reconsider next year the possibility of staging an "international health year."
The Veterans of Foreign Wars issued a statement yesterday declaring that the annual Loyalty Day parade along Fifth Avenue brought added business to the merchants.
HAVANA, Wednesday, May 27 -- Raul Castro, commander of Cuba's armed forces, was reported missing early today on a flight in a light plane over the Cienaga de Zapata swamp in south-central Cuba.
One of the greatest painting acquisitions by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a major work of El Greco, will go on exhibition today.

The New York City Ballet last night introduced to us an art as remote from its own as it could possibly be and still remain within the broad definition of dancing. This is Gagaku, which is translated as "elegant and authorized music," and it was presented by the musicians and dancers of the Japanese Imperial Household in their first appearance outside their own country.
PARIS, May 26 -- Premier Michel Debre stood firm today against the National Assembly's efforts to recapture some of its power.
LONDON, May 26 -- The Foreign Office rejected today Communist China's charges that Laos had violated the 1954 truce agreements on Indochina.
A housing survey in Huntington, L. I., has found substandard housing scattered in several small pockets, but not concentrated in any single area.

The son of the house is today in revolt. All during the year he has studied hard, and what thanks does he get from home? No thanks. From the head of the house, and all the rest of them, come whimpers only.

City License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell announced yesterday that he had refused to renew the license of the Harry Conover Modeling Agency. He said that he had rejected the renewal request after investigating the agency's books and records.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 26 -The Labor-Management Industry Fund of Sheet Metal Workers Union Local 55 announced today the establishment of a $15,000 scholarship program in lieu of a wage increase this year.
MOSCOW, May 26 -- One of the harshest attacks yet to appear in the Soviet press against life in Israel was published today.
DEVON, P.a., May 26 -- Windsor Castle, owned by Carl Miller Jr. of Battle Creek, Mich., took the lead tonight for the open jumper championship of the Devon Horse Show.

The Trafalgar Hospital, 161 East Ninetieth Street, will benefit from the first public showing of the motion picture, "Porgy and Bess," at the Warner Theatre on June 26. This performance has been arranged in cooperation with the Variety Club of New York.
SHRUB OAK, N. Y., May 26 -- A pair of drowsy suburban hamlets, Shrub Oak and Jefferson, Valley, became highly animated today.

HOW that man could talk. Who else, other than George Bernard Shaw? If there is anyone who has any doubts as to whether or not Shaw still was talking as he neared the completion of his ninety-second year, let him head for the Provincetown Playhouse, where "Buoyant Billions" was given its initial professional American outing last night.
The state commission on New York City announced yesterday that it had retained McKinsey Co., management and government consultants, to help lay the ground rules for its inquiry.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 -M. Monroe Kimbrel, chairman of the American Bankers Association's Committee on Federal Legislation, said today that, "banks, like nations, no longer can indulge the luxury of isolation."

RYE, N. Y., May 26 -- Joseph A. Lelash of Wykagyl, making his debut as a member of the Westchester Seniors' Golf Association, won the group's annual spring tournament with 35, 37 -72 over the South course at the Westchester Country Club today.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 26 -- Former King Leopold of the Belgians has expressed a desire to give up residence in Laken, the traditional home of the royal family.

The jail sentences and fines imposed here Monday on two officers of the hospital union, and the fining of the union itself for violating an anti-strike injunction, were the Culmination of an injunction process in the courts.
Four people recently were walking along Broad Street bucking a strong wind. Sud denly, they were struck down by a flying section of fence that had blown loose from a near-by excavation.

Just twenty-five years ago yesterday, the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad dispatched a new train from Denver to Chicago to be shown at the World's Fair then in session. The train, called the Pioneer Zephyr, was the world's first Diesel-powered streamliner, a single Diesel unit pulling three articulated stainless-steel cars.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -(AP) -- A limit of $50,000 on total price supports for any one farm or farmer won approval today by a Senate Appropriations subcommittee.

The Antitrust Division of the Justice Department opened an investigation yesterday into racketeering in the delivery of newspapers and magazines in the metropolitan area -- a radius of forty miles around New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower ordered a change today in the designs of the President's official coat of arms, flag and seal to increase the number of stars to forty-nine.

The net income of Eversharp. Inc., in the three months ending May 31 will be about double that for the year-ago period, according to Patrick Frawley Jr., president. He so informed the annual meeting yesterday in Chicago.

Patricia Neal has been engaged to star with Anne Bancroft in "The Miracle Worker." The William Gibson play deals with the life of Helen Keller and the task of overcoming deafness, muteness and blindness to educate her.
Two thousand IRT passengers were forced to leave a Lexington Avenue train through a tunnel to an emergency exit ysterday when a rail break stalled three trains near the Fifty-ninth Street station.
Price increases ranging up to 16 per cent in most household and industrial light bulbs will be made by the end of next month by two leading producers.

NEW HAVEN, May 26 -- The Yale School of Medicine and the Grace - New Haven Community Hospital announced today the incorporation of the Yale-New Haven Medical Center. This formalized an affiliation between the two institutions that began in 1826 and became an informal medical-center operation in 1954.
The allocation of $9,200,000 in state funds to two urban renewal projects in the city and fourteen elsewhere in the state was announced yesterday.
Movements in the stock market were mostly fractional yesterday, and the averages at the close showed trifling losses. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was the lightest since April 9.

An increasing number of developments on the economic front of late have combined to suggest that, while it is only about two months since the Report of the Joint Congressional Committee on the President's Economic Report appeared, its central conclusion, if not perhaps completely refuted, has at least been brought into serious question.
Twenty-eight contract bridge teams last night entered the second knockout round of the Reisinger Cup team-of-four championship in the annual Eastern States Championships at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -- A racial issue has forced the cancellation of a picnic that has been a tradition for twenty-seven years with the ninth-grade classes in Beverly Hills Junior High School in suburban Upper Darby.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The House approved tentatively today $651,896,700 in funds for the State and Justice Departments and the Federal courts.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Wednesday, May 27 (AP) -- Bert T. Combs, a mountain lawyer, appeared headed toward victory tonight over Lieut. Gov. Harry Lee Waterfield in his second try for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination of Kentucky.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Defense Department, refuting earlier assertions by one of its top officials, has told Congress it has no firm, long-range program for space research.
BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, May 26 (UPI) -- The Americanowned Power and Light Company was threatened with expropriation by Minas Gerais state authorities today.
SADDLE RIVER, N. J., May 26 -- This residential community of 1,600 is choosing sides as a two-year fight over the establishment of a private school enters a new phase.
EUROPE'S unluckiest king has bowed once more to the will of his people and taken one step farther from the throne he once occupied.
Henry Cabot Lodge, United States Ambassador to the United Nations, declared last night that free countries must discipline themselves to promote freedom more energetically if they were to survive.
Hubbell Robinson Jr. has resigned as executive vice president of Columbia Broadcasting System television network programs to set up his own independent producing organization.
LONDON, May 26 -- Price movements among the industrials generally were aimless in quiet trading in the stock market today.

The six-story building containing forty-two apartments and occupying a plot 140 by 100 feet at 1236 Forty-ninth Street in the Boro Park section of Brooklyn has been sold by Charles Himelfarb. It is assessed at $205,000 and was bought by an investor for cash over a mortgage of $195,000 in a deal negotiated by Harry Handschu, broker.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 26 (AP) -- The Florida Legislature enacted a law today to segregate pupils by sex.

James Hopkins Awards for the "greatest improvement" in humane food animal slaughter were presented last night to two companies and two individuals. They were given by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at its annual meeting at the Pierre Hotel.
HAVANA, May 26 -- Blas Roca, Communist leader, accused Premier Fidel Castro today of endangering the unity of the revolution by loosing an anti-Communist campaign.
CASTLETON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., May 26 -- Governor Rockefeller swung open a new gateway today to New England from the Hudson Valley.

MAN'S brawn and brains are rapidly being replaced by the battery. To the electric cell can go credit for vanquished cuticles and 5 o'clock shadows, for flames fanned to a blaze and shoes shined, for bodies beautified and Martinis mixed.
The third annual San Francisco International Film Festival will be held from Nov. 11 to Nov. 24, according to an announcement from festival authorities.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -Crane Company directors decided today to invest some of the corporation's cash in their company by buying 800,000 shares of its stock.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Kennedy labor reform bill appeared virtually orphaned today, making its chances of survival seem slim. The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, one of the last of the major interested groups to speak, said it would oppose the bill as passed by the Senate.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa conceded yesterday that he owned a one-third stock interest in the Gerosa Haulage and Warehouse Corporation and the Gerosa Crane Service Company, Inc.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., May 26 -- Al Brosch, 47-year-old Woodmere professional who first won the title twenty years ago, won the Long Island open golf championship for the tenth time today. Brosch carded a 54hole total of 214, 2 under par, at the Rockville Links Club.
HAVANA, May 26 (AP) -Premier Castro was reported today to have joined the airground search for his missing brother.

FOR many years the Artists Gallery, 851 Lexington Avenue, has operated as a nonprofit organization dedicated to bringing exhibition opportunities to little-known painters and sculptors. Each year a monthly series of viewings by a jury results in a group exhibition such as "Submissions '58-59," now on view -- a show that embodies most of the moods and idioms expressed in contemporary painting.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 26 -- A new alignment of democratic parties of the Left is in the making to combat regimes in the Caribbean area that are considered dic tatorial. The new group is expected to make a declaration of policy and to reveal its membership within two months.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 26 -- The Board of Education voted last night "to agree in principle" to a plan allowing parochial school children to ride public school buses if they paid their transportation.
The United Steelworkers of America made public yesterday the economic fact book that will be its "bible" in negotiations for a new steel wage agreement.

GENEVA, May 26 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union will meet in secret, restricted session here Friday after thirteen formal plenary meetings in which they failed to reach substantive negotiations.
Archbishop Molloy High of Queens took the lead as the field events were completed yesterday in the annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championships at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
CHICAGO, May 26. (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- The House Judiciary Committee approved a bill today to make it easier to deport undesirable aliens.

Perlbinder Broff, who constructed the eleven-story and penthouse apartment building at 141 East Fifty-sixth Street in 1940, have sold it to investing clients of Gerhsman Gellinoff, lawyers. Jack Nunberg, vice president of Abbott Adams, Inc., was the broker. The sale included the adjoining two-story taxpayer at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street.
Bobby Fischer, the 16-yearold United States chess champion, played to an adjournment in forty-two moves with Bent Larsen of Denmark tri the jubilee tournament at Zurich, Switzerland, yesterday.

A closing rush enabled the Cockfield Stable's Pantene to win the feature event at Belmont Park yesterday. The 5year-old son of Clarion, favored at 3 -- 2 by the crowd of 18,702, equaled the track record of 1:22 4/5 for seven furlongs on the turf.
LONDON, May 26 -- Christies and Sotheby's, London's most venerable art auction houses, are running hard for top place in the booming art market.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed yesterday for support of the pro-integrationist Southern Conference Educational Fund, Inc. Some of the group's leaders have been targets for Congressional investigations.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26 -Dr. Charles Malik, former Lebanese Foreign Minister, said in a cablegram published here today that he had been the victim of "an unworthy intrigue" when he was photographed May 8 in the Israeli pavilion at the New York Trade Fair.

DULUTH, Minn., May 26 (AP) -- A petition by the Mesabi Iron Company of New York for a stay of a court order calling for arbitration in a dispute with the Reserve Mining Company over royalty payments was denied today in United States District Court.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The House of Representatives tentatively approved today a bill to continue the defense contract renegotiation law for four more years. The final vote was put off until tomorrow.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 15 cents to $2.30 a bale yesterday. The new October was the weakest future.
MONTREAL, May 26 -- Traffic on the new St. Lawrence Seaway is moving at a tempo that augurs well for the gigantic international project.
For about an hour beginning just after noon yesterday the sun was ringed -- in black, at first -- and then in a spectrum of bright colors.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 -The 3,000,000-member United Presbyterian Church is expected to join the growing number of Protestant bodies that have endorsed, in one form or another, the practice of birth control.

WASHINGTON, MAY 26, -- The National Science Foundation warned the Senate today that cuts made by the House in its budget for the coming year would seriously handicap Government support of basic scientific research.

Balked at every other port of call, the Yankees yesterday turned to their old standbys in the trading mart to swing that long-awaited deal. They closed a six-player tranaction with the Kansas City Athletics, although at the moment only five players are involved.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Government issued an appraisal of the business situation today, which Secretary of Commerce Lewis L. Strauss said should convince doubt ers that "we have a strong recovery under way."
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 26--Premier Abdul Karim Kassim's Government is beginning to hint at a new emphasis on neutrality in Iraq's foreign policy.

Directors of the Greyhound Corporation declared a 5 per cent stock dividend yesterday in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents. The cash dividend is payable on June 30 to holders of record of June 8.
LONDON, May 26 (Reuters) -- Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev paid tribute tonight to John Foster Dulles as a distinguished politician, the Moscow radio reported.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold issued an injunction yesterday, barring the annual stockholder meeting of the H. L. Green Company for at least three months. The meeting had been scheduled for today at the Commodore Hotel here.
Several hundred school children and out-of-town visitors got more excitement than they paid for yesterday when a sightseeing boat stalled twice on her trip around Manhattan and had to be towed home.
OTTAWA, May 26 (AP) -Canada's trade deficit after the first four months of 1959 stands at $315,200,000, almost double the $169,800,000 for the corresponding period of 1958.

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP) -The St. Louis Globe-Democrat plans to publish on Monday its first edition in more than three months, Richard H. Amberg, publisher, announced today. There were indications, however, that it least one mechanical union at the morning newspaper might throw a monkey wrench into the plans.
WASHINGTON, May 26--President Eisenhower told Republican Congressional leaders today that there was no need to choose now between the rival Army and Air Force anti-aircraft missile weapons.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 26 -- An angry wave of popular reaction against an attempt to purge teachers has swept from office the three Little Rock School Board members backed by Gov. Orval E. Faubus.
MOSCOW, May 26 -- The Soviet Government has appointed Aleksei I. Adzhubei editor of Izvestia.
CAIRO, May 26 (UPI) -Crown Prince Seif al-Islam alBadr of Yemen was reported here today to be carrying out a major purge of "elements trying to sow dissension" in the Arab kingdom.

The first "outside" director to sit on the board of the J. C. Penney Company was elected by stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. He is Howard C. Sheperd, chairman and chief executive officer of the First National City Bank of New York since 1953.

YONKERS, May 26 -- Herman C. King's High Topper from Sweetser, Ind., driven by Howard Beissinger, scored a threequarters of a length victory over Gay Dancer in the Port Chester Pace before 20,387 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Mrs. Robert F. Wagner opened three sections of the central mall on Park Avenue yesterday for the Salute to the Seasons display. The sections are from Forty-ninth to Fifty-second Street.
" AS far as Cus D'Amato is concerned," said Bill Rosensohn, "I've had it, I'm fed up, right to here." He made a hand-across-throat motion.
GENEVA, May 26 -- Following are salient facts on the foreign ministers' conference at United Nations headquarters in Geneva:

New York City as a market for new cars not yet adequately exploited is being brought forcefully to the attention of the sales and advertising executives of Detroit's Big Four -- Ford, General Motors, Chrysler and American Motors.

A Mayor not having membership in the Board of Estimate would be freed from "the pressures and bargains of its caucus," a Professor of Public Administration and Government at Columbia University suggested yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Treasury and the Department of Justice today declined to support a bill to exempt from income tax the value of General Motors Corporation stock which might be distributed to E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. stockholders in an antitrust case.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., May 26 (AP) -- An early warning system to detect increases in radioactive fall-out is planned by the State Health Department.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., May 26 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson has not been using his right. He said he was afraid of knocking out his sparring partners, thus making them temporarily useless in his training program.
LONDON, May 26 (UPI) -Britons were assured last night that Chicago, which Queen Elizabeth will visit next month, is not the gangster-ridden city of the "Roaring Twenties."

CHICAGO, May 26 -- The transmission of the influenza virus can be checked by irradiating the upper air of rooms with ultraviolet rays, Dr. Ross L. McLean of Emory University School of Medicine in Atlanta, Ga., told the annual meeting of the National Tuberculosis Association today.

Several years ago, John E. McAuliffe discerned a lagging interest in women's professional golf. He decided to do something about it. Within a few weeks he had established a round-robin tournament and named it for his cable and conduit company.

MUNICH, Germany, May 26 (UPI) -- Tokyo and Innsbruck, Austria, were selected today as the sites for the 1964 summer and winter Olympic Games by an overwhelming vote of the International Olympic Committee delegates.
LONDON, May 26 -- Buckingham Palace denied tonight that Prince Philip had drenched two news photographers yesterday in a practical joke.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 26 -- The first effective session of the Transkeian Territorial Authority, hailed by the Nationalists as the first South African Bantustan Government, was opened in Umtata today by M. D. C. de Wet Nel, Minister of Bantu Development.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -The body of John Foster Dulles lay in state today in Washington National Cathedral.
TRENTON, May 26 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner may propose New Jersey's solution to the rapid transit problem at a special session of the Legislature this summer.

PARIS, May 26 -- Dulles wrote of Molotov: "I have seen in action all the great international statesmen of this century. * * * I have never seen such personal diplomatic skill at so high a degree of perfection as Mr. Molotov's." In January, 1956, I reminded Molotov of this expert opinion on his own abilities.
New security issues of two major steel companies will be placed on the market today by investment syndicates.
Earnings of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company for the three months ended April 30 were slightly below those for the like period of last year.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -Frank R. McGregor, a New Yorker who is a vice president of the Commodity Credit Corporation, was one of seven Department of Agriculture employes honored today for distinguished service in various branches of agriculture.
CALAIS, Me., May 26 -- The chances are that the three St. Croix River fishways needed to re-establish the Atlantic salmon run in this beautiful international stream will not be built this year.

The near-by cocoa positions declined yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, but the deferred months rose. The London market was weak, but did not fully reflect the 1-cent-apound limit decline registered in New York on Monday.

The 114th annual report of the Prison Association of New York tells an interesting story of activities in 1958 and the recommendations made to the Legislature last January. It also marks the forty-fifth anniversary of continuous service to the association by Edward R. Cass, who has been its General Secretary and administrative guide for the past thirty-seven years -a notable achievement in constancy and useful dedication.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 26 -- The trustees of Sarah Lawrence College today elected Harrison Tweed, a New York lawyer, to serve as president of the college until a permanent successor to Dr. Harold Taylor was chosen.

Nineteen local public housing authorities sold $104,760,000 of serial bonds yesterday to finance permanently low-rent projects backed by subsidy contracts of the Public Housing Administration. The bonds will come due from 1960 to 2000.

Three generations of Rockefellers are the subjects of a biographical study by William Manchester, which Little, Brown will publish June 8. It will be called "A Rockefeller Family Portrait From John D. to Nelson."

The line-up of thirty-three cars for the 500-mile race at Indianapolis on Saturday has been determined by qualifying speeds averaging 143.004 miles an hour. This is slightly less than last year's record of 143.445.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a $3,642,600,000 mutual security bill today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -President Eisenhower sent to Congress today agreements that would enable the United States to supply four Allied nations with the information and equipment needed to train their forces in the use of nuclear weapons.
The threatened jailing of two hospital strike leaders demonstrates anew the difficulties inherent in using injunctions and no-strike laws as instruments of industrial peace.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 26 -- A warning that the emancipation of Jews from ghetto life and their integration into a free society were a "new danger" to Jewish survival was sounded by the president of the World Zionist Organization today.

THIS summer American and Russian women will have a large-scale summit meeting of their own. Feminine curiosity will interrupt the "cold war" long enough for millions of Soviet citizens to get a close-up look at how average Americans live.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., May 26 (AP) -- Charles E. Goodell, Chautauqua County Republican chairman, was elected United States Representative from the Forty-third District tonight to succeed the late Daniel A. Reed.
MOSCOW, May 26 (AP) -Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev threatened today to set up missile bases in Albania if the United States puts rocket bases in Greece and Italy.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and city detectives arrested a 63-year-old Bronx man yesterday on charges of possessing $60,000 worth of silver fox skins that had been highjacked from a truck here last month.
Blood will be given today at the United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., 1412 Broadway, to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

The Times reported recently a statement by Francis W. H. Adams, Manhattan member of the Board of Education. The Public Education Association commends Mr. Adams for insisting that "there be a more thorough exploration of the re-allocations" of school funds to finance increases in teachers' salaries.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -A warm bath may prove the best protection against the accelerations of rocket travel, a symposium on space medicine was told here today.

Tolerance and moderation have won a signal victory over race hatred and rabble-rousing in -- of all places -- Little Rock, Ark., and by a popular vote at the polls. By the same token, Governor Faubus has suffered a major setback in his efforts to stem the inevitable: integration in the public schools.

The strike of nonprofessional workers in six New York hospitals has brought in its wake editorial denunciation of its impact on the sick, and court action by injunction plus pious expressions that these lowpaid, insecure and under-privileged workers, largely Puerto Rican and Negro (fertile ground for exploitation), should be helped in other ways.
LONDON, May 26 (AP) -Agents for the Timken Roller Bearing Company of Canton, Ohio, said today recent share purchases had given the company an 85 per cent holding in British Timken, Ltd.
A stock-manipulating scheme, with ex-convicts acting as agents in an international operation was disclosed yesterday by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Representative Overton Brooks, chairman of the House Space Committee, put his foot down today on plans by a Space subcommittee to go to Moscow for talks with Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.

Earnings of Sears, Roebuck Co. for the three months to April 30 were 25.3 per cent above those for the like period of 1958. Sales were up 12.7 per cent, the big mail order and store chain reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- The House approved today a four-year extension of the Government's power to renegotiate defense contracts and recapture excess profits. The roll-call vote was 378-7.

THE glamour girl of built-in lighting, the luminous ceiling, is being pinned up in more and more homes. And now that these ceilings are becoming prettier and less expensive, they may, like the once radical picture window, become a permanent part of th eAmerican background.
On Monday the New York Telephone Company will start measuring a caller's discomfort -- from the weather, that is.

Directors of the Celanese Corporation of America yesterday voted to distribute one share of common stock for every four shares held of record on June 25. The board also declared the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents, payable to common shareholders on June 25.

Angry mothers with their youngsters in hand protested in Lower Manhattan Court yesterday that the model agency operated by Harry Conover had failed to pay fees earned by their children for posing. The agency recently was denied a renewal of its license to operate because of non-payment of fees to models.
LONDON, May 27 -- That old picture of the ruminative, pipe-smoking Briton is beginning to fade.
ALGIERS, May 27 -- The French Army announced tonight that its forces entered Tunisia yesterday after being attacked by a nationalist rebel unit coming from there.
ALBANY, May 27 -- The first formal effort to block Joseph F. Carlino from becoming Assembly Speaker was made today.

CHICAGO, May 27 (UPI) -- Jesse Bowdry upset the lightheavyweight contender, Tony Anthony, tonight. Bowdry punished Anthony severely in nearly every round and won a one-sided ten-round decision in a televised fight.

LONDON, May 27 -- A columnist in The Daily Mirror, Britain's most widely read daily newspaper, vowed today that he would never drink again in a pub operated by the Watney brewing interests if Charles Clore gained control of the concern.

A fifteen-year study of hormone production and metabolism in the human body has reached a milestone, the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research reported yesterday in its twelfth progress report.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., May 27 -- Stockholders of the world's largest oil company heard an optimistic forecast on earnings at their annual meeting here today.

American Metal Climax, Inc., miners and refiners of copper, lead, uranium and other metals, leased nine floors in the American Building, 1270 Avenue of the Americas, at Fiftieth Street, from Rockefeller Center, Inc.

The Southern Railway announced yesterday it had concluded an agreement to buy the Interstate Railroad Company, an eighty-seven-mile carrier of soft coal in southwestern Virginia. The Interstate interchanges freight with the Southern Railway at Appalachia, Va., and at several other points with the Louisville and Nashville, the Norfolk and Western and the Clinchfield Railroads.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -Senator Harry F. Byrd urged today that the effectiveness of the final court order in the antitrust case against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. be delayed a year so Congress could consider tax relief.
The annual stockholder meeting of the H. L. Green Company was adjourned yesterday until June 17, pending a hearing in the Appellate Division scheduled for June 9.
