Dr. Wernher von Braun, the German-born rocket expert and space scientist, was awarded the Americanism Medal of the New Jersey chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, yesterday.

LONDON, May 27 -- Representatives of the Inter-Racial Friendship Coordinating Council called at the Home Office today to urge its promotion of a law to protect Britain's colored people from incitement to racial hatred.
Columbia University has begun a Chinese oral history project in which five key leaders of Nationalist China have begun tape-recording their recollections for future scholars.
YONKERS, May 27 -- A threesulky crack-up, which sent two drivers to the hospital, occurred in the third race at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

BERLIN, May 27 (UPI) -The seven-point plan advanced by Secretary of State Herter for an interim solution of the Berlin problem was pronounced "unacceptable and designed to draw the Western powers into military conflict" by Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- Sidney Poitier will co-star with Spencer Tracy in "The Devil at Four O'Clock," based on a novel by Max Catto.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -The Administration is urging Congress to permit Federal school aid to be used to buy Soviet scientific instruments for American schools.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A "vastly expanded" Federal cancer research program was urged today as a memorial to John Foster Dulles.

The Transport Workers Union retained the right yesterday to act as exclusive bargaining agent for all subway workers and for employes in the Manhattan and Brooklyn bus divisions of the Transit Authority.
HARTFORD, May 27 --Connecticut Democrats will take over control of county government on Oct. 1 for the first time in history.

We need another Harold Ross. Anyone who has to use the Long Island level at Penn Station is now bombarded with "background" music (which has never merited that adjective when I have heard it, though it may vary in volume; I don't linger to analyze).

A historical study of the first months of the Confederacy is given by Manly Wade Wellman in "They Took Their Stand." The story begins with the hanging of John Brown on Dec. 2, 1859, and ends with the first battle at Manassas on July 21, 1861.

As one who has consistently been critical of this city's mass transportation system and particularly of the rapid transit, I would like to give my support to your editorial of May 19 "City Transit's Good Job."
The director of the American College of Surgeons said yesterday that inadequately trained physicians were doing an increasing amount of surgery because every insured patient was a paying patient.

Flotations of new corporate securities closely reflect corporate plans. Yesterday the Securities and Exchange Commission reported from Washington that new stocks and bonds sold in the first quarter of this year totaled $2,300,000,000, about 5 per cent less than were sold in the preceding quarter.
A threatened strike against seven proprietary hospitals, which had been scheduled for "any time" after 7 A. M. today, was deferred yesterday as the city Labor Department initiated peace efforts.
Carlsberg of Copenhagen, one of the world's largest export braweries, soon will start its biggest advertising campaign in this country.
ALBANY, May 27 -- Further steps in the reorganization of the Republican State Committee were approved today by the party's high command.

The Wheatley Stable's Irish Jay had a bard job scoring an easy victory in the $17,600 Fashion Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park. The fleet daughter of Double Jay and Irish Witch created this paradox by lugging in often through the five-furlong sprint, yet winning the race by six lengths over B. A. Dario's Rose of Serro.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 27 -Bert T. Combs defeated today Gov. A. B. Chandler's close political friend, Harry Lee Waterfield, for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
BERLIN, May 27 (Reuters) -- The free world's press was warned here today to concentrate on news in depth as the only means of survival in the competitive battle with television.
The local law increasing to 5 per cent the city's 3 per cent tax on meals costing $1 or more was signed by Mayor Wagner yesterday. It will become effective on Monday.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., May 27 -- An increasing proportion of Long Island high school graduates will be unable to obtain a college education unless a major program of expanding public and private facilities is undertaken soon, State Controller Arthur Levitt said today.

The Times has informed its readers throughout the world that a children's story book in which a white rabbit marries a black rabbit has been withdrawn from the open shelves in the libraries of the State of Alabama as a result of segregationist protests.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- In all the pageantry of the funeral services for John Foster Dulles today, in all that was spoken from the pulpit in the Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul and at the graveside in Arlington, one word was the synthesis of the effort to which his entire public career was directed.

The nation's inventories of gasoline dropped 3,006,000 barrels to 203,610,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A week earlier they were 206,616,000 and a year ago 195,753,000.

Jewish farmers in the United States are "tenaciously holding on" to their land in spite of the continuing decrease in the number of farm operators through mechanization and amalgamation, the Jewish Agricultural Society reported yesterday.

Chicago borrowed $30,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance improvements in the city's water supply system. The money was raised by the sale of non-callable bonds secured by revenues and maturing serially from 1960 to 1984.
Members of the Riverside Church voted last night to call the Rev. James Gordon Gilkey Jr., pastor of a Congregational church in Chicago, to join the ministerial staff.

Governor Rockefeller, with the help of top members of his administration, answered questions on a wide range of state activities for an hour and fifteen minutes at a Citizens Union dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -There are often danger signals by which an oncoming serious heart attack can be identified, a Canadian physician said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A fourteen-man committee has been appointed to accelerate materials research and development to meet the needs of industrial progress and national defense.
A reorganization that will separate the "production" and sales of air transportation was announced yesterday by Charles S. Thomas, president of Trans World Airlines.
Sixteen contract bridge teams went into the third knockout round of the Eastern States teams-of-four championship last night at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

A need exists for variable annuities in the life insurance field but there could be "potentially serious abuses in their sales," Charles R. Howell, New Jersey Banking and Insurance Commissioner, said yesterday.

Virtually all main highways going north or west from upper Manhattan and the lower Bronx will lead to traffic chaos at peak travel periods this year, probably starting with this Memorial Day week-end.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 27 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's current visit to Albania took on increased military significance with the announcement that the Defense Minister of Communist China would arrive in Albania tomorrow.
The New York Philharmonic's tour of Western Europe and the Soviet Union may not take place this summer.
The first Soviet merchantman to call at the Port of New York in a decade is due here today.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 27 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today that the result of Monday's School Board recall election had not altered his policy of total resistance to desegregation.
THERE are still no silhouette revolutions in sight as the mad rush of the collections continues. Here is the picture that is emerging.
Maj. Gen. Edmond H. Leavey took leave of American corporate affairs yesterday.

PARIS, May 27 (UPI) -Neale Fraser and Roy Emerson of Australia's Davis Cup team gained the doubles semi-finals today at the French tennis championships. They scored a 6-3, 7-5, 6-8, 13-11 victory over Ronald Barnes and Carlos Fernandes of Brazil.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that the Government allow the nation's twelve trunk airlines a temporary across-the-board increase of $1 in all ticket prices.
The Julio Ramos murder case was given to a General Sessions Court jury of eleven men and one woman at 5 P. M. yesterday.

Alaska Juneau Gold Mining Company announced yesterday in Los Angeles postponement of its annual meeting to June 24 pending approval of a reorganization plan adjusting its assets. Accountants have stated that certain assets had been carried at values which were too high.

Bobby Fischer, the United States chess champion, defeated Andreas Duckstein of Austria in 22 moves in the seventh round of the jubilee tournament in Zurich, according to a report received through Swiss news sources lat night.

THE funeral service for John Foster Dulles at Arlington National Cemetery was covered by television with quiet dignity and restraint yesterday afternoon. The National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System used the same pictures but had separate commentaries.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 27 -A Lebanese light bomber was forced down by Israeli jets today. It was said to have been photographing Israeli border positions.
Construction of the Narrows Bridge, a project talked about for fifty years, will begin June 17.
The head of the country's third largest steel company asserted yesterday that the national economy could withstand a three-month steel strike this year without "depriving anyone of real necessities."

MILWAUKEE, May 27 (UPI) -- Don McMahon saved a victory for Warren Spahn tonight as the Milwaukee Braves beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 3. McMahon struck out Dick Schofield in the ninth inning to end the game with the tying run on second base.

The quiet on the Russian satellite front may very well have much more significance for the West than all the bartering over a table at Geneva. For if the experts are correct, the Russian missile lead will be next to overwhelming by the early part of 1961, and on the basis of the Communist mentality and Communist past performances it seems unlikely that they intend to sit down while we catch up.
MONTREAL, May 27 -- Deepwater shipping operations will have to be what seamen call "close hauled" to succeed on the St. Lawrence Seaway.
Broadway is beckoning Henry Ginsberg, independent Hollywood producer, whose last picture was the screen version of Edna Ferber's "Giant," which he made with George Stevens.
NEWARK, May 27 -- Mediators in the thirteen-day-old strike of electrical workers against the Public Service Electric and Gas Company took steps today to resume joint negotiations here.
HAVANA, May 27 -- Maj. Raul Castro and three other officers who had been missing in a huge swamp were rescued early today. None was injured.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 -- Windsor Castle, a big Canadian-bred gelding, won the puissance jumping at the Devon horse show tonight. It was the third straight class victory for the bay owned by Carl Miller Jr. of Battle Creek, Mich., and ridden by Max Bonham.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 27 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest of Joseph Frank Simonetti, a Birmingham business man, on charges of trying to transport the stolen $250,000 Krupp diamond from Las Vegas, Nev., to Newark, N. J.

Sales of the Grand Union Company for the first eleven weeks of the fiscal year ended on May 16, rose 34.2 per cent to $127,240,335 from $94,836,771 the year before. In reporting the figures to stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in East Paterson, N. J., Lansing P. Shield, president, said the rate of sales was "in excess of $600,000,000" a year for the first time in the company's 86year history.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -Premier' Khrushchev's remarks in Albania on Mr. Dulles distorted and misrepresented the views of the late Secretary of State, a State Department official said today.
RABAT, Morocco, May 27 -The Moroccan Government has published a royal law forbidding all radio transmissions in the country after the end of the year except those of the state radio.
CHICAGO, May 27 -- The possibility of mass immunization against tuberculosis by breathing BCG vaccine spray was suggested today.

Management of the International Railways of Central America defeated an attempt yesterday by a dissident stockholders' group to gain control of the company. The management's victory was secured by its voting of the powerful proxy of the United Fruit Company. United Fruit owns 240,100 of the carrier's 600,000 shares of voting stock.

LONDON, May 27 -- Mme. Nina Dmitriev, wife of the assistant naval attache at the Soviet Embassy here, asked the British Government today for permission to remain in Britain with her 5-year-old daughter.
LIMA, Peru, May 27 -- The dispute between the Peruvian Government and the oppositionist Popular Action party is sharpening.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -John Foster Dulles was buried with military honors today on a sunny hilltop in Arlington National Cemetery.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, testified today that the "bugging" of Bernard Goldfine's hotel room last year by a Congressional aide had been contrary to his instructions.
The Sanitation Department has decided to dismantle its canine comfort station at York Avenue and Ninety-second Street. Geraniums or no geraniums, the dogs didn't like it.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, May 27 -- When the constitutional status of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is reviewed in London next year, the word "boy" will be on the agenda.
WHEN South Africa barred Albert Luthuli yesterday from meetings throughout the country it chose a worthy foe. His inflexible ambition is to free the African people from white rule.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 -The practice of birth control was overwhelmingly approved here today by the United Presbyterian Church. It was the church's first action on the controversial issue since 1930, when it opposed the use of artificial means to limit family size.

AFTER a tour of eight major European cities in the last year, the exhibition entitled "The New American Painting" will open to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art. Eighty-one examples by seventeen artists are included.

The Pentagon's latest controversy, the Air Force's Bomarc missile versus the Army's Nike-Hercules, impinges on three issues that are far more important than the technical merits of the missiles themselves.
VIENNA, May 27 (Reuters) -- A last-minute breeze blew a Czechoslovak glider pilot to freedom in Austria after ill winds had stymied his escape for four hours, Austrian authorities revealed today.
ALTHOUGH beef Stroganoff and borscht are the best known of Russian dishes, one of the simplest yet most delicious of foods originated in that country goes by the unusual name of coulibiac.
Pep pills may improve the performance of athletes by as much as 4 per cent under some conditions, the American Medical Association reported here yesterday.
Ray Robinson, the beleaguered middleweight champion, is waiting now -- as he has so many times after a fight -- for the decision.
PARIS, May 27 -- The French Government approved three bills today that appeared to further Algeria's integration with France.
The successful marketing of the $75,000,000 Consolidated Edison Company mortgage bonds reinforced the improved sentiment that has prevailed in the bond market since the middle of the month.
Walt Disney's "Darby O'Gill and the Little People," a feature -length comedy-fantasy in color, has been scheduled for an early summer premiere at the Trans-Lux Normandie Theatre.
LONDON, May 27 -- An American museum is being established in Britain by the Halcyon Foundation of New York.

Gains for electronics, motion picture, machine tool and farm equipment stocks marked yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Other groups were mixed but the market as a whole posted a good gain for the day.

Using Judge Tilzer's opinion as a base, your May 23 editorial throws responsibility for the strike on hospital employes. Judge Tilzer's statement does not go to the root of this matter. His opinion deals with an important and obvious part-impaired service for the sick.
HAROLD ROSS, the Mr. Chips-on-BothShoulders editor of The New Yorker, developed many of the best writers of his day and created one great character. That character was Harold Ross.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Andrei A. Gromyko arrived in Washington today full of praise for John Foster Dulles.
LONDON, May 27 -- Industrial shares moved up today stimulated by the news of a fall in unemployment last month.
The eleventh annual Debutante Ball of the New York Junior League will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 25.

Steel is being consumed faster than had been generally expected, brightening the business outlook for the third quarter if there should be no widespread steel strike, executives of several major steel companies reported yesterday.

Premier Khrushchev's visit to tiny Albania has not been under way very long, but already he has used the occasion for his favorite sport, rocket rattling. His threat to set up Soviet rocket bases in Albania if Greece or Italy gets United States rocket bases is, of course, what had been expected. Nevertheless this threat has its mystifying aspects.

An investor has purchased the five-story apartment house for thirty-four families at 15 East Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx, from the G. Z. Realty Company. The property, 75 by 100 feet, was sold for cash over mortgages of $150,000. Leonard, Levites Schiller were the brokers.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 27 -- Marymount College, with a graduating class of 221 young women this year, conferred degrees on 120 at the campus here today and will confer 101 tomorrow in New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -A program to preserve the benefits of free-enterprise medicine and insure "that everyone gets all the medical service he needs" was offered today to the National Conference on Social Welfare.
" Continental Classroom," the television series offering a college course in physics, will be expanded next fall to include a course in modern chemistry.
Investment bankers headed by White, Weld Co. are offering publicly 120,000 shares of the capital stock of PackardBell Electronics Corporation, Los Angeles, Calif.
The nation will embark tomorrow on the year's first long holiday week-end amid stern warnings from safety officials and the police that death and injury await the careless.
A union representative was indicted yesterday by a Kings County rackets grand jury on charges of attempted assault and coercion in the pinball machine field.

CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -Chicago's Early Wynn hurled his 256th major league victory today, a fine five-hitter, for a 5-1 decision over the first-place Cleveland Indians. The season's seventh victory for the 39-yearold White Sox hurler left the Indians only one game ahead of the runner-up White Sox.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 27 -- The Bomarc B, advanced version of the Air Force's air-defense missile, had its first test flight today.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., May 27 -- A hundred merchants here have told the city that they will help pay off a bond issue now being paid with parking meter receipts if the city will remove the meters in the shopping district.
George A. Brenner, former Westchester County judge, pleaded not guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court to two indictments charging him with grand larceny and forgery.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 27 -- John A. Britting, former State Assemblyman, and Walter Salomon, a real-estate speculator, were found guilty of conspiracy in a "land-grab" trial here today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 27 -- Albert Luthuli, president general of the African National Congress, has been banned by Justice Minister Charles R. Swart from attending any meetings or gatherings anywhere in South Africa for five years.
NEW DELHI, May 27 -- Official quarters here admitted concern today over the situation in Laos. Consultations were said to be going on with the signatories of the Geneva armistice agreements.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -A salary of $12,000 a year for a teacher at each of six independent secondary schools was made possible today as the Donner Foundation announced grants totaling $1,800,000.
The Police Department insisted yesterday that stamps and coins sold to collectors were "used" items and that sellers must therefore have licenses as secondhand dealers.
MOSCOW, May 27 -- Diplomats in Moscow studying yesterday's speech by Premier Khrushchev in Albania seemed impressed by what appeared to be his terms of conciliation and reasonableness.
The second Columbia Journalism Award for "singular journalistic performance in the public interest," will be presented tomorrow in a ceremony at Columbia University.

The question, "What is a Silky Terrier?" was answered in these pages almost three weeks ago when the American Kennel Club announced that it had accepted the toy breed from Australia into its official family. There remained questions about who was behind the breed and other details.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -Moderates on the Education and Labor Committee said today they were determined to get a labor reform bill before the House of Representatives this session.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today bills to provide money during the fiscal year starting July 1 for the office of the President, the State and Justice Departments and the Federal courts.
Nearly 20,000 commuters were late to work yesterday as a result of brake failure on a New Haven Railroad train in the morning rush.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- The Navy urged Congress today to appropriate funds to build another conventionally powered aircraft carrier. This is contrary to the advice of Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, who has said such a step would be "stupid."

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the country's biggest, reported yesterday that it cleared $4,049,434 in April, against a deficit of $4,727,327 in the 1958 month. The profit in the month cut the deficit for the first four months of 1959 to $2,264,466. In the 1958 period the road had a deficit of $19,626,948.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., May 27 -- Workmen installing a fence in the middle of the hazardous Cross County Parkway here to prevent car accidents touched off an accident of their own today.

Speculator and dealer buying of hide futures on the Commodity Exchange of New York was influenced by a rise of 1 to 2 cents a pound in the price of actuals in Chicago. Scale-up profit-taking and new short selling supplied the contracts. Prices rose 25 to 75 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on eight-five lots, equaling the third largest volume of the year.

MONTREAL, May 27 -- Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, lashed out today at American governmental "indifference" to the interests of seamen and the welfare of the merchant marine.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 27 (Reuters) -- The Deutsch Golddiskontbank, suspended by the Allies in 1945, will be liquidated this summer, it was stated here today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 7 to 13 points yesterday in moderate trading.
LOS ANGELES, May 27 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted a Los Angeles Teamsters Union local and four union members on charges of conspiring to monopolize the grease rendering business here.

ST. GEORGE, N. B., May 27 -- Small-mouth black bass in Digdeguash Lake have not not yet come to their senses because the water is still too cold, according to the best opinion available at the moment.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- Japan's Foreign Minister, Ailchiro Fujiyama, said today the United States had agreed to consult Japan before using American forces based in his country in any Far Eastern war zones.

Electric power plants of the future may have ponds beside their steam generators as heat sources rather than coal, oil or gas furnaces. This was reported yesterday to 100 scientists and engineers attending a two-day symposium on solar energy here.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), May 27 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion appealed tonight to members of B'nai B'rith, world Jewish service organization, to link themselves closer to Israel, which he said was the only force that could unify the Jews of the world.

GENEVA, May 27 -- The pick and shovel brigade of the foreign ministers' conference today dug into the mountain of material erected by their chiefs in the last sixteen days. If the diplomats sing as they work, which is possible but not probable, they might choose the World War I tune: "Oh boy, oh joy, where do we go from here?" The answer in the song was "anywhere from Harlem to a Jersey City pier."

A ninety-nine-year leasehold on property at 1739-45 Broadway, 232 West Fifty-sixth Street and 241 West Fifty-fifth Street has been sold by the estate of T. Victor Searing. J. P. and L. A. Kissling were the brokers.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 27 -Gov. Orville L. Freeman advised Minnesota's Attorney General today to ignore a State Supreme Court order on the ground that it infringed upon the independence of the Executive Branch of Government.

ST. GEORGE, N. B., May 27 -- Small-mouth black bass in Digdeguash Lake have not not yet come to their senses because the water is still too cold, according to the best opinion available at the moment.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- Japan's Foreign Minister, Ailchiro Fujiyama, said today the United States had agreed to consult Japan before using American forces based in his country in any Far Eastern war zones.

Electric power plants of the future may have ponds beside their steam generators as heat sources rather than coal, oil or gas furnaces. This was reported yesterday to 100 scientists and engineers attending a two-day symposium on solar energy here.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -President Eisenhower will confer tomorrow with the Big Four foreign ministers, who have been negotiating on Germany and Berlin at Geneva.
ALBANY, May 27 (AP) -Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation won permission today to raise its rates by $7,500,000 a year, which means an increase of 25 to 39 cents a month for most customers.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 27 -Despite warnings by Chinese Nationalist leaders that renewed Communist attacks could be expected this week against the offshore islands and possibly Taiwan itself, the area has remained relatively quiet.

SANDWICH, England, May 27 (UPI) -- Five Americans made their way into the round of sixteen in the British amateur golf championship today. But Charley Coe, the United States champion, was not among them.
For a club that had absorbed a painful drubbing only the night before, the Yankees revealed surprising bounce at the Stadium yesterday.

At a moment when East and West confront each other in Geneva in a diplomatic showdown of potentially momentous consequences Congress is likewise approaching a showdown on one of our principal weapons in this contest -the mutual security program. This program, for which President Eisenhower has asked $3,930,000,000 for the coming fiscal year, is reaching the end of Congressional committee action and will have to be voted upon by Senate and House next month.

It is no fault of the Interstate Commerce Commission that its 103-page report on the problem of railroad passenger deficits leaves the reader with a sense of frustration and hopelessness. The commission has recommended many of the familiar "remedies" for the situation, but there is little evidence that all of them put together would come close to closing the passenger gap.

Listening to Ted Williams THE most feared .163 hitter in baseball, Theodore Samuel Williams, was in the dugout in full uniform even before the other members of the Red Sox entourage had reached the Yankee Stadium yesterday. He smiled warmly in greeting.

MILWAUKEE, May 27 (AP) -- Praise for the unparalleled twelve perfect innings pitched last night by Harvey Haddix mounted today. And as the praise mounted, the dust settled around the thirteenth inning in which Milwaukee rose to send the Pittsburgh left-hander to defeat.
Don Carter and his wife, Laverne, made it a family victory last night at Madison Square Garden by winning top honors in the one-day tournament of bowling champions.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 27 -- President Mario Echandi Jimenez of Costa Rica seems worried that Nicaraguan exiles may upset his policy of non-interference.
MOSCOW, May 27 -- What Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has called "angels of reconciliation" have descended on the strife-torn Soviet literary battleground.
Dolores Gray, leading lady in the Broadway musical "Destry Rides Again," soothed a capacity matinee audience yesterday when flames engulfed a stage curtain. She did it by singing a love ballad.
BUENOS AIRES, May 27 -Army troops in green field uniforms joined the police patrolling the financial district here today as the national bank strike entered its seventh week with mounting violence.
The monkey house at the Bronx Zoo went back into operation after nine years yesterday and the monkeys never had it so good.
CHICAGO, May 27 -- Roosevelt University was rededicated tonight to honor Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as well as her late husband.
Many frozen-food plants are seriously deficient in sanitary facilities and methods, a Federal official warned here yesterday.
BERLIN, May 27 -- West Berlin would be a "lemon waiting to be squeezed" if the Soviet plan of making it a militarized free city had gone into effect today, according to Mayor Willy Brandt.
ROME, May 27 -- Pope John XXIII may change his plan to perform the marriage ceremony for Prince Albert, brother of King Baudouin of the Belgians, to Princess Paola Ruffo di Calabria of Rome.

TRIESTE, Italy, May 27 (Reuters) -- Seventy-year-old Giovanni Massarelli of Trieste wrote to President Eisenhower two months ago that he would like to see his granddaughter, born of the marriage of a United States Air Force sergeant, Frank Roman, to the Trieste man's daughter, Ida. The Roman family then was stationed in Texas.
Baudouin I, King of the Belgians, arrived here last evening in the final stage of a twentyday visit to the United States. The 28-year-old King will stay in New York City until Saturday morning.

The proposed acquisition of the assets of the Booth-Kelly Lumber Company, Springfield, Ore., by the United States Plywood Corporation would involve about $80,000,000 in cash, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, May 28 -- The right of the State Education Commissioner to forbid the dismissal of New York City school-teachers who refuse to inform on their fellows with respect to past Communist activity was upheld by the Court of Appeals today.
PARIS, May 28 -- At the age of 53, Josephine Baker, American-born star of French music halls for more than thirty years, made a much-applauded return to the footlights last night.

A PORTRAIT of a ruthless man and ambitious labor-union leader who condones racketeering to achieve his ends was the theme of Rod Serling's play, "The Rank and File," seen last night on "Playhouse 90" on Channel 2.
TRIVANDRUM, India, May 28 (AP) -- A Gandhi-style non-violent campaign against the Communist Government of Kerala State was announced today.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, May 28 (AP) -- The Dominican Military Intelligence Service said today that former President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba plans to leave here secretly and land in the United States in some spectacular way to win political asylum there.
Salary increases ranging from $300 to $600 were proposed last night for the 2,586 staff members of the city's municipal colleges.
Stocks plodded upward to new historic highs yesterday but finished the day with unimpressive gains.
There have been many criticisms of the slum clearance program in New York City.

Yesterday was one of the most uneventful business days in the bond market in months. Yet in one way -- in its indifference to the rise of the Federal Reserve System discount rate -- the lackadaisical session represented a milestone in the postwar history of the bond market.
LONDON, May 28 -- Prices continued to surge ahead today in brisk trading.
A preliminary plan for redeveloping a twenty-block section of the upper West Side was submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate, which referred it to the City Planning Commission for review.
DEVON, Pa., May 28 -- Jayber, a former hunter owned and ridden by H. C. (Jiggs) Baldwin 3d, topped both open jumper events at the Devon Horse Show tonight.

Fay A. LeFevre, a director of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company, sold 22,500 common shares on May 15, according to the New York Stock Exchange. On that same day, Cyrus S. Eaton Jr., also a director, sold 22,500 shares.
Following are salient facts on the foreign ministers' conference at United Nations headquarters in Geneva: \
The City of New York stands to collect more than $5,000,000 over the next half century by not building a pier at Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn.

YONKERS, May 28 -- Speedy Pick was the solid pick of most of the 23,067 punters at Yonkers Raceway tonight. With the original field of a half-dozen free-for-all pacers reduced to five by the late scratch of Belle Acton, Speedy Pick was the 3-to-5 favorite.
The United Transit Employes Council, which lost a union representation election Wednesday to the Transport Workers Union, pledged yesterday to continue in existence.
Oil refiners could save $35,000,000 a year by more careful planning of capital improvements, an oil company purchasing agent said here yesterday.

Net income of the Royal Dutch-Shell group of companies in the first quarter was reported yesterday at $104,009,000, compared with $103,155,000 for the 1958 period. This was after providing $118,308,000 for taxes this year and $87,531,000, a year ago. Sales and operating income increased to $1,657,020,000, from $1,582,815,000.
SHREWSBURY, N. J., May 28 -- A $600,000 Federal and state project planned for this borough was resoundingly attacked by residents last night.

The New York Rangers returned yesterday from a four-week hockey tour of six European countries. The team which included some Chicago Black Hawk players, came directly from Geneva. The Swissair plane carrying the athletes landed at International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at noon.
SINGAPORE, May 28 -- The leader of the People's Action party asserted tonight that his party was "non-Communist."
MASSENA, N. Y., May 28 -- Anyone skeptical about the future of the St. Lawrence Seaway should talk to Martin W. Oettershagen, who helped plan and build it.

WARSAW, May 28 (AP) -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, his voice muffled by a Communist ban on loudspeakers, told a huge Corpus Christi procession today that recent administrative moves against the Church were "an insult to our religious feelings."
A leading publisher said yesterday that the present slump in the magazine industry could be corrected by reducing circulation and charging higher subscription rates.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate today scheduled formal debate next week on the nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce.
John Foster Dulles left specific bequests totaling $235,000 in a will filed for probate yesterday in Surrogates Court.
LONDON, May 28 -- Britain's coal production last year was the lowest in eight years.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Dr. Frederick J. Stare, Professor of Nutrition at Harvard University, asked Congress today for two new heart research items -- an $11,000,000 monkey colony and $15,000,000 for centers of cardiovascular research.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- Feed grains and soybeans were under general selling pressure today on the Board of Trade. When it seemed those contracts were on the verge of breaking through an accumulation of stop-loss selling orders, they attracted a sufficient volume of demand to recover about half the losses.
Another vice president has resigned from the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Dr. John Howard Morrow, North Carolina Negro educator, to be the first United States Ambassador to the new African Republic of Guinea.

CINCINNATI, May 28 (AP) -- The Crosley Division of the] Avco Corporation announce'd today it had received.a $21,500,-] 000 contract from .the Govern-I ment for radar equipment. It[ will be a part Of the air defense] Icommand aircraft data .acqulsi-] {Ion' n'etw6rlc.'
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) announced today a one-point reduction in its buying prices for mortgages in the secondary market.
CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A promising new method of cancer treatment that has just gone into use at one of London's biggest hospitals will soon be available here, one of its developers disclosed yesterday.

The second Columbia Journalism Award for "singular journalistic performance in the public interest" will be presented today to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher and chairman of the board of The New York Times.

The Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation announced yesterday that it would grant a total of $1,650,000 to eleven private medical schools to strengthen their teaching and research staffs "particularly in the basic medical sciences." No other condition was attached to the grants.
GENEVA, May 28 -- The West's negotiations with the Soviet Union are scheduled to resume in secret here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr., the chief architect of the nation's scientific programs for the last eighteen months, resigned today as President Eisenhower's Special Assistant for Science and Technology.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 28 -- A few years ago a lanky Harvard professor sought permission from the suburban Lincoln to dynamite some stumps on his twenty acres. The authorities wondered what evidence he could show that he knew anything about explosives.

Mrs. Michael G. Walsh's Independence jumped clean and ran fast yesterday to win the forty-third Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park. High weight of 162 pounds meant little to this full brother of Bold Ruler, for in scoring by six lengths he broke the track record in the event of about two miles and a half.
MILWAUKEE, May 28 (UPI) -- Bob Friend of the Pittsburgh Pirates pitched his first victory of the season today -- a four-hit, 3-0 shutout of the Milwaukee Braves. He had lost seven decisions.
Elliot E. Cohen, editor of Commentary magazine, was found dead last night with a plastic bag over his head. He was 60 years old.

The State Commission of Investigation yesterday offered evidence that the Harness Racing Commissioner and his subordinates had accepted $31,075.55 worth of free liquor and food from operators of the Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways in the last three years.

In a letter published in The Times of April 27 on the subject of "fair trade" laws Herbert Sontag referred to "fair trade" as unfair pricing. I am in disagreement, for those states which passed "fair trade" laws have made it a basic requirement that the merchandise which is priced by the manufacturer under the aegis of "fair trade" "must be in free and open competition with similar articles of the same general price class."
Robert Moses complained yesterday that he had been badly miscast.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Gov. James P. Coleman of Mississippi said today that he would not convene a grand jury in the Mack Charles Parker lynching case before next November because the Mississippi Supreme Court would not recognize any indictments a special jury returned.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- The General Accounting Office criticized the Air Force today for permitting "overestimates" of $500,700 on two 1956 contracts with a New York concern.

The Panama conference, now ended, of the Economic Commission for Latin America (ECLA), a United Nations subsidiary, made some progress toward the goal of a common market. Just to say that is a great deal. No one thought or hoped that a Latin-American common market would be created this year.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Lyndon B. Johnson finally turned on Senator William Proxmire today.
Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported sharp gains in operating revenues and net income yesterday for four and twelve months ended April 30. The utility serves the Chicago area.
The elusive Cus D'Amato, manager of the world heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, said yesterday that his fighter would defend against Ingemar Johansson on June 25 at Yankee Stadium as scheduled.

Five local bills designed to add $90,000,000 to the city's annual revenue from special taxes were assailed by business and civic groups yesterday at a day-long public hearing before the Finance Committee of the City Council.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A new pattern of relationships between Iraq and the United Arab Republic and also between those countries and the Soviet Union and the West seems to be emerging in the Middle East.

When the definitive history of man's conquest of space comes to be written a chapter will undoubtedly be devoted to the animals that paved the way. Laika, the dog that rode a sputnik in orbit around the world, will have an honored place and so too will Able and Baker, the two monkeys whose 1,700-mile ride in fifteen minutes in a Jupiter rocket's nose cone now excites our imagination.

Eighty-six of the Greater New York Fund's voluntary health, medical and welfare agencies have their principal offices in Brooklyn. Twelve others have district offices there, twenty-six also serve other boroughs, and Brooklyn residents have the use of 216 agencies serving the entire city.
The Public Service Commission granted permission to the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday to eliminate conjunctional (combined) billing gradually over five years beginning Monday.

Sighs of relief and satisfaction at a grinding task well done were heaved at 12:01 this morning by 500 employes of American Telephone and Telegraph Company and by 134 workers in the New York Post Office.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 685,745 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
MILAN, Italy, May 28 (UPI) -- Boris Pasternak, Russian author, said in an interview published here today that the world perhaps should be run by artists.
NEWARK, May 28 -- "Some progress" was reported today in negotiations in the two-week strike at the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

Four persons were injured in an automobile wreck yesterday morning, including John Kean Roosevelt, 69 years old, a cousin of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, and his wife, Elsie. The accident occurred on the Belt Parkway, Bayside, Queens, and involved five cars.
LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- Following is a list of the principal goods from dollar sources whose import quotas were affected by a ruling by Britain today:

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A leading international economist warned today the time had arrived to correct a persistent deficit in the United States balance of payments before the dollar became a "weak" currency.

Anent your editorial of May 26 on "Our Costly Parades," the Commerce and Industry Association has stanchly advocated for many years that parades in New York City, and particularly on Fifth Avenue, should be restricted either to non-business days or to the stretch of that thoroughfare north of Fifty-ninth Street.

Average borrowings by member banks dropped $195,000,000 to $658,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves dropped $269,000,000 to $336,000,000 from a revised figure of $605,000,000 the week before.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- An insurance executive said today that his concern had been subjected to harassing litigation for fifteen years because it tried to set its own prices for insurance coverage.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Big Four foreign ministers took their troubles above the clouds today in the first major airborne international conference in diplomatic history.

Dealer buying, light speculator short covering and stop-loss purchasing raised hide quotations 10 to 35 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Volume was 135 lots (40,000 pounds to a lot) the largest since March 26, 1957.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 9 points down yesterday.
LONDON, May 28 -- The Mermaid Theatre, the City of London's first in 250 years and the first for Greater London in about thirty, opened tonight with a musical version of an eighteenth-century satire.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The nature of the public service of Dr. James R. Killian Jr. has obscured the vast proportions and the vital qualities of the contribution he made to the defense of the non-Communist world and to the elevation of science and technology to the top level of Government.
Britain has come a long way since she was persuaded in 1947 to undertake her ill-fated "break for freedom" with respect to convertibility of sterling.

The shopping center occupying the blockfront on Fresh Meadow Lane between Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth Avenues in Jamaica Estates North, Queens has been sold by the Denario Company. Built ten years ago, it fronts 280 feet on Fresh Meadow Lane.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 -- Unwed mothers among adolescents are apparently increasing, the annual forum of the National Conference of Social Welfare was told today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Following are the texts of letters exchanged between President Eisenhower and Dr. James R. Killian, his Special Assistant for Science and Technology, whose resignation was announced today:

LIMA, Peru, May 28 -- Almost the entire high command of the Popular Action party, including Fernando Belaunde Terry, was arrested today as the Peruvian Government struck back at the Opposition's challenge to its authority.

A sculpture by Seymour Lipton, the American artist, and $25,000 have been awarded to Yuncken, Freeman Brothers, Griffiths Simpson, Australian architects, for their design of the Sidney Myer Music Bowl in Melbourne.

The theatre committee of the Youth Consultation Service has announced that it has arranged for the Dec. 1 performance of "The Sound of Music" to be its annual benefit. The Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, starring Mary Martin, is expected to open on Nov. 12 at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre.

WORKING women who have watched carefully hoarded shopping time tick away in search for sales help will be happy to know that one store at least has put an end to this. With the official start of Stern's Career Club, busy women can shop by appointment and make every minute count.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 28 -- The United States urged the United Nations today to consider what system of international law might be necessary to control the use of outer space.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The successful space journey of the two monkeys in the nose cone of a Jupiter ballistic missile marks another milestone in the exploration of space, which began nearly two years ago.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee began hearings today on a proposed Constitutional amendment to protect the appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 -- Senator Stuart Symington began sniffing California's political air today. The Missouri Democrat plans a tight schedule for six days that will take him from Sacramento south almost to the Mexican border.

If there is anything people like less than paying taxes, it is to pay higher taxes or new taxes. The Wagner administration has been learning this painfully again, in recent days, as the bills to raise revenues for the Mayor's 1959-60 executive budget of $2,174,946,957 are pushed through the legislative process over the anguished protest of those most directly affected.
GREEN vegetables are one of the most nutritious bounties of summer. Among the profusion, but often completely over-looked in this country, is sorrel.

SANDWICH, England, May 28 (UPI) -- Three Americans -- William Hyndman 3d, Deane Beman and Lieut. Bob Magee -- gained the semi-finals of the British Amateur golf championship today, along with an Englishman.

The Federal Reserve Board approved yesterday an increase from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent in the lending (discount) rate to member banks in the New York, Chicago, St. Louis, Minneapolis and Dallas districts. The new rate is effective today.

The Oct. 27 performance of "The Gang's All Here" has been chosen by the New York Committee of the Menninger Foundation in Topeka, Kan., for its annual theatre benefit. The play, starring Melvyn Douglas, is scheduled to open at the Ambassador Theatre on Oct. 1.
The fifteen-day jail sentences imposed on two union leaders for violating an anti-strike injunction in the hospital walkout were stayed yesterday in the Appellate Division.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Senator John F. Kennedy called on the Democratic party "to determine today what we are going to do in 1961."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 28 (Reuters) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev urged Greece today to detach herself from the Atlantic alliance and become a neutral country.
"THE YOUNG AND BEAUTIFUL," the Sally Benson comedy based on some short stories by F. Scott Fitzgerald, still weaves a magic spell over the theatregoer four years after it was done on Broadway.

LONDON, May 28 -- Mme. Nina Dmitriev, a Soviet diplomat's wife, has asked asylum here. She waited today with her 5-year-old daughter, Lena, at a guarded hideout while the Home Office considered her appeal.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- The figures that are most exciting in the motion-picture industry are anatomical. But the figures that are generally most important are statistical.
The Atlantic Refining Company is closing the gap between its refining needs and its crude oil production as result of new discoveries in Venezuela, Henderson Supplee Jr., president, said yesterday.

The Geneva conference of foreign ministers is resuming work after a "semi-summit" meeting at the White House in Washington at which President Eisenhower again put it on notice of his condition for attending a full summit meeting of the heads of government. The condition is that Geneva must achieve the "measure of progress" that would make a summit meeting both "desirable and useful."
A new sharpening of battle lines yesterday indicated that both sides had virtually abandoned hope of averting a national steel strike June 30.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Agriculture Department has refused to subsidize the egg market.
CAPE MAY, N. J., May 28 -- Just two miles west of this historic village is a stretch of barren sand, liberally sprinkled with polychromatic stones.
RYE, N. Y., May 28 -- Governor Rockefeller told the Westchester County Association tonight that the state must act promptly to meet its outdoor recreational needs.
The nation's leading solar technologists, impressed by advances made in research laboratories toward harnessing the sun's power, decided yesterday to hold another world symposium.

Two favored contract bridge teams trailed at the halfway mark of last night's knockout play in the Reisinger Cup team-of-four championship of the annual Eastern States Championships. The annual tourney is being held here at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.
HARTFORD, May 28 (UPI) -- The state police raided forty-four business establishments in Connecticut today and smashed a pinball machine ring.
SINGAPORE, May 28 (Reuters) -- Efforts to form a united front against the powerful left-wing People's Action party for Saturday's general election failed today.

The Southern Electric Generating Company, an affiliate of The Southern Company, Atlanta, Ga., sold $25,000,000 of long-term first mortgage bonds yesterday to a banking syndicate jointly managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 28 -- B'nai B'rith established today an international council to expand the world-wide scope of its service activities.
A "CHEMICALS CHEST" to keep dangerous household products away from inquisitive children was recommended yesterday for every family.
Alfredo Cardinal Ottaviani, Pro Secretary of the Supreme Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office at the Vatican, arrived yesterday for a month's visit in the United States.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, May 28 -- The Paramount Chief of Barotseland will go to London next year to fight against any change in the status of his country favorable to white settler interests.
New Yorkers streamed out of the city last night by train, airplane and auto as the Memorial Day week-end, the first warm weather holiday week-end of the season, got under way.

CLEVELAND, May 28 (AP) -- The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service entered today the deadlocked contract negotiations between the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers Union. More than 18,000 workers in eight cities have been on strike since April 16.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The secrecy curtain was withdrawn slightly tonight from a project that the Army hopes will give the United States its version of the flying saucer.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- A $50,000 ceiling on total farm price supports for any one farm or farmer was recommended to the Senate today by its Appropriations Committee.

All Americans can share the "very sincere regret" that President Eisenhower voiced yesterday in accepting the resignation of Dr. James R. Killian Jr. as his Special Assistant for Science and Technology. In his year and a half in that office Dr. Killian worked quietly but effectively to improve the organization of the nation's research effort and to increase our resources, both human and material, for further progress in science and technology.

SIX years ago Harvey Haddix was pitching for the Cardinals against the Phillies when Richie Ashburn batted in the ninth inning. Del Rice, the catcher, signaled for a slider. The little left-hander shook him off. He wanted a curve. So he threw a curve and Ashburn singled cleanly to right.
LONDON, May 28 -- Britain announced today a relaxation of curbs on imports of goods that must be paid for in dollars.
MADRID, May 28 (UPI) -- The Spanish Government has arrested at least eleven opposition Socialist leaders in a new move against illegal political parties, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- This was the day of the White House garden party for 700 aged and blind persons in homes here.
Hoyt Wilhelm tied the Yankees in knots with his baffling knuckleball delivery last night for the third time this season.

The Soviet Union's leading mathematical economist, whose theories had been ignored for two decades, has made a scathing attack on that country's traditional Marxist economists, charging that they have contributed virtually nothing of value since the Bolshevik Revolution.
In April the Union Pacific Railroad had revenues of $42,080,427, compared with $37,034,783 a year ago. Net income was $4,948,285, against $4,206,461 in April, 1958.
MUNICH, Germany, May 28 -- The International Olympic Committee expelled Nationalist China from the Olympic movement today and opened the door for the readmission of Communist China.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- Dr. Louis F. Bishop Jr., Assistant Clinical Professor of Medicine at New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, has been named president-elect of the American College of Cardiology.

A tall, open-faced man sauntered into the ticket office of William P. Rosensohn Enterprises at the Astor Hotel yesterday morning. He pulled an untidy roll of big bills from his pocket and through the 4 1/2-inch opening in the ticket window murmured:
FERNAND LAFITTE, a 39-year - old Frenchman, can tell a woman's nationality by her bathing suit and the way she looks in it.
Penn State is a solid favorite to capture team honors in the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America's eighty-third annual outdoor track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits told the Senate today that the plan of a Democratic colleague for tapering off grants of economic aid "could sound the death-knell for the entire Mutual Security Program."

BUENOS AIRES, May 28 -- More than 300 labor leaders and workers were in military and civil jails today following disturbances and clashes with the police here, in Cordoba and in the rail center of Junin.

A half dozen disciples of the Actors Studio soon will be on their way to the Gian Carlo Menotti festival at Spoleto, Italy. Those chosen are Vivian Nathan, Rosemary Murphy, Arthur Storch, Lou Antonio, Gene Saks and Patrick O'Neal.

While the Federal Reserve system raised the discount rate from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent, the Bank of Canada's interest rate moved downward for the first time in ten weeks. It now stands at 5.15 per cent, compared with a record of 5.30 per cent in the last two weeks.
WITH the fifth consecutive showing of couturier-designed, ready-to-wear clothes last week, there is every indication that business is hitting its seasonal stride.

The city of St. Louis, Mo., borrowed $7,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance improvements in its water supply system. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds secured by water revenues.

Closing the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Mondays is right in line with the present City Administration's curtailment of other free cultural opportunities: the abolition of Shakespearean plays in Central Park and the unconscionably long closing of branch libraries under the guise of "rehabilitation," a process which can be completed in three months but has been extended to more than twenty-four months (e. g. the Ninety-sixth Street branch).
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Balancing the Federal budget by increasing taxes on "frivolities that injure health" was proposed to a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today by a professor of medicine.

MINEOLA, L. I., Friday, May 29 -- John J. O'Rourke, vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was arrested last night on indictments accusing him and fourteen others of juke box racketeering in Nassau County.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The United States officially welcomed the British announcement today.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks declined $5,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a drop of $66,000,000 in the like week a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The House Appropriations Committee challenged President Eisenhower's defense planning today. It recommended more money for big missile programs than the President had requested and withheld money on other military projects.
Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Nathan Jr. yesterday upheld the constitutionality of a law governing the qualifications of psychologists.
PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered a hearing June 8 on a charge of unfair labor practices against Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

Two four-story buildings containing forty-three apartments at 250 to 260 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, were sold by the Forz Realty Company for cash over mortgages. The property is 125 by 130 feet and is assessed at $151,000. It was bought by an investing client of Irving Bira, the broker in the sale in cooperation with the Elm Realty Company.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today ruled that gems used in watches must contact a moving part at a point of wear in order to be advertised as jewels.

LONDON, May 28 -- The Cunard Steamship Company has decided against using nuclear power in the proposed liner to replace the Queen Mary. The company is still considering nuclear engines for eventual replacement of the Queen Elizabeth.
GLYNDEBOURNE, England, May 28 -- In this rustic setting of rare beauty, the Glyndebourne Festival Opera celebrated tonight the twenty-fifth anniversary of its opening.

As soon as a stubborn problem crops up in pleasure boating, an inventive person will barge into sight with a solution. A typical problem was the lack of adequate fuel for long-distance cruises in outboard powered craft.
WILTON, Conn., May 28 -- Republican voters here chose the late Senator Robert A. Taft next to President Eisenhower as the national figure, past or present, best representing Republican party aims.

All of us are more or less resigned to the Law of Deterioration, from which there is no appeal as it applies to ourselves and other living things. Even now at this season, when all about life is burgeoning, one knows that as new growth occurs here it is accompanied by a wearing out there; life is both a process of moving ahead and of falling back.

GREENSBURG, Pa., May 28 (AP) -- A New Jersey man and his wife were fatally injured last night in the head-on collision of their auto and a tractor-trailer on the Pennsylvania Turnpike near the New Stanton interchange.

ALBANY, May 28 -- Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, refused to say at the company's annual meeting in the Palace Theatre here today that the Central would not pay its shareholders a dividend for a long time.
LONDON, May 28 (Reuters) -- The liberalization of dollar imports has been expected ever since sterling was made partly convertible last Dec. 27.
Allan D. Cruickshank, ornithologist, author and artist, has confirmed heavy bird losses in the East in 1958 after an analysis of nation-wide bird counts that were made during Christmas week.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Government indicated today that it would cut allocations of crude and unfinished oil imports east of the Rockies and increase those for the Far West, Alaska and Hawaii in the last half of this year. The Department of the Interior made public proposed changes in the import regulations that would pave the way for such action.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 28 (AP) -- One of eighteen school teachers in Florida honored by the Freedoms Foundation of Valley Forge, Pa., will not be rehired next year, it was announced today.
Directors of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation have elected Robert J. McKim to the new position of chairman, and Lewis P. Seiler president, replacing Mr. McKim.
Five teen-agers were found guilty last night of first-degree manslaughter in the fatal beating of Julio Ramos last May 30 in Jefferson Park in East Harlem.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 28 -- Two monkeys were rocketed 300 miles above the earth today and then were plucked alive from the ocean 1,700 miles down the Caribbean missile range. They reached a maximum speed of 10,000 miles an hour.
ROME, May 28 -- Pope John XXIII in an unusual Corpus Christi rite amid the ruins of ancient Rome prayed tonight before the consecrated host for peace in the world.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 28 (AP) -- The newspaper Zafer, organ of the ruling Democratic party, was ordered closed today and an editor was jailed for offending the country's tough press laws.
A vacant plot 72 by 100 feet at 48 to 54 East Thirty-fourth Street between Madison and Park Avenues, has been purchased by Jac Associates, Inc., a corporation controlled by Kessler-Wohl, builders.
The election of Amory H. Bradford, vice president and general manager of The New York Times, as president of the Regional Plan Association was announced yesterday.
Joseph G. Luberda, the retired police sergeant who was found carrying $18,000 in $20 bills last March, was indicted yesterday for criminal contempt.

HAVANA, May 28 -- Cuba will be faced with "catastrophe" if the agrarian reform law is put into effect, according to a memorandum presented to the United States State Department by United States and Cuban sugar mill owners.

Steelmakers must hold down production costs -- especially labor costs -- if they are to withstand the growing competition of imports and substitute materials, the American Iron and Steel Institute was told yesterday.

Imre Nagy, the Hungarian Premier who was executed after the 1956 uprising in Budapest, is the subject of a biography called "Thirteen Days That Shook the Kremlin." Praeger will publish it June 16. The book is an attempt to answer questions about Nagy and his views on government, especially his attitude during the revolution.

The American fashion trend for the fall and winter is now being shaped, as Seventh Avenue designers unveil their collections to the press and to store buyers. The showings presently under way are the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July. The new clothes will be in stores by late summer.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Treasury will soon ask Congress for an increase in the national debt limit, probably to $295,000,000,000. This would be $12,000,000,000 above the present "permanent" ceiling of $283,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The State Department today cautiously censured the International Olympic Committee for its decision to expel Nationalist China.
Baudouin I, the unassuming 28-year-old King of the Belgians, made a modest appeal to the United States yesterday for an improvement in trade relations.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover received a gold model of a heart today in recognition of his designation as "the humanitarian of the year" by Variety Clubs International.

THE New York City Ballet last night presented its honored guests, the musicians and dancers of the Japanese Imperial Household, in their second program in the style of dance and music known as Gagaku at the City Center.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- The Senate passed its first two regular money bills of the year today in what Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democratic Leader, hailed as the beginning of a budget-cutting drive.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 27 -- A little-publicized "cold war" marked by incidents of violence provoked by Communists is under way in various areas of Central Java.

The Germantown Cricket Club and the Longwood Cricket Club will stage the two interzone Davis Cup tennis matches that will establish the nation to challenge the United States for the trophy at Forest Hills.
Democratic intraparty verbal warfare broke out yesterday before the Board of Estimate as to whether Manhattan's future would be traffic or trees.

LOON BAY, N. B., May 28 -- In the twenty-five miles above here, the St. Croix River has twenty-one rapids, which are almost always called rips hereabouts. Below almost all of them, fishing for trout and land-locked salmon is likely to be good at this time of year.

BEPPU, Japan, May 22 -- The Kinsui-en, one of the great private museums of Japan, stands a stone's throw from a coffee-colored beach where thousands of health-seekers bury themselves to the neck in supposedly therapeutic hot mineral sands.
ALBANY, May 28 -- The power of the courts to limit the amount of money lawyers may collect from their clients in contingent fees in negligence cases was upheld today by the Court of Appeals.
ALBANY, May 28 -- State Commerce Commissioner Keith S. McHugh announced today the appointment of Dr. Donald H. Davenport as Deputy Commerce Commissioner for Economic Development.
TRENTON, May 28 -- The question whether New Jersey actually has a new state scholarship program was clouded today by administrative and political maneuvering.
TOKYO, May 28 (AP) -- Japan dropped today her insistence that the International Committee of the Red Cross screen Koreans in Japan who want to go to Communist North Korea.
Four landlords have received summonses for building violations as a result of the second concentrated neighborhood inspection by teams from the Buildings and Health Departments.
LONDON, May 29 -- Jordan's political tranquility has been affected by allegations that the Deputy Commander in Chief of the armed forces was at the center of an army conspiracy against the state.

NAGASAKI, Japan May 24 -- Every day, rain or shine, hundreds of school children and local and foreign tourists plod to the top of a steep hill overlooking Nagasaki's beautiful, mountain-rimmed harbor to prowl through the sprawling house and garden of a long-dead British trader.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- In a flurry of development activity, Panama is striving to catch up with economic needs and problems posed by a spurt in its population over the last two decades. The recent rate of increase has averaged 3.5 per cent a year, the total rising from 576,000 in 1937 to 962,000 at the beginning of 1958.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The level of average wholesale primary market prices fell 0.1 per cent to 119.5 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

PARIS, May 29 (AP) -- Australia's probable Davis Cup team of Neale Fraser and Roy Emerson and Italy's veteran combination of Nicola Pietrangeli and Orlando Sirola today gained the doubles final of the French tennis championships.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 to 6 points (5 to 30 cents a bale) lower than Thursday, except new October which closed 7 points higher.
PORT WELLER, Ont., May 29 -- Canadian shipping interests are taking a serious view of the dispute between Canada and the United States over Great Lakes pilotage.

Standard Steel Corporation of Los Angeles has concluded negotiations with the Carrier Corporation to acquire the assets of a subsidiary, the Cambridge Company of Lowell, Mass., it was announced yesterday.
The minister of the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, announced this week his intention to retire on March 22, 1960, his seventieth birthday.
A prominent Negro leader has resigned from the Jamaica branch of the Urban League in protest against a testimonial dinner planned by the league for John T. Clancy, Queens Borough President.

MOSCOW, May 29 (AP) -- The International Aeronautic Federation admitted aero clubs from South Korea, North Korea, Morocco and Southern Rhodesia to membership today. It also decided to investigate some Latin American members delinquent in dues.
Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association has lost another battle to prevent scrutiny of its books and records by the Waterfront Commission.
Jackie Gleason, television's celebrated funny man, is planning to return to the Broadway stage next season in a musical.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A California gardener has invented an astronomical observatory. Its special feature is a suction system to get rid of the convection currents of air (heat waves) that distort an astronomer's view of a star.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- Sixteen auto assembly plants were closed today for a long Memorial Day holiday, cutting production for the week by 12 per cent from a week ago.

SURBITON, England, May 29 (UPI) -- Sally Moore of Bakersfield, Calif., reached the women's singles final of the Surrey lawn tennis tournament today, but Gwyn Thomas of Cleveland, Ohio, was defeated in the semi-final by Ann Haydon of England.

Columbia College announced yesterday that Jerome Shupack of 216 East Ninety-sixth Street, Brooklyn, had been named valedictorian of its graduating class. Henry Ebel of 665 West 160th Street was named salutatorian.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 29 -- John J. O'Rourke, a vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and twelve other persons pleaded not guilty here today to a sixteen-count indictment charging conspiracy, coercion and extortion in the juke-box industry in Nassau County.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 29 (Reuters) -- A busy schedule of flights from Communist countries into Albania today suggested the possibility of top-level Eastern bloc talks in Tirana, Albania's capital.

Stock prices boiled to new highs in May in quiet trading, despite warnings by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Stock Exchanges and brokers. Although trading slackened, prices continued to advance.

SINGAPORE, Saturday, May 30 -- Almost 600,000 persons are expected to vote today, in an election marking the end of Singapore's status as a British crown colony. The Leftist People's Action party is confident it will win decisively.
A pre-holiday atmosphere permeated most New York commodity exchanges yesterday and trading was listless.
LOOKING smart while keeping cool on a summer day in the city takes a lot of doing. Here are some points to keep in mind when it's a sizzling 90 degrees.
TRENTON, May 29 (AP) -- George Dooley of New Brunswick was on a liquid diet today, thanking the good fortune that put five doctors near him when he choked on two pieces of steak.
Those television antennas sprouting from rooftops across the land -- and the ungainly rabbit-ear type, too -- are expected to become as obsolete as buttonhooks before long.

TORONTO, May 29 (Canadian Press) -- Perkins, Ltd., of Peterborough, England, will start production in Brazil in the second half of next year of six-cylinder Diesel engines for five to eight ton trucks manufactured in that country.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Manufacturers' sales broke their pro-recession record last month, with the largest increase of the recovery period, the Department of Commerce reported today. The volume of new orders received also showed a big increase and hit a new peak.

BONN, Germany, May 29 -- Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss said today that East Germany had probably trained more than 1,000,000 persons in the use of arms. These include the East German People's Army, special border troops and several paramilitary organizations, he said.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Administration sent to Congress today its proposal for a new method of regulating the use of color additives in foods, drugs and cosmetics.
