Dr. Gordon advocates the labeling of bags with a warning sign and an admonition to "keep away from children" and "destroy immediately." In the same issue of The Times I also noticed that Congress may act to bar plastic bags from interstate commerce.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 29 (UPI) -- The Florida House unanimously passed a bill today making it illegal to tattoo boys and girls under 18.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The World Bank loaned $72,000,000 today to Iran for road development, including improvement of the Great Trans-Iranian Highway from the Persian Gulf to the Caspian Sea.
The first of seven hour-long news shows prepared by the National Broadcasting Company for prime evening time will be televised Friday, June 26.
HARDLY typical of the growing number of older women -- but certainly an inspiration to them -- is Mrs. Ezra Winter, a woman describing herself as 60-plus.
CLEVELAND, May 29 (AP) -- The United Rubber Workers Union and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company agreed today to meet with a Federal mediator next Wednesday.

TUNIS, May 29 -- M'hammed Yazid, chief spokesman for the Algerian rebels, declared here tonight that the only negotiations with France that the Algerian provisional government would accept would be those conducted in neutral territory.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 --- The drivers who will start in the forty-third 500-mile auto race here tomorrow received their instructions today. "Go," they were told, "but be careful."
STATION WPIX devoted two hours last night to a telecast about Moral Re-Armament.

Employes in private hospitals, unlike those in voluntary or nonprofit hospitals, are entitled to minimum-wage protection under the laws of the State of New York. However, they have not applied for it.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) -- A House hearing has been told that 214 employes of the Denver office of the Federal Bureau of Reclamation accepted pay from private interests in a fourteen-year period. The testimony at the hearing was made public today.

One of the most disturbing aspects of the Moses-Papp debacle is the immunity from direct public control that appointed officials like Robert Moses enjoy. Capriciousness and insensitivity are thus allowed to flourish unopposed. Newspapers are one of the few channels through which popular pressure can be exerted.
The first Soviet vessel to reach here in ten years docked yesterday as it was disclosed she had been granted permission to sail through the newly opened St. Lawrence Seaway.

The widespread belief in the financial district that the recent bond market decline had amply discounted a new rise in the Federal Reserve Banks discount rate was confirmed in a quiet trading session yesterday.
DEVON, Pa., May 29 -- Winning the stake tonight, Windsor Castle from Carl Miller Jr.'s Stable of Battle Creek, Mich., clinched the open jumper championship of the sixty-third annual Devon horse show.

The world's only serious hot war, that between France and an Algerian nationalist army, is moving toward a climax. The guerrillas find themselves increasingly isolated by French diplomacy, French propaganda and new French military tactics.

An art auction to be held next Saturday in the gardens of Mrs. Stanley Dorman's home in Scarsdale, N. Y., will benefit WAIF (World Adoption International Fund), the adoption division of the International Social Service.

Eugene J. Moran, a lawyer and son of former Deputy Fire Commissioner James J. Moran, obtained an order in Supreme Court yesterday to bar District Attorney Frank S. Hogan from changing the record of his father's conviction.
Protestant churches here and over the world will commemorate tomorrow the 450th year since the birth of John Calvin, one of the great religious reformers.

Congratulations on the Killian report on "Education for the Age of Science," particularly because it urges higher intellectual content in college and university courses in all fields of human endeavor.
TRENTON, May 29 (AP) -- A bill designed to speed action by the Public Utility Commission on bus and rail company applications was signed into law today by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 23 -- The Lebanese Government has begun deporting some of the Arab Communists who have been operating an international party center here.
The nation will pay homage to its war dead today.

BALTIMORE, May (AP) -- An examiner said today that fire had broken out in the Capital Airlines Viscount turboprop pane that exploded over near-by Chase, Md., May 12. The accident, at 14,000 feet, killed thirty-one persons.
QUITO, Ecuador, May 29 (AP) -- Ninety draftees garrisoned in Portoviejo mutinied late today. They handed out weapons to civilians who joined them in an attack on the regular army garrison.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 29 (UPI) -- The body of a Negro minister, missing almost a week, was found today on the banks of a public lake near Selma, Ala. The lake was the scene of two recent inter-racial incidents.
LONDON, May 29 -- To encourage bigger orders, British steel makers will reduce the price of steel beginning on Monday by about 2 per cent on shipments of ten tons or more.
Carter Products, Inc., producer of proprietary medicines, toiletries and drugs, has reported gains in sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended last March 31.
ALBANY, May 29 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals cleared the way today for a rehearing of a complaint that the Lake Placid Club discriminated against Jews.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- Selling continued in wheat, rye and soybean futures almost without let-up today and all those contracts had their sharpest losses in several days.
" The Horse Soldiers," a Civil War drama in color starring John Wayne and William Holden, is scheduled to open here on June 26 at the Astor Theatre.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 29 (UPI) -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq said his country would stop accepting American aid next week, the Baghdad radio reported tonight.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 29 (AP) -- Clark D. Ahlberg, former state budget director, was named today to a new position of vice president for administration and research at Syracuse University. He will take over his new duties Sept. 1.

LIMA, Peru, May 29 -- Fernando Belaunde Terry, imprisoned Opposition leader, awaited tonight a judicial inquiry into charges of subversive plotting. His supporters during the evening fought the police in futile efforts to stage demonstrations demanding his freedom.

The status of the press under post-World War II authoritarian regimes is the subject of a study by the International Press Institute. Called "The Press in Authoritarian Countries," it will be published Tuesday by Fraeger.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 29 (AP) -- Liquidators of I. G. Farben, once Germany's biggest industrial complex, reiterated today that they had not renounced claims to some $100,000,000 worth of General Aniline and Film Corporation shares seized in the United tSates during World War II.

With reference to your May 26 editorial "Trade With Russia" I wish to call attention to some facts that may throw further light on the subject. Commercial interchange between nations as well as private entities must be motivated upon mutual profit and a minimum of reciprocal faith.

Early in his visit, speaking as a young man from an old country to a joint session of the Congress in Washington, he said:

YONKERS, May 29 -- Clear of trouble at all times and in front almost all of the way after the first quarter, Mr. Saunders won the tenth annual Gotham Trot before 33,397 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
A Bronx County Court jury acquitted Mrs. Mildred Photides, 27-year-old mother, of first-degree manslaughter yesterday in the fatal stabbing of her husband last Sept. 6.
PARIS, May 29 -- Proponents of state aid to private Roman Catholic schools renewed their offensive in Parliament today.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) -- Independent casualty and fire insurance companies appealed to Congress today to protect them against price-fixing by powerful combines of competitors.
NEWARK, May 29 -- Four railroads put up a united front today against alternate plans for providing a crossing of the Hudson River for riders on New York Central's West Shore division.

Diverse trends were shown in new financing in May. Public offerings of bonds here were the largest of the year to date, while stock flotations declined sharply from the level of the month before to the second lowest total of this year.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products increased four-tenths of 1 per cent in the month ended May 15.

In expelling Nationalist China from the International Olympic Committee -- and thus eventually from Olympic participation -- the committee has yielded to the rawest sort of political blackmail. The action is not only, in the words of our State Department, "totally inconsistent with its [the Olympics] non-political tradition." It is cowardly, evasive and shameful.

NIGERIA, May 29 -- The trust territory of British Southern Cameroons will be administered directly by the British Governor General of Nigeria between December, 1959, and April, 1960. By then it is expected that a plebiscite on the territory's future will have been held.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 29 -- A 20-year-old ex-convict was sentenced to fifteen to seventeen years in prison today for his part in the shooting of two Englewood policemen on Jan. 29. An 18-year-old girl received an indeterminate term and a 21-year-old youth received a suspended sentence in the same case.

Jewelers in New York pooh-poohed yesterday a news report from Cape May, N. J., that beach stones found there for generations were "Cape May diamonds," which, when cut and polished, sell for $15 to $50 a carat.

HAVANA, May 29 -- Labor Minister Manuel Fernandez Garcia said in a televised interview last night that Cuba's Agrarian Reform Institute did not expect to break up the big United States-owned sugar plantations this year.

SANDWICH, England, May 29 (UPI) -- William Hyndman 3d beat Army Lieut. Bob Magee in a 38-hole match today and set up an all-American final in the British Amateur golf championship opposite his young Walker Cup team-mate, Deane Beman.
A boardroom of girls studying economics from a safe distance, ventured closer yesterday and acquired a part of American industry.

GENEVA, May 29 -- There has never been one before, and there may not be another, so it might be just as well to set down as much of a record as possible of the EastWest foreign ministers' airborne conference.
CHICAGO, May 29 -- Paul J. Kern, an attorney from New York City, won his fight today to have himself elected a director of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad.
An elevator fell five floors last night, but the twelve persons aboard escaped serious injury.

BUENOS AIRES, May 29 -- President Arturo Frondizi said tonight that Argentina's economic recovery plan would be fulfilled against the designs of "the Communists and some Peronist sectors" to thwart it.
A decaying reminder of one of the city's abandoned ferryboat routes remains on Welfare Island only because of a lack of funds to remove it.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 29 (AP) -- A 74-year-old widow from South Africa arrived in England today wishing she didn't have to spend u6,000 ($16,800) roaming the globe.
MOSCOW, May 21 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's proposal for a "zone of peace" in the Balkans and the Mediterranean was given major attention today by Pravda.
A 29-year-old Brooklyn man whose vigilante action had led to the capture of two robbery suspects foiled an attempt last night to kidnap him at the entrance of his apartment.

The Yankees may be on the upswing, although any such Statement should be made with caution. For by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 5-2, at the Stadium yesterday, they now have won two of their last three games.

Automobiles and Memorial Day have been associated in the public mind almost ever since automobiles began to be familiar vehicles on the American road. The first long-distance race on a track designed for high-speed cars was staged at Indianapolis in 1911 on Memorial Day.
The New Haven Railroad yesterday petitioned intrastate and interstate regulatory agencies for increases in its commutation fares, to become effective on July 1.
GENEVA, May 29 -- The Big Four foreign ministers explored the uncertain future of Berlin in their first private session in Geneva today.
MANY home accessory shops are closed on Saturdays during July and August, but not all.
Leone's Restaurant, one of the well-known eating places in this city, has been sold to a restaurant chain in a "multi-million-dollar" transaction.

A dozen horses are entered in the sixty-sixth running of the Metropolitan Mile at Belmont Park today. A star of the show, though, will be Eddie Arcaro, the 43-year-old jockey who has won the event three times. He will come as close as possible to being in two places at once.
The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, the nation's' second largest paper producer has a new president and chief executive officer. He is Read O. Hunt, who joined the company as a clerk in 1927.

A memorial plaza with a twelve-story illuminated steel Shaft has been suggested by a group of West Side Democrats as a replacement for the Soldiers and Sailors Monument at Eighty-ninth Street and Riverside Drive. The Park Department, however, is against the proposal.
NEW DELHI, India, May 29 -- A test of strength between political forces in the Communist-ruled state of Kerala over the control of schools has been postponed.

A threatened strike at six proprietary hospitals was averted yesterday when labor and management agreed to collective-bargaining elections among the institutions' non-professional employes. However, there was no sign of a break in the three-week-old strike at six voluntary, non-profit hospitals.
MEXICO CITY, May 29 -- The robbery of an American woman of a fortune in Cuban pesos put the victim in a Mexican jail today.

A relatively unknown contract bridge team won the Eastern States mixed teams championship early this morning. This event is one of five championships at stake in the annual ten-day competition being held here at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.
MONTREAL, May 29 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that the disparity of living standards between developed and underdeveloped nations was "the most important and fateful fact in the world today."
PARIS, May 29 -- Silence Week in Paris has come and gone and police officials expressed hope tonight that "the notion of silence" had entered the Parisian mind.

NEWARK, May 29 -- A settlement of the two-week-old strike of electrical workers against the Public Service Electric and Gas Company appeared near tonight. It was reliably reported that a major stumbling block in the negotiations had been removed.
CAMP HILL, Md., May 29 -- The long aluminum body of the first bomber to carry an atomic bomb lies on wooden blocks at the end of an unused concrete runway here at Andrews Air Force Base.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson agreed today under pressure from New Jersey interests to reconsider further subsidies to the depression-struck poultry and egg industry.

CLEVELAND, May 29 -- Mrs. Albert H. Van Gorder, mother of the chairman of the board of McKesson Robbins, Inc., was killed today when the car in which she was riding crashed into a tree in suburban Willoughby. Her age was 87.

The manufacture of petrochemicals -- chemicals derived from petroleum or natural gas -- will grow at a rate of 8 to 10 per cent a year in the next decade, J. H. Forrester, president of the Amoco Chemical Corporation, said here yesterday.

From a Communist point of view Premier Khrushchev was undoubtedly exhibiting great generosity and tolerance when he addressed the Congress of Soviet Writers. Instead of excoriating writers who had strayed from the party line these last few years, he called for their rehabilitation so they might have a second chance.

The threat of an immediate strike against several proprietary hospitals was lifted yesterday and the Mayor's fact-finding committee continued its efforts to end the three-week strike against the voluntary, nonprofit hospitals. In the realm of court proceedings all was confusion, awaiting completion of various steps of litigation and appeal.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., May 29 -- This town is famous for its Revolutionary War memories but the atmosphere evoked by last night's concert at the local high school was that of Restoration England.

Paul J. (Frankie) Carbo, reputed underworld boxing czar who has been sought for ten months on an indictment charging illegal operations in boxing, was arrested in a hideout in Hayden Township, N. J., early this morning.
James E. Brodhead, an actor between plays, spent eight solitary hours Tuesday in a world of distorted reality.

THE old master of Versailles, Louis XIV, was outliving his grandchildren. The young mistresses were entering their perpetual middle age. Along came the Duc de Saint-Simon to make an immortal, angry record of the Sun King's noon and twilight and death.

The stock market was in a holiday mood yesterday. Trading moved at a leisurely pace as many Wall Streeters left early for the long Memorial Day week-end. Even so, prices rose to new historic highs, with some issues showing sharp gains.
COPENHAGEN, May 29 (AP) -- The International Tin Council today increased the export quotas for its six producing members from 23,000 tons to 25,000 tons for the three months starting July 1.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Officials at the Pentagon said today they were disturbed order the tendency of Congress to substitute its own military judgment for that of the Defense Department.

Now and then, and even often, we should stop to think in these hectic times of the broad underlying developments that are affecting our world. Adlai Stevenson did just that in his thoughtful address at McGill University, Montreal, yesterday on receiving an honorary LL.D. degree.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., national retail chain, is entering the mid-South market with the purchase of Goldsmith's in Memphis.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced last night one of the largest transfers of police officials in his department's history.
POPLARVILLE, Miss., May 29 (AP) -- Circuit Judge Sebe Dale called today for an end to "piecemeal leaks" from Government sources on the Mack Charles Parker lynching case.
New York showered ticker tape and affection yesterday on a reluctant celebrity, Baudouin I. the youthful King of the Belgians.
New financing in the public capital market promises to move along at a lively pace next week, with major issues of common stock vying with bond issues for the favor of investors.

LEWISBURG, Pa., May 29 (AP) -- A Cincinnati minister who went to jail rather than pay taxes to help finance the country's military program, was freed today from the Federal prison farm at near-by Allenwood.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Defense counsel in the conspiracy trial of Richard A. Mack and Thurman A. Whiteside demanded a mistrial today. Their motions were promptly turned down in Federal District Court by Judge Burnita S. Matthews.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Arthur B. Johnson, manager of Grace Line's Great Lakes operations in Chicago assailed today the "medicine men and drum beaters" who extol what he termed the nonexistent virtues of the St. Lawrence Seaway and Lakes ports.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 29 (AP) -- The Florida Supreme Court upheld today a finding by the Dade County Circuit Court that Leo Sheiner, former Miami lawyer, should not be disbarred for refusing to say whether he ever had been a Communist.
GENEVA, May 29 -- Israel was provisionally admitted today to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Only Indonesia cast a dissenting vote. Pakistan abstained.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher and chairman of the board of The New York Times, received the Columbia Journalism Award yesterday for "singular journalistic performance in the public interest."

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that he would not shy away from further criticism of Lyndon B. Johnson despite a counter-attack by the Texas Senator.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., May 29 -- Joseph Barbara Sr., host to the 1957 Apalachin gangland meeting, suffered a heart attack today and was taken, semi-conscious, to Wilson Memorial Hospital in Johnson City.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Government will explore for the first time this fall an agricultural development that farmers have been considering as a means of gaining greater bargaining power.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), May 29 -- Avraham Harman, former Israeli consul general in New York, has been nominated as Israel's next Ambassador to the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) -- A Brooklyn Congressman said today that he would go to the Soviet Union to talk over outer space problems with Russian leaders -- with or without the approval of the House space committee chairman.

WITH the summertime exodus to the country, the stay-put New York family has the city at its feet. Normally unobtainable theatre tickets can be had for the asking. Restaurants that customarily demand reservations in advance are eager to serve the drop-in diner.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- President Eisenhower caught up today with the people of Washington, who have been flocking to Griffith Stadium. He went there and watched the suddenly ferocious. Senators defeat the Boston Red Sox,

CANTALOUPES, a perennial hot weather favorite, are now beginning to make their appearance in New York. Although not yet in the bargain category, increasing supplies over the next two weeks should result in an appreciable drop from the present price range of 15 to 29 cents a pound.

MANCHESTER, England, May 29 (AP) -- Britain's decision to cut restrictions on dollar imports will help the Eisenhower Government's campaign for an "even more liberal" trade policy, United States Ambassador John Hay Whitney said today.
ROME, May 29 -- Foreign Minister Giuseppe Pella accused Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today of "an intimidating propaganda campaign" against Italy.
A 21-year-old man on parole in a previous car theft was arrested yesterday after a stolen auto he was driving struck and seriously injured a child.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), May 29 -- In a dry river bed in the Judaean hills, B'nai B'rith dedicated today a shrine hewn out of solid rock in memory of Jewish men, women and children who died under Hitler's regime.

In your editorial of May 20 "Reporters and Red China" you propose that the American people have a right to be informed, from direct observation by American citizens, of what is taking place in Red China.
Departing for Europe yesterday, Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Company, said he adored Maria Callas and hoped to hear her and meet her while he is abroad for the summer.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, said today that unions serving the maritime industry were allied only for the purpose sought by Government and the industry itself -- uniformity of contract termination dates.
Following are salient facts on the foreign ministers' conference at United Nations headquarters in Geneva:
The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway will stay in the express business even if the Railway Express Agency expires, Ernest S. Marsh, president of the Santa Fe, said yesterday.
A strike of maintenance and clerical employes of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company was scheduled last night to start at midnight tomorrow.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 29 -- More likely than not the skippers of the ninety-three cruising yachts that began the new season's first really big distance race today faced a night of cold and dampness. There was better than an even chance that it would be foggy, too.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Two space-pioneering monkeys, Able and Baker, flew here under military escort tonight for a medical examination and a news conference.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (UPI) -- Senator Stuart Symington told the Commonwealth Club of San Francisco today that the United States must expand its economy by 4 or 5 per cent a year to meet the threat of the Soviet Union and Communist China.

One of the youngest records on the books was broken and the oldest mark was equaled yesterday in the qualifying trials for the eighty-third annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America track and field championships.

Neither the favorite's role, a twenty-four-and-three-quarter-pound weight advantage nor the longest reach in boxing did Nino Valdes of Havana any good in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
SAN JUAN, P. R., May 29 -- "It was just like the Fourth of July," Jalmar F. Forsman of Kreole, Miss., a Navy frogman, declared today.
Gotham's stores moved quickly yesterday to lay in an adequate stock of room air conditioners as uncomfortable temperatures persisted.
LOON BAY, N. B., May 29 -- Grave philosophical speculation and discussion are going on here tonight over why fish sometimes strike short all day long and refuse to come back for a second try.

There are twenty-two agencies affiliated with the Greater New York Fund that have their main offices in Queens. Nineteen other agencies have district offices there, thirty-six serve other bor oughs as well as Queens, and 241 make their services available on a city-wide basis.
CARLE PLACE, L.I., May 29 -- America's teachers have failed to do their "homework" on current proposals for Federal school aid, Senator Jacob K. Javits charged here today.
ONLY one Confederate veteran remains alive this year to take the salute on Memorial Day for the more than 3,000,000 men who fought on both sides in the Civil War.
A daring aviator came down from Albany aboard his flying machine yesterday.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 29 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham is at the end of his Down Under crusade. He rates it the most exciting of his career.
LOUISVILLE, May 30 (UPI) -- Bob Goalby of Crystal River, Fla., sank a 15-foot eagle putt on the eighteenth green today to protect his lead in the $20,000 Kentucky Derby open golf tournament.

ON the first page this morning, Mr. Lynes is paying his respects to James Thurber and "The Years With Ross." This is a book that has been in the works for a long time indeed, with publication date announced and then postponed, as the author culled more anecdotes.

DUBLIN, May 30 -- Three directors of the Shanahan Stamp Auction Company and the wife of one of them were detained tonight by the police. On May 9 stamps worth $1,200,000 reportedly were stolen from the company's auction rooms at Dun Laoghaire, eight miles from here.
The latest monthly report of the National Association of Purchasing Agents describes business as booming. Concern about a possible slump in the third quarter is fading.

The proposal of Beardsley Ruml, "Memo to a College Trustee," written for the Fund for the Advancement of Education, assumes that trustees are experts in curriculum planning, course sequences and prerequisites.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 30 (UPI) -- Ralph Neves was given a "sixty-forty" chance to live atfer a two-and-a-half hour brain operation tonight.
PARAMUS, N. J., Sunday, May 31 -- Dick Weber of St. Louis posted one of his highest individual victories by winning the $17,000 Paramus Eastern Open bowling tournament.

Total nonagricultural employment in Illinois rose steadily during the first quarter to 3,348,100. The state has recently changed the coding structure for the report and brought the comparative figures for 1958 into line with the 1959 figures.

SPECULATIVE scientists known as "wildcatters" have discovered most of the world's oil supply. The name dates from the early days of drilling in Pennsylvania when wildcats fought at night over the food scraps left by daytime drilling crews in remote places.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -House subcommittee will hold a public hearing here June 17 and 18 to determine the need for emergency action to alleviate a serious depression in the egg and poultry industry.

TWO portulacas -- the weedy pursley or purslane (Portulaca oleracea) and the lovely rose moss (P. grandiflora) -- are of interest to gardeners. Strange as it may seem, pursley once was more highly esteemed in European countries than was the colorful rose moss.

Serious heart attacks are often preceded by "premonitory" symptoms of pain in the heart, calling for precautionary measures that may prevent the attack, it was reported last week at the convention of the American College of Cardiology at Philadelphia by Dr. Robert E. Beamish, Assistant Professor of Medicine at the University of Manitoba in Winnipeg, Canada.

PENNEBAKER PRODUCTIONS, operating on two continents with Marlon Brando filming "OneEyed Jacks," his first directorial effort, at Paramount, and with "Shake Hands With the Devil," the James Cagney drama dealing with the Irish revolutionary "troubles" now in its premiere run in Dublin, is headed toward an even heavier schedule.

HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa., May 30 -- Ch. Shirkhan of Grandeur, a gray brindle Afghan hound who reached the pinnacle of canine success in acquiring a Westminster bestin-show title a few seasons ago, today topped a lesser field of 507 contenders and laid claim to his twenty-third best-inshow rosette at the Huntingdon Valley Kennel Club's thirtythird annual fixture.
A crowd of 20,230 appeared at the Polo Grounds last night for what may well be the world's noisiest sport -- stockcar racing on an asphalt track.

ISLAND BEACH, N. J., May 30 -- Island Beach, one of the last remaining wilderness areas along the North Atlantic seaboard, was invaded for the first time today by crowds of bathers, picnickers and surf fishermen.
THE growing interest in amateur color printing is reflected in the total of 301 entries submitted in the International All - Color Print Exhibition sponsored by the Metropolitan Camera Club Council.

The Indian Government is planning to make funds available to India's ship owners for the purchase of used ships or the construction of new vessels. The move is designed to put the Indian merchant fleet at the 1,600,000-gross-ton level.

Except for a few minor setbacks, Cleveland business activity continued to surge toward higher levels in the week ended May 23. Strength was especially apparent in steel, electric power output, auto sales and, to a lesser extent, railroad carloadings. Meanwhile, unemployment continued its steady decline.

It is upsetting to find James L. Clifford asserting in his article, "For Candide and Rasselas All Was Not For the Best" that Rasselas returns "to the Happy Valley in Abyssinia." On the contrary, Samuel Johnson makes it quite clear in "Rasselas" that once an inhabitant leaves the Happy Valley, he has left it forever.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 30 (Reuters) -- The Indonesian Government has made the north Sumatran province of Atjeh a special district with increased autonomous rights, Dr. Hardi, First Deputy Premier, announced here.

AN announcement the other day seemed, at first glance, to be routine. "'The Warm Peninsula,' starring Julie Harris," it read, "will open at the Helen Hayes Theatre Oct. 22." First glance in this case, as in many, was deceptive.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -Rodger Ward is a handsome 38-year-old native of Beloit, Wis., who turned to driving racing cars after leaving the Army Air Force pilot ranks in 1946.
Summer hours for the New York Public Library system, effective tomorrow, will close many of the reference divisions in the Fifth Avenue building all or part Saturdays and Sundays.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Government for the first time is moving to keep scientists informed on scientific developments in Communist China through translation of Chinese scientific publications.

A BOOK called "Kangaroos in the Kitchen" came out last week. It's by Lorrain D'Essen, tells the story of her Animal Talent Scouts -- which supplies animals to Broadway, etc. -- and makes quite a do about such friends actually being in the D'Essen kitchen.

FROM wells in Texas to refineries in Illinois, or Sumatra to California, or Saudi Arabia to New Jersey, and on to consumers all over the country, there flow each day millions of barrels of oil and oil products.

AS a Middle Easterner who is not an Arab I want to say that I was very shocked by Hal Lehrman's review of "Nasser of Egypt" by Wilton Wynn. It is very hard for a person who has had the opportunity to see Egypt before and after the revolution, to accept the fact that Mr. Lehrman really believes some of the generalized statements he makes.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., May 30 -- Saratoga Raceway, one of the early night trotting tracks, will begin its eighteenth season Thursday when it opens a sixty-nine-night summer meet.

AFTER a tour of eight major European cities the exhibition entitled "The New American Painting" is now to be seen at the Museum of Modem Art. Reactions abroad ranged from approving comment on the impact and daring of the work, its color and its individuality, to assertion that it was oversize, a joke in bad taste and little better than brush wipings.
" Memorial Day is a reminder that not all is peaceful in the world," the Rev. Dr. Zev Zahavy observed yesterday in his sermon to Congregation Zichron Ephraim, 163 East Sixty-seventh Street.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 30 -- Smith College has named two educators trustees for five-year terms, Benjamin F. Wright, president, announced today.
Commencement week of the 205th academic year at Columbia University begins today for the 6,591 students who will receive undergraduate and advanced degrees.

Advance contingents of buyers from all over the nation were in the city last week to look over the Fall styles, and resident offices were pleased with the sales volume so far. Next week will see an even higher volume of sales, the offices report, and there will be many merchandising shows for the member stores to view the styles.

The New York Higher Education Assistance Corporation has completed its first year of operation with loans totalling $2,903,934 to 5,493 students. The corporation will start processing loans for the next college year in June. Applications may be made to the corporation at the State Education Building, Albany.
SINGAPORE, Sunday, May 31 -- The left-wing People's Action party scored a landslide victory yesterday in elections for a new Assembly that will take over local rule from the British here.

Before man can risk his first voyage to outer space, the scientists must be certain they can bring him safely back to earth. This involves three main problems: (1) cushioning the spaceman against the mighty acceleration and deceleration forces during ascent and descent; (2) keeping him alive in airless, radiation-charged outer space with all its hazards, and (3) overcoming the tremendous heat which friction with the earth's atmosphere produces when a vehicle re-enters it.

The fact that the male of the human species is by nature a restless animal may be lost on us most of the time. He has been well trained to heel in recent eons by that tough but wise taskmaster, civilization.
MILWAUKEE, May 30 -Homers by Henry Aaron and Eddie Mathews lifted the Milwaukee Braves to a 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.
HANOVER, N. H., May 30 -Dartmouth College announced this week the appointment of Dr. John W. Masland as provost. Dr. Leonard M. Rieser was named deputy provost.

FROM June, 1917 (when the Stutz was a most estimable automobile and croquet was a popular game), to approximately the present is the span of Noel Clad's expertly controlled big novel. "Love and Money" comes close, in a general way, to being a social history of our last four decades.
CHICAGO, May 30 -- The students of the University of Chicago's undergraduate college are apprehensive.
Miles F. York, president of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters, last week pointed proudly to marine insurance as one of the few services that was cheaper today than it was a decade ago.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the United States chess champion, adjourned his ninth-round match in the jubilee international tournament in Zurich, according to a report reaching here last night through Swiss news sources.

CROTON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y. -- The lower Hudson Valley has gained a new attraction for sight-seers. It is the restored 1680 Van Cortlandt Manor House and subsidiary estate buildings of early Dutch-English design on 175 acres beside the Albany Post Road (U. S. 9) here.

GENEVA, May 30 -- The member countries of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreed without enthusiasm today on the framework for a settlement of the issue of West Germany's import restrictions.

A MOTORIST stopping at a filling station for a tank-ful of gasoline is a participant in the final act of a fascinating drama whose scenes span a period of several million years. The consumption of motor fuel, lubricants, kerosene, natural gas, diesel and fuel oils and other by-products marks the end of this long drama.

ON Friday, Danes will celebrate one of their most important holidays, Constitution Day. This is an occasion that resembles our Independence Day. The Danes make speeches, either political or cultural. And it is a happy holiday, a time when children ride carrousels and Ferris wheels and the residents of Copenhagen stroll in the fairy-tale Tivoli gardens or walk along the Langelinje promenade to see Den Lille Havfrue, the famed Little Mermaid in the Sound.

Basil Ince of Tufts University erased a twenty-seven-year-old record shared by two Olympic gold medal winners in the concluding session of the eighty-third annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America track and field championships yesterday.

I HAVE read with disappointed interest the review by Roger McHugh of the "Black Diaries" of Roger Casement. Most of the biographies on Casement are mentioned in the review but the most important one is ignored, that one being "Casement's Last Adventure" by Captain Robert Monteith, who shared the final six months of Casement's life and liberty.

IN "Elizabeth," the Russian-born French writer, Henri Troyat, has written the third novel in his chronicle, which he calls "The Seed and the Fruit," about a twentieth-century, middle-class, free-thinking, provincial French family.
Naming a new vessel is an impressive affair, complete with crashing champagne bottle. But the name won't stick unless a long legal procedure is carried out.
MADRID, May 30 -- The Spanish Government is reported to have arrested about twenty persons in the last eleven days in a nation-wide roundup of suspected anti-regime elements.

WHEN Jose Vasconcelos, as Minister of Education, set Diego Rivera to painting the walls of Mexico, he inaugurated a school and a policy. Art, like the political revolution, broke with the Hispanic past and began to draw the Indian into its web.

Activity in trade circles was pronounced last week. Retailers posted gains over a year ago in the Kansas City Federal Re serve district. Since the start of 1959, department stores sales have shown increases over a year ago every week except one and that was distorted by the Easter holiday.

Railroads serving or based in the Upper Midwest continue to report higher operating revenues and net incomes. Four railroads -- Rock Island, Milwaukee, Wisconsin Central and Burlington -- were the latest to report greater operating revenues for April, 1959 than a year ago.
THE last musical comedy of the season turns out to be the season's best. As a production, "Gypsy" hangs together with professional ingenuity and gives Ethel Merman something responsive to work with.
