Thus in Genesis is the first written record of man's use of petroleum, literally rock oil, which is one of the most abundant and widely distributed substances in the earth.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP) -- Three horses finished less than a length apart as Mrs. H. L. Nathenson's Midontrial won the $15,000 added Tomasello Memorial Handicap today at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 32,305.
STANTON, Del., May 30 (AP) -- Gray Flank, a $4,500 yearling buy last year, won the $12,875 Polly Drummond Stakes for 2-year-old fillies by two lengths today at Delaware Park before a crowd of 20,646.
WINNIPEG, Man., May 30 -- International spectators are watching closely the federation plan proposed this year to help Winnipeg meet problems created by explosive metropolitan growth.
The old idea that earthquake vibrations are seldom noticeable on ships at sea was rudely shattered this month in the North Pacific.
LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- A storm of outraged protest mounted in Britain tonight over the justice of jailing a widow on relief who toiled in secret to feed her sick children.

At least sixty colleges this year have over 1,000 students spending one of their four undergraduate years studying, for full credit, in a foreign university. Another sixty-odd colleges will send 1,000 or more abroad for organized summer study programs.
The farm equipment industry is reaping a rich harvest this spring. Sales and earnings have been soaring as a result of past and anticipated future record crops.

No matter whether spring is early or late, May somehow evens out the season. By May's end everything is pretty well in order, the trees in full leaf, the apple blossoms gone, the late lilacs faded, peonies either in fat bud or first bloom. Dawn comes early, sun sets late, the sky is blue, not yet white-hot with midsummer. Evenings still have a freshness, even a benevolence, that will be rare in another month.

THIS is a remarkable and penetrating book, a brilliant, cold-blooded, skeptical analysis of the diplomatic techniques and aspirations of communism as developed at its central base, the Soviet Union. It is somewhat awkwardly written, but it is profound and its conclusions are, on the whole, direct, logical and terrifying.

In July, 1950, art lovers were shocked to hear that the Kinkakuji -- the Temple of the Golden Pavilion -- in Kyoto had been deliberately burned by a crazed young monk. At his trial, this ugly, stammering priest said that his hatred of all beauty had driven him to destroy the six-century-old building.

WHEN soldering sweat joints on copper pipe with a propane torch, joints which are close together sometimes loosen up from the nearby heat. To prevent this, wrap each joint as it is completed with a wet rag.

Trends in nearly all business categories continue favorable in New England. The overall picture in the opinion of local bankers is about as good as it ever has been. Some of the largest business concerns in this area, however, are up in arms over tax rises and are publically warning that if government spending does not end, they will consider moving elsewhere.

ONE of the many little conveniences which modern plumbing affords is the automatic thumb-control faucet spray on many kitchen sinks. When these need repair or replacement they can now be easily serviced by the home handyman because the industry has standardized all replacement equipment and parts.

EACH day some 800,000,000 gallons of crude oil pass through petroleum refineries throughout the world to end up as a myriad of finished products. The refiner's job is to take the ugly black liquid and extract from it a wide variety of fuels, lubricants and chemicals.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -The Federal Bureau of Investigation has washed its hands of the Mack Charles Parker lynching in Poplarville, Miss. As it so often must in cases of this kind, it has returned to state authorities the responsibility for apprehending and punishing the culprits.
To the Drama Editor: Recently I have had the opportunity of seeing two of the important "hits" of the Broadway season: "J. B." and "Sweet Bird of Youth."

To the Screen Editor: YOUR recent Sunday article titled, "Ever-New Realist," made me wonder if a basic tenet of films has finally gone by the board. The adage "Nothing succeeds like success" has made it unthinkable that any moneymaking photoplay would not, in fairly short order, spawn a host of imitators and set exhibitors to vying with one another to show these productions.

I READ with great interest Howard Taubman's article last Sunday and was happy to see the Boston Pops Concerts get well-deserved credit for their success in introducing "the glorious sound of a symphony orchestra in the flesh" to "an audience, largely youthful, that does not patronize winter concerts" and for providing "music for relaxation rather than uplift" in an atmosphere of informality and sociability.
BUENOS AIRES, May 30 -- President Alfredo Stroessner suspended his experiment in "controlled democracy" in Paraguay today, dissolving the Chamber of Deputies and restoring a state of siege.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -The House Foreign Affairs Committee is expected to propose amendments to the Mutual Security Act that would tighten the conditions on military aid to some less-developed nations and put more emphasis on economic aid.

ODEON and Pathe are the names of two of the oldest and most respected record companies in France. Through the years both have built up especially large catalogues, and both have had more than their share of collectors' items.

In the display of photographs entitled "Portraits of Natural Laws" (May 17), there was one that struck me particularly, not only because of its appearance but because of what was said about it. A wrench thrown through the air "seems to be wildly tumbling" but "the center of mass travels a smooth trajectory."
MEXICO CITY, May 30 (AP) -- While the police held for questioning a United States woman robbed of 3,676,500 Cuban pesos, belief grew today that the robber had made good his escape.
Each year, many families come to the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery, 540 East Seven ty-sixth Street, to seek help. Their story, for the most part, is simple.

Many debutantes of the 1959-60 season will begin their round of parties with dances and dinners in the June "little season" on Long Island. During Thanksgiving week and the Christmas holidays they will make formal bows in New York at the annual cotillions and presentation fetes.
CINCINNATI, May 30 (AP) -- Roy Face, Pittsburgh's reliefpitching artist, entered in the eighth inning today and protected a 3-1 victory for Bennie Daniels over the Cincinnati Reds.
The Southampton Horse Show at Southampton, L. I., will be a two-day event this year divided between English and Western saddle classes. The dates will be Aug. 8 and 9.

Along with three other people I am contemplating renting a thirty-foot cruiser for a two-week period during the summer and cruising up to Cape Cod. Unfortunately, the boating fraternity has never got around to organizing a nautical version of the American Automobile Association.
The closing on Mondays of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, scheduled to begin July 6, has created indignation among the museum's large following.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy described Mr. Hoffa tonight as a man who surrounds himself with "thieves and racketeers and crooks and Fifth Amendment people."

The excellent article "Why Russia Needs the Iron Curtain" by William J. Jorden (May 3), states: "The most elaborate system of radio jamming known keeps the Russian people from hearing news or 'propaganda' from the outside world."

SALEM, Mass. -- New England history from the Sixteen Thirties on is graphically displayed in many scores of houses, some primitive, some ornate, in this venerable and beautiful region. From the earliest arrival of white men on these coasts, their habitations have remained as a standing record of their lives and development.
MORPETH, England, May 30 (Reuters) -- Officialdom here recognized today the right of a man to live in a tree.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 30 (Reuters) -- Premier Khrushchev attacked West German "militarists" today and criticized France for backing them.
HAVANA, May 30 -- Cubans and the outside world are today attempting to measure the degree of influence the Communists have in the revolutionary government of Premier Fidel Castro.
BUDAPEST, May 30 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's surprise visit to tiny Albania looks from this part of the world more and more like a try for a political triple play.
CORNWALL, Ont., May 28 -An unusual rehabilitation program is thriving near here in a series of villages and towns along Lake St. Lawrence.

GENEVA, May 30 -- All those connected with the foreign ministers' conference here this week were professing utter boredom with the proceedings and consoling themselves that the real business of the negotiations finally seemed at hand.

TULSA, Okla., May 30 (AP) -- Ham Richardson, first-seeded player from Washington, defeated Gene Land of Oklahoma City, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, in the semiFinal round of the Tulsa tennis club's invitation tournament today.

SOMEHOW an excess of women and women's problems seemed to flood the screen last week, putting the steady (male) filmgoer in peril of being swamped. Not that there's anything wrong with women or with their problems. After all there are only two kinds of people about which you can make movies. Woman is one of them.

THE costumes, properties and all the portable scenery of the Dallas (Tex.) Civic Opera Company's production of Cherubini's "Medea" are taking two transoceanic boat rides this year. Last week the Queen Mary delivered them to Southampton to reach London for five performances of the opera at Covent Garden, starting June 17. Later they will be shipped back to Dallas to be reused by the company on Nov. 19 and 21.

BOCABEC, N. B., May 30 -- To somebody must go the first striped bass caught at the mouth of the Digdeguash River, which empties into the Bay of St. Andrews, an arm of the Bay of Fundy. But who gets the honor of this marvelous thing?

ISTANBUL, Turkey -- Although most tourists never think of this ancient city, built, like Rome, upon seven hills, as a seaside resort, that is what it is rapidly becoming, thanks to the construction of new hotels fronting the Sea of Marmara and the Black Sea.

The recovery of two small monkeys after a fifteen-minute round-trip journey into space in the nose-cone of a Jupiter rocket, which took them to an altitude of 300 miles at a speed that reached 10,000 miles an hour, has provided dramatic confirmation of earlier experiments which had indicated that higher animals can survive flight into the outer reaches of the atmosphere and into space itself.

NEW plants are the prima donnas of the garden world. Where do they come from? A great many of them have arrived in this land through the efforts of plant explorers. Others have been introduced by nurseries and plant breeders.

OIL products have rewritten the history of transportation in every field. The industrial revolution sparked by the discovery of the first well 100 years ago has brought sweeping changes in moving people about the globe, whether by sea, in the air or on the ground.
Following are salient facts on the foreign ministers' conference at United Nations headquarters in Geneva:

To the Drama Editor: THE raves for "Gypsy" point out anew how premature are the awards each spring by the New York Drama Critics Circle. Their impatience mocks and confuses the traditional theatrical calendar, so long and generally acknowledged.

Stationery shops carry humorous signs: "This is a non-profit-making organization. We didn't plan it that way but that's how it turned out." Kratter Corporation, which started business a month ago, seems to have been planned that way.

Britain, a nation that "must trade or die," has fought an uphill battle since the end of World War II to reestablish its world trade position. The wartime devastation of Britain's industrial plant, the loss of many of its colonial markets, a severe dollar shortage, and Western restrictions on trade with Communist countries have posed formidable obstacles.

To the Travel Editor: In your issue of May 17th is a letter by C. Vernon Kane, of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on the subject of credit cards. In this letter appears the following statement: "Stripped of all frills, the credit card is simply a system of borrowing money."
LONDON, May 30 -- Leading citizens of North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries are to assemble here Friday to study means of developing greater unity within the Atlantic community.
BALBOA, C. Z. May 29 -- Several tests are being made in the Panama Canal of new methods for handling ships while they are in the locks or transiting the narrower reaches of the channels.

FROM East Coast to West Coast and from the Canadian border to the Rio Grande, sweeping changes since the mid-Nineteen Thirties have transformed natural gas from a bothersome waste product into a valuable fuel resource serving more than 31,000,000 home and industrial accounts in 1958.
NEW and old are certainly relative terms, for the last-minute novelty of the season happens to date back specifically to the ninth century, and more generally all the way to the seventh.

In "Friends and Foes of Columba Livia" (May 3), David Dempsey's coined word, "pigeonogynist," for "pigeon-hater," was an unhappy flight; but Mr. Glassman's correction, "columbaphobe" "Letters" (May 17), half Latin and half Greek, hardly gets off the ground.

Merchants varied sharply as the week drew to a close on their estimates of department store volume, chiefly because of the holiday that ended the week. The estimates ranged from about even to 7 per cent above 1958 levels.
DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- Little Sombrero, a Pennsylvania-bred gelding, won the working hunter championship of the sixty-third annual Devon horse show tonight.
GALVESTON, Tex., May 30 -Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana entered John Sealy Hospital here today and was placed under the care of a noted psychiatrist.

MENTAL hospitals have never stood high in the public regard despite some excellent work which is done in them under difficult conditions. Regarded by some as historic accidents, they were founded originally to get the sick out of poorhouses and prisons, cellars and garrets.
PELHAM, N. Y., May 30 -The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia won the senior eightoared race for the James H. Hughes Trophy today on the 2,000-meter lagoon course at Travers Island.
OUT of every ten barrels of oil produced in the free world, nearly nine come from three places: the United States, the Middle East and Venezuela.

Sooner or later during a yachting season, in a fog or other marine emergency, the small-boat skipper needs a loud voice. Occasional craft still have on board the old style horn with a wooden or metal mouth-piece. Leather-lunged old salts never knew any other kind.
The Lighthouse Gala Ball, planned for Nov. 12 at the Waldoff-Astoria, hopes to raise $100,000 toward the annual operating expenses of the New York Association for the Blind.

Modern paintings, drawings and prints, together with Old Masters and eighteenth and nineteenth century works, will be auctioned on Wednesday and Thursday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
PARIS, May 30 (AP) -Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy overpowered Ian Vermaak of South Africa today in the men's singles final of the French national tennis tournament, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

BROADWAY has provided employment for three horses this season at an aggregate wage of $450 week, before taxes. The brutes are Jordan in "Rashomon," Athos in "La Plume de Ma Tante," and Tommy in "The Music Man."
Bishop Frederick Buckley Newell of the New York Area of the Methodist Church reported to his constituents last week that the area was the most integrated of any in the denomination.
Ten years and 1,012 cases ago Theodore W. Kheel was named impartial chairman of New York's turbulent private transit industry after a period of strikes and threatened strikes.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 30 -- The United States Military Academy will graduate its 161st class Wednesday morning.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Although this island resort has long been identified with winter vacationing, it is now holding out the welcome sign for summer visitors at greatly reduced rates. The large hotels that have long catered to affluent winter visitors are closed for the summer months but there are many luxury motels on South Ocean Boulevard facing the ocean where summer accommodations are obtainable at about half the winter price.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- A visitor to Western Europe these days is impressed by the change in the political questions of intelligent Europeans about the United States. They no longer ask how is Eisenhower, but who will succeed him.

The most appalling aspect of the current wheat surplus seems to be completely ignored. To produce more food than needed is bad enough. But infinitely more serious is the fact that production occurs at the cost of unavoidable shortages in the well-foreseeable future.
There is a school in one corner of the sprawling Bayonne Naval Base where grown men "play" with fire and learn ABC's.

After surrendering a goal in the first minute of play, the Legia eleven of Poland scored eight times in the second half and routed Hakoah, the American Soccer League champion, 8 -- 1, at Ebbets Field yesterday.
Painters appeared yesterday in the heart of Greenwich Village. But were they painting landscapes, portraits, nudes? No.

DUNEDIN, Fla., May 30 (UPI) -- Duffers across the nation will have a chance to beat the United States Open champion, Tommy Bolt, and the Professional Golfers Association title-holder, Dow Finsterwald, this week.

THE paperbound semi-annual "New World Writing" has, with its fifteenth issue, suspended publication. The New American Library, which brought it out, felt it took too much editorial time for the less than overpowering newsstand circulation it had.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 30 -Any lingering Western hopes for an early economic or political split between Communist China and the Soviet Union received a severe setback last month. The appointment of the Moscow-trained, super-party- line theorist Liu Shao-chi to replace Mao Tse-tung as Chairman of the Peoples Republic once again made it clear that Communist China was not destined to become an Asian Yugoslavia in the near future.

To the Travel Editor: We read with great interest the series of articles in the Travel Section of The New York Times which discussed credit cards, discount services and the interesting arrangement suggested by Mr. Kane wherein he recommends that credit card clubs reduce their percentage to 1 per cent and raise their annual fee to $25 to the card holder.
Three apartment developments and a modern shopping center in Queens have been sold for more than $55,000,000 in one of the largest real estate transactions in the borough's history.

IN the 100 years since the drilling of the first successful well the petroleum industry has evolved into one of the largest industrial activities with a gross investment approximating $100,000,000,000.
The pulse of the art world has slowed to something less than half of normal with the coming of June.
TALL, vertical accent plants lend interest and drama to the rounded outlines of the flower border. There are many spired perennials, biennials and annuals that provide needed height.

Deposits in .the state's 128 mutual savings banks rose $7.757,000 during April to $20,421,645,000 in 11,409,852 accounts, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York has reported. A year before, deposits totaled $19,123,228,000 in 11,031,973 accounts.

THE yellow gorse was blooming in the hedgerows, and the green hills of England were never lovelier than on that spring evening of crisis fifteen years ago. In all the southern towns the pubs were strangely quiet, the streets were empty. Time seemed to have stopped.

The judicial ruling that Louisiana's statute requiring segregation in sport is unconstitutional is a triumph for both justice and common sense. Such a finding was inevitable under the law and the Supreme Court's interpretation of it. It is welcome because it is realistic and will prevent the turning back of the clock.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., May 30 (AP) -- The sole senior among twenty-one Negroes at Warren County High School here lacks one credit for graduation.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 30 -- A tradition will end at the Naval Academy's graduation ceremonies Wednesday in the Field House. Out of the graduating class of 802, six midshipmen will be commissioned in the Army.
GENEVA, May 30 -- Britain unwrapped the Western package plan today by inviting the Soviet Union to negotiate an improved situation in West Berlin.

To the Screen Editor: Mr. Crowther's Sunday article on movie buffs may elicit a few barbs from the aficionados like myself, who resent the "otherwise average" tag on the "Ziegfeld Follies of 1946." What about that wonderful "Numbers, Please" routine? And what about Gershwin's "The Babbitt and the Bromide" with Kelly and Astaire?

The American high school, unlike those in many other countries, has the task of educating youths of a wide range of abilities and interests. It must provide for pupils with both high and low I. Q.'s, and for those who want vocational as well for those who want academic training.
The straw hat season is booming and the outlook for fall hats is excellent, manufacturers report. Orders for straw hats are as much as 30 per cent greater than last year's.
ART may be a commonplace in the home today but, as every family discovers after settling down with its first acquisition, something special is needed in the way of display.

MOSCOW, May 30 -- One of the Soviet Union's leading writers has composed a writer's credo based on true belief in country, willingness to speak frankly about unpleasant things, hatred for anti-Semitism and racial prejudice and understanding of the "unity of world culture. "

JAPANESE art is certainly quantitative if not always qualitative. In any one week Tokyo will have special art shows at no fewer than seven department stores and eleven major galleries, and several of these will hold two or three exhibitions at the same time.

ALTHOUGH the current war of words between North and South has reduced communications between the embittered sections, it has not discouraged a Southerner living in New England from attempting to "breach the wall of emotional misunderstanding which has risen between the South and the rest of the country."

SHORTWAVE listening, once a popular pastime in the days before people sought Nirvana in television, is on the rise the world over. At least that is the opinion of O. Lund Johansen, a white-haired Dane who edits one of the world's most complete guides of when and where to tune in on whomever one is interested in hearing.

GENEVA, May 30 -- A thousand differences of birth, education, training and belief separate Christian A. Herter and Andrei A. Gromyko. But circumstances have cast them for similar roles in the foreign ministers' conference here.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- Tom Morgan of Detroit wild-pitched across one run in the eighth inning and made a balk leading to the decisive run in the ninth as the Chicago White Sox took the second game of a double-header 4 -- 3, today. The Tigers won the opener, 4 -- 2.

LOS ANGELES, May 30 -- Self-styled defenders of "Americanism" and "three R's" in education claimed a victory in city elections this week while the citizenry at large won a point in governmental economy.

LOS ANGELES, May 30 -- Organized labor bought half-page newspaper advertisements this week to protest as "a gross miscarriage of justice" the short prison term given a painting contractor who had shot a union representative to death.
BASS ISLANDS, Lake Erie -- Toward the extreme western end of Lake Erie lie the beautiful and historic Bass Islands, with their surrounding archipelago, comprising some twenty islands in all.
New York City will be the center of the world oil industry this week.

To the Travel Editor: IN behalf of the civic, historical, service and business organizations of Gettysburg, which I was privileged to represent in the hearings before the Department of Interior and Related Agencies Committee of the Committee on Appropriations of the United States Senate, I want to thank you for the article, "War Sites in Peril," which you published in the May 24 Travel Section.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 30 -Premier Abdul Karim Kassim indicated today that he felt ready and able to check the Communist party of Iraq if he ever deemed it a threat to "the rights of the people."

REBEL blue, Tory green and King George's hated red flash brightly through this embattled tale of Gwen Bristow's native South Carolina. But not even "Butcher" Tarleton knows what swamp-dun hue is worn by Marion's guerrillas.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., May 30 -- Sports car drivers from twenty-six states gathered for the annual two-day racing jamboree at this village's Grand Prix course today and were almost able to get their program under way on schedule.

MODESTO, Calif., May 30 -The University of Texas' sprint relay team bettered the world mark for the 440-yard relay with a clocking of 39.6 seconds and Roscoe Cook of Oregon equaled the world mark of 9.3 seconds in the 100-yard dash at the California relays tonight.

A YEAR ago, Tommy Flach, aged 9, of Camp Hill, Pa., was given a new fountain pen by his grandmother. Apparently inspired by the TV program, he sat down and with it dashed off "The missing clue with Perry Mason.

IN the past three years, the Supreme Court has been denounced for "judicial misbehavior" by a wide assortment of critics, ranging from the American Bar Association and Southern officialdom to state court judges and the Daughters of the American Revolution. Bills and constitutional amendments have been sponsored in Congress to limit the Court's jurisdiction, and to make the justices think twice before extending their "offensive" doctrines.

HAVANA, May 30 -- All foreign or domestic commercial, industrial, mercantile, financing, agricultural and some other types of companies in Cuba will be taxed 40 per cent of their profits in a new tax law that will be enacted by the revolutionary Government.

David Wallace is a young lawyer whose career so far reaffirms the value of being in the right place at the right time. He went to the Alleghany Corporation as resident counsel in 1954, just as that huge investment company was heading into a cluster of lawsuits extraordinary even for the concern that has sometimes been nicknamed "Litigation, Inc."

ONE of the supremely ecstatic and mystical paintings in the world, El Greco's "St John's Vision of the Mysteries of the Apocalypse," a picture which seems to transcend the limitations of human understanding, is now for the first time on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art which acquired it in 1956.
Fourteen short years ago this Memorial Day week-end, investigators of the United Nations War Crimes Commission arrived in Europe to begin the long task of compiling evidence on Nazi atrocities.

The Yankees put on a display of power yesterday in crushing the Senators, 11 -- 2 and 11 -- 0. The Indians split with the Athletics, winning, 3 -- 2, and losing, 3 -- 1. The Red Sox beat the Orioles, 5 -- 4, 8 -- 3. The Braves topped the Phils, 4 -- 2.

AARHUS, Denmark, May 30 (AP) -- All nine opposition members of the City Council -- including one Communist -- boycotted the official program today when Yugoslav Vice President Edvard Kardelj arrived for a two-day visit.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The President smiled when he "suggested" to Chancellor Adenauer that the Big Four Foreign Ministers should remain aloft in the airplane which bore them back to Geneva from Washington until they had reached an agreement. And he chuckled when he added that if necessary he would arrange for a tanker plane to refuel theirs in the air.

An opportunity for amateur shell collectors to meet the experts will occur June 30 through July 3 when scientists of the American Malacological Union break with tradition at their twenty-fifth annual meeting and admit novices to hear discussions on popular topics on conchology.

IN May the low-growing perennial herb known as sweet woodruff (Asperula odorata) makes its debut. The white four-petaled blossoms and the green whorl of slender, starlike leaves are distinctive assets. In wine-making regions the plant is used as a flavoring agent for May wine.

IN this book, Andre Maurois has turned his attention to one of the most famous success stories of our time. The story is centered around penicillin, still today the most spectacular achievement of therapeutic medicine.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 30 -- Back in 1955, not long after he had moved into the Governor's chair, Orval Eugene Faubus observed that "in politics it's often your friends that give you the most trouble."
Art Quirk, a pitcher for Dartmouth College, recently hurled a 1-0 shutout against Brown University and his team-mates gave the "game ball" -- the ball in play when the final out was made -- to him.

SOME of the most spectacular collisions between white mariners and savage tribesmen occurred along the North Pacific seacoast, where towering fiords imprison the ocean in deep, timbered chasms. Three nations -- England, Russia and the embryonic United States -sent their sailing vessels in quest of furs and a quick passage to India.
TELEVISION last week experienced another of those top-echelon shakeups that periodically set the industry agog.

NEW ORLEANS, May 30 (AP) -- The season's first tropical storm, Arlene, swung into Louisiana today. It skipped across the small town of Franklin, blowing down some branches and disrupting electrical power, then headed into the marshlands.
Progress toward a settlement of the three-week-old hospital strike was disclosed yesterday by William H. Davis, chairman of Mayor Wagner's mediation board.

" CONTINENTAL CLASSROOM," a pioneering educational series now televised by the National Broadcasting Company, would expand to other networks under plans being formulated by various groups interested in educational television.

The stewards of a United States Air Force plane that took off from Washington at 3 P. M. last Friday had laid in a supply of vodka, along with other drinks and the materials for a tasty dinner consisting of hers d'oeuvres, fresh fruit cocktail, roast turkey, crabmeat salad and strawberry tart. Mr. Gromyko, one of the passengers, did not take the vodka. He asked for and drank three or four slugs of Coca-Cola.
A special upper-air center to provide pre-flight weather data for jet airliners and other long-range planes has been set up by American Airlines.
YONKERS, May 30 -- A crowd of 36,459 at Yonkers Raceway saw Jimmy Cruise turn in an almost incredible job of driving as he saved himself from a nasty spill tonight.

BONN, Germany, May 30 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer returned to Bonn from Washington today after having attended the funeral of John Foster Dulles and having held talks with leading United States statesmen.

SIXTEEN years ago John Chamberlain, as a New York Times reviewer, called James Burnham "an interesting problem." Once "a believer in medieval scholasticism" and later "a Marxist and a Trotskyist," Mr. Burnham had become "an old-fashioned American liberal."

PETROLEUM must have been created just for petrochemicals. No other natural material is more suited for chemical production than crude oil, natural gas or natural gas liquids. This conglomerate of precisely formed hydrocarbons lends itself to untold combinations and reactions to produce a broad range of products.

ONCE when I was climbing a hill in Uganda I came upon a small creeping plant starred with tiny yellow flowers. "That's the toothache plant," said my companion, a trained botanist. Witch doctors, he explained, used an infusion of the flower to treat toothache.
LOS ANGELES, May 30 -- Thirty-three years of doodling in metal and concrete by an immigrant mason suddenly became the focus this week of an art controversy that reverberated from coast to coast.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -Scientists and the two space monkeys, Able and Baker, presided at a news conference today.

THE Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has caught the public's imagination because the decision to build afresh opens exciting new vistas. Questions of architecture, seating capacity and acoustics are still in the forefront of discussions, and not far behind have been the quickened hopes that the member institutions of the Lincoln Center will have the opportunity to do their work more efficiently and more imaginatively.

MOSCOW, May 30 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev rejected today proposals by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter for Berlin and Germany at the Geneva foreign ministers' conference. He accused the West of "horse-dealing tricks" in the crucial negotiations.
" COMPARED with what it was like when I broke into the big leagues," said Mike Higgins, "the kids of today have it easy."

THE new six-story 200-room Sheraton Inn opened last Sunday in Binghamton, N. Y. It is, according to Sheraton officials, the first "downtown" hotel to be built in upstate New York in more than thirty years.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 30 (Reuters) -- Philip Gunawardene, former Minister of Food and Agriculture, said last night Ceylon's opposition parties would join together and force the Government of S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike out of office if it did not hold new elections.
Alden Ward, who wrote against "Wozzeck" and who wants to get back to things "healthy and comfortable and sane," sounds as if he's running for office on the Coolidge ticket.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 30 Navy salvaged the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League title by beating Army, 4 -- 3, in twelve innings today. A sellout gathering of 5,000 at Doubleday Field saw the midshipmen post their eighth victory against one league defeat.

ONE night recently, Hugh Downs, the National Broadcasting Company announcer, was about to deliver a commercial during the "Jack Paar Show." As he read the copy he noted that it required him to give viewers the impression that he had witnessed a test that proved the quality of the product being advertised.

THIS first novel is an avalanche of small-town gossip tumbling from the lips of Gladys Wilcox, wife of a Stringtown filling station owner in the heart of the Mississippi Delta. Gladys' monologue (as Mississippi-born novelist George Patterson replays it) is heard by two long-suffering listeners on the August wedding day of Chardene Montgomery and Bubba Johnson, both members of high-class families out on Egypt Ridge.

IT seems almost impossible to assume a middle-of-the-road attitude toward modern music in Germany today. This fact has been forcefully illustrated recently by Alois Melichar's new book, "Music in the Straitjacket" and by the stormy manner with which both press and public have reacted to it.

The Brookmeade Stable's Sword Dancer discarded his runner-up role for the Metropolitan Mile at Belmont Park yesterday. Ridden by Willie Shoemaker, the 3-year-old son of Sunglow won the $115,900 handicap by more than three lengths from Myron Goodwin's Jimmer while covering the distance in the good time of 1:35 1/5.

SANDWICH, England, May 30 -Deane Beman, a crewcut collegian from Silver Spring, Md., became the eleventh -- and youngest -- American winner of the British Amateur golf championship today. He beat William Hyndman 3d, 3 and 2, in the scheduled 36-hole all-United States final over the Royal St. George's Links.

RYE, N. Y., May 30 -- When today's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound sailing was finished, one skipper had a fairly firm position for a special prize. He was Edgar Craig of the Larchmont Y. C. in the Herreshoff's Class boat Polaris.

PRODUCER William Goetz and Director Charles Vidor, here in this historic city for the filming of "A Magic Flame," the life story of Franz Liszt, are discovering that moviemaking in Vienna is not a waltz.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 (UPI) -- Mike McCormick struck out eleven batters and pitched a five-hitter today as the San Francisco Giants scored a 5-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
An issue as old as the spear and the shield -- the struggle between offense and defense -- provided last week the background for the latest Pentagon controversy.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -Harmon Killebrew, the 22-year-old slugger from Payette, Idaho, whose sensational clouting suddenly has made him the man of the hour in the nation's capital, hit his eighteenth home run today.

THE age of oil has revolutionized the life of man. The impact of this fuel upon technical developments, grand strategy, the economies of power, social structures -- and hence, upon international politics -- has been profound.

JUST one century ago, on the afternoon of Saturday, Aug. 27, 1859, Uncle Billy Smith and his two sons, working for "Colonel" Edwin L. Drake, struck oil at Titusville in northwest Pennsylvania. It had taken Drake, a former train conductor, more than a year to dig his well, just 69 1/2 feet deep. With his discovery that afternoon, the history of the American petroleum industry began.
AFTER the presence of oil has been indicated by thorough exploration, the next question obviously is: How is the oil brought out of the ground? The answer -- equally obvious -- is by drilling.

New York City has 148 hospitals -- 81 of them "voluntary" institutions (private, non-profit); 45 of them "proprietary" (private, profitmaking); and 22 of them cityowned. In recent months unions have mounted a drive to organize the non-professional help at the voluntary and proprietary hospitals -- nurses' aides and orderlies, porters, launderers, laboratory technicians and kitchen help.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- By now it is clear to most of the potential Democratic candidates for President what routine is expected of them when they come to assay the California political soil a whole year ahead of their campaigns.
LONDON, May 30 - Big Ben! Big Ben! The clock they could not kill, Chime out again and tell all men That England's England still.
ROME, May 30 -- When the Sicilians go to the polls Sunday, June 7, to elect a new regional parliament they will show to what extent they heed Roman Catholic Church dictates in the field of politics.

There will be a power lawn mower on sale at the local supermarket before very long. There'll still be food, and plenty of it, but here and there partitions will go up, and shoe departments, clothing sections, hardware displays and more will move in.

IT is rare that we have a chance to hear Haydn's works for the baryton and even rarer to hear them performed on the odd instrument for which they were intended. Haydn's patron, Prince Nicholas Esterhazy, was a passionate amateur performer on the baryton.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McCellan accused James R. Hoffa today of juggling figures to make it appear that the Teamsters Union had been growing.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 30 (AP) -- Five thousand Greek Cypriote delegates attended today the opening of the first congress of E. D. M. A., a political organization formed by district leaders the old E. O. K. A. underground movement.

MILES CITY, Mont. -- This southeastern Montana prairie town, which glories in the title of Cow Capital, is recovering these days from the recent celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Montana Stock Growers Association, that hard-riding body of cattlemen who banded together in those rough days to take drastic action against the rustlers and the bad Indians.
Three would-be safecrackers came to grief yesterday because they had been too absorbed in their planning to notice that the police had been following them for three weeks.

IN this book Louis J. Halle has brought to bear on his reading of standard textbooks and secondary works his experience acquired the hard way in what he calls the "engine room" -- the policy planning staff of the Department of State.
WHITE PLAINS, May 30 -- The Westchester Community College is at one of the crossroads of its thirteen-year life.

The recent marketing of $104,760,000 of Federally-subsidized public housing bonds was an emphatic commentary on the way investment yields on the obligations of local governments have risen in recent years to the best relative values in the bond market's history.

Following are excerpts, supplied by Reuters, from a speech by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and the text of an address, supplied by The United Press International, of a speech by Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd of Britain at the foreign ministers conference in Geneva:
I am delighted that Margaret Mead in "Job of the Children's Mother's Husband" (May 10) has at last caught sight of the obvious, if only in the very last paragraph of her article:

CLEVELAND, May 30 -- Rip Coleman gave only six hits in pitching the Kansas City Athletics to a 3-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the second game of a double-header today. The Indians won the opener, 3 -- 2.
The New York City office of the United States Weather Bureau has announced two new weather services for boating and fishing interests.

A CAUSE of delay and of general distress familiar to all publishers is the disease of title fever which, oddly, often becomes acute while a book is "in hand." Outsiders think an author writes his title before he starts his book.

ONE of the most controversial of the new bidding conventions is a new kind of double, best known by its nickname, the "sputnik." Like the "unusual no-trump," described in this department last week, the sputnik is an innovation of the Roth-Stone system of bidding; but unlike the unusual no-trump, the sputnik has not yet been adopted into other bidding systems.

OIL when poured on political waters, has generally reversed its traditionally pacific role by making them more troubled and turbulent. Almost from the turn of the century, when petroleum and its by-products became a measurable factor in the economic life of the nation, oil has been at the center of one political storm after another.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 30 -- President Luis A. Somoza Debayle suspended guarantees of some basic civil rights today and imposed limited martial law throughout Nicaragua.

FROM coast to coast June's festivals and pageants mark the beginning of the summer vacation season. The tourist calendar for the month covers a wide range of interests, from cultural events to sports competitions. Among them are the following:

HAVANA, May 30 -- Two Americans, Jake Lansky, one of the owners, and Dino Cellino, manager of the casino in the Hotel Havana Riviera, who had been detained for twenty-five days, subject to deportation, were released tonight by order of the Minister of Interior, Luis Orlando Rodriguez. They had been held in Tiscornia Emigration Station.

NEWARK, May 30 -- An elaborate program of music, drama and ballet has been arranged for Newark's first arts festival next week. The event will commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the Newark Museum.
Continuing business concern with the decline in United States exports suggests the need for a corresponding emphasis on factors tending to put the issue in more rational perspective.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- A cross-section of American painting and sculpture from 1918 to the present will be displayed at the United States National Exhibition in Moscow next summer.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -A record crowd of 200,000 saw Rodger Ward of Indianapolis win the forty-third 500-mile auto race today in a Leader Card Special. He set a race record of 135.857 miles per hour, eclipsing the mark of 135.601 set by Sam Hanks in 1957.
Electronic devices that make life more pleasant and efficient stream daily from laboratories and plants that were designed for the forging of weapons of war.
GENEVA, May 30 -- Geneva will recall during week-long ceremonies starting tomorrow its historic association with the Reformation.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., May 30 -- Plans for the annual East Hampton Ladies Village Improvement Society Fair July 31 were announced this week by the fair chairman, Mrs. M. A. Kennard. The plans were discussed at the group's May meeting, held at the summer home of its president, Mrs. Ellery S. James.
The five-year trade agreement reached by Britain and the Soviet Union last week marked an important breakthrough in Moscow's campaign to secure a sharp rise in East-West trade.

THE small merchants whose fortunes depend on the volume of tourist traffic along Maryland's Eastern Shore figuratively have stolen a section of a main New York to Florida route from rival motel and restaurant owners in the bustling Baltimore area.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The career of the Rev. James Clark Brown combines religion and government.

To the Screen Editor: Mystery award of the year ought to go to Billy Wilder, as a credit to the bewilderment his latest cinematic adventure arouses in the minds of his admirers. What could have possibly induced him to make "Some Like It Hot"? Is this utterly tasteless and puerile film designed as a holiday for transvestites, a kind of inside joke for the benefit of those in the "know"?
The 1958 edition of The New York Times Index was published yesterday.

For the fourth time since the evidence of business recovery became unmistakable last September, action has been initiated by the Federal Reserve System looking toward a general rise in the rediscount rate. The first move in that direction became effective last Friday, when five of the twelve district banks moved their rates from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, May 26 -- A new castle stands in Hiroshima. To many Japanese, and visitors from other lands, the stately structure of five tiled roofs one above another is a symbol of a people's ability to rise over any catastrophe.

To the Drama Editor: I hate to see such a figure in our theatrical annals as Joe Cook depart from our midst (even though he had not been around much since his illness began) without at least one small fanfare of muted trumpets. Maybe it's because Joe has meant something to me personally.

Dr. Paul R. Hawley, director of the American College of Surgeons, said at a meeting of the Group Health Institute in New York last week that "it is now reliably estimated that today one-half of the surgical operations in the United States are performed by doctors who are untrained, or inadequately trained, to undertake surgery."

To the Travel Editor: My only interest in the credit card systems is that I am a member of two of them. The law of common sense dictates that a $25 per annum charge for a credit card would effectively kill the card company.

For anyone who had doubts about the recovery from last year's recession, Secretary of Commerce Lewis L. Strauss had strong words last week: "By now even those who were most reserved in their appraisal of the upswing recognize we have a strong recovery under way."
MINEOLA, L. I., May 30 -- Public-school operating budgets and bond issues totaling more than $50,000,000 will be recommended to Nassau County voters in thirteen districts in June.
Across the nation and at military cemeteries abroad Americans paid tribute to their war dead yesterday.

HALIFAX, N. S., May 30 (Canadian Press) -- T. H. Glynn Michael, general manager of the Chemical Institute of Canada, said in an interview this week there are approximately two job opportunities for every chemistry and chemical engineering graduate in Canada this year.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- L. Corrin Strong, philanthropist, art patron and former Ambassador to Norway, will head a national campaign to raise funds for construction of the National Cultural Center here.

Appropriations totaling $110,203,000 next year for the National Institute of Cancer were recommended last week in testimony before the Senate Subcommittee on Appropriations for Health, Education and Welfare by Dr. Sidney Farber of the Harvard Medical School and Dr. I. S. Ravdin of the School of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, The total exceeds the Administration's proposal by $34,985,000 and the recent House vote by $26,895,000.

DETROIT, May 30 -- Michigan's economy has improved substantially in recent months but additional income is needed for the Unemployment Compensation Fund, the Michigan Employment Security Commission indicated this week.

AMONG the alibis of producers, directors and actors whose films are not profitable is: "How could any movie make money with that title?" The rose that smells as sweet by any other name does not grow in the movie business.

The undiminished importance of the Mediterranean to the Soviet Union has been brought out by Nikita S. Khrushchev's visit to Albania, the smallest and most backward of the Soviet satellites, but the only one with access to the Mediterranean.
The lot of shippers of small general cargo shipments of merchandise from East Coast ports to exotic destinations in the Southwest Pacific has been eased considerably.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 30 -- W. Arnold Hanger's Waltz waltzed to an eleven-length victory in the eighteenth and final running of the Jersey Stakes at Garden State Park today.

" YOU'RE the top," Ethel Merman sang zestfully in "Anything Goes." That was in 1934 and, ever since, Broadway has been singing it right back to her. Indeed, with "Gypsy," the town's newest hit, the monumental Miss Merman may have topped her past glories, among which some 5,000 performances in a dozen major musicals stand out.
A state liquor administrator believes that state governments should seriously consider abandoning their controls over interstate liquor advertising, which duplicate Federal regulation.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., May 30 -- Rupert Waltl, a 23-year-old German-born cyclist from Brooklyn, coasted home 450 yards ahead of the rest of the field today in the sixteenth annual fifty-mile Tour of Somerville.

BUFFALO, May 30 -- The future of the Welland Ship Canal as the key to tomorrow's shipping between the Atlantic and the Great Lakes is being widely discussed by maritime experts on both sides of the border.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 30 -- Substantial progress since the start of the year in the improvement of living standards and government planning is clearly evident here.

THERE is a moral to Robin Maugham's "The Man With Two Shadows," -- a novel which is both a story of intrigue in North Africa and a psychological case history. The moral is that schizophrenics do not make the best undercover agents.
Frankie Carbo, shadowy figure of the boxing underworld, was freed on a $25,000 bond in Camden County, N. J., Court yesterday afternoon after a twenty-minute hearing.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 30 -- The forest ranger service on Long Island is to be discontinued next September by the State Conservation Department.

THE era of specialization has left its mark on nostalgic Americans. It is fashionable to be an authority on country stores, covered bridges, old trolley cars, country auctions, folk lore, rural music, pewter, and recipes for elderberry wine.

HARTFORD, May 30 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff announced today that he and members of the State Development Commission were going to California next month to meet representatives of industries that might be planning to establish branches in the East.

Electronics stocks took off again last week on another spectacular rise, pushing the market averages into new high ground. But for the rest of the market, it was more of the same -- stocks moved irregularly in slow trading.
CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- Manassas, the 14-5 favorite owned by Mr. and Mrs. John Zitnik of East St. Louis, Ill., won the $57,850 Balmoral Turf Handicap by a neck in Washington Park today.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 30 -The fourteenth Storm Trysail Club's race around Block Island was shrouded in fog today. The committee at Stamford Yacht Club tonight was unable to even venture a guess as to when the first finisher would arrive.

THERE'S a new state out in the wide blue yonder, and a new state -- the one under discussion is Hawaii -- must have a literary life. This one does. James A. Michener lives there now, and indeed his next book is called "Hawaii." William Lederer, co-author of "The Ugly American," lives there, too.

SHERIDAN, Wyo. -- Motorists en route to Yellowstone National Park, 202 miles to the west of here, have the opportunity, by making a brief detour, to add their own theories to an archaeological mystery that has puzzled visitors for generations.
Natural gas comes officially to the peninsula of Florida tomorrow.

DETROIT -- Motorists driving across country on the chain of turnpikes that link the East Coast and Midwest will find it easier than ever this year to make a side trip up to Detroit to see how an automobile is built Last month a new toll-free segment of the Toledo-Detroit Expressway, which connects Detroit with the Ohio Turnpike, was opened to the public.
The secret of successful track coaching, says Vern Wolfe, is psychology.

LES BAUX DE PROVENCE, France -- From the ramparts of the ruined castle which surmounts this ancient village, the view is superb. To the south, twenty-five miles away, the Mediterranean shimmers in the sun. Twelve miles to the west, the ribbon of blue which is the Rhone River reaches to meet the sea, branching out into tributaries as it gets close.

LIMA, Peru, May 30 -- The Peruvian Government emerged victorious in this week's contest with the country's largest Opposition party, but it will continue to face a difficult problem until it decides the case of Fernando Belaunde Terry, head of the Popular Action party.

STATISTICS on birth rates and changing family sizes can make pretty dull reading when they are presented in tables or charts. Those figures affect everyday life, however, in a multitude of ways most people never think about.
The passage last week by the State of New Jersey of legislation permitting the sale by life insurance companies of variable annuities elicited a mixed reaction in the financial community.
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -- Iron ore mined in Canada has begun moving through the St. Lawrence Seaway to United States steel mills.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 30 -- In Zandvoort centuries ago the North Sea pounded the edge of low, flat Holland into towering sand dunes, some a hundred or more feet high and all of them covered now with high, coarse grass.

NDOLA, Northern Rhodesia, May 30 -- Many windows in this commercial center of the copper belt look out on paved streets, excavation and construction projects -- and the vast expanse of "bush," or African countryside, in the near distance.

ONE can turn to this book for many things. There is poetry by Ruth Benedict, by Edward Sapir, by Margaret Mead. There are letters written by them and by Franz Boas and Reo Fortune. Some of Mrs. Benedict's most important writings are republished, often in condensed form.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -Three years ago Judge Stanley N. Barnes, the Eisenhower Administration's first antitrust chief, remarked on his policy of ending as many cases as possible by consent decrees instead of going to trial.

UP on Morningside Heights, Mrs. Beatrice Nosco of the Department of Slavic Languages at Columbia University read "Doctor Zhivago" and liked it. She was moved to write Boris Pasternak a note. She said in effect that she regarded the book as a magnificent account of human tragedy, adding that she felt the political and historical setting had been of secondary interest to its author.

CLEVELAND, May 30 -Great Lakes shipments of iron ore, bituminous coal and grain up to May 1 more than doubled the movement of the three major bulk commodities in the corresponding 1958 period despite a large decline in grain shipments.
Canny New Yorkers, ever alert to a bargain, have found a hidden advantage in banking's fastest growing new service, revolving check credit.

RABAT, Morocco, May 30 -- Three companies of Moroccan Army paratroopers have been flown to the border of the Spanish colony Rio de Oro following "skirmishes" there, according to a report telephoned to Rabat early today.
A huge field of 260 contract bridge pairs started play yesterday afternoon in the Open Pairs Championship of the thirty-first annual Eastern States Championships.

IT is becoming something of a literary cliche to picture the white South African as hag-ridden by feelings of guilt and fear. Yet one doesn't have to be a graybeard to recall a time when white South Africans assumed their herrenvolkism to be a manifestation of the Divine Order.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 30 -- For the second time this year Sweden's Parliament entered the royal palace today for a meeting with the King.

In his letter published May 24 Jonathan Bingham poses the existence of a dilemma between the constitutional right to travel and the desirability of withholding passports from "Communists." He therefore suggests that only an "exit and reentry permit" be given to "identify the holders as persons whose travel the United States Government did not approve of."

MILWAUKEE, May 30 (AP) -- Wallace (Buddy) Werner of Steamboat Springs, Colo., was chosen today as skier of the year by the National Ski Association. He was the top American in downhill and slalom competition.
THE fine flowering of Spanish polyphony in the century or so before 1600 is the subject of a new Columbia disk, recorded by the Agrupacion Coral de Pamplona de Espana, Luis Morondo conducting.

PROBABLY nowhere in the world are there as many bizarre and unusual statues as in the spacious lake country of northern Minnesota. Some are quaint, some historical, some humorous. They depict everything from fish to the fabled Paul Bunyan.

HAROLD WALLACE ROSS who conceived, founded and for twenty-six years edited The New Yorker, a "comic weekly," once put his head into the office of the checking department of his magazine and asked in all seriousness, "Is Moby Dick the whale or the man?"
RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 30 -- Long Island's strawberry crop is ready for the traditional Mememorial Day opening of the berry-picking season.

LONDON, May 29 (Reuters) --World shipping tonnage is increasing more rapidly than the demand for it, Birger Krogius, Finnish president of the Baltic and International Maritime Conference, said at the conference's general meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -The President's $3,900,000,000 foreign aid bill came through its first committee stage this week. The House Foreign Affairs Committee authorized appropriations of $3,600,000,000 -a cut of roughly 8 per cent.

An opportunity for pure research rather than the lure of higher salaries may be the answer to the perennial problem of attracting young engineers to the teaching profession, according to a veteran engineer.

A SHADOWY familiar of twentieth-century fiction has been the executioner in the gray-flannel suit. The assassin as bureaucrat has stalked countless pages, from Conrad's "Secret Agent" and Koestler's "Darkness at Noon."
BOSTON, May 30 (AP) -- Ted Williams celebrated his twentieth anniversary in the majors today by hitting a decisive two-run homer.

TODAY'S column deals with one of the minor annoyances of the book world. It has to do with the titling of books, and especially with the all too common practice of both British and American publishers in devising a different title from the one used in the country of the book's origin.
Mediators led by City Labor Commissioner Harold A. Felix sought yesterday to avert a strike set for midnight tonight against the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.

The annual garden party of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women at Ossining, N. Y., will be held on the grounds of the home next Saturday. Mrs. Charles W. V. Meares, president of the home, and the board of directors are giving the fete.

Delicate clusters of flowers stud mountain laurel, viburnums and rhododendrons. Iris fanciers will find tall bearded and Siberian types at peak bloom. June is the month of roses, and many gardens in the New York City area are colorful with early-flowering varieties.

THREE amateur photographers and a free lance, all with distinctive styles, have a group show at Image Gallery, 100 East Tenth Street, to June 21. Hours are 1-6 P. M. daily except Monday and to 9 P. M. Thursday.

HERE is a book that takes some of us back to the days of that pungent character, the late Albert Jay Nock, and further back still to Henry George and Adam Smith -- although Frank Chodorov is by no means an uncritical disciple of the great exponent of the single tax. Mr. Chodorov is, one might say, agin' the government, any government practically.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., May 30 -- The tradition of June Week began yesterday at the United States Air Force Academy. The 207 members of the first graduating class are scheduled to receive diplomas Wednesday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 30 (AP) -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton and Lois Felix of Meriden, Conn., retained their singles titles today in the Connecticut state tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Despite recent signs of growing friction, relations between President Eisenhower and Congress are basically no different from what they have been since January, 1955, when the Republican executive was first confronted with a Democratic Legislature.
CLIFTON, N. J., May 30 -- The United States Animal Quarantine Station is earmarking its tenants for future reference.
THE New York State Traffic Commission has just taken its first modest step toward establishing realistic speed limits for the growing network of mall-divided, multi-lane state highways.

MODERN methods of soil conservation on farms and ranches, "terracing, pasture improvement, pond construction and tree planting," in the phrase of the United States Post Office Department, will be saluted by a 4-cent yellow, green and blue stamp to be issued on Aug. 26.
NAZARETH, Israel, May 25 -- On one of the stony hillsides on which this ancient town is draped, workmen were putting the last fittings into rows of small, two-family concrete houses this week.

STATELY iris will be on display this afternoon when Region Nineteen of the American Iris Society stages an Iris Show at Blake Hall, New Jersey College of Agriculture, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N. J. Show hours will be from 12 noon to 6 P. M.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, has canceled a trip that would have taken him to Cannes, France, for a food conference Tuesday and to London for the June 5-9 North Atlantic Treaty Organization meeting.
ALGIERS, May 30 -- Twenty Moslems and twelve Europeans from Algeria will be elected to the Senate of the French Republic tomorrow.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), May 31 (Reuters) -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, said here tonight there were indications of a "slight improvement" in the treatment of Jews as a national minority in the Soviet Union.
MEMBERS of the television audience who have found that lecturers on educational programs are generally dry and dull should try "Out of This World."
The Weather Bureau's New York office introduces today a new hourly weather measurement, the Discomfort Index.
The Grace Line has ordered 1,500 large cargo containers to be used aboard two freighters, the Santa Eliana and the Santa Leonor.
LONDON, May 31 -- The stock market was still booming last week, with turnover the highest on record and industrial share prices again rising.

A summary of the conclusions of the New York Metropolitan Region Study, conducted by Harvard University for the Regional Plan Association, follows. The full study, directed by Dr. Raymond Vernon, will be published in nine volumes in 1959-60.

Bishop Loughlin High of Brooklyn capped a comeback year in track and field yesterday. Loughlin won the team title in the thirty-second annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championships at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

RABAT, Morocco, May 31 -- Crown Prince Moulay Hassan flew to Paris today to make preliminary arrangements for a meeting in July between King Mohamed V, his father, and President Charles de Gaulle of France.

The class of '42 at the high school held a reunion dinner-dance on a Saturday night at a restaurant in town. The affair was two years in the planning and the committee that had worked on details was proud of the fact that 240 of a possible 280 graduates turned out for the occasion.
Business in the steamship charter market was described yesterday as "listless."
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Government at all levels -- local, state and Federal -- is pushing up the wage-price spiral.
A premature explosion of fireworks rocked a five-block section of Brooklyn last night, breaking about 200 windows and causing nervous shock to four persons.

Sales of the Sperry-Rand Corporation rose by $125,000,000 to $989,601,559 in the fiscal year to March 31, 1959, but net income remained relatively stable, compared with fiscal 1958. Earnings were $27,644,092, equal to 96 cents a share, compared with $27,481,239, or 96 cents a share, in the year to March 31, 1958.
New York is the "cleanest" city in the world, Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh declared yesterday.
LONDON, May 31 (Reuters) -- A widow with four children, sent to jail Thursday for two months for earning money while on relief, has decided to appeal her sentence, it was announced here today.
Two of the nation's largest advertising agencies yesterday announced the elections of new vice presidents.

Pipes, valves and fittings built by the ancient Romans used metals with properties corresponding to modern technical standards, according to an Italian engineer and metallurgist attending the Fifth World Petroleum Congress here.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 31 (UPI) -- University and high school students decided today to strike until Wednesday despite the state of siege.
YONKERS, May 31 (AP) -- A Yonkers group cabled Mao Tse-tung today requesting the release of Hugh F. Redmond Jr., whose father died here Friday at the age of 73.

The newly formed United Improvement and Investing Corporation today is offering 1,238,994 shares of common stock. The new company, which will become the parent corporation of Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company, has been formed to make available to stockholders of Lawyers certain business opportunities of which Lawyers itself, as an insurance company, cannot take advantage.
Thomas K. Finletter charged yesterday that a whispering campaign was being used to discredit the reform movement in the Democratic party by associating it with bigotry.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- About 1,000 persons spent another day searching in vain today for an elusive black bear loose in the nation's capital.

ALBANY, May 31 (AP) -- The Albany County Welfare Department has refused to permit newsmen to inspect its relief rolls or records of physicians and vendors with whom the department does business. The Albany Times-Union said tonight.

" Peace" is not a mere political slogan in the Soviet Union. It is a national preoccupation. The Kremlin-inspired "peace offensive" would lead one to expect declarations of Russia's peaceable intentions from Soviet officials.
With two victories yesterday, Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union again took the lead in the Jubilee international chess tournament at Zurich, according to a report received here.
THE combination of fine weather, the Washington Square Outdoor Art Show and "tower music" brought a large throng to Washington Square yesterday afternoon.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 31 -- Two developments last week mirrored a reversal of the trend toward lower interest rates: bond prices dropped sharply and the bank rate was raised from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent by the five Federal Reserve banks.
LIMA, Peru, May 31 -- Peru's chief Opposition leader was under special guard today in an offshore island prison following his frustrated attempt yesterday to swim to freedom.
The merger of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association with the Brotherhood of Marine Engineers now has the final stamp of approval by the memberships of both unions.
ALGIERS, May 31 -- Senatorial elections today brought defeat to Right-wing politicians who have dominated the Algerian scene since the political upheaval of May 13, 1958.

Twelve agencies affiliated with the Greater New York Fund have their principal offices in Staten Island. Eleven more have branches that serve other boroughs as well as Richmond, five that serve the borough specifically.

An urgent immediate task of United States diplomacy is to quell the smear campaign directed from various quarters at our most valuable single ally, Britain. Surely, the Western powers cannot hope to negotiate successfully with Russia while simultaneously knifing each other in the back.

BONN, Germany, May 31 -- Otto Frank, father of Anne Frank, the girl who died in a Nazi concentration camp and left a diary that became famous, laid the foundation stone today for a West German village named for her.
For the fifth time in three years the Board of Higher Education is looking for a new college president: the $25,000-a-year post will become vacant next year at Hunter College.
A national real estate syndicate made up of more than 3,000 investors will operate the recently sold Glen Oaks Village in Queens, it was learned yesterday.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 31 -- Skippers representing the Centerport Yacht Club captured the honors in the Tri Club week-end regatta, confined to two races today because of yesterday's fog and dead air.
Joseph F. Carlino, the Republican leader of the State Assembly, said last night that the provisions of the state income tax law affecting nonresidents should be revised.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 31 -- President Luis A. Somoza Debayle declared last night he would maintain the present limited state of siege "until the Nicaraguan people cool off a little bit."
RANGOON, Burma, May 31 (AP) -- Communist Chinese Army border guards have crossed into Burmese territory twice in the last ten days, according to reports reaching here today.
The center of the world's longest vertical lift bridge was floated into place yesterday across the Arthur Kill between Elizabethport, N. J., and Arlington, S. I.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti,{ 1V[ay 31 -President Francois Dualier's illness is causing~ c~ncern and speculation today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- University of Pennsylvania archaeologists will resume excavation work in Iran this summer on the site where they found the famed Hasanlu golden bowl.
Missions of the Protestant Episcopal Church and the Church of England to seamen are trying to combat the loneliness of merchant mariners, a visiting clergyman said here yesterday.
Cool breezes and a starry night provided the setting for the opening concert of the fifty-fourth season of the Naumburg Summer Concert series Saturday on the Mall in Central Park.
GENEVA, May 31 -- The Western nations will move this week for a limited "barter agreement" in which the freedom of West Berlin and the person of President Eisenhower are curiously involved.
AFTER thirteen years of portraying other people's designs, Esther Larson, one of New York's foremost fashion illustrators, has become a designer herself.
Nearly all those New Yorkers who had streamed out of the city since Thursday evening were trying to get back last night.

GENEVA, May 31 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union will meet in a restricted session tomorrow afternoon to begin what Western diplomats consider to be the critical week of their confidence.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 (AP) Johnny Antonelli limited Chicago to five hits and belted a three-run double as the second-place San Francisco Giants posted a 6-3 victory over the Cubs today.
Two Honorable Mention awards, the highest given to city policemen, were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy. One of them was posthumous.

MILWAUKEE, May 31 (AP) -- The first-place Milwaukee Braves and the last-place Philadelphia Phillies divided a double header today. The Phillies won the first game, 6 -- 0, behind Robin Roberts' four-hit hurling and the Braves took the second, 2 -- 1, as Warren Spahn yielded four hits.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (AP) -- Six positions were changed today in the final standing of yesterday's 500-mile auto race.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- State Department officials said today the Soviet Union had given assurances that it would not try to establish military bases in Antarctica.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to establish a transcontinental radio link by use of satellites late this year.
WESTWOOD, N. J., May 31 -- The new Pascack Valley Hospital was dedicated this afternoon. Tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock it will receive its first patient.

Regulations governing the administration of the new 5 per cent tax on meals that cost $1 or more and wines and liquor that are sold for on-premises consumption were made public yesterday by City Treasurer Hilda G. Schwartz.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, recently tapped for temporary duty as special assistant to the Secretary of Defense, has been using the office assigned to him as a retired flag officer in the old Navy building. His failure to move over to the Pentagon with the military chiefs may stem from more than inertia.

Jack Paar will get a four-day work week under the terms of a new contract with the National Broadcasting Company. Although the contract has not been signed by the television star, both parties have agreed to the proposed terms and it is expected to become effective in July.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 31 -- Jamin today suffered his first defeat of the year. After eight consecutive victories, the great six-year-old French horse finished a bad fourth in the 80,000-kroner (about $11,500) Danish International trotting championship.
BAYONNE, N. J., May 31 -- Fire damage the interior of the Bayonne Free Public Library early today. Much of the city's collection of books, antiques and historical memorabilia was feared lost.

The National Securities Series of mutual funds reported over the week-end a gain of 51 per cent in net assets in the fiscal year ended April 30. The year-end figure was a new high as was the number of shareholders.
CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- Despite the approaching harvest of an almost certain bumper crop, wheat futures were the only contracts to close with gains last week on the Board of Trade.
BRESCIA, Italy, May 31 (AP) -- Mario Carlo Abate and Gianni Balzarini of Italy in a Ferrari Grand Tourism car won the watered-down Mille Miglia, once famous Italian road race, today.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics routed Early Wynn with five runs in the second inning and Barry Latman on Preston Ward's grand slam in the sixth en route to a 9-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.
FRAMINGHAM, Mass., May 31 -- Ch. Fezziwig Ceiling Zero, a black-and-white Old English sheepdog, won his first top award in the fifty-second annual Framingham District Kennel Club show today.

NEW DELHI, India, May 31 (Reuters) -- The Indian Government decided today to drop charges of abuse of power and negligence against H. M. Patel, former principal Secretary of the Finance Ministry. It had weighed action against him for his role in the investment of about $2,600,000 in funds belonging to the state-owned Life Insurance Corporation in shares of private companies.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee reported today that Communist party membership in the twenty Latin-American countries had grown about 5 per cent in 1958.

The Minute Maid Corporation is expanding its operations into Mexico. Through its subsidiary, Minute Maid International Corporation, formed here last year to handle export sales activities, a minority interest has been acquired in a new Mexican company, Jugos Concentrados, S. A.
The first truly portable television set -- capable of running on battery power -- will be sold in stores all over the country by the end of this month.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 31 (AP) -- King Baudoin of the Belgians, saying that his three-week tour of the United States had left him with "warmth and affection for this country, departed tonight in a special plane for his native land.

Laws pertaining to real estate and related subjects that were passed by the recent session of the Legislature are summarized in a booklet being distributed by the Home Title Guaranty Company, 51 Willoughby Street Brooklyn. The information is being sent to about 18,000 lawyers throughout the state.

GENEVA, May 31 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India has called for the reconvening of the international supervisory commission for the Indochinese state of Laos, usually reliable sources said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Along about 4:35 this afternoon it is more than likely a feeling of apprehension swept through the American League.

Margaret Hamilton, stage, screen and television actress, will test her new one-woman show next Sunday night at the Hedgerow Theatre in Moylan, Pa. Because it is based on twenty-five years of experience as an actress, Miss Hamilton thought a fitting title would be "Ham's Hash."

JUST before the Olympic Games began at Melbourne in 1956, the lid blew off the kettle. The Hungarians rebelled against their Communist oppressors and the Soviet cracked down with tanks and guns. Britain and France followed an Israeli attack on Egypt by moving into the Suez Canal area.

As is indicated in your May 28 editorial on the problem of railroad passenger deficits, the recommendation of the Interstate Commerce Commission that steps should be taken, where a local commuting service is essential but unprofitable by state and local authorities, or both, "to provide the service, paying the carrier cost plus a reasonable profit," may be a counsel of despair.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Five Asian religious leaders have told the House Committee on Un-American Activities that the Governments of Communist China and North Korea have resorted to torture and mass murder to wipe out Christianity in their areas.

FOR many years, one of the pleasures of visiting the Beaujolais wine district of France has been sampling the region's produce at small roadside stands. Tourists are surfeited with literature describing the vineyards and, for a modest price, may sample a few glasses of their world-famed wines.
Parkinson's disease, which stiffens muscles and causes shaking and tremor, may be a reversible condition, Dr. H. Houston Merritt said here yesterday.

The Amsterdam Overseas Corporation of this city has acquired the business and assets of the Northern Finance Corporation in Minneapolis, Minn., and its wholly-owned subsidiaries, Minneapolis Securities Corporation and Northern Credit Plan, Inc.
Heart specialists and diet experts report that many people are eating fewer eggs now in the hope of reducing the amount of cholesterol in their diet.

SINGAPORE, May 31 -- The Left Wing People's Action par-left-wing People's Action party, which won a landslide victory in yesterday's general elections, reiterated today that it would refuse to form a government unless several extremists formerly "closely connected" with the party's leadership were released from jail.

BERLIN, May 31 -- A spokesman for RIAS, the American-directed German-language radio station in West Berlin, said tonight that for the majority of East Germans the station had become a by-word for freedom of information and for contact with the West.
