IN moments of depression I sometimes feel that almost anybody can write a book, not necessarily a good book but one good enough to be published. Each year hundreds of professionally expert authors write thousands of competent books that are destined to be forgotten within three months of their publication.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended May 30:

LUANSHYA, Northern Rhodesia, May 29 -- The Central African Federation's great copper belt, the third largest source of copper in the world, is looking to the day when the Kariba Hydroelectric Project gives it a vast new charge of power.

Having benefited from the guidance of the New Dramatists Committee, a non-profit organization that imparts the know-how to deserving playwrights, Charles Best now feels qualified to graduate into the ranks of Broadway authors. His new play, "The Kids," is to be produced by George Hamlin and John W. Caldwell in the fall.
SHOPPERS in Bloomingdale's infant's furniture department are likely to be deflected in course, if not purpose, by a small and arresting display.
ROME, May 31 -- Nearly 400,000 persons voted on the Italian mainland today for new local administrators.

LOUISVILLE, May 31 (AP) -- Don Whitt of Borrego Springs, Calif., won his second golf tournament in two weeks today when he finished the Kentucky Derby open with a 72-hole total of 274. He shot a 4-under par 67 in the final round.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 31 -- Bob Bavier Jr.'s Gulf Stream Thirty, Memory, the next-to-smallest yacht in the fleet, found the right places to go in gaining her greatest sailing triumph tonight.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 31 (AP) -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of United States Naval Operations, said today that human freedom was in greater jeopardy now than ever before "simply because the means to destroy it are far more powerful than ever before."

A ROOM air conditioner probably takes more abuse than any other appliance. Half of it hangs outside all year; the inside is wet whenever it is in use; tremendous amount of refrigeration capacity is concentrated in a small area, and it works continuously when in use, unlike a refrigerator, whose motor goes on and off.
Daniel J. Riesner, board chairman of the National Republican Club, said yesterday that his party had a "rich reservoir" of potential candidates for Mayor in the 1961 election.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Sixty-nine corporations in many fields are matching the gifts their employes make to colleges and universities, according to a report made here by the American Alumni Council.
A fight between a small Communist force and the larger Royal Laotian Army began last month north of the northern Laotian city of Luang Prabang.
Despite the enormous increase in the volume of air traffic and the speeds of planes, airline safety has shown notable improvement in recent years, it was reported yesterday.

BELLPORT, L. I., May 31 -- A twenty-five-knot southeaster sharply reduced the fleet for the final day of the week-end regatta of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club today. Seven of the craft that did venture out were disabled.
Dr. George Rothenberg and Howard Berger, both of New York City, won the Goldman Pairs contract bridge title yesterday in the Eastern States Open Pairs Championships.
ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, May 31 -- Victory came at last today to a BRM. The auto outfit, which raced for the first time eleven years ago, had never before captured a world championship race.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Government has begun to concede officially as well as unofficially that "defense support" aid for a key group of nations is needed regardless of the military effort of those nations.

LINCOLN, Ill., May 31 (AP) -- "The political profession is freeing itself from the unpleasant connotations with which it has been saddled for so many years," Mayor Wagner assured Lincoln junior college graduates today.

To mark the 450th year since the birth of John Calvin Reformed and Presbyterian leaders over the world called yesterday for a drive toward Christian unity that in time could end the separatism Calvin did so much to bring about.

A strike scheduled at the Brooklyn Union Gas Company was postponed last night shortly before the midnight deadline. Union leaders agreed to hold off the strike as long as negotiations continued with company representatives.
Roman Catholics were urged yesterday to seek God's help through the intercession of the Virgin Mary.

BACON, a favorite breakfast meat, need not be limited to service with the morning eggs. It can lend its hearty appetizing flavor to a variety of luncheon and dinner dishes. The American Meat Institute reminds that, in common with all pork cuts, it is an excellent buy today.

The Rev. Dr. Ernest R. Palen of the Middle Collegiate Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, said yesterday it was necessary to remember the ideals for which our armed forces had fought and died since the Civil War.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 31 -- Membership in the United Nations is expanding so rapidly that proposals for enlarging the organization's $67,000,000 headquarters are under consideration.

WESTHAMPTON, L. I., May 31 -- A young parachutist dangled forty feet from the ground for half an hour today after his parachute had caught in high tension wires and then climbed down uninjured on an extension ladder from a Long Island Lighting Company emergency truck.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 -- Steelmakers were rushing shipments last week but many steel consumers were still far from happy over the size of their steel inventories. Furthermore, it seemed a certainty last week that if there is a strike on July 1 a substantial tonnage of steel -- slated for delivery before June 30 -- will not reach consumers until the mills reopen.
Fletcher Richards, Calkins Holden, Inc., has captured the National Guard Bureau account.

Attempts have been made in recent weeks, under circumstances that might well cause a raising of eyebrows, to revive, in a new guise, a monetary theory that reached, and passed, the crest of its popularity a generation ago.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 31 (AP) -- Two University of California scientists say they have determined that cosmic rays from outer space produce the high-energy protons in the vast radiation belt encircling the earth.
THE English art of making "fine china" dinnerware still flourishes mainly because a former English colony likes to set a handsome table.

MEDIA, Pa., May 31 A 3 - year - old silver miniature poodle outshone 592 other contenders today and was named best in the Delaware County Kennel Club's twenty-ninth annual show on the Rose Tree hunt grounds.
LOS ANGELES, May 31 -- The automobile insurance "merit plan" being tried on a large scale in California has just completed an inconclusive month.

RYE, N. Y., May 31 -- "This," said Jack Helmle, "is a day a race chairman dreams about." Helmle is the race chairman of the American Yacht Club and a fleet of eighty-six boats sailed today in the third regatta of the club's seventy-seventh season.
HONOLULU, May 31 (AP) -- Charles E. King, a Chicago business man has added another Malayan rubber plantation to his string.
Mutual funds take pride in being the fastest growing investment medium.

Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, the president of the Fund for the Republic, suggested yesterday that "the decay" of communications media and education left the people unprepared to deal with their responsibilities in a democracy.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Department of Agriculture noted last week that egg production in the nation was well above that of 1958 and predicted that the high output might continue the rest of the year.

Surface Transit, Inc., wholly owned subsidiary of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., has signed an agreement with the city giving up its right to operate its buses in both directions on Third and Lexington Avenues. This will permit the city to establish one-way traffic on those streets.
The motive of the Christian faith and human motivation in general were analyzed yesterday in a sermon at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventy-third Street.
ST. LOUIS, May 31 (AP) -- The Morning Globe-Democrat published tonight for the first time in more than three months. It was shut by a strike of the American Newspaper Guild Feb. 21.

On my frequent and always amiable visits to your hospitable shores I usually try to appraise the current trend of thought on some major topic and then equate it with the climate of opinion in my own country on the same subject. This can be a very rewarding experience, particularly when there happens to be a vigorous and healthy dissimilarity in our respective thinking.
MOSCOW, May 31 -- The frankest expression yet offered of Soviet concern over the re vival of German militarism has been laid down by Premier Khrushchev.
The Rev. Dr. John M. Krumm called yesterday for an "Intellectual Manifesto" proclaiming that the cultivation of the life of the mind has an indispensable role in the fulfillment of human purpose.

The Soviet Union has sent birthday greetings to Mrs. Ethel Lilian Voynich, the 95-year - old American author whose novel, "The Gadfly," published in 1897, has sold 3,000,000 copies behind the Iron Curtain.

TUCUMCARI, N. M., May 31 (UPI) -- Hand marks on the concrete of Conchas Dam led searchers today to the body of a second drowning victim in Conchas Lake in eastern New Mexico, thirty miles northwest of here.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 31 -- Dave Kelley's black gelding, Heat Wave, in the open jumper division, and Kay Tremper's hestnut gelding, Ashland, in he working hunters, won championships at the show of the Fairfield-Westchester chapter, Professional Horsemen's Association today.

The headlong pace of change in the lives and surroundings of the sixteen million people who live in the twenty-two-county, tri-state, New York metropolitan region is dominant in the Regional Plan Association's monumental survey of this area, a preview of which has just been made public. It is also a striking reminder of how different the changes have been from what had been expected in the past.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 -- Huckleberry Finn will have to go it alone in the movies. He will have no Tom Sawyer to help him in or out of mischief on the Mississippi for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
Yesterday the midtown area was virtually emptied of New Yorkers and filled with tourists vacationing in the city during the holiday week-end.

The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, broke ground yesterday for St. Andrew's Church, the first Bronx edifice to be built in the diocese's 175th Anniversary Expansion Program.

LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, in a speech tonight in Albania, again warned the West that if it ever struck at the Communist bloc the Russians would hit back with a blow from which the West would never recover.

Three organizations of Orthodox rabbis are seeking conferences with the Port of New York Authority to protest a planned synagogue at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The New York Board of Rabbis, sponsoring the temple, said yesterday, however, that it hoped to break ground for the synagogue this month.

There is no reason to be complacent about the outcome of the election held in Singapore to provide the basis for the new autonomous government. Quite to the contrary, it runs up an ominous danger signal. It also shows how not to fight the Communist menace.
DETROIT, May 31 (AP) -- Charley Maxwell socked Jim Perry's first pitch in the ninth inning for a three-run homer today, enabling the Detroit Tigers to gain a 7-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., May 31 -- Walter Hansgen, whose father repaired carriages, drove his 302-horsepower Lister Jaguar to victory today in the twenty-five-lap feature at this village's Grand Prix course.
Starting July 1, the heads of city departments and agencies will have to use medium or lightweight cars instead of the expensive limousines -- most of them Cadillacs -- in which they now ride.
The weather-minded reader can compute the Weather Bureau's new Discomfort Index with half the trouble that it took him to figure the old temperature-humidity average.
Except for a modest recovery last Wednesday, cotton prices in the domestic market tended to soften last week.

A floor in the new office building at 125 Maiden Lane has been leased by the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company, specialists in engineering insurance. The lease is for twenty years at an aggregate rental of $1,000,000. It was negotiated by Ronald Binder of Collins, Tuttle Co., broker. The lessees will move from 90 John Street.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- John L. Lewis said today that President Eisenhower had thrown the weight of his prestige against the workers in the current wage negotiations in the steel industry.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 31 (AP) -- Quiet descended upon Asuncion today under the weight of a resumed state of siege, modified martial law, imposed after students and the police clashed here Friday night.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 31 -- The world's population is increasing at the rate of about 45,000,000 a year, the United Nations reported today.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 31 (AP) -- Senator Russell B. Long told a joint session of the Louisiana Legislature tonight that his uncle, Gov. Earl K. Long, had had a breakdown because the duties of his office were more than he could stand. He said the Governor might be away "a considerable period of time."

NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 31 -- A three-day rally and youth festival of the Right-Wing E. D. M. A. party, which is essentially the old E. O. K. A. underground movement in political form, reached a climax today as thousands of Cypriotes poured into Nicosia for sports events and other celebrations.

Britain's most famous clock, as Walter H. Waggoner described it in a dispatch to this newspaper, has "works like a steam locomotive's and the voice of a musical frog." Never mind. For a hundred years, the age it reached yesterday, Big Ben has spoken for a country, an empire, finally an international commonwealth. Like a certain bell in Philadelphia, it has proclaimed liberty throughout the land.
BEAVER DAM, Ky., May 31 (AP) -- Three exhausted coal miners crawled to safety today from the pit in which they had been trapped for more than forty-one hours.

IN cocking a critical eye at the metropolitan region for the last three years, Dr. Raymond Vernon says he has looked for fact, not fault. But his preliminary findings already are under attack as pessimistic.

Arthur B. (Bull) Hancock said yesterday his 4-year-old colt, Nadir, who pulled up lame in the $115,900 Metropolitan Handicap won by Sword Dancer Saturday at Belmont Park would be sent to the farm in Kentucky.
A syndicate of investors has purchased the two twelve-story apartment buildings at 310 and 316 West Seventy-ninth Street from Soltzer Lampert, realty operators.

A collection of political essays by Milovan Djilas, former Vice President of Yugoslavia, will be published by Praeger June 25 in an English translation entitled "Anatomy of a Moral." The eighteen articles, published in the closing months of 1953, record the intellectual metamorphosis by which Djilas' disillusionment became first criticism and finally defiance of the Yugoslav Communist movement.
Continued growth and prosperity for the tri-state New York metropolitan area were forecast yesterday in a regional study.

Alex Rose, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, reported yesterday that the union had spent more than $6,000,000 to help the headwear industry recover from the recession.

FREEHOLD, N. J., May 31 -- "We're sitting on a keg of dynamite, and the fuse is burning low." With these words, a driver for Henfruit Express summed up today the critical depression in the nation's poultry industry. He was hoisting egg crates onto the tail of his truck.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 1 -- The Eighth Theatre Congress opened here today in University Festival Hall. All but two of the thirty-five member countries of the International Theatre Institute, which is celebrating its tenth anniversary this year, are represented.
BATON ROUGE, La., June 1 -- Leaders of Gov. Earl K. Long's political machine were attempting to hold it together today.
Robert T. Barnes a former City Councilman, and Assemblyman Anthony P. Savarese Jr. appeared yesterday to be the likely heads of the Republican ticket in Queens this year.
"THE World of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart" was the title of an all-Mozart program presented at the Phoenix Theatre last night for the benefit of the theatre's subscription drive.
ALGIERS, June 1 -- The French Army said tonight that nationalist rebel fighters were surrendering in greater numbers than at any time since the beginning of the rebellion four and a half years ago.

The first round in the legal bout between the two heavyweights, Eddie Machen and Ingemar Johansson, staged in Federal Court yesterday ended in no decision. The trial will continue today before Judge Irving R. Kaufman.

The nation's 518 mutual savings banks added $6,000,000 in deposits in April for a total of $34,300,000,000, according to report by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. The April gain was substantially less than the $313,000,000 rise in March and the $92,000,000 in crease in April of last year.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -The grain futures market worked its way out of most of its early fairly broad setbacks today on the Board of Trade. However, all new-crop soybean contracts still were well down at the finish.

Sales of the eight major department stores and their branches in the New York area in May were about 1 per cent above those in the 1958 month, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

HAVANA, June 1 -- Two former Cabinet Ministers and the man to whom Gen. Fulgencio Batista turned over command of the armed forces when the former Cuban President fled from the island Jan. 1 received prison sentences today from a military court.

Textron, Inc., plans further diversification of its activities through the proposed acquisition of the Randall Company, makers of automotive equipment, leather-working machinery and cooking, utensils.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 1 -- Belgians lined the roads from the National Airport to the center of Brussels today to give King Baudouin a roaring welcome on his return from a three-week tour of the United States.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 1 -- Mike Souchak, one of golf's long hitters, set the qualifying pace in the metropolitan district's trials today for the United States Open.
CINCINNATI, June 1 (AP) -- The National League decided today to give a silver tray and a dozen sterling goblets to Harvey Haddix for pitching an almost perfect game last Tuesday.
ROME, June 1 (AP) -- Mayor Urbano Ciocetti has aroused a storm by refusing to approve an official celebration of the fifteenth anniversary of Rome's liberation from the Germans.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 1 -- British East Africa, with a territory as large as Western Europe's, but far less settled, is forging steadily ahead with an expansion program for its port and railway facilities.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Eisenhower censured Congress again today for having failed to change the existing price support and control program to deal with the wheat surplus problem.
TERRY MURRAY, pianist and senior research associate for an advertising agency, gave a recital last night at Town Hall.
TUNIS, Tunisia, June 1 (Reuters) -- Tunisia's new American-style Constitution became official today.
YONKERS, June 1 -- About 25,000 shoppers and window-shoppers jammed the home-center aisles of the S. Klein Westchester department store at its opening today at 2500 Central Avenue.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 1 (Reuters) -- The Assembly was warned tonight of a possible army take-over after refusing for the second time to approve President Sukarno's bid for near-dictatorial powers.
Aetna Securities Corporation and Roman Johnson head a banking syndicate offering 275,000 shares of Investment Corporation of Florida common stock at $4.50 a share today.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senator Mike Mansfield renewed his demands today for a fundamental revision of the foreign aid program.

"Say One for Me," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic comedy, starring Bing Crosby, Debbie Reynolds and Robert Wagner, will be the next attraction at the Paramount Theatre. Frank Tashlin produced and directed the feature.

THERE is a theory that wars never really settle anything. It may be true. But few would like to have been on the losing side of some of the organized carnages that have shaken civilization. Except, possibly, such encounters as the American Civil War, since the descendants of the losers have jubilantly taken as their province all eternity in which to revenge their secessionist cause against the once-victorious blue-coats.

Censorship may not be quite so certain as death and taxation, but it has been around as long. Some people have been saying and writing things that other people haven't liked, or believed others shouldn't be exposed to, since words were born.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A key figure in the campaign against the confirmation of Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce removed himself from the line of fire today.
When Chester Dale, noted collector, buys a painting now, it is an event. Such an event took place, however, last week when he bought "The Visit" by Edouard Vuillard.

First National Stores, Inc., which had 543 food stores in operation when its fiscal year ended on March 28, showed record sales of $531,521,108 for the year. That exceeded the previous year's volume by $10,026,115, Adrian O'Keeffe, president, reported.
Underground nuclear explosions have an outside chance of bringing oil from shale and sand that cannot now be worked economically, Dr. Edward Teller said here yesterday.
GALVESTON, Tex., June 1 (UPI) -- Governor Long was reported today to be "stubbornly resisting" attempts by psychiatrists to treat him for an "upset mind."
A Queens woman with tears in her eyes testified yesterday that she had received a traffic ticket because she had asked a patrolman a question.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -Iraq's renunciation of United States military aid was expected here as a consequence of the Iraqi Government's policy of "positive neutrality."
ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, June 1 -- Like all sports, motor racing can prosper only when there is a star or stars that the public will pay to see.
A re-enactment of the historic twenty-three day New York-toSeattle automobile race of fifty years ago started yesterday at City Hall.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- A school planning authority said today there was not a school system in the country with buildings completely free of serious fire hazards.

WHEN Joe DiMaggio was in the twilight of his career, he singled solidly to right in his first at bat in the Grapefruit League opener at St. Pete. The fielder scooped up the ball carelessly on his gloved hand side, leaving himself in no position to make a throw. The alert DiMadge never hesitated.
Oil men from around the world began a week-long series of scientific and technical meetings at the New York Coliseum yesterday in the first working session of the Fifth World Petroleum Congress.

With all the bright news about business recovery, not much has been reported about a boom in capital expenditures. Yesterday the word came from the National Industrial Conference Board. It has just completed its latest Quarterly Survey of Capital Appropriations for Newsweek Magazine.
A Soviet artist and an American architect exchanged cordial wishes yesterday for the exhibition each is planning in the other's country this summer.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it completed the laying of one strand of a twoline trans-Atlantic cable system and had begun work on the laying of the second line.

While the Western powers labor at Geneva to ward off the latest Soviet menace to Berlin and pave a path to peace, Premier Khrushchev has not only continued his rocket-rattling against the West but has also launched a new and wider flanking move to wrest the eastern Mediterranean from Western control.

The Colgate-Palmolive Company has joined a show it couldn't lick. Effective in October, it will become the alternate-week sponsor of the Ed Sullivan show, which is televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Sundays from 8 to 9 P. M.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court upset the dismissal of an Interior Department employe today on the ground that the department had violated its own rules designed to assure him "a meaningful, fair, decent and dignified hearing."
Two medium-size accounts changed agencies yesterday.
Birmingham, Ala., announced yesterday its tentative plans to offer $22,750,000 of water revenue bonds for competitive bidding on June 25. Maturities and other details were not immediately disclosed.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey called on the nation's special libraries today to meet the challenge presented by the growth of printed materials in the "research era."
More than 300 persons were killed in traffic accidents throughout the country during the Memorial Day weekly on exceeding the 260 toll death stated by the National Safety Council.

GENEVA, June 1 (UPI) -- The Swiss Government warned the, East German Communists today against misusing neutral conference facilities for propaganda purposes. The East Germans rejected the protest, saying the Swiss had been "misinformed."
BALBOA, C. Z., June 1 -Ocean-going commercial ships pushed Panama Canal traffic to new highs last month.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A nation-wide study of drugs to combat arthritis will start next September at ten clinical centers.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court rejected today, for the time being, an appeal by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People from a contempt conviction in Georgia.

Morgan Cie., Paris, the wholly owned subsidiary of J.P. Morgan Co.. Inc. until its recent merger with the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, will be merged into the parent Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Following a custom of several years, Bloomingdale's is having wild strawberries flown in from France. The tiny fraises des bois are scheduled to make their debut this afternoon. Thereafter, weather permitting, supplies will be flown in every Tuesday and Friday of the season, which usually lasts through July.

Yields to investors on commercial paper sold through dealers in the open market were advanced by one-eighth of 1 percentage point yesterday. The new rates for these unsecured promissory notes range from 3 3/4 per cent on the four- to six-month notes of leading industrial concerns to 4 1/3 per cent for the paper of lesser industrial concerns and smaller finance companies.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 1 -One hundred and forty women graduates of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart were told today to accept as "exhilarating challenges" the space age and the threat of communism.
ROME, June 1 -- Communism scored a slight but significant success in local administrative elections in Italy yesterday and today.
The Transit Authority signed contracts yesterday to purchase 190 new buses from the General Motors Corporation for $4,947,917.32. The vehicles will be used in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
To be a javelin recordbreaker, one has to be a thinker and a theorizer, as well as a strong-armed thrower.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 1 -- The National Guard is hunting armed invaders in southwestern Nicaragua, it was officially announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Robert F. Kennedy, counsel to the Senate Rackets Committee, said today gambling and vice rackets had flourished in Lake County, Ind., in open violation of the law.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 1 -- Ernesto Esguerra Serrano, Colombian Minister to Haiti, appealed for public aid today in tracing a missing Colombian, Rafael Jesus Velasquez, the third foreigner to have vanished on this island in about a year.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
MOSCOW, June 1 -- The controversial novel "The Yershov Brothers" has been turned into play from which the last vestige of controversy has been extracted.
The current controversy about presenting plays in Central Park seems to me to be marked by an unfortunate amount of rigidity on the part of everyone except Mr. Moses.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 1 -- President Alfredo Stroessner jailed scores of dissident leaders of his Colorado party today and moved cavalry troops into the capital to control student demonstrations.

Secretary of Agriculture Benson may be forgiven if he looks with a jaundiced eye at his breakfast eggs, be they boiled, scrambled, poached, baked or made into a cheese omelette. The bottom has almost vanished from the egg market in recent months and the resulting political splatter has landed on Mr. Benson, who had troubles enough before with wheat and other farm commodities.
PARIS, June 1 -- A year ago today Gen. Charles de Gaulle took over as a receiver in bankruptcy -- political and financial -- for the Fourth French Republic.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Two pretty models did something today that many people have wanted to do on a hot, muggy day in the nation's capital.

OTTAWA, June 1 (Canadian Press) --Canada's mineral production slipped in value last year as only uranium-producing areas --Ontario, Saskatchewan and the Northwest Territories -- showed a gain over 1957.

BONN, Germany, June 1 -- A 34-year-old secretary in the West German Defense Ministry and her husband were arrested two weeks ago on suspicion of espionage, the Federal prosecutor announced in Karlsruhe today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- All the analyses of how the New York Yankees got out of the American League cellar have overlooked a historic fact. This is that Charles Dillon Stengel, like many other distinguished statesmen before him, directed the recovery of his constituents by the simple policy of coming to Washington.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 11 points yesterday. The far months were weakest.
HAVANA, June 1 -- Social editors in Havana fear that high society will suffer a mortal blow from the tax that the Castro Government proposes to put on society pages.
CHICAGO, June 1 -- Last year's super piston - engine planes will soon be worth only their scrap value, according to a study published today by the Northwestern University Transportation Center.

IF anyone doubts that the suburbs are child oriented, a visit to White Plains' shopping center will convince them. Children tumble forth from station wagons, play tag around store counters and in general comport themselves with great hilarity.
GENEVA, June 1 -- Along the sunny quays, the foreign ministers speed from meeting to meeting in their shiny limosines, and their thoughts are on Berlin.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- In just thirty minutes today the House approved by voice vote its own $100,279,350 budget. No amendments were offered to cut the amount.

GANDER, Nfld., June 1 (UPI) -- Airline pilots threatened today to boycott Gander Airport less than three weeks before Queen Elizabeth is scheduled to open officially its new $6,000,000 terminal building. The opening is planned for June 19.

The results of the Senatorial elections in Algeria on Sunday confirmed the trend in favor of the moderates against the die-hard integrationists. As such it was a good result for President de Gaulle and his efforts to build up popular support for an Algerian community that will remain attached to France.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The appointment of 130 persons to the National Advisory Committee for the White House Conference on Aging was announced here today by Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

The Outdoor Cleanliness Association of the City of New York, Inc., will hold its twentyseventh annual Flower Mart on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral next Tuesday. In the event of rain it will be held the following day.

The Mutual Security Program this year has become one of the most controversial issues in our foreign policy. If we do not consolidate our forces, the program will suffer from the current differences in support between those who stress foreign military aid and those who stress economic aid.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Appointment of Marion W. Boggs as deputy executive secretary of the National Security Council was announced by the White House today. He succeeds S. Everett Gleason, who resigned to become cultural attache of the American Embassy at London.
Request for allocations for nine projects, including three new courthouses, were submitted yesterday to the City Planning Commission by Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen.
The New York regional Red Cross blood program collected 12,237 pints of blood in May. The April total was 12,247. Included in the May total were 143 pints of blood donated on Friday.
Two Air Force Colonels joined Columbia professors yesterday in a seminar on "Brink or Threshold? Challenge of the Space Age."

The inquiry into the State Harness Racing Commission was told yesterday that hotel and entertainment bills and car-rental charges of commission staff members in Florida amounted to more than $15,000 in 1958 and 1959.
NEWARK, June 1 -- The strike of electrical workers against the Public Service Electric and Gas Company was marked by violence today.
LONDON, June 1 -- A report in The Times of London that Prime Minister Harold Macmillan was planning to replace Selwyn Lloyd as Foreign Secretary caused a furor here today.

The Long Island Lighting Company has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the proposed offering of $25,000,000 of thirty year first mortgage bonds after June 18.

The parents of 2,000 Negro pupils from the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn will be given the option next fall of sending them to schools in other parts of the borough and Queens, the Board of Education disclosed yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 1 -- The American Red Cross, having trouble raising funds, is "regearing" its methods in an attempt to tap potential sources of income more efficiently.
CHICAGO, June 1 (UPI) -Joe DeMaestri, with a triple and his third homer of the season, furnished the scoring punch for a 3-1 Kansas City victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
CORNING, N. Y., June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller indicated here today that he planned to take no steps to block the entry of his name in the New Hampshire Republican Presidential primary next year.

I think the sooner Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union comes to Washington, as I hear he wants to, the sooner we might clear the air and get down to a realistic approach on the critical issues that plague the world.
Steel production increased slightly last week, for the third consecutive week, but again failed to achieve the scheduled rate. A further rise has been scheduled for this week.
Budget Director Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday that a newly created unit in his office would supervise the assignment and use of city cars under the order issued by Mayor Wagner Sunday.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn, Democrat of Texas, and Representative Clarence Cannon, Democrat of Missouri, professed their mutual admiration and friendship today.

MILWAUKEE, June 1 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Giants moved to within a game and a half of the National League lead tonight by overwhelming the first-place Milkaukee Braves, 11 -- 2, in the opener of a four-game series.

Mrs. Lytle Hull, president of the Musicians Emergency Fund, has announced that most boxes already have been taken for the concert by the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, Herbert von Karajan conducting, which will take place at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 17.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday postponed indefinitely, his department's scheduled crackdown on illegal smoking in movie houses and legitimate theatres.
The market for fixed-interest securities marked time yesterday as many dealers and investors stretched out the Memorial Day week-end for an additional day.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday a thirty-day delay to July 1 in the effective date of its order allowing the Consolidated Edison Company to start ending conjunctional (combined) billing.
GENEVA, June 1 -- Prime Minister Macmillan moved quickly today to offset the effect of published reports that he was about to remove Selwyn Lloyd as Britain's Foreign Secretary.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Eisenhower and Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, held a secret White House meeting late today with Congressional leaders of both parties.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Treasury bill rate rose steeply this week, with 182-day bills selling at a record interest yield, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

The owner of Luchow's Restaurant, Jan Mitchell, was elected president and a director and took over the active management of Longchamps, Inc., restaurant chain, yesterday. He had previously purchased 86 per cent of the Longchamps stock from pension trusts held for the benefit of employes of Springfield, Mass., newspapers.
George Meany, president of the merged labor movement, called yesterday for war by organized labor against "restrictive, discriminatory and anti-labor" legislation.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -Democratic tax experts in the House of Representatives are considering pushing through a two-year extension of wartime tax rates on corporations, cigarettes, liquor, beer, wine and automobiles.
The Weather Bureau received an unexpected rush of telephone calls yesterday because of a misunderstanding of its new Discomfort Index.
A $500,000 damage suit against the state and a state police sergeant has been discontinued here. The claim had been an aftermath of the gangland convention at Apalachin, N. Y.

PARIS, May 31 -- Exports of manufactured products by France in the first quarter of 1959 were 21 per cent greater than in 1958, according to Valery Giscard d'Estaing, Secretary of State in the Ministry of Finance.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Phillies today signed Alvin Neiger, a left-handed pitcher attending the University of Delaware, for an undisclosed bonus.

If two rival producers stubbornly adhere to present plans, Broadway will find itself in the bizarre situation next fall of having two presentations of Bertolt Brecht's play, "Mother Courage," opening the same week.

BAR HARBOR, Me., June 1 (AP) -- A woman scientist at the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory is credited with discovering a combination of chemicals that will support animal cell life in a test tube.

Parents, who have floated paper craft in bathtub seas and folded paper into whizzing air-planes to amuse their youngsters, now can make menageries of paper giraffes, kangaroos, dromedaries and exotic birds.
Four contract bridge teams last night met in semi-final matches of the Eastern States knockout team championship at the Statler Hilton Hotel.
L. Judson Morhouse counselled Republican leaders throughout the state yesterday to nominate "able, aggressive and attractive" candidates for local offices to be filled this year.

Eight places are still open for the New York-New Jersey district qualifying round of the Bowling Proprietors Association of America team handicap tournament. Teams with any average, possibly the lower the better, are eligible.

The site of more than 10,000 square feet at 316-22 East Fiftyeighth Street, between First and Second Avenues, has been assembled for future construction of an apartment house. The assemblage was made by the Sonnenblick - Goldman Corporation, broker.
Columbia University will award undergraduate and graduate degrees to 6,591 students and honorary degrees to ten civic and educational leaders today.

Members of Local 101 of the Transport Workers Union ratified last night a contract with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company. This ended the threat of a strike called for midnight Sunday and then postponed.

LIMA, Peru, June 1 -- Peru plans to boycott next February's conferences of American Presidents and foreign ministers in Ecuador unless she receives assurances on a longstanding border dispute with Ecuador.

Record sales and earnings for the quarter and twelve months ended May 2 were achieved by Federated Department Stores, Inc., according to the report of Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman, released today. The chain includes Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus stores in New York.
The post of executive director of the New York Diabetes Association, Inc., was assumed yesterday by Abraham Bluestein.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company has sold its 52.74 per cent stock interest in the Hinde Dauch Paper Company of Canada, Ltd., to St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., a major Canadian paper and paperboard manufacturer based in Montreal.
An amended Department of Traffic regulation permitting advertising on the exteriors of trucks and buses became effective yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The ghosts of Washington, all equipped with typewriters, are so numerous, and so active at their special trade, that the real personalities of most officials, legislators (and, rumor whispers, quite a few judges) are lost in the prose these specters produce for them. But fortunately for contemporary public estimates and future biography, the real man inevitably emerges in news conferences and often in the Congressional Record.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court denied a hearing today to two New York lawyers convicted of perjury and obstructing justice during a grand jury investigation of Harvey M. Matusow, a turn-about Government witness.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- A proposal to let Congressional committees ride herd over a huge minerals stockpile is expected to get early consideration by the Senate Interior Committee.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 1 -- Bob Bavier Jr. of Noroton, Conn., said today that three factors contributed to the hands-down victory his Gulf Stream Thirty, Memory, achieved in the 200-mile Storm Trysall Club race around Block Island.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Consumer installment credit outstanding rose $423,000,000 in April, the biggest rise for any month since the boom of 1955, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The New York Metropolitan Chapter of the American Society for Public Administration has given its 1959 award for outstanding achievement in the field of public education to Police Inspector Robert R. J. Gallati, commanding officer of the Police Academy and assistant dean for police studies, City College.
Following are salient facts on the foreign ministers' conference at United Nations headquarters in Geneva:

Six drawings from the British royal collection will be among those shown at an exhibition entitled "Great Master Drawings of Seven Centuries." It will be open to the public from Oct. 14 through Nov. 7 at M. Knoedler Co., at 14 East Fiftyseventh Street. There will be a private preview there on Oct. 13.

TRENTON, June 1 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court directed the State Public Utility Commission today to reconsider an $11,000,000 rate increase granted to the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company last year.

Recent testimony before a House committee, just released, places the number of persons murdered by the Red Chinese in the past decade at about thirty million. This figure is slightly higher than that which has been generally accepted as the toll in lives of the Communist blood bath. It is still far below what Mao Tze-tung said that he could spare in the course of Red China's road to triumph.

GENEVA, June 1 -- The Western foreign ministers, led by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter, assailed today the Communist propaganda and subversion apparatus maintained in East Berlin and East Germany by the Soviet Union.
Beardsley Ruml's plan to finance higher education, though "well intentioned," will prove to be a serious hindrance rather than a help, an educator predicted here yesterday.
Work on the second, or lower, deck of the George Washington Bridge was started yesterday after a delay of thirty-two years.

NEW DELHI, India, June 1 -Seth Ramkrishna Dalmia, one of the world's richest men, was sentenced today to two years imprisonment for embezzlement of $4,200,000 worth of securities. The securities were misappropriated from the Bharat Insurance Company, one of Dalmia's own concerns.

Franklin Pierce of New York and Gerard Alleyne of Brooklyn, two unseeded players, advanced one round ahead of the field in the Brooklyn men's tennis championships at the Knickerbocker Field Club yesterday.

The board of governors of the Can Manufacturers Institute, trade association of the metal can industry, yesterday selected a symbol to mark the 150th anniversary next year of the invention of the familiar tin can.

Public administrators of the tri-state New York metropolitan area were told yesterday that a sprawling urban complex, highly dependent on the automobile, was greatly complicating the region's transportation crisis.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -The capital's footloose bear appeared today to have tired of city life.

SEVENTH AVENUE, America's garment center, swung into the second week of fall fashion showings yesterday. Two outstanding collections -- those of Jane Derby and Maurice Rentner -- showed that clothes next autumn can be either soft or snappy, depending on the customer's whim.
GENEVA, June 1 -- West Germany put on the record today its fear that the allies might accept a standstill solution of the Berlin crisis that was not specifically tied to Germany's reunification.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) Senator Ernest Gruening, Democrat of Alaska, urged Congress today, to remove the secrecy label from military aid to Cuba. He called the administration's action in making the aid secret a "scandal."

The most meaningful developments in the crucial negotiations for a new steel wage agreement have a way of happening far from the bargaining table in the Presidential Suite at the Roosevelt Hotel here.
The head of the State Labor Relations Board took a major step yesterday in the war against racket unions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 1 -- Eighty-five governments have poured $235,000,000 into the United Nations program to aid under-developed nations during the last ten years, the Technical Assistance Board said today.

YONKERS, June 1 -- Claim Agent, the A. B. C. Freight Forwarding Corporation's 3-year-old bay gelding, was the opening line, 2-1 favorite to win the second race at Yonkers Raceway tonight. That is, Claim Agent would have been the opening favorite, except that Claim Agent ran his race in the morning and was scratched at night.

A package of 765 mortgages, totaling about $4,000,000, on homes built in Richland, Wash., by the Federal Government, was purchased yesterday by the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York.
A fireman who had been indicted by a Nassau County grand jury for alleged juke-box racketeering was suspended without pay yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
Arrivals of out-of-town store buyers showed a sharp increase yesterday, compared with those of a year earlier.

The Transport Workers Union threatened again yesterday to strike Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc., if "even one employe" should be laid off as a result of one-way bus operations.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- A spokesman for the merged labor movement said today that "decent personnel practices, wages, hours and working conditions for nonprofessional hospital employes should be a prerequisite for hospital accreditation.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon is the subject of a biography by Earl Mazo, which Harper will publish June 23. It is called "Richard Nixon: A Political and Personal Portrait." The author, a member of The New York Herald Tribune's Washington Bureau, had access to many of the Vice President's personal and private papers.

Alvin Handmacher's 4-year-old filly. Meticulous, won the feature mile race at Belmont Park yesterday. With Bob Ussery riding, the odds-on favorite beat Vincent Georgi's filly, Lament, by a head in the Virginia Purse.

George E. Judd Jr., managing director of the New York Philharmonic, and Carlos Moseley, associate managing director, met with a committee of orchestra members yesterday to negotiate a new contract. Al Manuti, president of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, headed the committee in the talks at union headquarters, 261 West Fifty-second Street.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- Stunt men have borrowed from the ballet to make themselves more appealing -- and to prevent broken necks.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 1 (Reuters) -- Europe's "outer seven" agreed today at free-trade-area talks to avoid splitting the seventeen nation Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
LONDON, June 1 -- Industrials moved irregularly in a very active stock market here today. The number of transactions recorded was 21,279, an historic high.
"Slow" and "uninspired" were the descriptions used by traders yesterday of conditions on most of the New York commodity exchanges.
GALVESTON, Tex., June 1 (AP) -- A hospital spokesman said tonight that Governor Long "had a quiet day after a somewhat restless night."
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 1 -- The United States Embassy said today that Iraq had renounced American military aid on the ground that it conflicted with her policy of positive neutrality.
NOBODY has been able to draw a solid line from the bluefish of North Carolina's Outer Banks to those of Long Island, but it would be a nice trick, because the Banks are doing big bluefish business.
ALBANY, June 1 (AP) -- New York State's law designed to root out labor-management racketeering went into effect today.

TOKYO, June 1 -- Japan's most widely circulated newspaper, Asahi, predicted today that the Socialist party would win more than one-third of the seats in the House of Councilors, the upper chamber of the Diet (parliament), in tomorrow's national elections.

Here we are locked in a world struggle with unscrupulous adversaries, the Communists, who repeatedly announce their intention to bury us. One-third of this same world is sitting on the fence cautiously and anxiously watching for indications whether the free nations or the Communists are going to win and wanting desperately to be on the side of victory.

Wall Street ended its holiday grudgingly yesterday. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange shrank to the smallest level since February 12. Prices were fairly firm for most of the day, but fell in the final thirty or forty minutes and ended with a net loss.

DETROIT, June 1 (AP) -Paul Foytack, with a string of ten straight incomplete games behind him, pitched a five-hitter against the Cleveland Indians today as the Detroit Tigers gained a 3-1 victory at Briggs Stadium.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Dr. Charles Malik, President of the United Nations General Assembly, expressed the opinion tonight that the West was weak in the ways of "cold war."
Middleton Miller has been :named to the board and Jamesl VT. Coultrap has been promotedj to executive vice president of[ Miehle-Goss-Dexter, Inc., Chi-I cago printing machinery manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The House of Representatives approved today a five-year program to assist Alaska's .transition from territorial status to statehood. The program now goes to the Senate, where concurrence is expected, but perhaps after more scrutiny.
AFTER thirty-one years on the air, the "Voice of Firestone" presented last night what may have been its final program.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 1 -- Music critics here paid reserved tribute today to a Swedish contribution to the space age -- the opera "Aniara."
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
DETROIT, June 1 (AP) -- Auto assembly lines went back into high gear this week after a slight cutback because of the Memorial Day holiday.

President Somoza told The Associated Press in a telephone interview last night that the Nicaraguan National Guard had surrounded a rebel force of twenty-five men flown into the country from Costa Rica yesterday.
JOHN WILLIAM RYAN Jr. is a man of precise neatness, meticulous in his personal habits and meticulous in his ideas about how public officials should act while in office.

THREE electric appliances that will do the work of a dozen helpers are the mixer, blender and drink maker. Each is designed to complement, not compete with, the other. Ideally, every home would have all three.

Boxing buffs had a delightful outing at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. For the better part of two and a half hours the 1,616 spectators oohed, aahed, shrieked and frantically grasped their neighbors as twelve fighters pummeled each other.
Mayor Wagner's mediation board found the hospitals coolly noncommittal yesterday on its formula for settling the hospital strike.
BUENOS AIRES, June 2 -- The value of the Argentine peso plunged to less than one United States cent today.
The big surprise at Belmont Park yesterday was not the horses but the spectators.
The Port of New York smoothly handled yesterday the largest influx of ship passengers so far this year. Eight liners arrived with 4,350 passengers.
The year 1959, less than half gone, may be headed for distinction as a new record year for bank mergers. These are calculated in two ways -- the number of banks absorbed and total assets absorbed.

Two men charged with permitting a total of 130 violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law in buildings they operated pleaded not guilty yesterday in Special Sessions Court. Justice Edward F. Breslin set Sept. 15 for both trials.
CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- The grain futures market turned a bit more bullish today on the Board of Trade although a few weak spots still remained in corn and oats.

The New York committee for a supper fashion show to be held at the Edgartown Tennis Club, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., on July 24 has been meeting here to discuss arrangements for the event. Proceeds will go to the Edgartown Boys Club.
YONKERS, June 2 -- The "early birds" catch no worms at Yonkers Raceway. Every once in a while, though, they catch a winner and that, at a horse park, is the main idea.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- One of the last of the "old pros" among Washington's diplomats, Baron Robert Silvercruys, Ambassador of Belgium, retired today.
BUTTE, Montana, June 1 (UPI) -- The Anaconda Company, one of the world's largest producers of non-ferrous metals, announced today that it had quit the newspaper business in Montana.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee, in a sharp rebuff to President Eisenhower, approved funds today to start building seven reclamation projects.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 2 -- A Georgia delegate urged the American Red Cross today to consider partnership in United Fund campaigns.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Eisenhower told Republican Congressional leaders today that he would not withdraw the nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce even if Mr. Strauss requested it.
YONKERS, June 2 -- A United Nations delegation -- accustomed to the uncertainties of international political weather -- braved the rain yesterday for an evening at the races.

In a number of cases, British firms have submitted the low bid for heavy engineering equipment for Government dams or other Federal installation. Though the lowest, their bids were rejected for a higher bid from some American firm.
The American Museum of Natural History will have a new director on Sept. 15 -- Dr. James A. Oliver, now director of the Bronx Zoo.
The New York Central Railroad has switched its advertising account from the J. Walter Thompson Company, the nation's largest agency, to a much smaller concern, Robert Conahay, Inc.

The Electronics Investment Corporation reported yesterday gains of 89 per cent in net assets and 78 per cent in share asset value in the fiscal year ended on April 30. Net assets totaled $29,273,203 as of April 30.

In a debate that is growing increasingly bitter as the Geneva conference of foreign ministers reaches its crucial stage, Andrei A. Gromyko has now followed up his rejection of the Western peace plan with an even more categoric rejection of the detailed Western plan for Berlin and appears to be driving toward a formal annexation of West Berlin by the East German puppets.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Able, one of the two monkeys who made the historic trip through space last week, died last night on the operating table.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 2 -- Lieut. Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, Indonesian Army Chief of Staff, banned all political activity in Indonesia tonight, the Antara News Agency reported.

Today the annual conference of the International Labor Organization begins an epoch-making meeting of an epoch-making agency. Delegates from no fewer than eighty member nations of all political persuasions -- two representing their Government and one each the employers and workers from each country -- are assembled in the stately headquarters of the I. L. O. on the shores of Lake Geneva. Their sessions will last for three weeks.
PARIS, June 2 -- Finance Minister Antoine Pinay announced today that French industrial production had increased by 4.4 per cent front March to April.
A 36-year-old Brooklyn man who had been convicted of robbery, assault and grand larceny in a hold-up last June was freed yesterday in Kings County Court. Another man had admitted the hold-up.

After surviving ten rounds without a loss, Bobby Fischer, the United States chess champion, met his first defeat yesterday in the eleventh round of the jubilee tournament at Zurich, according to Swiss news sources.
Bill Rosensohn testified yesterday in Federal Court that he had been told that the rematch agreement between Eddie Machen and Ingemar Johansson was now legally binding.
Directors of the Railway Express Agency are going to take a hard look during the next month at a new proposal of the Agency's executive staff to continue railroad ownership of the business.

IF it is a happy country that has no history, it also seems to be true that an unhappy country is likely to inspire literature. The American South, with its racial and economic problems and its memories of war and defeat, is an example. Certainly more novelists have been born in Mississippi than the population statistics would lead anyone to expect.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would buy frozen whole eggs to help the egg and poultry industry.

The visit of Soviet Premier Khrushchev and Defense Minister Malinovsky to Albania, at the head of a large delegation, and the announced visit of the Defense Minister of Communist China dramatically illustrate the strategic importance of Albania to the Soviet Union.
STANTON, Del., June 2 (AP) -- Two horses were killed and their jockeys injured today in a freakish collision during their warm-up just before the seventh race at Delaware Park.

Copper prices dropped 56 to 61 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The volume was 655 lots. Heavy speculator liquidation offset scale-down dealer buying. Trading was influenced by lower London prices and the fear that heavy production in this country in anticipation of strikes might hang over the market.
The Transit Authority sent its Daily Double Special on a trial run to Aqueduct yesterday. The start was slow, the course rough and the finish indifferent. Time: 28:43.

It is costing the First National Bank of Cortland, Cortland, N. Y., $387 a year to be fully prepared for a national emergency such as a nuclear attack -- or a local disaster such as a flood, fire or hurricane.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., June 2 -- Governor Rockefeller announced here tonight that he had ordered a survey of the state's power needs in the next ten years and its potential energy resources.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed by voice vote today President Eisenhower's nomination of William B. Franke of New York to be Secretary of the Navy.

LONDON, June 2 -- Queen Elizabeth went down to Kew today, a bit too late for lilac time, to celebrate the 200th flowering of the botanical gardens planted there by one of her royal ancestors, Princess Augusta of Saxe-Gotha.
GENEVA, June 2 -- The deadlock in the foreign ministers' conference over Berlin worsened today.
Senator George A. Smathers of Florida called yesterday for the creation of an inter-American police force to keep the peace in Latin American countries.
MOSCOW, June 2 -- Russia's biggest show, designed for the American public, went into production rehearsal today at the Bolshoi Theatre.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP) -- Harvey Haddix, who last week pitched twelve perfect innings against the Milwaukee Braves only to lose, 1 -- 0, in the thirteenth, hurled an eight-hit shutout tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates downed the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 -- 0. The Cards won, 3 -- 1, in the completion of a suspended game that preceded the regular contest.
Thomas H. Ryan has resigned as a general executive in the Columbia Broadcasting System television program department to become vice president of Hubbell Robinson Productions Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- Representative Torbert H. MacDonald, Democrat of Massachusetts, charged today that the major oil companies were consigning American tankers to the "scrap heap" by hiring foreign ships and seamen "at sweatshop wages."
Your editorial of May 28 is titled "Let Us Reason Together." The body of the editorial, however, directs this sentiment only to one side in the current hospital dispute.

Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan accepted more than $1,800 worth of improvements on his house from a contractor who later received nearly $2,000,000 for construction at the Monticello harness racing track, the State Investigation Commission was told yesterday.

HONOLULU, June 2 -- The Honolulu Advertiser has reported in a series of copyrighted articles that equipment and supplies worth several thousand dollars are missing from storerooms of the territorial Legislature in Iolani Palace. The Legislature adjourned May 11.
The defending contract bridge champions led by Edgar Kaplan of New York last night held a decisive lead at the three-quarter mark of the finals in the Eastern States knockout teams championship.
CHICAGO June. 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The leasehold on the five-story business building at 24 West Fifty-eighth Street, opposite the Plaza Hotel, has been purchased by Alan H. Posner. The leasehold rents total almost $1,000,000. The plot is 25 by 100 feet.

A GATHERING of the staff yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History wore its collective heart on its sleeve for the guest of honor, Dr. James. Arthur Oliver, who was being welcomed back to the fold.
Leaders of Reform Judaism were advised last night not to discount Jewish population shifts in Manhattan and Brooklyn in evaluating future expansion plans.

Plans are being completed by the Women's Division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York for its sixth annual art auction for the benefit of the Special Fund of the appeal. The event will take place Tuesday evening at the Parke-Bernet Galleries at 980 Madison Avenue.

The difficulties in Nicaragua come as a stunning surprise. This has to be said despite the fact that the regime, headed by the two sons of the former dictator, Gen. Anastasio (Tacho) Somoza, has been labeled for months as a target of the liberal revolutionary movement in the Caribbean.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, June 2 -- In the production of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," which was added to the repertoire of the Memorial Theatre here tonight, Peter Hall has broken with all the traditions that usually influence directors of this play.
Free Shakespeare yesterday lost a court plea for continued performances in Central Park. Meanwhile, plans were announced for a new park amphitheatre that will charge admission.

There is a strong international flavor at the Fifth World Petroleum Congress, being held this week at the New York Coliseum. A distinctly American touch, however, is provided by W. W. Keeler, who, in addition to being executive vice president of the Phillips Petroleum Company, is also Principal Chief of the Cherokee Indians.
LOS ANGELES, June 2 (AP) -- Racketeers are doing a half-billion dollar business in mailing indecent literature and films to youth, clubwomen were told today.
MEXICO CITY, June 2 (AP) -- Mexico deported today Mrs. Marilyn Kay Thal, the American woman who was robbed here of a fortune in Cuban pesos.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 2 -- The head of the banned Communist party was reported to have entered Paraguay as student skirmishes with the police continued today.
THE wild and wooly world of Seventh Avenue, America's fashion center, is now passing through the most hectic week of the most frantic month for buyers of women's clothes.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 2 -- The Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry said tonight it had reliable information that three yachts filled with armed invaders had left Cuba for Nicaragua.

Paramount Pictures Corporation is planning to enter fields unrelated to motion pictures, Barney Balaban, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday. He said the company was considering the acquisition of certain companies but did not wish to identify them at this time.
Stores all over the country again will be offering 21-inch color television sets made by the Admiral Corporation by late August.
Hopes for ending the hospital strike this week all but vanished yesterday as Mayor Wagner's special mediation board ended its hearings without achieving a settlement.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 2 -- The Belgian Government announced today that the wedding of Prince Albert and Princess Paola Ruffo di Calabria would take place in Brussels and not in the Vatican.

Numerology can shape the ends of a big Wall Street deal. The proof came yesterday in the bidding for the the $50,000,000 bond issue of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company. The winning bid was 101.283, which just squeezed out the next best bid of 101.282.

Federal, state and county prosecutors welcomed yesterday the state Labor Relations Board's bid for a cooperative effort to prevent racket unions from using the labor law as a "cloak of respectability."
LONDON, June 2 -- Oxford University indicated today that at Britain's oldest seat of learning Latin was not a dying language.

An inadvertent, serious omission occurred in my column on Sunday, May 31, titled "Science in the Nazi Era," the story of the Ravensbrueck Lapins. Dr. William Hitzig, distinguished and dedicated New York physician, went on a mission to Poland in 1958, examined all of the patients with their Polish surgeons, and his comprehensive report was fundamental in establishing their treatment program in the United States.

AS every one who does much grocery shopping knows, broiling and frying chickens have been one of the thriftiest protein buys in recent months. Since the first of the year, heavy production on poultry farms has resulted in record retail supplies of birds weighing from two and one-fourth to three and one-half pounds.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 2 -- The removal of Governor Long to a Galveston hospital in a National Guard airplane on Saturday is reliably reported to have been carried out against his will. The Governor of Louisiana is immune to commitment to a mental hospital while in his home state.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd. and its United States and Canadian subsidiaries had a net profit of $20,599,000 for the nine months ended on April 30. The company cleared $19,902,000 a year earlier.

NEWARK, June 2 -- Electrical service to 5,000 customer's in Mountainside, N. J., the northwest part of Westfield and the northwest corner of Cranford Township failed for nearly an hour tonight. The police reported that the Mountainside substation had been broken into and two switches had been pulled.
The Russians swapped a "nyet" for a State Department "no" yesterday. The exchange crippled efforts of a little theatre in Wilton, Conn., to combine international goodwill with publicity.
PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -- Reading Railroad stockholders were told today that revenue in 1959 should be about 8 per cent higher than it was last year.

The assessed valuations of real estate and special franchises in New York City for 1959-60 have been set at a final total of $23,549,007,007. This is an increase of about 5 per cent over the $22,450,284,947 for 1958-59.

LONDON, June 2 -- Sir David Eccles, President of the Board of Trade, said today that the Soviet Union expected to place orders for capital equipment and other industrial goods worth 600,000,000 to 700,000,000 ($1,680,000,000 to $1,960,000,000) in the next five years.

GALVESTON, Tex., June 2 -- A judge ordered Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana held in protective custody today at a hospital. He granted a petition by the Governor's wife and Dr. Arthur Long of Baton Rouge, La., a physician and the Governor's cousin.
A PRELIMINARY report on the effectiveness of the state educational television project was made last night in a special program over WPIX.
Soviet labor camps where millions of political prisoners once slaved in the forests of Siberia or on gigantic construction projects are, from all available evidence, things of the past.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- United States District Judge Alexander Holtzoff dismissed today a suit aimed at forcing the disclosure of staff payrolls of all members of Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee moved today to create a State Department "inspector general" for policing the administration of the foreign aid program.
TRENTON, June 2 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed a measure today granting New Jersey's full-time county and state judges a $2,000 annual salary increase.

The Institute for the Crippled and Disabled yesterday presented diplomas and special awards to 160 handicapped persons of all ages at its forty-first annual graduation exercises. The ceremony took place at the institute, First Avenue at Twenty-third Street.
A Navy radarman used his leave to have a hole in his heart repaired in a Brooklyn hospital. He said Navy physicians had refused to operate.
CHICAGO, June 2 -- A vice president of the merged labor federation urged organized business today to work with labor to reduce the number of fund drives.

Something new in gymkhana courses, an eight-tenths-of-a-mile set-up, has been laid out on the Roosevelt Raceway parking field at Westbury, L. I., for the Republic Motor Sports Club's "Mach 2" event on Sunday. The title is a physics term indicating twice the speed of sound and the drivers will have an oppor tunity for high speeds on some sections.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- James R. Hoffa declared today that the paid, per capita membership of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in May was 1,567,347.

CAIRO, June 2 -- The captain of the Danish ship Inger Toft refused today to unload his cargo of Israeli-produced cement, potash and leather as ordered by a war prize court of the United Arab Republic. The captain said he was acting on orders from the ship's owner on Copenhagen.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Representative George H. Mahon opened debate on the $38,848,339,000 defense appropriations bill in the House today with a warning against overemphasis on limited-war strategy.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, urged the nation's colleges yesterday to create a better intellectual atmosphere for their students.
KANSAS CITY, June 2 (AP) -- Seven and one-third innings of tight relief pitching by Tom Sturdivant helped the Kansas City Athletics post a 5-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

This is what can be said about "2 x 4" the miniature revue that opened at the Showplace in Greenwich Village last night: There's a lot of it. Thirteen numbers in the initial session and ten in the second.

TRENTON, June 2 -- The dismissal of a Newark school teacher who refused to answer questions regarding alleged Communist party affiliation was upheld today by Dr. Frederick M. Raubinger, New Jersey Commissioner of Education.

Barry MacKay, an airman third class, has received permission from the Air Force to represent the United States at Wimbledon. He will pair in the doubles there with Alex Olmedo, his Davis Cup team-mate.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A Presidential request to Congress to increase or abolish the legal ceiling of 4 1/4 per cent on Government bonds is expected shortly, the Senate Republican leader said today.
NEW DELHI, India, June 2 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made a new defense yesterday of his administration's plans to develop cooperative farms in India.
WINCHESTER, Calif., June 2, (UPI) -- A B-47 medium jet bomber crashed and burned near March Air Force Base early today, killing three of the four crewmen.

THE Musicians and Dancers of the Japanese Imperial Household, who are appearing in the season of the New York City Ballet at the City Center, last night presented a third program of brief dances and music in the style known as Gagaku.
Because of a shift in his production schedule, Alexander H. Cohen will now bring "The Last Days of Lincoln," Mark Van Doren's first play, to Broadway earlier than he intended.
Mayor Wagner expressed the "deep gratitude" of the people of the city yesterday to sixteen policemen as he decorated them for "conspicuous and extraordinary acts of bravery" in 1958.
STOCKHOLM, June 2 (AP) -- The "outer seven" today got a green light from the "inner six" to form a second free trade area.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- Officials in Lake County, Ind., helped enforce a pinball monopoly that netted operators more than $12,000,000 in five years, the Senate rackets committee was told today.

NEWARK, June 2 -- A $10,000 reward was offered today by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the men who yesterday assaulted two nonstriking employes.

MONTAUK, POINT, L. I., June 2 -- The pollock run is thinning out now and charter captains are complaining that it is hard to stay with a school once it is located. But there is a chance that the visiting dude can get at them in the right way, that is, on top-water bait.
Stadium Concerts still need $29,000 to reach the goal of $100,00O to cover the expected deficit for this summer's concerts at Lewisohn Stadium.

Gene Inyart has been named winner of the 1959 Franklin Watts Fiction Award for her juvenile, "Tent Under the Spider Tree." Miss Inyart, who is now vacationing in Italy, will receive $1,000 as an outright payment and $2,500 as an advance against royalties.
PARIS, June 2 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle's final place in history may well depend on his success or failure in putting France's relations with Africa on a healthy, durable basis.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 2 -- Peter M. Dawkins, the famed halfback on Army's undefeated Eastern championship football squad, was signally honored at the traditional athletic review staged in conjunction with June Week festivities at the United States military academy today.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, returned to his old neighborhood in the Bronx yesterday. He was there to receive the first annual Labor Award from students at Samuel Gompers Vocational-Technical High School.

GENEVA, June 2 -- A "unique opportunity" now exists to achieve the goal of a worldwide system of non-discriminatory trade on a multilateral basis, according to a statement issued by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) today.

United Air Lines, Inc., has placed an order for seven 720 jet transport planes with the Boeing Airplane Company, increasing its orders for the new 720's to eighteen. Orders for the first eleven of these jets were placed late last year and first deliveries are scheduled starting the new 720's are this September.

MILWAUKEE, June 2 (AP) -- Milwaukee's Bob Rush stopped San Francisco with a five-hitter tonight as the first-place Braves posted a 3-0 victory and moved back into a two-and-half-game lead over the Giants.
Objections were raised yesterday to plans to clear a site for Cooper Square.

FLOWER HILL, L. I., June 2 -- Three armed bandits stole a diamond ring and $1,200 in cash in a private home at 125 Woodhill Lane here today after binding their victims and threatening the family's 14-year-old daughter.

In an uncomfortably warm room on the second floor of the firehouse, just over the big red and silver engines, the village Civil Defense Council was holding its May meeting. The council director was here, as he had been at every monthly meeting of the council since it was reorganized in 1950.

Professional investing institutions -- insurance companies, savings banks and managers of pension and trust funds -- have been the major buyers in the bond market ever since the Great Depression, when the supply of investment money outran the demand and depressed interest rates to a level having little or no appeal to the individual investor.

Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State, urged American business yesterday to pay less attention to "temporarily unfavorable attitudes" in the under-developed countries and to increase private investment in these areas.
Plans for a new city on six Boca Ciega Bay islands, near St. Petersburg, Fla., at a cost of $200,000,000 were announced yesterday.
An African Trade and Travel Fair, stressing the art, culture, industrial products and craftsmanship of tropical Africa, will open in New York in the fall of 1960, it was announced yesterday.

Kenneth MacKenna, head of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer story department for the last twenty years, has resigned his post to return to Broadway in the leading role of Dore Schary's new play, "The Highest Tree."

Thomas J. Deegan Jr., vice president-staff of the Alleghany Corporation, has resigned his position with that holding company. In a letter to Alleghany's chairman and president, Alan P. Kirby, Mr. Deegan expressed his regret at severing his employment with the holding company but explained that the growth of his own business affairs prevented him from continuing as an officer. Mr. Deegan continues as public relations counsel for the New York Central Railroad.
NEWARK, June 2 -- The Central Railroad of New Jersey was granted a 20 per cent interim increase today in its intrastate commutation fares.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Eisenhower and Republican Congressional leaders agreed today that something more should be done to get the party's "message across" to the public.

LONDON, June 2 -- Trading continued active in the stock market today and industrials remained irregular. However a slight predominance of gains lifted the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary shares by six-tenths of a point to a new high for the year at 240.7.
CHICAGO, June 2 (UPI) -- Bugs, not the batters, got to Hoyt Wilhelm of the Baltimore Orioles tonight in the first inning of the game with the Chicago White Sox at Comiskey Park.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 3 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi's pro-American Liberal - Democratic party was far ahead of the opposing Socialists as nearly half the votes were counted in yesterday's election to the House of Councilors, upper chamber of the Diet (Parliament).
