WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Henry R. Labouisse, whose appointment to a high administration post was vetoed by the Republican National Committee, has taken a job with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2 (AP) -- The Navy had too much water today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -- A space suit that a man could wear to the moon was demonstrated today at the Philadelphia Naval Base.
Dr. Barnaby C, Keeney, president of Brown University, yesterday cautioned universities to weigh government support carefully to make sure that the price was not too high.
Stocks went through a gentle shakeout yesterday but won back about a third of their losses in the late afternoon. Volume was low during the early declines but expanded somewhat when the rally began.
Signs of instability reappeared in the bond market yesterday.
Industrial securities valued at more than $20,000,000 will be offered to investors today by banking syndicates as follows:

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 2 (AP) -- Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit and Roma Neundorf led Canada to a 4-2 victory over South Africa today in the first round of the British Commonwealth women's golf championship.
A proposal to merge the New York Trust Company and the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank has been approved by directors of both institutions, it was announced last night.

Degrees were conferred on 189 graduates of the College of Mount Saint Vincent yesterday in ceremonies at the school's Riverdale campus. Sixty-four of them were Sisters of Charity who had completed studies in the college's Sisters Division.

SINGAPORE, June 2 -- The British Governor of Singapore agreed today to the condition laid down by the People's Action party for forming a government and then formally proclaimed the new Constitution which creates the self-governing state of Singapore. The charter takes effect tomorrow.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- The 650-passenger ship Leilani, two years in the Hawaiian trade, was put up for auction by the Government today.

The volume of world oil trade will double by 1967, Bernard T. Stott, a vice president of the First National City Bank of New York, said yesterday. Speaking at a meeting of the Fifth World Petroleum Congress at the New York Coliseum, Mr. Stott predicted that the value of world oil shipments would rise to $20,000,000,000 by 1967, compared with $9,300,000,000 in 1957.

The most extraordinary aspect of de Gaulle's come-back is that, in one year, the General has restored to France her self-respect, her international prestige and her fiscal health without, in fact, materially restoring France. That is to say, the same essential weaknesses that eroded the Fourth Republic still erode the Fifth: cumbersome distribution, archaic taxes and the bloody, cruel, expensive Algerian war.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Charles E. Goodell Jr., a Republican, was sworn in today as United States Representative from New York's Forty-third District to succeed the late Representative Daniel A. Reed, a Republican.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 2 (AP) -- President Juscelino Kubitschek today gave the United States-owned American and Foreign Power Company sixty days to improve the supply of electricity in the state of Minas Gerais in order to avoid expropriation.
Los Angeles County, Calif., raised $40,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance flood control installations.

The steel industry asserted yesterday that the jobs of 170,000 members of the United Steelworkers of America were "jeopardized by wages that are so high they cannot meet competition of foreign producers."

Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Vice Chancellor of West Germany, arrived in New York by plane yesterday for a week's visit to this country. He said there were "good grounds for hope of a solution in the case of Berlin which will take care of the position and needs of the city."
Discomfort Index or no Discomfort Index, the weather was pretty miserable here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The United States Government vigorously condemned today the expulsion of Nationalist China from the International Olympic Committee.

Following are the texts of the citations read yesterday by Dr. John A. Krout, vice president of Columbia, in presenting candidates for honorary degrees to Dr. Grayson Kirk, president, at the university's commencement:

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, in a new spirit of harmony with the Atomic Energy Commission, approved today a modified version of the Administration's atomic power program.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Dempster McIntosh will resign soon as head of the Development Loan Fund and be appointed Ambassador to Colombia.
The largest graduating class in the history of Barnard College received degrees yesterday. The 342 graduates included sixty who received their degrees with honors.
In a move that took many boxing observers by surprise, the New York State Athletic Commission refused yesterday to vacate Ray Robinson's world middleweight title.

A plot at the northeast corner of First Avenue and Seventy-second Street has been purchased by Louis Goldfarb and resold to a client of Dreyer Traub, lawyers, for improvement with a twenty-story apartment building.

The path of landlords seeking to evict tenants is seldom smooth. But John Foffe, Brooklyn Heights restaurateur, can attest it gets even rougher when the question of whether art is a profession is raised.

A change in the Sugar Act to permit the Secretary of State to reduce a foreign country's share of the United States market if the country does not deal fairly with American nationals will be requested by Senator George Smathers, Democrat of Florida.
The proposal for a $21,430,829 Title I housing and redevelopment project in the Gramercy Park area has been quietly dropped by the Board of Estimate.
DIDSBURY, England, June 2 (AP) -- Mimi Arnold of Redwood City, Calif., reached the third round of the Northern tennis championships today by defeating Linda Vail of San Francisco, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 2 -- The Knesset (Parliament) has decided to postpone indefinitely collection of a compulsory loan that was to have helped finance the integration into Israel of 80,000 immigrants in the next eleven months.

CAIRO, June 2 (Reuters) -- The Minister of Public Works for the United Arab Republic said today the Soviet Union, which is providing credit for the first stage of the $1,300,000,000 Aswan High Dam, had demanded changes in the blueprint.

LONDON, June 2 -- The Treasury announced today a decline last month of 47,000,000 ($131,600,000) in the reserves of gold and convertible currency held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area.

Joseph Sager Sons, builders, have assembled the blockfront on the east side of Third Avenue from Sixty-sixth to Sixty-seventh Streets for improvement with a twenty-story apartment building for 255 families.
Rain interfered with practice yesterday, so a dozen of the women professionals who will participate in the Triangle round-robin tournament attended a luncheon at Leone's.
Blood will be given today at the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, 625 Madison Avenue, to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

THE Dodgers had the Phillies beaten with two out in the ninth when the batter slammed Dutch Leonard's pitch over the wall for a three-run homer that ended the game. The manager of the Brooks, a certain Charles Dillon Stengel, was a mind-reader even then. There was fire in his eyes as he bore down on his catcher, Babe Phelps.
RYE, N. Y., June 2 -- Walter S. Pease of Plainfield, N. J., took a two-stroke lead today as the United States Seniors' Golf Association's fifty-fifth annual championship got under way.
A battery of Nike-Hercules missiles went through a simulated firing yesterday to make a point for the Army in its missiles feud with the Air Force.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 2 -- A Massachusetts Institute of Technology student who devised a portable microfilm reader is the winner of the top prize for seniors in the Luis de Florez contest for 'outstanding ingenuity" in design projects.
The Court of Appeals has upheld the Waterfront Commission's refusal to grant a checker's license to Arnold F. Jaccarino of 1087 Shore Parkway, Brooklyn.
LONDON, June 2 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told the House of Commons today that he and Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd hoped to carry on their work together "for a very long time."
The international president of a 40,000-member union proposed yesterday that every citizen be compelled to vote in national elections.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Nicaragua's Ambassador, Guillermo Sevilla-Sacasa, asked the Organization of American States tonight to meet in emergency session to consider the invasion of his country Sunday by airborne troops.
The controversial Great Lakes ship pilot problem moved into a new and complicated phase yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Robert Dechert, general counsel of the Defense Department, said today it appeared that some leading companies had withheld cost information in working out contract settlements with the Pentagon. He did not give any names.
New issues of public utility securities totaling more than $100,000,000 will be offered to investors today by banking syndicates as follows:

The American fashion trend for the fall and winter is now being shaped, as Seventh Avenue designers unveil their collections to the press and to store buyers. The showings presently under way are the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July. The new clothes will be in stores by late summer.
A total of $4,000 was presented yesterday to ten winners of the eighth annual scholarship contest of the Utility Workers Union of America, Local 1-2.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- A letter by Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, questions the fitness of Lieut. Gen. Emmett O'Donnell to become a full general and command the Pacific air force.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Senators learned with obvious pleasure today that Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy expected to return more than $29,000,000 of a secret fund of $30,000,000 Congress voted to him last year.
DETROIT, June 2 -- The Yankees, who on May 3 helped Jimmy Dykes make a triumphant debut as a manager by blowing two games to the Tigers, still were extending a helping hand to the Bengals tonight.

CAIRO, June 2 (Reuters) -- Sudan's chief spokesman said in an interview here today that two generals in the Sudanese ruling junta, arrested yesterday, would be tried for treason before a military court.
The Transit Authority's "park-and-ride" program will start Friday. It will enable autoists to leave their cars at fields adjacent to outlying stations and use the subway to congested sections.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2 (Reuters) -- Premier Otto Grotewohl of East Germany joined Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union today on a visit to a state farm in Albania.
Cutting funds to museums and libraries as a means of solving our budget problems disregards the needs for the services these institutions provide.

Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic State chairman, announced yesterday the formation of a public relations concern to be known as Michael Prendergast Associates. Its offices are at 295 Madison Avenue.

Among the 6,571 degrees conferred yesterday at Columbia University was one for an aspiring teacher named Bela Kiraly. As a major general he commanded the Budapest garrison when Hungary rose unsuccessfully against Soviet forces in 1956.
A blond coed was crowned queen of the Summer Festival yesterday with a gilded circlet bearing a Statue of Liberty design, and New York's Summer Festival was officially opened.

FRANK SULLIVAN once called them the Oyster Bay, or out-of-season, Roosevelts. That, of course, was during the New Deal, when the Hyde Park Roosevelts were enjoying their great season in the sun. Now, in a searching, spirited and amusing memoir, "Day Before Yesterday,"* Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. of those Oyster Bay clan diggers tells us about her side of America's most fabulous family.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Eisenhower today dashed the fragile prospects for getting the present session of Congress to put the Development Loan Fund on a long-term financial basis.
RYE, N. Y., June 3 -- Top honors in the first section of the United States Seniors' Golf Association's fifty-fifth annual championship were captured by Virgil V. Roby.
PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -- Pills made of a cortisone derivative reportedly have proved to be used successfully in treating extreme sunburn cases.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Representative Overton Brooks touched off a dispute in the House Space Committee today with an appeal that talk of a committee trip to Moscow be dropped.

Grant Advertising, Inc., has been chosen to handle the advertising for the Chrysler Corporation's new standard-size car, called the Dart, which will be introduced in September, according to an informed source.
ALBANY, June 3 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the state's new transportation chief today to make a broad study of New York's future transportation needs and how to meet them.
Carmen Basilio agreed to terms yesterday to fight Gene Fullmer for the National Boxing Association's version of the middleweight title.

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- After faltering slightly in early transactions, grain futures prices worked moderately higher again today on the Board of Trade with the old-crop corn months leading the advance.

FARMVILLE, Va., June 3 (AP) -- Prince Edward County Supervisors formally approved today, "with profound regret," a county budget stripped of all appropriations for the operation of public schools in the 1959-60 fiscal year.

After an ownership of three weeks Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has sold the five-story apartment house at 657-59 Second Avenue and 238 East Thirty-sixth Street, the southwest corner. The parcel, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, was bought by an investor.
Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister of the Economy, declared yesterday that aid to the underdeveloped countries was "something we must undertake."

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A system of "skywriting" radar that keeps continuous track of the course of an airplane or a storm was demonstrated here for the first time today at the annual convention of the Armed Forces Communications and Electronics Association.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- Representative Francis E. Walter said today that more than half of sixty-seven paintings and sculpture sent to the United States fair in Moscow were the work of artists with "records of affiliation with Communist fronts and causes."

June 3 (AP) --The House of Representatives voted today to prohibit the use of Army personnel 2md equipment at the 1960 Winter Olympics in Squaw Valley, Calif., if athletes from any "free nation" were banne/.
LONDON, June 3 -- Britain's brewers were back in the news today with the announcement of a prospective merger of two of the biggest concerns in the industry.
Degrees of Doctor of Medicine were conferred yesterday on eighty-two graduates of the Cornell University Medical College.
The Ford Motor Company announced here yesterday details of its plan to increase its ownership in Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., through purchase of stock from shareholders.
MANY summer dresses are like geraniums. They are marvelous in bloom but they do not last long. Women who inevitably get bored with their wilted wardrobes by mid-July can act now to prevent boredom.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 3 (UPI) -- Vice Admiral A. C. Richmond, the commandant, swore in seventy-nine men today as ensigns in the Coast Guard.
Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack and other city officials inspected several run-down tenements in Harlem yesterday and were appalled at what they found.
SEATTLE, June 3 -- A nation-wide program of education and action for world peace was presented today to the board of the National Council of Churches.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 6 points yesterday.
Computers are lending a quick, accurate, legible hand to air-traffic controllers in New York and Washington.
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- Nikita Khrushchev's boast that the Soviet economy can overtake this country's in the foreseeable future "can be dismissed as no more than a campaign promise," Mr. Butler said at the convention.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 3 -- "Somebody up there still likes me", said Rocky Graziano as he came off the eighteenth green of the Canoe Brook Country Club today and was besieged by teen-age autograph seekers.
ONE hundred of New York's best-dressed students, who wore hats and white gloves to classes, were graduated this week. They were the senior class of the Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers.

JERUSALEM, June 3 -- Egypt's refusal to permit a Danish ship carrying an Israeli cargo to pass through the Suez Canal is a blow not only to the interests of Israel but also to the integrity of the United Nations, Premier David Ben-Gurion declared today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- William Birrell Franke -- pronounced FRANK-ee -- has such a reputation for hard work and conscientiousness that a story he told about himself in the commencement address at Annapolis today came as a surprise.

" WHEN I think how I scrambled and struggled toward a degree as a Penn undergraduate," said Lou Little with a pleased smile. "This one is coming to me the easy way. I didn't have to do anything to earn it."

The latest listing of reports on stock transactions made to the Securities and Exchange Commission by officers, directors and large stockholders of listed corporation details the Penn-Texas Corporation's purchase last month of 75,654 shares of Fairbanks, Morse Co. stock.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -- William F. Butler, vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said today that 1960 would be "a year of very great prosperity," but that "another recession could start in 1961."
The Pennsylvania State Highway and Bridge Authority raised $10,000,000 in the bond market yesterday by the sale of serial bonds due over twenty-one years and secured by rental revenues.

A tire that contains no rubber or fabric, and that does not have to be inflated, has been developed by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company as a possible solution to some problems of landing rocket-powered aircraft of the future.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, June 3 -- Renewed rioting erupted here tonight when civilians attacked and burned the Security Office. Seven more persons were killed, making a total of at least nineteen dead as a result of the present unrest.

Gary Gubner, De Witt Clinton junior, set a meet record in the shot put and Alvin Napier, Bayside, won two events to provide the highlights yesterday at the fifty-fifth annual Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
Carmine Galante, a hoodlum who has been a fugitive for almost a year, was seized yesterday on the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey.
Frank Canizio wrote an autobiographical account last fall of a life of crime and his brushes with the law. Yesterday, he encountered the law twice more.

Baron Robert Silvercruys, who has just retired after sixteen years as Belgian Ambassador and forty-one years in his country's diplomatic service, has had a right to be happy. Best of all, he intends to remain that way in retirement and to spend half his time in Washington and half in Brussels.
Trading in commodities was dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices moved in narrow ranges and closed irregular.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 24 -- Rumania's oil industry, once thought to be on its last legs, is again a mainstay of the country's economy and is growing every day.
The first salvos were fired yesterday in the United States Customs Court by an art collector battling to have a mosaic by Pablo Picasso declared a work of art.
MANILA, June 3 -- Political opposition to the Government of President Carlos P. Garcia has begun to crystallize.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 3 -- Henry Cabot Lodge told the 161st graduating class of the United States Military Academy today that "missiles can never replace men."
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that a summit meeting hinged on acceptance by the Soviet Union of Western rights in Berlin until Germany was reunited.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 3 -- The Iraq Petroleum Company will pay to Lebanon royalties of about $3,458,000 a year on the 7,500,000 tons of oil passing through pipelines in Lebanon. This is a rise of about 250 per cent from the $1,031,111 a year the Government received previously.

Dr. C. C. Clark, reputedly the first professor in this country to teach a class over television, will retire this month from the faculty of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance. He has been a member of the faculty since 1926.

GENEVA, June 3 -- The United States, Britain and France are ready to freeze troop strengths in West Berlin in their efforts to reach an interim agreement with the Soviet Union that would perpetuate and codify free access to the city.

Dr. Erwin Nievergelt of Switzerland defeated Dieter Keller of Switzerland, who overstepped the time limit and resigned after thirty-nine moves, in the twelfth round of the jubilee international chess tournament in Zurich, yesterday according to a report received here from Switzerland.

The hospital strike is creating a deep rift in our community which will leave a residue of unrest and bitterness unless prompt action is taken to achieve an equitable solution. Perhaps the saddest part of the entire mess is that it could so easily have been avoided if goodwill had prevailed.
How does an expert go about buying good dogs? What does he look for? How much demand is there? Where are they found?

The American fashion trend for the fall and winter is now being shaped, as Seventh Avenue designers unveil their collections to the press and to store buyers. The showings presently under way are the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July. The new clothes will be in stores by late summer.
LONDON, June 3 (Reuters) -- Britain has granted permission for the sale or mortgage of British ships to the Soviet bloc, Transport Minister Harold Watkinson said today.
A disorderly price retreat in United States Government securities deepened the cloud over the bond market yesterday.

The Investors Funding Cor,oration, of New York bought a xpayer with fourteen stores at 3520.52 Johnson Avenue, corner !of-West 236th Street, in the !Rlverdale area of the Bronx. I The plot.is 211 by 100 feet. The properts was sold by Harry Appel through Norman Katz of IOssip Associates, broker.

" MUSIC FOR A SUMMER NIGHT," a series making its debut last night over Channel 7, should go a long way toward appeasing those viewers who regretted the departure on Monday evening of "The Voice of Firestone." Except for the difference in titles the two programs are much the same.
President Eisenhower issued a fresh appeal yesterday to labor and management in the steel industry to exercise "self-discipline" against an inflationary wage agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican National Chairman, denounced today the "won't do" record of the Democratic Congressional majority. He said that record would cost aspirants in Congress the 1960 Democratic Presidential nomination.
Carl E. McDowell, executive vice president of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters, was returned to office yesterday as president of the National Council of Seamen's Agencies.

Ingemar Johansson, the Swedish challenger for Floyd Patterson's heavyweight title, testified in Federal Court yesterday that his father, Jens, was his manager and that he had never paid his adviser, Edwin Ahlquist, any part of his earnings from boxing.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 3 -- The Yankee Clipper, a New York-Boston express train, usually rushes through this town like a house on fire. Today it stopped here because a house was on fire.
CAPETOWN, South Africa June 3 (Reuters) -- South Africa's lower house of Parliament adopted today the Nationalist Government's controversial African self-government bill.

Directors of Textron, Inc., increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday to 31 1/4 cents, payable July 1. This placed the stock on a basis of $1.25 a year, compared with the previous rate of $1, or 25 cents quarterly.
MONTAUK POINT, L. I., June 3 -- For some reason that nobody around here has been able to figure out, the pollock went back to work today, after a short strike, and productivity was pretty high.

It is an unfortunate reflection on the economic attitudes of some Congressmen that the Secretary of the Treasury, Robert B. Anderson, should have to hesitate about asking Congress for a law raising or abolishing the 4 1/4 per cent ceiling on the interest that can be paid on Treasury bonds of five years or more. The only right thing to do is to raise the ceiling.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, May 27:
ROME, June 3 -- The Vatican confirmed today that Pope John XXIII had taken the initiative to avoid political crisis in Belgium.

BONN, Germany, June 3 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that West Germany's foreign policy would not be changed because of the 1961 elections. He is convinced, he said, that his party, the Christian Democratic Union, will win.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 3 -- When college graduates constitute a majority of the American electorate, the role of higher education will face its first real test in meeting a democracy's needs, Dr. Mason W. Gross said tonight.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 3 -- The United States made the world's first known attempt today to rocket animals into a satellite orbit and to bring them back to earth alive. However, initial indications were that no orbit had been achieved.
PARIS,. June 3 -- President Charles de Gaulle set the stage today for the first French parliamentary debate on Algeria in more than a year.
No one can cut the grass so well as the gardener. This is admitted by all, including that upright figure himself. However, his reason for saying so differs from the causes inspiring others.
EVEN the best-run households are plagued by the unwanted insects of summer. Several new methods for controlling insects efficiently and safely are offered at Hammacher Schlemmer.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Joe Brown of Baton Rouge, La., still is the lightweight boxing champion of the world. The 33-year-old fighter retained his crown in Uline Arena tonight with a technical knockout of Paolo Rosi of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A former Atomic Energy Commissioner, Thomas E. Murray, said today that a secret White House report showed that a proposed quota system of inspections for enforcing a nuclear test ban would not be effective.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 3 (AP) -- Federal Judge Albert V. Bryan ordered the Arlington School Board today to review before June 22 the applications of twenty-six Negro students denied admission to white classes.
HUDSON, N. Y., June 3 -- Poultry farmers from nine Hudson Valley and Catskill counties met here tonight to map plans to combat the recession that has struck the egg and poultry industry.
DISBURY, England, June 3 (AP) -- Three American women -- Mimi Arnold, Sally Moore and Belmar Gunderson -- today gained the fourth round of the Northern tennis tournament.
CHICAGO, June 3 -- The president of the American Cancer Society charged today that federated fund raising "was slowing up the fight against cancer."

Gabriel Genovese, described by Assistant District Attorney John G. Bonomi as a "chief lieutenant of Frankie Carbo, the underworld boxing commissioner,'' was convicted yesterday of being an undercover, or unlicensed, fight manager.

BERLIN, June 3 -- The West Berlin de-Nazification chamber ruled today that Hermann Goering was a leading war criminal and ordered confiscation of his "entire" Berlin estate, set at 756,000 marks ($180,000), as "atonement."
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Senate today passed the Alaska omnibus bill, designed to put Alaska on an equal footing with the forty-eight other states.
A $458,429,535 rise in assessed valuations in Queens, a borough of small homes, served to accent yesterday a proposal that "homestead exemptions" of as much as $7,500 be given on all small dwellings.

" Treasury Honors Credit Cards on New Bond Issue." With this headline atop the news, The Bawl Street Journal is on the newsstand today. It's Volume XXXII, No. 1 of the annual fun issue published by the Bond Club of New York. It sells for $1. Circulation 50,000.
EPSOM, England, June 3 -- Parthia, an English bay colt regarded as indolent and unreliable, hurried down the stretch today and won the 180th English Derby by a length and a half.

Electric power production was estimated at 12,761,000,000 kilowatt hours last week, down from 12,931,000,000 in the prior week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the comparable week of last year output totaled 11,155,000,000 kilowatt hours.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -- The Bolshoi Ballet is getting its share of the culture swap. It might be said that the dancers are going Hollywood and lucky to be leaving tomorrow for San Francisco.

THE Icelandic - American String Quartet, which made its United States debut in Boston Monday evening, played its first New York performance last night at the Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library.

MOSCOW, June 3 (Reuters) -- A new history of the Soviet Communist party published in Moscow today says that the role of Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov in World War II was "greatly exaggerated" and out of all proportion to his real contribution.

Susan Trustman, a 19-year-old drama major in her junior year at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, received a film scholarship for summer-session study at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. The scholarship, called the Susan Hayward Academy Award Scholarship, is sponsored by Twentieth Century-Fox in conjunction with the current movie, "Woman Obsessed," starring Miss Hayward.

IN the vicinity of Tenth Street are many products not generally available throughout the city. Three recipes utilizing some of these products are given. The recipe for chicken soup with vermicelli uses culantro, a seasoning that may well be unfamiliar. It is used in Puerto Rican cuisine much like parsley and, in fact, is often called Spanish parsley.
OAK BEACH, L. I., June 3 -- The dredging of Fire Island Inlet and companion projects to nourish eroded beachfronts here and at Cedar Beach are scheduled to start Friday.
LONDON, June 3 -- Stock market prices moved irregularly today after profit-taking had cut into early gains.

Chemical studies of ancient rock formations by the Lamont Geological Observatory of Columbia University suggest that salient events in the formation of the surface of the earth occurred eighty million years earlier than has been generally believed.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- An agent of the Chicago gangland syndicate tried to gain a gambling and vice monopoly in Porter County, Ind., the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field was told today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Eisenhower has finally cut through the tedious rhetoric and propaganda of the foreign ministers' meeting at Geneva and stated his guiding principle for negotiating with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev on the future of Germany.

HONOLULU, June 3 -- Acting on instructions from Gov. William F. Quinn, Territorial Attorney General Jack H. Mizuha today ordered an inventory of all materials, equipment and supplies purchased by the recent Senate.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., June 3 (UPI) -- The Air Force Academy graduated its first class today, commissioning 205 second lieutenants.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House Public Works Committee approved today legislation to pay $4,295,600,000 to states for toll and free highways included in the 41,000-mile Interstate Highway System.
For many years your readers have helped to send needy, aged, blind and crippled women for a brief vacation at Shelter Island Camp.
The city's Master Plan of Arterial Highways and Major Streets was modified by the City Planning Commission yesterday to include proposed changes in the Manhattan area south of Canal Street.
A petition for the return of 121,000 television tubes valued at $513,000 that had been seized in an investigation of a television tube racket was denied yesterday in the Bronx Supreme Court.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3 -- William B. Franke, Secretary of the Navy, told 795 graduating midshipmen of the United States Naval Academy today that they must "find the proper balance between competition and cooperation -- between advocacy and loyalty."

The Florida Power and Light Company, Miami, sold yesterday $25,000,000 of thirty-year first-mortgage bonds to investment bankers headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The price was 100.15 for obligations bearing a 5 per cent interest coupon.
Rush-hour queues for tokens may be considerably eased in a few months if an experiment begun yesterday by the Transit Authority works out.
HARTFORD, Thursday, June 4 -- A session of the Connecticut General Assembly that enacted sweeping state-wide reforms ended at midnight yesterday.
GALVESTON, Tex., June 3 (AP) -- Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana, who was declared mentally ill yesterday, was told today that he stood a good chance to recover within three months.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 3 (AP) -- Two Roman Catholic hospitals today quit the city's Metropolitan Health Council because the Planned Parenthood Center had joined it.
Parents and other taxpayers who attended a hearing yesterday on the Board of Education's proposed building program for 1960 became a captive audience for bond-issue electioneering.

DETROIT, June 3 -- The Yankees performed some heroics tonight to bring a lot of grief to a majority in a crowd of 43,146 and at the same time pull themselves back into the American League's swirling pennant race.
Reginald N. Webster's Quill found no trouble with the weight or the distance at Belmont Park yesterday.

The J. I. Case Company, Racine, Wis., producer of farm implements and industrial equipment, showed a sharp recovery in its results for the first half of its fiscal year and set a new sales record for the period.
GUAYAQUIL, June 3 (AP) -- The renewed fighting brought out looters who began breaking into the city's shops. Troops pursued the thieves, and heavy machine-gun fire continued into the night.
ALTHOUGH Sessue Hayakawa is Japanese, his "Evening of Rare Pleasures," which opened at the Seven Arts Center last night, seems less Oriental than "Rashomon."

Arnold J. Winters, a 56-year-old jeweler, was arraigned in Felony Court yesterday. He was accused of having planned and supplied the weapons that were used in the attempted robbery of a diamond merchant last February.
PURCHASE, N. Y., June 3 -- A symphony orchestra will occupy the grandstand of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here Saturday afternoon to give a free concert for picnickers on the polo field.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The American people would be "badly hurt" if the entire national debt were placed eventually in "short-range money," President Eisenhower warned today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Whatever its advantages in other lands, President Eisenhower thinks the parliamentary system of government has no place in the American scheme of self-government. [Questions 14 and 22, Page 14.]

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Unusually far-reaching effects of a newspaper article -- that in The Times of London with respect to the tenure of Selwyn Lloyd, the British Foreign Secretary -- were demonstrated today when the President of the United States told a White House news conference: "I think there is nothing to it whatsoever."

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat of Georgia, charged today that a pending bill would change the Renegotiation Act to benefit seven leading missile manufacturers in which the United States has invested more than $1,000,000,000.
The rapid rise of Africa as a source of oil and gas was a major topic of interest at the Fifth World Petroleum Congress here yesterday.
MONTREAL, June 3 (Canadian Press) -- Jean-Claude Lessard, vice president of the St. Lawrence Seaway, said today that complaints about the new waterway were premature.
The idea that New York is ever uncomfortable in summer was assailed here yesterday as something akin to Florida's admitting to rain.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 3 -- The development of a "democratic elite" was urged here today at the thirty-eighth annual commencement of Douglass College by Max Lerner, author, teacher and newspaper columnist.

The late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is the subject of a critical biography by Richard H. Rovere that Harcourt, Brace will publish June 17. Called "Senator Joe McCarthy," it tells of the rise and fall of the member of Congress from Wisconsin.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A year's continuation of war-level taxes on corporation income and automobiles, cigarettes, liquor, wine and beer was recommended today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- Army medical exports told the House Space Committee today that they expected an autopsy to show the amount of cosmic radiation, if any, in the tissues of Able, the space monkey who died Monday night.
Any possibility of a rift between the merged union movement and Senator John F. Kennedy over labor legislation appeared yesterday to have been removed.

GENEVA, June 3 -- The United States and Britain have expressed concern over the plan of West Germany's Parliament to elect the country's next President in Berlin. The election is scheduled for July 1.

A supervising housing inspector has been suspended without pay for thirty days by the city's Department of Buildings for failing to report that one of his subordinates had removed files from his office.

Since "The Music Man" made its memorable entry here Dec. 19, 1957, local theatregoers have been wondering what Meredith Willson, who wrote the book, music and lyrics, might have in store for them. Although contracts have not been signed, everything points to "The Unsinkable Mrs. Brown" as Mr. Willson's second Broadway attempt.

A contribution of $25,000 has been made to the Margo Jones Theatre '59 in Dallas, Tex., by Mr. and Mrs. Eugene McDermott of that city. A spokesman for the group said yesterday the gift would be applied to next seasons production fund.

The two-week Russian Festival of Music and Dance, which S. Hurok will present at Madison Square Garden next month during the period of the Soviet Exposition at the Coliseum, will present two different programs instead of the one originally announced.
A quiet, scholarly island in a sea of commercial and often noisy exhibits is provided by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) at the Fifth World Petroleum Congress.

GENEVA, June 3 -- The forty-third International Labor Conference was faced with a resolution by the United Arab Republic calling for a study of "undesirable" mass migratory movements when the conference began a three-week session here today.

Mayor Wagner's three-man special mediation and fact-finding board has failed to end the long strike against the voluntary, nonprofit hospitals. When the board makes its report the issues and the way to a solution may be clearer. But, in the meantime, certain principles may be stated.
A panel of four judges agreed yesterday that the traffic court had an educational as well as a penal function. But they did not agree on how those functions might best be carried out.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3 -- Eleven newspaper men have been selected to attend Harvard University for one year as the twenty-second annual group of Nieman Fellows. They will start their studies next September.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 4 -- Japan's electorate gave Premier Nobusuke Kishi's pro-Western Government increased backing in Tuesday's elections to the House of Councilors, the upper chamber of the Diet (Parliament).
GENEVA, June 3 (Reuters) -- East Germany is the only country that has broken the rules of the International Press Center here since its formation in 1954, the center's secretariat said last night.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa fired another shot last night in his running war with the Board of Education over "waste and extravagance" in the school construction program.

WHITE PLAINS, June 3 -- Westchester's vigil against dangerous radiation has disclosed sixty-five hazards in hospitals and medical offices, the County Health Department reported today. Many of the hazards were quickly eliminated.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Eisenhower said today that he did not believe the bitter Senate battle over confirmation of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce had impaired Mr. Strauss' ability to work with Congress.
The plastics industry is issuing a warning on the plastic bags that have suffocated children who have used them as toys.
In your issue of May 24 there appears an article by Walter H. Waggoner, written in London, under the headline "Collision Renews Iceland Dispute."

The Financial General Corporation has acquired a substantial interest in the Atlas Plywood Corporation, George Olmstead, president of the former, a holding company, announced yesterday. At the same time Atlas elected a new president and added a member to the board.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Department of State has only preliminary and general reports on the rioting in Guayaquil, an official said today.

LONDON, June 3 -- Harold Watkinson, Minister of Transport and Civil Aviation, told the House of Commons today that he would lead the British delegation to the shipping conference in Washington next week.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa accused the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today of negotiating "sweetheart" contracts and of accepting "company unions" into its ranks in Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Nicaragua, invaded by airborne rebels and beset by grave internal difficulties, got no immediate help from the other American republics today. At an emergency session of the Organization of American States, Guillermo Sevilla-Sacasa, Nicaraguan Ambassador, said the threat to his country justified invocation of the Rio Pact. Cuban representative described the situation in Nicaragua as an internal affair, one that did not merit the intervention of others.
PARIS, Thursday, June 4 -- The French Government and the National Assembly passed early this morning through the first crisis of the new regime and the Government has emerged the winner.
PARIS, June 3 -- The foundation of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's view of world affairs is his refusal to accept the idea that national influence should be proportionate to national material power.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse confirmed that he would oppose his Democratic colleague -- Senator Richard L. Neuberger, for re-election next year.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 3 -- The serious nature of the fund-raising crisis confronting the American Red Cross has been made plain in the last three days at the organization's convention here.

MOSCOW, June 3 -- The magazine New Times says the Soviet Union has called for a summit conference of Balkan states to discuss Soviet proposals for turning the Mediterranean area into an atom-free zone.
Subscribers to Group Health Dental Insurance will receive increased benefits with no rise in premiums, starting July 1, the organization announced yesterday.

SINGAPORE, June 3 -- The biggest political rally in the history of Singapore was held tonight by the People's Action party, whose leaders will be sworn in Friday as the first Government of the new state of Singapore.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Confusion over the outlook for a labor reform law thickened today as public and private leaders, from President Eisenhower down, voiced a variety of views and demands.
CINCINNATI, June 3 (AP) -- Stan Williams held the Cincinnati Reds to two hits tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers won, 5 -- 1, with the help of John Roseboro's two homers and four runs batted in.

President Eisenhower said yesterday that it would be tragic if anti-Semitism became a serious issue in connection with the Senate controversy over the appointment of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce. Every thinking American will agree, we are sure.

Merger news continued to dominate the banking scene yesterday. The State Banking Department said no application had been received in connection with the proposed merger of the New York Trust Company and the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank.

A tract of land adjacent to Flushing Airport in the Whitestone area of Queens has been purchased by Jack P. Schleifer, a realty investor. It is bounded by 138th and 140th Streets, Fifteenth and Twentieth Avenues.
The nation's gasoline stocks showed a small decline last week. This is natural with the approach of the summer driving season, when consumption usually rises sharply.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 3 (UPI) -- President Sukarno has counseled the Army Chief of Staff to refrain from any drastic action in the crisis over the "guided democracy" plan, it was learned tonight.

GENEVA, June 3 -- Avery Brundage, the American president of the International Olympic Committee, rejected today charges that the committee had yielded to Communist pressure in withdrawing recognition from Nationalist China.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Senate approved today a multi-billion-dollar farm money bill, including a strict $50,000 limit on price-support loans to individual farmers and farm companies.

SUMMER is imminent, and one of the most colorful indications of the season's approach are the open-air markets on lower First Avenue. In the vicinity of Tenth Street, greengrocer stands are awash with golden peaches, ruby-skinned cherries, carmine-fleshed watermelons and varicolored mountains of asparagus, green beans, mustard greens, radishes and fresh dill.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 3 (Reuters) -- Czechoslovakia handed a note to the United States Charge d'Affaires today saying systematic violations by United States planes of Czech air space had created a dangerous situation on the West German border, the official agency Ceteka reported.
NORWALK, Conn., June 3 -- The Board of Education tried a new maneuver last night in its effort to obtain more money from the Norwalk Board of Estimate.
FORT MADISON, Iowa, June 3 (UPI) -- Four convicts sawed their way out of the Iowa State Penitentiary early today while holding two guards captive at knife point.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Eisenhower expressed concern today over the influence on the defense program of what a questioner called the "munitions lobby."
NEWARK, June 3 -- The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad has retreated from its announced plan to give up all suburban commuter service by June 9.

Lopert Films, Inc., which is presenting the highly successful revival engagement of Charlie Chaplin's "Modern Times" at the Plaza Theatre, yesterday announced plans for the showing of another Chaplin comedy, "The Gold Rush." According to Ilya Lopert, company president, the second acquisition will be "blanketed" in theatres across the country during the next two weeks.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 3 -- A Costa Rican commercial plane was forced down by Nicaraguan Air Force fighters today and detained in Puerto Cabezas on the Caribbean coast, the National Guard announced.
The 153 graduating students at Cooper Union's 100th commencement were told last night that the institution was embarked on a new era of growth.
LONDON, June 3 (Reuters) -- Russia has designed what would be the world's largest blast furnace and is in the process of building the world's biggest hydraulic station, Moscow radio said today.
TRENTON, June 3 -- The validity of the state's new college scholarship program today was questioned in a taxpayers' suit filed in the Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court.
A request that Fifth Avenue bus routes be "totally and permanently" diverted from Washington Square Park was made public yesterday by the Washington Square Park Committee.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Studies of thirty-eight pairs of twins have indicated only a slight possibility that rheumatic fever may be hereditary.

Hourly and salaried workers in the steel industry in April totaled 620,601 -- almost back to the average for pre-recession years, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. The figure was about 17,000 higher than in March of this year when it reached 603,635 and about 118,000 above the total for April, 1958, when it fell to 502,653.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- William R. Connole, vice chairman of the Federal Power Commission, today suggested formation of an impartial Government-industry agency to recommend an over-all national fuels policy.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference:
There may be more television cameras than ships on the St. Lawrence Seaway when the new waterway officially opens June 26.

With the Geneva conference of foreign ministers in the showdown stage, President Eisenhower has again called on the Soviets to match their peaceful words with deeds and show some willingness to reach at least preliminary agreements to justify a summit meeting. As a minimum, he suggests, they must end their drive to oust the Western powers from Berlin and accept clear commitments not to impede Western rights in that city until Germany is reunited.
The Reisinger Cup teams-of-four championship was won early yesterday by Edgar Kaplan of New York and his teammates for the fourth successive year.
Enrollment in Jewish schools in this country has increased 131 per cent in the last decade, the Fourth National Conference on Jewish Education was told last night.
The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on an appeal by the striking hospital workers' union from an anti-strike injunction and contempt citations against two union leaders.
Stocks rose briefly yesterday morning and then declined slowly for the rest of the day, ending about where they started.

George P. Monaghan, State Harness Racing Commissioner, approved a plan last year that enabled Yonkers Raceway to borrow $1,750,000 at 2 per cent interest, the State Investigation Commission was told yesterday.

The State Commission Against Discrimination announced yesterday that two Negroes had been admitted to membership in the union local that controls the sought - after clerk and checker jobs on New York piers.

Eight members of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects who have been elected fellows of the institute were honored yesterday at the chapter's annual luncheon meeting at its headquarters, 115 East Fortieth Street.
MILWAUKEE, June 4 (UPI) -- Orlando Cepeda drove in seven runs, five of them on two homers, in leading the San Francisco Giants to an 11-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves and Lew Burdette today.
Prices of wool rose sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading was influenced by improved demand for actuals here and in London. Futures trading was moderately active.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- Henry Cabot Lodge has told the Daughters of the American Revolution that the organization's position that the United States should withdraw from the United Nations was based on "virtually total misapprehension."
EVERYTHING about "Dr. Willy Nilly" is fine except for one thing. As acted at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre last evening, it was not very funny.
Governor Rockefeller's name will probably appear on the Republican Presidential preference ballot in next May's Oregon primary, Gov. Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon disclosed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for $343,000,000 extra for the 1958-59 fiscal year, which ends June 30, and for the coming year.
The cotton futures market moved irregularly yesterday. Prices at the close were 11 points lower to 14 points higher than on Wednesday. The far months were strongest.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations said today he hoped the dispute over the seizure of Israeli cargoes in the Suez Canal could be settled as a legal not a political problem.
The final phase of the permanent financing of the $460,000,000 Con.necticut Turn16ike is in negotiation among 'the state officials and investment bankers.
What percentage of earnings should a company pay in cash dividends?
Governor Rockefeller pleaded yesterday for cooperation in reducing highway accidents after he had presented cash awards to winners in the National Traffic Safety Poster Contest.
PARIS, June 4 (AP) -- The French Government today granted an oil exploration permit for an area in the Sahara to a new company partly owned by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- State Department officials today urged Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister of the Economy, to seek fuller German participation in projects for the assistance of under-developed areas.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) -- The Committee for Economic Development urged the United States Government today to support freer trade in Western Europe.
Hernan Pelayo, baritone from Santiago, Chile, and Lucille Sullam, soprano from New York, gave a joint recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
BALTIMORE, June 4 (AP) -- Gene Littler of Singing Hills, Calif., and several other touring pros made the new Pine Ridge Golf Course look easy today.

The United States Plywood Corporation in the fiscal year to April 30 turned in the highest sales in its history and more than doubled its net income over the preceding fiscal year. Sales and earnings for the April quarter also set a record for any quarterly period, S. W. Antoville, chairman, reported.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Arthur S. Flemming warned today that this country had the choice of the Administration's school-construction program or no legislation on that subject this year.
The Federal Reserve System has backed up the recent increase from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent in its lending (discount) rate to member banks by tightening pressures on member bank reserves.
ATHENS, June 4 -- Greece made a formal answer today to the Soviet note of May 14 warning against permitting guided missile bases on her territory.

LONDON, June 4 (Reuters) -- An awe-struck London high school audience today gave a rip-roaring welcome to thirty young actors from Texas appearing in a cowboy version of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A group of non-unionized Nebraska truckers won permanent authority to transport freight to St. Louis and Chicago that large carriers had refused to handle because of "hot cargo" clauses.

GENEVA, June 4 -- Two battles on the European front of the "cold war" are now approaching a point of decision: the struggle for Berlin and the big Soviet political offensive, in which Berlin has been only the pivot.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 687,726 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,981 cars, or 0.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 157,947 cars, or 29.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 16,681 cars, or 2.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Council of the Organization of American States voted tonight to set up a fact-finding commission to investigate Nicaragua's allegations that she is being invaded and that a danger to peace in the Americas exists.

TOKYO, June 4 (AP) -- Jet planes, believed to be Russian, made three observation approaches on a United States airliner over the North Pacific today more than 200 miles off Soviet territory, Northwest Airlines reported.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 (AP) -- Nathanael V. Davis, president of Aluminium, Ltd., today said sales were improving in all major markets.
Construction costs in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts are increasing at such a rate that "difficult decisions will have to be made," John D. Rockefeller 3d warned yesterday.
PARIS, June 4 -- Premier Michel Debre warned France's allies today that they must make France's cause in Algeria their own.
GENEVA, June 4 -- West Germany informed its allies here today that no definite decision had been taken on the holding of the Federal Presidential election in Berlin, reliable sources reported.
Lumber production was 253,028 board feet last week, compared with 212,551 board feet in the comparable week of 1958.

Van Jones of Kings Point advanced to the semi-finals in the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference tennis championship yesterday at Brooklyn College. He eliminated Bernie Levinsky of Long Island University, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, in the opening round and moved into the round of four by defeating Don Levy of Pratt Institute, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.
OTTAWA, June 4 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports took a spurt during April, climbing by more than 7 per cent to $404,633,000 from $376,903,000 a year ago.

"Caligula," written by the Nobel Prize winner, Albert Camus, is promised for the New York stage once more. Chandler Cowles and David J. Cogan are the latest to declare their intention of doing a joint presentation of "the philosophical melodrama," dealing with the Roman tyrant, on Broadway late in November or early December.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company yesterday celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of its health and welfare program for policyholders and the general public.
More than 16,000 Rotarians and guests from seventy nations will attend the fiftieth annual convention of Rotary International at Madison Square Garden for five days, beginning Sunday.
CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Plans have recently been completed for an exhaustive study of a lonely stretch of Alaskan coast where five hydrogen bombs may be used to blast a harbor from the tundra.

At the Sokolniki Park exhibition in Moscow this summer, Russians will get a new insight into pleasure boating. They will see among selected American creations the Sudbury Laboratory's transparent pram.
Nonprofessional employes at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital will go on strike at 6 A. M. today, Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union announced yesterday.
CINCINNATI, June 4 (AP) -- Joe Nuxhall hurled his second complete-game victory of the season tonight as the Cincinnati Reds downed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5 -- 3.
The Staten Island ferryboat Cornelius G. Kolff slammed into the approach slip of her terminal at South Ferry a 10:40 A. M. yesterday.

Average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $191,000,000 to $849,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Reserve balances exceeded requirements by $326,000,000, a decline of $18,000,000 for the week.

The amount of outstanding loans to business by the larger New York City banks declined 272,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a drop of $105,000,000 in the comparable week of last year.
Market values on the New York Stock Exchange fell almost $3000,000,000 yesterday in a decline that embraced every group and all but a handful of stocks.
A sight-seeing train for airport visitors will begin operating today at New York International Airport.

The market for United States Government securities experienced a change of sentiment yesterday afternoon after many of the issues of Treasury bonds and notes had drifted to new lows. As a consequence, most of the issues -- especially those of long term -- made gains on the day from 1/16 to 1/8 of a point.

Bolts of lightning seem to be hitting Latin America as if a great storm were sweeping over the area. Nicaragua, Ecuador and Paraguay, in their different ways, are responding to the electric tension set up by the victory of Fidel Castro and the Cuban revolutionaries at the beginning of the year.

A new feature film dramatizing the plight of Christians under communism in East Germany has been commissioned by the Lutheran Churches of America. The untitled project is the second feature movie undertaken by the religious body, which produced the highly successful "Martin Luther" six years ago in conjunction with Lothar Wolff and Louis de Rochemont Associates.
The American Ballet Theatre will give a performance at the Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday, June 27, under the direction of Lucia Chase and Oliver Smith.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads estimated yesterday the net income of Class One railroads in April at $62,000,000, nearly four times the $17,000,000 cleared in April of last year.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A House subcommittee was directed today to speed an investigation of the hiring of retired military leaders by defense contractors.

LONDON, June 3 (Reuters) -- Led by Peter May's century England recovered from an early collapse to score 358 for six wickets on the opening day of the first cricket test against India at Nottingham today.

The second volume of a three-volume biographical study of Benjamin Harrison, twenty-third President of the United States, will be issued July 27 by University Publishers. Written by the Rev. Harry J. Sievers, a Jesuit priest, it is called "Benjamin Harrison: Hoosier Statesman."

If any "public servant" is more thoroughly dedicated to the abuse of the public's patience than the Fifth Avenue Coach Line I have yet to hear of it. I am obliged to wait for the Eighth Avenue branch of this line at Nineteenth Street every afternoon between 3:15 and 4.
A demonstration at Fordham University yesterday showed that drinking "so impairs a driver's judgment that he cannot make critical decisions fast enough."
Great Lakes shipping interests have honored Col. Loren W. Olmstead, an Army Corps of Engineers construction expert, by naming him "Great Lakes Man of the Year."
Dr. Bernard Mandelbaum has been appointed provost of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.
LONDON, June 4 -- A leading United States travel promoter predicted today that 360,000 American tourists would visit Britain this year and 1,000,000 a year would be coming here by 1969.
SINGAPORE, June 4 -- The release today of eight Leftists jailed as subversives put a question mark over the political future of the two-day-old state of Singapore.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today recalled his financial plight of forty-three years years ago. The President used the story, in a speech to business-magazine editors, to emphasize the need for curbing inflation.
A sign-changing ceremony to mark the new name of a three-quarter-mile portion of Fourth Avenue took place yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 (AP) -- Stan Musial of the St. Louis Cardinals tied a National League record with his 651st double today, but it wasn't enough to prevent the Pittsburgh Pirates from whipping the Cardinals, 9 -- 3.
The United Steelworkers executive board emphasized yesterday that the union was ready to be "flexible and reasonable" in wage negotiations with the twelve biggest steel companies.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Two major changes in foreign aid legislation will be proposed by the Draper committee in a forthcoming report.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- There is plenty of honest statistical evidence to show that the rising costs of production in the United States are tending to price American industry out of world markets. And today some legislators argued that an industry entirely within the domestic pattern can and should be required to operate at losses also traceable to this rising cost of production.
The Empire State Music Festival will take its production of Ildebrando Pizzetti's "Assassinio nella Cattedrale" to Montreal on Thursday, Aug. 6.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A training, research and publicity program to support an organizing campaign among professional and technical employes was approved today at a meeting sponsored by the Industrial Union Department of the labor federation.
GENEVA, June 4 -- Andrei A. Gromyko refused to discuss the key issue of access to West Berlin at the foreign ministers' conference today.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Senate completed passage today on the authorization of $485,300,000 for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration during the fiscal year starting July 1.
DETROIT, June 4 -- The Yanks are moving again.

A woman can buy a new wardrobe in New York today and the bill will not come to any more than it would have three years ago. But groceries, for which about one-third of the entire income is spent, cost 8 per cent more.

ROME, June 4 -- The Fifteenth anniversary of Rome's liberation by Allied forces was observed by Parliament today in a formal commemoration. The Center-Right city government, however, all but ignored the date despite public protests.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 24 -- Bucharest celebrates its 500th anniversary this year. To mark the occasion, the Communist city fathers are working out an elaborate plan for the development of the capital.

The two houses occupying a frontage of fifty feet at 440-42 West Fifty-eighth Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, have been purchased by the Spring Holding Corporation, headed by Charles Punia of Punia Marx, Brooklyn builders.
NORWALK, Conn., June 4 -- An invasion of snapping turtles is disturbing the Norwalk-Westport area.
The Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday that it would reduce coach fares fort family and group week-end round trips between here and Philadelphia.

Full ownership of the Medical Arts Centre building at 57 West Fifty-seventh Street, northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) has been acquired by Charles and Milton A. Kimmelman, realty investors.

Employes of The Associated Press, 50 Rockefeller Plaza, will give blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today. Employes of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Companies will join in the donation.

Japan's election of members for the upper house of the Parliament indicates that the trend that seemed apparent in earlier elections was not deceptive. The majority of the Japanese electorate has shown its support for a moderate, middle-of-the-road and flexible government. This was forecast in both the local and provincial elections.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- An optimistic report on sulfinpyrazone, a newly discovered drug to relieve gout, was made today to the Second Pan-American Congress on Rheumatic Diseases.

A major general whose portrait has adorned a twelve-cent postage stamp for more than twenty years will be relieved in that respect by a brigadier general tomorrow when a new twelve makes its first appearance at Oxford, Ohio.
Ground was broken yesterday for a thirty-two-story office building at 235 East Forty-second Street, northwest corner of Second Avenue.

The president of the American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company said yesterday he was hopeful of a rise in zinc prices. Speaking at a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts here, Howard I. Young said:

RYE, N. Y., June 4 -- The first half of the field in the United States Seniors Golf Association championship yesterday left a score of 148 as the target. It was the lowest thirty-six-hole total registered at the Apawamis Club course on Tuesday and Wednesday.
A "limitation of funds" is forcing the Maritime Administration to curtail operations at several of its installations.

LONDON, June 4 -- Industrials turned dull in the stock market here today. The recent favorites declined a shilling (14 cents) or so, but the falls generally were in pennies and were accompanied by many rises.

When New York City's Summer Festival is on, as it now is for June, July and August, the official position is that the weather hereabouts is perfect for visitors. It certainly was a curious coincidence that in the very week Mayor Wagner was proclaiming a 1959 tourist season from which business men hoped to reap a dollar bonanza the United States Weather Bureau should begin publicizing a Discomfort Index in New York.
OTTAWA, June 4 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada interest rate shot up this week to record level of 5.33 per cent, the central bank reported today:

The twenty-ninth annual volume of The New York Times Index, with its 1,029 pages bulging with the summaries of a half million news items that tell the history of the year 1958 in all phases of man's activity, is off the press.
Engineers began inlaying a new Idlewild runway this week with "flush lights" that will make landings possible in almost any weather.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Formation of a United States-Euratom joint research and development board to guide reactor work was announced today.
A Brooklyn export packing company has filed a $2,000,000 libel suit in the State Supreme Court against the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists, 327 Lexington Avenue.
HAVANA, June 4 -- The Government promulgated the new land reform law today. Under its terms, 1,666,000 acres of cane land are to be expropriated from United States sugar companies within a year.
BONN, Germany, June 4 -- Konrad Adenauer wants to give up his candidacy for the Presidency of West Germany and continue as Chancellor.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 4 -- The Soviet Union, East Germany, Rumania and Nationalist China have been admitted to membership in the International Theatre Institute, Jean Darcante, its secretary general, announced today.

Check volume in the twenty-six major cities of the nation in the week ended on Wednesday totaled $24,134,880,000, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. This represented a gain of 2.2 per cent over the prior week's turnover of $23,614,387,000 and 17.5 per cent over the $20,546,889,000 of the similar 1958 week, a holiday week.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Pentagon's research chief confirmed today that the United States was experimenting with a death ray as a defense against ballistic missiles.
MIAMI, Fla., June 4 (AP) -- A cache of arms and ammunition, believed stored by Nicaraguan rebels, was seized here yesterday. Three persons were jailed on charges of violating the Neutrality Act.
A 26-year-old secretary, Miss Lillian Freiberg, was found guilty last night of voluntary manslaughter in the slaying last Nov. 9 of her sweetheart, John Conwell, 28, a former Air Force pilot.
Air Delight, won the first running of the Annapolis Hurdles at Belmont Park yesterday by a head -- that is, Jimmy Hobales' head.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A secret White House report prepared by leading scientists concludes that, theoretically, steps could be taken to improve the detection of underground atomic explosions as well as to conceal such explosions from an international inspection system.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Dr. Erhard was informed of the report that Chancellor Adenauer had changed his mind about resigning in a message brought in to him during a conference with Deputy Under Secretary Robert Murphy at the State Department late this afternoon.
A Long Island union was ordered yesterday to repay members for dues collected under a closed-shop contract during the last four years, and to help make up pay losses suffered by insurgent members.
Sid Caesar, who terminated a. contract with the National Broadcasting Company two years ago, has signed a long-term exclusive television pact with the Columbia Broadcasting System.
New York's corps of foreign consuls -- or a good many of them -- went up to the Bronx Zoo yesterday to have a look at some of the animals from back home.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -- The San Francisco Board of Supervisors is scheduled to approve an agreement next Monday to bring an oriental art collection valued at $12,000,000 to $15,000,000 to the M. H. de Young Memorial Museum here.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Senators, Representatives, state officials and suburbanites asked Federal help today to keep commuter trains running. Witnesses told the Senate Surface Transportation subcommittee that the Government had a duty to insure continued commuter service until the mass transportation problem could be solved.
OTTAWA, June 4 -- Howard Green was named Canada's Minister for External Affairs today.
Dissatisfaction with the Board of Education's proposed $100,000,000 building program was expressed yesterday at the final public hearing on the board's 1959-60 capital budget.

THE musicians and dancers of the Japanese Imperial Household last night introduced the last of the four Gagaku programs they are presenting in the season of the New York City Ballet at the City Center.

TWO HUNDRED years ago next Sept. 13 the fate of the North American continent was decided in a battle that lasted for only about ten minutes. And not many combatants were engaged on the Plains of Abraham just outside the City of Quebec on a high bluff overlooking the St. Lawrence River.

The belief that any future wars will be won or lost "overnight" is hurting this country's maritime preparedness, Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A nine-man majority of the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee said tonight that Lewis L. Strauss should be confirmed as Secretary of Commerce because of his "honesty and integrity, competence and his long record of achievement as a top administrator."
Most Jewish parents in this country are ignorant of their religious heritage, Dr. Judah Pilch, executive director of the American Association for Jewish Education, asserted yesterday.

BERNARD SHAW'S infrequently done comedy, "Getting Married," may have its moments of garrulity. But, as it was revived last night at the Provincetown Playhouse on Macdougal Street, it shone brightly for the most part.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Taxpayers who might gain from the Supreme Court's forthcoming ruling on the taxability of strike benefits are advised by the Internal Revenue Service to make their claims before their legal time limit expires.
One man was killed and two women were injured near Grand Central Station yesterday evening when an automobile veered out of control and mounted a sidewalk.
GENEVA, June 4 -- The East Germans at the foreign ministers' conference let it be known today that important talks between East German and Soviet leaders would be held in Moscow next week.
CAPT. JAMES W. LA BELLE is a tall, graying, slow-spoken New Englander with piercing eyes and bushy brows who will turn 50 later this month.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 4 -- President Somoza said tonight that Nicaragua had contained the invasion and had "sufficient means to take care of the situation."
GENEVA, June 4 -- Dr. Adenauer's reported decision to remain as Chancellor caught West Germans here by surprise.

Despite repeated advice that the law was not being complied with, Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan permitted Yonkers Raceway to proceed with construction in 1958, the State Investigation Commission was told yesterday.
Capt. James W. La Belle, master of the luxury liner Constitution when she collided with the Norwegian tanker Jalanta last March 1, has been found guilty of negligence by the Coast Guard.
The Reid newspaper fellowships, which have been awarded to fifty-nine persons in the last eleven years for study abroad, have been temporarily discontinued.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- New York's Congressmen are ready for drive to deepen harbors in New York State likely to benefit from the St. Lawrence Seaway.

Governors of the American Stock Exchange yesterday adopted a new rule for the control of traders operating on its floor. The regulation, which follows criticism of floor trading by the Securities and Exchange Commission, will become effective June 15.
Dancer - Fitzgerald - Sample, Inc., which lost the Nucoa margarine account two years ago to Guild, Bascom Bonfigli, Inc., won it back yesterday.

Four more delegates to the 1957 Apalachin crime convention were held in high bail yesterday in Federal Court after they had pleaded not guilty to an indictment charging conspiracy to obstruct justice.
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., June 4 -- The transition from rails to tires in the New Jersey commuter's daily crossing of the Hudson has brought frustrations that make him long for "the good old days."

DIDSBURY, England, June 4 (AP) -- Sally Moore of Bakersfield, Calif., was the only American winner and Mimi Arnold of Redwood City, Calif., was the principal upset victim today in the women's singles quarter-finals of the Northern tennis championship.
Dick Tiger, the British Empire middleweight champion, and Rory Calhoun of White Plains, N. Y., will meet in the scheduled ten - round feature fight at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Petroleum deposits probably exist in offshore areas of the Atlantic Coast of the United States, a group of geologists reported yesterday.

BONN, Germany, June 4 -- An East German spy organization of 12,500 agents is seeking state secrets and ammunition for psychological warfare in West Germany, according to a report published here today by the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan renewed his "declaration of war on slums" yesterday in an appeal to Mayor Wagner.
About 150,000 persons of all ages participated yesterday in the 130th Anniversary Day parades of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union.
GENEVA, June 4 (AP)-- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd of Britain and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union held a brief private meeting today to discuss the renewed fighting in Laos.

It is gratifying to those of us in the field of science education to see the problems of science teaching in American schools brought to the attention of the public by the President's Science Advisory Committee.
WILTON, Conn., June 4 -- A complaint charging Raymond Massey, the actor, with breach of the peace was dismissed today by Julian A. Gregory, Wilton's prosecuting grand juror.
TRENTON, June 4 -- An extradition warrant for Frankie Carbo, alleged boss of the boxing underworld who is wanted in New York, was signed today by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 4 -- Barry MacKay, who will play at Wimbledon this month, appeared in exhibition tennis matches today at Mitchel Air Force Base.
Judge Irving R. Kaufman reserved decision yesterday in Federal Court on a suit to block the forthcoming heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson, the Swedish challenger.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, June 4 -- This sprawling port city was tense today under an around-the-clock curfew imposed by the Ecuadorian army.

At a moment when the North Atlantic alliance is undergoing its severest test at Geneva, the Atlantic Congress, the first of its kind, will be formally launched by Queen Elizabeth in London today to cement the solidarity not only of the governments but also of the peoples of the Atlantic community and make it a more potent factor in world affairs.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the 16-year-old United States chess champion, and Paul Keres of the Soviet Union were both winners in the thirteenth round of the jubilee tournament in Zurich, according to a report last night from Switzerland.
