Investment bankers headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler placed on the market yesterday $4,470,000 of 4 1/2 per cent serial equipment trust certificates of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad. The certificates mature annually to 1974, and are priced to yield 4.35 per cent to 4.70 per cent.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 4 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union flew to Budapest today with the unconcerned air of a holidaying salesman unable to resist showing his wares. The bouncy Soviet leader cut short his scheduled twelve-day visit to Albania to make the trip here from Tirana in a TU-104 jet airliner.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 4 (AP)-- Discoverer III's four black mice apparently are dead.
Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, urged the graduating class of the Collegiate School yesterday to cultivate "systematic habits of rational thought."
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 4 -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim announced tonight Iraq intended to withdraw from the sterling currency area in the near future.
LONDON, June 4 -- The Lancet, a leading medical journal, is urging British physicians to fight for the abolition of boxing.

In his letter published in The New York Times of June 1 Mark Goulden posed the following question to Americans: "Has your long preoccupation with the Russian menace (serious though it is) distracted your attention from another menace which some of us in England consider to be no less insidious or minatory?"

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -- The resignation of Kenneth MacKenna on Tuesday as story boss of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer prompted one of the movie industry's most important executives to consider today the changes that have occurred in recent years in story departments of movie companies.

THIS will be as profitless as voting the straight Republican ticket in Georgia but it must be done. In less than a week baseball's top brass will formally arrange a second All-Star game, probably in Los Angeles early in August. That is one All-Star game too many.
WASHINGTON, June 4--President Eisenhower gave his strongest hint today that he would ask Congress to increase or abolish the interest-rate ceiling of 4 1/4 per cent on Government bonds.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) -- An atomic energy expert predicted today that nuclear power would supply about 10 per cent of the nation's energy demands by 1975 and could replace coal as a major fuel by the year 2000.
"PLAYHOUSE 90," which earlier in the season presented "The Plot to Kill Stalin," last night examined "The Killers of Mussolini."

HARTFORD, June 4 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky, Republican National Chairman, declared tonight that he was "going on the assumption there will be a contest" for the Republican Presidential nomination at the national convention next year.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Ogden R. Reid to be Ambassador to Israel.
The election of Mrs. Mark Van Doren as an alumnae trustee of Barnard College was announced yesterday at the sixty-fourth annual meeting of the Associate Alumnae. She will serve a four-year term.
LAWS and leases -- not just salesmen -- should be consulted before purchasing major appliances.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 4 -- Bonnie Randolph of Columbus, Ohio, took a 2-point lead in the first round of the seventh annual Triangle round-robin tournament over the south course of the Canoe Brook Country Club today.
New York City borrowed $27,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public school construction and to fund the city's social security costs for the first half of 1959.
The "most ambitious program in the city's history" for the treatment of narcotics addicts was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Metro Holovachka, while a $12,000-a-year prosecutor in Lake County, Ind., paid $43,599 mostly in cash for a home, a Senate investigator said today.

WIESBADEN, Germany, June 4 (AP) -- A team of investigators will look into the wartime mystery crash of a United States Liberator bomber in the Libyan desert in 1943, the United States Air Force reported today.

YONKERS, June 4 -- Sixth after three-quarters and third at the top of the stretch, Trader Horn finished with a burst of speed and won the $25,000 Palisades free-for-all mile trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

A possible increase in the dividend of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company in the next quarter was indicated yesterday by Ralph W. Burger, chairman and president of the nation's largest food chain.

The American fashion trend for the fall and winter is now being shaped, as Seventh Avenue designers unveil their collections to the press and to store buyers. The showings presently under way are the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 4 -- The Great Neck South Shareholders, Inc., will liquidate its holdings of seven shares of stock tomorrow after two months of careful scrutiny of market returns and sometimes frantic trading by its fifteen speculators.
BOSTON, June 4 -- The American Cancer Society authorized today an intensified program to alert the public, particularly teen-agers, to the dangers of cigarette smoking.

Special meetings of stockholders in the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank and the New York Trust Company probably will be called within the next four or five weeks to vote on the proposed merger of the two banks.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, took issue today with President Eisenhower's decision to shun a summit conference unless the foreign ministers at Geneva made "a measure of progress."
Governor Rockefeller pledged last night to do all he could to strengthen the Republican party in New York State.
A drug discovered by accident two years ago is said to have revolutionized the most common major operation, the removal of cataracts.

HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., June 4 -- The only run of bluefish around Long Island that could be called consistent has been going on here for a few days. But it appeared today to be dwindling, and expert opinion was that it couldn't last much longer.
Queens detectives credited a hold-up man yesterday with collaborating with justice. He robbed a supermarket, they said, and then he took an incriminating picture.
David Dubinsky, vice chairman of the Liberal party and one of the labor movement's leading liberals, attacked "phony liberals" yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A wheat bill "nobody wants" was sent to the floor of the House of Representatives today.
THE bright red strawberries that shoppers buy today may well be the first of this year's Long Island crop. If not, they are probably from New Jersey, where the peak of the season is approaching.

Communist China was ruled ineligible yesterday to compete in the 1960 Winter Olympic Games. The action was announced by Robert L. King, executive secretary of the games, which will begin at Squaw Valley, Calif., Feb. 18.
CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- A private crop report that traders described as slightly bearish depressed prices of most grain futures moderately today on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon hopes to fly across Siberia on his trip home from Moscow next month.
A saleswoman of the Lord Taylor department store, 424 Fifth Avenue at Thirty-ninth Street, was killed yesterday morning in an elevator accident.

Former Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont said last night that a dangerous situation was being created because many United States citizens of Jewish faith "seek a relationship with the foreign state of Israel, which is different from that which other Americans have with Israel."
Bellevue Hospital may be the "star" of a new television series.

I am afraid that Arthur Krock's column of May 19 commenting on the recent indictment of International Ladies Garment Workers Union Local 25 under the antitrust laws gives a somewhat one-sided picture.
The four-week strike against six voluntary, nonprofit hospitals has now spread to a seventh. Improper to begin with, its continuation and expansion are wrong morally and in the sight of the law.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Senate opened formal debate today on the nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce.

In another surprise move Chancellor Adenauer has reversed himself and announced his "unshakable intention" to continue in his present post of power instead of moving to the more ceremonial office of West German President.

The four-week strike of hospital employes spread yesterday to a seventh voluntary institution, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. At the same time a group of proprietary hospitals averted a strike by granting union recognition.
PARIS, June 5 -- President Charles de Gaulle was on the road again today, talking to provincial Frenchmen about everything that interests him and them, from foreign policy to cheese.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Two Texas cattlemen propose to register their brands as trademarks. One brand has been applied to protesting calves for ninety-nine years.

A Coney Island factory fire caused a subway tie-up yesterday morning in Brooklyn that delayed 12,000 rush-hour riders. Two other delays, in Manhattan occurred as the aftermath of fatal falls in front of trains.
LOS ANGELES, June 5 (AP) -- Nearly 60,000,000 Americans cannot be sure there is enough water available to put out a major fire on a hot summer day, a water official said today.

MOSCOW, June 5 -- Soviet spokesmen insisted today that the Western powers were committed to a summit conference on Germany despite President Eisenhower's insistence that such a meeting depended upon the results of the foreign ministers' talks in Geneva.

In 1958 other countries withdrew $2,275 million of their balances here in the form of gold. Through May of this year they had drawn down another $346 million. By the time we have set aside the gold required for our new subscription to the International Monetary Fund our gold stocks may well have fallen below $20 billion for the first time since 1940.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., June 5 (AP) -- Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck, who died May 21, willed gifts to Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish institutions, it was disclosed today.
Fordham University will hold commencement exercises Wednesday at 3 P.M. on the terrace of Keating Hall on the Rose Hill campus.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 5 (AP) -- A judge was on the verge of jailing a newspaperman for contempt of court today but the newsman finally disclosed a confidential news source after having gained permission from the source to do so.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee asserted today that military aid had at times bolstered dictatorships strained foreign economies and disrupted relations between non-Communist nations.

CINCINNATI, June 5 (AP) -- Big Don Newcombe, working his curves and change-ups to perfection, tamed the San Francisco Giants tonight on three hits as the Cincinnati Reds scored a 7-2 victor. The 33-year-old right-hander tired in the last inning but hung on and completed his victory.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 5 -- Governor Rockefeller announced tonight a broad new program designed to encourage the building of thousands of apartments that middle-income families could afford to rent.

WHAT makes a woman in a supermarket switch soaps in a few seconds, reject a brand of soup or stay faithful to one floor wax? Women are revealing the answers inside a large stone house in Peekskill, N. Y. This is the headquarters for the Center for Research in Marketing, a 2-year-old organization that determines people's subliminal and conscious reactions by scientific techniques.
GALVESTON, Tex., June 5 (UPI) A hearing on June 16 will determine whether Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana is to be confined to a mental hospital here for an additional ninety days.
BALTIMORE, June 5 (AP) -- Gene Littler carved five strokes off par 72 at Pine Ridge today and finished one shot ahead of his nearest competitor halfway through the Eastern open golf tournament.
A bill to allow policemen to remain in service beyond the mandatory retirement age of 63 to qualify for Social Security benefits was passed unanimously by the City Council yesterday.

HAVANA, June 5 -- The proposed tax on society news in Cuban newspapers and magazines will be excluded from legislation scheduled to be put into effect July 1, according to the Minister of the Treasury.

COMPTON, Calif., June 5 (UPI) -- Al Cantello, a 28-year-old lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps, broke the world record for the javelin tonight with a throw of 282 feet 3 1/2 inches. The performance came in the first event of the twentieth annual Compton invitation track and field meet.

Sales and earnings of the Sunbeam Corporation so far this fiscal year are well ahead of those a year ago and are expected to stay ahead for the rest of the fiscal year, R. P. Gwinn, president, told the annual meeting in Chicago.

Major changes in the economic life of the New York metropolitan region in the new two or three decades are forecast in a series of books that will be published by Harvard University Press. They are based on the three-year New York metropolitan region study conducted by Harvard University for the Regional Plan Association and financed by the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the Ford Foundation.
The Fund for the Republic has announced that its headquarters at 360 Riverside Drive will be transferred from New York to Santa Barbara, Calif., by Sept. 1.
Dogs have occasionally appeared on the stage as performers, but there was one in the audience at last night's Town Hall concert of the Charles Pope Choristers.

YONKERS, June 5 -- Sanders Russell drove Uncle Dave, a 4-year-old bay horse, to a dynamic victory in the featured Class AA Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Dynamic, too, was the drive turned in by the 59-year-old Russell with the $5.20-to-$2 favorite.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The chairman of the House Agricultural committee called upon Ezra Taft Benson today to "follow the intent of Congress" and use available Federal funds to prevent egg and poultry farm foreclosures.
BRILLIANT strokes of courtesy and punctilio may be expected by the civilized world beginning today when the politest fishing contest of all time begins off Cape Hatteras, N. C.
RYE, N. Y., June 5 -- With a round of 71 John W. Dawson of Palm Desert, Calif., retained the United States Seniors Golf Association championship title today.

Kidder, Peabody Co., underwriter and dealer in securities with headquarters at 17 Wall Street, has leased space in 2 Broadway from Uris Brothers, the builders. The lessee will use the Broadway quarters to provide enlarged offices for its general office staff.
If the senior police officer on duty in Central Park decides to wander afoot in his domain these days, he may carry a walkie-talkie radio outfit.
CHICAGO, June 5 -- A new board of directors of the Canadian British Aluminium Company has been elected.

Spiegel, Inc., Chicago mail order company, is offering to shareholders the right to purchase $15,417,500 of 5 per cent subordinated debentures at a price of 100. The offering is on the basis of $100 principal amount of debentures for every twelve shares of common held. The offer will expire June 22.
Organized employers joined with organized labor yesterday in praising moves by the State Labor Relations Board to prevent racket unions from availing themselves of the board's help.
LONDON, June 5 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer's decision to withdraw his candidacy for the Presidency of West Germany and to remain as Chancellor has startled the British.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets remained at 119.5 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
The Chrysler Corporation formally announced yesterday that it would offer a new "smaller" car this fall. It said the car, called the Dodge Dart, would be marketed by Dodge dealers.

Today marks the eighth celebration of National Golf Day, the one day in the year when the 5,000,000 or so men and women in this country who are devoted to the ancient game have an opportunity to compete against the champions.
BOSTON, June 5 (AP) -- Two Children's Hospital physicians reported today that a new measles vaccine had prove effective, in the first group of children to whom it was given.
Two producers were cited yesterday for screen achievement.

Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that New York State would market $50,000,000 of construction bonds in two blocks on June 30. One block of bonds will consist of one-to-fifteen-year maturities and the other of one-to-twenty-year maturities.
The city moved swiftly yesterday to prevent accidental suffocation of children in plastic bags.
Dorothy Stickney's dramatization of the life of the late American poet, Edna St. Vincent Millay, will be brought to Broadway in September under the auspices of Sol Hurok.
The United Cargo Corporation's container shipping service will be extended to Europe this summer, the company announced here yesterday.

THE American woman shopper spends more money, decides faster, returns more purchases, is less polite to sales people and less timid about expressing her personality through her clothes than an English-woman.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 5 -- A chic, energetic woman who once put tigers into a turquoise cage and seals behind flamingo-colored bars to enhance their "glamour" stepped into the presidency of the world's largest advertising specialty house this week.
PALERMO, Sicily, June 5 -- The Communists seemed confident and their adversaries worried as campaigning for a crucial election in Sicily ended officially tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The four-nation fact-finding commission named to investigate the Nicaraguan crisis put off today an observation trip to the area of strife.
AN unusual, comprehensive and frank review of America's immigrant and minority groups started this week on the National Broadcasting Company radio network.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 4 -- Nylon stockings, as many as a hundred to a bundle, have been overwhelming the local office of the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals since it published an unusual appeal Monday.
MADRID, May 28 -- Evidence of public discontent in the independent-minded Province of Catalonia is mounting.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) -- A Senate Labor sub-committee voted today to set up a youth conservation corps patterned after the old Civilian Conservation Corps of depression days.
SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., June 5 -- The nation's bond executives were crossed up today by the United States Weather Bureau.

It should be gratifying to every true sportsman on the grounds of genuine sportsmanship, and to every human being who prefers political realities to mythologics, that the International Olympic Committee has decided to drop the pretense that the Chiang Kai-shek Government on the island of Formosa is the actual Government of China.

The scientific and technical marathon known as the Fifth World Petroleum Congress crossed the finish line yesterday. Plans already are under way for the next meeting, which will be held in West Germany in 1963.

Latin America now has its own equivalent of Van Cliburn. He is a 17-year-old Bolivian violinist, Jaime Laredo, who beat the best that the United States, Russia and the rest of the world could put together, in Brussels last Week. This was the Queen Elisabeth of Belgium International Music Competition, a major European contest. It is the first time any Latin American has won a musical prize of such importance.

The State Investigation Commission has given Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan until Tuesday noon to decide whether he will appear before it to answer charges of violating the state's Code of Ethics.
Not to be outdone by the Aqueduct set, Yonkers Raceway fans will get their own special subway train starting June 18. The train will operate on the East Side line of the IRT.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The way was cleared today for the House Labor Committee to start consideration of a labor regulation bill next Thursday.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 5 -- The fabled "ivory towers" of American colleges are in fact fortresses against ugly attacks upon the spirit of freedom, Herbert Block told an audience of 800 at the thirty-first commencement of Sarah Lawrence College today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 -- Two or three years ago Ellsworth Hunt Augustus stood on rising ground in central Ohio and surveyed the landscape below him. It was a stretch of beautiful, tree-dotted, rolling farm land, marked by a large, inviting lake.
SUMMIT, N. J., June 5 Betsy Rawls shot a second par 72 over the 6,200-yard south course of the Canoe Brook Country Club today for a thirty-six hole total of 144.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 -- The nation's Chief Scout Executive said today that it was imperative that American youth be made to recognize "that without freedom there can he no security."
ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 4 -- Paraguay's financial situation, reputedly the soundest in South America, forms a paradoxical background for the country's political disturbances.

GENEVA, June 5 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of seeking to annex West Berlin to East Germany and of establishing in East Berlin one of the world's heaviest concentrations of subversion and espionage.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 5 (UPI) -A Cuban exile was shot dead tonight when he and a group of colleagues stormed the Cuban Embassy to avenge the slaying of a Dominican boy and the wounding of another Cuban.
Swift Co. showed a sharp increase in earnings in the semi-annual report issued yesterday by the nation's largest meat packer.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 5 -- Long Island won the Golf Illustrated Trophy and Mrs. Bruce McGhie gained the admiration of the tournament's players at the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's triangular team match today.
Stocks drifted through a dull and inconclusive session yesterday. More stocks fell than rose and the standard market gauges disagreed.

The Schact-Ryan Holding Corporation, which built the three-story garden apartment building at 133-01 to 133-09 North Hempstead Turnpike, Flushing, Queens, in 1957, sold it to the Parkview Realty Company. The property fronts 100 feet on the Turnpike, and feet on 134th Street.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points off to 4 up, with the far months showing the most strength. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)
NEW DELHI, India, June 4--The Indian Communist party has decided to hold a week-long campaign for national support of the Communist position in the Kerala school controversy.
BUFFALO, June 5 (AP) -- An action to strip citizenship from Dominic D'Agostino of Niagara Falls, a delegate to the Apalachin gangland convention, was taken by the Government today.

Events today: Daniel Caruso, bass, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30 P. M.; Golden Hill Chorus, assisted by members of the Downtown Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Blues, Ballads and Gospel Songs, Carnegie Hall Chapter Hall, 8:30; Young Artists Recital, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30.
The Grand Union Company is disposing of its Canadian stores.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., June 5 -- Five stores were burned out tonight in a fire that raged out of control for more than two hours near this city's principal shopping center. Four firemen were slightly injured.
STRATFORD, Conn., June 5 -- The Health Department here has canceled a series of polio-immunization clinics in a controversy involving the Fairfield County Medical Association.
Minnijean Brown, standing tall and proud in a white dress with a corsage of red roses in her hand, was graduated yesterday from New Lincoln High School in Manhattan.

CAMDEN, N. J., June 5 -- Frankie Carbo, a leading underworld figure in professional boxing, was sent to Camden County Jail today to await the results of a legal battle over his extradition to New York.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Vice Chancellor, said today that he would make no decision on his future political plans until he returned to Bonn.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The man who developed and named the Discomfort Index suggests that New Yorkers stop complaining about the title and start advertising what the index shows -- that the city's weather is relatively undiscomfortable.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 3--The Government has no intention of quickly resuming its drive to collectivize the remaining independent peasants, an Agricultural Ministry official said today.
A modified plan for widening Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets was offered yesterday by Borough President Hulan E. Jack.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 5 (UPI) -- Two speeding commuter trains collided head-on during the rush hour at a station just outside of Sao Paulo tonight, causing a heavy loss of life.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- William P. Rogers Jr., Attorney General, today announced the indictment of nine present and former deputy sheriffs of Montgomery County, Ohio, on charges of mistreating persons in their custody.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 5 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev's visit to Budapest took a nautical turn today. Accompanied by Hungarian Communist leaders and a gypsy orchestra, the Soviet Premier went for a boat ride on the Danube River.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 5 -- Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, chief of the Nicaraguan armed forces, said today that the current attempt to overthrow the Government was "a flop."
Cardinal Spellman will bless and dedicate tomorrow at 3:30 P. M. a new $1,600,000 wing at St. Patrick's Home for the Aged, 66 Van Cortlandt Park South, the Bronx.

Rich Tradition of the Meadow Stable won the mile purse for 3-year-old fillies at Belmont Park yesterday by the comfortable margin of three lengths. The victory was warmly applauded by the favorite players in the crowd of 19,450 as Mike Sorrentino guided Rich Tradition to the winner's circle.
SEOUL, Korea, June 5 (AP) -- South Korean troops repulsed four attempts yesterday by North Koreans to slip across the armistice zone into South Korea, a South Korean Army spokesman announced today.

Both Soviet players suffered unexpected defeats in the Jubilee chess tournament yesterday, according to a report from Zurich, Switzerland.

JONES BEACH, L. I., June 5 -- A new ocean - front bathing area, representing the first stage in a $15,000,000 project for the development of the western end of Jones Beach, opened to the public today.
Six inches of water seemed to. be missing yesterday from the St. Lawrence Seaway, but it was only a paper loss.

The most important negotiation now going on in Geneva resumes active meetings Monday. This is the effort by the British, the Russians and ourselves to draw up a treaty that would end those nuclear tests now menacing mankind's ultimate heritage.
A 15-year-old boy was shot and critically wounded in a fight with two other youths on a Harlem street last night. Two women standing near by were injured by stray bullets.

The five-story building containing twenty-two apartments and three stores at 868 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the 868 East Tremont Holding Corporation, which had owned it for thirty-five years. A client of Morris Klausner, lawyer, paid cash over mortgages amounting to $55,000 for the property in a deal negotiated by Robert E. Hill, Inc., broker.

CLEVELAND, June 5 (UPI) -- The chief executives of the nation's five railroad operating brotherhoods have rejected a proposal by the Association of American Railroads that a Presidential commission be appointed to study working rules.

The use of atomic energy to find and produce oil is widespread in both the United States and the Soviet Union, according to reports presented to the Fifth World Petroleum Congress here yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., June 5 (AP) -The Dominican Consul, a Miami policeman, a Tampa flier and four others were indicted by the Federal Government today for conspiracy to smuggle arms to the Dominican Republic. Prosecutors said they hoped to arraign all next Friday.

LONDON, June 5 -- Are time clocks really necessary ? Are surveys of illness and absenteeism worth the trouble? Are half-a-dozen pink, blue and white slips essential to getting an item from a stockroom to a sales counter ?
GENEVA, June 5 -- An Indian lawyer said today there was a prima facie case of the crime of genocide against the Chinese Communists because of their "mass killings" in Tibet.

A Congressional investigation of the National Labor Relations Board was demanded yesterday by the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A "denervation" operation said to provide "safe and consistent relief from arthritic pain" was described at the second Pan-American Congress on Rheumatic Diseases here today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) -- The Defense Department said today that a bomber discovered in the Libyan desert recently took off from a base in Africa sixteen years ago on a bombing mission to Naples.

LONDON, June 5 -- Thursday's setback on Wall Street prompted a bout of selling in the stock market here today and many industrials fell several shillings.

CHICAGO, June 5 (UPI) -- Harry Simpson's bases-loaded pinch double in the eighth inning scored all three runners tonight and led the Chicago White Sox to a 5-2 triumph over the Boston Red Sox. By winning, the White Sox lifted their American League lead to a game and a half.
Jack Howard of Brooklyn Poly and Van Jones of the United States Merchant Marine Academy gained the final of the fifth annual metropolitan collegiate tennis tournament at Brooklyn College yesterday.
Seven voluntary hospitals are now coping with the biggest emergency cases in their history -- themselves.

Thirty-three children from Public School 33 in Queens, made the first run yesterday on the new sightseeing train at New York International Airport, Idlewood, Queens.

Fifty vintage artillery shells, some dating to the Spanish-American War, brought the police, the Army and the Fire Department to the abandoned storehouse of a dealer in antique munitions and equipment last night.

Clergymen of four major faiths called yesterday for general recognition that "licensed drivers have a moral as well as legal responsibility" on the highway.

Rory Calhoun of White Plains, N. Y., and Dick Tiger of Nigeria went into last night's Madison Square Garden ten-round middleweight bout evenly rated.

SARATOGA, Calif., June 6 -A century-old California vintner showed off to the public today a $2,500,000 modernistic champagne cellar built on the proposition that Americans' taste for wines would continue a steady growth.

THE principal events in Robert Bell's first novel occur in Moss Bayou, Ala., a sleepy village across the bay from Mobile, where time takes on "the dimensions of forever." Peter Abbott, a sensitive orphan of 20, comes there in the still, hot summer to live with his great-aunt, Miss Clarice Billy.

TORONTO, June 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian candy industry is asking the Federal Government for protection against imported confections, which amounted to 16 per cent of the Canadian market last year.
Signs are beginning to appear that the new Soviet SevenYear Plan's capital investment program is already running into trouble.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 6 -- One state and three meet records fell today as Section Eight (Nassau County) captured the sectional team championship for the ninth straight year in the twelfth annual New York State public high school track meet on Schoellkopf Field.

After reading Mildred Adams' "The American Tourist Reigns in Spain" (May 17), I could not resist offering a few suggestions to the Air Force wives who are having difficulty adjusting to life, Spanish style.

MIAMI BEACH -- The halt in new hotel construction that came with the disastrous winter season of 1957-1958, remains, but there is now a resumption of development of new facilities in terms of towering additions to the area's two largest hotels, and the building of big apartment houses with hundreds of units.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- This is a report on how to endure and survive a commencement address in a hot June sun and is prepared at the request of a young man in Cambridge who is about to be sprung from Harvard.
The Ford Foundation announced 181 fellowship awards last week as part of its program to bring about a better understanding of foreign and international affairs.

Mikhail Tal, Soviet grandmaster at chess, was in first place yesterday after winning in twenty-eight moves from Hein Donner of the Netherlands in the fourteenth round of the Jubilee tournament in Zurich, according to a report from Switzerland.
Beardsley Ruml's "Memo to a College Trustee" is wide of the mark in its analysis of the problems of colleges.

THERE is a first-rate band of Shavian actors at the old Provincetown in Macdougal Street. Today they will give two performances of "Getting Married." On Tuesday they will act "Buoyant Billions," with "Overruled" as curtain raiser.

SOME two years ago, in a letter from Paris published in these columns, I spoke of "Tempo di Roma" by Alexis Curvers, a Belgian poet and novelist, as a book which delighted me greatly -- as it apparently did many other readers.

STRATFORD - on - Avon in Ontario has become more than a great North American attraction because of its annual Shakespeare Festival. It is also a convenient center for a leisurely week in which interesting side-trips can alternate with the playhouse, as well as with a Music Festival, Film Festival, and other attractions.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -Ezra Taft Benson might well stand on Capitol Hill today and wave a shock of wheat. Such a gesture would symbolize how thoroughly he has thrown the enemy camp into confusion.

CAPE MAY, N. J. -- This resort village at the southern tip of New Jersey has a venerable history. It was founded as a whaling settlement early in the seventeenth century, and before the Revolutionary War it had become established as a seaside resort.

THE twelfth annual Rose Festival will get under way at 3 o'clock this afternoon at the Queens Botanical Garden, Flushing Meadow Park. Otto H. Langhans will be on hand to answer questions on rose growing.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 6 -- Legislative supporters of Gov. LeRoy Collins have beaten off attempts to commit Florida to a course of bitter-end resistance to school desegregation.
LONDON, June 6 -- Gen. Lauris Norstad told the Atlantic Congress today that the greatest danger of war lay in the possibility that an enemy's "probing operation" would get out of control.
A deeper dedication to the intellectual traditions of religion was urged by the Rev. Dr. Louis C. Gerstein in a sermon yesterday.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., June 6 -- One of the fastest growing suburban areas in Westchester County will go to the polls Tuesday to vote on a $4,547,198 school expansion program. The hope of officials is to catch up in one big leap with runaway ranch-house construction.

IN the end is the beginning. Group shows, which every September herald the new art season, at its June close ring down the curtain. One and all retire. Masters and followers; those for whom the game is up or just beginning, and art's Vicars of Bray, soon to return brandishing the new look.

MILWAUKEE, June 6 (AP) -- Charley Tidwell captured three events and anchored a winning relay team as Kansas piled up a record 98 points tonight in winning the Central Collegiate Conference track and field championship for the fourth straight year.
WINDOW boxes add a finishing touch to homes of every size and style. Since they are on public view at all times they need careful planting in May for a display all season.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 6 -- Acts of terrorism and vigorous police searches kept Managua on edge last night.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) -- The Coast and Geodetic Survey reported today that one of its men had climbed the highest peak in Ethiopia with the help of a helicopter.
A psychiatrist said yesterday that Alcoholics Anonymous had far surpassed medical science in the treatment of chronic alcoholism.

The scholarship fund of the New York Council of the Navy League of the United States will gain as a result of the world premiere of the motion picture "John Paul Jones" at the Rivoli Theatre on June 16.

THE story of medicine is written in the lives of men who dared to break with tradition, usually in the face of serious opposition, and often with the treat of death hanging over them if they failed. Here, in three fine biographies which adults as well as high-school and college students will enjoy, are the stories of three of medicine's greats, a surgeon, a research specialist, and perhaps the best medical teacher in history.
CHICAGO, June 6 -- Two-run homers by Vic Wertz and Frank Malzone cooled off the first-place Chicago White Sox today and provided Boston with a 4-2 victory.

THE history of nursing in America -- and a bright history it is -- is well served by these two new biographies. The focus of the first is on a beautiful young Quaker girl who left her pleasant New Jersey home to nurse Union soldiers on the battlefields of Pennsylvania and Virginia.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 6 -- Harrison Rosdahl of Ridgefield Park established himself today as the best weightman in state schoolboy history. He set records in the shot-put and discus, highlighting the forty-first annual New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association track and field championships at Rutgers Stadium.
PARIS, June 6 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer's decision to remain Chancellor of West Germany was interpreted today by many here and in other capitals as a move in defense of "Europe."
WHY hasn't someone warned me before concerning off-Broadway theatres? Last week I saw my very first off-Broadway show at the Phoenix and came out of that theatre with tears in my eyes.

For more than forty years this English medical missionary worked among the desperately poor people of Labrador -- that barren region which Jacques Cartier described as "the land God gave to Cain."
SINCE my last letter the big thrill in the world of the London stage has not been the opening of a new play, but of a new playhouse, actor Bernard Miles' Mermaid Theatre.
Greek shipowners said yesterday that unlike other Europeans they find no fault with the 50-50 Cargo Preference Act and do not advocate its amendment or abolition.

PHILADELPHIA -- The Governors of the thirteen original states are being invited to participate in a historic ceremony at which the nation's forty-nine-star flag will be raised officially for the first time at Independence Hall at 11 A. M. on the Fourth of July.

DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -Those auto junkyards that dot the landscape on the edge of town grew by leaps and bounds last year. An authoritative estimate shows that almost 4,500,000 motor vehicles were scrapped in 1958.
QUITO, Ecuador, June 6 -- President Camilo Ponce Enriquez said today that the bloody riots in Guayaquil this week were part of a Communist-directed effort to overthrow the Government.

LONDON, June 5 -- A five-year plan for the prevention of blindness and care of the blind in colonies, protectorates and other areas of British responsibility has been announced by the Royal Commonwealth Society for the Blind.

SALTSJOEBADEN, Sweden, June 6 -- Economic experts have been trying this week to chart a basis from which the longsuspended negotiations for a seventeen-nation free-trade area might eventually be resumed.

Each day of conflict appears to reinforce the crusading fervor of the combatants and to render the peace-making mission of Mayor Wagner's mediation board more difficult of accomplishment.

The Maritime Administration last week set the rates at which States Marine Lines will be compensated by the Federal shipping agency for acting as general agent for the nuclear passenger-cargo ship Savannah, which is scheduled to be ready for operation in the early spring of next year.

UNIVERSAL - INTERNATIONAL has done its bit to make that comparative rarity, the featurelength animated film, loom larger this coming year on the over-all screen scene. Black Hills surprised the majority in a crowd of 36,486 by registering a decisive victory in the $28,200 Peter Pan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

June days are just the right length to include a little time to sit and wonder about some of the questions that never make headlines. Why, just to pick at random, are the mosquitoes more numerous and more vicious this year than usual? And why so early? Are they precocious this year, or are they just reminding us that there are other problems than the conquest of outer space?

The West Course of the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, N. Y., where the United States Open championship will begin Thursday, has undergone relatively few changes since the tournament was held there in 1929.

PINEAPPLE plants make a welcome addition to the house plant collection. Once established in a sunny window, they bear little resemblance to the stiff tops from which they are grown. Leaves become straplike and flexuous, curving in a graceful rosette around container rims.

After a drop to 4,250,000 births in 1958, the nation's birth rate is once again on the way up. Based on rates for the first three months, this year there will probably be around 4,320,000 births in the United States.

FOR a short course in the Japanese traditional theatre, I have found nothing so thorough and comprehensible as this short book by Earle Ernst. In 200 pages Mr. Ernst, Professor of Drama at the University of Hawaii, gives us, in addition to the plays, essays on the three types of Japanese traditional or classic theatre: the No theatre, the Doll theatre, and the Kabuki.

CLEVELAND, June 6 -- It is not likely that anyone henceforth this season will be asking the question: "what's wrong with the Yankees?" For Casey Stengel's Bombers continue to provide the answer with convincing effect.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- One of the important, but most obscure, activities of the Government is about to enter the stage of major political debate and decision.

LONDON, June 6 (Reuters) -- India's cricket team, with seven wickets left in its second innings, needed 120 runs to avert an innings defeat at the close of the third day's play in the first test match against England at Nottingham today. VIENNA, June 6 -- Communist China has made its first sale of machinery to a European country -- Czechoslovakia.

TO simplify the job of cleaning or storing paint brushes immediately after use, here is a thick, jellylike fluid which permits a brush to be laid aside for weeks or months without hardening. The paint-laden brush is simply dipped into the liquid when the day's work is done, and then laid flat on a piece of aluminum foil.

IN recent years a number of Russian words have become familiar to most Americans: tovarich (from both the Broadway play and that war palship); nyet (courtesy of Messrs. Molotov and Gromyko when they were at the U. N.), and sputnik (from you know what).

IT has long been apparent that Fred Hoyle, of St. John's College, Cambridge, is no ordinary astronomer. His theories (in "The Nature of the Universe" and "Frontiers of Astronomy") have been excitingly provocative; he has dabbled successfully in science fiction ("The Black Cloud").

MIAMI BEACH -- Culture is becoming a basic ingredient of Miami Beach's allurement. In this famous vacationland, have observed hosts of alert residents busily engaged in obliterating the widespread impression of the Beach as a cultural hinterland.

A REMEDY for hemorrhoids has presented the National Association of Broadcasters with the first significant test of its powers to enforce its code of self-regulation. ATLANTA, June 6 (UPI) -The publishers of the Atlanta Journal and the Atlanta Constitution have been convicted of contempt of court and ordered to pay a $20,000 fine for printing articles in connection with a trial that contained material not brought out in court.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff continue to differ among themselves over how best to defend the United States against surprise air attack, Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, said today.

The New York Public Library's June issue of "Branch Library Book News," a collection of titles culled from its lists of suggested reading of the last forty-five years, is available, free, at all branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island and in the Fifth Avenue building.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 3 -- The Belgian Congo's capital, Leopoldville, is destined to become architecturally one of the world's most up-to-date tropical cultural centers.

MYSTIC, Conn. -- The tangy air of the sea and ships is charged with a special new ingredient here these days. Mystic Seaport, a sea-going version of Colonial Williamsburg, has been clearing a berth for the arrival of the latest of its growing fleet of high-seas sailing celebrities.

SINCE 1950 Douglass Cater has been Washington correspondent of a fortnightly, The Reporter. This has given him a chance to observe the work of his colleagues who struggle against daily deadlines. The result is a considered examination of the strategic role of the Washington correspondents, so vital, Mr. Cater finds, as to be in reality the fourth branch of government.

ALGIERS, June 6 -- The French have strengthened their military and political position in Algeria. Their generals and civilian officials believe that the nationalist Moslem rebels are in great difficulty. But the French have learned, from bitter experience, not to make premature victory claims.

LAKE CITY, Colo. -- This is an article about the travel enchantments of the Western Slope of Colorado, but before going into that we must come to grips with a psychosis called acrophobia, which apparently prevents at least five out of six motorists from ever visiting the Western Slope.

EVER since Benjamin Franklin first flew a kite during a thunderstorm to demonstrate that lightning is actually electricity in action, men have been working on methods for protecting themselves against these violent displays of nature's fireworks.

The Civil War Centennial Commission has announced plans for a re-enactment of the First Battle of Bull Run near Manassas, Va.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 6 (Reuters) -- A nation-wide advertising campaign today advised Swedish smokers to avoid lung cancer risks by not smoking their cigarettes down to a tiny stub.

With the aid of a $340,000 grant from the Ford Foundation, Goddard College in Plainfield, Vt., will begin this fall a six-year trial of a college curriculum built mainly around student work projects rather than a formal program of courses. SUMMER is off-season in the Caribbean. Tourists are sparser but the bargains are bigger. Hotels on the islands reduce rates for the summer visitor, and the airlines offer special fares on Caribbean flights.

HENDERSON, N. C., June 6 (UPI) -- The strike at the Harriet-Henderson Cotton Mills entered its thirtieth week today. A dynamite blast last night added another item to the record of violence that has marked the strike.

THE American "way of life" presented to the Russians in Sokolniki Park, Moscow, beginning on July 25, will include three separate, all-day gushers of stereophonic sound that exhibit both the high fidelity components idea and a broad-scale cross-section of American music and musical performers.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- If the President's nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce is rejected by the Senate, that will be only the eighth exercise of this constitutional power since the establishment of the republic. Partisan war between a President and the Senate fought on the high level of opposing political philosophy has been the reason for several of the rejections; less intellectual partisan considerations explain others.

BROMLEY, England, June 6 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said today that history might judge cricket as one of Britain's greatest gifts to the world. He was speaking at a cricket club party in his constituency here, a London suburb.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 6 -Years of debate will culminate Tuesday in a municipal referendum on the question of loosening an archaic limitation on Minneapolis liquor licensing.

The major corporate news of the week in the Wall Street was the merger proposal of the New York Trust Company, with seven offices, and the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank, with 94 offices. The consolidation would produce the nation's fourth largest bank.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 6 -- Hillsdale, with a thrilling stretch run, captured the $54,700 Argonaut Handicap today in scoring his sixth stakes victory of the year.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L. I., June 6 -- A $600,000 recreational development for the 25,000 residents of this community was dedicated by the Town of Hempstead here today. It will open to the public tomorrow.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 6 -- Walter S. Gubelmann's Windigo, John T. Potter's Touche and Robert Coulson's Finn MacCumhaill were the winners in Classes I through III, respectively, today in the New York Yacht Club's 105th annual regatta.

WHITE PLAINS, June 6 -Suburban high school graduates who will soon begin commuting to new jobs in Manhattan are being warned by the New York Central Railroad to beware of the commuter-seaten mit packagen und umbrelleren uppen-gepiler.
Negotiating teams in the steel industry wage talks deluged each other with contradictory statistics last week without moving one inch closer to an agreement.

LONDON, June 6 (UPI) -- The son of an American Negro slave urged today the transformation of the Atlantic alliance from a military machine into an instrument of economic might that would save the struggling millions in Africa and Asia from Communist blandishments.
ST. LOUIS, June 6 -- A plan for a partial consolidation of the city of St. Louis, St. Louis County and the county's ninety-eight municipalities will be presented to voters of this area Nov. 3.
SINGAPORE, June 6 -- A gigantic experiment officially began at 4 P. M. yesterday in a speck of Asia. It is led by far Leftists who say they are competing with violent communism.
LIME ROCK, Conn., June 6 -George Constantine of Southbridge, Mass., drove as AstonMartin 4.2 roadster to an easy victory today in the United States Auto Club's pro-amateur sports car race.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, Warwickshire -- "A pretty town of bricke and tymbre," was a medieval description of Shakespeare's Stratfordon-Avon. And so it is still. It had 2,000 inhabitants in his day, now it has 15,000. This makes it not too large to remain a country market, typical of the English midlands.
New York University's 127th annual Commencement Week opens today with a baccalaureate service at 4 P. M. in Gould Memorial Library at N. Y. U.'s University Heights Center in the Bronx.
RICHMOND, Va., June 6 -The first test of Virginia's new flexible program on school segregation shaped up this week.

THE ferryboat has long played a distinguished and important part in transporting Americans across the continent. But in this age, when speed counts for so much, it has gradually given way to the six-lane bridge and the mile-long tunnel.
A young singer with a familiar last name gave his New York debut late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.
MILWAUKEE, Wis. June 6 -The play-wirting team of William Shakespeare and Mayor Frank Zeidler was the talk and toast of the Milwaukee theatre community this week.
MONTREAL -- The St. Lawrence Seaway has been opened only a few weeks and already it has become the subject of more inquiries from prospective tourists to this region than almost any other topic.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., June 6 -- An unusual college preparatory program has given fifty-nine "late bloomers" and "under-achievers" a chance to prove they deserve to go to college despite poor high school records.

I found the treatment of Africa's race problem in "Cry, the Divided Country" by Denis V. Cowen (May 17) very interesting. However, instead of showing the seriousness of the situation by devaluing the possibilities of a reconciliation between the races, he would have exhibited more realism by discussing the negative aspect.

NO one has ever written the true biography of Henry Hudson. Time and circumstances have done their editing of the materials on which such a study might be based. All that we have left are limited records of four years and four voyages in the life of a man whose birth date and antecedents are unknown.

PROVIDENCE, R. I. -- Motorists bound for a weekend, a week or the whole season at one of Rhode Island's vacation areas will have an easier time getting there this summer, simply because a ribbon was cut last Oct. 18.

STANTON, Del., June 6 (AP) -- Pantene, a French-bred horse from the Cockfield Stable of Mrs. Marian Eppley of New York, equaled Delaware Park's grass course record of 1:42 2/5 for a mile and a sixteenth today in capturing the $26,625 Brandywine Turf Handicap before 27,392.

THE amazing success of Charlie Chaplin's twentythree-year-old comedy, "Modern Times," in its current revival showings at the Plaza Theatre and the surprising amount of public interest recently manifested in the revival of old silent pictures at the Inwood Theatre in Forest Hills, Queens, has started an obstinate train of thinking in this observer's mind.
GENEVA, June 6 -- Three or four years from now a young man who has just finished his studies at Carnegie Tech or M. I. T. may come across this kind of want ad in a newspaper:

FREEPORT, L. I., June 6 -In one of the most rugged events ever held in Eastern waters, Jim Lacy, piloting a Hunter-19 sixteen-footer, topped the outboard division in the first Long Island Marathon motor boat race today.

THE American who comes to South and Central Africa expecting to see the exotic and colorful native life that he has already viewed in the movies is due for a rude shock. Instead of dancing naked natives he will see African men and women in European dress going on foot and on bicycles to and from their work.
EARLY June usually signals the beginning of outdoor vacations for house plants. In the garden plants will have fresh air, cooler-than-house temperatures, rains and natural growing conditions.

JERUSALEM, Israel -- On Sept. 10, leading contemporary harpists and aspiring harp virtuosi will climb the steep, stone steps of historic Mount Zion in a pilgrimage to the tomb of King David, the most celebrated plucker of harp strings.

Ship traffic in New York Harbor showed an increase last month, both over the previous month and also over May of last year, William F. Giesen, general manager and counsel of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, has announced.

HONOLULU, June 6 -Hawaii is virtually certain to send at least one person of Oriental or part-Oriental ancestry to Congress. And, at the moment, the Democratic party appears to have a good chance of making a clean sweep of all three Congressional seats.
FRED ASTAIRE, whose first and only live television show last October was a superb achievement in quality entertainment, will star on at least one and possibly two special programs next season.

Jerusalem (Israeli sector) June 3 -- The recent convention here of B'nai B'rith demonstrated that the 116-year-old service organization was in agreement with Premier David Ben-Gurion on one point: that the Hebrew language must be a creative link between the Jews of Israel and Jews elsewhere.

JAMES P. WARBURG carries on into the second half of the twentieth century the faith in reason, progress and human nature that the eighteenth century instilled in so many of the founding fathers of the United States.

GENEVA, June 6 -- The Western powers today hammered but failed to break the solid Soviet front on Berlin. Andrei A. Gromyko refused to discuss access to West Berlin in what the West considers realistic terms.
YONKERS, June 6 -- Paul L. Nelson's Kenny J., unbeaten this season, scored his fourth victory by taking the $10,000 Monitor junior free-for-all pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Some forty to fifty persons daily, about half of them tourists, find their way to a 200-year-old Spanish town house in an out-of-the-way correr of this city.

The drama of determining the winner of the United States golf championship is slated for the nation's golf fans this week. A field of 150 experts will bid for the title, beginning Thursday, at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y. Prize money will be approximately $40,000.

WHEN one is left holding the bag he is being made the scapegoat; he has been left in an awkward predicament not of his own devising, or blamed for or punished for all the faults committed jointly by himself and others.
LOS ANGELES, June 6 -California's eclipsed Republicans looked with silent envy this week on a puzzling ferment of activity among their Democratic rivals.
Another break-through into higher power ranges for ship motors has been announced by Burmeister Wain of Copenhagen, the world's largest builder of marine Diesel engines.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., June 6 -- Same Petrone of Hubbard Heights today opened the defense of his Metropolitan Golf Association public link championship at the Mohansic golf course. He had to go to the eighteenth hole before eliminating John De Piero of Split Rock, 2 up, in the first round.

ON Tuesday, the nation's first ballistic - missile - firing submarine will be launched by General Dynamics' Electric Boat Division at Groton, Conn. It is named the George Washington but its Navy designation is SSB (N) 598. Translated, that means ShipSubmarine - Ballistic (Nuclear - powered) hull number 598.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 7 (UPI) -- John Cowles, publisher of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, said today that the traditional American concept of national sovereignty was obsolete.
How to take the white ring off your dining room table and how to tell a Louis XV from a Louis XVI chair are but two nuggets of information to be mined from "Seng Furniture Facts."

WHEN chocolate chips were introduced some twenty years ago they were a baking innovation that home cooks greeted with enthusiasm. Chocolate-chip cookies became great favorites and the tiny morsels have been, too, used for making sauces and candies. Now come lemon-flavored chips packed under the Baker's label by General Foods.
Ten thousand Rotarians from seventy-two countries opened their fiftieth annual convention here last night at Madison Square Garden. Attendance at the six-day convention is expected to reach 16,000.

The taxpayer containing twelve stores at 49-01-17 Thirty-first Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets in Woodside, Queens, has been purchased by the Engel Realty Company in a deal negotiated by Joseph R. Ruffino of the Kraham Realty Company, Kew Gardens brokers.

A part of Chatham Square -- the spot in Chinatown where Doyers, Mott and Worth Streets meet East Broadway, Park Row and the Bowery -- was renamed Kimlau Square yesterday. The action honored a Chinese-American pilot killed in World War II.

MILWAUKEE, June 7 (AP) -- Johnny Thomson of Boyertown, Pa., led from start to finish today in the 100-mile big-car race at State Fair Park. He finished almost a mile ahead of Johnny Boyd of Fresno, Calif., and averaged 98.61 miles an hour.
Senator Walter J. Mahoney, Republican majority leader of the upper house at Albany, conceded yesterday that he was in disagreement with some of the views of the liberal wing of his party.

President Eisenhower sent a message last night congratulating the fifty persons in the first graduating class of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, its faculty members and 750 community leaders who helped build it.

The board of directors of the National Sharecroppers Fund has expressed its strong support for and sympathy with the striking hospital workers of Local 1199, Retail Drug Employes Union. In so doing, the board greatly regretted the unfortunate refusal of the hospital managements to recognize and negotiate with their employes, which has driven the union to strike action with consequent hardship to both patients and workers.

To some of us who live in Manhattan it occasionally seems as though this once leafy island has slowly turned into a leaf-shaped slab of concrete. At one time it was all thick woodland; by Henry James' time lower Manhattan was a street-lined market place with the farms above Fourteenth Street.

The dramatic building program at New York International Airport will enter a new phase in the coming months. United States airlines will begin then to vacate the old, consolidated passenger terminal for new, individual quarters.
LONDON, June 7 -- Last week's stock market setback has led financial circles here to wonder whether the young bull market had balked at the "yield gap."
POZNAN, Poland, June 7 (UPI) -- The United States put its faith today in a corner drugstore and other services to draw crowds here from a Soviet exhibition on mechanization.

A regrettable tendency of the city administration to let important questions drift until they become too serious to ignore has now resulted in what Park Commissioner Robert Moses calls a "desperate" pollution of recreational waters. A committee of high officials, including the Public Works Commissioner, Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, and Mr. Moses, has warned Mayor Wagner that somehow the city must find $160,000,000 above its basic pollution control program to save many beaches from contamination.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 7 -- This was dress rehearsal day at the Winged Foot Club where golf's big show opens on Thursday.

GENEVA, June 7 -- David Ormsby-Gore, British Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, said tonight that a summit meeting would probably be required to get final agreement on a treaty banning nuclear weapons tests.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor warned today that only "prompt decisions by competent authority" could halt the rivalry among the armed forces. He agreed that the rivalry was unhealthy.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 7 (AP) -- A bungled attempt on the life of President Luis A. Debayle Somoza was made last night by four or five men who fired rifles at his palace, informed sources reported today.
BUENOS AIRES, June 7 (UPI) -- The Argentine Government may ask the withdrawal from Buenos Aires of some Communist diplomats within the next forty-eight hours, authorized quarters said today.
National folk song and ballet groups will give ten Sunday matinees at the new amphitheatre in Central Park beginning July 19. Admission is expected to be 50 cents to $1.

President Eisenhower's proclamation that the United States would begin the United Nations-sponsored World Refugee Year on July 1 was received in Arab circles as a hopeful sign that the plight of the refugees -- including the Palestine Arab refugees -- has at last attracted sympathetic attention.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 7 -- Benjamin F. Wright, presiding at his last Smith College commencement, conferred 460 Bachelor of Arts degrees twenty - eight masters degrees and two masters certificates today. He will resign this month.
Additions to the assets of the John A. Hartford Foundation last year pushed it up among the country's major philanthropic foundations.
NEW HAVEN, June 7 -- Integrity of purpose is "perhaps the most pressing need of the society in which the universities exist," A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, declared today.
Charles Culp Burlingham, lawyer and one of New York's greatest crusaders for civic virtue, died late Saturday night at his home, 860 Park Avenue, after a short illness. He was 100 years old.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 7 (Reuters) -- The Jordanian lower house of Parliament gave Hazzal Majali's new government today a formal vote of confidence by 49 votes to none with one abstention.

I'm sure hundreds of New York drivers are enjoying a vicarious pleasure in reading about Mrs. Meyer Fish's appeal in the traffic court of New York. Her situation is not unique but rather an everyday occurrence, as enraged, frustrated drivers exit from New York courts, fined unjustifiably without recourse to explanation (elucidation being expensive, as Mrs. Fish is discovering).
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard said today that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's decision not give up the Chancellorship of West Germany was "to be regretted."

An American edition of a new book by Eric Williams will be published June 19 by Coward-McCann. Described as a novel, it is called "Dragoman Pass: An Adventure in the Balkans." Mr. Williams and his wife left England in July, 1956, in a specially equipped Land-Rover on a 12,000-mile journey through the countries behind the Iron Curtain.
ZURICH, Switzerland, June 7 (AP) -- Bobby Fischer of New York and Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union played to a draw in the fifteenth and last round of the international chess tournament tonight.
Two separate reports pointed yesterday to the growing number of complaints of discriminatory practices by employment agencies.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A strange political feud reached a climax of sorts with the disclosure by Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, that he would fight the re-nomination and re-election next year of Senator Richard L. Neuberger, Democrat of Oregon.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 7 -- Pierre Mend es-France proposed today that industrialized nations earmark a percentage of their national income for aid to under-developed countries.

An investor bought the four-story building containing thirty-six apartments at 180 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, from Esther Davis in a deal negotiated by Harry Handschu, broker. The property is 75 by 140 feet and is assessed at $125,000.
The Memphis Red Sox swept a Negro American League double-header from the Kansas City Monarchs, 2 -- 1 and 5 -- 3, yesterday at the Yankee Stadium before a crowd of 7,118.

The Hamburg-American Line's cruise ship, the Ariadne, made her first visit here under the German flag yesterday. The 7,500-gross-ton yachtlike vessel had just completed a successful series of Caribbean cruises out of New Orleans.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- A group of United States scientists said today that a system could be set up to detect "any serious violation" of a ban on nuclear bomb tests.

The European Travel Commission account is any agency's prize.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that, while prospects for achievement at a summit conference were not "very good," it would still be "worth while" for the President to attend.

The men's clothing industry operated at 84 per cent of capacity during April, compared with 63 per cent in the 1958 month. While the increase in operations was sizable, the 1959 month is compared with a depressed period, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- New York's two Republican Senators sharply criticized today proposals by Mike Mansfield, Senate Democratic whip, to cut off outright foreign aid grants in four years. Senators Jacob K. Javits and Kenneth B. Keating assailed the Mansfield plan as a device that might hamstring the recovery of many weaker nations and make them dependent on Communist aid.

A 26-year-old woman who was to have been married later this month was killed yesterday when the car in which she was riding struck a utility pole in Springfield Gardens, Queens. Her fiance, the driver of the car, and another passenger were injured.
GENEVA, June 7 -- The possibility of a breakdown in negotiations is being discussed by Western diplomats here as the foreign ministers' conference prepares to enter its fifth week.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 7 -- The Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland has started a long - range drive against bilharziasis, a parasitic disease.

Chancellor Adenauer's present political convolutions seem puzzling and disturbing. Nevertheless, a thread of logic runs through his apparent indecision on whether to run for the Federal Republic's Presidency or to remain in his present office.

THE pursuit of intellectuals by Channel 13 apparently is to be challenged by Channel 5. At least last night, while David Suskind was opening another marathon installment of "Open End" over WNTA - TV, Marva Mannes, author and television critic, was beginning her own half hour of talk over WNEW-TV.
PALERMO, Italy, June 7 -- About 2,500,000 Sicilians voted today in a regional parliamentary election crucial for all of Italy.

CINCINNATI, June 7 (UPI) -- Orlando Pena, going the route for the first time this season, pitched the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants today. The Giants took the opener, 5 to 3, on Jack Sanford's six-hitter.
Plans for two housing projects in Manhattan were announced yesterday by Robert Moses, chairman of the city's Slum Clearance Committee.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 -- The small electrical charges found naturally in the air have physiological effects important to health, according to a report today to the American College of Chest Physicians.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 7 -- It was another frustrating day for the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound today.
A policeman's doubts about an apparent suicide brought quick results yesterday in Brooklyn. Two youths were arrested on homicide charges.
ROME, June 7 (AP) -- The Milan club, founded by a group of Englishmen at the turn of the century, won Italy's top league soccer championship for the sixth time.
NEUDAM, South West Africa, May 19 -- This is lambing time in the heart of the karakul country. More than 2,708,000 pelts with a value of more than 5,168,000 ($15,000,000) were exported last year.

LONDON, June 7 -- Henry A. Kissinger, an American defense analyst, has warned the Atlantic Congress here that North Atlantic Treaty organization forces in Europe must be strengthened to deter Soviet enncroachments.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Mr. Benson said today that Congress was playing politics with agriculture.
CLEVELAND, June 7 -- The mad flight of the Yankees from the second division was slowed today by Joe Gordon's Indians.
City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs said yesterday that he would not vote for a 10-cent tax on taxicab rides unless the city also restored the $5 and $10 auto-use tax, which was repealed last year.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Lewis L. Strauss, the Supreme Court and the national debt will keep Congress busy this week.
BALTIMORE, June 7 (AP) -- Dave Ragan, 23-year-old Florida player, won his first professional golf tournament today with a birdie 3 three holes from the end of the Eastern open.

BONN, Germany, June 7 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer's decision toremain as Chancellor, notwithstanding considerable protest within his party and despite the encroachments of age, has spotlighted one of the great deficiencies of West Germany's post-war political development: the failure to groom leaders for the period when the men who molded the nation's recovery from World War II will have a passed from the scene.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Several key farm leaders in Congress are urging the Democratic leadership to draft an omnibus farm bill this session.
LEESBURG, Fla., June 7 (AP) -- A Presbyterian church leader said tonight that two summer youth camps at Weekiwachee had been canceled because of threats of violence if Negroes participated.

A 24-year-old Egyptian and his 22-year-old wife, a Chinese refugee, were ordained ministers of the Disciples of Christ yesterday in a ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church, 1010 Park Avenue. They plan to work as missionaries in South America.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 7 -- President Nathan M. Pusey told the graduating class of Harvard College this afternoon that "the finest fruit of serious learning should be the ability to speak the word God without reserve or embarrassment."
Cotton prices last week closed mixed after moving in a narrow range.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- The Chamber of Commerce warned today that Philadelphia's multi-million dollar grain export trade was threatened with extinction unless a proposed rail freight reduction was approved.

News of a new political party in India is encouraging. Prime Minister Nehru is undoubtedly sincere when he says he welcomes the formation of this Opposition group, even if he does not agree with its views. Mr. Nehru and his Congress party are committed to state socialism. The new party is strictly for private enterprise. It is truly a "conservative" party although it has rejected that name in favor of "Swantantra," meaning freedom.
Garry Moore has hired three writers formerly with Phil Silvers to put more laughs into his TV variety show next season.
MOSCOW, June 7 -- Two United States child-care experts report that Soviet specialists are preoccupied with a fresh evaluation of the precepts of pediatrics and youthful conditioning.
A suspect in a Brooklyn killing was found yesterday to have narcotics the police valued at $1,200,000.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 26 -- Outside the train window, the table-like Rumanian plain unrolled, green with the promise of harvest.

McRAE, Ga., June 7 (UPI) -- Three engines and sixteen freight cars, two containing thousands of gallons of deadly chlorene gas, where derailed here tonight. Authorities said that the town might be evacuated.

COLUMBUS, Ga., June 7 -- A Southern Presbyterian minister was summarily removed at this morning's service as pastor of his church here in a controversy that began when he wrote an article in a national magazine urging "creative contact" between whites and Negroes.
Representative Emmanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, has urged state and Federal authorities to block the proposed merger of the New York Trust Company and the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank.

LIKE a well-planned play, a preview of next September's first day of school -- kindergarten level -- took place recently at Public School 163, 163 West Ninety-seventh Street. The classroom "stage" was set and the adult "actors" were ready. It was one of the increasing number of tryouts now being scheduled to prepare children for their first day of school.
PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- A committee of sixty persons has been formed to sponsor the observance next year of the cenItennial of the .birth of Jane Addams.

CANTON, N. Y., June 7 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers said today the cost of racial incidents in this country "in terms of our standing among the peoples of the world cannot be calculated."

St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn yesterday won its first Catholic High Schools Athletic Association baseball title since 1941. St. Francis defeated Cardinal Hayes of the Bronx, 5 -- 3, at Fordham Field, the Bronx, before 1,500 fans.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., June 7 -- The defending champion, Sam Petrone of Hubbard Heights, led the way into the quarter-final round of the Metropolitan Golf Association's twenty-second annual public links championship today at Mohansic.

J. P. Stevens Co., Inc. had a net income of $8,002,708 on net sales of $209,177,242 in the six months ended May 2, according to the semi-annual report issued for publication today. In the similar period ended May 3, 1958, the textile producer reported earnings of $2,832,420 on sales of $173,770,098.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 7 (AP) -- John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, told 1,300 graduates of the University of Notre Dame today that all their lives would be affected by the atom.
TOKYO, June 7 (UPI) -- American Army Engineers revealed today a device capable of measuring to within ninety feet the distance between two points on earth.

Although handicapped by a sprained right ankle and a pulled muscle in her left leg, Marjorie Larney, the American Olympian, scored a triple in the women's senior metropolitan track and field championships yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, June 7 (AP) -- Hoyt Wilhelm pitched his ninth victory without a loss for Baltimore today, a 3-0 shutout of the Kansas City Athletics.
Jewish spiritual leaders and teachers were urged yesterday to reinterpret their traditional educational role to enable them to serve as "guides for the perplexed."

GOTEBORG, Sweden, June 7 (UPI) -- The French wonder horse Jamin was beaten for the second straight time when the Italian-owned horse Icare IV scored an upset victory today in the Abys Stora Prix, a Swedish trotting race counting toward this year's European championship.
PARIS, June 7 -- President Charles de Gaulle spoke today of efforts within his Administration to "maneuver" French policy on Algeria and said measures had been taken against them.

ORONO, Me., June 7 (AP) -- The president of New York University expressed "heartfelt concern and fear" today that the education of Americans to share responsibility for Governmental affairs was lagging.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., June 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. Harry De Leyer's horses, Wayward Wind and Snow Man, captured both ribbons in the open jumper championship in the C. W. Post College horse show today.
NEWARK, June 7 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner tonight announced the appointment of a nine-member state Scholarship Advisory Committee.
EVERY year about this time, advice by the column-full is addressed to mothers -- most of it on getting Junior ready for camp, the rest on preparing little Laura for kindergarten come fall.

MILWAUKEE, June 7 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves exploded for eight runs in the seventh inning today to salvage the finale of a three-game series from the Los Angeles Dodgers, 8 -- 2. Bob Buhl pitched four-hit ball as the Braves ended a three-game losing streak.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday there probably would be continued delay in City Council action on the pending bill authorizing him to appoint a nine-member commission to revise the City Charter.

Strike ultimatums were served yesterday on six proprietary hospitals and two institutions for the aged. Action was threatened unless the institutions negotiated before midnight tomorrow with Local 144 of the Hotel and Allied Service Employes Union.

Enkells-Rakoff Co., realty operators, contracted to buy the building containing fifty-four apartments at 233 East Thirty-second Street in the Kips Bay section. The property, 75 by 100 feet, was bought for cash over mortgages amounting to $255,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 -- Jerry Lewis will receive $10,000,000 from Paramount to star in fourteen films in the next seven years.

THE trouble with many novelists, particularly many first novelists, is that they take themselves too seriously. They insist on grappling with too many problems at once and doing so in far too many words. The special merit of the two first novels up for discussion today is that they are neither overly ambitious nor overly long.

The newly independent nation of Sudan was the subject late yesterday afternoon of a documentary study by the Columbia Broadcasting System's news division. The program, for which Charles Collingwood was narrator, was a worth while and informative half hour of background material on one of the many focal points of emerging African nationalism.

FOR the first time in thirty years the United States Open championship will return this week to Winged Foot, one of the world's great golf courses. This is the prestige tournament of the season. At stake is the most cherished prize that the divot-digging pastime has to offer. The sweetest swingers in the business will tour the Mamaroneck links for single rounds on Thursday and Friday and a back-breaking thirty-six holes on Saturday.
