OYSTER BAY, L. I. June 7 -- Forty-two yachts began the second half of the New York Yacht Club's 105th annual regatta today and none finished.
ZURICH, Switzerland, June 7 -- The shares of all three great Swiss commercial banks rose to new peaks last week.

The appointment of Richard A. Kimball, New York architect, as the new director of the American Academy in Rome was announced yesterday by Michael Rapuano, president of the academy. He said Mr. Kimball would take up his duties on Jan. 1.

The Goldman Band will begin the forty-second year of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts on Wednesday, June 17, on the Mall in Central Park.

NEW DELHI, India, June 7 -- An Indian Communist spokesman charged today that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru had not disavowed violations of democratic principles by Congress party leaders in Kerala State.
Doubting the mercy of God "is to play the fool," the Rev. Francis X. Duffy said yesterday at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., June 7 -- Dr. Leona Baumgartner, New York City Commissioner of Health, received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Skidmore College today at commencement exercises for 196 seniors.

Volume was up last week in the steamship charter market, but rates on the whole remained at previous levels.

PHILIPPA DUKE SCHUYLER devoted the largest part of her Carnegie Hall recital yesterday afternoon to impressionist piano music.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- The grain futures market experienced a succession of mildly bearish influences last week but managed to work out a few moderate gains on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- One of the most ambitious projects ever undertaken to study the energy and origin of the mysterious cosmic rays that bombard the earth is being planned by the Navy and the National Science Foundation.

The first Rotary Club was founded more than half a century ago by a young Chicago lawyer named Paul P. The Rev. Dr. David H. C Read called on space age churchgoers yesterday to cease "shouting defiance at the scientists" from the periphery of their beliefs.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 7 (AP) -- As the new-born Bravata quadruplets slept in incubators at East Orange General Hospital today, their 39-year-old father, Ciro, admitted having a wife and two children in New York, besides Louise Struhlein Bravata, 31, the mother of the quadruplets.

The Chromalloy Corporation has acquired the Chromizing Company of Los Angeles, it was announced over the weekend by Joseph Friedman, president of Chromalloy, and Maurice R. Commanday, president of Chromizing.
Leonard Bernstein will appear as conductor and piano soloist in the opening concert of the Lewisohn Stadium series or Monday, June 22.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Issues ranging from the legality of Communist party membership to a censor's ban of the movie "Lady Chatterley's Lover" await decision by the Supreme Court as it goes into the final weeks of its term.

SADIE KNIGHT, the blind soprano who made her debut here in 1951, sang a Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon, showing what can be done by a determined performer in the face of the most formidable obstacles.
George P. Monaghan, the State Harness Racing Commissioner, said yesterday that he had turned down a new invitation to testify on his activities before the State Investigation Commission.

WHEN Thomas E. Whelan was first proposed for a united States ambassadorship, the ruddy-faced North Dakotan picked Nicaragua for his post: first, because it is primarily an agricultural country, and also because during a half-hour layover at Managua airport, he found Nicaraguans friendly.

A further diversification is under way at I. Rokeach Sons, Inc., producers of kosher foods. It is going into the kosher wine business.

When a suburban housewife answers the doorbell, she is taking a calculated risk. It may be a friend, a neighbor, a salesman with a legitimate product. Or it could be a a sharpster hawking subdivisions of the Brooklyn Bridge.

PALERMO, June 7 (AP) -- Italy's ruling Christian Democrats had an uphill battle in an effort to unseat Silvio Milazzo, who bolted their party last winter and became the island's President with Communists and Fascists in his Government.
" Men of 1959 are as likely to put wordly things before the things of God as were ancient men," the Rev. Dr. C. Rankin Barnes said yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 7 -- Richard Robinson's chestnut gelding, Monday Evening, ridden by Penny Johnston, won the children's hunter championship at the Greenwich Junior Horse Show today, by capturing four blue ribbons for 20 points.
The Port of New York Authority has announced that it plans to sell $30,000,000 of its consolidated bonds, due from 1960 to 1979, on June 17.

CAIRO, June 7 -- The Egyptian Air Force said two Israeli planes violated the United Arab Republic's airspace over Sinai today and were engaged by an Egyptian aerial patrol. One of the Israeli planes was seen trailing smoke as it headed home, the Egyptian statement said.

LYNBROOK, L. I., June 7 -- A mother saved the life of a neighbor's child here today when she climbed a five-foot picket fence separating the two houses, released the child's head from a rope noose and applied artificial respiration.
Venice has its Lido, London has the Serpentine. Berlin has the Wannsee and Paris the pools on the banks of the Seine.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- As the steel contract deadline (June 30) approaches, more and more steel users are clamoring for steel. Many of these customers are urging deliveries not because they are afraid of a strike, but because they need more steel now.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- Ambassador George K. Yeh of Nationalist China said today his country would apply under another name to compete in the 1960 Olympic Games.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 7 -- At least ten Latin-American countries are expected to join in moral support of the Nicaraguan rebels, according to a spokesman for the National Liberation party here.

The fundamental issue at the Geneva conference of foreign ministers is now evident. It is whether or not that meeting will reach a minimal agreement representing progress sufficient to justify a summit meeting later this year. The past week's developments make plain, however, that the United States and Soviet views on this issue remain poles apart.
The graduating class of 2,922 students at Brooklyn College was told yesterday that they must now protect those who do not have learning and help those who seek learning.
